description:
We had a sudden craving for XLB.. and lone behold... This was the first restaurant we see as soon as we get in to the mall on our way to the movie theater! Some places don't serve XLB did dinner... But this place did.

Warning: if you're new to this whole dumpling thing... Poke it first, let it cool, then slowly eat it... If you don't --it will burn your mouth!! Our juicy dumplings were so hot (temperature wise), I couldn't even lift the handle on the spoon it's resting on. 

We only tried the pork dumplings... It was yummy, but I've had better.

Their chili sauce had an unusual curry smell/taste to it. It wasn't bad, just a little odd.

Also.. their dishes are ala carte... Decently portioned for 2-3 people... Large soup was just right for 3-4 people...

Hot and sour soup was more hot than it was sour.

String beans were yummy. Cooked perfectly!
author: Angela A.

description:
5 stars solely for the beef noodle soup,which is expensive at $17 and I would go there only to eat the soup again (I ordered two!). But, everything else (other food and service) was pretty awful.

The staff / service was pretty awful, took probably 15 minutes for our drinks to arrive, and the waiter kept asking us what we ordered and barely paid attention to us. The rest of the food was mediocre.

A huge negative was also that the waiter couldn't seem to grasp an understanding of a peanut allergy, and wasn't sure how to check whether there could be or couldn't be cross contamination. I'm shocked that the restaurant doesn't know how to handle orders for allergies - so be wary!
A slight negative was that after waiting 15 minutes for our drinks, my wine was such a sad, small pour! But, that's how it is sometimes.

Overall, I am being generous in my review solely for the beef noodle soup, which I'd go back for and spend the $17.
author: Karen C.

description:
Peking Duck and Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles!

I know what you are thinking -- really, a celebrity chef restaurant in a mall?! But I am here to tell you it is good! M Y China is in our Chinese food trio of San Francisco: Yank Sing for Dim Sum; R & G Lounge for Cantonese -- and specifically the Salt & Pepper Crab; and M Y China for the Peking Duck and Scissor Cut Noodles.

We are not shoppers, but occasionally we need to go to Westfield Mall. Today it was Torneau to get some watch batteries replaced. And what better way to while away an hour than with Martin Yan's perfect Peking Duck. Gloriously lacquered, crispy skin and succulently moist and flavorful meat. We get a half order -- plenty for two. Served with pillowy steamed buns, hoisin, cucumber and julienne of leaks, it is a perfect dish. And we always get the scissor cut wild boar noodles to go with it -- excellent perfectly cooked noddles with a mixture of veg and a nice sauce.

We can never finish it all, so we order some more buns and garnish and have another meal. M Y China has a very extensive menu, but I don't think we have had anything else. But judging from what we have had, I am sure the rest will be great as well. Always friendly service, never rushed or hovering.
author: John C.

description:
The M.Y. In M.Y. China stands for Martin Yan. I didn't realize that until I saw his name in the menu. I have always been a fan of this master chef, and have actually met him on two separate occasions. Nice man.

The restaurant is located on the fourth floor of the upscale Westfield mall. It is a big open air restaurant that is adjacent to the cathedral like dome. It reminded me of the simulated outdoor  restaurants in Vegas. The dining room is large with comfortable seating. There is a full service bar with an ornate iron bell in the center of it.

For dinner we had the Xiao Long Bao (aka juicy pork and crab dumpling), Salted Egg Yolk Crab, Seven Spice Pork Ribs, and Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles.

I grew up calling Xiao Long Bao "soup balls" because of the delicious broth that leaks from the sealed packaging. These were delicious. The noodle wrapper was thin and tender. It didn't distract from the goodness inside.

The crab dish was the crown jewel of our meal. The market price was north of $50 so it better be good..right? The crab was huge. The crab is dredged in seasoned egg yoke and then fried. This created a spectacular crust. The crab was fantastic although quite messy and an effort to eat.

I thought the Seven Spice Pork Ribs were amazing. The tender ribs had a crispy fried coating. They were seasoned with a dry rub that was spicy and complex. The spices that I recognized were five spice, cumin, curry, hot red pepper, green onion, and cilantro. A bite of the topping alone was an explosion of flavors and a party in my mouth.

The Wild Boar dish was my least favorite of our choices. The house made noodles were stretched and cut into straw-like pieces. This dish was good, but tasted like a common stir fry that you could find at many Chinese restaurants.

A highlight of our visit was watching one of the chefs carve a squash into an incredible piece of art. You have to see it to believe it.
author: Paul C.

description:
**UPDATE**

Came back for the happy hour, which is offered Mon-Fri 3-6 pm in the bar and lounge area only. My friend and I arrived around 5:20 on a Tuesday and snagged the last table available. Their happy hour menu offers deals on alcohol (cocktails, wine, and beer) as well as some bites. 

I thought the cocktails were a good deal, but both of us were not impressed by the food. I ordered the Spring Rain (rum, lime, blue curacao, cranberry juice) for $8, and liked it so much that I ordered it again. It was such a pretty drink with the cherry garnish and tasted great as well.

For food, we split the calamari ($7) and the bang bang chicken wings ($7). To be honest, the calamari was the saddest looking calamari I've ever seen. It was incredibly bland and barely crunchy at all. I understand they serve it with side seasonings, but at least add some salt to it! The portion size was tiny as well. The chicken wings were sweet and tasted okay, but I probably wouldn't get it again.

I'd come back here for a chill happy hour when I only want drinks and no food.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Loooove the string beans & wild boar lettuce cups!!!

Did not love the shu mai (spelling??). Their hot and soup is very different, seems like it is more tomato based than most other ones I've had. 

The mixed green chicken salad is a terrific, healthy, albeit not traditional Chinese food. They cook the chicken in the style of Peking duck, so it's super juicy with a crispy outside. Even my mom loved it & she usually doesn't like chicken. The dressing is a little creamy for my taste.

A lot of wine options which is great & unusual for a Chinese restaurant.
author: Kylie F.

description:
Came here to celebrate a coworker's birthday because she wanted Chinese food near FiDi. 

I made a reservation and made a note that we were celebrating my friend's birthday. Although I was about 15 minutes early, I was very happy that I was able to be seated. The servers were very attentive. They brought out water right away and asked if there was anything else I needed while I waited for my coworker. 

Between the 2 of us, we ordered:
1. Crispy Organic Tofu (which I loved)
2. Mu Shu Pork Tacos (which my coworker wanted and enjoyed)
3. Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles (we both enjoyed)
4. Sweet and sour pork (good)
5. String beans
6. Side of rice
7. 1 cocktail (for my friend)
8. Tea Infused Creme Brulee (skippable)

The portions were alright for the price. We both ended up pretty full and didn't have any food left to take home. because it was my coworker's birthday, they gave us sugar egg puffs on the house. Those, were very tasty. I especially like the vanilla cream that was served with it. The food was well seasoned and appeared to be fresh. The service was also very attentive, even though, as the evening progressed, the dining room filled up.

If I were to come back, I would definitely order the tofu again (because I liked the way it was prepared compared to other places that service crispy tofu) as well as the scissor cut noodles.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: Thanks to its famous promoter, Martin Yan, this place already has plenty of marketing and exposure without my review... but I can hopefully save you some experimentation with the dumpling part of the menu... and you definitely want to get dumplings here.    The best ones, by far, were the crab and pork dumplings.  But you can try the other style(s) just to be sure.  They also have decent squid ink Snap Noodles, which comes with a garlic sauce.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Went here for lunch after a recommendation from a friend, and it was pretty decent. I had the Wonton Soup and Wild Boar Lettuce Cups. Both items were nice, but not that filling. Guess it was my fault for picking something small, but I was also trying to eat healthy, and everything on the menu seemed so high in calories (hence the 4 stars)!
One of my friends had the Kung Pao Chicken and the other had a vegetarian item, and both said their food was amazing, and filling too.
author: Haylee M.

description:
First let me say that our waiter was amazing. We felt very well taken care of! I was skeptical about eating at a fancier place in the mall, but I have to say it was great. It still felt like I was eating at an upper scale restaurant and the food exceeded my expectations. 

We ordered quite a variety:

*Beef rolls: the wrapping was niche and flakey as it should be
*Beijing knife cut noodles: the noodles were very unique, wide but thinly sliced with a spicy sauce
*Honey walnut prawns: a Chinese American favorite. I wanted to see if it was any better than my neighborhood joint, which is delicious. I would say this was better because it was more fined in flavor and lighter in batter
*Peking duck: served lots of skin and fluffy steamed buns. I haven't had great Peking duck out of Asia, this ranks higher than average in the US, but still far from those in Asia
*Whole Rock Fish: nice fried covered in spicy sauce. This was huge - enough for 4 people. 

We are as much as we could but definitely had enough left over for probably 4 more people.
author: Angelito R.

description: Stick with apps and vino, and you shall be satisfied. Perfect spot to hit up after a movie. Fried tofu, veggie rolls, wine. Don't make it complicated. Heed my advice. If ya don't, you'll feel me: simplicity is key.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
This place lost 2 stars because of a single dish and poor service.

My last visit was stellar, but yesterdays lunch just fell short.

I did not like the crispy noodles with grease, I mean chicken. It just lacked flavor! and was really greasy. I have had so many other great noodle dishes here in the past.

As far as service we sat under the dome and were forgotten at first, though another server stepped in and took care of us and empty water glasses. We really came for the hot and sour soup but questions that we asked about size of bowl and cup were met with shrugs and a hand gesture, so we just ordered cups not wanting two family size portions on the table. Hot and sour soup is not listed or priced on the menu! No drinks desserts or appetizers were offered so none were ordered.

The saving grace is that the hot and sour soup is still Fantastic and a post and picture about it on Facebook garnered many comments & debate from friends that have their favorites and never been to MY. *MY China is still my favorite of the hundreds I have tried.

Its a shame about the shortcomings this visit, but I imagine I will return the next time I am in SF.
author: Jim V.

description:
My wife has asked that we visit M Y China for quite some time.  As a local I was hesitant, so many incredible spots closer to home.  Today is my wife's bday so as I looked for a lunch spot near work, I caved in and made a reservation. 

The food was great.  Fresh and tasty.  Each recommendation over delivered our expectations.  The environment was good and the dome a wonderful setting.  Yet a solid 4 star review bumped to a 5 stars thanks to the ease of booking and birthday request follow through with a beautiful desert.

Thank you M Y China, my wife was super happy, you made me look great and it was so easy.  We will be back.
author: Ken M.

description: Hands-down the best mall restaurant I've ever eaten at. Very upscale in beautiful the food was exquisite. Cut the wild boar noodles vegetable eggrolls Dim sum!
author: Kathryn F.

description:
I have tried this place 4 times and each time I wonder why I gave it another chance. There are some passable items on the menu, but the dim sum selection is small and not that great. The food is overly sauced and typically oily but the oil tends to weigh down the flavor rather than enhance it. The only dish I've truly liked is the crispy tofu. Do not. Do not. Get the crispy noodle though. It is covered in this sticky gross sauce and comprises noodles of a strawlike consistency instead of pan fried noodles. Served with offputting styrofoam chicken and sticky bok choi. Avoid.

Service is nice though
author: Sylvia L.

description:
Came here on a Thursday evening at 6:15pm for a friend's surprise birthday party, his girlfriend made reservations beforehand and that seemed like a smart idea for a party of 20+ because it was pretty paced in there. If you're a fan of YAN CAN COOK on PBS (my parents used to watch this all the time), I wouldn't set your expectations SUPER high. I feel like this was on par with many other Chinese restaurants I've been to (except the whole time I was there, my friends and I were the only Asian people I saw in the restaurant, everyone else was a white family....) You could probably find food that is just as good at a cheaper Chinese place but the vibes might not be as classy or fusion feeling. I think the mood of the restaurant fit the setting of the celebration I was participating in, but I wouldn't come here for a meal with my family or just casually, because I think I could get a better deal somewhere else. That being said, the food wasn't terrible, but it also wasn't amazing.

Located in FiDi, it's a really annoying place that a lot of people don't like going to. I recommend taking Bart to Powell and it's a 900 ft walk to get to the mall, then take the escalators up to the 4th floor to find the restaurant. 

The restaurant has a cute outside area that you can get happy hour drinks and small bites if you're waiting for your reservation (or scare your friend if he's sitting with his back away from the restaurant). 

When a few more people form our huge party came, they sat us in this area in front of the kitchen (where it was very hot actually) while we ordered happy hour drinks. I got the buddha breeze, which was very tasty and probably my favorite thing I consumed that entire night.

Our party of 20+ slit up into a few tables, so I shared the following with 3 other people:
- wok seared beef (on top of arugula, this was VERY good - probably the only thing I thought was really worth ordering actually)
- yang zhou fried rice (straightforward, what you think fried rice would look and taste like)
- Black Pepper Glazed Snapper and Tofu (had eggplant that was decent)
- HK crispy noodle with chicken

The food was average to me, but it could be because I had higher expectations. I would come again if my friends absolutely wanted to come, but the trouble it takes to get out here from the East Bay, price, and quality of food, I would only give it 3 stars. Also it's unfortunate that their happy hour drinks don't continue on the dinner menu at a more expensive price, because the buddha breeze was really good but is only on the HH menu.

Apologies for no pics, was too caught up in the celebration haha. My friend was saying his dad says that Yan Can Cook's appeal is the aesthetic, but that the food might not be amazing, and that is correct.
author: Irena S.

description: Best Chinese food in the city! It's a little pricey but worth every penny.
author: Val V.

description:
MY China is surprisingly good regarding it's a mall restaurant. When my friends took me here I thought it's just another overpriced, tourist trap kinda Asian restaurant. But it turned out pretty well. 

I love their Peking Duck bc the skin is crispy but not overwhelmingly oily. Their tasty Pork and Crab xiao long bao came on top of cucumber slices in ready-to-eat spoons so you won't have to worry about breaking them. We also had chicken feet, har gow, dumplings, and fried rice. They were okay. 

The price is pretty cheap considering the restaurant interiors and professional service.
author: Hannah V.

description:
I have now eaten here with so many different friends. I have literally eaten here over 150+ times. I can't tell you how much I have enjoyed each and every experience. The food, service and atmosphere are all around great. Here are some of my go to favorites: 

Pork & crab juicy dumplings
Honey glazed walnut shrimp (no wasabi)
Crispy tofu
Wild boar lettuce cups 
Chairman mao
Steamed jasmine rice 
Wild Boar Scissor cut noodles 
Deserts: Sugar Egg Puffs 
Drinks: Mojito's non-alcoholic drinks house made strawberry lemonade

My fav waitress: Jessica
My favorite waiter: Cedric
My favorite bartender Eduardo (Lalo)
author: Kevin R.

description:
It was a cold rainy day in San Francisco and I was in the mood for some dim sum.  I didn't want to walk too far & I was too lazy to head to China town.  M.Y. China was the closest, decent looking place near the Union Square area and they had HAPPY HOUR!  Sold!

Headed to the Westfield Mall where they are located and was quickly seated.  The restaurant is very nice and upscale for a Chinese restaurant and I just loved the decor.  The bar area was my favorite -- hanging from the ceiling is a large bell which draws you in and is the focal point of all the wines & spirits.  

I was all by myself and had a view of all the cooks preparing dishes in front of me which provided some entertainment.  I ordered the following dishes:

Xiao Long Bao (Pork Juicy Dumplings on the menu) - pork steamed soup dumplings
Shiu Mai - pork, shrimp, & morel mushroom 
Har Gow - jumbo shrimp, served with spicy soy sauce
Sugar Egg Puffs - chocolate fondue, vanilla bean chantilly cream, & raspberry coulis

Yes, I ordered all of this just for me.  Guess what?  I ate freaking at it all. Not even kidding.  It was amaaazing.  The xiao long bao's came out steaming hot.  So hot I actually burnt my tongue because I was so excited to try it.  It was good, but wasn't the best I've had.  The shiu mai & har gow were tasty as well.  My favorite of the night had to be the sugar egg puffs though (duh, I love desserts!).  I've never had a dessert quite like it.  It was really messy to eat, but oh so delicious.  I loved breaking it into little pieces and dipping them into all the different sauces.  My favorite was the raspberry coulis.  The vanilla bean chantilly cream could have had a stronger flavor in my opinion, but was still good, especially when paired with the raspberry coulis.  YUM!  

I definitely recommend coming here, especially for happy hour and if you're too lazy to head over to China Town.  It's definitely more pricey, but the atmosphere makes for it.  Also, if you're familiar with Chef Martin Yan, this is his restaurant. Go, eat, enjoy.
author: Maria P.

description:
The noodles here are allllllll amazing. I ordered the da dao fish noodle, it has big chunks of seafood inside, the sauce is really good. Pro tip: ask them for their spicy sauce, it is not spicy but it is so tasty with the fish noodle!

My boyfriend ordered the beef noodle( the first one on the noodles page) , to be honest this is the best beef noodle I have ever eaten in North America since I come here in 09. The soup is unbelievably tasty and the beef melts in your mouth. 

One taking one star off? Because their drinks are really bad, we ordered mango mule and the cocktail called forbidden garden. Mango mule just tastes like ginger and there is just no mango taste at all, forbidden garden is very good looking but tastes so bad. I think they messed up the ingredients. 

Anywayz, come here for their food. And try the noodles!!!!!
author: Shuang W.

description:
Liked ~ Liked ~ Liked ~ Liked ~ Liked ~ Liked

Tea Selection 

Chairman mao's chicken... favorite!!! Dry rub spicy chicken with bell peppers and onions 

Bang bang chicken wings 

WonTon Soup 


Disliked / Disliked  /Disliked  /Disliked /Disliked

Shumai... the texture was too chunky kind of tasted like shrimp and pasta 

Kung Pao Chicken wasn't spicy like we thought 

All the Chicken Dishes could've been a lot juicer it was a bit dry but the flavor was great
author: Marian D.

description: Came in for lunch and was pleasantly surprised. The wild boar scissor cut noodles came recommended by the waiter and they were fantastic. Oh my god those noodles are soft and tender. The meat and veggies well seasoned. The shrimp and pork shumai fell a bit short...I felt like they tasted a bit too fishy...wasn't feeling the after taste. I would try some others though since the experience was very good and timing was perfect for a business launch for in and out under an hour.
author: Alicia C.

description:
Actually authentic and really delicious. 

I'm surprised with how much I actually liked MY China. Of course there are a lot of apprehensions because it's a Chinese food place in the mall... That's going to make anyone nervous right? I came for the Lunar New Years dinner. It's a family style meal that serves 6-8 people for $288. It was so worth it for the food that we got. 

It was so delicious. It definitely brought me back to my childhood when we used to gather together for large meals during the holidays. They have a little bit of everything, fried fish SuZhou style. It's fried crispy and served with sweet and sour sauce. The other main dish was the chicken with sticky rice, cooked perfectly and hearty. The salted egg-yolk fried lobster was so delicious. It was juicy and such a healthy portion with so much flavor. Another notable item was the soup! I'm such a sucker for delicious broths. Some people say that these soups are the reason that Asians stay looking young. It's packed with so many notorious goodies. It's also a nice clean broth to lighten up the meal. The dessert was gorgeous! 

The perfect experience!  I look forward to coming back to try new items.
author: Tina Y.

description:
To be honest, I was a little skeptical coming to M.Y. China. Situated at the dome of the Downtown Westfield Mall, it is a perfect location for a tourist trap. But I grew up watching Martin Yan's East Meets West and loved his personality. Surprisingly, my family decided to eat here for Chinese New Year. There was 12 of us, ranging from my millennial cousins to my 93-year-old grandma. I highly recommend making reservations.

We ordered plenty of dishes served family style, including: dim sum sampler, xiao long baos, fried rice, noodle dishes, veggies, meats, and more. Some portions were pretty small, so we had to order at least 2. All in all, everything tasted good and got my picky's uncle stamp of approval. They also have a full bar, so I got a Blushing Dragon, which was served in a cute teapot. I didn't see the final bill, but since I didn't hear anyone complaining, I don't think the damage was too bad. If you're looking for a clean, modern restaurant with traditional Chinese food, this is a solid option.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Finally tried this place after many years of wanting to come here. Service was really slow and this place is pricey for what you get.

Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles bean sprouts, scallions, wood ear mushrooms-this was the best dish of the night. Really flavorful and the noodles are perfect

Wok Seared Beef Sichuan peppercorns, arugula-good flavor. Beef was tender. Can do without the arugula

Peking Roast Duck green onions, cucumber, hoisin sauce, housemade buns-half order. This was ok. We saw everyone ordering it and was thinking it must be good. The skin needs to be more crispy. The buns need to be softer

Yang Zhou Fried Rice barbeque pork, egg, beech mushroom, shrimp-nothing special.
author: Karen H.

description:
Still very busy and a staple for dining at the mall, Martin Yan's China survives where many others have failed.  It is definitely a destination dining experience if you don't mind eating in a mall.  The food court downstairs is fairly eclectic and attracts a large crowd but upstairs M.Y. China and Tap415 are the only two restaurants with seating.  Other restaurants concepts (steakhouse, thai, and pizza) have all failed leaving the Atrium restaurant experience dead.  M.Y. China like any good Chinese restaurant attracts many Asian diners and will still have a line on busy evenings.

Because of the cavernous mall, the open air restaurant can be loud, but if you are an antsy person you can walk over to the Bose store or Nordstrom's just yards away.

Came here to see a movie which makes this a great pre-movie destination and to celebrate Chinese New Year.  Had wild boar lettuce cups, pork dumplings, wok seared beef, and baby bok choy along with jasmine tea and $2 bowls of rice.  Add in a "Beijing" tropical cocktail and the price came to $83 before tax.  

As always the food was top notch and Cepei was a great waiter.  Dumplings were so hot we had to let them sit for a bit.  Dumplings do take 15 min or so as they are fresh.

This is a really great place to go with out of town friends (not too big of a group) if you happen to be in the area and don't want to deal with Chinatown.

Gung Hay Fat Choy!!
author: Erik H.

description:
My ABSOLUTE favorite Chinese place in the City! I always bring out of town visitors to this restaurant. I love the fact that it's inside the mall! The food is ALWAYS amazinggggg! I wish I liked spicy things more because they have the best seven spice entrees. They are amazing -- according to my sibling! I can't take the heat but I wish I could. 

Always get some dimsum & their combination fried rice (they call it something else lol)

Service is amazing. 

I also made reservations via Yelp & it was pretty smooth. Table was ready when we arrived!

Another plus, their rest rooms are ALWAYS clean.
author: Autumn C.

description:
With M.Y. China, Martin Yan brings a more upscale Chinese cuisine to the Westfield Center.  Located on the top floor of the Center, the restaurant has a bar area on the right with a large bell over the bar that was imported from Asia and dining areas in the center and left areas. There are tables in the patio area for those that would like a Under the Dome dining experience.  We opted for an inside center table near the patio which allowed for a view into the mall and view of the open kitchen area.

We were here for a Gilt City special menu.  Our friendly server, Daniel, explained the menu to us and described each dish as it was brought out.  

Lobster and Papaya with young papaya, tomato, thinly slice jalapeno, red onion, mint, cilantro, citrus juice, and fish sauce. The dish had a lobster claw meat and was nicely plated. Though Daniel stated this only had a mild spice, it was medium.  It was at the max of my spice, but it was too spicy for my dining partner.  Suggested to him that the menu should state that this dish is spicy. 

Seared scallops with smoked salmon roe, citrus soy vinaigrette. Perfectly seared scallops that was complemented well by the vinaigrette. 

Matsutake Soup with chicken, dried scallop, ham and wolfberry.  A full flavored traditional soup, which reminded me of soup that my Mom made. 

Spicy Sichaun lamp chop with forbidden rice, crispy noodle, gai lan, Sichuan bean sauce.  Though listed as spicy, the chop had only a hint of spice. The crispy noodles under the chop seemed out of place with this as it falls out of the plate as you're cutting the chop.  The Gai Lan were plain and needed some oil and soy/oyster sauce. The forbidden rice which consisted of red and brown rice and barley was tasty. 

Surf and turf - wagyu beef, jasmine tea smoked seabass, yang zhou fried rice, black pepper sauce. This was delicious dish. The honey glazed seabass was so flavorful and perfectly cooked. The beef was tender and tasty with the black pepper sauce. The scoop of yang zhou rice with bbq pork, egg, mushroom and shrimp was good. 

Matcha tiramisu in a caramel sugar cloud.  The sugar cloud is made of spun sugar made for a dramatic presentation. You need to slowly collapse the cloud into the dessert or set it aside to eat the tiramisu, which was not like your typical tiramisu. 

Though located at a mall, the MY China's food is not mall fare.  Nice ambience under the dome with friendly service.  Two of our dishes needs a little tweaking, one for taste and the other in plating. Otherwise food was very good. Would like to be back to taste the hand-pulled noodles and XLBs.
author: Al L.

description:
Great space, clean and inviting. In the mall. Open later but feels pretty ghost town in empty mall. 

The service was friendly but a little clumsy. Not sure if they were training new people or implementing a new system but timing and things were off. 

Had the following:

Crispy veggie spring rolls - great
Pork riblets - great 
Beef noodle soup - pass. Noodles not particularly interesting, wasn't served hot, broth was sweet, not pleasant 
Peking duck - good. Buns could use some improvement but overall great 
Garlic pea shoots - good

Solid spot. Not worth an out of the way visit but a nice option to have in the mall.
author: Ryan B.

description:
MY China used to be my go to place.  It was an easy place to meet up with clients or even to enjoy my meal and meetings. 

My most recent visit for lunch couple weeks back was very disappointing.  
The restaurant was not busy, wait staff took a while to get to us and wasn't paying attention to our request for water refill or provided us with condiments for the Xiao Long Bao and Wild-boars noodles we also had another hot food item which served lukewarm;(((((
author: P C.

description:
First, the food is good.  It's not the absolute best I've had but I would eat it again.

However, this place is pricey and one could easily argue the food, while good, is not worth the cost.

The service is quick and professional, however courtesy is not it's strong suit.
author: Jim P.

description:
This restaurant definitely feels like a tourist trap, but a nice place to get Chinese food in an upscale, PF Chang's like dining room. If you are a fan of Martin Yan, who for me was the first cooking show personality I can remember watching on TV, then it is worth a trip here too as you can pick up signed copies of his cookbooks here.

Although the food is pricey for Chinese (a few bucks more per dish than you would expect in Chinatown), you are paying for the fancyish ambiance and gorgeous presentation of the dishes. For instance, the xiao long bao soup dumplings come in a pretty package: with each dumpling resting in its own Chinese-style soup spoon of an alternating color. The food is Chinese, with some dishes having more of a PF Chang's fusion feel, while others have a more authentic slant. For authentic, I recommend going for the scissor cut boar noodles or the hand-pulled noodles (which are only available in the niu rou tang mian, or beef noodle soup. 

Getting seated at the countertop bar facing the open kitchen is a must, because you can watch chefs transform a ball of dough into hundreds of  noodles within minutes. It is a show, seeing them stretch, pull, and twirl the dough like magic. If you have never witnessed this process, then making the trip here is worth it alone just to see noodle making in person.

Tip: the restaurant is located on the upper level of the Westfield mall in the heart of San Francisco Union Square/Downtown.
author: Peijean T.

description:
Daaaaaayyyyyuuuummmm
I just found my G Spot.. Let's put in # 

#instago
#instagood 
#food
#foodart 
#yummy 
#foodgasm
author: Ryan R.

description:
Delicious modern Chinese food with a creative culinary twist, fresh ideas and revisits of Chinese favourites.  A little sweet, savoury, tangy, spicy - something for everyone. Opened by Martin Yan and food created by executive chef Tony Wu, this restaurant gives a good taste of what modern SF Chinese food is all about. 

Deep fried hargow (shrimp dumpling), Kobe beef slider with brussels sprouts and drunken chicken.  A snapshot of traditional dishes made accessible.
author: Karen L.

description:
This was my first visit here. I came here because this place was highly rated on Yelp. The restaurant is located in the Market Street mall on level 4. 

I was here for lunch as a single without a reservation. I was seated immediately. I started with a Forbidden Garden cocktail for $12, which tasted very nice. I also enjoyed my Chairman Mao's Chicken for $18 with white rice adding another $2. 

My total balance of $36 included a SF employer mandated charge of $1.50, which is mandated by SF law for healthcare.

Daniel did an excellent job of servicing my table needs. The manager also stopped by to check on my satisfaction. I will definitely return here again for the same meal.
author: Tony J.

description:
Highly recommend the Beef Noodle Soup! Beef is super tender. Only complaint is the broth may be a tad salty, but wouldn't hesitate to order again.

Other recommendation is the Whole Wheat Potstickers, especially with happy hour prices!

I love fried tofu but the Crispy Organic Tofu dish fell a little short only because I wish it was a bit crispier. May order again.

Venison Chow Fun had probably 5-7 pieces of venison. Not a bad dish, but a little over-spiced for my taste. Likely it was to hide the potential gaminess of the venison. Didn't think it was gamey & a lot more tender than I expected!
author: Carol N.

description: A VERY tasty and classy Chinese restaurant in Westfield. Honestly, I've passed by here many times, but have never actually tried the food until today. My friends and I stopped by here for dinner around 7 PM (no waiting for a table, thank GOODNESS!) For $61, we got the wok-seared seafood, ribs, and forbidden rice. Portions are very reasonable, and the food is absolutely delicious! The only downsides are that the menu isn't 100% authentic, and the dishes are all on the pricier side. Overall, though, I especially loved the seafood. Not too oily, but still flavorful enough on its own or mixed in with a side of rice. My friends also loved the ribs! They were pretty meaty, and there was just the right amount of kick from the spice. Would easily recommend this to those who are either looking for a higher-end Chinese place, or who want to enjoy a fancier dinner with coworkers, family or friends.
author: Connie X.

description:
Normally we have dim sum whenever we come to San Francisco. This time, at the recommendation of a friend we decided to have dinner here instead many are glad we did.

We had a wonderful server. We ordered the seafood dumplings, the scissor cut noodles, and the Peking Duck. Each dish was better than the previous one.

I remember Chef Yan from his TV show Yan Can Cook. It was the only cooking show I watched regularly. it was a pleasure to finally eat at one of his restaurant.
author: Harry R.

description:
I've eaten here twice now and I'm sad to change what once was a 4-star review down to a 3. We came here for a team lunch which meant that we were able to try tons of different dishes. While they could have been good, I felt like a lot of the subtle intricacies of what makes the traditional versions of these dishes so great was missing. 

I very much felt like I was just in a fancier American Chinese place instead of a renowned Chinese food establishment. The ma po dofu was bland, the fish overly sweet, the various noodles we had were decent (but to be honest they're hard to mess up) and the dumplings were fairly mediocre. Definitely disappointed to see this place fall into the trap of "mediocre mall food".
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
This place is VERY classy for a mall restaurant. My family and I enjoyed the meal as the portions were reasonable. For sure loved the Crispy Whole Rockfish, it's worth the higher price as it's a bigger dish than the rest of the fish choices. Another dish we loved is the Da Dao "Big Knife" Fish Noodles.
On Sundays, the hours right after most people eat lunch is the best time to go as it is less crowded. Definitely would come back.
author: Bianca A.

description: I love the sautéed string beans here. Everything else on the menu is good too, but those beans - wow - MAGIC!! It's a beautiful room too, and the patio is great. Thank you, MY!
author: Bee G.

description:
Yan can cook, indeed! M.Y. China - Martin Yan's China - was a nice discovery for us.

My husband and I came to San Francisco for the 2018 Bay to Breakers last weekend. We had eaten way too many times in Chinatown on previous trips to the city. This time, we wanted to try some place new. The manager at Hotel Zelos recommended M.Y. China. 

The manager's recommendation turned out to be a real treat. M.Y. China is located in the vicinity of our hotel near Union Square. The walk from hotel to restaurant is less than 15 minutes. We came here twice in a span of 3 days.

First Visit May 19, 2018

Three of us came shortly after 5:00 on Saturday for dinner. There was no line. We were quickly seated at a table just outside the main entrance. The view from our table was amazing. Yes, we were dining on the 4th floor of the busy Westfield San Francisco Centre, but as we pan our surroundings, we didn't get much of the hectic vibes at all.

We ordered Wok Seared Beef, Grandma's Gai Lan, Steamed Tofu & Portobello and brown rice. 

* Wok Seared Beef - Aromatic arugula enhanced the flavors of the the meat. Loved the slightly chewy, yet tender, beef.  
* Grandma's Gai Lan - Lightly seasoned. Sautéed the way my Mom used to. Loved the Chinese sausage.
* Steamed Tofu & Portobello - Beautiful presentation. Tofu was silky smooth, very fresh. Loved the scallion-ginger sauce 
* Brown Rice - Perfect accompaniment for the dishes. Loved the texture. 

Second Visit Monday, May 21, 2018

We were initially concerned about the choice of M.Y. China for our lunch for 5 because one of our guests is a vegetarian. But it turned out that there were quite a few dishes that would work. We ordered 6 dishes to share, including 3 vegetarian ones.

* Wok Seared Beef - Tasted just as delicious as Saturday's, but the beef didn't look as appetizing. Presentation a little off.
* Grandma's Gai Lan - Every bit as good as Saturday's. Fresh gai lan, lean lap cheong. Loved it.
* Garlic Pea Shoots - Vegetarian. This was a hit. Fresh and tender. Seasoned just right.
* Eggplant & Tofu Clay Pot - Vegetarian. Loved the flavor of basil and black pepper sauce.
* Tempeh Sliders (2 orders) - Vegetarian. Nicely garnished with pickled daikon and cilantro.
* Roasted Chicken - Excellent. Crispy skin, tender meat. Didn't even need the seasoned dipping salt. Easily our favorite for this lunch.
* Brown Rice - Very good. Nice to find brown rice in a Chinese restaurant.

Our overall impression:

* Food - Excellent, as expected of the renown Chef Martin Yan.
* Service - Just okay. Saturday server seemed to rush us when there wasn't a crowd waiting to be seated. Service was better on Monday.
* Price - Reasonable for a good San Francisco restaurant.
* Location - Convenient. Accessible by public transportation. No need to drive and fight downtown traffic.

In summary, all 5 of us enjoyed dining here, although there were comments about the dishes showing up lukewarm, not hot. The gai lan, for example, was served already cold. That was disappointing.

It's a solid 4-Stars for M.Y. China for both of our visits. We'll be here again on our next trip to San Francisco. This time, we'll inquire about the secret Chinese menu mentioned in one of the Yelp reviews. We'll also try the popular Dim Sum Sampler and the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles.

A final note: I don't know what management can do about screaming kid(s), if anything. On Saturday, there was a grandma, mom and a young kid seated at the table cater-cornered to ours. The kid was screaming repeatedly. At one point, she got on top of the table. She  pulled on a plate, dropped and shattered it on the floor. Her screaming became piercing. It was impossible to carry on a normal conversation. A very noisy kid in this fine dining spot wasn't exactly a blow to its nice ambiance, but it almost ruined a great experience for us.
author: Luz L.

description:
Decided to drop in randomly during happy hour after work (currently from 3-6pm)

I've always randomly passed this place, but I'm glad I decided to try it out. Just wanted to catch up with my friend and we ordered two cocktails, which were really good! (and pretttty lol). Their drinks seem to change all the time, so I'd just order whatever sounds good on the menu. I really recommend their lemon/zesty drinks though, they have such good flavor in them!

We ordered the Bang Bang chicken wings which were really delicious! They were really sweet and a little bit tangy, but they are definitely worth trying. I think this was the highlight of the happy hour tbh, it was great. We also got the salt + pepper calamari, which was also really good. The waiter warned that it would be spicy, but it wasn't at all - just a touch. I liked this dish a lot too.

The staff were really friendly and the atmosphere is pretty nice. (besides the fact that its in the mall lol) I would definitely come back to try the rest of the menu
author: Melanie T.

description: Quality of the food wasn't as good as I expected. I just visited for the second time and had a very different experience than my first visit. The first time I dropped by during happy hour and was seated outside and ordered off the Bar menu. I was looking forward to going again since that first visit was memorable. I made a reservation with thoughts of eating the items I found on the restaurant's website. I was really hungry when we got there. I ordered what I had seen and waited patiently. I was disappointed in the quality of the meat which was very chewy, even the Chairman Mao's chicken, usually so soft and spicy. The chicken was hard fried and the spices were hard to chew. The stars are for what I think a meal here could be if you stick to the Bar menu. I do like the look of the restaurant and the general ambience inside.
author: Brenda K.

description:
After a long day of shopping and already being inside the West Field mall we decided to give MY China a try. We walked to the host and were offered kitchen bar seating but if we wanted to wait 15-20minutes for a table (they also make sure to let you know that can't guarantee the time) so we decided to wait for a table, which literally took 2 minutes. 
We started with two small plates, pork belly & beef rolls. Both were really good and perfect portion for two.
We had the honey glazed pork and cold noodles as the main. Both complimented each other, sweetness of the pork and the spice and freshness of the noodles. 
I can't believe this was our first visit. I'll definitely be back to try out more dishes.
author: Nicole A.

description:
My extended mostly Muslim family was in town with a vegan and a couple of gluten free folks along. I setup a pre-set meal for everyone that was basically a pork-free Chinese meal. This is really, really hard to do without a lot of work, but the staff didn't even flinch as we worked through the menu and its alternatives. The food was absolutely delicious. The service very attentive. The servers went around the tables and got special orders from people. 

Our party was about 24 people. They didn't have a private room for just us, but it worked out ok. I hope someday they can get private rooms because that meal in a segregated setting where it was just my family would have been over the top.

I would happily book another big family meal here. I really loved the experience.
author: Shabbir S.

description:
My family and I took my dad out for his 60th birthday to M.Y. China in SF. I grew up watching chef Martin Yan's cooking show Yan Can Cook with my family. My parents always admired his recipes so it was fitting to take them to Martin Yan's restaurant to celebrate my dad's special day. We enjoyed delicious food, fun conversation, and the company of one another . Majority of the noodles are hand pulled and oh so good. The rest of the entrees are a good portion size and perfect for sharing. We had quite a bit of left over but here's a list of what we got:
Appetizers
- hot and sour soup
- vegetarian longevity noodle soup
- crispy spring rolls
- bang bang chicken wings
- pork soup dumplings

Dinner
- vegetarian chow fun
- Vegetarian scissor cut noodles
- Yang Zhao fried rice
- claypot eggplant and tofu
- black pepper glazed snapper
- garlic pea shoots
- Sichuan green beans
- Kung Pao chicken

Dessert
- egg puffs with chocolate and raspberry sauce
author: Sahiba J.

description:
Leo and Raul amazing bartenders!  They made our anniversary special!

The charcoal cocktail and East Side were rockn!

The red snapper with tofu and eggplant was my favorite!
We can't wait to return!

Celebrating our anniversary!
We will be back!
author: Clara B.

description:
This restaurant has gone downhill tremendously over the years in terms of quality but not in price! 

I stopped by here with 2 friends last night and we started with some cocktails. Despite being told the drinks are "well balanced" we got diabetes in a cup. Sent those back. 

Note to seld & you: don't get the cocktails. Whoever the bartender was a few years back has left 

We ordered the usual wild boar scissor cut noodles: these were extremely oily! Terrible. They use to be so good 

The roast chicken: the first piece was great the rest of it was very very dry 

Wonton soup; large came with 6 pieces. This wasn't bad, it's just extremely over priced. 

Overall, this restaurant is just another glorified mall food joint now. Don't bother - it's way too over priced for what you get. Meh. Sad times
author: Annie Z.

description:
Definitely my lucky day. Came here and Martin Yan was onsite. Yeah! Got a picture with him. 

Issue I have is that my mom didn't come on the trip to San Fran with me and I never know what to order at a Chinese restaurant. Yes I stared blankly at the menu. Martin told me that their walnut shrimp and kung pao chicken is really good. So I ended up ordering that.

Walnut Shrimp is quite interesting. It has a hint of wasabi taste to it. 
The Kung Pao Chicken is mild spicy. Nice flavor to it.  Colorful with the peppers in it. Except the chicken was a bit dry. Overall, I liked both the dishes and it goes well with rice.

Best if you have more people so you can share dishes. 

Décor is really nice. Place is clean looking and stylish. Lots of people here. They were basically busy the entire day. I came very late too. Best to make a reservation if you decide to dine here.
author: Denise W.

description:
Finally came here to try the famous Martin Yan's restaurant at the Westfield Mall. 

Everything we ordered was very tasty. We had a vegetarian with us but that did not hinder us from getting yummy food. Something that stood out to me was their Forbidden Rice. It was red sticky rice with some other ingredients in there. Even if you're not a vegetarian, I recommend this dish! It complements a lot of the other dishes they serve. 

Their soup dumplings were good as well! It came with vinegar and ginger on the side! Everything tasted totally traditional but elevated!

Good job Yan Can COOk! Until next time!
author: Mai W.

description: M.Y. China is a great place to go if you're looking for good tasty Chinese food at a location that's ultra convenient and don't mind spending a bit more (emphasis on spending a bit more). If you've ever heard of Martin Yan, the man from the Yan Can Cook series on TV, this is his restaurant. I've been here over 10 times now and haven't been disappointed once. Instead of taking "normal" Chinese food and trying to elevate it, which is the trend these days with all new restaurants in San Francisco, M.Y. China just focuses on delivering simple food that tastes good. If you're one to try cocktails, I'd highly recommend getting the Beijing. They may have a rotating cocktail menu so catch it while you can. Regarding dishes, I'd highly recommend the Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp and the Peking Roast Duck.
author: Austin W.

description:
Got a prefixe dinner deal and everything we had was delicious!!

I'll be honest I wasn't super impressed by M.Y. China the first time I went when it opened. To me the food was just okay for the prices they are charging. 

Food:
The best dish we had was the surf and turf - it was a cod in this yummy honey glaze, fried rice and beef. The fish was AMAZING, cooked to perfection! I was really impressed and was not expecting it. The whole preset dinner was six courses and every course was good or above. I don't remember all the dishes we had or what it was called exactly but here's the breakdown:
- 1st course: cold lobster and something salad, it was too spicy for me to eat
- 2nd course: scallops and salmon roe, this was delicious
- 3rd course: mushroom soup with... different types of mushroom and some chicken
- 4th course: lamb chop with fried noodles and some yummy rice, lamp chop was one small piece
- 5th course: surf and turf (best course & my fave!)
- 6th course: matcha tiramisu dessert

Service:
Our waitress was nice, but I did find service to be a bit lacking. I found it odd that on a preset dinner menu they only explained what the dish was half the time, so the other half I was confused as to what was in front of me. Overall, service was alright.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
I was blown away at M.Y. China. We were yelping for a dinner location and came across this place in the Westfield mall. My wife and her friend (from Singapore) told me that Martin Yan used to have a pretty popular cooking show broadcasted in Singapore and they wanted to check this place out. I wasn't sure of what to expect. We ordered beef rolls, yang chow fried rice, and half chicken. The beef rolls were awesome (tender beef pieces rolled in soft dough), fried rice was fragrant and just delicious. The highlight for me was the chicken. It was very tender with crisp skin and served with plum powder with spices. It is a pretty cool presentation of chicken that is common in so many cuisines. 

While we were about to be done, someone stopped by our table and asked if we enjoyed the food. While I was looking up to talk, I had a brief glimpse on his white coat which read Martin Yan (M.Y., get it?). My wife and our friend were quite star-struck. They asked to take pictures and shared with their families! Martin Yan was especially friendly and upon finding out that the girls are from Singapore, told them he is going to host a cooking event to display Malaysian cuisine at H. L. Peninsula Restaurant in San Mateo on September 7, 2018. He was extremely friendly humble and friendly. We teased him and asked him what was his favorite dish on the menu. He said he is too biased to answer but said he could confidently say that everything on their menu was decent.
author: Doruk B.

description:
Came here with a large group of colleagues and tried a lot of the dishes from the menu. My absolute favorite was steamed sea bass - beautifully prepared and tasted like heaven. The hot and sour soup was very delicious. Our party devoured the fried crab and shrimp dumplings. The duck was a bit dry and the smoked sea bass was too sweet for my taste. 
Overall, the food was delicious and beautifully presented. I will definitely be back for more!
author: Anna S.

description:
Tonight was a start of new holiday traditions for myself and siblings. M.Y. China was our 1st choice and it did not disappoint.

Reservation:  Made my reservation via Yelp.  Appreciated getting confirmation of my reservation via text message.  I also received a reminder of my reservation the day before.  

Arrived to M.Y. China about 10 minutes early.  The restaurant was very busy but we were seated within 5 minutes.  Our server, Gemini was very attentive and even made recommendations for alternate selection because a couple of the party did not do well with spicy hot.  Thank you for the recommendations.

Our menu selection consisted of the following: Pork Juicy Dumplings (XLB) 2 orders, Chicken Scissor cut noodles, Peking Roast duck, Wok Seared seafood, and Garlic Pea Shoots.  Each dish came out hot, very tasty and presentation was top notch.  The garlic soy sauce in addition to the ginger vinegar was a nice touch to go with the XLB.  For dessert we ordered Sugar egg puffs which is served with chocolate ganache, Chantilly cream and raspberry coulis and Salted egg custard buns.  YUMMY!

We never felt rushed in having to finish our dinner and vacate the table.

If you love good food and don't mind paying the price...I highly recommend M.Y. China.  

Next time I would love to sit near the open kitchen and watch the chefs and cooks prepare the various dishes.
author: Nelson C.

description:
Decor and the environment was amazing. When it comes to Chinese food, I'm a little picky because I find a lot the main dishes taste exactly the same from place to place. I really look for distinction and personality.


They did use a lot of chili spices and herbs, but it was very main steam and for the price the portions were small.

This is a wonderful establishment and very cozy place to bring your family of your okay with the cost.
author: Komatsu O.

description: Enjoyed happy hour at this restaurant. Several items that start at $5. The wings & calamari was really good. The seasoning on the calamari was very delicious. Potstickers & dumplings were good too! The ambience was nice. Huge place.. wouldn't mind coming back next time I'm in town.
author: Sarina S.

description: Very comfortable environment, great food! Not exactly 100% authentic Chinese food, but more of an Asian American fusion style which is also delicious. The lobster on crispy noodles appetizers are so tasty! I also highly recommend the stir fry rice cake, it's sooo authentic Chinese flavor and it's just great! The different salads are also pretty good too so if you're on a diet(like I am) you can order their salad for a fresh and also healthy meal.
author: Hermione L.

description:
A pretty late review.


This is definitely one of the reasons why I hate going to higher priced places that consider themselves family sized plates. They arent! I would say each plate is good for 2 people. Nothing more for sure.

My favorite thing was the wild boar noodles. I wouldn't be back, and I would rather go to an sf local place, like San tungs
author: Lynn C.

description: Lively place, came here for lunch.  Liked the Peking duck and squid ink pasta.  Will come back.
author: Aline N.

description:
Long overdue, we came back and this time with my parents for done Dim Sum and hand-pull-noodle on the Pride Parade 2018 Sunday.

It worked out perfectly because at lunch time, the entire restaurant was only about 10% occupied. Perfect for us, get away from the parade after 2 hours of watching... It was 85 degree hot day and we were starving.

Beautiful layout, love the bar with that gigantic bell. We were told part of the bar came from a Chinese monastery. It's a century old and weighs 1,800 pounds.

They've hired a world-champion noodle puller. Chef Yong Dong Wu, but people call him Tony. Chef Wu was the first chef to pull 16,000 noodles in two minutes with his bare hands. (He can also do it blindfolded, no kidding). Nice to know but in this slow Sunday, my parents do didn't get to see any spontaneous noodle-pulling performances, but rather a quite Dim Sum lunch, very quiet! 

Service was good by our waiter. We chose all the food ourselves. 

Fung-Chao chicken feet was very good. My parents ordered 2. 

Hot and Sour soup was a tad too sweet and too sour for my taste!

Dumplings was OK. Shiu Mai was very good. 

Shandong Beef Rolls was OK.

Bok Choy sautéed in garlic was good.

Rice Cake with Wild Board was interesting, but also oily.

Pork Juicy Dumpling (Xiao Long Bao) was good and served super hot which we enjoyed.

Hand pull noodle with beef, green onion, bean sprout was good in texture but too oily, we didn't want to finish them.

Baby chrysanthemum tea is also very good here.

We were also offered the special Dungeness Crab menu special offers from six regions/province in China. 

GUIYANG PROVINCE  - Chili Pepper Crab, onions, shallots, hot pepper sauce. We chose this and it was very good, almost reminded me of Cajun style for some reason. 

CHAOZHOU PROVINCE - Dungeness Crab in Black Bean Sauce, garlic, green onion, black pepper. This was quite nice and flavorful. 

The crabs were pricier because it's not really a crab season now in San Francisco. 

It's a convenient spot to eat if you need a break from shopping, but I wouldn't go out of my way to dine here. Something about dining at the mall doesn't do it for me. And it's definitely not a place for us to go out of our ways to come for dinner nor celebration, unless we are in the area. 

Now that Crystal Jade is closing, I'm sure M.Y. China will surely get more business.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Always delicious. We love the shrimp dish with fried rice. The hot souse makes it even better. I like they bring the food fast. So even on my lunch breaks I can go and eat fast.
author: Hani G.

description: Service is horrible!! Like really bad. Asked about the roast chicken And the server had no idea. Server never checked up on us till we were done waiting for boxes, dropped off boxes and instead of bringing the check server went behind the bar and just ate his dinner. We had to ask another server for the check while we watched the server eat for about ten mins.  Here is a picture of our server eating!
author: Ro L.

description:
I was very surprised about this restaurant rant cause it was in a mall.  But THis place was very impressive, the foood was delicious and very unique Asian cuisine.  
A group of 5 ate family style for $70/person with 1.5 drinks each.  It was all a bit overpriced even for SF. The lobster in cold noodles was spectacular , as were the bang bang spicy Sweet chicken wings which were very meaty, the seafood dumplings were slightly spicey but perfect.  The wild boar noodles were thick and perfext but the salt and pepper calamari were a bit spicy even when we asked for mild. 

Neil was our server he was very attentive and good recommendations, but looks like he was stretched thin and it was difficult to get his attention cause they were understaffed.
author: David C.

description:
I'm so bummed out that I never went to M.Y. China when they when they first opened with Chef Martin Yan overlooking the kitchen.  It wouldn't be until a couple years later that I would finally visit for lunch with my family to celebrate my birthday.  And I'm glad I made that decision because we had a good experience, but unfortunately as I expected, Chef Martin Yan wasn't there.

With it being my birthday lunch, I went with ordering one of their specialty cocktails to celebrate.

East Meets West -- http://bit.ly/2itedEA
chrysanthemum infused Russian standard's vodka, orange blossom honey, lemon juice
This was a great cocktail to start my meal with.  Very refreshing!

On to the food.  I really was just in the mood to have some noodles and so I decided on their Beef Noodle Soup to satisfy that craving.

Beef Noodle Soup -- http://bit.ly/2ithuDX
slow simmered short rib, baby bok choy
This soup was way better than I expected and it was loaded with noodles and a generous portion of short rib that easily broke apart.  The broth was very good too with a lot of flavor but not too salty surprisingly.  I'm glad I ordered this!

We also shared the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles and Pork Juicy Dumplings for everyone around the table.

Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles -- http://bit.ly/2itcleY
bean sprouts, scallions, wood ear mushrooms
This is one of M.Y. China's signature menu items.  I liked the imperfection of the noodles and they were cooked perfectly with a good chew and the wild boar and mushrooms gave it a more hearty substance.

Pork Juicy Dumplings -- http://bit.ly/2itgi38
Basically Xiao Long Bao and they were delicious!  A little pricey though compared to other places where you can get XLB.

And then for Dessert I finished with the Lychee Panna Cotta.

Lychee Panna Cotta -- http://bit.ly/2it3DNR
chrysanthemum granita, mint essence
This dessert was AMAZING!!  I love Panna Cotta and I love lychee so putting the two together made for a very delightful dessert!

Overall, I liked M.Y. China.  It was a lot better than I thought it would be and it's a great spot to  dine for any occasion whether it be for a big party or if you're just stopping by for a quick noodle lunch.  I would definitely return again to try more of their menu items which there were plenty of.  And hopefully maybe next time Chef Martin Yan will be there.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Nice restaurant located at the top of Bloomingdales in Westfield mall. Came here for dinner before watching a movie. People rave about this place.
The bang bang wings were sauced and perfectly crsipy. 
The string beans was basic 
The soup dumplings weren't as flavorful as ding tai fung, obviously and the sauce didn't add anything to it. 
the salted egg crab was massive and flavorful, but it was definitely challenging to eat. 
The crispy noodles were good, but definitely not the normal portion size you would get from other traditional chinese restaurants. 

The total bill came to $126 for all these entrees. Kind of pricey for chinese food, but I guess the location makes the difference. It wasn't amazing for the price we paid.  IMO, I would rath pay less for traditional dim sum. Not that the food wasn't good, I just don't think Chinese food should be so fancy.
author: Jenna T.

description: My friends and I came here for dinner on a Thursday. The interiors are nice and I was excited to try a new place. We ordered the Dan Dan noodles and we were surprised to find they were cold noodles. I don't think that was mentioned in the menu. Additionally we ordered the dim sum (Xiao long bao) and Kung Pao chicken. Both dishes were sub par; the dim sum had an odd flavor and the skin was thick. The chicken was way too dry. I had to order and gorge down hot sauce to eat that dish. Truly disappointing Chinese food.
author: Vyoma K.

description:
Let me start off by saying most of my food was excellent. The Wild Boar Scissors Cut Noodles was amazing and the Hong Kong Crispy Noodles with Chicken was also very flavorful but the M.Y. Dim Sum Collection and the Juicy Dumplings weren't as flavorful as they should have been. The worst part was "the service" and that's why I decided to leave a review. We had a dreaded waiter that took our order and left some of our order out and when my daughter politely called his attention to it he didn't apologize, when he brought our bill back to us he still had it listed even though she had spoken to him about it minutes before, and again he didn't apologize for his mistake when he took the bill back for corrections. He then took too long bringing it back to us with the corrections and he still did not apologize for his mistake and behaved arrogantly, as if we were a terrible inconvenience. 

I have eaten at thousands of restaurants and I know good service. There are tons of restaurants out there which serve equal quality food and their service is excellent and their servers apologize when they get an order wrong or leave something out. He needs to keep that in mind since he represents the restaurant to all those he serves and when he takes orders but forgets to bring something ordered it's all on him to make things right and apologize for the mistakes and put a little hustle in making it back to the table with the correction. At this time I would not recommend this restaurant to my friends.
author: Lilia R.

description: So, I decided to come back after a disappointing dinner at the beginning of this year. This time around, we had an outstanding dining experience in which the host and server went the extra mile to make it enjoyable. Recommendations were on point and service was top. I would come back without hesitation.
author: Veritas V.

description: told us not to be wary that it was in the mall, and they were spot on! Do not hesitate to come here just because its not in "China Town" and inside a mall. The food here was nothing sort of delicious and incredible. I recommend the  1/2 Peking duck, one side and one appetizer if you have 2 people. The portions are very generous! Overall I cant wait to come back here on my next SF trip & wish they had one in LA!!
author: Arica R.

description:
I feel disheartened to give my China one star because I've been coming here for years. Every time I come here, I order one dish : scallion lobster clay pot. 
Chefs here are inconsistent, sometimes too salty, sometimes too bland, and sometimes the lobsters are mushy ( bad quality). 
Nevertheless, I'm always very forgiving when it comes to this dish because I love it so much. 

But lately, M Y China is skimming on quantity AND quality. I am a lobster lover and I've been to this restaurant so many times so I am extremely aware of the portion size of the lobster. They now charge $68 for this dish and they now skimming and don't give you the whole lobster.  I only got two tiny ass piece of lobster tail when I dined here last two time, the pots were full of small claws and Inedible parts. This is OBSURD AND UNACCEPTABLE. Now I'm thinking about it, I really should have asked for refund on these 2 pots. 

Sigh, M Y China, you are doing a really good job at disappointing your customers, I finally gave up on you. Will never recommend or bring anyone here unless they stop skimming.
author: Alli Y.

description:
Here is my advice: 

If you are a group of 5 people order two orders of the wasabi shrimp (amazing), a large order of the Peking duck, and one order of the choy sum, and you will be very very happy. Those are their best dishes in my opinion and we are never disappointed by them.
author: Lana B.

description: After years of watching Yan Can Cook, I have finally made it to Martin Yan's restaurant, and he did not disappoint. I grew up eating Chinese food daily, and the food was more than up to my standards. The service and decor was great as well. We had the Spicy Seafood Dumplings, Garlic Pea Shoots, Peking Duck, and Scissor Cut Noodles with Wild Boar. Great flavor and texture for all our dishes. We will be visiting this place again!
author: holly c.

description:
Overall, wouldn't go back because of food quality and pricing. Felt like a rip off especially the noodle dish. We went here because it was conveniently open after the movies and I've seen videos of rave reviews but it didn't live up to expectations. 

Service was fair and prompt. 4/5
Food...
Pork noodle dish: flavor was ok but not very much depth, mostly just salty. Also ABSOLUTELY NOT ENOUGH MEAT. There were literally 4 specks of pork the size of peas. I couldn't even tell you what the meat was like. It was criminal they even advertise it as having meat. 1/5
XLB: flavor was good and had a decent amount of broth. I liked that the skins weren't too thick like they often are in sf but still not as good as in LA and way too expensive. 3.5/5
Pork sliders: again, decent flavor but way over priced. The meat was good but the best part of it was the steamed bun that you could get from a bakery for 25¢ 3.5/5

Maybe if this place was half the price I wouldn't have minded. But no amount of money would be ok for that noodle dish.
author: Anna N.

description:
Jasmine tea smoked sea bass - Delicious, soft, and savory but very small portions (see pictures).

Black pepper glazed snapper and tofu - Pot was delicious and filled with thick pieces of tofu and snapper. 

Bok choy - Basic, simple, healthy.

Donuts - Dessert at the end was complimented with whip cream, sweet and sour, and chocolate dip. 

White rice - As all Americanized Chinese restaurants, it's extra. 

Service - Nice, but our waiter was constantly stressed out.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
I came here with my friends since we were in Westfield and couldn't decide where to eat, and this place caught our attention since it was near where we met up. We came on a Wednesday around 12:30ish and it was busy, but we were seated immediately (there were 3 of us). This place is definitely an upscale Chinese place, and the food is kind of expensive for the amount of food and the quality of it, maybe because I'm used to going to cheaper Chinese restaurants   around the city with my family where I get more bang for my buck, but I digress. This place has a mix of dim sum and Chinese dishes, and the wait for our food wasn't long, around 10-15 min. 

Food:

- Har gow (3): The har gow comes with some soy sauce (I didn't try the sauce since I don't usually eat har gow with sauce, but the har gow was packed with shrimp inside, and was definitely my favorite out of all the dishes.

- Pork juicy dumplings (5): This is basically xiao long bao, and it was delicious. It comes in little individual spoons and comes with the usual vinegar sauce. There was also a slice of cucumber in between the spoon and dumpling, which was interesting but it didn't enhance the flavor of the dumpling or anything, so maybe it was there for aesthetic purposes or something, but still delicious, nonetheless. 

- Kung pao chicken: This is actually the first time I've had kung pao chicken, and it was alright. The dish comes with chicken (which were kind of dry), bell peppers (which were delicious), some chili peppers (which my friends said weren't spicy, but since I'm a weakling with spicy food, it was a bit spicy for me), and peanuts (very delicious!!). This dish had good flavor and spiciness.

- Yang zhou fried rice: The amount of food was kind of small for the price, and it comes with mushrooms, BBQ pork, and shrimp pieces. The rice was good, but a little bland, and it worked well with the other dishes.

The service was great, and the servers refilled our waters when it was getting low in our glasses. Overall, this place is great if you want the upscale Chinese vibe and if you're in the area, though I wouldn't come back since I've been to better and cheaper Chinese restaurants.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This is a mall restaurant. More of a friend get together place. No suitable for family... 

1) Food: this is a fusion Chinese restaurant, good food, good selection and very tasty.

2) Service: I would say ok... not great nor bad

3)Price: average for 2 will be $50 to 60 per person

4) Environment : clean, good setup, clean and very modern.

I would recommend that if you have a chance and are in the neighborhood then try it out. But this may not be a day to day dine out type of restaurant
author: Kalani S.

description: Food was really good.. I've always wanted decent indo-Chinese and this could be my Goto place. Though the orders were late
author: Naby S.

description: Fast seating, friendly service  and even faster food service for "the most delicious Peking Duck we have ever had". Hong Kong Fried Noodles were great too. Pretty restaurant setting. Surprised to find it in a shopping mall. Large portions. Would highly recommend.
author: Lisa O.

description:
I really put high hopes on this restaurant, but here's why this place only deserves a 3 stars.

LOCATION AND PARKING
======================================================================
Location of this restaurant is inside the Westfied Mall in SF. So you would have to park your car inside the parking structure, otherwise parking street is the other option. I believe the rate per hour on weekend is $2.5 (please correct me if I'm wrong), but it's not mindblowing crazy. 

FOOD
======================================================================
For DIMSUM section we ordered;
1. Beijing dumpling (that's what people here have been recommending): skin is quite thick, you could almost tell that it has too thick when you taste the flour more than the filling). 
2. Har Gaw: nothing special. Other dimsum have better har gaw

For Noodle we ordered;
1. Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood (海鲜墨汁朵麺) $18. I asked our server what kind of noodles they were serving with for this dish, turned out the noodle was a point finger size cut. So it was not like regular chinese pulled noodle (which I thought it would be). The meats cooked with the noodle are shrimp, scallops, calamari, with brussels sprouts and bell peppers.
Truthfully I dislike this dish, what I had in mind, it was going to be similar with Italian squid ink pasta, except they're using chinese noodle. However, what we had was totally different with what I had in mind. The taste itself, wow, underrated. I feel like eating regular chinese noodle in a fancy restaurant with premium price. Lack of flavor, portion is enough for two people, and this dish costs $18 exclude tax and tip.

2. We also ordered Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles (野豬刀剪麺) $16. The dish was originally for my kids. I requested to substitute the mushrooms with chicken. The veggies it has bean sprouts, scallions only. Again, they were serving this dish with a finger cut size noodle. It was easy for the kids to stab it with forks, but again, this second noodle dish lack of flavor. It even almost tasted the same with the first noodle dish we ordered (the squid ink noodle).

For the drink we ordered milk jasmine tea, it was just okay. 

To sum it up; 
This would be an American Chinese restaurant that has fancy decoration and located prime inside the Westfield Mall. It may be your dining destination if you are 
1. Never adventure in Chinese cuisine
2. Going to the mall is your one stop destination where you want to shop and have lunch at the same time.
3. You hate to eat in the hole in the wall restaurant. 

If you are nowhere close to the 3 lists I mentioned, please save your money and time by not going here. Browse any other restaurants which I bet they are going to be tastier than this one!
author: Maureen M.

description: Really nice setting under the Rotunda at the mall. Nice upscale decor. The maitre d seemed fairly disinterested, our waiter was great but food was just meh. The chicken was dry.
author: Sunil R.

description: Terrible service! they made me to sit at the bar table and when I was ready to order and seeking someone for help, I was completely ignored even the waiters actually saw me waving my hand, they also gave me a cold-eyed stare. food is good but I won't come back again
author: San N.

description: I've tried four dishes here and they have all been, at best, average - not worth paying the premium they charge. Their drinks are very hit or miss, usually only one person in my group will like any given drink. Maybe worth trying this for the experience, but I will definitely not be a regular.
author: Caelin J.

description:
Great service and ambiance, but the dishes we ordered were just ok. 

The Eggplant and Tofu Claypot was way too oily. The eggplant and soft tofu were just sitting in a pot of oil, which was not appetizing.

I liked the Da Dao "Big Knife" Fish Noodles better. It had a good flavor, but it was also pretty oily, and the noodles were very mushy.

Also, none of their dishes come with rice, so you have to separately order a bowl of rice if you want it.

I would not come out of my way to eat here, but if I were to return, I would not be against it. I would come back to try their other menu items because the other dishes did look pretty good as I was looking around at the other tables. However, I would not recommend the Eggplant and Tofu Claypot or the Da Dao Noodles.
author: Celena C.

description: I was checking out the Westfield Mall, & decided it was time to grab a bite.  At first I was a little apprehensive. The atmosphere is extremely dark, especially for the afternoon on a sunny day.  However, I was very pleased with the service & food I received.   My bartender was awesome!  I wasn't in the mood to make decisions, & every recommendation was perfect. He even let me sample a couple of different wines before committing to a full glass. The Scissor Cut Noodles were fabulous!
author: Joby W.

description:
My first time here. It is in the Westfield Mall, 4th floor.
It reminded me of the restaurants you see in Las
Vegas. Got there early: 4:30 pm since I didn't have lunch. There were tables,  but we had to wait to be
seated. 
  Once we were finally seated , one of the main waiters
asked us if we were ready to order . We hadn't had
time to look at the menu. This happened several times.
It felt like we were being rushed. Once we ordered.
The food came rather fast : crispy spring rolls, Dan Dan
noodles, fried rice, Kung Pao chicken with bell peppers
and onions and Walnut shrimp. Spring rolls were good,
Dan dan noodles had some noodles, but mostly
shredded vegetables. Kung pao chicken had 
breaded chicken, walnut shrimp had wasabi.
I needed to look at the menu more closely.
  Service was good, but we felt rushed. Food was
okay, but not amazing.
author: Gayle G.

description:
Been to M.Y. China a few times and have never been disappointed. 

+ Hong Kong crispy noodles
Really spicy, not that much chicken, small bok choi cooked lightly

+ Tea infused Chinese taco
Very fluffy and light bread! Meat was hidden and overpowered by the sauce and cilantro but very tender

+ Pork Juicy dumplings
Came with 5, very cute red spoons but not sure how I feel that they're chipped spoons? Might be my favorite soup dumplings in town

+ Honey Walnut Prawn
Had a wasabi mayo glazing, didn't come with much for $23, the vegetables were bitter as F

+ Braised Pork
Super duper expensive and dry for just a couple of pieces

It is rather expensive for Chinese food, but it's calm and sophisticated ambiance makes up for it. It's also really relaxing to be under the dome of the mall. The service is really good and attentive as well. Overall I would recommend this restaurant for someone that doesn't want to make the trek to Chinatown for Chinese food.
author: Linda K.

description:
Decent upscale Chinese food in a modern restaurant setting at Westfield. I will admit, M.Y. China is my go to restaurant at times when I'm looking for something to eat around Union Square. I've been a few times and for the most part, the food has been pretty good and is flavored authentically. 

M.Y. China contrasts a lot with other more authentic and traditional Chinese restaurants in that the prices are steep and the attitude of the food is definitely more modernized/fusion. I can see that this restaurant is definitely a place where people come in to order more Americanized and typical Chinese food such as chow mien. 

The menu includes small eats, "dim sum," soups & salads, noodles, roasted, lobster, wok and vegetarian. There's a huge variety of food so it's easy to feel tempted to try everything, especially the dim sum dishes. I do enjoy the fact that they have a vegetarian section, there's definitely something for everyone at this place. Most dishes will run around $20. Portions are pretty filling.

Beef Noodle Soup - Broth is pretty good, but I'm not a fan of the fact that it's cooked with udon noodles instead of the more traditional hand pulled/narrower noodles.
