Vegetarian Longevity Noodle Soup - Unfortunately didn't get to really finish or enjoy it as there was a hair in it the fish time I got it (yuck!). Could've have been a nice and affordable healthy option though for $12.

Black Pepper Glazed Snapper - My favorite dish at this place. You can't go wrong with this one. Highly recommend.

I came recently with friends who shared some dishes family style while I tried the Eggplant & Tofu Clay Pot. According to them, and from my observation the noodles aren't that great. 

Eggplant & Tofu Clay Pot - Really enjoyed the flavor of the sauce and the fried edges of the tofu and eggplant. I did think this dish was too oily/greasy, but it seems like most dishes are here at M.Y. China. Was around $19 including tip and tax but I was able to save half of it for leftovers the next day.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
A beautiful restaurant on the 4th floor of the Westfield Mall. I've gotta warn ya, that it's pretty expensive! If you came with a huge group of people like I did and shared the dishes, it's not worth it and no promises that you'll leave with a full belly. 

The servers weren't extremely attentive, our finished dirty plates would build up on the table. Get the My Dim Sum so you can get a little bit of everything. I really liked the Squid Ink Noodles, the seasoning was perfect and the noodles were cooked perfectly as well! The food was pretty good overall, it's just really expensive.
author: Jenni T.

description: M.Y. China is a westernized Chinese restaurant, but the dishes are pretty good and so we've ate at the restaurant probably a dozen or so times. The one thing we have to always do when we eat here though is to tell them to go very light on both the sauces and salt, otherwise the dishes have way too much sodium. Remember to tell your waiter this!
author: Thomas C.

description: We have eaten here at least once a month for the past six years!! We love the kung pow chicken. This is the only restaurant in America to serve fui hang chillies!!! The customer service is always top notch!!
author: Julie Z.

description: The best staff i seen downtown yet, hands down, super impressed ,wilk come back definitely,  the bartenders an runners an chefs , all the Best ,thank you , great experience see you soon , Lalo bartender ,Execellent employee an the others as well ,Thank you
author: Robert G.

description: It's a rare thing indeed to discover an exceptional establishment whose proprietors step up to accept responsibility instead of defensively evade or shirk responsibility for its mistakes, however minor, as in this case. And Carol, manageress of M Y China, is clearly and sincerely genuine in her concern for the customers dining at her restaurant, promising nothing but a pleasurable experience. She has gone way out of her way to most graciously rectify what was surely a transient lapse in customer service. And her positive and supportive response merits this amended review with nothing less than our highest recommendation. Which goes to show, most importantly, you can never judge any establishment purely on the basis of any single, solitary experience, no matter how good or bad. So don't hesitate to patronize this one. If you do happen to have a less than favorable visit, or even the smallest complaint, you can rest assured that M Y China will in the end, somehow, make it right. And make it good, too!
author: Dave T.

description:
This is a more swanky Chinese restaurant with great food! I've been here for happy hour with discounted shu mai and potstickers. We also got je seafood fish noodles dish on the dinner menu and it was amazing! 

I would order everything but the potstickers again. Also, the kitchen is pretty visible and open which I enjoy. The Chinese food here isn't greasy and decently priced/portioned. 

The ambiance is a little noisy and the restaurant is full after work. Service is great and the "outside" seating is great. So weird but awesome that this restaurant is inside the 4th floor of the Westfield Mall!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
First Impression: Long Line... must mean Good Food??!!! 

Food: The Duck meat was so delicious !! Must try the Walnut Shrimp !! The fried rice  taste very good. 

Service: Server was great. Kept coming around to make sure my wine  glass was full! Especially because my group was celebrating my birthday  

Details: Cool restaurant.
You can see the chefs cooking your food through glass.
author: Steph S.

description: Have to say we were fairly disappointed. I saw a video about the place on INSIDER food, and was really excited to go try the different types of noodles. We ordered a sizzling jian bao, juicy soup dumpling, beijing cut noodle, and da dao cut noodle. I have to say all of the food are presented very well, the taste... not so much. The jian bao was very average, nothing special. The soup dumpling, huh, what a disappointment it was. The dumpling was served in individual spoons and it stuck on the spoon! Both of the noodles were below average. Not necessarily the noodle itself but how they cooked it. It seems as if they were trying to Americanize it and it went horribly wrong.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Celebrated my husband's birthday here, very casually. We just finished with Museum of Ice Cream and I needed him to have some noodles on this day. 

We sat at the bar for Happy Hour and had a great mid-afternoon meal.

Threw back a few cocktails...(fabulous), har gow , shiu mai,  beef pancake rolls, bang bang chicken wings and the beef noodle soup....yum, yum, yum, yum. Seriously, the staff was attentive, but not crowding although we sat at the bar, it still felt intimate. Thank you for a great afternoon.
author: elizabeth c.

description:
My favorite restaurant in downtown SF. Need not to say much. The food are awesome! When I have friends coming from out of states, I will definitely bring them to this restaurant and everyone seems to like it and love it. The duck is really good! The "Big knife noodles" used to be my favorite but seems like it has changed. Not too good but still delicious. Maybe they changed chefs?? Overall I love that restaurant and service is good. I will definitely recommend anyone to try it! 

After tonight dinner, I have to downgrade my rating for this restaurant. Why? 
Service was bad. Servers were having mood swing, not knowing how to organize our foods on the table and show her anger on the plates. Loud & her face is showing anger & impatience. Food quality dropped at least 25-30% from the last time I dined in. Huge disappointment but my friends were satisfied with their first try. I will drop 2 stars and hope they can surprise me when I come in next time with better service, quality of foods. It's not that expensive but you have to pride in service & quality when it comes to restaurant & service.
author: W.K P.

description:
Ran into this place on New Years Day...we were shopping inside the Westfield mall SF and the restaurant from the outside looks very nice, elegant traditional Chinese decor. I love that they have an old church bell in the middle of the bar I thought that was interesting. We got seated by a friendly hostess immediately although the place looks packed. For a party of two, they placed us in a table almost like a community table. We were seated very close to other couples which in not my preference because I like my space but the restaurant was packed on New Years Day and I am just starving to try their food. 

So far getting seated was quick, we got greeted by the bus boy and served us water right away but it took a while for the waitress to greet us and take our order. She took our drink orders, I got a hot jasmine flower tea and it was so aromatic. It took another long time before she got our food orders. Once we placed pur order it was not before long that we got our dumpling appetizer. We had the crab roe juicy dumpling and wheat potsticker and it was good but nothing beats the juicy dumpling at Din Tai Fung.

For the main course we had the salted egg roasted crab. That was pretty epic. The crab meat was sweet and tender but the flavor of the little bits of fried batter you can't stop picking and savor in your mouth. Definitely mouth watering stuff in this kitchen!
author: Erzi E.

description: Love Love Love. I'm super surprised this place only has 3 1/2 stars. Every time we're in town we go shopping and have lunch here. It has never ever disappointed. Great food great service. The noodles are to die for. We have something different every time we come and everything has been great.
author: Rebecca E.

description: Exceptional food and service was first class. The staff was friendly and attentive. Had the "Chairman Mao's Chicken" which I highly recommend if you enjoy a spicy dish that is both flavorful and exquisite
author: Hector P.

description:
What's not to love? It's got great ambience, and the drinks are fantastic. Love their selection of teas, although they don't always have all their listed options available. 

The food is outstanding! I'm vegetarian, and found tons of great options. I especially love the crispy organic tofu and the lava bao! 

It's a fairly kid friendly place, so all in all, it's a very nice place to stop for a relaxing meal when you're in the midst of shopping.
author: Swati R.

description:
I'm bummed to update this review because I had such an incredible meal on my first visit but the service, food, and changes in the menu no longer speak to my original 5-star review.

I thought I loved M.Y. China. I'd rave about the crab feast that 3 friends and I got with the scissor cut noodles, numerous sides, and affordable but delicious wine bottles. 

My visit yesterday, granted we didn't do a shared crab dinner, was so disappointing. My dining partner and I ordered the pickle plate as an appetizer when our server first came to the table, along with their Mango Mule beverage - a non-alcoholic drink that sounded fresh and delicious but tasted like a too tart blend of a dash of ginger ale and a powdered drink mix packet. For $5, it was not something I would recommend or order again

We sat for a bit and then ordered the crispy tofu app, a side of brown rice, and the "spicy" portobello mushroom dish from the vegetarian section. We were bummed that the only vegetarian noodle dish they have is a soup and they aren't able to make any of their other noodle dishes into a vegetarian version.

We were waiting and waiting and waiting and saw tables around us get their food- tables that came in after we'd already ordered get their food. Unfortunately, it was difficult to flag down a server, though there were so many running around a restaurant that was a third empty. A part of me thinks they were short staffed that day, which happens, of course, but it felt like our table in particular was the 'dropped ball'.

After a roughly 20-minute wait, our entree comes out. I ask about the pickles that we'd ordered well before everything else with our drinks. The food runner seemed confused but still said it was coming... after 20 minutes? after the entree? after the other hot appetizer that also hasn't come out? Why does a small, cold plate take longer than everything else?

He ends up taking the entree back with him, so now we're back to having no food. A few more minutes pass, we're confused, were nervous that now they're just going to scrape together the pickle plate and then come back and serve us a cold entree. 

We flag down someone to ask them to just cancel the pickle plate but it seems like he doesn't understand. He sends our server over who now drops off our hot appetizer, the crispy tofu. I ask him to cancel the pickles since they hadn't come and explain about the weird appearance of our entree and then disappearance of it and the server's response was, 'oh you wanted the pickles as an appetizer?" in an actually pretty snide can't-admit-that-he's-wrong way. As if the blame is on me, the customer, to tell the server that the cold dish listed under their "small plates" menu that we ordered with our drinks before any food, that I want it to come before our entrees. 

Why would anyone order a dish first, with their drinks, and expect it to come out after their dinner? As if the cold pickle plate is ordered as a dessert. No. That never happens. You forgot it- someone forgot it. And instead of just admitting it after 25 minutes, or comping the $6 dish, which would have been appropriate, you tried to place the blame on your table and then just say, 'Ok, I'll hold the order so it doesn't get made'. Like, DUDE, it's been 25 minutes. No need to press, 'hold', it's not f*cking coming and I'm not an idiot. At least have enough sense to throw the kitchen under the bus for your mistake and not your customer. 

So we never got the pickles, nor did we get an apology for how they were forgotten. We eventually got our crispy tofu and that was fine. Not stellar and the dipping sauce was super pedestrian. I liked the potpourri of jalapeno bits and spicy stuff on the plate, but for the price this is a completely skippable dish. 

Our entree, surprise surprise, came back out shorty after. Lukewarm with the rice being straight up cold. The portion is small, the dish labeled as spicy wasn't spicy in the least, and the texture of the portobellos wasn't appetizing at all. So tough and squeaky and you felt like you were somehow chewing gristle and not mushrooms. The dish was our server's recommendation and I can't second that opinion. It was ok, but not great and if that's the best veg dish they have... well, maybe just don't have vegetarian dishes because its clearly not something you care about. 

I'm bummed that M.Y. China doesn't offer the selection or service it once did and that my dinner on Valentine's Day (though not for Valentine's Day) was such a sad experience. I think if you eat meat then you may have a perfectly fine experience here, though I can't speak to those dishes which make up most of the menu. I want to hope that the crab dinners are just as good as I remember but I can't see myself coming back after this experience. We didn't spend a lot of money here, but we did spend some and that's cash I could've used elsewhere for better selection, quality, and service.
author: Candice G.

description: Super food! We had 3 plates that where totally different that anything I had taste before for Chinese food. They where amazing
author: Maru M.

description: In the 1990's cooking shows could be called "The World According to Martin Yan!"  Indeed Yan Can Cook was a phrase that resonated with anyone who admired Chinese cooking, i.e. the preparation!  I visited one of his suburban outposts along the Bart Line years ago that was  a huge disappointment.  M.Y. China has the feel of a Las Vegas Venetian restaurant with the New World Western charm of the City by the Bay.  I only had the opportunity to try some of their won ton soup, and har gaos for an appetizer.  I was pleasantly surprised by the simplicity of the won ton soup with fresh bok chop, and a home cooked broth.  Although I typically hate restaurants in malls, M.Y. China seems to be a wonderful little gem.  Now all I need to return is the hope of meeting M.Yl - Martin Yan himself!
author: Thomas W.

description: Great place. Went here twice in two days. Definite favourite dish is the beef noodle soup. One of the best I've had so far. Also had both the spicy and bang bang chicken wings which were really good with my favourite being the spicy. Good service and atmosphere otherwise. Recommended.
author: Dan N.

description: This was a dismal disappointing place. A bit of marketing hype... We order several dishes and each one stuck out on not being fresh, greasy, limited in appeal and/or cold.  Prices way too high and service not very good.  Given all the other wonderful Asian cuisine places in SF, why go there?  I guess Yan can't cook!
author: Randy W.

description:
I brought my wife of 48 years here for her birthday and she invited two senior girl friends and our house guest who is a graduate of the Le Cordon Bleu College of Culinary Arts.  My wife and I have been here before and were impressed enough to want to share it with friends.

Being in a mall for some might be a turn off, but for us the location has been ideal.   Coming from the East Bay it is remarkably accessible by BART.  The location can be construed to be a Chinese touristy place and be off putting to us Asian American locals.  So our first timers were in for a pleasant surprise.   

We were able to come early before our reservation time to have happy hour in the bar and be able to sample the appetizers.  My favorite was the chicken feet with black bean sauce.  Of course, it grossed everyone else out; so I did not have to share!

Our Chinese-Ecuadoran waiter for dinner was excellent by all measures. The 91 year old friend thought he was cute and even wanted a picture with him. The table was in a perfect location on the outer edge of the front of the dining room, adjacent to the rotunda where it was quiet enough for us seniors to hear each other speak at a conversational tone without straining.  That is a real plus.  Do you "hear" me?  

Afterwards the guests raved about the dining experience and our chef friend said, "I can see now why you like M.Y. China!"   The 91 year old friend called the next day to thank us again for the good time and for bringing her to M.Y. China.  I told her whenever she wanted to return to "OUR China"  (spelling error is intentional) I would take her!
author: Art H.

description:
The food is more of a 3 star rating, but the mall location, cramped space, lack of ambiance, and poor service resulted in a one star review. 
The starters were pushed out quickly, and the spring rolls were crispy and hot. The MuShu pork was delicately flavored and did not need the usual plum sauce and cornstarch sauce commonly offered by others. Long delay for the entrees. Also my dish was brought out first, followed by the entree 20m later. The noodle dish was I suppose "authentic" as it tasted terrible. Won't be back. OK for a quick bite while shopping but not as a flagship Resto on a culinary trip the SF
Won't be back.
author: Dino D.

description: Food was great but im not too happy about these random charges that showed up on my bill. Also we were served beers that expired last year. Would you please explain what the hell a SF employer charge is? And why arent you up front about it? Shady business thats for sure
author: Charles B.

description: This is my new favorite Chinese restaurant. I love their beef roll and Peking duck. It can get quite busy sometimes, best to book a table before coming to avoid waiting.
author: Mai V.

description: Pretty good!  Shrimp with walnuts was super tasty.  Veggies also cooked nicely.  The ambiance in a mall leaves much to be desired, but the place was busy so I opted to give it a shot. Overall very good.  Service was fine too.
author: Melissa R.

description:
2/2017

What a pleasure to dine at a restaurant whose service is as stellar as the food. 

M.Y. China is chef Martin Yan's concept restaurant and whose classic Chinese recipes have a modern twist. 

It felt especially right to dine here on the eve of Lunar New Year. 

Infused with flavor with lots of ginger, daikon radish, salty-savory black bean paste and flavorful meats wok-tossed to perfection, we enjoyed favorites and new dishes: Shanghai soup dumplings (XLB): minced pork in spicy bean paste, knife cut Beijing noodles with refreshing and crunchy julienned cucumber, bean sprouts and carrots; pork belly sliders.

Tea-infused pork belly sliders on mu shu pancakes with spicy sauce, daikon radish and cilantro were a miss: the pork was overcooked and stringy and lacked the creamy unctuousness of pork belly. 

The manager came over to apologize and asked if we wanted a replacement dish or if they could remove it from our bill, especially generous since my food incinerator son had already devoured one. 

Even kinder was the manager gifting us the delicious sugar egg puffs we ordered. They overheard my son saying his Lego store shopping trip and M.Y. China dinner was to celebrate placing 5th in the school spelling bee and they made a little fuss over him that made him feel very special.

I requested seating at the bar overlooking the noodle station. We were there too early to see the dynamic noodle tossing so we'll have to return for that. 

Great service, delicious food in an elegant yet casual dining room just off the gorgeous dome.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
A group of friends and I came here for Grandma Wu's Chinese New Year Dinner.

We all started with cocktails, so I had the East Meets West. It was a tasty drink, but a tad on the weaker side. 

We had the following courses:

Good Luck Soup - our least favorite course. I found the soup to be on the bland side, but I assume as a starter it was probably meant to be this way. 

Fortune Platter- a medley of goodies! Everything on the platter was delicious, but my favorite was the squid! Really flavorful and cooked perfectly. 

Ocean Treasure - these fried oysters were HUGE! Everyone loved them!

Golden Lobster - FAVORITE COURSE! The seasoning and batter of the lobster was drool worthy. Definitely recommend this dish!

Perfect Catch - good steamed fish, it went well after having all the fried courses before this. So it was a nice light dish. Loved the sauce that came with it. 

Happy Opportunity - described as a fried chicken, but this is unique since it wasn't battered. It looked like it was just roasted, but the skin was light and crispy while the meat itself was incredibly juicy. It came with sticky rice that paired with it nicely. 

Long Life - these noodles looked bland, but they were super flavorful! I was pleasantly surprised! Everyone enjoyed this dish a lot as well!

Child's Delight - cool presentation with the spun candy on top! The dessert itself was just okay. It was simple. 


Thanks M.Y China for hosting us! It was a great dinner!
author: Noelle H.

description:
M.Y. China is pretty uppity, but still has some quality food. You'll definitely end up spending a lot of money here because it's on the pricier end. I come here when i want noodles and I'm at Westfield mall in down town SF.

Service is fast. Ambiance is sophisticated and classy.

I really like any of their noodles and noodle soups. 

I've ordered the
Dan Dan noodles
Wild boar noodle soup
author: Sean W.

description: Food is solid but a little generic. Great happy hour if still available. Been a while since I have been there but last time Martin Yan himself showed up- shook everyone's hand at the bar, and prepared noodles in a great fun presentation!! The man is charismatic.
author: Doug G.

description: The ambiance of this place is great but that's where it ends. They had a section of their menu called small eats. They have redefined the meaning of small and eats. Whatever you do DO NOT ORDER THE RIBLETS. They are small, are regularly sized, sharp pieces of ribs with little to no meat doused sauce. They are downright dangerous to eat. So bad that we sent them back and exchange them for the lettuce wraps, which were quite good. The tacos were also quite good. The Wonton Soup, usually my measure of Chinese food, was terrible. Although the wontons were tasty, there were only a few scallion slivers floating in the broth, nothing else... No other vegetables. Overall we found the food to be very salty. The straw that broke the camel's back was them circling the suggested tip rate on the bill. Frankly, other than my husband, I don't like anyone telling me or suggesting to me how much I should tip. I understand the need to put suggested tips on bills... It helps make the calculation easy. But to Circle it... No thank you. We will not be coming back here... Ever.
author: Sue F.

description:
I was here a while ago, years really, and had a good general recollection of it, but this time they really shined. We had a group of 6 of us, and they sat us at a very nice corner table where we could enjoy an animated family birthday visit without being disruptive. This was my request, and they were happy to oblige.

M.Y. China is in the Westfield Mall, a fairly close location to both the Orpheum, and Golden Gate Theaters, where we are season subscribers, so knowing a good place in the Market Street corridor is a good thing! (it is especially difficult to find a good place downtown that is open on Sunday)

I'll start by saying that we ordered a lot of different dishes, and there was not a single miss in the whole bunch! We really like that they adjusted the number of pieces (dumplings, ribs, etc) to fit the number of people at the table. We had a variety of dishes, beef, tofu, BBQ pork, sea bass, veggies, on and on...everything was delicious, rich, yet light and fresh. 

The staff was friendly and efficient, and in no hurry to turn the table. We stayed a reasonable hour and a half and never felt rushed, or forgotten. They were careful to make sure we got to the theater, unrushed. 

The six of us ate well, left satiated, had a total of eight cocktails, and our bill was a very fair $315.oo plus, tip (Total $372, that's only $62 each, with cocktails and tip, for fine dining!) 
We all felt it was a very good value. It would even be a good place to stop for a nosh (how do you say "nosh" in Mandarin?... oh, Dim Sum, I bet) or a cocktail, and they have a few nice selections for dessert. M.Y. China is an oasis from the shopping havoc at the mall or the starkly real world outside.
author: James G.

description: Service was horrible. The waiter had no personality. He had an attitude the entire time. The food was okay. I've had better. The wontons sucked. The sweet and sour soup was the only thing that was good. I work in the area and won't be coming back. None of the people who work here have personality. It's what you expect from mall food.
author: Sean V.

description: I use to work at a Chinese restaurant.  I also use to love to go to Chinatown in nyc as a kid. And since moving to San Francisco I've tried many of the great Chinese restaurants in the city.  The service here at MY China was very good. The atmosphere is nice.  The food is just not good. We ordered noodles with pork.  There was just a few pieces of pork in it.  We had pork dumplings and they had no flavor and were filled with water. Sorry to say it but don't go.  There are so many great restaurants in San Francisco.  Pick another.
author: Bob M.

description: We love their food! Restaurant is inside the Westfield mall and right in front of the common space where kids building blocks are available to kids, great location!
author: Sunny S.

description:
Updating my review:

Came back for round 2, the service was on point this time. Came on a Friday night this time (busy night). Our service was amazing she was really sweet, had great recommendations, was very attentive to our table and to all her tables, and came by enough times. She was definitely on top of her waitress game. Thank you to Janica for providing amazing service and making our experience at MY China great!
author: Abby C.

description:
If you're shopping in the mall or watching a movie and don't want to walk too far for lunch/dinner (FYI, everything in the mall's lower food court is subpar), if you're entertaining business guests in the area, if you're looking for a nice dining atmosphere, and/or if you're looking for the best Chinese restaurant in this area, I'd recommend M.Y. China. 

I discovered this restaurant in early 2015 and have come here on a regular basis since then. My team at my old job used to come here often for celebrations, I've been here with friends, and I've also taken my boss and colleague here when they're visiting from Germany (they both loved it). 

I've tried a lot of things on the menu, but I always go back to the same favorite things: mu shu pork tacos, wild boar scissor cut noodles, and duck egg yolk crab (the first time I ordered this, Martin Yan came out and greeted me). Some other great items: salt & pepper chicken wings (which are spicy), bang bang chicken wings, and calamari. The wagu beef and the cream puffs for dessert are both excellent. Their menu is pretty extensive, so lots to try. 

I like this place for their decor / atmosphere, as well. It's a nice and appropriate place for business lunches/dinners. Or, if you just want a nice place to eat dinner after you shop.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Bloody expensive!

But really very nice food.

My wife had her favorite Peking Duck and pronounced it to be excellent with very crispy skin. I ordered wok fried seafood and salt and pepper calamari. We shared spicy seafood dumplings. The food was sensational.

So, why only three stars? Well, this place charged us $93 for the above with just one glass of wine for my wife and a soft drink for me. I don't mind that in itself, but this bill included a tax of 5% because, apparently, the restaurant owners, are too lousy to provide benefits to their staff. Fair enough if you are a subsistence level eatery...but this is a top end restaurant.

And that's a rip-off.

And no single place will ever rip me off more than once.
author: David F.

description: My idea to come here cause we had to wait for 1hours for movies. We come here at 8:45 and surprise , they still take us. The service is not thing to complain, they very nice. We tried the pecking duck with some buns. The skin of duck is crispy and taste so good( not like the other place I tries before ). We will come back to try dim sum here and hopefully, I can see my fav chefs Martin Yan .
author: Amelia D.

description: I don't go to San Francisco that often. However, whenever I find myself in town, I must make it a point to go and enjoy M.Y. China's outstanding food. Their BBQ pork appetizer is a must. Their deep fried tofu is outstanding. Also, their scallop fried rice and their seafood noodles. I have never been disappointed with any of the items I have ordered. Executive Chef Tony is great. Also, who does not enjoy Chef Martin Yan's cooking shows? I grew up watching him and he is an outstanding teacher. Can you guys please open another restaurant in the LA area? In the meantime, I will continue to enjoy M.Y. China when in San Francisco!
author: Jose J.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars!

I remember when i first bookmarked this place, Yelp gave me a notice that this place received very abysmal health scores from the city. I'm glad that as of 11/2016, i can say that this has been rectified.

The first time I ate here was the day after I arrived home from a vacation which included a trip to Hong Kong. I was spoiled silly with amazing, high quality Chinese food, and I wasn't ready to give that all up, so I came here with a friend.

Dishes I've tried:

- Hong Kong Crispy Noodles with XO Sauce (great sauce and tasty dish overall, but for the price, i was hoping for a bit more than prepackaged noodles)

- Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles (the noodles were thick and chewy, but nothing more spectacular than what you'd get at a less fancy hand pulled noodle place)

- Shui Mai (Some of the best Shui Mai I've ever had outside of Hong Kong

- Hargow (Some of the best Hargow I've had. The dipping sauce of soy sauce, chili, and vinegar is fantastic)

- Farmer's Dumplings (Pretty good, nothing special)

- Crispy Organic Tofu (nice seasoning and perfect texture)

- Lucky Buddha Beer

- Nice View Cocktail (aromatic and refreshing)

- Thyme and Again Cocktail (maybe my favorite cocktail - great use of thyme and egg whites)

I've been here 3 times now. I enjoy ordered from the Happy Hour menu, with dishes from the regular menu for accompaniment.  

TL:DR / Pro-Tip: Peking Duck is not presented in the traditional way and it served with thick steam buns instead of thin wrappers.
author: David D.

description:
Upscale Panda Express. Pretty furnishings, somewhat attentive waitstaff, but the food Is priced about 3x their equivalents at Panda Express... and honestly, Panda Express tastes better overall. 

Hot and sour soup was pretty good, $6 gets you a decent small bowl. $10 Roast pork was extremely dry and very tough, a little piece sliced and spread sideways then doused with sugar sauce. $2 "Jasmine" white rice was subpar compared to Panda, looked like bottom of the cooker,
All clumped together and fairly tasteless. And of course they tack on the phony "SF Mandate" BS and don't mention it beforehand as the law requires. 

$25 spent here makes you wish you'd just gone to the Panda Express in the basement, unless you just want to feel like a "more important" person. 

Perhaps Yan Can Cook, but as for his restaurant.... not so much. Panda Express or any random on Stockton or Grant will do you so much better for so much less. But if wood interiors turn you on, the decorations here are real pretty.
author: T J.

description:
MY China is a nice spot for dinner inside Westfield.

On this occasion, we had:
* Xiao long bao (pork) [3] -- it's not really authentic when compared with DTF, but it's quite tasty.
* Spicy chicken wings [3] -- normally, I love the spicy chicken wings, but today, they felt off.  Somehow more like supermarket wings.  But, have had them ~3 times before where they were phenomenal with the spices being unique and tasty!
* Da dao big knife Fish noodles [5] -- this is one of my go to dishes here.  Lots of seafood and mushrooms and a pit of pea shoots.  I heart this dish!
* Egg yolk crab [4] -- Tasty, well executed and the crab was a nice, big size!
* Pea shoots [4]-- well executed. Like a less metallic spinach if you've never had this before.
* Wok seared seafood [4] -- I was initially unimpressed by this when I just had the seafood part.  But, the presentation is really nice.  It comes with this fried noodle / nest looking thing.  It's quite tasty and provides a nice crunch / texture when we broke up some of this and had it with the seafood & gravy!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
One word to describe the day after Christmas in downtown SF, chaos.  One word to describe closed local coffee shops, sadness.  One word to describe closed restaurants in FiDi, hangry.  Since the malls were open, my friend suggested mall food which lead us to M.Y. China.  At first I was like, bleh mall food?  But as we were waiting in line, the servers kept bringing out dishes that looked appetizing.  We waited maybe about 10min before being seated at the bar.  Our server, whom resembled Kev Jumba (youtube star), was super friendly.

Pan Fried Pork Bao - Nice crispy bottom, right amount of filling. These are bigger than normal; I guess sometimes bigger is better
Fried Rice - Can't really mess up on fried rice.  Its simple and it reminds me of my childhood, love it
Salt & Pepper Calamari - perfectly cooked, not too greasy.  They forgot to mention it has a kick to it
Buddha Beer - light

Food and service are equally great.  Our server was kind enough to wash the Buddha bottle for me so that I can take home.
author: Linda N.

description:
All I can say about this place is YUMMM. There were so many different dishes that we wanted to try...so we ordered A LOT. 

We started with:
Soup dumplings (XLB) 
Chinese greens
Pickled radish and cucumber
Abalone
Squid ink pasta with vegetables (SO delicious) 
BBQ pork
Some tofu dish (probably could have gone without this)
Chamomile tea

The portions weren't too big, so the two of us were able to get through most of everything. Good portions, decently priced, amazing flavors and taste, and great service. 

Will definitely be coming back!
author: Jane S.

description: tried to have dinner here. There was no one at the host desk. We waited for 10 mins and in that 10 mins, 8 employees walked by us and just stared. Did not acknowledge us or tried to find the host to seat us. After being ignored like that, we left and went next door to tap 415 where we were immediately greeted and served with a smile. For a fancy Chinese place charging fancy prices, you would think you'd get better service. Anyways was really looking forward to eat there but will not be handing over my hard earned money to a place where I am invisible. No thanks, you get better service downstairs at Panda Express!
author: Kat L.

description:
My Chinese friend told me that this place had very authentic Chinese food (even though a little pricey). Well we had an amazing time here, the service was great, the food was tasty. The only thing I wasn't a big fan of, was the desert, hence -1 star. We had the lychee pana cotta, I was pleased to see they put actually real lychees at the bottom however the shaved ice cream just made the whole desert icy. 
In terms of plates we had the honey walnut glazed shrimps with Wasabi and the seafood noodles. The shrimps were very tasty, my fiancé didn't really like the Wasabi taste, I loved it. The noodles were on the other hand a big win! 
We will come back here.
On a side note, restrooms were not so clean which is a bummer for a nice looking restaurant were quality and hygiene seem to be a strong focus.
author: Rachida I.

description:
Let the record show that I'm Chinese...

Party of 5 for lunch today. We had - which I'll rate inline:
xiao long bao - 4*
sichuan green beans - 4*
dan dan noodles - 3*
knife cut noodles - 4*
green onion pancake -3*
ma po tofu - 5*
wok sear beef - 5*

Overall, I thought the food was good. It was slightly more expensive but no different than Yank Sing.  Work was paying, so I didn't care about cost. 

You could tell ingredients were high quality than average. The flavors more delicate and thoughtful than over powering. Sometimes after a big chinese meal, I feel over powered by certain flavors or ingredients.  I didn't feel that way after this meal.  I felt like it was more balanced. Each dish hit different notes. It was a bit of an awakening in Chinese food.

The Ma Po Tofu was a thinner sauce, but I thought it really pushed new boundaries in flavor. I really liked it, but it's a different style all together. Wok seared beef reminded me of 'Shaking Beef' at Slanted Door. It was very good. Xiao long bao (XLB) was delicate, consistent in size, flavor, and broth. I enjoyed it but hard to compare against Shanghai Dumpling King.

Noodles were a bit disappointing.  Maybe I wanted more rustic flavor but I thought the noodles were average. Dan dan mein was cold. Presentation was good, but I wanted stronger flavors, thicker gravy. This was thin and light. I wanted more chewiness. 

I'd go back... it helps if you're not paying but I felt much better afterward than many Chinese meals.
author: suckafree c.

description: GREAT vegetarian (Vegan) food. They even have a small separate menu for vegetarians. My favorites are the crispy organic tofu, tempeh sliders, and if you order a cocktail, the best one is Red Moon. Just ask for them to make it sweeter by adding more blackberry syrup (unless you don't like sweet drinks).
author: John D.

description:
I was blown away with how nice and prices are easy on the wallet. 
Great food and nice people 
Recommend highly
author: Brett H.

description: Surprisingly good Chinese food - considering this is in a mall! I've visited this restaurant many times and always had a great meal. The place can get extremely crowded during holidays/big shopping days, so I now avoid it during those times, especially because I like to sit inside the restaurant (vs in the mall area, which is bright and not very pleasant). The wasabi shrimp is delicious, the Peking duck is good, and all the vegetable dishes have been a hit.
author: Mona B.

description:
I've been wanting to try this restaurant for a while since my dad used to watch Yan Can Cook back in the day. Let me just say that for a restaurant in a mall, this is pretty legit Chinese food. I'm Chinese and rarely go out for Chinese food, but I would definitely come back after I'm hungry from shopping.

Food:
-Walnut Shrimp: one of my favorite Chinese dishes! There's a slight twist from the traditional dish since I tasted wasabi in it. Still good though, just interesting.

-Grandma's Gai Lan: delicious green veggie. Would reorder.

-Beef on arugula: very tasty and flavorful

Dessert: 

-Green tea tiramisu: one of the BEST desserts I've ever had in my life. My favorite food here, and the best way to end a meal

Service was great and attentive.
author: Corinna T.

description:
We had the spicy chicken wings for an appetizer. True to their name, they were spicy, but not insanely so. They're now my second favorite chicken wings in SF (the first being Angel Wings at Marnee Thai).

For our entree, we shared the pork scissor cut noodles, wagyu beef medallions, and the forbidden rice. All were tasty, especially the sauce for the noodles. We requested medium for the medallions, but got them closer to rare, unfortunately.

For dessert, we had the matcha tiramisu. It was definitely matcha, but much more like a pudding (with just a single, thin layer of ladyfingers at the bottom), than a cake. It also had a strange aftertaste, almost like you might expect an air freshener to taste. Perhaps there were some flower petal notes? Anyway, it was odd. Perhaps doing it much more in the form factor of a traditional tiramisu would be better.

We'd eat there again.
author: Paul L.

description:
We were there entire family on advice.
The first impression was, that is not real restaurant. It looks like a Bistro or, rather, Sweet Tomatoes. No tablecloth, old plates and spoons, crap knives, etc.
Inasmuch as we had a special day, we wanted to try there the Peking duck. We were already eaten Peking duck before in another places in USA. And here we were very very disappointed. It was the worst Peking duck I had ever tried! (for a whole duck we had just a little sauce, and other greens) . Also we tried soup. It contained too much salt in. Moreover, a lot of dough and a little bit pork or shrimp filling was in  Chinese style ravioli.
After dinner we were not hungry, but sorrowful that spent time here. 
So, we'll never go there again.
author: Nika S.

description:
This place has a different vibe than the dim sum places that I've been to. It's feels more like a fine dining Chinese restaurant. Overall, the food tastes good, but the portion sizes are really small and at high cost, so it's not really worth it to me. 

There are lots of seating at the restaurant and the place seems to always be packed with people. Some of the tables are quite close to one another, so movement can be a tiny bit difficult. We ordered several dishes to share among us. 

Honey glazed walnut shrimp - there is wasabi flavoring on the shrimp, an unconventional addition. I'm not a big fan of wasabi flavor, so I didn't like it very much. 

Lava custard buns - the custard inside was hot and was like a thick liquid just like lava. Careful about burning your tongue. It tasted pretty good. 

Beijing knife cut noodles - the noodles are super good. There's good flavor and the noodles are a bit chewy.

Fried chicken wings - not bad. Six wings on a plate.
author: Julia K.

description:
This restaurant is located on the 4th floor of the Westfield Mall. I saw this restaurant on the Food Network channel. I was hoping to witness the chef making the hand pulled noodles, but unfortunately was not privileged to see it. We had 6 people in our party and ordered 6 dishes and shared Family-style.

I'm Chinese and I love noodles. It was perfect timing as I was traveling to SF  for the Half Marathon. I could carb up...a perfect win. I loved the Vegetarian Longevity Noodle Soup and the Hong Kong Style Crispy Noodles (perfect amount of spiciness for my timid taste buds and beautifully presented in a bird nest basket). The Scissor Cut Noodles with Wild Boar was okay. The boar was very tender though I think it's just pork...that's what it tasted like to me. The noodles were thicker and had a more doughy texture that I do not prefer. The Venison Chow Fun was okay. I didn't like the venison (my 6 year old loved it and picked all the meat) and the rice noodles tasted like other rice noodles I've had. The Chairman Mao's Chicken had a great texture. We had the sauce on the side as my kids vary in spice preference. 

The service was great for us. We were waited on quickly and the food came out in a very timely manner. Waitresses were polite and bussed our tables throughout our meal, creating more space.

Would I come back? Not sure...it is a bit on the pricy side when you think of Chinese food. The portions are small compared to Monterey Park, CA. You are definitely paying for the ambiance.
author: Jenny K.

description:
We went here on Wednesday lunch around 1pm-2pm after shopping at Westfield mall. I had great experience. Drinks were delicious. Octopus was yum yum. 
Of course, I would recommend this place. Interior is very well done. Might be a bit packed place but it's busy district in SF. Please, enjoy
author: Svetlana K.

description: Love this place! Everything on menu is great!! Boar scissor cut noodles are a must!! Went in once and met Martin Yan - very friendly and suggested we try one new dish every time we come in (which is often). Can't go wrong!!
author: Abbie A.

description:
Middle of the road.  Prices way to high for what you get here.  I probably won't be going back. Had the Mu Shu tacos, the seafood dumplings and seafood noodle dish. 
Tacos:  Nothing special. Standard Mu Shu.  To much liquid. They were leaking everywhere
Dumplings: I enjoyed these.  Well cooked good flavors.  
Seafood noodle:  This is where it really started falling apart.  These noodles where so horribly over cooked..The seafood tasted fresh. But softness of these noodles just ruined the whole dish. I was very disappointed considering this place is all about their fresh noodles.  They promote them all over the place inside.  
3 Stars.  This place is all show. It looks fancy and nice but it's really just a show.
author: M B.

description:
Oh my, that was NOT good. Bland food, processed mcnuggests, high prices.

The "wild boar" lettuce cups were made with some non-descriptive meat product, chewy and gelatinous.

We requested to have our second dish served mild,  which apparently meant no sauce, no flavor.

I don't recommend this spot, even if you are in a rush ahead of a movie.

The one bright spot was the service. They were prompt and courteous.
author: Alisa W.

description:
Best mall food ever ever ever! We love coming here after a movie, after a day of shopping, or even ordering delivery when we are lazy and hungry.

The staff is always pretty friendly, the space is quite nice, and the menu selection is expansive. We love the pot stickers, the duck, and whatever else they recommend...you can never go wrong!

Haven't had MY China in some time, so it's starting to seem like it's about time!
author: Meaghan H.

description: Great for groups. Always a solid meal. Noodles are fresh and delicious. Share plates!  Oh, and they can make dishes vegetarian if needed. Great service always, too.
author: Pauline L.

description:
My favorite spot to get beef noodle soup in SF - and they don't skimp on the beef.

Yes, the portions are generally smaller than in most Chinese food joints, but what can I say? They're delicious and convenient with good ambiance. 

Pricing-wise, --- you know not all Chinese food is cheap right? Just as there are dollar burgers and $25 burgers, there's going to be some range when it comes to something as broad as Chinese cuisine.
author: Jay K.

description:
TL;DR Slightly overpriced Chinese food on the 5th floor of Westfield, but extensive seating, good food, great service! Look at the photos of food before you order. 

We came on a Monday night and there was a decent amount of people there. We ordered 4 dishes: beef noodle soup ($16), wok stir-fried seafood ($23), mapo tofu ($8), and a half order of Peking duck ($24). 

Beef noodle soup was pricey but there was a lot of meat that was cooked well and really tender. The noodles were really smooth so they didn't really absorb the broth flavor but now I'm just being nitpicky haha. I super regret getting the stir-fried seafood. It was just cooked calamari, scallops, shrimp, and a ton of celery for the same price as Peking duck :( Mapo tofu is my boyfriend's comfort food so we ordered it. It was a "side" portion but it did taste good and pretty classic. 

Peking duck! The star of the meal came with 8 pieces of skin, lots of duck meat underneath, 6 delicious and fluffy steamed buns, hoisin sauce, green onions and cucumbers. It was a very generous portion for each bun and the skins were roasted to perfection. I would come back just for the duck because the portion and price was amazing. 

Some dishes were pricey for what it was but the Peking duck for the price is pretty awesome :) I would come again if I pre-gamed my menu :D
author: Barbara C.

description: Food is OK but it is a little bit pricey - it's a nice place ambience wise and close to the cinema. They have a happy hour but it finishes a little bit early. Would say this is amazing food but pricey but I would definitely come back
author: Bert K.

description:
As a vegetarian I'm happy with all the choices available here.  They're always accommodating with my vegetarian alterations as well. 

In my experience, the food is always fresh. Services are always attentive (polite w an Asian flare).  Definitely use Yelp or Opendoor to make reservation and be there on time. I'm proud to have a good quality Chinese restaurant- in terms of food, design, and operation - that's accessible to many. 

They frequently have festivities that celebrates both Chinese and local culinary culture like crab fest, Chinese New Year specials etc.  I love the open space that spills into the iconic dome atrium.  This is the quintessential San Francisco experience. 

I wholly disagree that Chinese food should be "cheap" if you understand the level of thoughts went into MY China's whole operation. Contrary I feel their price is fair and I'm happy to continue being a regular patron.
author: D M.

description:
Pretty reliable, albeit pricy, Chinese restaurant conveniently located in the Westfield Mall. My dishes are on the expensive side for Chinese food, but the ingredients are definitely more high quality than what you would find at your typical hole in the wall. Martin Yan, the restaurant owner, has some pretty god street cred in the Bay Area. He does a great job with the decor and menu, but the service and taste sometimes offset the overall dining experience. Reservations are not required. 

[Dinner]
My favorite from the menu is the noodle dishes, the Beef Noodle Soup and Scissor Cut Noodle. You can sometimes see the chef hand-pulling the noodles in the open kitchen, so it's great to see the authenticity behind what you're paying for. The XLB Soup Dumplings are really overpriced for what you get. I really don't like that it's served on cucumber on its red spoon when steamed - it takes away from the overall flavor profile of the soup dumpling. The peking duck is decent. Nothing too special about the dish, but it seems to be a favorite with diners. The one time I ordered hot and sour soup, it came out lukewarm.

[Drinks]
They charge you a lot for tea, and the other beverages. Overpriced. 

[Service / Decor]
Awesome bar decor. Also located under the Dome of the Westfield mall, so its pretty look at it if you're in Westfield late. The servers don't really know the menu well enough, and the recommendations they give aren't really highlights or "traditional" Chinese dishes. It also seems like there is a lot of turnover from the service standpoint. I come to MY China pretty frequently, but the staff seems to change a lot. 

Overall, if you're looking for a decent dining experience after shopping,I would recommend giving MY China a try. There's definitely room for improvement, but the restaurant serves dependable food and you typically don't need a reservation.
author: Alice Z.

description: Very good food and the service is good too. They also have good cocktails.  With that being said it's very popular so expect to wait for a table after walking through the mall to get to it
author: Tony C.

description:
This is a favorite of ours to come with the kids and in-laws for a lunch. 

All the food we order is always well cooked and tasty. Never had a bad meal. Cocktails are nice too and plenty of room for the kids to roam as they get antsy. 

You can't really compare this place to a hole in the wall Chinese place. Nor should you. The flavors are a lot cleaner and not as greasy.
author: Katarina M.

description: This was a frou-frou Chinese restaurant inside Westfield mall. We didn't have a bad dish but none stood out that we would recommend as a must try. The place was busy, service was awful. Our server  barely checked up on us. The bill was pricey enough that food and service should've been better than it was.
author: Trish V.

description: My China is one of my favorite place in sf. To be honest it's pretty fancy Chinese food :) it located in downtown sf the food is good,server are very nice~
author: Clancy Y.

description: Longtime San Francisco residents and we decided to give this place a try. Went clothes shopping, then had dinner at M.Y. and ordered seafood with veggies. Next morning both my wife and I woke up with, I am sorry to say upset stomachs. We eat at lots of Asian/Chinese food venues and tolerate the food really well. This place made us sick. Had nothing else to eat that night and we both are ill. Highly likely it's that place. The health department ought to check on their hygiene practices. Do not go here if your health is dear to you.
author: Alex G.

description:
Reliable Chinese food. This place should be rated much higher (some people may penalize it because that they are not used to pay higher prices for Great Chinese food). Good stop when you are shopping in the mall for an afternoon pickup. 

MUST HAVE's:
Sweet and sour soup is excellent - order it extra hot (temperature - wise) given that it's served lukewarm sometimes.  Good balance of tofu, egg drop, mushroom, etc. we always order this when we come here. 

Mu Shi pork tacos - first i was skeptical of anything that has an Americanized name like Mu Shu (bringing me back to greasy bastardized Americanized Chinese fast food from middle school days in CT). This one is a winner. Perfectly seasoned. Innovative, and I love the taco shells too - a bit like Peking Duck wraps but not quite. A prefect dish. 

SOLID:
Wild boar scissor cut noodles. Like the texture and shape of the noodles here. Pretty good. 

Order Kung bao chicken with less sugar. Well executed dish. I will never own the wok with industrial stove to cook this dish at high temperature at home. Even though I am in general more weary of Americanized dishes, the breading on the chicken is thin and crispy and the bell peppers is crunchy, with none of the gooey sauce that often covers the ingredients in a fast food Chinese restaurant. 

Peking duck - excellent. I like the buns that come with the Peking duck. The skins are just right. Ask for more scallions with this. 

If you come here for happy hour, the red wine with 7 grapes blend is decent and good value. 

SKIP:
Skip the wok-based beef - the meat is a bit too chewy.

Crispy veggie roll is solid but not exceptional. The sauce is a bit too sweet. Ask them for ginger soy sauce (that accompanies seafood dumpling) for the alternative sauce. 

Steamed vegetable dumplings - too bland

Pork riblet - the first bite tasted good but then you get a bit tired of the meat due to the sweetness and greasiness. Maybe much better with rice.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I've only been to M.Y. China for their happy hour. And they probably have one of the best happy hour specials in the area. 

As one of the best-kept secrets in the area, you can go to town at M.Y. China without breaking the budget. The happy hour menu offers cocktails for $8 and bites for $5-$7. My friend and I ordered one of each item, and our favorites were: crispy tofu, calamari, and the bao. Both the crispy tofu and calamri were seasoned to perfection and very, very flavorful.

Tip: order the sugar egg puffs dessert! It's not on the happy hour menu but it's reasonably priced and very tasty. Think: a hollow sugar donut puff with chocolate, vanilla, and raspberry dip!
author: John L.

description:
Yan Can cook signature spot!  That's how I always reference this place since it is affiliated by him in some sort of way. 

I like their non-alchy drinks and I'm sure their cocktails are made well too. 

Xiao long baos are a must get!  It's juicy and great. 

Their entrees are made presentable and clean. 

I adored their fluffy egg puffs with chocolate and raspberry fondue!  We ordered a side of ice cream and all that scrumptiousness was deliciously amazing!

Service and ambiance was up to par as it should be of some standard in Westfield mall.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Kind of had an interesting first time experience here and I would hope that my experience was an anomaly. 

Essentially, came here for happy hour with friends and requested  seats for 3 people and got seated at a community table which is fine. We were waiting for our third person to show up shortly when the people next to us at the community table grabbed our third place setting for our friend who was on their way. Then, from there one of the servers took away the chair that meant for our third person who arrived 5 minutes later and pretty much had to stand until a chair became available. It took a while for the servers to even acknowledge us or even take our order despite having all of our menus closed and making eye contact with servers. The only saving grace with our service was that the host was nice enough to realize and apologize for the server who took our chair and for our third person who had to stand.

Aside from that, their happy hour menu was great and the prices are great. We got the Salt and Pepper Calamari, Har Gow, and Shui Mai. For drinks we ordered the City View and Buddha Breeze.

I'm not entirely sure if I'd come back again given the service.
author: Ashley V.

description: I had the spicy dim sum and it was fantastic! I also had the Dan Duk fish noodles, again great. The flavor was fresh and the pop of jalapeño was tasty. Try the tea, also great.
author: Regina N.

description: More of a 3.5.  This is a large, bright, corporate-y restaurant in the mall that makes you feel as though you're not in SF.  Everything we had was pretty good but not necessarily memorable - vinegar pork ribs, pork belly sliders, baby bok choy, scissor cut noodles, and the egg custard lava bao.  Given the lack of decent Chinese places in Soma, I think we'll definitely be back.
author: Simon L.

description: I know this is going to be a really overdue review but here it is anyway. My friend and I ended up coming here for Restaurant Week. We were disappointed to find out that this restaurant was not participating on the day that we came. Note: Be sure to call the restaurant to see if they are participating that week or the day that you are going to be there. We ended up just ordering 2 appetizer dishes. Lets just say, these two dishes didn't make us disappointed anymore. We ended up getting the shandong beef rolls and bang bang chicken wings. For the price they were both cost around $9 and they tasted sooo delicious! I definitely need to come back to this place.
author: Michelle R.

description: This is the place I always hang out with my friends and colleagues. Furthermore, the salt and pepper chicken wings are so good, even thought it is a little pricey.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Been here twice.
First time, we were a bit hesitant to try it out since it's inside a mall.  However, we took a leap of faith and gave it a go.
We ordered various dim sum items as well as the beef noodle soup.  The dim sum items were good, a mix between traditional dim sum and a twist of modern touches, for example, their sticky rice is made with wild grain rice, which was different, a little less sticky, but not bad.  Their beef noodle soup was excellent, had great Taiwanese flavor with chunks of very tender beef.  The noodles did not seem to be hand pulled, but still nice and tender without being soggy.  They don't skimp on the bok choy as some places do for their beef noodle soup.
The decor is very classy and could be a 5 star restaurant on its own.  So it does seem a bit out of place inside the mall, but I get it, you can't beat the foot traffic afforded by the Galleria mall patrons.
The next time we dined here, we had the dim sum sampler, it was consistent with the first time and their noodle soup was still great.
Price is a big high for the food, but consistent with the area.

Service was very solid, nice attention to our needs. We never had to flag anyone down.  Martin Yan would be proud.
author: Rob L.

description: Always enjoy this restaurant. Good food and good service. The noodles top my list as they are made fresh.
author: David J.

description: As usual a great meal. The cold Dan Dan Noodles are a treat! Peking Duck expertly prepared. Our Server Bolo was so professional. Great experience.
author: Beau R.

description: my favorite spot in the city for happy hour, best place to meet for business meetings or a friend to go shopping after. This is one spot i dont miss in san francisco, who doesnt want to miss the noodle show?!
author: Carmin W.

description:
I wanted to visit M.Y. China as it's Martin Yan's restaurant. I have watched some episodes of his show "Yan Can Cook." The show has won: Daytime Emmy Award for best cooking show (1998), James Beard Award for Best TV Food Journalism (1996), and James Beard Award for Best TV Cooking Show (1994). The restaurant is conveniently located within a mall. I disregarded the poor food safety score that pops up on yelp and came in during happy hour- $5 bites. 

They changed the menu, so it differs from the one posted online. I was disappointed that the pork juicy dumplings were no longer on the happy hour menu. I ordered the salt & pepper calamari, shui mai (4) and har gow (3). My favorite was the calamari. I was a bit disappointed with the shui mai and har gow. They are two dishes I always order when I eat dim sum, and I wanted to compare theirs with what I've had. The ones here are maybe a bit bigger and the ingredients are a bit better, but I didn't think they were that much better. I also had the tea infused creme brulee. I liked it overall with whipped cream and gaufrette (wafer) but felt like it didn't need the other things on top. My experience was just ok, but I'm glad I tried what Yan can cook.
author: Helen H.

description: Good place for quality Chinese food to be found in the mall. I will suggest setting a reservation there to help make the process easy. Staff is friendly and easy to work with. The best part is actually seeing the kitchen which is a huge plus.
author: Adam S.

description: The food at M.Y. China is surprisingly delicious. It feels like an upscale Chinese restaurant, but it's in the Westfields which makes it's atmosphere a little odd. It's nicer if you get a seat inside, but we were sat outside in the actual mall which wasn't a great experience. The service is great, but can sometimes be a little bit slow. I recommend the pork juicy dumplings, calamari, 7 spice pork ribs and wild boar scissor cut noodles!
author: Carol Ann V.

description:
Good food, ok service, moderate to high prices (pending what you order).

Pros:
+ All dishes were great and not overly seasoned
+ Comfortable seating, modern feel
+ Prompt seating for 2 on a Friday night

Cons:
- Mediocre service/system/policy...

Recommendations:
- Spicy scallop? dumplings, 5/5
- Bok choy, 5/5
- Garlic Steamed Lobster, 4/5

Total damage: $130 w/ tax and tip

Note:
I asked to try one of their wines for my friend and I, but you could tell they were hesitant. We ended up trying it, but when we asked again, their limit was two. For such a nice restaurant, I'm a bit meh about this. Then again, I've also never encountered this before at a restaurant. You don't lose much on letting people try a little. You lose more when you're a stingy establishment.

I'd come back for those dumplings and maybe other dishes. That $60 lobster, while good, was OMG expensive. Will feed 3-4 alone.
author: Fanny W.

description:
M.Y. China is a collaboration between Martin Yan (television cooking show host, local personality) and Koi Palace (famed restaurant with locations in the Peninsula, East Bay, and South Bay).  It sits atop the Dome of the Westfield San Francisco Centre and reveals a grand plan to not only have top shopping destinations and brands, but also renovated food courts and sit-down offerings (Din Tai Fung at Westfield Valley Faire, M.Y. China at Westfield SF Centre).  

While purists will likely find faults with the modern interpretations and execution of Chinese classics, many mall demographic people will be happy with the modern and clean decor, spacious seating, and elevated cuisine compared to either the mall food courts of past or even of the area.  

Tourists visiting the area could easily head to the Sunset or Richmond district or even find Thai or Vietnamese fare in the Tenderloin that would both be cheaper and more delicious, but it's not likely it would be as comfortable.  

We ordered a broad selection of the menu and were happy with our diverse choices and glad at the professional service and their ability to sit a large party on a busy weekend with little notice.  Honestly, I'd say the execution is the low or middle part of the menu and that our misses were at the high end.  Our order:

Hot and Sour Soup - $12.  More like hot and very sour soup.  I think the waiter overheard me saying this and brought another complimentary bowl by later, but it was more of the same....very sour and more chili oil so very hot.  Pass.

Beef Pulled Noodle Soup - $15.  Solid.  Tender beef, tasty bok choy and round standard noodles.  The soup broth was flavorful and piping hot.

Hong Kong Crispy Noodles with Chicken XO - $16.  Another solid dish.  Nicely crispy fried noodles topped with plentiful sauce and large chunks of tender, but white meat chicken.  Not much XO but I enjoyed it.  

Wok Seared Beef - $19.  Tender filets of beef with a touch of sichuan peppercorns.  A bit odd paired with bitter arugula, but the dish had a nice flavor.  

Crispy Whole Rockfish - $32.  Heading into the weaker part of the menu.  I should have read the description carefully, but I expected whole large pieces of rockfish stir fried with sauce.  Instead, it was a deep fried entire rockfish fried to a very crispy finish and topped with a nice sauce.  While the presentation wasn't as expected (it's very similar to a popular Americanized Chef Chu dish in Los Altos ), I was still game.  I soon realized why they deep fried it for so long.  In short, it probably wasn't swimming recently. 

Salted Egg Dungeness Crab - $48.  This is a classic dish and I was hoping for a tasty rendition.  The salted egg coating was decent, but again, like the fish, the crab quality, despite dungeness crab season opening late this year, wasn't up to par.  I'm used to going to places with seafood tanks (Koi Palace, Yum's Bistro, etc.) so I should have known.  Disappointing at the price point.  

Overall, we had a solid meal at M.Y. China.  There's much to like with the decor, service, and location, especially if you're a tourist visiting SF or simply doing some shopping in SoMa.  Chinese cuisine in these parts is going to be either expensive (Hakkasan, Crystal Jade) or mediocre or some combination of both.  If you stick to the noodle dishes and small plates, you'll do fine.  Just don't go for the high end banquet items as this place doesn't quite have the ingredients to go the distance. 

M.Y. China accepts credit cards, including American Express.
author: Randy F.

description:
I was a little trepidatious going to a Chinese restaurant in a mall. Not my recipe for a rewarding experience. I ordered the Dan Dan Noodles and the Mapo Tofu after the waiter patiently tried to answer a series of questions about the ingredients for me. 

I found the Dan Dan Noodles to be vinegary and just okay (noodles were good, but the vinegar in the sauce really detracted from what I was expecting. My reference being San Mateo's Little Sichuan.

I asked the chef to put some extra "sichuan sauce" in the Mapo Tofu... and it was amazing. Seriously the best Mapo Tofu I have found in the city so far. The spiciness was good and they had a lovely strong numbing from the peppercorns. So far the best Mapo Tofu I have found in SF. And the price is really good. I'll definitely be returning soon!
author: Kane D.

description:
[Ambiance/Location]: This was the first thing I noticed about M.Y. China. was how stunning it was. Finally, quality Chinese food at an establishment that isn't run down or dirty. It was a nice change of pace. Getting to see the cooks do their thing in the kitchen was also a nice addition to the overall experience. Being located on the top floor of the Westfield Mall in SF is great as it avoids all the hustle and bustle from the bottom floors.

[Food]: All the food came out quicker than our server had told us it would, but it was pretty slow so that may have been why. 
* XLB - My favorite thing here in terms of taste. The filling of the XLB were really nice and gingery which I enjoyed, but a majority of the bao's were already broken which was sad. They came in spoons which made the situation better, but still - a bummer!
* Spicy Seafood Dumplings - Another favorite. The sauce was delicious and pulled everything together. We were using the remaining sauce on all the other dumplings as well.
* Beijing Knife Cut Noodles - Decent. The shape of the noodles were not very symmetrical, but overall still good.
* Shiu Mai & Har Gow - Both Dim Sum classics. Not bad, but not great. Overall nothing too special about these. 
* Lychee panna cotta - I'm half Italian and half Chinese, so this sounded interesting - like the best of both worlds! Unfortunately, it was kind of odd. Definitely not panna cotta at all, but more like pudding. Beautiful presentation, but I wouldn't bother getting this again.

[Service]: Every employee we encountered, including the host, buser, runner, and of course server, was professional and kind. Our server checked in on us enough to make sure our water was full and that we doing okay overall, but never in a way that was bothersome or annoying which I appreciated. 

All in all, I appreciate M.Y. China for it's modern dining. Although it's definitely on the pricier side, the prices aren't outrageous all things considered. However, what really disappointed me was our experience afterwards when my entire family started feeling very thirsty and tired - symptoms normally caused after eating MSG. My family and I mostly came here in hopes to avoid MSG, especially since this is a higher end restaurant and we didn't think they'd add any.
author: Mars S.

description: I went to dinner last night and the service was horrible. The waiter was downright rude. We were literally in mid sentence when ordering and he ran away. One of us ordered a cocktail and he ran away before the rest of our party of three can order their wine. I asked a bus person for a wine list and she said "hah"? Every time we were able to talk to the waiter, he was so impatient, it's unbelievable. Forget about asking about the menu. Major bad guy. He should not be in the restaurant business. I am a regular at Koi Palace, which is MY China affiliate, and their service is much better. I understand it was Father Day but there has to be some minimum standards.
author: Frank L.

description:
Was here for their happy hour. Overall I was impressed with their menu and selections. Price is a bit pricey but the taste made up for it.

The spicy calamari was tasty with great flavors and spice.

The shredded pork tacos were a bit on the salty side but definitely different.
author: BT B.

description:
M Y China is on the 4th level in the Westfield Mall. Decor is great!

Quality of the food is absolutely authentic and delicious. The fried Pork Bao (buns) I had were really really nice. The Bao is let down only by the amount of filling inside. Fill the bun up a bit then they'll just be perfect. The skin of the Bao was well made and heavenly, lightly fried to perfection. 
The beef slices in the noodles with soup were very generously cut. The broth was full of flavour. The noodle was made on-site and was nice, again didn't get a lot of it (noodle) in my portion though. 
$6 for chrysanthemum tea is extortionate. 
The place is great and I wish it prosperity. I do somehow feel ripped off though. Final bill came to $31.90 for one!
author: Eve M.

description: Surprisingly good for an in-mall dining experience. I was prepared to be disappointed but wasn't. The "wild boar" noodles were especially good, but everything was good, including the service. Beer is available only in bottles (typical for Chinese restaurant) but here at least there were some craft brews on the menu.
author: Robin H.

description: Our second visit to M.Y. China.  Not your typical Chinese restaurant.  Martin Yan's China is a gourmet restaurant at decent prices.  We will definitely return.  Service, food, and atmosphere are all great.  Probably a good place to take a date.  I guess this was a date for my wife and I.
author: Jerry S.

description:
Decent food, good atmosphere. Took my girlfriend here for her birthday, both had a pretty good experience. 

Food portion is on the smaller side, so order more if you're a big eater!

Service is pretty meh. Friendly staff but received very little attention throughout our meal. I don't necessarily mind but taking five minutes to track down the server was a bit annoying. 

Very busy restaurant, lots of chattering in the background. I don't mind that personally, but if you want a quiet meal you'd want to go somewhere else. 

Also, be sure to reserve your seats ahead of time! Otherwise be ready to wait. Not sure how long but the line was pretty long.
author: Rinder R.

description:
MY China is the famous Martin Yan's restaurant in the Westfield Shopping Mall. Today I went there for an early dinner with friends. We ordered the spring rolls, garlic & butter crab, chow fun venison and honey walnut prawns to share between the four of us. The spring rolls were light, crispy and flavorful. The venison chow was flavorful and the chunks of venison was so tender and was a nice addition to the chow fun.
The garlic and butter crab is must!  You are provided extra napkins and utensils to  get crabmeat out of the shells. The honey walnut prawns were also very good. 
The staff were efficient and friendly.
I highly recommend MY China!
author: Madeleine M.

description: I must say I don't know why this place isn't rated higher. To be sure that our first experience was not a fluke my girlfriend and I recently dined at M.Y. China again and it was just a good as the first time. Wonton soup, pork dumplings, spicy wings, bbq pork fried rice, calamari, it's all damn good. Service is also excellent. Food comes out fast and waiter was on top of it. Highly recommend
author: Josh S.

description: I'm very particular when it comes to Chinese food. I can confidently recommend this place! There's a brilliant variety of dim sum and the Peking duck is on point. It's always a treat to eat here!
author: Annadean F.

description: I crave this all the time lol but after i had it just made me want to throw up! but they have good happy hour menu not that bad lol ! i would come back maybe every other month. but everyday NO lol ..
author: Lara J.

description:
I've always been curious about this place since I see it whenever I am at the mall. It's always packed and now I can understand why! It's convenient if you're shopping or on your way to see a movie, the space is upbeat and modern, and they have a great menu.

I would give M.Y. China 4 stars for food, and 5 stars for service. Before I dive into the food, I want to point out that the service here was top notch. The hostess was very friendly and sat us right away. We decided to sit at the bar and all of the bartenders were very welcoming and knowledgeable with the menu. Service was also quick and very attentive.

As far as the food goes....I wouldn't consider M.Y. China to have the kind of authentic cuisine that you'll find in hole-in-the-wall restaurants in China Town. However, the thing I appreciated about M.Y. China's food is that they are very direct with what they are serving. What you see on their menu is what you will get. They deliver quality, modernized Chinese cuisine. That was the best way my husband and I were able to describe their food. We also loved that their noodles were homemade. They were delicate, silky, and fresh. For dinner we ordered:
- Bang Bang Chicken Wings: Crunchy and loved the sauce! Kind of tasted like spicy sesame chicken.
- Pork Juicy Dumplings: If you've never had soup dumplings, get these! 
- Beijing Knife Cut Noodles: Loved the noodles! Minced pork was a great addition. Very tasty dish.
- Wok Seared Beef: The Sichuan peppercorns gave this a very unique flavor. Beef was cooked perfectly. Dish wasn't spicy in case you were wondering. I love spice though so I put their chili sauce on top - delicious!

All in all I really enjoyed this place. I like their modern take on Chinese cuisine. Looking forward to coming back!
author: Chisholm T.

description: This was a wonderful meal. The location is a little bit odd... On the floor fourth floor of a shopping mall, and difficult to find. The menu was broad and varied. Everything was cooked to perfection. Shrimp and scallops with squid ink cracked noodles, Peking duck, juicy pork dumplings and spicy seafood dumplings.  I would highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Andrew A.

description: Weird staff. Kind of dismissive. Underwhelming food, atleast for the price. The Kung Pao chicken and General Mao's chicken were pretty okay, a bit on the dry side. The spicy shrimp dumplings were a total waste of money, they were soaked in sauce and kind of tasteless. The Hong Kong crispy noodles were good, kind of weird to pair with chicken though.
author: Nina A.

description: Great service with delicious Chinese food. Peking duck, pork bun and their vegetables have good authentic tastes to it. Their deep fried ice cream is something to experience. Overall we had a good time.
author: Cayets C.

description:
This place doesn't deserve 3.5 stars as it says in yelp.  
To reiterate, when it comes to Chinese food, I put higher weight on the food, than service.  That being said, the service was better than average for Chinese restaurants, and in par with normal fine dining.  Agreed with lots of review, the location actually makes people think of PF Chang type of food....  but it's not.  The menu looks like it though....

This my people's food, so I can say the food is very authentic, with a modern twist.  Martin Yan really did a fantastic job with this place.  We ordered chow fun, BeiJing noodle, mix seafood wok (I forgot the real dish name :). And pea shoots.  
First, peashoots, very authentic sautéed vegetables....  great with rice or by itself, not too salty....
Beijing noodle, fresh noodle with new twist, not normal shape, but it was cut, taste a little like dan dan noodle, served with cucumber, carrots and bean sprouts....
Chow fun was also great, perfectly seasoned, and the beef was very soft and tasty.
Seafood wok was also perfectly seasoned, shrimp and squid were not too hard, soft actually....  
This is a tip for most people, don't skip the desert!!!!!
