Chinese restaurant usually don't do great desert, but they do!!!
Matcha tiramisu....  this is so awesome, not only they perfectly marry the matcha with the concept of tiramisu, they also put a hint of flower fragrance!!  Alter a while, my wife and I thought it was orchid....  fantastic!
The other one we ordered was ice cream, passion fruit....  thought it would be just normal Ice cream, NOPE, there is a hint of I think Chinese plum in it....  I can't think any Chinese restaurant with fantastic desert, at least right now.  They really deserve much higher rating!!!  
CHINA LIVE, this is how you do it!!!
author: Steve D.

description: As Asian fusion, MYCHINA did a really good job. they provide most signature Chinese dish, like soup dumpling and crisp whole fish. i love MYCHINA noodle section, must to try!
author: Faye L.

description: It's in the Westfield mall, but I felt the service and food was excellent, not your typical mall food. A pleasant dining experience. The hot wings were my fav and so were the scissor cut noodles. The Mango Sea bass has was a Lil overwhelming at the end. Definite gem in the city.
author: Gomz G.

description:
Great discovery! And strangely, in the mall...a little tough to find if unfamiliar with SF, but it's upstairs in Westfield mall. 

Get the egg custard bao and dumplings! Great service and food
author: Kristin S.

description:
First off let me tell you in an area where there is a ton of Asian restaurants this place has some serious competition. Truth be told Man can still cook! Got a chance to meet this culinary genius on our second visit to his establishment while in San Fran. Yes it was so good that we went not once on our extended weekend stay, but twice..Everything was top notch. 
I only wish he had  a restaurant on the Northeast it would definitely be a hit!
author: Sean W.

description: My sister and I just finished shopping and wanted to eat Chinese food. We went to MY China and the hostess who was wearing a red and white striped dress and black ankle boots, asked us if we had a reservation and we said we had none, she made a dismayed face which we ignored. We just wanted to eat. So we sat down and looked at the menu, meanwhile not noticing no one even came to ask us what we wanted to drink. Anyway, we picked what we wanted from the menu and discussed it. We looked around and no one was coming. We saw this man 1 table away that was fixing napkins, chopsticks and silverware. We asked him if he can please find a server. We saw him talk to 2 waiters who looked at us and made faces but no one even approached us to even say, I'll get your server. Even if they weren't assigned to us, just give us the courtesy of knowing someone will come and take our order. We couldn't believe it was happening, we looked at each other and decided to leave. My sister stopped by the reception area and told the same hostess that no server came to us. She didn't even try to rectify the problem nor did she apologize for what happened. Unacceptable!  Was it prejudice? It was deliberate! They chose not to serve us! In this day and age it was unreal! For the owners of this restaurant, how can you let this happen and be in business? It happened around 4:30 pm and we left at 4:45 pm today July 21,2018.
author: Jackie V.

description:
Came here for Happy Hour (3-6 PM), but left before getting seated. Understandably, it's first come, first serve, with seating limited to the bar and a few surrounding tables. Guessing it gets full by 5 PM.

Knocking off a star because the hostess could have been friendlier and more helpful. There were two free seats at a communal table the entire half hour we were waiting. When I asked, the hostess said that someone waiting for their guests to arrive. Would make sense if groups were seated only when their entire party is there. Definitely could have chowed down on some shiu mai in that time period. Oh well, maybe next time.
author: Aye E.

description: Went here with my bf. we ordered peking duck, fried rice, and a fish. Taste was great. Service was friendly and fast. We can't to wait try the other foods. Definitely come back!
author: Urangoo G.

description:
I'm surprised that this place is only 3.5 stars. They don't offer truly authentic Chinese food, so don't come if that's what you're looking for. Instead, they offer their own take on popular dishes from various different regions. Part of this interpretation is the use of high quality, noticeably fresh ingredients that impart a bright texture and flavor to the dishes. 

Pork juicy dumplings $9- I think these were the most authentic dish we tried. Very comparable to xiaolongbao that I've had in Shanghai. You get five on their own individual ceramic spoons. It doesn't sound like much, but they are on the larger side. Unlike other soup dumplings where soup spills out when you break the skin, these hold their soup inside the meat filling so you get more and more in your spoon with each bite. 

Wild boar sticky rice cakes $16- These were great! The rice cakes were wonderfully thick and chewy and taste homemade, the veggies fresh and bright.

Beijing knife cut noodles $13- This is a play on zhajiangmein but doesn't taste anything like the real thing. The dish was still delicious in its own way, and I liked that they created a sauce with toppings that really suit the texture and shape of the noodles. 

East meets west $12- Highly recommend! It's like drinking sweet chrysanthemum tea with a hint of lemon. Great for people who don't like the taste of alcohol.

Matcha tiramisu $8- A bit too sweet for my liking. The best part of tiramisu is that the coffee flavor cuts down the richness and sweetness. Green tea just doesn't do the same thing. This was yummy though, and they really captured the flavor of jasmine and matcha.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Always a good meal here! Perfect for just before the movies!
Feels a little like you're going out but also low-key and casual. Not a chinese food fan but I do crave MY China when Im near here!
author: E B.

description: Love this place! I ordered the twin scallops fried rice, the cold mushroom salad, sweet chili prawn and the lychee panda cotta as a dessert. Everything is good! Definitely will be back!
author: Steven W.

description:
M.Y. China was on my list for my most recent trip to San Francisco, and I was surprised to find that it was inside of a mall. That said, it is DEFINITELY not your typical mall restaurant, which is probably why it is included in Westfield's "Food Emporium."
 
First, let's start with the look and feel. The restaurant plays host to a spacious dining area and beautiful bar with a huge bell over the center of the bar. That's right--an almost ancient-looking bell that almost acts as a hood over the center of the bar. It's brilliant. 
After receiving some informative suggestions from my server at the 
Ordered the chairman's chicken, which is a fried but not greasy chicken chunks with a nice hit of spice, pepper, and onions and steamed rice. The side dipping sauce is amazing and I could probably drink it by the gallon. 
For drinks, I had the vodka-based East Meets West, which I LOVED. The chrysanthemum infusion was bold yet muted and honestly, I don't think I've ever tasted such a strong flower essence in a drink that did not overpower the whole thing. The Rum Blossom tasted like a sweet rum punch from Jamaica and was gone in as many sips. 
Had an amazing conversation with the woman next to me at the bar for over an hour. It's clear that some of the people in here are regulars. The service is superb, and I'm not sure if I've ever been so pleased with a restaurant that is technically inside a mall. 
Sugar egg puff dessert (think big, fluffy sopapillas) is fantastic, especially when paired with choya dessert wine. I don't even really like raspberries, but the raspberry sauce that goes with the sugar egg puffs is GREAT! It doesn't have that sharp bite of most raspberries and is actually sweet. #delectable

The bar team is super cool and friendly, and it was obvious that they were very well acquainted with some of the regulars who were in here. The staff are very knowledgeable about each dish and are quick to suggest a pairing. They even gave me a quick rundown of which dishes did not contain any seafood-based sauces, which was a great help. 

Don't pass on M.Y. China just because it's in Westfield Mall! Truly a gem.
author: Willie R.

description: Excellent Atmosphere, great food, especially the Fry rice, dumpling. Great customer services. The most important, no lines. Love to come back
author: Tracy L.

description: We stopped here while we were in San Francisco.  It is located in the Westfields Mall on Market Street on the top Floor "Under the Dorm".   We were seated in the cafe section - very near the beautiful Christmas chandelier.  So pretty!   We ordered the Dim Sum collection which lets you taste a selection of their wonderful Dim Sum.  It also comes some special soy sauces.  Delicious.  Then we had the Beijing knife cut noodles.  They come with cucumbers, bean sprouts, pork, carrots and dark bean sauce - lovely.  The service was great and we really enjoyed our lunch
author: Jennifer M.

description: Not the worst meal I've had but completely underwhelming for the price. My family of 5 agreed. We ended up going somewhere else for food because of the meal. We ordered honey walnut shrimp and maybe there was 7 shrimp. The Kung Pao chicken had mainly peppers, with about 8 pieces of chicken. We spent  $200 on dinner and left hungry and dissatisfied with the flavorless food. Very disappointing.
author: Allison C.

description: One of the Highlights is a 2lb crab cooked with rice cakes in Shanghai style, taste good and the price is very reasonable.
author: Zimeng J.

description:
Not impressed. For the price and location, I had higher expectation. 

The bang bang chicken wings were tiny, the sauce portions were tiny for our generals chicken, and everything came separate-no full meals to be found in the menu. 

Go to sunset for waaaay better Chinese and half the price. 

Only pro was the pretty location.
author: shannon m.

description:
We made reservations at last minute and didn't know what to expect, especially because the restaurant is in a mall.  We were so pleasantly surprised with the service, the ambiance, the menu and meeting Mr. Yan himself.  We had a terrific time and the food was excellent.  We never finish a Chinese meal when we order appetizer and two main entrees, but we did!!
We are already making plans to go back when we return to SF in July and we have already told many Bay Area friends and family about the restaurant.
author: Nancy T.

description:
First of all, the ambience of this place is unlike any other Chinese restaurant I've visited in the Bay Area. I love how modern yet traditional the furnitures look, and overall it just feels very clean. I also think it's interesting how they have the kitchen behind a clear counter, because it is not only fun to watch, but also assures customers of the foods' cleanliness. Also, service was great and was very willing to explain some confusing dishes, which is a plus!

When it comes to the food, while it's undeniably good, it's definitely very pricey. I tried the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, which was similar to the taste of beef chow fen. The noodles didn't taste like I expected---it wasn't as chewy as I had hoped it to be. Also, the dish was VERY greasy. The Spicy Seafood Dumplings were good; I really enjoyed the sauce, but it was nothing MIND-BLOWING. The best one in my opinion were the Pork Juicy Dumplings. I loved how they were presented in little red spoons, which made it convenient to consume the soup in the dumplings!
author: Diane Z.

description:
Upscale Chinese restaurant more-so catering to the western world. Very nice anterior, patio (although still within Westfield) seating, and friendly staff. 
Food: I tried the beef rolls, squid ink noodles, Peking duck, and lava buns for dessert. 
-Beef rolls were okay, not much meat and pretty thick flour rolls. Good thing was that the beef was more like chunks of steak instead of slices. This came with 4 pieces 
-squid ink noodles: the term "noodle" is misleading. I wish the waitress told us that the noodles are knife-cut noodles, so instead of the typical long noodles, they're round and flattened. Stir-fried with bell peppers and shrimp. I wouldn't recommend this, the squid ink was just used to make the noodles a black color, whoop-dee-do.
-Peking duck (half portion): came with 6 buns and half a portion of duck. Essentially DIY duck tacos. This was great, the skin was crispy, the meat was well cooked and tender, and they did a good job de-boning it for the most part. I wish it came with more cucumber slices and green onions. But I RECOMMEND this the most, from the items I tried ! 
-lava buns: soft buns with a sweet , runny egg-yolk- based center. REALLY sweet. It's worth a try.
author: Cindy H.

description: This is solid Chinese food in a nice chain restaurant ambiance.  It is what is said it is, and it is a good exemplar of the genre.  Enjoy it for that.
author: Amjad S.

description: It's a little pricy for a mall restaurant but their food is really tasty. Spicy shrimp dumplings and mushu pork tacos are on my must-order list, and I just discovered my new favorite that got added to the list - the beef stew soup!! It's a well known dish from my hometown in China, MY China certainly delivered! Reservation recommended for dinner as it gets very crowded.
author: Carol Y.

description: Fantastic happy hour. We got the shiu mai, Har Gow, and calamari. All of it was delicious! Given the weather, we also asked for a hot toddy and three were very accommodating and it was a huge portion!
author: Laura W.

description:
Happy HOUR is awesome here. Must come and HH ends at 6pm. Food and drinks at a really good price. $5 for their Pork Juicy Dumplings. YUM. Juicy and the presentation is too cute. Drinks are about $7 and house wine is $6. The dumplings are one of my favorites at M.Y. China. 

My friends and I always try to catch happy hour but if we do miss it, we still grab a sit. The food is pretty good. I really like their Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles but i feel like its a hit or a miss something. Guess depending on the chef. Also a fan of their Jasmine Tea Smoked Sea Bass. Very flavorful. Overall it's pretty good but on the more expensive side, if you're not having happy hour. But you are eating inside a nice mall, there goes your prices.
author: Sandy B.

description:
I love getting lunch or dinner here! The food is high quality and great presentation. I know some people will disagree that the hole in the wall place is better. It might be, but you come here for the convenience of your shopping or seeing a movie. 

I always get the juicy dumplings and the bang bang chicken wings are great.
author: James H.

description:
Spent the day doing Christmasy stuff around union square and the Westfield Mall. It was dinner time but none of us wanted to fend the food court. My brother suggested this spot.

We rolled up and there was a line! I hate lines! Searched OpenTable nothing. Opened Yelp. Reserve a seat? Yes, please! Ta-da! We skipped the line and were seated right away. We kinda giggled as we heard people being told it would be at least a 30 minute wait. You should really yelp!!

To start, our server was super sweet and attentive and had great recommendations. She and the wait staff were excellent. Our water glasses and tea pot were constantly filled and our table was cleared quickly. We ordered a lot for three people so this was imperative for space saving.

We ordered some delicious tea to start. Definitely order tea! Then we had the Crab Dumplings which I would probably skip next time. The Salt & Pepper Calamari, yummy but more salty than peppery. The Hot & Sour Soup, so hot so yummy!!!!

As main and side dishes we ordered the Kung Pao Chicken and Chairman Mao Chicken which was lightly fried and stole the show. I personally loved the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, they where so yummy!!!!! As was the Yang Zhao Fried Rice, I'm not a big fan of fried rice but this is no regular fried rice. The pork and shrimp are beautifully seasoned and the flavors are just right!

Major Tip: save room for sweets! The Sugar Egg Puffs and Black Sesame Ice Cream were amazing. Both of them sounded unappealing to me after the large meal but when I had my first bite I was practically licking my plate clean.
author: Caro S.

description:
Underwhelmed. Where's the flavor? The spice? The sauce? Everything we ordered had great potential to be delish, but just missed the mark and left us wanting to order more to fill the void. The best part of my meal? The tea! How sad.

Recap: The wild boar scissor cut noodles were way too dry, borderline bland, and skimpy on the meat. The 7-spice pork ribs were $18 for 5 ribs. Not worth it.

Service was brusque, obviously wanting to keep tables turning unless we were ordering more. Though, they did refill our teapot at no charge, which was a nice bonus.

I will say, the ambiance is definitely nice for a mall restaurant. It's strangely both upscale and family friendly, packed with large groups (definitely make a reservation). Random note: there was a chef bouncing around the dining room, twirling noodles in a rave-style dance, while playing Gangnam Style on a portable stereo. Ok!

*If* I go back, I'll need some better recommendations for ordering.
author: Nique F.

description:
Went there for lunch the other day.
Food: 3.5 stars
Dim sum was about 3 stars. Had the M.Y Dim Sum collection. The city has so many good dim sum places, so was a little disappointed in the texture and the wrappers were a little dry.
The highlight of the lunch was the Beef Noodle Soup. Good flavor and enough to share! For $16 it better be decent though!

For dessert we had the Lychee panna cotta.
Pretty light and refreshing.

Service: 3.0
Not great but not bad
We weren't checked on that often. The table was small and they didn't clear our cramped table very often. 

Will go back for the beef noodle soup.
author: Lynn K.

description:
This was my 3rd visit to MY China. My previous two weren't very memorable. But this time was much better. The dishes were all beautifully prepared. The flavors were blended in unique ways that are refreshingly different than most Chinese restaurants. 

Surprisingly what really stood out for me were the desserts. I loved all three that we ordered and shared: candied ginger ice cream, jasmine tea creme brulee, and lychee pana cotta.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
My friend and I went there on Chinese new year's weekend and was a very good experience.
Ordered a dimsum combo; that was nice selection.
Dessert custard bun. My friend wanted a tart, but the waitress didn't understand that. My friend was little upset; but the bun we got was good too.
Hot tea
Great ambiance.
Loved it.
author: Honest O.

description:
3 words: Very Expensive Letdown. 

First and foremost, the hostesses need retraining. I do not need to feel forced to watch them discuss whatever they are discussing that has absolutely nothing to do with me. I had a reservation, I made it a point to be exactly on time. Seat me first then giggle and talk about whatever you like. Professionalism. 

The space itself feels and looks like you are in an airport. It isn't comfortable or luxurious.The prices do not match the space. I was seated at an end table in the outer perimeter of the restaurant which was nice, but with the tables unnecessarily close together, watching my dishes quickly fill that tiny table was overwhelming. Limited elbow room due to the party at the table beside me made trying to eat comfortably annoying. 

If you want to buy the most overpriced XLB, try it here! 6 pieces for the price of an entree. It was good, but not that good. Now that I think of it, Dragon Beaux has a similarly priced XLB with the same amount of dumplings. I do not recommend, I would not reorder this. 

The overcooked chicken wings were saturated with a sweet and salty sauce that made eating one wing enough for me. 

Steamed Fish. This was delicious but overpriced. The long stalks of vegetables were awkward to eat but they were cooked correctly. 

The squid ink snap noodle? OUTSTANDING.  Wonderfully balanced with perfectly cooked seafood alongside toothsome noodles. This was perfection on a plate. If I only ordered this, my review would have a different tone. 

My egg puffs were hollow. I basically poured the random dipping sauces inside of them to eat. Such a shame to not have the lovely tender web-like center to contrast with the crisp sugary outside. I'd be happy to have a properly cooked egg puff without the sauce distraction. 

The highlight of my visit? My server. She was attentive and professional. Polished. The busers were also excellent. They deserve 5 stars. 

When I consider the price point, the stressful feeling of being crammed into a space, and the weird reception, I would not recommend this restaurant. I could have spent the same money at sibling restaurant Koi Palace for an amazing meal in a comfortable dining space. 

If you are in the mall in jeans and a t-shirt, sure. Come by for a bowl of noodle soup (I spied a LOT of folks having that). If you really want a good meal while shopping go to the basement where the food court is.
author: Jennifer C P.

description: Got to experience the modern day China food, roasted pork, beef noodles, you name it! everything 5 stars! This is one of the essential places to eat in sf! Keep it up
author: Nabi S.

description: Great place for happy hour (3-6 pm) or a break from shopping. The Lucky beer comes in a Buddha shaped bottle which was cool. House pinot noir was good (not the crappy cheap wine). Pork ribs and dumplings were among the faves. Great prices and service!
author: E C.

description: Was here years ago and it was impressive. Things have gone down this last visit. Service wasn't good, had to ask for our server many times, probably due to under staff. Plate delivery person almost knocked down our drinks few times, not caring about where the dishes land on the table. Food was still good but Deep Fried Chinese Donut was just barely warm.
author: Eric T.

description: Food was so-so. Service was great. Management asked our group to leave after the bill arrived because they needed the table. Very rude and disappointing.
author: J C.

description: Had brunch at this place for the first time today. Ambiance was pretty nice. BF ordered the Hong Kong crispy noodle with chicken and a side of fried rice. Both tasted good. I ordered a Don Don noodles and I was in a bit of a shock when I had my first bite. I was not expecting my food to be cold. This dish is very similar to the Vietnamese vermicelli bowl which I love by the way. Now, the dish was good however, I was expecting a hot meal or at least room temperature for this dish.
author: Michelle A.

description: How I spent $31 (including tip) on non-fried rice, room temperature green beans and veggie egg rolls, I'll never know. The flavor was bland and it took forever for our food to come out. Our waiter seemed overwhelmed, yet they kept putting people in his section. I got my fried rice w/o pork and it's like they forgot flavor. It still had shrimp but very few pieces. They then brought cold soy sauce (like straight from the fridge) for me to use on it. My friend got pork belly buns and chicken wings which looked yummy. The vegetarian options just fell flat. That's what I get for having expectations from a mall restaurant. This was my second visit and it will be my last.
author: Carrie T.

description:
Food is so so. Crab is delicious.
Service is like: a waiter cleaning table for us spilled hot tea on my pants. After he said sorry, it looked like nothing happened and no body were aware of it. I was unhappy. Also, I raised my hand for 3 mind with several waiters walking by. Ridiculous
author: Xiao W.

description: Spicy seafood dumplings, shandong beef rolls, scallop fried rice, salmon appetizers, eggplant tofu claypot.  These were super delicious, and we really enjoyed the atmosphere.  Glad we tried the restaurant, very happy!
author: Lola M.

description:
A hidden gem, seriously!!!!

I quickly google searched "best eats in union square" and found a chronicle article listing this place. My boyfriend and I were soooo hungry we didn't even think twice we just showed up... It was a huge surprise walking into a mall and having to take 4 escalators to find the place!! We had second thoughts but the hunger made us move forward... And I'm so glad we did!

First of all we asked to sit at the counter facing the open kitchen, because that's always fun! We were accommodated right away and our waitress was amazing, honest and quick! I asked her suggestions and everything was perfect.

Pork soup dumplings, wild boar hand pulled noodles and half a duck with fresh little buns!!!! The noodles were out of this world, imagine lo-mein but the best you've ever had and then some.

Another great thing about this restaurant is the beer, duvel tripel is the same price as a tsing tsao-- score!!!

Would recommend this to everyone and hope to come back soon -- the manager recommended their happy hour all beers $3 and lots of $5 bites! 

Side note: the bathroom is communal so if you don't want to be walked in on LOCK the door. It locks to the opposite side and apparently people have issues with that as I walked in on two of them...
author: Molli W.

description: I came here with a group of girls on a bachelorette party because the bride-to-be was craving dim sum. After walking 2+ miles to find out another Chinese restaurant was no longer opened, we settled on MY China. It was a good experience, we ordered several dishes and shared with the table. We sat at a high table right by the bar, which was ideal for our group. I would definitely eat here again!
author: Danielle S.

description: This is a solid choice for Chinese food particularly when you want a place close to the shopping district. Highly recommend the wok seared beef, forbidden rice, Peking duck and the steamed sea bass. They do several versions of Dungeness crab (all relatively decent). Highly recommend the lychee panna cotta for dessert.  Service can be iffy though.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Tasty but overpriced food with a nice ambiance. I tried coming for happy hour after work but they only serve HH 3-6PM to people at the bar and in the outside dining area. Since we already sat down inside, we decided to just stay for dinner.

Recommend:
Shandong Beef Rolls (9)
Eggplant & Tofu Claypot (12)
Wok Stir Fried Lamb (21)
Beijing Knife Cut Noodles (13)
Tea Infused Crème Brûlée (8)

Skip:
Bang Bang Chicken Wings (9) - These chickens must've been underfed because 3 of 6 wings were so tiny! These were tasty but definitely not worth the money. They are only $5 during HH so that's the only time I would recommend ordering these.
Lychee Panna Cotta (8) - Not memorable

I won't be back for dinner, but will attempt HH some other time.
author: Lucy N.

description:
Tis the season, where I go downtown, embrace the 30 person line at the mall and eat dinner at M.Y. China. 

I came here with a friend and I wasn't sure what to expect! Of course, we ordered drinks which included this smoked apple cocktail (super strong) and a cucumber ginger drink which was amazingly refreshing. 

A friend recommended us try the Mao Chicken and Big Knife noodles. I really didn't know where to start on the menu just because I was a bit overwhelmed. I guess I'm used to ordering certain things at Chinese restaurants but I'm glad I tried something new! First off if you're a fan of XO sauce which I am, you definitely need to try the Big Knife noodles. It's basically seafood stir fried with wide rice noodles, eggs, mushrooms and XO sauce :) the Mao Chicken was alright, nothing crazy special but it was very tender for white meat. Also their balsamic sauce that came for dipping was A+!!! We finished off with their puffed  egg pastry which was the best I've ever had. So light and fluffy. Everything I love about beignets and eggettes rolled into one.  Over all, the tab came out to around $90-100 after tax. Each entree was $18, each drink was $13 and the dessert was like $12? 

Not too bad, and apparently they have happy hour which I'll be back for!
author: Shelly W.

description:
If you can get over the indoor mall location this is a solid spot and for the quality of the food there is never a wait(rare for SF). Ordered:
-Hot and sour soup: Plenty of mushrooms and not afraid of shying away from the hot.
-Black pepper snapper with tofu, bok choy, and eggplant: Delicious fish/ginger sauce, served in a clay pot. Large cuts of eggplant soaked in the mouth watering sauce.
-Peking duck: Buns served in a steamed basket, skin was delicious as you would expect. Duck meat was a bit on the dry side but that drizzling the ginger sauce from our fish dish solved this easily.

Service was fast, lighting was low, kitchen was open and huge. Overall a great environment, though I recommend sitting in the restaurant, the patio seating can be a bit bright with the mall lighting.
author: Sean M.

description: My husband and i love Chinese food. We went for lunch during the weekend end. No wait plenty of seats. It's located in the mall right on market street.    We've seen this chef on tv and we knew we had to try it. We started off with mango ice tea, water came in a little glass bottle, and Diet Coke. Mango tea was great. For appetizer we got the dim sum Crispy Shrimp Wonton. They came with a mayo fruit dipping sauce it was different but ok. The entree was wok seared beef and we ordered the Yang Zhou fried rice. It was delicious.
author: Ingrid K.

description:
I have been wanting to try M.Y. China and finally got there last night. Made reservation of a late dinner at 8:15 pm. and met my daughter at the Westfields Mall 4th floor. The restaurant is beautiful next to the Rotunda of the Mall. We sat at a corner booth and ordered a bottle of Cannonball Cab for the table. We ordered the following dishes:

Pork Belly Sliders 5 stars excellent with some pickled radishes inside
Shandong Beef Rolls 4 stars strips of beef steak in flakey skin.
Trio of pickles 3 stars shredded daikon, pickled radishes, and pickled squash.
Steamed Sea Bass 5 stars excellent fresh slices of sea bass. small portions though.
Shandong Lobster Clay Pot 5 stars comes in clay pot with glass noodles.
Wok Seared Beef Filet 4 stars on a bed of arugula great taste very small portion for $19
Stir-fried Green Beans 3 stars very salty, soft, 
Scissor - Cut Wild Boar Noodles 4 stars very good, Noodles were not to thick.

Ambiance = 5 stars
Service = 4 stars
Parking across the street in lot at 5th and Mission.
$214 before tip.
author: George F.

description: Even though MY China is in a mall, the decor tries to be quite swanky and the food is pretty darn tasty.  The dumplings were flavorful (specifically the soup dumplings).  My hot and sour soup was also awesome, as was my shrimp and papaya salad (the shrimp were especially plump, and awesome).
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Some of the food is awesome, like beef noodle, tofu and fish wok, etc. Some dishes are not good like Kung Bao Chicken. They are doing American Chinese food. The dish is pricey.

The waiter at the bar is not friendly, they want you to drink wine (expensive ones), otherwise their service is not good, like they try to give you a poker face or ignore you.
author: Michael C.

description: Oh. Em. Yessss! I love Asian food, and literally everything we had here was spectacular! My suggestion, go for happy hour. 3-6 pm, we had several drinks and apps off of the menu and seriously everything was delicious! This is the type of place I'm not scared to order something random off of the menu because everything they have looked and it was delicious! GO!!
author: Amber C.

description:
My daughter really wanted to see the noodles being pulled and have some food at M.Y. China after finishing her school year. 
Of course, there was no noodle pulling and she was disappointed to the max. 

I made a reservation and was seated promptly since they just opened. We were seated where I could see clearly a bunch of wait staff chit chatting and not checking on the customers. At one point there were four standing in an alcove talking and not doing much else. This irritates me, especially at a fine dining establishment. 

We got our salmon appetizer quickly and after some time the wild boar noodle followed. The wait came with the pork dumplings. It took quite a while for it to reach our table and my daughter wanted to just leave at that point. 

I am not sure what is going on with this restaurant. It was great when we were invited back after a very dissatisfying first experience and we had a great time the second time around. On our own again, this restaurant proved to disappoint once again.
author: F. L. C.

description:
Came here during a lunch rush. The wait was a bit longer than expected, but they were pretty attentive. 

Waters were constantly refilled, dishes taken away, we were asked how our meal was ... Impressive for a packed restaurant during lunch at Westfield.

The food was above average, better than many mom and pop places. The prices are a bit higher than it should be, and portions are smaller than Chinese joints in the East Bay, but it's not surprising given the area around here.

All in all it was an enjoyable experience. I would probably give them another try when they weren't so busy. 3.5 Stars rounded to 4.
author: Alton D.

description:
What $20 Will Get You @ M.Y. China:

1) A pickup lunch labeled as the "Dim Sum Collection" (fka dim sum).

2) Two good sized and tasty Shiu Mai and two Har Gow.

3) Two surprisingly unique Farmer's Dumplings with diced yam, pumpkin and crunchy bamboo shoots. 

4) An unremarkable Steamed BBQ Pork Bao and two would've-been-cool-with-more-Har-Gow-instead Seafood Dumplings.

5) An extremely gloppy, overcooked and unappetizing pile of rice wrapped in lotus leaves.

6) A clueless hostess.

7) A promise to return to M.Y. China only if someone else is footing the bill.

8) A Note to Self to go to nearby La Cocina to eat all the sugary things.
author: Amy C.

description: I was skeptical, but a friend suggested this place and I didn't do my research. I really liked the mango drink with ginger beer, which I will now make myself. I had scallion pancakes, which were okay. Service was good, though I felt a bit out of place since others were dressed up and wait staff were in uniform.
author: Ellen L.

description:
I have been here many times and the food is fantastic!   I especially love that they are dog-friendly as long as you can get one of the tables closer to the rotunda side. 

I had a little incident where I made a reservation for my birthday and specifically asked for one of the round banquet tables because I wanted to bring my two fur babies.  My party of 4 humans and 2 dogs arrived before our reservation time, but they did not have the table ready for us!  After a few times speaking to the front of the house staff and one exchange where I told them how upset I was, they finally got one of the round banquet tables ready for us.  Once we were seated, we had a great time.  The wait person, Yan, was super excellent and attentive!  Knowing that it was my birthday lunch, they gave us  a complementary dessert - the yummy doughnuts!  Nice touch...thank you! 

I hope the reservation incident was just a little hiccup.  When one makes a reservation, we don't want to hear excuses about why the table is not ready.  At least place a "Reserved" sign on the table.  

We all love the food and we will be back.
author: Evelyn W.

description:
Doing some shopping at mall, a mall employee mentioned this place, as high-end Asian cuisine.

I arrived just at happy hour. Place was crowded and hardly any place to sit. Was sat at the counter, close to kitchen and on a tiny chair, some guy had his shopping bag on the counter, blocking my view. The patio which faces the mall could have been a longer wait.

Full menu available - but they had no ramen, only noodle soups. In such case, I opted for the happy hour menu.

Happy hour until 6 p.m. Monday thru Friday. A tiny assortment (a handful) of Dim Sum dishes at $5 each (which is average for a pricey dim sum place). Food was great; portions seemed small - but this is happy hour, small bites & finger foods.

Mixed drinks are very good but not excellent. Had to ask for a well drink to get back to basics. 

After three dim sum dishes, I was ready to resume shopping. ~ $39 

In hindsight, a longer wait to sit at the patio or at a table would have been worth it. Right before leaving, a couple was happy they could sit at my chair.

Friendly, efficient service. Ambiance was noisy but engaging for people watching (and being watched). Very clean premises.
author: 鳥巢

description: Located at the top floor of Westfield, this restaurant served definitely the top 3 Chinese cuisine in town. Yangzhou fried rice and spicy crabs were so delicious that it would be pity if you did not try them.
author: Hsuan P.

description:
Decent, good-quality Chinese food that's dressed up and priced for the venue's showcase location right beneath the dome of the Westfield.

The Shandong beef rolls with hoisin sauce, for example, are good enough for a small meal and have enough beef in them to justify the price. The squid ink snap noodles with shrimp, scallops, and calamari were also a decent choice and, again, had enough seafood relative to the price. Neither dish tasted all that memorable - if anything, it was all sanitized for Western tastes - but nothing was objectionable either.

If you're a fan of Martin Yan, this beautiful venue is worth a visit. There's a massive bell from a Chinese monastery that weighs almost a ton, and there's also a noodle chef who pulls honest-to-goodness, mile-long noodles in front of you for entertainment value.
author: Vincent L.

description: Excellent quality food at affordable prices.  I cannot make any specific culinary recommendations because everything I have tried is good.  It's pretty cool that an establishment that nice is in a mall (with a movie theater).  Make a day of your visit, you will not be disappointed.
author: Kendall B.

description: This is my favorite place in San Francisco for Happy Hour after retail therapy since its located at the Westfield Shopping Center. Its easy to get to by Bart train as its right off the Powell Station. Their specialty is in authentic Chinese food, a great restaurant choice for lunch and dinner. Service is fast here too. The specialty cocktails offered at Happy Hour are the best. "Buddha Breeze" drink is number one on my list. Its a deliciously refreshing cocktail to have after a long day. The appetizer to order during happy hour is Salt and Pepper Calamari that comes with a sweet sauce to balance off the spice of the calamari.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
For sure, the best time to go is around 1:30-2pm - right after the lunch rush and right before their Lunch menu ends so you can jump in on a DUMPLING PARTY!!!!!!!!!!! Because it's all about their dim sum and dumplings...

I LOVED the Pork Soup Dumplings. It's served in a "deep" soup spoon so if the wrapper rips before it gets in your mouth, all the soup will conveniently be pooled in your spoon. Genius.

They also have a Seafood Dumpling - kinda spicy but soooo yums. And it comes in a spinach wrapper so it's GREEN! But it's not the soup dumpling kind, it's actually "shui jiao".

I'll pass on the Sizzling Pan Fried Savory Pork Bao next time though. It's mostly just bun and kinda sorta really dry with minimal meat inside.

OMG! We also got to see Martin Yan pull noodles to Gangnam Style!!!! It was AMAZING!!!!!! For those who don't know, Martin Yan is THE Lee Kum Kee guy (I'm pretty sure)!

When this "no crab off California coast" thing is over, I'll have to go back for the Pork and Crab Roe Soup Dumplings. AND the Steamed Farmer's Dumplings, which is sweet potato and pumpkin!
author: Athena C.

description:
Sometimes you need to class it up and Panda don't cut it!

Ambiance is dope, right under the Westfield dome
Food is fantastic, Yan aka the only Chinese chef I can name... can cook
Service is awesome, ASK FOR NIKKI, SHES MY FAVE, WILL GIVE YOU MORE HOT SAUCE

Tacos are awesomely kind of Peking Duckish & priced like La Taq in the mission
Boar scissor cut noodles are cheap and delightful, can't go wrong with any noodles here
Just like crispy duck rolls @ Hakkasan, my favorite things here are the cheapest!
author: Roger L.

description:
First time trying this place. 
The wait can be a little long, the price is slightly higher than other Chinese restaurants. 
But boy it is so worth it!!!
I am attaching pictures as I am not great with dish names.
I can't wait to go back and I ll probably have the exact same items. 
We absolutely loved the service the ambiance and of course the delicious food.
author: Imelda G.

description:
I'm not rating about the food in this dinning place but customer service, last time I've been here having a great customer service, and today I'm here again and I'm having a bad experience this time. 




Updated: my second time been this place total spend including tips was 85, and my credit card charged 90? Excuse me? The person who took care of this transaction need a shortsighted glass? I'm not complain about the over charge on my credit card, just 5 dollars. I'm complaining about the service, really?   "This is cute tho"  : )




Final update:

My problem is fixed, and I went back yesterday, the server was very nice. Hopefully this type of situation won't happen to anyone else. I would definitely come back with friends/families.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Overpriced, but definitely an interesting restaurant to check out, especially if you are ever in Westfield. The restaurant was very well-decorated. 

I ordered the Wild Boar Scissor Noodles, which was good! Add hot sauce and bam, the dish was pretty good. However, there wasn't enough "meat" either, especially in proportion to the onions and noodles. The noodles were fresh though and thick! $15 bucks - pricey, but try it at least once! 

I also ordered baby bok choy, which was very good! For $8, they gave a good portion. The vegetables were fresh, delicious and tasteful. I would definitely recommend ordering this side. 

As for customer service, our waiter was super attentive and attended our table pretty frequent
author: Chinsin S.

description: Food is very delicious. Six ways to cook crab! The noodle guy did gangnam style dancing while piling the noodles. So much fun :)
author: April J.

description:
M.Y. China is what I expected. Not necessarily authentic Chinese food, but good. I would have given 3.5 stars and rounded up to four, but the prices are really high for Chinese food that was good, but not great. Presentation was good, and I really can't complain about the food itself, but the prices are just too high for what you get.

We tried the dumplings, which were somewhat bland, but the texture was good. The beef rolls were not what I expected. I had thought it would be lighter and have more flavor. We also tried the kung pao chicken, seven spice pork ribs, and the dan dan noodles. These three dishes were very good. I'm not normally a kung pao chicken fan, but the way they treated the peppers was excellent. Lots of flavor and surprisingly good. The seven spice pork ribs was a pork rib that was basically a version of what you would get for a salt and pepper pork chop at a regular Chinese restaurant. It was good, but overpriced. The dan dan noodles is served chilled with some heat and was also tasty. So, basically, 3-2 when it came down to which dishes were good.

Minus a star for them adding an extra $2 to my tip, which I noticed on my online credit card statement. I had already given an 18% tip, so I was a bit shocked and had to do a double take. I thought about letting it go since it's only $2, but it just didn't sit well with me. This prompted me to place a dispute with my credit card and call the restaurant. They called me back after I left a message and said they would look into it. Shortly after that first call, they called again saying that they needed to have a General Manager, who would not be in until after the weekend, credit the $2 back to my card. Finally, I got a call a few days later saying they would credit my card, and a few days after that it finally showed up on my online statement. Because of the trouble I had to go through, I have rounded down what would have been a better rating.
author: Ruben P.

description: Definitely a place to eat if your in the mall or in the area and are unsure of where to go. The portions are decent for the price and the food is delicious as well. They do have cocktails that are tasty as well but I think the drinks are more overpriced compared to the food. The service has always been amazing the times I've been there as well.
author: Nathan S.

description:
I'm a world traveler and have lived in Northern California's wine country for the last 12 years. I've been to many of the great restaurants around the world and I gotta tell you, this meal was right up there with the best of them!  

My friend and I went to the MY China at the Graton Casino - and you can see my review there, it was horrible service and horrible foood. But we were persuaded to try the M.Y. China restaurant in SF as it was supposed to be outstanding. So glad we did! It was beyond great! It was a fantastic experience!

The online marketing manager, Carol, invited myself and a guest to the SF restaurant for dinner. She suggested the lobster. So we got there and ordered: 2 garlic lobsters (2 lbs EACH and seriously, just one was enough for 3 people), 2 glasses of chardonnay, 2 cocktails (Mai Tai and an East Meets West), 1 order of juicy dumplings, 2 papaya and shrimp salads, a plate of wild boar noodles and for dessert, these delicious giant cream puffs with melted chocolate sauce, raspberry sauce and whipped cream. (We ended up taking home the wild boar noodles which were okay, but not great).  

I'm embarrassed to admit this, but my brother and I seriously killed it. We ate it all! I was afraid that they were going to award us the Trough Award for being the biggest piggies. Ha!  The food was so impressive, we can't wait to go back and try their garlic crab! And the waitress kept recommending the chicken salad, so we will definitely be back for that as well as the Papaya and shrimp salad.

The lobster is the one dish that I recommend everyone try. It was incredible! (Like an orgasm in my mouth!)  It was cut up into manageable pieces and had fried garlic everywhere. It was outstanding!  An absolute must try.  Another stand out dish was the papaya and shrimp salad. It blew our minds with how good it was. I have never eaten fresher or better tasting shrimp! 

The bar was crowded and for good reason. My brother loved their chardonnay wine and I loved their "East Meets West" cocktails.  (Just thinking about my meal is making me swoon.)  If you can force yourself to eat one more thing after eating the lobster, I highly recommend the egg puffs with the two sauces.  

(Pardon me, I've got to go wipe the drool off my keyboard as I write this!)

My experience in San Francisco was so different from the one I had at M.Y. China at the Graton casino, I find it hard to believe it's the same ownership!  They seriously need to send the SF manager, Daniel Nunoz? to that Casino and whip it into shape!

Okay, bottom line, growing up in the SF area (Hello, Pacifica!) I've enjoyed hundreds of Chinese restaurants, BUT have never, ever, had such a gourmet experience as what we experienced at M.Y. China SF!

The decor was stunning - we loved looking at the massive, ornate rotunda dome while eating. And the decor and food were not the only things 5 star about this restaurant - the service was superb!  Couldn't have been better. Listen, I know I'm gushing here, but M.Y. China needs to be the place you go to with friends and family to celebrate . . . well, anything! I will definitely be back with my family and friends. I can't wait for them to try the food - especially the LOBSTER!

PS: Location is at the mall on Market St.. Parking was only $1 an hour at the Ellis-O'Farell Parking garage, which is free valet parking and only a block away.  I would post several of the photos I took, but I can't figure out how to do it.  The photos would make you pick up the phone and make a reservation right now!

You gotta try this place. I was overwhelmingly surprised at how good it was.
author: Anne J.

description: Food is ok but the service is atrocious. Waitress took the order and then never came back. Requested standard condiments (soy and chili sauce) numerous times, no one brings it.  And they clearly don't care.
author: Alex S.

description:
I was shocked when Mama Fabulous (my momma) said she wanted to try M.Y. China. It's not her usual style to try these kind of restaurants, but who am I to say no. Whatever Mama Fabulous wants, she gets. And plus, we watched Yan Can Cook in the house growing up, so I was curious to try his restaurant.

Upon arrival, I was immediately turned off by the open mall seating. We were seated at a table that was half indoors and half in the mall. It made me feel like I was eating at a food court! The servers were also unhelpful and piled the dishes on our table without giving a care about placement. It felt they were all eager to get the dishes out of their hands ASAP.

On to the food!

Juicy Dumplings: Our favorite dish of the night. The skin was thin and the filling was soft. Extra points for the crab dumping because we can really taste the crab flavor.

Salt & Pepper Calamari: Not bad, a little on the spicy side. It wasn't anything too special though.

Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup: This was good too. Nothing to rave about. Portions were small, especially given the price. 

M.Y. Sweet & Sour Pork: Mediocre

Jasmine Tea Smoked Sea Bass: The sea bass is pretty flavorful, but I've been spoiled by a similar dish at R&G Lounge that is to die for!

Twin Scallops Fried Rice: Meh. It had little fresh scallops in it, but it was a bit bland.

Overall, I think M.Y. China is worth a try if you're a fan of Martin Yan.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
mmmm, main complaint that it is overpriced for what you get. we went for lunch on saturday and the restaurant week wasnt available! SAD. so then we had to browse the extensive menu and pick out the gems - which was hard, especially because one of my friends is vegetarian.  anyhoo - we got: dumplings, crispy egg rolls, XLBs, wild boar scissor cut noodles, crispy tofu, and char siu. ended everything with matcha tiramisu. sooo honestly, nothing was BAD, but everything was just okay. XLBs didnt have a whole lotta flavor, and the char siu was a bit tough.. the noodles were probably my favorite thing, but if there wasnt hot sauce on the side, they'd be slightly bland! WAH!

really good cocktail list!  this is definitely a chic chinese restaurant ahah - less expensive than hakkasan, but i think not as delicious either, so depends on what kinda experience you want. i would probably come back but...not without hesitation.
author: Christina L.

description:
Great atmosphere, busy, attentive but not obtrusive servers, probably the most stylishly served dumplings I have had anywhere - Tasty Too.  

Terrific selection of teas and drinks.

Seasonal Dungeness crab in Clay Pot with Rice Cakes is a trifle low on rice cake, but otherwise very very tasty if pricey @ $52.00, but Crab in the area is A. Q.  (As Quoted)

Parking in the area is pretty much 5/Mission otherwise Uber or Lyft.  The location is an urban center.  

Reservations are a must. I'll be back for sure.
author: Parrish W.

description: Since we were so disappointed during our last visit not to be able to try the Chengdu dumplings from the special menu, because they were sold out, Carol the Manager reached out and asked us to come back.  We took her up on that generous offer and sure enough there were dumplings for all!  They were just as good as what I dreamed of, actual chunks of filling in a delicate wrapper. Craig, the GM stopped by and let us know that the dish was so popular they are adding it to the regular menu.  SCORE!
author: Heather D.

description: Dined in for a late lunch with the whole family while we were in town visiting. Oh my, their spiced crispy ribs are delicious! Skip the xiao long bao! I tried it and it was subpar. We also tried the yang chow fried rice and the peking duck. But my vote goes to the ribs. We didn't have to wait but needed to split our party into two tables, which was fine. Anyway, I'd come back here again.
author: Mika D.

description: Very clean taste Chinese food. Great Beijing duck. Delicious dimsums - great chicken feet. Good to pair with milk taste oolong tea.
author: DJ K.

description:
The wild boar scissor cut noodles will haunt your dreams in the best way possible! Tasty & toothsome!

The Szechuan string beans are searingly spicy- and delicious. 

The xiao long Bao soup dumplings are very good. Only critique is they're served on spoons individually and to avoid sticking, they add a thin slice of pickle in between spoon and dumpling. The taste of said pickle is somewhat unappealing. 

Don't let the mall location fool you- this is a top notch Asian restaurant. Don't forget those noodles! And take a ride on the spiral Escalators while you're there!
author: Robin W.

description: The food delicious... delicious delicious. I'm a resident from San Diego CA were we have awesome food but My China restaurant I can only say it was so good. Just look at the picture. Customer service needs a little improvement but it's worth trying the food.
author: H. L.

description: This restaurant is decent. If one is looking for a clean place with good service, this is the place. They are pet friendly, too. The food is average. The bang bang chicken wings were ok and could have been a little more crunchy. Our scissor cut noodle dish was just the average pan fried noodles.
author: addoo d.

description: It's in the middle of a mall so points off for ambiance right there. But the inside of the restaurant is nice, modern, a little dark. The hostess was pleasant but our server and the other wait staff helping us were gruff. "Can we have another bowl?" and he answered, "Uhkay," as he walked away, frowning. Never produced the bowl - guess the three of us were supposed to eat that won ton soup with the three spoons, two bowls and one SERVING bowl they gave us. Geez. They call their xiao long bao (soup dumplings) "juicy pork/crab dumplings" here. They are served on individual soup spoons inside the steamer baskets with a slice of cucumber under each dumpling - the spoons take a while to cool off so it was tough for some of us to even pick it up for a while, and the cucumber gave the dumpling a weird taste I don't expect from xiao long bao. We had some crispy noodles and fried rice that were very tasty, and the won ton soup was good (even though I ate it out of the serving bowl). But nothing memorable. And btw this is totally overpriced for Chinese food. You can find better for cheaper. I won't go out of my way to go back.
author: Florence A.

description: Noodles are not good quality and are over cooked. Flavors are bland. Overpriced. Overall, bad noodles for San Francisco, especially for the price. Head over to Chinatown for better quality and price
author: Sara S.

description: Been here many times with my friend. We like this place because it's very connivence, after shopping, it's a good place for ppl stop by, drinking, eating & chatting. Like their atmosphere not too loudly very enjoyable. Today we order some special stuff since the Chef who know my friend, he made lots of special stuff for us. Very beautiful and tasty. Recommend ppl come here try their food.
author: Yueming G.

description:
I'm a fan! The interior is luxurious with hints of Chinese decoration, and the food is great (don't let the restaurant in a mall thing deter you!). 

For 2 people, we ordered to share:
- Spicy seafood dumplings: Delicious. The seafood was plentiful, juicy, and fresh. The spicy dipping sauce that came with it was also perfection.
- Beijing knife cut noodles: Don't remember the exact name, but I also enjoyed this dish. It came with a lot of seafood, and the sauce was pretty good. My main critique is that the noodles were not al dente (too soft) which detracted from the dish).

On the pricey side for Chinese food, I will definitely be back for the comfortable seating, good service, and solid food. The drink menu looked really good as well.
author: Claudia C.

description:
One of those restaurants located at the top dome of the Westfield mall. They have outdoor seatings that are part of the mall. Since it was my first tine coming here with my mom, we asked the host if we could browse the inside of restaurant first before we decided to dine in. Very modern trendy ambiance with the asian/Chinese theme since it is a chinese restaurant. They had that somewhat looking bell by the bar area. Had like an open kitchen. Told the host that we decided to dine in. He didnt ask us if we wanted to sit indoor. Not sure if they wanted to fill the seats outside first even though there were actually people inside.

Anyways, lets talk about the foods.
1. Mu shu pork tacos (comes in 2). They put too much of the green onions. The meat has a good amount of flavor
2. Chicken wings. Although its a tasty chicken, Had a lot of sweetness flavor on the skin in the beginning when i first bite into it. taste better with the rice
3. Squid ink snap noodle with seafood. Theres more vegetables/bell peppers than the seafood proteins. The squid ink snap noodle, never taste the squid ink on noodle before so taste wise was not bad. Interesting flavor. There was some juice at the bottom of the plate that had some salty flavor

Decent experience here
author: Julie N.

description: Chef Tony Wu is an artist. The dishes are delicious and artistic. It's an amazing dining experience!
author: Jiayu J.

description: Strongly recommend longtivity noodle soup
author: Olga Z.

description: Tony the Chef is one of the best original chefs as well as original and authentic recipes in the world! Craig Berold GM is awesome and treats his employees and customers fantastic...and Edgar and Leo the bartenders are the best at what they do and very creative with drinks and cocktail selections!!!
author: Johnny D.

description: Was craving good Chinese food but was disappointed. Waiter took our order and never returned. Had to literally call the restaurant to request they send someone to our table with the check. Addressed this with the person who brought us the check and she literally just looked at us like, " ok and ?". No gesture no acknowledgement, NOTHING.
author: Art R.

description:
I've amended my review. The manager reached out to me, we had a great discussion, and I'm convinced we just happened to visit them on a night where their game was a little off. 

It is a beautiful place and for certain - no one invests that kind of energy into the way something looks (and the way the food looks, it's worth noting, is like art).

But, because the management was so concerned about our experience and specific during our discussion, I'm guessing they usually get things right.
author: Todd B.

description: Checked out the place with a friend for our birthdays because I read on previous Yelp reviews that they had hand-pulled noodles here. Unfortunately, they use a machine now for their noodles, so it's not the true experience. That being said, we ordered the beef noodle soup, the dan dan noodles, and the garlic pea sprouts to share between the two of us. The dan dan noodles (cold) were solid but unmemorable, but the beef noodle soup was good but not spectacular, with a rich, flavorful broth that was a bit on the salty side and a pretty decent noodle that was in the style of hand-pulled noodles -- thicker noodles with a bit of a chew to them. Garlic pea sprouts, while a little on the pricier side, was definitely one of the stars of the show. Solid 4 stars here, especially for the attentive service and pleasant atmosphere, which was really conducive to a long conversation.
author: Elaine C.

description: Expensive but delicious!  So far I've tried the Mapo Tofu + rice, and the Yang Zhou fried rice.  Both were good!
author: Julia Y.

description:
The atmosphere and the food are out of sync here. With great service in an art gallery-like dining room, they are clearly trying but fall sort of justifying this price.

The $16.00 Mixed Greens with Papaya and Grilled Shrimp salad did not meet expectation. The papaya was only a garnish hard and sour but the dressing was flavorful and the shrimp delicate, perfect.  

At $38.00 the Jasmine Tea Smoked Sea Bass was also very delicate but too sweet to enjoy. A very small portion of mixed greens and a sweeter dipping sauce accompanied it. This dish is screaming for some contrast like rice. 

At $18.00 the M.Y. Sweet and Sour Pork pieces were large with a hard thick batter crust over moist and tender pork blobs.

Although food tastes can be very subjective, It seems to me these dishes fall short of being as extraordinary as the price and atmosphere.
author: Caesar A.

description:
I've walked by M.Y. China multiple times while shopping at the mall and attended events at Bespoke, but honestly I assumed that this was subpar touristy Chinese food. I was proven wrong when I finally had the chance to visit with a giant group of people. And by giant, I mean like 15-20 people. Crazy! We were there near closing time, but the staff was still very accommodating and patient with us.

The benefit of dining with such a large group is being able to eat family-style. I swear I got to try almost everything on the menu, including the Big Knife Fish Noodles, Dan Dan Noodles, and Venison Chow Fun. All the noodles were delicious, and I love that M.Y. China is not shy with the amount of spice they use in their food. The flavors in every dish were on point.

This restaurant is ideal for bigger groups, because trying only 1 or 2 dishes does not do the menu justice. I would imagine that making a reservation here is optimal, though having to wait while in a mall is not the worst scenario imaginable. Would recommend, whether you're a local or visitor!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
the best Peking duck ever ever
you have to try it to believe it
definitely will visit again when we're in San Francisco
author: Danielle N.

description:
Really good Chinese food. I think if it were in China, it would be a popular restaurant. Service is good, too. 
M.Y.China is in the Westfield Mall, near Powell Bart Station and the Market Street. It's absolutely a nice place.
author: Guanpeng Z.

description:
It was unexpected tasted good for the Xiaolongbao. Of course i like their chicken wings and tofu. I love their drinks, i meant cocktails because i only order cocktails. Very good place to happy hour.  Order Xiaolongbao if you were here, it is a must. Xiaolongbao takes time to come, so order it first before you order other stuffs.
We miss the Xiaolongbao, we are going back there in coming Monday to do Happy Hour again. :)

The crabs are super good too. Must Try!!!
author: Meichelle L.

description:
A decent place to grab a bite while shopping - I would describe it as a slightly more authentic variation of PF Chang's. The service was spotty, there was a long wait between the drink order and food order, but once we put in our order, the food came out pretty quickly. 
The pork belly sliders and the scissor noodles were the highlights. The green beans were a decent side. I'd pass on the Mapo Tofu next time, the flavoring just tasted a bit off.
author: Gloria N.

description:
I give this place a solid 3.5**** If it wasnt for the price, then it probably would have gotten more stars. Was definitely $4-10 more dollars than what you would have normally paid. 


For the mall, this place wasnt that bad. The food was decent as well. It definitely wasnt your standard chinese food. More quality taste to it. 

The honey walnut shrimp was fire. I was wondering what that extra hint of flavor was. They mixed wasabi in with the mayo. It was really good. Their drinks were not that bad either. I got the East meets West. Had a nice old fashioned taste to it. Their pastas were really large sized too. Had lots of seafood. They definitely dont skimp on the ingredients. 

Their eggs puffs though. (CRY) I was expecting to bite into a warm, fluffy egg puff. Instead it was crispy and no flavor at all. Not even the sugar which it was coated in saved it.

The reason for the star deduction was the service. The food took really long for it to get to us. By the time we got out food. It was slightly cold. So our waiter was saying that the portions were family style. We asked if any of them came with rice. He said nah so we ordered a bunch of sides of rice as well as some fried rice. So when we finally got our food. We basically got double the amount of rice because our honey walnut prawns (which basically everyone ordered). 

Overall, the experience was alright. Will probably update it again if I go back.
author: Serggio A.

description:
I came here with my parents to use a $100 gift card we received for Christmas. Honestly, if we had to pay for our food out of pocket, I really do not think it would be worth it. 

The atmosphere is definitely nice. The interior is intimate, warm, and dimly lit. They had a gender-neutral bathroom which is something I thought I would only see at Berkeley (props for the inclusivity even if I think they just did it because they didn't have room for two separate bathrooms). 

The service was nice, no complaints there. 

We ordered the tofu eggplant clay pot, the squid ink noodles, half duck, and bang bang chicken. The bang bang chicken was probably my favorite dish. The sauce was sticky and just the right amount of salty and tangy. However, I know that this place is well known for their duck. Everything else seemed like something that I could either make at home or get at a much cheaper Chinese restaurant. The squid ink noodles were a bit disappointing. I've had squid ink dishes before and I know that squid ink has a very distinct, subtle flavor, a flavor I couldn't taste in their dish. 

What really threw me off was the size of their chopped vegetables. If I'm paying $15 for a dish, I expect the chefs to care about what they're making. In both the clay pot and in the squid ink noodles, the bell pepper and onions were cut in huge chunks, almost as if they were in a rush to chop them. Maybe I am missing the artistic/flavor purpose played by the roughly chopped veggies but to me, it just seemed a bit too careless. 

Tldr decent food but definitely not worth the price.
author: Sarah Y.

description:
Actual rating 3.5.

To quote Robin Sparkles, "Let's Go to the Mall!"

Lately the Westfield San Francisco is redefining "mall food" because their listings are places I would proudly admit to going. The No1DP had to buy some chocolate at the mall and one of the staff at that place suggested eating "under the dome". 

CONCEPT: A collaboration between Martin Yan (of Yan Can Cook, a staple resource for rice-cooker owners) and Ronny and Willy Ng, the owners of "Koi Palace" in Daly City. 

VENUE: One of the more "formal" sit-down dining options "Under the Dome", SF's premier dining area. There's indoor and "outdoor" seating. The No1DP and I chose to sit directly next to a "open kitchen" (it's actually partially sealed so less mess) so you can watch the cooking show in front of you.

SERVICE: A little slow on a Friday afternoon, but we managed to get our drinks and entrees in a reasonable amount of time.

No1DP and I ate here prior to a movie so we primarily went with their happy hour menu.
- Afternoon Zu (Zubrowka bison grass vodka, ginger liqueur, elderflower). A bit disappointed with this vodka because I had high standards for zubrowka, which is supposed to be high-quality polish vodka. It tasted like there were two conflicting "herbal" flavors in the drink.
- Vesper (Vesper Gin, vodka, Cocchi Americano. Shaken, not stirred). Slightly better than the Afternoon Zu, but the flavoring was still slightly "off".
- Buddha Breeze (Hangar One "Buddha's hand" vodka, thai basil & cucumber). Should have gotten this, his drink was mixed perfectly and tasted quite refreshing with a hint of tart.

- Shui Mai (pork, shrimp, morel mushroom), $5. The shu mai is a bit more plump than typically served at dim sum. Each piece was dense with meat.
- Har Gow (jumbo shrimp, served with spicy soy sauce), $5. Like the shu mai, the piece is more plump than typically served at dim sum. Had a slightly hard time picking it up with plastic chopstick. The skin easily came off from the shrimp. This is one of the pieces that goes well with chili and soy sauce - eating it plain tastes somewhat bland.
- Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup (slow simmered short rib, baby bok choy), $15. The dish had excellent presentation. Bok choy was slightly firm (just right!) and moist and soft ribs that could be easily sliced with the fork. Although noodle quality is not like Shangdong handmade noodles (my gold standard), it tasted more "doughey" and doesn't absorb too much of the broth.

In retrospect, though the No1DP and I liked our experience here, this restaurant is more suited for real dinner. Should we come back here I'd like to try more of their dinner dishes, especially their famed dungeness crab served in six different styles based on six regional Chinese cooking styles.
author: Isabella B.

description:
Much thanks to our waiter who moved us away from the kitchen when the bleach smell was too strong. (Thank goodness for clean kitchens!) 

For the price, would highly recommend Hakkasan. Order their duck or two ducks and sea bass. 

The food was hit or miss, horrible honey shrimp walnut (mayonnaise is a bad idea) and sea bass (sweet honey sauce?.) Wild boat noodles were good, similar to stir-fry udon but cut. Squid ink noodles were nice as well.

Not a place to go for those who like authentic Chinese. Seems great for those interested in Chinese fusion!
author: Mio S.

description: Have wanted to eat here for years, walked in got a table quickly.  Dumplings are a sizing, the hand cut noodles were very good.  The boneless pork BBQ was nice.  The walnut shrimp wok dish was very nice as well.  In general highly recommend we had a great time.
author: Ali A.

description: I went to M.Y. China for dinner with my friends on Friday and was so disappointed. The food honestly tasted fine (not the best Chinese food I had but still enjoyed it). However, everything else was a mess. The seats were so dirty so we asked them to clean it up and when it wasn't much better we asked them to move us. After that, we ordered our food. We waited for our last dish for so long but honestly the worst part was the inattentive staff. It is so hard to get anybody's attention here. Please improve the customer service...
author: Grace M.

description: Best happy hour in the city $5 for drinks and apps. Delicious. The tofu, calamari and dim sum is always a hit
author: Mary L.

description:
I came here recently for dinner with my boyfriend and another couple fully expecting Americanized, greasy Chinese food. While this is by no means "authentic", it was an enjoyable meal and the food was definitely of a higher quality than your average takeout joint. The interior is beautiful with some upscale touches and the restaurant boasts ample seating with enough space for a dinner party or intimate seating for couples. The other couple had been here a few times and guided some of our ordering. We ordered:

-Pork Juicy Dumplings ($9): Good soup dumplings, nothing out of this world. I would order these again if I were in the mood.

-Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles ($16): Really good. This was the first split dish to "go". The flavors were great and not too greasy. I would order this for myself next time.

-Chairman Mao's Chicken ($18): Not what we expected. The chicken was served with sauce on the side which is fine if an individual dish but to share was just a mess and there wasn't enough sauce. This was definitely the least favorite dish of the 4 of us.

-Wok Seared Beef ($20): Quite good also. I liked the arugula with it as a different flavor.

I will say, the one thing that was odd to me were the noodle chefs coming out in the middle of the dining room swinging noodles to "Gangam Style". I get that this is supposed to be fun but ultimately, I just felt bad for the chefs going through what seemed like a humiliating display. I felt somewhat uncomfortable during this, but maybe I am being a wet blanket.

Overall though, I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of the food and the portions. The 4 of us could not finish this amount of food even though we are all big eaters. The service was also very attentive. If I were in the mall and craving something a bit more formal than the food court downstairs, I would be more than happy to eat at MY China again.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Yes, It's in the Mall, But it isn't mall food by a long shot.
Think General Tso's Chicken made by hand. I physically watched a young apprentice hand batter the chicken, then fry it, then mix in all the ingredients and plate it. Yeah.
And Hand cut noodles. And Dumplings! and every other kind of treat for you tastebuds you can imagine. All amazing.
author: Carl O.

description:
M.Y. China is a special destination dining location. The Seven Spice Pork Ribs were transcendental, Chow Fun noodles as good as it gets (we had them prepared vegetarian with Tofu rather than venison), and be sure to try the Honey Walnut Shrimp.

Don't forget dessert! Egg puffs, light, airy and wonderful, served with two dipping sauces and whipped cream and/or the lychee Panna Cotta were ethereal. 

Worth the drive from Napa or the Peninsula. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jean M.

description:
It's ok.  Nothing special.  There are a million better Chinese restaurants in the city.  This one is just nice because it's one of the fancy Under the Dome restaurants, if you're into that kind of atmosphere.

The scissor cut boar noodles are wayyyyy overhyped.  The Peking duck is pretty decent.  I did really enjoy the soup dumplings, though the portions are too scarce.  The fried rice is sadly unremarkable, which was disappointing because you would think this staple dish would be reliable since the restaurant bears the branding of Martin Yan.

Overall, I would say this restaurant is overhyped and overrated for what it presents itself as.  I would go back probably, but it's not one of my favorites.
author: Tee B.

description: This is a cute spot and they have a secret menu (basic Chinese restaurant food on The secret menu) !
author: Eric G.

description:
It's never easy to write a positive review for a restaurant supposedly run by a famous chef that has a poor food safety score. With that being said, my husband and I ate lunch at M.Y. China a few weekends ago after an afternoon of shopping and running errands. We had talked about checking out the restaurant on multiple occasions but rarely find ourselves at the mall. 

The setting is pretty upscale given that it is in a mall, but it's not certainly a place I would get dressed up for. We started with two cocktails (greatly needed after traipsing through the mall). I had the Ginger Mist, and my husband had the Rum Blossom. Both drinks were well-balanced. For starters, we ordered the Shiu Mai and Pork Juicy Dumplings. They were very tasty, and on par with the dumplings that you can find in Chinatown. We also ordered the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, which was our favorite dish by far. I never had scissor cut noodles before, and I really liked the texture. I'm also a total sucker for anything with wild boar. The Sichuan Green Beans and Kung Pao Chicken dishes were fine, nothing super special. 

Overall, there are numerous places in Chinatown that I would prefer to eat at if I was craving any of these dishes, but it's a good option when you are in the downtown area. My only serious complaint would be the pricing. I found most of the dishes to be pretty overpriced, and thusly underwhelming (given the prices). Service was standard, as was ambiance.
author: Regina L.

description:
My husband and I felt like tourists walking around Downtown San Francisco.  We were deciding where to eat for dinner.  It was either M.Y. China or Cheesecake Factory.  We decided to go to M.Y. China inside the Westfield Shopping Center on Market St. between 4th and 5th St. under the old Emporium dome on the 4th Floor.  

I love watching Martin Yan's cooking show, Yan Can Cook.  Since this restaurant is Martin Yan's, I very much wanted to try the food for some time now hoping that the food is phenomenal and out of the ordinary.  I guess not because it was just mediocre.  We wanted so much for the food to be great.  

M.Y. China's ambience is modern and trendy.  One can view through the glass of the open kitchen watching the chefs and sous chefs working.  

The menu is plain and simple and all the items are sad to say, overpriced. 

There's also a SF Employer Mandates surcharge of 5% onto your bill depending on the amount of the food and beverage you ordered.  
______________________
FOOD:
We ordered three dishes among the two of us to share and were not filling and did I say overpriced already?

 - Hong Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken XO 雞球煎麵 $16.00.  
It was good and hot but average tasting.  I've had better in other restaurants which costs half the price.      

 - Mixed Greens with Papaya and Grilled Shrimp 木瓜煎 蝦沙律 $16.00 with mango and birds eye chilies.  
There were only six thin slices of mango and six pieces of whole grilled shrimp on a bed of mixed spring greens.  The dressing was oily and no flavor.  Although the mango was soft and sweet, the whole salad was not worth $16.00.  It was a small portion.  We saw another one of the same salad which was a bigger portion so that's why we decided to order it.  When ours came, the portion size was not the same.  Not worth it.  Wonder if it's because it's just the two of us and we ordered three dishes that's why our portions are smaller.  I hope that's not the case. 

 - Beef Noodle Soup 牛肉湯 麺 $16.00.
It's slow simmered short rib with baby bok choy.  It's a very small bowl and the ingredients only filled up like 3/4 of the bowl.  The flavor was good but there was not enough ingredients and it wasn't steaming hot.  Had better Beef Noodle Soup elsewhere.  
_____________________
SERVICE:
We're glad that our server was nice but he was semi attentive.  He did not even refill our bottle of water.   
_____________________
RESTROOM:
 - Restroom is Unisex.  It felt weird seeing men in the restroom together with the women.  Luckily, the restroom stall doors are completely tight.  The stall that I went to, the door lock was wet.  Eew!!!!!  Gross!!!!!  I wonder if it's someone's urine.  I definitely hope not because I touched it.  That was disgusting!!!!
_____________________

I wish I could give M.Y. China 5 stars but just couldn't.  The 2 stars I gave for this review was for the nice ambience and decor of the restaurant.  I thought M.Y. China doesn't use msg, but we were very thirsty afterwards.

Sorry, we would not return.
author: J W.
