description: What a surprise to find such delicious and unique dining in a mall!  Went here on a whim with my daughter and we were blown away by the quality of the food.  Highly recommend even though prices are a bit high, even for SF standards.
author: Jason J.

description:
Very bad experience! I was so embarrassed because I decided to take my bachelor party here because of me watching a special KQED on this place.

First off, our food came out at different times. From the first person to receive their food to the last it was about 15minutes. We had to keep asking when the last persons food was coming. Horrible!

Secondly, the guys who cleaned our table came in fast and started cleaning like they wanted us gone! We were not loud and we we're dressed appropriate. The busboy dropped a fork on one of my groomsmen and didn't even apologize. I wasn't finished with my meal and he kept coming back asking me if he could take my food ‍

Lastly, we asked our waitress to take us a picture and we had to wait for that as well. On top of us never finding her for refills and condiments.
This was a horrible experience and I would never go here again especially in a mall!
author: John-David V.

description:
Good food. Tried vegetarian and all the dishes were good.
Nice ambience and friendly staff
author: Arjan N.

description:
Short Story:
A decent Chinese restaurant despite it being overpriced...

Long Story:
I made a reservation for 3 here on a Monday night and it was about 25% full.  We were promptly greeted and seated at the door.
They have a pretty expansive menu and most of the dishes are pretty expenive.
Yes, you are in SF and in Union Square, so you expect to pay some...but stillit's a lot.
We got the xiao long bao, half peking duck, and fried rice.
The xiao long bao was okay, I've definitely had better both in Chinatown and at home.
The Peking duck was pretty good and authentic.  So was the fried rice.
I think our total bill was about $95 after tax and tip.

Verdict:
I probably won't be back anytime soon
author: Michael W.

description:
Meh, I was always curious about this place.  Had the yolk crab, pork belly sliders, some Dan Dan noodles, and other junk.  Really NOT impressed given the price.  I would expect better.  Go to koi palace or R&G lounge.  

With such a small menu, I wouldn't think you could mess it up.  Things ether had too much flavor or just oil taste.  

Customer service, meh.  They don't have enough people.  But you can tell moral is down.  They are definitely looking for other places.

All in all, big letdown 

Update for Carol:

Thank you for reaching out to improve the experience at your establishment.  In regards to customer service, there was not enough staff.  Had menus closed for 10 minutes (eye contact with waiter too) before order would come to be taken.  Asked waiter what items he would prefer but it didn't look like he knew the menu (could be new).  Food and bill took too long to come out.  2 Orders came out twice (would think this is a communication between expediter and waiters.
author: Nathan S.

description:
This is an update to my 12/28/2013 review of M. Y. China.

I was back in SF for the American Counseling Association annual conference.  I was staying at the Marriott and wanted to have dinner with a dear friend who doesn't get Chinese food very often.  So, after searching through Yelp and my iPhone, I saw a review for M Y China.  My previous experience was underwhelming, but being a forgiving sort of guy, I thought let's give it another try.  I reviewed the most recent Yelp reviews and noted the items that were mentioned consistently as excellent.  Taking my list and my friend, we went to M Y China on a Sunday night.

The room has not changed.  Great decor, especially the wall of Buddhas.  I'm a martini drinker and they had a "genever" on the menu (a historical precursor to gin). I was impressed.  It was a Netherlands genever (Bols).  Very good start to the evening.

We ordered the Pork and Crab Roe Soup Dumpling as a beginning.  Wow!  5 ceramic spoons with a cucumber on the bottom (prevents sticking), delectable broth, and hot (temperature) in a bamboo steamer.  So flavorful!

Then we had the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, Honey Walnut Shrimp, and Baby Bok Choy.  Triple Wow!  Each was a unique and distinctive take on a foundational Chinese food.  The noodles were perfection with delicious wild boar, scallions, and mushrooms.  The shrimp dish had a hint of wasabi in it, not in the least bit overwhelming but additive to the flavors of the dish. The bok choy had a touch of fish sauce, a staple in southeast Asian cuisine, and a tremendous complement to the perfectly cooked crunch of the bok choy.

Nothing else.  One of the best Chinese meals that I have ever had.  And to top it off, the owner, Martin Yan, was there, going table to table to ask the diners if their meal was good.  Nice touch, Mr. Yan.

So ... bottomline is that I'll be back.  Oh, and order this meal as it is simply perfection.
author: Mark P.

description: Sooo good! Not sure why the reviews are not higher. Went with a group of 4 and we Loved every dish we ordered. Favorites were probably the duck buns and egg tart brûlée. Good vibes. Lovely atmosphere but not too loud. Would recommend.
author: Vanessa M.

description:
Have been here 3 times and have had a great experience each time.

Regardless of the time or day that it happens to be, this restaurant is always packed!! It is a higher end Chinese fusion restaurant (very hard to execute) located on the 5th floor of Westfield shopping center. The restaurant itself is beautiful. There is an ancient bell decorating the bar and the kitchen is all glass and visible to diners. I was also impressed by the all-Chinese (or at least all Asian) kitchen staff, which made me think the food must be somewhat authentic :)

Cocktails are potent and beautifully presented - a bit on the expensive side $11-13. Wines by the glass are more reasonably priced. 

The noodle dishes are some of my favs on the menu. The beef noodle soup is delicious and has been my go-to when I have pho cravings (hard to find pho without MSG and other unhealthy ingredients these days). The beef is extremely tender and a bit fatty, the broth is savory with a bit of sweetness, and you get delicious bok choy. 

The total for 2 came to ~$70 for dinner, which is a bit pricey for 2 drinks and 2 entrees, but in my opinion, worth it for the high quality ingredients, amazing drinks and fun fast-paced environment. Nice option for a casual Asian fusion restaurant and when Hakkasan is a bit too over the top :)
author: Yin H.

description: Honestly I think I can cook better,service sucks,I'm not blaming my server because she's not Chinese,if you work in a Chinese restaurant you need to change your customers plate often,especially my plate is full of lobster shells...been sitting there for hella long,gave 18% tips but I'd never go back,I thought crystal jade is the worst but this place is just terrible,real Chinese food I preferred R&G or Yank sing...JS
author: Glenmorangie S.

description: We had a nice meal here, but we kind of expected a little more given the price and atmosphere. Everything was tasty, but aside from the green tea tiramisu at the end the flavors were nothin particularly special. The hand cut noodles had a great texture, but you could have told me it was pork and not wild boar and I wouldn't have noticed and it tasted like many other noodle dishes I've had. It was good, just not as special as it sounds. Overall you'll have a good meal here, just don't expect the best Chinese you've ever had.
author: Kyle D.

description: My friends and I always come here for a splurge lunch spot and we get their chicken Hong Kong style pan fried noodles, chow fun and the pork Shanghai soup dumplings.  Food is good, but service is a bit of a hit or miss.  Sometimes their on top of it, other times you're flagging any waiter down to get a refill on water or some sauce you need.
author: Carmen C.

description:
If you're at the mall, and want more of a sit down kind of dinner, it's an ok spot.  In my experience - the food was decent both times I went to this restaurant.  During the most recent visit, we had a few different servers (all generally attentive) except they were all single purposed - one took the food order, one or two different people brought the food, someone else checked up on us, as did the original waitress who took the order.  It was hard to know who to ask for things -  more water (the ended up just bringing us a bottle so we could serve ourselves), we asked for lemons & an extra plate which never came, and more food (we were ordering small plates so we added on to the original order).  This isn't a place I'd come back to unless there really wasn't another option - and in SF there are generally other options :)  If you're in a pinch and just want a snack in the mall, I would suggest trying another establishment - spend your money on something you'll actually enjoy :)

Update: As you can see Carol reached out, which indicates to me that they care about their service.  I'm not saying it was any better than the 2 star I actually gave it, but I will recognize that restaurants that are trying to improve are worthy of some recognition.  I bumped up my star rating for that purpose.
author: Priti M.

description: Panda Express is a lot better down stair fusion or no fusion waste of my time and money to eat here. Food too salty, staff slow but they nice people. Anyway if I can only give no start I will definitely will.
author: Joe L.

description:
A girlfriend mentioned we should all have Chinese New Year dinner. Since MY China was doing a special CNY menu between February 5th and February 20th, she suggested going here. We had dinner last Friday, February 19th. She made a reservation for 10 people at 7pm.

Grandma Wu's New Year Dinner ($38 per person for parties of 6 or more):
*Fortune platter: roast duck, squid, jellyfish, cucumber, barbeque pork
*Good luck soup: organic chicken, pork shoulder, dry seaweed, lotus root
*Ocean treasure: oyster, seaweed, lettuce
*Golden jade road: chicken, cilantro, beech mushroom, pine nut, bean sprouts, lettuce wrap, crispy wonton nest
*Perfect catch: whole fish of the day, pepper, green onion, chili bean sauce
*Happy opportunity: organic fried chicken
*Long life: bbq pork, shrimp, pepper, beech mushroom, egg noodles, xo sauce
*Child's delight: strawberry and pineapple tapioca pearl, blueberry, mango, pumpkin puree

I'm off red meat for a while, so I wasn't able to taste the soup. But everything else was pretty tasty. (Make sure to ask for hot sauce if you wanna spice up your dishes.) The fortune platter had most things you'd find in a bbq platter on a banquet menu. I adored the roast duck and jellyfish. The ocean treasure is deep fried which I wasn't expecting. But the batter was nice and crispy. I love lettuce wraps, so I liked the chicken and mushroom wraps. The nest added a nice crunchy element. The whole fish was definitely a good size. I'm a fan of steamed fish with soy, green onion and ginger, so this was a little too heavy for me. Too much sauce. The fried chicken isn't the typical American fried chicken. More like a crispy chicken. And you can't have a meal without noodles! By now, I was getting super full, so I barely ate the noodles. They were al dente and had a nice chew. The dessert was something in between a palette cleanser and a shot of boba fruit smoothie. I thought it was a weird dessert.

Selected New Year Wine ($25 per bottle or $8 per glass)
*Prosecco, Gancia, DOC, Italy: fruity bouquet of golden apple and maple flavor x3
*Sauvignon blanc, Joel Gott, Napa, California 2014: bright citrus aroma complemented by tropical note x2
*Pinot noir, De Loach, Russian River Valley 2014: enticing with flavors of cherry, plum and rhubarb preserve x2

And what's dinner without drinks?! We decided to take the suggestions from the CNY menu and order all the bottles offered. They paired well and were fairly priced. I do enjoy a crisper sauvignon blanc and a drier bubbly, but these were still pretty good. The pinot was light and fruity which is the opposite of what I look for in a red. But the menu had lighter fare, so it went well with the latter dishes.

Being located in a mall, I thought the food was going to be way more Americanized. It wasn't as American as I thought it'd be. And the price point was definitely a win. Dinner plus drinks, tax and a very generous tip worked out to $75 each. Not bad for a wine filled CNY dinner.
author: Elena N.

description:
It's a place to bring Bob the Account Manager visiting from the Charlotte branch office. Def splurge on the expensive meat and fish entrees. The quality of ingredients speak for themselves. The cocktails are nice too!

The rice and noodle dishes are really not great, though, and those "small eats" are where authenticity counts. The beef noodle soup simply can't compete with similar fare in Chinatown and Inner Sunset/Richmond.

It seems like the team here works hard though, so I don't want to knock em too much...
author: Ken H.

description: Great food, quick service, friendly staff! For anyone having trouble finding this based on the address, it's on the 4th floor of the mall.
author: Valerie C.

description: Just had dinner with my girlfriend here today. And we both get food poisoned. This restaurant needs to do better for its price.
author: Yueyang J.

description: Hi I was going for a massage and am stopped by to get something to eat befor.  I ordered the beef noodle soup.  First thing I said is this is a lot of food.  My first spoonful was the broth.  OMG.  Was it good.  It was rich and tasty. The second thing I tried were the noodles another Omg.  The noodles were light and were a perfect compliment to the broth.  Then I had the beef it was tender    Three Omg in one dish.   I keep trying to get back can't wait for my next massage appt
author: Katherine M.

description: Booked the restaurant for birthday gathering. We ordered many dishes to share. Both vegan and not. All were good. Service was great.
author: Saran D.

description:
Expensive Yan restaurant.  Really wanted to like this place as I followed Yan cooking show as it improved my skills years ago... But it's very Americanized Chinese rendition.

Won ton is small and full of fat, ditto for the shumai and far from excellent for the price.  Just go to millbrae for the real deal.  Kitchen at millbrae is 50% larger, juicy and tasty in contrast.

Even with happy hour prices I don't think it's worth it for foodies.  The wings for example also pales when compared to angel wings in crunch or taste.

Only win here is the good alcohol drinks not found in Chinese restaurants.

British word poser also appropriate in this target rich environment.
author: David H.

description:
I give one star because the "Beijing knife cut noodles" are disgusting and not even knife cut. They were lasagna styled noodles that looked like raw bacon or some kind of seaweed. Very gross

However, the service and the atmosphere  along with the juicy pork dumplings was beyond 5 star. 

I'm Chinese and very familiar with Chinese dishes and knife cut noodles are SUPPOSE to be ACTUALLY CUT with a knife. 

If you go...order everything BUT the Beijing noodles. 

It needs to be discontinued or properly prepared. 

(The kitchen was Asian staffed) nothing wrong with that. I just don't understand why a Chinese chef who opened a franchise would want to shoot himself in the foot. 

I will not come back here. 

I'd rather just make these noodles myself and comeback for the pork dumplings.
author: Jon L.

description: Amazing food. Great service. The best things my wife and I tasted today was the honey glazed pork, the matcha doodle ice cream and the egg puffs.
author: Joshua B.

description:
3/26/16

This is Chinese food is presented in an upscale and elegant manner with a definite cool factor.  MY China gets extremely busy during dinner time so if you plan on a day of shopping and dinner later, may I suggest booking an appointment (online)?  I did it with Open Table.  There was one occasion where we couldn't get in so either it was too late, to capacity, or just under forecasted how many diners there were going to be that night, but what they hey,

As we approached, there was a long line so I thought we would miss our reservation.  Happily, a greeter came down the line and asked who had reservations.  "We do, We do!!"  The hostess whisked us to a table that was waiting for us.  

Our strategy was only to order what we could finish.  The other method is to order lots of things in order to get a taste of more things and take home leftovers.  But you know the old saw - "You wok it, you eat it."  Its not quite the same after you get it home!  

The fare for the evening was:
Seafood dumplings:  excellent, served over a sauce.  Good choice

Wok seared beef:  delicious;  served on a bed of arugula and IMO I think the dish could stand to be more colorful if they used some colorful garnishing.

Scallop fried rice:  an all time favorite

Aaaaaaaand.... the piece de resistance:  the honey walnut prawns.  My buddy ordered this and my first thought was "but you can get this on Clement Street."  I'm glad I kept my mouth shut because there is a sublety to it that you can't get elsewhere.  We didn't first know what it was, but the wasabi gave it a kick in the pants.  It was served immediately after it was prepared because the prawns were still delicate and crisp after the sauce was laid on top.

Although hectic, the staff was gracious and spot on.

At their Rohnert Park location (now closed ) I also liked their Kobe Beef Medallions.  At the time it was served in a basket made of deep fried rice noodles.  Love their Spring Rolls.  

I do think a basic type of tea, for example Oolong or Bo Nay should be comped with a meal as with not so elegant restaurants.  The exotic teas are pricey so we opted with water.

Will try other things in the future.

It IS an authentic Chinese restaurant because there are toothpicks at the front reception podium .

ps:  I don't know what's the big deal with Gai Lan.  Having had it all the time growing up, it is still sprouting out my ears.  Wont order that!

pps:  Check out the bathroom.  It is very elegant and progressive.  The main area is a long trough sink for all sexes for hand washing and primping.  There are 2 very private floor to ceiling stalls so that cures the 'bathroom conundrum' if there are gender issues.  (oh, I stand corrected: there are 3 stalls)
author: Kevin L.

description: We came here on a Tuesday afternoon. The place is very clean and beautifully decorated. You will not find a cleaner Chinese restaurant in San Francisco. But I am sorry to say their food is horrendous. The wonton soup is salt water and the wonton had a skimpy filling with a thick wrapper. The Beijing Knife Cut Noodles wasn't very good. We also ordered the honey glazed walnut prawns. It was disgusting. Not crispy but gooey and way too much mayo. I cannot believe they actually serve this crap to people. Do yourself a favor and stay away from this tourist trap. Martin Yang please close down this restaurant. The food sucks. :)
author: ryan d.

description:
Oh dear. Don't judge me. I ate here. Yes.. a Native Chinese American person born in San Francisco ate at this Chinese restaurant at the mall............... I know.. I know..
I hate myself for paying for overpriced Chinese food.. especially because Chinatown is like, a mere 15-20 minute walk away. I KNOW.

But, I trust my friend's taste. She comes here all the time with her mom when they go shopping. She said it was good! And, to be honest, it was better than I was expecting. Pricey? Yes. But I think it's fair for the quality of food and to be honest, most of these items are, in fact, a step up or slightly different than what you would get at a typical Chinese restaurant, so it's worth the extra.

AND, hello, CLEANLINESS and convenience at the mall? FINE. Not to mention, it's beautiful inside and the service is amazing. AND they have happy hour?! (I need to return for happy hour for one of my shopping days! It's M-F 3-6)

We got the wild boar scissor cut noodles, dan dan mein, and string beans. They were all delicious and we got fair portions.. and even some leftovers!

I would recommend this restaurant....... (/slightly hides in shame). But, really. This place is pretty darn decent. Good job, Martin Yan! You did well. I'm really happy this place lives up to your name!
author: Emily C.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend and his family while they were visiting us. 
I cannot for the life of me remember our waiter's name but he was phenomenal and made excellent recommendations. 
My boyfriend had been to M.Y. China before and had met some of the staff. Chef Tony was kind of enough to prepare a special appetizer for our table that wasn't even on the menu!

The dishes are very large portions and best served family style. We order a couple of different dishes and shared them. While I am a vegetarian, the others in my party were very happy with their choices. 

We ordered:
-Forbidden Rice: very unique but delicious, great texture, best as a side dish. 
-Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles: my boyfriend and his father raved about this dish. They dubbed this one their favorite of all that we ordered. The noodles were cooked perfectly and the texture was phenomenal.
-Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood: this was my boyfriend's mother's favorite dish. She talked about it the rest of their trip. Very unique from other dishes but tasted excellent. 
-Mapo Organic Tofu: this was my personal dish. It was amazing. The sauce was spicy but not overwhelming. The tofu was soft and the texture was creamy. I loved it!
-Kung Pao Chicken: not as special as the other dishes but I think it was just overshadowed by the unique dishes we had. This is probably a dish that would be a safe bet for someone less adventurous or willing to try something considered a traditional Asian dish. 
-Sugar Egg Puffs: yum! This might be one of my favorite dishes. Crispy but airy, this dessert was elegant to say the least. They come with a cream as well as a raspberry and chocolate sauce to put on the top. I still dream of these. A must. 

We had a reservation. It is a popular spot but it seemed like people did not have to wait long to be seated in my opinion, based off the changing people around us. 
The staff is so kind and we never once felt rushed or hurried through our meal. I can't wait to go back.
author: Taylor W.

description:
The review is not about the food, it's about their reservation management. 

I made a reservation through Yelp for 8:30 pm. One day before, yelp sent me a text message reminder and reiterated reservation for 8:30 pm. On the evening of the reservation we are on our way and we feel that we might be late 5-10 min. I call the restaurant to let them know and to my surprise the restaurant is only open until 9:00 pm! 

Why would you allow people to reserve 30 min before you close? Worst, why would you confirm the reservation and not call back to say that you'll close 30 min after the reservation!!! I'm very surprised!!!
author: Hoda M.

description:
FOOD: 
MY China is really good for fancy Chinese food. I really enjoyed the calamari, which was a little spicy but super crispy, the bang bang chicken wings and the beef noodle soup!!! The bang bang chicken wings are really crispy and had a sweet sauce-I would get this if I went back. The beef noodle soup is really good here too!! The boar scissor cut noodles are also worth mentioning because of the delicious noodle itself. This place is pretty pricey for Chinese food but you're really paying for the ambiance, the classy environment and the upscale feel in the restaurant.

SERVICE:
Friendly staff. Food came out quickly.

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? Yes, if you don't mind the price.
author: Kelley Y.

description:
Generally I'm not the biggest fan of more Americanized Chinese food but I have to say, M.Y. China totally won me over! I came here for lunch with a few of my co-workers. We were a pretty big party (7 people) with no reservation but it wasn't too crowded and we were able to get seated immediately. 

These were the dishes I got to try:
- Milk Oolong Tea: The name of it is slightly misleading. It sounds like a boba drink but it's actually regular tea with the slightest hint of milk in it! I was pleasantly surprised by how much I liked it.
- Shiu Mai: Meh. Tasted okay but nothing spectacular. Probably wouldn't get it unless you're a huge shu mai fan.
- Har Gow: Tasted decent, but again, nothing too special. Although I really liked the sauce they provided with it. Had a little bit of a spicy kick.
- BBQ Pork Buns: I think the meat was a tiny bit on the dry side but overall I liked the seasoning and the texture of the bao.
- Egg Custard Bun: This was amazing. A tiny bit on the too sweet side but otherwise I loved it
- Honey Walnut Shrimp: the portion size on this was a bit disappointing given it's price point but the taste was amazing. A lot of times the shrimp coating is really soggy because of the sauce but they managed to retain the crispyness of the coating this time. Probably the best honey walnut shrimp I had!
- Wild Boar Noodles: Note, I have no idea what the meat was suppose to taste like so I can't really commentate on that but the noodles (which I believe are hand made) were so good! It was similar to udon noodles but not quite as soft and a little bit thicker, so definitely a must try if you like thick noodles.

Overall, slightly more expensive lunch/dinner location but not too bad for FiDi. Definitely would come back again, especially if I have dimsum cravings and don't want to walk all the way up to Chinatown
author: Cassie Z.

description: I had read online about M.Y. China, or Martin Yan China.  If you enjoyed Martin Yan on the television food network few years back, you will enjoyed his food here.  Fantastic.  Situated inside the Westfield mall, beautiful location, clean open atmosphere.  Shop and then have dinner. We came in early December for a pre-Christmas get together with my cousin's family--ten of us.  Peking duck is the best--buns just right.  Everything we ordered was tasty.  Surprise!  Martin Yan was there, came by and asked about our experience on every dish.  We took photos with him, must have been nearly twenty pics.  He was thanking us as customers, what a great chef and host.  This is the place for Chinese food in San Francisco.
author: C C.

description:
First time eating here. Food is served family style. My husband and I ordered 3 plates between us and we couldn't finish, but I think if we got 2, we'd still be hungry. 
We had:
 Da Dao "Big Knife" Fish Noodles- best noodles I've ever had. Life changing. Next time, I'm ordering my own... and not sharing.
Honey glazed BBQ pork- don't think sauce. Think roasted individually and hand rubbed with seasoning. Amazing flavor.
Forbidden rice- I liked it, but I'm a fan of wild rices. My husband and kids.. not so much. 
Jasmine Tea- if you're a true tea connoisseur... ask for another bowl to put your strainer. Otherwise, decent quality jasmine. 
Looking at our neighbors food, I'm going to try the Mixed Greens with Papaya and Grilled Shrimp Salad. 
We'll be back. With more people.
author: Christine D.

description: Came here recently after a long day of shopping and it made my day! We ordered two types of pork dumplings and the squid ink noodles. I was surprised that there was no wait, since it was a Sat night. The preparation here was excellent - the wrappers on the xiao long bao were super thin, and the soup was light yet full of umami-savoriness. The squid ink noodles were more like squink ink rectangles (not long noodles) and had a satisfyingly chewy texture. This dish also had really great wok flavor, which is almost impossible to replicate at home.
author: Jean L.

description:
Here is the most delicious Salt and pepper fried chicken wings,It's the best I've ever had.

The chef Tong Wy  is very enthusiastic,The manager is also very professional.

NO.1 IN DAN FRANCISCO!
author: Jun L.

description:
Boo!.. Martin wasn't in this time

but his food speaks 4 itself n makes up 4 Chef Yan not being there

this was my 2nd time going there, since my big 30th there in 2013!  Getting 2 meet my favorite chef from my childhood, Master Chef Yan during that time!  4 those of u who don't know him, he is pretty corny, but @ the same time the most personable, down 2 earth, funny person u will ever meet in ur lifetime.. his food on the other hand is top notch!

(feel free 2 jump down 2 the 2nd visit which is my current review, as I will discuss about my 1st visit 2 catch u up2 speed!)

During our 1st visit, I had the Hong Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken XO; it was the best! noodles were crispy, chicken was perfectly executed, as the flavors were there, moist n if a second extra, it would have been overcooked, the vegetables complemented it well, the XO sauce was so good!  My wife enjoyed her Wok Seared Beef n we shared the Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders; they were so freaking good!  Drinks were good as well, I had the Monkey Prince during that time.

(2nd visit)

this time around instead of sitting in a table, we sat @ the bar n instead of doing dinner as we planned, we did lunch just like the 1st time.. we ordered drinks 1st, we both had Mai Tais n then beers (Lucky Buddha beer n a local San Fran beer).. all the drinks were good, the Mai Tai was good n strong, the beers were good, especially the Lucky Buddha, 1st time having it

now the food..

we decided 2 change it up n although we wanted 2 order the same favorites we had our 1st time, we decided 2 try their dim sum, so we ordered their Beijing Dumplings, which were more on the dry side like pot stickers n they were really good n tasty, filled w/ vinegar, fresh pork n chive flavor n ingredients.. we also had the juicy dumplings, which came in a Big Bamboo Steamer, the server opened it up n viola 3 red spoons which each hold a pork dumpling w/ a spoon full of broth n 3 white spoons which each hold a pork & crab dumpling w/ a spoon full of broth.. we absolutely adored the presentation n we loved the pork n crab roe dumplings, they r the best so far in the planet! lots of flavor, crab does a dumpling good

service is top notch n consistent

u can watch the chefs cook, as the kitchen is viewable from the seats

the restrooms r unisex as u go in the restroom there r doors leading 2 the toilets n a shared unisex sink that can have 4 sets of hands washed

the decor is off the hook; Martin definitely put a lot in2 this place!

Martin Yan's China is definitely a top place 2 go here in the states!
author: Johnny L.

description: Came for Mother's Day and had wonderful meal. My mom and dad as well as my husband and 9 year old daughter came in am for brunch. We sat out in the atrium. Had dim sum to start including pork buns we were delicious and didn't need any soy sauce because they had such nice flavor. Then had pork dumplings and the combination pork and crab dumplings. Served on a spoon with juicy dumplings and ginger vinegar sauce. They were excellent and my daughter's favorite. Next we had the tenderloin slider which was ok. Peking  duck was outstanding as was the garlic steamed crab and coconut shrimp. Fried rice was delicious as well and the sugar puff dessert was a favorite. Definitely our new favorite Mother's Day restaurant
author: E T.

description: I have eaten at many Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area. I used to catch Martin Yan on "Yan Can Cook" on PBS back in the day..Make a connection: I wanted to eat here. I was pleased with the meal I shared with my date. We had calamari, beef rolls, pork belly sliders, gai lan, and the wild boar scissor cut noodles. I liked all of it and we got a good amount of food to give this place a serious taste. The scissor cut noodles had a generous portion, but they were not too exciting. I would compare eating here to going to a nice Asian restaurant like Osha Thai. Is Thai food better than Chinese food? Maybe..it depends. I liked the location at the Westfield mall and the nice decor and interior. My friend thought the service was kind of sloppy when they placed dishes on our small table without arranging anything. It was a good experience at MY China. Yan Can Cook and will cook!
author: Denise C.

description: I love to come to MY China for soup dumplings and the Shanghai style crab. Both are some of my favorites in the city. I also recommend coming for happy hour for the discounted dim sum selection and drinks!
author: Kent Q.

description: Love this restaurant. Ambience terrific and the food is incredible and beautifully executed. Thanks Chef! The service and the management are awesome! Thanks Craig. (the GM) for running a 5 star establishment! Trust me you won't be disappointed eating here!
author: Deborah B.

description: This is a nice place for Chinese food and it has a nice view of the Dome.  Food was served warm but they helped out nicely with a discount to get us back to happy.  The hot and sour soup has lots of fungus and chewy things that we liked.  The boar tacos were tasty with the hoisin and green onions.  Didn't like their cauliflower dish with mushroom.  Bathroom are unisex and have shared sinks.
author: Steve T.

description:
Positives: S&P calamari is delicious. Not too spicy and the sweet chili dipping sauce offers a nice balance to the spices. Second favorite was the shu mai. I loved the soy sauce dip. And it definitely was flavorful without using too many spices. Happy hour is the ideal time to come. Each appetizer cost about $5. The cocktails looked exotic but I have yet to try them. Serving staff was also super friendly. 

Negatives: Service was slow & the fried tofu was too spicy. Seating was tight-- almost elbow to elbow with the table next to you. It's best to order all at once because the servers hardly come back to place your order. 

Overall, I enjoy the happy hour. It's M-F from 3-6pm. There isn't a wide selection of happy hour items. I would say it's pretty cocktail heavy though so if you're in the mood to truly unwind, have a mixed drink! It should do the trick! I know I'll be back. My cousin and I often crave the S&P calamari.
author: Brittany D.

description: Our first visit here Genesis was our server.she made great recommendations and was attentive. That was last night. We are going back tonightt
author: Terri F.

description:
Did you know that my Mom took a cooking class from Martin Yan back in the day?  He was secretly one of my favorite people on TV growing up.  There were not a lot of Asian people on TV period, and I just loved seeing him come on TV!  "If Yan Can Cook, So can You!!!"  Then I got a bit older and my Mom mentioned that she had taken a class from him when she was thinking about being a Chef.  ZOMG (before zomg was even a thing...I feel old...)

Ok, back to the review. I have been begging the man to take me here and finally we got around to it.  We really wanted to catch happy hour, just in case it was a case of "not-worth-id-rather-go-to-chinatown-itis".  The atmosphere is rather nice for being in a mall.

I was pleasantly surprised.  I found that everything here was of a quality that made it worth a little extra cash.  The portion sizes were generous, and the happy hour prices meant it wasn't even a stretch.  

The hand pulled beef noodles were probably my favorite dish that we had.  Rich broth, tender (but a bit too much gristle) braised meat, perfectly cooked bok choy.

The Shanghai Dumpling/Soup Dumpling came way too hot to eat.  I was quite disappointed in these but found them overall satisfying.  They did not hold together if you tried to pick them up.  I think they know that their soup dumplings are not structurally sound because each one is served in a spoon.  I admit, Shanghai dumplings are hard to do right.  The meat and broth inside the dumpling was good, but nothing to write home about.

Bang Bang Chicken Wings were my least favorite dish.  The chicken inside was dry.  There was way too much sauce on them.  The sauce was very strong and overpowered any chicken flavor.  If you like really sweet slightly spicy and VERY sticky sauce, you will feel really happy that you can drink it off of a dry piece of chicken.  Like I said, not my favorite.

BBQ pork bun (steamed).  This is a classic dim sum dish for all beginners.  It was really fresh and quite delicious. Fluffy with all the right flavors.  I'll give M.Y. a good grade on these for sure.  The man loved them.  I would love them if I hadn't eaten way too many BBQ pork buns in my years and years and years of eating dim sum--thus being generally biased against BBQ pork buns haha.

The drinks are more affordable at happy hour, but with the rise of the artisan cocktail movement, the bar (no pun intended) for a good cocktail is high.  I thought my drink was in the middle of the road..

I really would like to give this place 3.5 stars but that isn't an option.  And I had a bit of a hard time going for 4 because I just reviewed Crystal Jade in the same Yelping session.  Now I'm second guessing myself am I even comparing apples to apples?  I hate when people Yelp comparing places that aren't apples to apples...  Ok, enough talking to myself.  

3 stars for Mr. Yan!  It's a billion times better than your fast food chain venture...oh yeah, I remember that (feeling old again...)
author: Susan C.

description: I'm not sure what to make of this place. Location aside (it's in a mall), it seems authentic in some ways yet gives in to Americanization in others. We started with the Beef Rolls which were excellent. We moved on to the steamed tofu and broccoli rabe which was outstanding with unique flavors. It was very fresh and unusual in the Shanghai style. We moved on to the Pea Shoots. Very solid. Then things turned odd. The vegetable fried rice was a bit too greasy. It should have been called parsley fried rice as it lacked real veggies. Arriving at the same time was Chairman Mao chicken which I assumed was their stab at good old American General Tso. Hoping that it was prepared in the Chinese style of flash frying in the wok, we were disappointed to find deep fried white meat cooked to maximum dryness. It came with tasteless sauces on the side. A bigger disappointment was the whole Dungeness Crab which was severely over cooked. It had a very tasty rub but the meat was stringy and dry. Service was excellent however. With all the great Chinese choices in SF, we will pass on this for a return.
author: David M.

description: Over priced relative to the quality of the food and atmosphere. I don't recommend it and will not be going back.
author: Ed W.

description:
My 6th time at this restaurant ... 
It is still good but found the appetizers had  shrunk a bit...
On the other hand the servers are nice and helpful... 
Inside is a bit loud but the outside is fine
I know I shall be back!
author: Gears J.

description:
Glad there's a clean fine chinese restaurant.. 
I love chinese food but I hate the fact that I have to bear the dirtiness and unhygienic environment when I go to a chinese restaurant. 
But My china seems clean and nice environment and the food and the plates seems clean too. 
Also the servers are kind and they seem professionally educated as a server. 
Well.. as for the food, I cannot say this is real authentic chinese food but more like americanized/ foreignized(?) chinese food. Not bad at all. I rather take this place to eat with my kids although it's less authentic.Also the chef came outside the kitchen and do some showtime, making long noodle sometimes. 
Anyways, I love their wok seared beef and wonton soup..
author: JS P.

description:
Gourmet food inside the Westfield Centre... Who knew? 

Had the pleasure of "meeting" Martin Yan a few years ago at a benefit in San Francisco. I say "meet" because he was mobbed by adoring fans from his PBS cooking days. Whether or not I knew exactly who he was, it was abundantly clear that he's a big deal.

When our reservation for four at R&G Lounge over Thanksgiving was canceled due to overbooking, M.Y. China saved the day! All we wanted was some Dungeness Crab, and I recall someone saying that the offerings at M.Y. China were pretty good.

On Black Friday, this place was crazy busy! Luckily they honored our reservation and we were seated in the back dining room where it was still bustling but not overstuffed with people. Kudos to the front of house manager who gave us the ten cent tour while we waited for our table to be cleared/re-set.

The party of four ordered a bottle of vino, garlic crab, chicken noodles with XO sauce, pea pods... plenty for everyone! Once the bill came, I was worried that we'd overdone it, but split four ways it came out to $40-something each, plus tip. Not too bad for a ton of good food!

Sure, you're in the middle of a mall, but who cares? Good restaurants can be found in alleyways, strip malls, basements... As long as it's tasty, I don't care!
author: Abby S.

description: Consistently good quality. Overall not a fan of Chinese food, but this place is legit!
author: Alex G.

description:
Saw this place by chance when strolling through the mall and knew it was right up my boyfriend's alley. I brought him and our friend back for an early dinner on a Saturday and it was still pretty empty so we were seated right away. 

Let me start by saying the interior is incredibly surprising for being inside of a mall, and that's what caught my attention in the first place. It's reminiscent of something you would find at the Wynn in LV. When you walk in, you pass the chef's counter where you can watch them pull noodles and prepare your dish which is cool, but the more romantic dim-lit seating is in the back. 

We ordered:
- Wonton Soup
- Chairman Mao's Chicken
- Hong Kong Crispy Noodles w/ Chicken XO

Honestly, the food wasn't bad but it was my least favorite part of this experience (along with the price). Although more innovative than P.F. Chang's, I felt the quality was about the same. The wonton soup was bland and unmemorable. The Hong Kong noodles barely had any sauce, and the XO sauce that was on it was overly fishy for me. The Chairman's chicken was definitely the best dish we had - it was spicy but incredibly flavorful. 

The service was excellent, and not one of our water glasses ever came close to being empty. I'm definitely looking forward to coming back and trying some of the other dishes, but if anything this place would be great for grabbing a drink or bringing a date - if they can get past the fact that you're eating in a mall.
author: Kate K.

description:
I tried the Buddha Breeze cocktail. I really like it a lot.  It had a citron and cucumber flavor.  I think it is better than the Hemingway daiquiri,  The Bang Bang chicken wings (Dry Fried chicken wings with sweet and tangy sauce) were also good. I also tried the juicy soup dumplings again. They were perfect. It tasted the same as before, fresh and juicy.

Customer service during Happy Hours was very good.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: Martin Yan can cook! I had a great dinner.  We started with the salt and pepper calamari, Mu Shu pork tacos, and Bang Bang chicken wings.  All were incredible.  The salt and pepper calamari had a spicy kick to them. I can't wait to go back and try everything.
author: Funk G.

description:
Noodles - got the beef noodle soup - AWESOME

the dim sum - YUCK. xiao long bao - great presentation, not so great taste, and skimpy serving of ginger. 
green onion pancake - didn't see any onion, felt very greasy
vegetarian sticky mochi rice - why no meat option?? glob of sticky yuck

har gow was ok
BBQ pork bun ok. 

mall location - distracting with screaming children. need to have glass wall to take kids outside if they are screaming and to keep screaming mall kids sound out.
author: Sophia Y.

description: We went here to have family brunch. The food was good. The waiters were awesome and very attentive. Sadly, the "management" was unprofessional, condescending and rude. They ruined a great meal. Before my elderly parents even finished their dessert, the "manager" asked us to hurry up since it was "a busy day." Everyone at the table was stunned. So they can't even wait for us to finish our meal and already asking us to hurry up and leave. Who in their right mind, asks customers to hurry up and vacate the table without even asking if we are done? Great way to end a meal M.Y. China. management. We will never return.
author: R B.

description: The only restaurant I have ever been asked to leave after eating because they "needed the table". Waste of money and terrible management. General Manager extremely rude. Save your money and eat elsewhere.
author: Jonathan M.

description: So glad the other restaurant Tap in the Westfield shopping center fourth floor  ignored me so I left .Then I  had a great experience at this super delicious restaurant   My lavender laced drink was so good I had 2 The service was really excellent and the staff is so friendly No wonder they are so busy.  I will add this to my favorite SF restaurants .  I visit at least yearly.
author: JoAnn W.

description:
Nice setting and quick food service but food was mediocre esp for the price.
Wild boar noodles- best dish, very good
Peking duck- dry and bland
Wok seared beef- over done and dry
Yang Zhou (BBQ pork, shrimp) fried rice - ok
Green beans- ok

Wanted to like it but I won't be back.
author: Lynn M.

description:
I've been here twice and have enjoyed myself on both occasions.

Hit:
The roast duck (crispy skin, steamed buns, f*** yes!!)
House Cocktails
Buddha Beer (because it comes in a bottle shaped like Buddha, duh)
Pork Belly Sliders
Wild Boar Noodles
Chairman Mao's Chicken

Skip:
Dan dan noodles (barely any meat, way too much $$)
Chicken Wings - ehh, not worth it

It can be extremely packed (read: get a reservation) inside the restaurant, which leads to having to yell a bit to be heard, but overall I always have a good time.
author: Andreas H.

description: Worst service to date... was asked to leave our seats while finishing our deserts. So is it customary to ask customers to leave their seats after they pay for their meals while in San Francisco??? ... poor food, poor management... over priced dim sum and Chinese food  for  "mall food"... go to Panda Express they'll at least treat you like a human being.
author: joe b.

description: I brought a party of 16 people to eat brunch and as we were eating our dessert, the General Manager asked us to leave. He said, "he needed to turn the table for other people and we have been there too long". I spoke to him after he asked my parents to leave and he said, "that he had the right to ask us to leave." I found that extremely rude and unprofessional. General Manager needs to take some management courses and learn about customer service.
author: J B.

description:
I had dinner here because it was included in the "Top Chinese Food in SF" article of Eater San Francisco. The restaurant is on the 4th floor of a nice shopping mall. It had the look and feel of an elegant upscale restaurant, and service was very attentive.

As appetizer, I ordered pork xiao long bao (called Pork Juicy Dumplings on the menu). I had eaten xiao long bao in Shanghai, China, at Din Tai Fung (California, Washington State, and Ontario), Asian Legend (Toronto), and at many lesser Chinese restaurants in New York City, Philadelphia, and Washington DC. Comparing with these, MY China's xiao long bao ranks at the bottom because its dough skin is too thick and there is very little broth inside the bao. After reading rave reviews about MY China's xiao long bao, for me the real thing was a disappointment.

For main course, I had the black pepper snapper with tofu. This dish was done well. What I found irritating was that rice did not come with this main course, and if I wanted it, it's another $2. No side rice for a $23 main course? Not cute.

If MY China truly offers top Chinese food in San Francisco then I am not impressed.
author: Trong D.

description: When low quality Chinese food is flooding the market, this one stands out by offering high quality Chinese food. If you are sick of all those greasy Chinese food, maybe you can give this one a try!
author: Beth G.

description: This place honestly has just gone down hill. A couple years was decent. Now food is meh, service is even worse.
author: Xiaoying T.

description:
The hustle and bustle of this place is testament to its gregarious staff and regal interior, definitely not the quality of food.

The few times I've eaten here have not been satisfying in taste. The portions are fine, for what you pay, but I get the impression they're pushing out dishes (and keep in mind it still takes a while to get your food) to hit quantity over quality. Noodles are not always cut in proportion, meat can be too dry, and some of the garnishments just taste off. Conversely, some of the meat is hella good (venison) and the appetizers are more reasonably prices and scrumptious (all the dim sums are winners).

My recent grievance that inspired this review lies in three factors:

1) Long wait time even with a reservation and they initially forgot my soda (which is not the first time, maybe they just think soda is pedestrian).

2) Crispy roast chicken was just bad, very dry, very bony, and the skin was too thin to carry much flavor. Salt plum seasoning is a curiously nasty move, tasted like cinnamon and cummin got into a death match, but initially it did help the chicken go down. I've had better for half the price.

3) Bathrooms are gorgeous but the highlight of any restaurant should never, ever be taking a piss.

To end on a good note, the desserts are great.
author: First Name L.

description:
First time here, and I was very impressed.  Its in the Westfield mall, and generally I'm not a huge fan of restaurants in malls.  We almost made a reservation, but because we had two kids with us, we weren't sure if we could make it at a specific time.  But they had one table available for us.  The decor is really cool, with an indoor/outdoor feel (in the mall under the dome, not actually outdoors).  The spices, lighting, open kitchen, and various buddha statues make for lots of interesting things to take in.

The food was great too.  We shared lots of small plates.  The tempeh sliders were unique and tasty.  I'm usually not a fan of tempeh, but it was soft and the sauce was delicious.  We topped it off with the matcha green tea ice cream on the waitresses recommendaiton, which hit the spot!

The service was great - there when you needed it, lots of spot on recs, and friendly yet professional.

I'll definitely be going back when I'm in the Westfield mall again!
author: Vishwas P.

description: Everything was delishious...  I was expecting a little bit more infusions or creativity, but it was just a little amplified tasty chinese food.
author: Sunny S.

description: Yesterday I went here before going to work. I've been here a couple times for the bang bang chicken which I think is bangin which is why I went back. I've been fighting a cold so thought I'd see if M Y China had a noodle soup to help me feel better. So I call and the hosts tells me yes, a beef noodle soup. So I let him know I'd like to order for pick up. I also ask him if it's spicy, he says it has jalapeño in it so I ask if they can add extra. He tells me yes "for $5". I almost asked him if he was on dog food! I should have hung up then but for some reason I continued with the order. So after I placed the order I then asked how much it would be. He said $18. I told him this better be some hella good soup! I was given a couple opportunities to not get the soup first when he said an extra five bucks for A jalapeño then when he said 18 dollaz for the soup itself. When I finally got to work and start eating, the soup was a MAJOR DISAPPOINTMENT! I can't even explain it. It wasn't nasty or gross it just didn't taste like anything...it definitely didn't taste like EIGHTEEN DOLLAR SOUP! M Y China will not be getting my money for awhile. Looks like I will be putting them on a time out for some time.
author: Nhp C.

description: Excellent cuisine and wonderful service. The ambiance is very cool and sophisticated, while comfortable and casual. Fresh crab with black bean sauce was amazing, though, of course, somewhat of a job. The whole rock fish was also outstanding and the Peking duck delicious, though could have been crispier. All in all a terrific experience.
author: Donna H.

description:
The restaurant has a very good internal environment - nice table and chairs, nice menu, nice servant, etc. We picked several suggested dishes on the menu, including steak chops on a hot iron plate, spicy fried shrimp, chow fun, and cauliflower with mushroom in addition to several side dishes like appetizers. Though the style is still Chinese-like, every dish is more or less westernized in both the flavor and the way it is cooked. 

One thing to keep in mind before going - located in a mall in downtown SF, very hard to find street or free parking. We end up at a paid public lot at $10/hr. You might consider walk there or take cable car/muni.
author: Tim Z.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend on a Saturday and the place was actually pretty packed. I was surprised given how large the restaurant was. Anyways, M.Y. China serves actually pretty authentic Chinese food for a pretty high price. Would recommend making a reservation on OpenTable since they have a lot of available reservations but there was a bit of a wait for walk in.

My friend and I got: soup dumplings, wild boar noodles, sauteed beef, and the pork buns. Soup dumplings are really interesting here because they're served to you in a spoon, which eliminates the hardest part of eating a soup dumpling -- the part of picking it up. That being said, there was still not a ton of soup and the bottom of my soup dumpling was really moist... which was not pleasant. Not super delicious. The pork buns we had were solid, but like good pork buns anywhere. Sauteed beef and noodles were all decent, but nothing to rave about. 

Overall, the quality of the food is good, but these four dishes came out to be about $70-80 dollars which is ridiculous for lunch. The food wasn't that much better than stuff that I can get from Chinatown, and those places are a lot more easily accessible than having to go to the fourth floor of a mall.

tldr; it's authentic, but the prices are really high and the food is only really okay
author: Jasmine X.

description: Best Happy hour specials & excellent service. The bbq wings & Kung pao are both good choices. I've been here 3 times before I decided to give them a review & I will keep coming back. Don't even bother with Chinatown. This place has best Chinese I've had in years!
author: Matt K.

description:
Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles- #73 on the 2014 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

Since we were shopping at Westfield, my friend and I decided to stop by and check out M.Y. China. The restaurant looks very swanky, and we decided to order the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles (Bean Sprouts, Scallions, Wood Ear Mushrooms, $14, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2?select=QLm0n8gpVuxLINU58r8tKw#QLm0n8gpVuxLINU58r8tKw) to go. Our orders were ready in less than 15 minutes. I reheated the noodles for dinner, and you can tell the noodles were freshly made since they have that nice chewy quality to them. The boar was tender, but I couldn't tell much of a difference from pork aside from it also being chewier. The flavors of the noodles were good, but I didn't think this dish was amazing. However, I'll probably be back to try additional items from M.Y. China (despite the higher prices) since there are a few other dishes on the menu that looked really appealing.
author: Amy D.

description: We love the food here on a couple of occasions couple of hiccups with staff but since things much better. The hostess today should be taught to greet the paying customers with a smile and respect. Otherwise the server was outstanding hope she enjoys her special tip.
author: Jim S.

description: Somewhat difficult to order if you're unfamiliar like we were. Our server was a big help.
author: Terry C.

description: This place had been on my restaurant list of places I have been wanting to try. Finally went here last week for date night. We ordered the spicy chicken wings and salmon appetizers. They were delicious. For the main course we ordered the chicken over crispy noodles and the crispy chicken. The portions were generous and we left with enough for lunch the next day. We were too stuffed to try dessert but I definitely want to go back. The only thing that was not great about the place was the service. We felt like our waitress was not attentive and also not very friendly. Despite that everything else was great and we will go back to try other things on the menu!
author: Nia R.

description:
I've been curious about M.Y. China for a while now. It could really go either way. I mean, I'm Taiwanese and am particular about my food. I read through all the Yelp reviews (especially from the Asians, sorry I am unapologetically biased here), and figured it was worth a shot since I didn't want to trek all the way to the Richmond -- my typical go to neighborhood for authentic Chinese eats.

But surprisingly, M.Y. China is pretty darn good. Like, I would return and even take my parents there good. I read up on what dishes were the favorites, and Yelpers didn't let me down. And I was pleasantly surprised to see a decent number of Asians eating at the restaurant too. But with the fully English-speaking waiter, they definitely are able to cater to the tourist/office/Westernized crowd as well. Let's just say I didn't place any of my orders in Mandarin.

Here's what we chowed down on:
* Wild boar scissor cut noodles: believe the hype, this noodle dish is legit. the perfect chewiness (QQ) to the noodles, good flavoring. Could it have done with more boar? yes, but that's not the point of this dish. 
* crab and pork soup dumpling: I love me some XLB. I was slightly disappointed by these -- loved the presentation but the skin stuck to the big red soup spoons and the meat filling wasn't as tender as I'm used to. the skin was thin, which was a plus, but I just expected more. 
* seafood dumplings: these come in a garlicky, slightly spicy sauce and were a delicious variation of your typical har gow/shrimp dumpling. I would get these again. 
* Peking duck: a solid dish. Their mantou steamed buns were perfectly light and fluffy and the duck skin nice and crispy. The duck meat was well seasoned and while a tad on the dry side, still well excuted. 
* Sauteed snow peas: dou miao is a go to for me, and this was executed fine. nothing mind blowing but just a standard garlic saute version. 
* Sauteed green beans: again, fine. a bit soggy but flavor was good. 

By the end of the meal, there was nothing left between the three of us. All of us thoroughly enjoyed our meal there and I would be happy to go back for another meal. A solid option for (real) Chinese restaurant when you don't want to trek out to the Richmond.
author: Vic C.

description: Great chinese restraunt under the dome. First time at this place and it has a calm atmosphere. Menu prices are cheap not that pricey. Plenty of seating good place for family and friends.
author: N K.

description:
Location: in the 9-story mall Westfield San Francisco Centre. On the 4th floor near the entrance of Nordstrom. Setting: modern and Chinese fusion, and very popular.  Service: friendly and pleasant. Make a reservation on Yelp that can save you twenty-minute-long waiting. Food: I love the crabs, six styles of cooking. It is Market price, and was $51 on Black Friday after Thanksgiving. We ordered:
   Beijing Duck $20 for half duck and 6 buns. Very tasty and less greasy, 5 stars
   Whole fish with chilly bean sauce, $33, 5 stars. 
Parking: it is San Francisco!
Highly recommended!
author: Rose Z.

description: Made a special trip to the city and found MY China shut down for a private party. This is certainly their prerogative but they need to know they lost a loyal customer as a result. A restaurant should always keep at least a small area open for regulars in my opinion. Again it's a private business but they need to know it comes at a price.
author: Mike B.

description: Saturday at 2 o'clock in the afternoon is a perfect time to go after the crowds had dissipated and after a little bit of shopping in the Westfield Mall. They sat us under the Buddha wall in the back which was quieter and allowed for good friends to have a fabulous time. I have my favorite restaurants for Chinese food and this one is pretty good. We had Kung pao chicken, onion cakes, shrimp shumai, stir fried seafood, lettuce cup with beef, and it all fared pretty well. We had an attentive and friendly waiter, and really enjoyed ourselves. We would come again.
author: Ron W.

description: I will give one extra star for the fact that this place has seating. However, I disagree with the fact that this restaurant has a very easy opportunity to serve more vegan options and still decides to put fish sauce in virtually every vegetable there. For example, the bok choy is cooked with fish sauce. For the love of animals, can't you just use soy sauce!!! This is San Francisco- a city filled with restaurants with vegan options. I'm grossed out. By the way, this place serves octopus, be prepared to sit by someone that will order it. It is so gross.
author: EatVegetarian F.

description:
4.5 stars! 
I made a spontaneous trip here after a long day of shopping in the city. I didn't want to go to the food court and I was too tired to walk elsewhere...plus it's hard to go wrong with Chinese food! Since it was a mall restaurant, I honestly did not expect good food to be honest but my meal turned out to be amazing. I waited about 15 minutes on a Saturday night at 6pm with no reservations...not bad, but it was super crowded so I think I got lucky. Reservations recommended. 

We ordered:

1. Seafood dumplings- SO GOOD. The chili oil that came with it was delicious. Lots of flavor and they did not skimp on the seafood filling. Get this. 

2. Juicy dumplings- This was also amazing. This dish has both crab and pork dumplings but I liked the pork a lot more than the crab one. This seemed to be one of their more popular dishes. 

3. Wonton soup- Eh...this soup was too bland. I had to add a little bit of the chili oil from the seafood dumplings into the soup so that there was sort of flavor. I would skip this....next time I want to try the hot and sour soup. 

4. Wok seared beef- Not my favorite but the rest of my table really liked it. The beef was cooked a little more than I usually like.

5. Wild boar noodles- I really liked this dish...there was a good noodle to meat ratio and I loved that the noodles were thicker. 

6. Sichuan green beans- Really good but suuuuuper spicy for me. I wanted to keep eating them but couldn't because my mouth was on fire!

7. Lychee panna cotta- Try this!!! Really unique and refreshing and tastes wonderful!

Service and atmosphere were both good. Prices were a little expensive but it is in a mall so what do you expect? It was worth it though....I was pleasantly surprised by how good the food was! Will be coming back for more dumplings and to try other dishes!
author: Kristine L.

description:
Ate here for the first time in many years - really excellent. The garlic green beans are fresh with just the right amount of firmness and the Hong Kong crispy noodles were perfect with large chunks of chicken (white meat). Best of all - two families with four kids total ate for about $100. 

Highly recommended
author: Stephen M.

description:
Who'd think that a restaurant in a mall could be this good?  Saw this place featured on Check Please Bay Area and after reading the reviews on Yelp and Open Table, I thought I'd drag the hubby to eat here.  He is not a fan of most Chinese restaurants as he thinks most of them do not use not the highest quality of ingredients.  I'm happy to report that he really enjoyed our dining experience here.  He even said he'd like to return and try other dishes!

The hostess thanked us for taking the time to make a reservation when she seated us on one of their outside tables.  She said it gets really busy there on Friday nights.  When we arrived, there were quite a number of people at the bar area already having a drink and eating during Happy Hour, which is from 3-6 pm.   We perused the menu which was nice and manageable, not super long like most Chinese restaurants.  We ordered the following:

Seafood Dumpling -- one of the best I've had.  The scallops and shrimp were perfectly cooked and they were enveloped in a medium thin spinach wrapper.  The sauce was so good!  I should have had the server leave the leftover sauce, so I we could have poured some on our rice!

Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders -- It's not as good as The Chairman, but it was good.  I think a little bit more sauce on it would have made it better.  The pork was tender and flavorful.

Seven Spice Pork Ribs with Chili and Thai Basil -- This was our favorite dish!!!!  I was so happy that it was not the sticky mess that I've seen and had in other restaurants!  These ribs were fork tender, so they have been slow cooked, and they had been fried and dusted with a coating of spices and chili.  OMG!  The thai basil is more than a garnish.  It really added more flavor to the pork!  It was a generous serving of 5 large ribs.  

Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles -- Again, another good dish.  Perfect accompaniment to the bold flavors of the Pork Ribs dish.  Noodles were perfectly cooked and was not swimming in sauce.

Sugar Egg Puffs with Chantilly Cream, Chocolate Sauce and Raspberry Coulis -- perfect ending to a filling dinner.  The puffs were truly light and eggy!  My only complain is I wanted more Chantilly Cream! 

For beverages, my husband had a glass of a dry Sauvignon Blanc from Charles Krug, and I had a glass of the Under the Bronze Bell cocktail.  St. Germaine and The King's Ginger are two of my favorite liquer, so I had to get this cocktail.  Yum!  We will definitely be back!  Both the service and food were great!
author: Hazel C.

description: I tried again.. I am not sure why but the food is not quite right. Maybe other dishes are good but this is my second try at eating Kung pao here.. And it is horrible. I don't know if they treat their chicken with poo mayo or what.. It is really nauseating.. I mean.. I'm running to the restroom now to puke it out. So 30 dollars for one lunch for me alone.. Down the drain.
author: Mike T.

description: Even though I am not an Asian cuisine lover.....I am a fan of M.Y. China. I have tried a few items on the menu and they are all my rotating items when I go. The Singapore Noodles with that bomb ass brown gravy ....... Hella good.....those crispy hard fried chicken wings on point ev'ry time. Nice lookout spot..check, decent happy hour check..check and last but not least good pricey Americanized Asian food check..check..check.....the only way I'll eat it!!!
author: Stacie J.

description: We came here because we saw it in food show. We are visiting for the weekend and came to eat. We tried squid ink noodles and beef rolls. It's was different and delicious. I recommend making reservations like we did and we got right in at prime dinner time. Great place.
author: Juan S.

description:
This is my favorite place to take friends and family when meeting up! Phenomenal dim sum, awesome noodles, a fabulous variety of wok dishes -- AND -- They have cocktails in the mall! 

The garlic crab is the stuff of my dreams, and I'll gladly demolish a lobster for a special celebration. 

This restaurant is where I celebrated my birthday last year and so many other important milestones. 

As a part of the restaurant community, it's important to give back, and I always see this team out supporting local charities. Great food and great people.
author: Erin A.

description: We ordered scissor cut noodles with wild boar. The dish was ok, but the price dish ratio was disproportionate. I could not distinguish if the Wild Board was just pork or not. It was under spiced and I had to had hot sauce. Sorry guys, not impressed. The waiters were nice and friendly. Thanks for a happy face.
author: Joe M.

description:
I came for dinner before a show with my wife and a good friend.  My experience was much better, I'm happy to say.  The place was packed at 6:00.  I'm glad we had reservations. Had the salt pepper wings that were really spicy but good.  6 deep fried pieces topped with a lot of spice so if you don't like it hot you should tell them. 

Had the seafood spinach dumplings.  My friend that ought they were the XLB I said I didn't think so but I was right.  These are essentially six boiled dumplings with a slight soy sauce.  The filling was generous.  My friend was disappointed it wasn't the XLB they have at lunch time. 

We had the venison chow fun.   The venison was not gamey at all and extremely tender, almost like filet mignon.  I would not have said it was venison after tasting it.

We also had the cumin lamb.  The portion size was very nice and the lamb very tender and not gamey. It was seasoned perfectly.

My wife really like the Ginger mist cocktail.  Service was great!
author: Frank T.

description: I have been here multiple times and really like their squid ink seafood noodle. The pork dumplings were good. I like the roast duck and eggplant with tofu too. Its quite authentic and worth a visit while at Westfield San Francisco.
author: Elly G.

description: Great food and ambience - love the bar and salt and pepper shrimp - amazing cocktails and clay pot dishes.
author: Terry H.

description:
I'm convinced that Yan really can't cook.

Came here on a whim for Happy Hour.

First off, I'm not sure if they had a whole bunch of new servers, but 2 different waiters took our order, and then dissapeared.

Then a third waiter showed up and asked if we wanted drink and to order, and we were perplexed, since we thought we had just placed our order with the other waiters.

Whatever. 

So we ordered the "Bang Bang Chicken Wings," which cracks me up every time I say that.

This was both sweet and sour and overall tasty.

Then we had potstickers, which were okay, but not as hot as we would have liked. It tasted like it had been sitting around.

Next the Har Gow, and Pork Buns, and the lobster noodles which they were advertising as a special for some Lobster Seasonal thing.

All were just okay, but the lobster I think could have been better. As in, I could have had cheaper and better Lobster Noodles elsewhere.

Service was soooo slow, and they were all confused. They actually gave my credit card to a table at the end. Yikes! Thankfully I got it back or else I'd be buying dinner for some random strangers.
author: Jack R.

description:
I was told by my friend that they had tasty appetizers here and the prices were significantly lower than the original since we came here during rush hour.

ATMOSPHERE:
It wasn't crowded at all when we came in and was greeted immediately by the host. She told us that we could sit anywhere so we seated in a bar-like area where we could see the staff prepare food which made it seem more authentic.

FOOD:
I didn't know what to order so I just let my friend order. We got the calamari, pork in a bun, and shumai.

Calamari: 5/5 - Oh. My. Gosh. These were probably one of the best calamari I've ever had! The chewiness and crunchiness were perfection and I was a bit saddened when we ate it all. This is something I HIGHLY suggest ordering!

Pork in a bun: 3/5 - I've had something like this similar from the Philippines and it wasn't as good as I expected it to be in comparison with the ones my grandma usually bought me from the Philippines.

Shumai: 3/5 - Not gonna lie, these shumai we're tasty but they weren't the best. I would say they were a bit above average. They tasted significantly better with the sauce so don't forget to dip it!

One thing I didn't like was that the water they gave us (they give you water in a vase) wasn't cold at all. It definitely was lukewarm and I didn't like that.

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
At first, they were very prompt but got slower during check out. I looked around and there weren't many patrons dining in.

Would I come back here? Yeah, I would for happy hour. Would I recommend this to my friends? Sure!
author: Aj C.

description:
I can't say anything. The only word I can say is: Perfect!!! 
The food is soooooo good and the services is good as well. I eat there every week at least twice. Even though the place is so crowded but my food still come out fairly as anyone else
author: Hieu N.

description:
Surprisingly is very delicious.. I Thought i will be eating typical Chinese food in the mall, but this can be considerably one of the best.. We ordered pork dumpling which is okay, the sweet and sour pork is good, the calamari with salt and pepper are good, the chairman mao's chicken are not so good, the crispy hong kong noodle is very good, and lastly the dungenous crab with egg yolk surprisingly delicious.. 
Very unexpectedly.. Nice joint
author: Raymond P.

description: It was tough leaving the following review but the way I felt in our last visit here was not a great experience. Let me start by saying that the only reason I visit this restaurant is because my husband loves their beef soup. With that said, we have visited this location multiple times and the service has been great. My husband is a veteran who suffers from PTSD and we have a service dog that accompanies him everywhere he goes. On all our previous visits we have never been isolated or discriminated against because of this. We have been sat in the main dining area with all guest of which they have never even noticed a service dog was under the table because she is trained to do a job. On this visit, we were sat in an isolated area with no one around us and midway through our meal, we noticed all the employees were eating in this area as well. 5 minutes into us sitting down, a random person who didn't identify himself (tall Caucasian guy) came over and said the following "we are a pet friendly restaurant but we like to keep our pets separate from the other guests". My blood was boiling after hearing his ignorant comment for which I told him, she is not a pet, she is a Service Dog performing a job. He still didn't get it. I would have gotten up and left but being 6 months pregnant  this level of ignorance was not worth my time. Maybe this employee/manager doesn't value the service my husband provided to ensure he had a job and felt safe in this country and maybe training needs to happen to tell the difference between a pet and working service dog. The food was amazing. But because we were in an isolated part of the restaurant service was not the same and we can observe the employees eating while we waited for our food. We even waited 10 mins just to get our check. I will stop my husband from returning to this place at all cost. I refuse to support businesses who don't know the guidelines of the customers they are servicing.
author: Cristina P.

description: This restaurant is a favorite of mine whenever I am in downtown SF. Whenever I have friends or relatives, I always give them a treat on this restaurant. For me, the food is great. But today, I was not happy with the way I was received by the hostess ( latin woman).  I said good morning to  her and she just looked at me and asked how many people in the party. Very cold way of accepting a customer. She seated us in the table for 4 and I asked if we could be seated in a bigger table because I know it will be cramped with the food I am planning to order for my guests. She said there were four of us so we can only seat in a table for four.  Well, our waiter was very nice to us and he was even the one who said that next time I should ask for a bigger table if I'm planning to order a lot of food so that we will be comfortable. To make the long story short, we finished our lunch and was satisfied with the food. I took the bill and paid with a 15% tip. I went to the bathroom and as soon as I got back to the table, our Chinese waiter was complaining to my guest about the tip. I then asked what it was and he said if I am satisfied with his service, I should at least give 18% tip. He was loud and I got embarrassed with the people who heard and to my guests of course. So I just gave what he wanted. It is just fine with  me but the manner of which he told me is what bothered me.  Does MY China require their waiters to do this? Nice & accommodating hostess needed too.
author: Nancy L.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this gem of a restaurant in the westfield mall. The duck was spot on and reminisced me back to a trip to Beijing. The knife cut Beijing noodles were pretty tasty. We also had the wild boar lettuce wraps and pork belly bao were nicely balanced. Generous portions on the duck. Small appetizers. A bit expensive for the meal but understandable given the location. Would return to try the long life noodles and get some more duck.... def need to order extra bao for the duck.
author: Anthony R.

description: Very good service located inside the mall. The restaurant is nice and the food is authentic (skin duck is a must). I loved the variety they had and how the food was affordable and they were generous with portions. Overall great experience!
author: Khalil S.

description: Great food, good service and a nice atmosphere. Great place for client lunches - easy valet parking on 5th Street Market. Try the shrimp gao, spicy tofu, and whole wok fried Dungeness crab (messy but worth it).
author: Laura L.

description:
Our group of 12 had a set menu for dinner on a Friday night. Needless to say, the line was long and the restaurant both "inside" and "outside" (there's patio seating but since it's the mall it's still indoors) was loud and boisterous. 

I was most impressed with the service because we were seated promptly and the dishes were flowing. The staff should be commended for how seamlessly they ran the show. Our water carafes were never empty, and the food came out consistently.

My favorite dishes:
- Peking roasted duck: succulent meat with a crispy exterior, served with homemade buns, cucumbers, green onions and hoisin sauce to make the best sandwich
- Rice cake with wild boar with cabbage, edamame and green onions: the flavor! like their own version of soy sauce
- Seven spice pork ribs with chili and Thai basil: spice, spice, spice

There's also a great lineup of nonalcoholic drinks. The Mango Mule had a refreshing balance of cucumber and citrus, along with not-too-sweet mango. It's also made with ginger beer.
author: Esther G.

description: Food was good portions were decent for 12 people and the atmosphere was typical but nothing to rave about. The waitress was mediocre. She didn't introduce herself, wasn't personal until I finally had to ask her, her name and if she will be our waitress today? (I work for the watergrill in Santa Monica and as a waitress this service would get us written up or fired. Certain places have standards and this place just gets by, I expected better from Frisco when I traveled 6 hours from LA. It's ok but China town honestly is better for portions and service.
author: Raya R.
