description: Food very good, but tables extremely crowded for the money you're paying.   Very noisy, and two feet away from tables on either side of you.  More like paying high prices to eat in a school cafeteria.
author: alex u.

description: We had dinner at M.Y. China tonight. The food was amazing! The best Chinese food I've had in San Francisco so far. The ambiance and service were delightful. Our waiter was very knowledgeable and gave us great advice in ordering the right dishes. We thoroughly enjoyed everything about this restaurant!
author: S M.

description: First time eating here.  Food was great service was awesome and location is great.  Also a bit of nostalgia for me as I used to watch Yan can cook when I was younger.
author: Mike And Lorena Y.

description: Great food. Service was very slow. Milk oolong tea and scissor cut wild boar noodles. The cold dan dan noodles were interesting. The hot and sour soup was a great started with the pork and crab roe dumplings.
author: Tierney B.

description:
Summary: Overpriced, small portions, below average taste, and ok service

ordered the beef wokplate as well as a pineapple fried rice plate. My date got the sweet and sour pork the beefplate was ok but the portion was wayyyyyy to small for the price a few small strips of cheap beef over greens for $20 not even enough for one person to eat. Pineapple rice was plain and made me feel a bit queezy later on in the day. Didnt try the sweet n sour pork but my date said it was good and the portion was ok. Overall probably wont be back as those 3 small plates cost $60 can get those same 3 entrees but better at any chinese place for a 3rd of the price. dont come here if your looking for good chinese food. All you get is ambience and nice decor. Martin Yan himself was there that day visiting tables but only ones that had asian people... Will not repeat much better out there.
author: Abdul Qader R.

description:
Came in for a quick bite to eat and a cocktail!

Outstanding! Dylan at the bar made the experience so lovely! He was attentive and knowledgeable! So glad we stopped here! Wonderful drinks! Just wow! 

Come in and sit at the bar! You won't be disappointed!

- Pork dumplings are THE best!
author: Marisa C.

description: Much tastier than I'd expect from a restaurant at the top of a mall! With five Chef Partners - including Martin Yan, who I grew ok watching on Wok With Yan! Love him, he saved me from my family's single-cuisine mindset and taught me food prep can and should be fun. That energy of loving food and the food sharing experience still translates into this elegant dining experience. There's even ample vegetarian fare, hurrah!
author: Be F.

description:
Had a great time after the Pride Parade here at the Westfield mall. My younger sister is a huge fan, and typically comes here for happy hour. She told me the noodles are fresh and hand made. Also, this restaurant was either owned, or perhaps produced, by Martin Yan.

For our lunch we had: Bang Bang Chicken, Juicy Pork Dumplings, Tan Tan Noodles, Venison Chow Fun and Vietnamese Coffee Ice Cream. Overall a decent meal. IMO better than most the food I've had in Beijing, China. Although they are pricey, it is nice to have every now and then.
author: Charlee C.

description: Food was cold, main course came out while still having our soup.   No taste, tasted like any local Chinese food restaurant, expected something special and delicious.  Would not recommend. Also very overpriced.  Not worth what we paid.
author: David B.

description:
If I can give this place 10 stars I would! The moment we walked in we were treated like celebrities! The hostess gave us two options on where to sit, which was nice. She wanted to make sure we were comfortable. 

Right when we sat down, the manager Craig welcomed us and introduced himself. Very genuine and humble person. He made sure we were taken care of! He talked so passionately about the food and how he loves the atmosphere. He's right about when you step into the restaurant, it doesn't feel like you're in the mall anymore!

Oulu! She was our waitress! She took care of us real good! She made sure nothing we ate had any type of peanut or tree nut products! She always had a smile on her face! We also had her as a waitress when we took our wedding party here for dinner. M.Y China is lucky to have her! 

So let's see.. First we tried the Seafood Dumplings- So Good! It had a real nice kick to it! Not really that spicy, which is a plus for me!

Calamari-Fried to perfection! It didn't have that greasy taste where you would find at other restaurants! 

Cucumber Wrapped Scallops- The combination of flavors was just perfect! 

Bang Bang Chicken Wings!! OMG!! This is a MUST get small plate! I really enjoyed the crispiness to it! Messy to eat, BUT totally worth it!!

Hong Kong Style Noodles! Eat them fast before it gets soggy! Even if it does get soggy, it's still really good! 

Garlic Lobster- If you like garlic like I do, this is a must get!!! It comes with vermicelli noodles underneath the 2.5LB lobster so it soaked the garlic sauce pretty well! And a side of scissor cut noodles which was to die for!! 

We had this dessert that was so pretty to eat! Pictures will be posted with this review! It came with a donut with ice cream on top and on top of that was chocolate and some type of berry sauce! 

Great atmosphere, great food, and amazing people.. What more can you ask for? I'm definitely coming back for my bachelorette dinner and I'm for sure for going to take my parents here! We don't have a place for a rehearsal dinner for our wedding, this place may be the place!! 

Thank you Craig, Carol, Oulu, and Julie! You made our anniversary dinner something to remember!!
author: Darlene M.

description: Surprisingly good food to be had at this mall restaurant! This is our go to place when we feel like dimsum but don't want to wait. Its on the more expensive side for dimsum, but still reasonable. Try the hand cut noodles!
author: Liz L.

description:
Surprisingly good experience here. There can be a wait, so I recommend just reserving through OpenTable since they put priority on those with reservations (they allow same day). If you are craving legitimate Chinese food after some shopping but are too lazy to make it to the Richmond or Chinatown, just go here! 

We got the string beans, Peking duck (half), and beef noodle soup. The beef noodle soup was very good, I actually don't know where else to get this dish since sf is so lacking of authentic Taiwanese food. The Peking duck was great as well, though I wish they provided the thin pancake slices to eat with instead of the steamed buns. The string beans were pretty standard and nothing special. 

The service was also really great - despite us having a seat more towards the outdoor area, our waitress Jessica was super attentive. We are glad to have a good Peking duck option in sf, without having to trek to Berkeley. It was also just so clean and luxurious. I wouldn't mind coming back again.
author: Elisa L.

description:
Used to be one of my favorite restaurant to go to but not anymore..
I think they may have hired new employees because the service was not there.  Made a reservation , got seated , waited over 15 minutes but still no one comes by to even give us water. Had to ask for water.. Servers around us acted like we were not there.. went to the front to ask for another table .. passed by a bunch of employees in a huddle just standing looking at our table  ..Like they were confused ! And, one of them come to find out was the Manager .. After waiting again for few more minutes, we decided to get up and leave ..went next door to Tap 415 where the service was excellent !
author: Mary Ann S.

description:
Since Martin Yan is one of the OG asian celeb chefs, I had to give MY China another chance. 

I went ahead and ordered one of my favorite classic Asian dishes along with some fusion items. I figured last time I went with some of the more heralded dishes, this time I'll go with what I think looks good on the menu.

Peking Duck: 
Fantastic. Perfectly crispy skin, with a generous amount of duck. The white steamed buns were soft and paired perfectly with the green onions, sauce, and duck. Very nicely executed. 

Wild Boar in Lettuce Cups:
A very nice and refreshing counterpoint to the Peking Duck. The lettuce provides a nice crunch and light flavor to the wild boar. I really enjoyed this dish a lot.

Bang Bang Chicken Wings:
Similar to Korean Fried Chicken wings - but with their own version of sauce, these wings were super crispy, juicy, and bursting with flavor.

Sugar Egg Puffs:
One of my favorite things to get at a dim sum restaurant - they took these to another level by providing chocolate fondue, vanilla custard cream, and raspberry coulis.

If you can, try to get a seat outside so you can dine under the fantastic Westfield Dome.
author: Henry W.

description:
For those who may not know, M.Y. is for "Martin Yan". If you don't know him, this guy can pay debone an entire chicken with a meat cleaver in less than 20secs. Tons of cooking shows over the years, one thing that keeps playing in my damn head is that stupid song associated with the make-shift flash mob commercial for Granite Expo (Martin Yan LOVES Granite Expo btw). Anyway, I've been a little reluctant to try this spot (a little bit because of that tv commercial, a little bit because of the location inside the Westfield Shopping center). In addition, I'm spoiled because my better half is Chinese from Taiwan and her mom can bang out the "super authentic/non-American-ized" menu. All I can say is.. I've been shortchanging myself. This is not "upscalemall food! 

FOOD: Since it was our first time, we wanted to try a wide scope of the menu. Loved loved loved the "Bang-Bang Chicken Wings" (6 for $9) & "Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders" (2 for $8); only comment here, & this is my palate mind you, is that I didn't get the smoked flavor. I also wish there was a little more belly since there's only two per order. / Moving onto the Entrees, we ordered the "Wok Seared Beef" on arugula ($20). This was super tasty, but lots of arugula. We also ordered the "Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood" ($18) which was beyond good, as well as the "Yang Zhou Fried Rice" ($11); a little more pork please.. Rounding up the mains were two more: something from the "specials" for the night and a house-hold staple. The "Eggplant Clay Pot with tofu and veggies" ($12) was good, but the winner for the night was the "Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp w walnuts, cumbers and wasabi" ($23); just enough bite from the wasabi to open your nasal passages. Dessert: Sugar Puffs w. chocolate fondue, vanilla bean chantilly cream, raspberry coulis (5 for $8).. Just the right amount. 

SERVICE: It's Monday night @ 7pm and the place is packed due to all the foot traffic from Oracle World down the street. Here I was thinking it would be easy/breezy/quiet to celebrate my wife's bday. Wrong. But here's where the surprises started. I mentioned that we were celebrating a bday in the OpenTable reservation and wanted a low-traffic spot in the restaurant to chow & enjoy each other's company. The hostess gets us in the perfect spot; close to the kitchen, but far enough away from the large group section. (Win). Then the shift manager Daniel comes up and hands us 2 comp glasses of bubbles and a bday card signed by everyone working that night. (Whaaaaaaaaaaaaat? I mean seriously, who does that anymore..). Now that is a testament to a smart manager going "above and beyond". Things like our water glasses were always filled when they hit the 1/2 way mark; An informed server that could provide suggestions and tell me why; Our dishes served hot and together, or one right after another. These actions aren't just reserved for dining at Gary Danko or Boulevard, they are the result of actions associated with a true service mentality and phenomenal venue management. (I'm speaking about Daniel). 

PRICE: This is San Francisco. Not much I can say that anyone reading this review will be shocked about when it comes to the price point for menu items. One thing to factor is to have an understanding of the "cost" per plate for the house -vs- menu price. An indicator is not only the overall portion for the order, but the amount of the premium element (how much beef to amount of arugula / how much seafood to noodles to veggies / how many shrimp to cumbers / how much pork in the rice, etc...). That being said, the price point for each item was affordable, but the main items were all a little light. Probably because of the rent they have to pay, which I'm sure is insane. 

AMBIANCE: This is where you're teetering on inside/outside dining that's not actually "outside". A few tables along the perimeter of the restaurant which you need to navigate to reach the check-in station. Nice bar along the right side, while a open kitchen layout with counter seating. Nice blend of 2 and 4 tops with very limited number of booths (which I highly recommend if you can get them). There's an overflow room in the back which is great larger groups, but be prepared to talk loud. Well lit, and spaced out so you're not rubbing elbows when you go for your napkin. All in all, a comfortable dining experience where I could have a conversation, sitting in a booth mind you. 

If you haven't guessed, I'm a stickler when it comes to eating out. I cook, so I know. One of the BEST service and food experiences I've had in San Francisco in a very very very long time. I will be back for sure!
author: Sen-Sei S.

description: My husband had the Seven Spiced Ribs and Mu Shu Pork Tacos. We sat at the bar with excellent service and great food.
author: Maria B.

description:
I'm always a bit reluctant when I visit a higher end Chinese restaurant, especially when clearly round-eyed items like "Mixed Greens with Papaya and Grilled Shrimp" are on the menu. But my mom really wanted to try this place and one should only rarely no to mom.

Some of my initial fears were put to rest when I saw a healthy mix of young and old Chinese diners along with round-eyed diners as well. At least one waiter is bilingual. And just so I wouldn't feel out of place, some of the elderly Chinese customers were busy cleaning the plates and silverware set on the table. I've never understood this common Chinese practice growing up. I mean think about it, you clean the plates and silverware because you don't trust the restaurant to do it properly, what about the food itself? I guess you can take the person out of Chinatown but not the Chinatown out of the person.

We ordered the deep fried oysters in black bean sauce and salted egg yolk dungeness crab. 

The deep fried oysters were very large and very fresh. Very clean tasting and the portion size was very generous.

I really liked the batter on the salted egg yolk dungeness crab. A bit messy to eat and some manual labor is required but you will be rewarded with some really tasty bits of crab that is unique to dungeness.
author: Glen L.

description:
I ended up going to M. Y. China with my former college housemate after sitting in the Metreon for a good hour trying to decide what to have for dinner only to resort to a random number generator. M. Y. China looks to be a fancy and modern Chinese restaurant within the busy SF Westfield mall with an open kitchen and a somewhat sophisticated yet comfortable ambiance.

Having decided to aim for a budget of ~$15 per person for this meal, we ended up ordering three dishes that hit exactly $30 pre-tax. We were seated at the counter facing the kitchen which was nice since I very much enjoy watching chefs at work, but it also resulted in some space issues when all the dishes to share arrived.

We started off with the Honey Glazed BBQ Pork which has five spice and sesame listed as ingredients. I found it to be about average as it simply tasted like regular bbq pork on a plate of honey. It's a solid choice if you happen to like bbq pork, but I would otherwise give it a pass. Next came the Mapo Organic Tofu and the Twin Scallops Fried Rice. These dishes were both executed very well and complemented each other to some degree. The tofu was at a nice soft texture with the gravy like black bean sauce which just had the right amount of flavor. The sauce wasn't all that spicy nor all that salty, allowing the tofu to really shine as the star of the dish. The scallop fried rice, though simple in concept, was clearly prepared with a great amount of skill. The egg white was neither too firm nor too watery and same with the rice. The dried scallop was all throughout the rice in thin strands with its subtle seafood flavor. I find that many Chinese restaurants fail to get this recipe done correctly and well, but M. Y. China shows they know what they're doing with this dish.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Really bad. I don't post one stars very often but this lunch was that poor. Over cooked calamari, an undressed salad with unripe mango and a broken tea pot (that burned my fingers) made this experience unfortunate. 

I'd grab something quick elsewhere and wait till later for a quality meal. One star for the efficient but embarrassed waiter who could barely look me in the eye.
author: Joseph S.

description:
I was here on 5/3/2014 for lunch and 5/4/2014 for dinner. 

5/3/2014 
After a girls spa day with my closest friends, I ended up having lunch here with one of my good friends.  We ordered a ton of food and some drinks and ended up spending about $100 for 2 people.  It was well worth it cause the food was very good.  We enjoyed the dim sum and had wonderful service.  We never had to flag down the waitress to keep refilling our water because they made sure to keep it filled. 

Here's a list of several of the items we ordered: 

Spicy Seafood Dumplings which is scallops, shrimp, spinach wrapper
Crispy Shrimp Wontons with honey aioli, seasonal fruits
Chairman Mao's Chicken (crisp chicken bites, sweet & spicy sauce)
Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp with cucumber, wasabi
Forbidden Rice (red rice, brown rice, barley, wolf berries) -- I LOVED This rice
Sugar Egg Puffs with chocolate fondue, vanilla bean chantilly cream, raspberry coulis

Everything was cooked to perfection and absolutely delicious. It was so good that I made reservations for an early Mother's day dinner with my family for the next day. 

5/4/2014
Our service wasn't as great as the service I had the day before but the food was still amazing. 

I can't wait to go back and bring my husband and son.  Thanks for a great dining experience!
author: Christine P.

description:
I am so glad that M.Y. China is on the fourth floor of the Westfield San Francisco Centre on Market Street in the downtown corridor. It's is so centrally located that if you want to shop or watch a movie or theatre show or have an appointment at a certain time then this could be the option for you! This is the second time I have been to M.Y. China and I can honestly say I always want to go back for more! Now this is one of the higher end and some would say pricier options on the gourmet Chinese scale, but with recent San Francisco high profile additions like Hakkasan and Crystal Jade making waves and Din Tai Fung coming soon, I would have to say that M.Y China is one of the more pleasant surprises in the city.

The place is not perfect, but I have to admit the location, the overall food, and decent service was more than good enough to make this a must eat destination for any lover of high end Chinese cuisine. Whether you're taking family of friends, M.Y. China is one of the better San Francisco destinations, in a mall of course.

My friend and I got there at about 6pm on a Tuesday evening with an immediate appointment to see a movie at the AMC Metreon movie theatre across the street, so we knew we had to be out by 6:45pm in order to make our show. After being sat in the lovely open air area underneath the mall's dome, our server Oulu noticed our anxiety about timing and asked if we were in a rush. We said we were and immediately asked for recommendations. My friend really wanted M.Y. China's noteworthy hand pulled noodles but neither of us wanted soup. Oulu our server recommended the Da Dao "Big Knife" Fish Noodles which was served with shrimp, scallops, calamari, skitaki, enoki, jalapenos and XO sauce, as that was the only wok fried dish on the menu at M.Y. China that had the pulled noodles that didn't come with an additional charge. We then both wanted to try their Xiao Long Baos, otherwise known as their water dumplings. Oulu recommended we get the Juicy Dumplings in which you get 6 dumplings, (3 each of pork and pork and crab roe).

Our meal came out in no time flat with plenty of time to enjoy the ambiance and the food while under the dome. Out first came the Da Dao "Big Knife" Fish Noodles which were tasty and piping hot with plenty of seafood and long long noodles. We had to ask for our traditional Chinese hot chili oil and paste to jazz up our meal. But I found the dish to be quite the delicious surprise, a bit on the greasy side, but that's to be expected with a wok fired dish. The real star was when the 6 Juicy Dumplings came out in a huge bamboo basket. Although they were very hot temperature wise, we had to blow on our customary soup spoon even after we doused the dumplings with red vinegar. The dumplings do stick to the spoon, which I expected with that much steam and warmth, and you had to break them into two pieces as bite into them. We found both found these dumplings filled with flavor and on the better side of the few dumplings I've had in the Bay Area.

M.Y China was a great place for us to come to when you are in a rush and need to get a good meal in a bit of a rush. We finished our meal in under forty minutes! The food was unique and all-around delicious. The prices are not cheap but you do get what you pay for while you are here. (Our bill came about 38 dollars for just those two dishes.) This was my second time coming and now I want to return for a third time to try even more of their numerous noodle dishes and other small bites that M.Y China has to offer, including their Happy Hour! If you are looking for a good place to go to in downtown's Westfield San Francisco Centre, then M.Y. China is a decent, well thought-out option in which you should consider trying.
author: Jason F.

description:
Food wasn't good at all, smelled a lot better than it tasted and service wasn't great.

Wings were ok, as were the shrimp wontons.

Both mains were tasteless and overpriced.

We would not go back.
author: David K.

description:
My husband had come here on a business dinner and had really liked what he'd experienced, so he thought I should come as well. Why not... It looked really nice on the outside.  Using the VERY helpful Yelp reservation App (Saved my bacon a few times in this city) I made my ressie for 7:15 pm and showed up RIGHT on time.  The hostess took my name, and I sat for about 5 minutes before we were shown to our table. 

The place is something else. It is upscale, quite lovely and the decor is just grand.  It isn't what you expect for a mall eatery.  We walked past the open kitchen towards a table near the back and were seated. Our waitress Oulu came and took our drink orders, offering us either sparkling water or flat water.. we opted for the flat, which was served in a decorative glass long necked bottle. 

When she came back, about 5 minutes later, we knew what we wanted: The husband had a bowl of hot & sour soup and General Miao (?)'s chicken. Me, I ordered the Wonton Soup and the crispy baked chicken.  I was advised that the chicken would take about 20 minutes, if that was ok. It was.  We also ordered a pot of Jasmine pearl tea.

The soups were delivered separately, his first, mine about 4 minutes later.  The husband really liked his, mine.. it could have used salt or soy, neither of which was on the table. 

When the mains came out, same thing... separately, as if they were different courses, but I knew to expect that mine would be later.  The husband's food was beautifully presented. The red and green of the peppers contrasted prettily with the golden skin of of the chicken.  It also came with a couple of dipping sauces.  I was worried that it might be too spicy for me, but it wasn't.  It had really good flavour.

When mine came out, it had been chopped prettily, a powered plum sauce was in a small dish and there was some chopped ginger off to the side. The chicken had a lovely flavour but it was a tad dry. I ate about 1/2 of what was on the plate, sharing some with my husband. 

We opted for dessert, something we're not want to do often these days, but I couldn't resist the Sugar egg puffs with three dipping sauces: Vanilla bean whipped cream, Dark Chocolate and Raspberry coulis. LORDY! This was the highlight of the meal. They were light and hot, and the sauces, either alone or mixed really brought the whole thing to life. 

I might come back, the prices were a bit steep, but the flavours were nice.
author: Dianna B.

description: I can't put my finger on why it only gets 4/5 stars. They didn't do anything wrong - it was just standard. Like a standard nicer Chinese restaurant.  Everything I had was good. Service was good. Environment was good.  Maybe I just felt weird bc it was in the mall and didn't know that when I made reservations here earlier in the day. Like- why would I eat at the mall in San Francisco? It makes me feel like I ate at Cheesecake Factory or something. :/
author: Julianna I.

description: Great restaurant with super quick service and delicious food. We love their crispy tofu, it's the best tofu perpetration in a long time! We also love the mapo tofu, and chow fun noodles. Dessert menu if worth a look too. Also, try the mango soda, very refreshing. If with a baby, try the outdoor seating, as that gives enough space and open environment for the baby/ toddler.
author: Anisha Y.

description: Came over invited by owner. This is so good Asian cuisines modern restaurant. Preping, cookijg and Presentation are so innovative by fine picking the best of cross Asian best dishes.
author: Youliang W.

description: Dinner was better than lunch. Dinner was tastier and food cooked through, while lunch was under cooked for vegetable dumpling & cauliflower. Ribs were dry and wild boar chow fun seems to be cooked separately, so the dish was bland.  Everything for dinner was well cooked and flavorful.  Suit Lung Bao was juicy.  Lichee dessert was good, but diced strawberries were sour.
author: Janet J.

description:
Get the Juicy Dumplings!! Get the Juicy Dumplings! Just get them!! They aren't cheap but what do you expect if you are going to a high end Chinese restaurant in downtown San Francisco!?!?!?! The dumplings come prepare already in a red spoon! You don't have to worry about the soup spilling everywhere! 

Get the Shandong Beef Rolls too!! Super good! I think they taste 10x better than the beef pancake/rolls from Z&Y in SF Chinatown!

We also got the Bang Bang Chicken Wings, Wild Boar Lettuce Cups, Salt & Pepper Calamari to start and they were all good.

For the main entrees, we got the honey glazed walnut shrimp, Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood, Sichuan Green Beans, Twin Scallops Fried Rice, Yang Zhou Fried Rice and the Peking Roast Duck. The Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles and the Peking Roast Duck were my favorites!

For dessert, we had the Sugar Egg Puffs/ Chinese donut. They were bigger than expected but very good.

I was a little dissapointed that I didn't get to see Martin Yan but Tony Wu was there pulling the noodles.

I'll definitely come here again for the juicy dumplings and the Shandong beef rolls!!!!
author: Alice X.

description: I went to M.Y. China for happy hour one day after shopping in SF and it was delicious!! Seriously. M.Y. China is like a fancier version of PF Chang's! (IMHO) Anyway, the happy hour is really good. They change their cocktails depending on the season & the bartender was really helpful! I remember my drink had a nice cinnamon/nutmeg taste (this was a couple weeks ago in the beginning of October) I was dining alone so obviously I went to the bar (not sit at a table) and I even made a new friend while enjoying my drink. For food I ordered their shao mai. Anyway 4.5 stars in my book and I would return again.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I have been here twice and just mmmmm'd my way through the whole meal. Really flavorful and delicious all the way around. Sichuan green beans... just right spicy and cooked tender crispy. Dim sum; had the bbq steamed bao, the shanghai soup dumplings, and the shu mai, all delicious! (I will say Din Tai Fung has these Shanghai soup dumplings in a competition though...) but good fresh flavors all around. Had the wok fired beef, tender absolutely melt in your mouth delicious. Yang Zhou fried rice was heavenly. So light, first fried rice I ever had that had all the fry and none of the grease. 
Service was adequate and efficient, atmosphere enjoyable and comfortable. A wonderful, delicious respite from shopping and will go many more times. One of those restaurants that you go to and remember later, and crave more.
author: Paige B.

description:
After a night of shopping, we came here for dinner. Knowing it was Martin Yan's restaurant, I was excited to try the food.  We ordered the crispy noodles, stir fried lamb, and Sichuan string beans. 

I thought the flavors of the string beans was very good. It was not too spicy nor too oily.  The curry lamb was flavored and cooked perfect. The lamb did not have any taste of game.   I found the crispy noodles to be soaked in too much sauce. The noodles would have stood out if they did not add too much of the sauce.   

Overall it was a good meal.
author: Marck N.

description:
Came in here and orderd the wok fried lamb, hong kong crispy noodles and the stir fried string beans. All were very tasty. The string beans had the right amount of spice and savory. I thought it was the best flavored of the 3. The lamb was tender and flavorful - not as gamey as one might think. 

I ordered the east meets west cocktail. It was a little on the weak side and I think needed a little more alcohol in it. 

Overall experience was good. Prices were rather reasonable here.
author: Kenson K.

description: in a word: bland. even the vinegar sauce tasted watered down. the mixed drinks were quite good, and the scallion pancakes were nice and light and crispy -- but then served with no dipping sauce? maybe i've been trained into a false norm with that. the cauliflower and portabello in hoisin sauce had gloves of garlic visible but not tasteable. i'd say the overall quality was maybe just above a pf changs. for my money, i'd take the oriental pearl above this any day.
author: Alex M.

description:
First off the service here SUCK BIG TIME!! 

2. I asked the hostess to sit us somewhat quite but were sat in the middle of everyone. 

3. Our server has an attitude not sure why but we were not treated here like a paying customer just like everyone else.  

My mom and I was so DISAPPOINTED at this place, we were so DEGRADED!! We ordered the Hong Kong style crispy noodles and Chaiman Mao's chicken with a side of rice. The noodles came after 10-12 min of ordering, we was wondering what have happened to our other order which was the Chairman Mao's chicken, since we have the noodles and waiting for our other order. My mother noticed that our next door table complained that, what's he's EATING wasn't his order when it was supposed to be OURS ( Chairman Mao's Chicken) we have the same server. My mom was watching them, our server took  their wrong order and brought it to the order counter and just asked the person who is in charge there to just add some more chicken so he can just give it to us since that was our order.. REALLY M.Y. China??? Don't they train they're staff? That is so UNSANITARY AND GROSS!! They were supposed to throw that away and give us a new one and FYI ATLEAST fucking apologize to your customer that I'm sorry I delivered your order to a wrong table and your order is coming up!! Instead our server ignored us even though she saw my mom complaining to the person that was in charge at the order counter.. Finally the the supervisor came up to us and apologize with the mixed up orders and saying that the Chairman Mao's chicken is coming up, but at this point we don't have an appetite anymore and just wanted to leave. We was not even offer a discount or anything. Still no apologies from the stupid server that thinks he's high above than everyone else. We left DISSAPPOINTED AND DEGRADED! 

To the General manager of M.Y. China, please have some compassion with your customers. Train your servers well. My mother works in customers service so she knows how to treat people well. 


FYI Yelpers, watch the servers moves  over here they might do the same thing with you mixed up the order and might feed you your next tables left over!

Date:3/7/17 we came around 11:50 left by 12:30... 

Do something about this management, by reading the reviews here I noticed that the service really suck!!
author: Diane M.

description: Even though this place is overpriced for Chinese food, it is DELICIOUS!  All the handmade noodle dishes are excellent.  The mu-shu tacos are amazing too.
author: Mimi C.

description: I enjoyed my black peppered snapper. It was cooked nicely with the right amount of flavor. Presentation was pretty good too. Server was not friendly, seemed to be in a rush when the restaurant was not even busy. I personally did not like the location of this restaurant, but I would definitely be back to try other selections on the menu.
author: Andy D.

description: We go here for lunch with my co-workers pretty often as this restaurant is conveniently located and can accommodate larger groups. Hong Kong crispy noodles with chicken and their lettuce boar cups are to die for! Their tea selection is pretty nice as well and the service is up to par!
author: Irina B.

description: Excellent food.  Excellent service.  Well appointed.  You'll forget you are in the mall.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Came here first time and last time. 

The dessert is lacklustre and noodles, boar meat, and fruit salad had something in them, more likely msg that caused a headache and altered my mood until I went to bed.  

I don't usually eat out and this place seem ok aesthetically. 

I have a clean palate which means I eat whole foods primarily and that is how I prefer to eat. 

Every now again,  I will go out and try something out of my range.  

The last time I had a msg headache was when I had dim sum at yang sing.  

From my experience,  Chinese food equates to msg,  and more likely to feel the effects if you have sensitivity.  

Usually my safe bet is Japanese.  Japanese is my go to and until Chinese can learn to cook without msg,  this is a total pass. 

6.00 for tax,  3.00 for sf employer mandate on top of what you order and a tip... you will pay at least $70 + .... which is not something I am willing to pay for a headache and chemically prepared food. 

I thought the food was great up until right before we left and feeling lightheaded and strange only to realize,  I had the same reaction at yang sing.  

If certain items are great and some are not,  then this indicates inconsistencies.

It should also be said that I cannot comment on happy hour or beverages as I do not drink.
author: V V.

description:
Service was outstanding. The waiter sat me quickly and made a solid recommendation after asking me a few questions of what I like. 

Food was solid but served very very hot (temperature). Xiao long boa were very flavorful but the spoons they were served in were WAY to hot. By the time the spoons cooled enough to not burn your lips, the dumplings cooled enough to start sticking to the spoon. I'd probably get them again and try to time my eating better. 

Chairman Mao's Chicken was very good but, again, served too hot. Because the chunks were so big, it felt cool enough on the outside but the inside was mouth-burning hot. This were cubes of chicken deep fried then dry-tossed with salt, pepper, Chili peppers, onion, and green pepper. Many places would call this firecracker chicken - it is NOT covered in gross goo. I recommend it.
author: Michael O.

description:
This restaurant's food safety warning on Yelp is real. We used to come here often, but during today's dining experience we found long hairs in our dishes on two separate occasions :( 

Can't say we're coming back anymore.
author: P A.

description: We went on a random Saturday night and guess who was there, Mr. Martin Yan himself!! It was my second time at this restaurant, we liked it so much I threw a surprise birthday party for my friend. Best surprise ever Martin Yan joined us and talked to us took photos and videos lol!! Now on to the food my favorites are the green seafood dumplings, beef roll, seafood noodles, and lychee panacotta. I'm Chinese and I know what good Chinese food is. This is legit!
author: Karen T.

description: An excellent restaurant, conveniently located at the Powell BART station, near the convention hotels. We've traveled extensively in China and found that the food here was entirely satisfying. The decor was pleasing and relaxing. We had lunch with friends; they were delighted. We actually  thought about returning again for dinner! Would definitely return again next time we're in San Francisco.
author: Lance N.

description: We recently visited with a large group this upscale Chinese restaurant in a Mall for a birthday dinner. The hand-pulled noodles, Spicy Seafood Dumplings and classy cocktails drew us back the following evening for dinner. The service is wonderful and very attentive.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Review update
The restaurant contacted me, spoke with the waiter, and offered to make it right.     I have not had the opportunity to take them up on it.   Very professional response.   I am satisfied - all is forgiven.
_______________________________________________________
Ate here lunch Sunday 9/3.   Had reasonably high hopes.  High end Chinese with high end locations in China.  Fancy signs and finishes.    Kung Pao Chicken and Pork Egg Fried v tasty (see later). Waiter ( White, wrap around beard, quiet demeanor) disappeared after taking our order.   I mentioned this to give a hint - he did not take the hint.   The bus boy guy brought hot sauce and soy sauce-  needed on the above.   Rounded it out perfectly  (is there a reason the rice comes 5 minutes before the dish with which it goes?-  maybe there is).  And yes you guessed it -   The waiter appears with the bill!.    Not before I grabbed my wine back from him as it was unfinished.    The kids then started and ate the brown rice we ordered.   The check sitting on the table all the while.   The last persons dinner was caked in the small bowl brought as clean.  When we raised this it was explained ' it's difficult to get off' -  I stated this could not be the case

I sat and figured what this service was worth.  0.75 c each - is $3.    It's been 20 years since I reduced a tip - in this case the reduction was deserved.    Food truly delicious (when the sauce arrived from the bus boy).   Service - see above

Mr MV needs to come back from his travels and get on the sloppy under-managed situ here!
author: Chris S.

description: Best Chinese food at the best price! Went everywhere that's supposed to be the best Chinese restaurants here in SF and yes, they are also good, but to have great crab, great xiao long bao, best noodles all at one place,l is only at MY China. Saw Mr Martin Yan at restaurant several times here, serving guests; such commitment from a famous owner is unheard of!
author: Enchante T.

description: The food is outstanding and the service is excellent. Yes, it's a little pricey but I think it's worth it (and I tend to be pretty frugal)
author: A K.

description:
I know dim sum and Chinese food well having lived in SF for 9 years and being a Chinese American.

Here's what you'll get from MyChina, overpriced touristy food with a transparent fancier twist. Twists like making Shanghai dumpings worse by adding a slice of cucumber.

I expect crappy service when I'm in Chinatown, but not in an overpriced Westfield restaurant. The servers are mostly Mexicans? From what I can tell the busers also hand out your food, muttering the dishes as they drop them on your table.

I had to ask 4 times to get soy sauce with our table of 7's dim sum. That's like putting chips on the table with no salsa at a Mexican restaurant.

The only saving grace of this place are the hand pulled noodle soups, which are $15 for a small bowl (I could eat 3 bowls, I'm 160lbs). Also, I wouldn't be surprised if they weren't actually hand pulled like their menu suggests.

No thanks.
author: Michael W.

description: This place was quite good.  Dim sum sampler: solid.  Beef noodle soup: broth a bit on the bland side, but the beef was melt-in-mouth, baby bok choy was tender, and the noodles were clearly fresh and house-made.  Pea shoots were terrific.  Slick interior and it's fun to watch the cooks at work in the kitchen behind the glass.  Dining "outside" the restaurant in the mall area under the big beautiful dome is nice, but can feel a bit isolating.  Unfortunately, it's all pretty expensive, but hey... it's a celebrity chef place, in a fancy mall, in San Francisco, so what do you expect?
author: Eric B.

description:
First time today, enjoyed an amazing lunch of Peking duck, Beijing knife cut noodles, and xiao long bao. I was blown away at the deliciousness. Esp the noodles. OH. EM. GEE.

I'm coming back. Nom nom.
author: Christine T.

description:
Yes, this place is overpriced.  I will say that over and over, but it doesn't change the fact that their food is great and they really do cook up dishes that fit my idea of what good Chinese food should taste like.  That being said, now:

Dim sum: They have the best soup dumplings I have tasted in San Francisco city proper.  If you want to haul ass down the peninsula to Santa Clara and the like, yes you're going to find something better.  Here, they serve them steaming hot each in large oversized red ceramic spoons. The dumplings are adhered to the spoon with a piece of sticky flour, so don't try to pick them up, peel them off.  Just poke a hole and enjoy sipping and eating them from the serving spoon. They put a piece of cucumber on the bottom of each spoon that synergizes well with the oily soup.  Their other dim sum is decent, but their soup dumplings are the best over here.

Main Dishes (meats, fish): I've tried and liked the Honey Glazed BBQ pork and  Tea Smoked Sea Bass.  Both dishes are very good, splurge on the sea bass if you're interested in seeing how fish can taste like fatty meat :3

Peking Duck:  pass, go to excelsior's Beijing restaurant.  The duck here is old, dry and the rest is whatever.  Also they serve it with buns, not the pancake.

Others: Forbidden rice is crack. It's mixed rice (purple, wild, other) that is steamed and then seems to be lightly fried or tossed in sesame oil?  It's very fragrant. Another great thing is the garlic pea shoots (it's a side).  Priciest damn plate of greens ever, but they do pick very good quality greens, crunchy, tender and sweet perfectly stir fried with garlic oil.
author: Alice S.

description:
No matter you are sitting inside or outside, you still can be ignored. Order one item wait like 40mins because the first 10mins I couldn't find anyone to take my order. Menu did not have lots of selection is ok, but plate is mess too. Maybe I expect too much, M.Y just a "high class" cafe.

Updated 2/26/17
I was really disappointed how M.Y. China treat customer like this. I ordered carb & pork dumplings, it came out 3 of the carb & pork dumpling and 2 of the juicy pork dumpling when one order supposed to have 5 of the carb & pork dumpling. I ordered shrimp & papaya salad, it came out with mango, not papaya. Seriously? Staff can't even realize what's different between papaya and mango? How about if I allergy for mango? If there is out of papaya, this is yours the responsibility to let customer know. I mean I feel like someone trick on me. I don't like business treats customer on this way.
With the comment below, I thought they take serious to read customer's comment. I want them to be better, and wrote an email to carol like he/ she said. Unfortunately, I did not get any reply from him. I mean at least reply me back, and let me know he was received email right? Never come back. Both make me sick.
author: Rainy G.

description:
4.5 stars! 

For a mall restaurant, this place is surprisingly exceptional. 

My favorites are the spicy seafood dumplings, juicy dumplings and the honey walnut shrimp. The seafood dumplings come in this tangy, spicy sauce that I would put on anything and eat. The juicy dumplings are just really good xiao long baos, lol. An order comes with both pork with crab roe and pork dumplings. Personally, I prefer the pork to the pork and crab roe. Their dumpling wrappers are thin and soft, just perfect to hold all the filling in. Honey walnut shrimp can be found on almost all Chinese restaurant menus, but this place adds wasabi in their honey mayo mix that just takes it to another level, I LOVE it. I've also had the wonton soup, which isn't anything exciting, rather plain, but warm and comforting nonetheless. I can't wait to try other menu items, like the tacos and pork belly baos.

The atmosphere is nice and the restaurant is clean and well decorated. Service is pretty quick and the servers are friendly. Depending on the time and day, there could be a wait, but I don't think it would ever be anything completely ridiculous. Regardless, I recommend making a reservation just to be on the safe side, especially on days the mall is the place to be.
author: Katherine L.

description: Best place to eat in the mall. So fun and a wonderful variety on the menu. Even GF options which makes me very happy.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Dont know why I haven't tried this place before! 

Happy Hour M-F 3-6pm!
$7 cocktails, $6/$24 wines, $3 beers, $5 bites:)

We had:
*bang bang chicken wings - AMAZING
* crispy tofu - aite
* har gow - YESSSSSSSS SOO GOOD the skin is perfect and the shrimp is so freshhh
* shui mai - juicy
* pork juicy dumpling - AMAZINGGGGGG definitely not din tai fung or yanksing, but it's perfectly soft and oh so juicy! & only $5 for 4! Zucchini adds nice touch too!

Cant wait to come back
author: Cheri K.

description: Taste sucks and service sucks. Our food came much later than people who came much later than us. After we asked about our food, then it came. I'm sure the server forgot to serve our food. We felt terrible and just left without being done with food.
author: Suckwon L.

description:
Went to SF early in the morning with my girlfriend and decided to get some food in the mall. We came here after seeing a video of it on YouTube and decided "Why not?" the lL d is beautiful and the service was spot on. The food was amazing as well. Ordered us some dim sum (shiu Mai and Har gow) and sweet and sour pork. The dim sum came out quick, then shortly after we finished the dim sum, our entree came out. 

Tl:Dr -  Good food and service
author: Chris N.

description: Beef Shandong rolls, Chairman Mao's chicken, Crispy Tofu, with dirty martinis. Weekend brunch done right!
author: Ninad S.

description: Upgrading because they've really improved on any and all of my past gripes.  Their stuff tastes great and is innovative.  Clean and beautiful restaurant with great service.  A nice mix of authentic and fusion.  For several weeks they had an anniversary special menu with what we call 'squirrel fish' in China.
author: Zheng G.

description: We came here on a Friday night before watching the lion king at the Orpheum.  We sat at the bar for happy hour and tried a few of their dishes.  The cocktails were outstanding and there were a variety to choose from.  The dishes we tried were dim sum style and they were also excellent.  They were steaming hot, and just awesome.  We had a great bartender that night too.  Awesome spot to kill time at in the Westfield mall on the third floor.
author: Michelle S.

description: The Food here is phenomenal. Started the night off with the Pork bun sliders and the dim sum. For the entrees with had the crispy noodles, mao chicken, black snapper, pork ribs, fried rice, pea shoots, and green beans. Lets just say we got our money's worth. Ended the night off with the cream puffs, tiramisu, and creme brûlée. Also the lemonades are really good here (strawberry/raspberry/mango). Definitely a spot to come back.
author: Kamalu K.

description: I was here in Thursday Lunch with my friends.We ordered the beef noodle soup$16 ,stir fry vegetables €16, tea$6, dianxin$8, bun with pork belly $8. Very small portion for every dish! So pricy!  The taste is just average. The service is good though.But will not come back for such expensive lunch!
author: Benson H.

description:
Friend and I have been here before and like coming when we go shopping downtown.  We both like the modern concept of Chinese food. Shiu mai and mu shu taco were very tasty.  Tried the tofu noodle salad which I liked but friend was less impressed. We both thought the chicken salad was a little too bland.

I am giving 4 stars because I have been here before trying other dishes (especially the noodles and dim sum) and enjoyed it.  Service was friendly and efficient. The restaurant is a pleasant environment to rest and talk with friends.
author: Gayle N.

description: Had the minced beef knife cut noodles, roast duck, juicy pork dumplings, and a lychee pudding for dessert. Food was absolutely amazing. I have no idea why others have left subpar reviews. The friend I dined with told me the dishes were authentic Chinese food, and she didn't understand why anyone would give this restaurant  less than five stars either. Good for us, I guess. Less of a wait when we want to eat here!
author: Jiwon K.

description:
"If Yan can cook, so can you!"

Ever since I was a kid, Martin Yan's signature line has been burned into my brain.  However, being limited to just watching his TV show, Yan could cook it but I could never try it.  That is, until he opened up his restaurant in the Westfield Center.  So, after my friend and I found our original lunch plans thrown for a loop and seeing nary a line outside M.Y. China, we decided to check them out!

The décor of the space was really nice, but I especially liked how our seats at the counter allowed us to watch the kitchen do its thing (I'd recommend it for small parties).  As for the menu, it was pretty cool how there's a mix of both traditional and more modern versions of Chinese dishes.

- WILD BOAR SCISSOR CUT NOODLES with Wood Ear Mushrooms, Scallions and Shaoxing Wine...$14
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2#PoUjuaiGxLPP0O-AEjOu9w)
While it wasn't bad, the dish wasn't all that exciting.  I liked the consistency and texture of the noodles, but the flavor could have used more of the boar.

- WILD BOAR JUICY DUMPLINGS (4) with Ginger, Garlic, and M.Y. Seasoned Salt.....$8
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2#td64XEqqhnqR7uy2OPzGqQ)
The wild boar was much more successful here than in the noodle dish.  Each dumpling was decently filled and the meat was pretty juicy.  I wish there had been more soup in each one, but the dish was fine otherwise (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2#QJuydsrQplssABvejnUB6w).

- M.Y. DIM SUM COLLECTION - Shiu Mai (2), Steamed BBQ Pork Bao (1), Multi Grain Rice (1), Har Gow (2), Seafood Dumpling (2), and Mongolian Beef Bao (1)...$19
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2#E0RSyIwF0AnlEHexFCq0oA)
Yes, we knew it was expensive for dim sum, but it allowed us to try several more items in one dish.  Overall, it was underwhelming.  The Shu Mai was actually pretty good and the Har Gow and Multi Grain Rice were okay.  The two baos were pretty "meh" though and I didn't care much for the Seafood Dumpling.

- WOK SEARED BEEF FILET with Sichuan Peppercorns on a bed of Arugula...$18
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2#M1rnqAkCUOFl_f_VHfPGtg)
Easily my favorite dish.  I feared the meat would be tough, but each piece was both tender and flavorful.  The beef combined really well with the arugula too.

As far as the prices go, it's undeniably higher here than at other Chinese restaurants in SF.  However, I'd be reluctant to say M.Y. China is "overpriced" since both the quality of the ingredients and the service are much better.  Plus, it's somewhat expected given the name above the door and their location (it is Union Square).

Money aside, the food itself was the bigger issue for me.  While the beef and dumpling dishes were good, the other two didn't do much for me.  Nothing bad mind you, but nothing amazing.  I wouldn't be opposed to coming back though...especially to try the Beef Noodle Soup (Niu Ro Mien) Erika C. tried!
author: Mike L.

description: Food not so great. Not worth the price. Service is lousy. Took 40 minutes to get the food served. Waiters do not routinely follow up with customers what they need. I observed food deliver to wrong customers several times. I do not get why a lot of people visit this place. There are so many great places in the city with good price and great service. I am not happy with my experience and not recommending this place.
author: Ernesto C.

description:
This is one of the worst restaurants I have ever been to. 他們的食物不好吃味道像狗屎 (almost everything was tasteless/seasoned poorly and the pork filling of the XLB had a really odd texture to it). It was as unauthentic of an experience as it gets. Martin Yan has brought much disgrace upon the entire Chinese community.

But to be fair, they didn't have 3 different parties all sharing a single table, the utensils were clean and the waiter brought out exactly what were ordered - the signs were all there.
author: Jonathan H.

description: A group of us went to MY China on Chinese New Year Parade day in SF. We serendipituously ran into Chef Martin Yan from "Yan Can Cook". He was super friendly, entertaining and ensured we had a good time! The food was great & high quality, also kept its authentic Chinese cuisine.
author: Su L.

description:
Came here tonight for Happy Hour. Being Asian myself, I was a bit skeptical about going to a Chinese restaurant for happy hour with coworkers. I thought, "must be potstickers, small bowls of wonton noodle soups, small plates of fried rice and chow Mein" Boy was I wrong! I got here in time for their happy hour menu. Ordered every thing on their HH menu which were $5 bites and $7 cocktails. Each plate was served pretty quickly. The waitress was super nice and attentive and came by a few times to refill our glass bottles of water and cups. The foods itself was superb!! My favorites were the octopus calamari, the spicy tofu, pork dumplings, shrimp dumplings (huge shrimp portions) and the smackin' semi spicy fried chicken. The batter on the chicken was crisp with every bite. Absolutely loved it with their special sauce. Also ordered the Hong Kong style crispy noodle. This is a must try. The texture and taste satisfied my palates.

Drinks- I had the Lan Kwai Fong drink. Forgot what it was made of but if you like something on the fruity side, give this drink a try. It was a unique flavor that i never had elsewhere. It gave me a really nice buzz. I also had a drink that the bartender name Derrick made. I'll call it "Derrick's Special" since that was his name. It was grapefruit and I think honey infused. Yummy!! 

This is by far one of the best Asian fusion Chinese restaurants I've been to. I definitely will come back to try the rest of their menu.
author: Lynd A.

description:
(update) I still love My China .. but was a little disappointed with the happy hr menus change .. I think they had it right the first time 

Just got the news you took the soup dumplings off the happy hr menu. This was the whole reason me or any of my friends came in. I will no longer be coming here. Thanks My China !!! :(
author: Micah W.

description:
Happy Hour Review:
Higher end Chinese restaurant with some basics, specializing in noodle dishes. Good for a first date or meal with friends and probably not ideal for families with young ones. Happy hour here is great for a sampling of small plates and drinks. HH Menu doesn't include any noodle dishes though. Snapshot of HH menu in my photos below. 

Location -- Third floor Westfield shopping center under the dome. Easy stop if you're in the area shopping in downtown SF.

Service -- I gotta give it to our waiter Dylan for doing a great job recommending food and drinks. A+ the guy knew what he was taking about!

Price -- Median price for main course dishes $15-18. Take advantage of Happy Hour menu Monday-Friday 3-6p. Specially drinks $7 and small plates $5.

Try:
Small plate
-Bang Bang chicken wings (HH price $5) 
 Think San Tung style spicy sweet 
Drinks
-Buddha breeze (HH price $7) 
  Light and crisp (Hangar one vodka, basil and cucumber)
-Frolic (HH price $7)
 Sweet and fruity (blue coat gin, prosecco, lemonade, muddled strawberries)

Off the Regular menu:
-Wild Boar scissor cut noodles $15
 Similar to beef chow mein with thicker noodles. Noodles are hand cut. See photo.
author: Shanna M.

description:
This mall establishment actually serves some pretty decent real Chinese food. Sure the dim sum is 2-3x what you would pay compared to a Chinatown restaurant but it's the ambiance and service you pay for right? Well, at least that's what I kept telling myself while nibbling away on my $7 shui mai order. Order the BBQ pork. It's cooked perfectly with a honey glaze. A bed of soy sauce soy beans would complete the dish! The XO rice noodles was also a hit with my party as well. I think everyone voted it as the best dish.

So the tacos (mooshu?) just didn't hit the spot as the flour tortillas could have been easily replaced with maybe a thinner pancake or bun (like those used for Peking duck). The flavors of the filling were good though. Our party was partial with the pan fried noodles (dressing was a tad salty) and we were somewhat disappointed with the dan dan noodles (noodles were vermicelli-like rice noodles instead of thick noodles). 

Nonetheless, I give this place 4 stars for offering a good food option beyond the food court. 

Just to put it out there. The bathrooms stalls are unisex and we're quite filthy the afternoon I was there. This was in stark contrast to the dining room which was impeccable and nicely decorated with art/artwork.
author: W A.

description:
Expensive, but happy hour more affordable.
The Asian hostess, at the podium, was a straight up bitch. She thinks she's above all the wait staff. She asked me to move to another table because it was still not cleaned. I told her the other hostess told me I could sit there. There was only one plate, the check, and a glass that needed to be cleaned. 
Instead of saying "we'll get it cleaned up right away," she huffed away. 
Get over yourself. 
The calamari were big slices instead of small rings, which I'm partial to and on the spicy side.
The roast chicken I ordered was moist and some skin was crispy,  but a little bland. 
There are just so many Chinese restaurants that are cheaper, better and without the wanna be pompous staff.
author: Geraldine H.

description:
Fast service great food, make sure to make a reservation and to order the beef noodle soup.
Excellent atmosphere...
author: Osmani V.

description:
IF YOU HAVE FOOD ALLERGIES AVOID THIS PLACE!!!!!

TLDR: Of the 2 dishes I ordered, they screwed up 4 times and would have given me a severe allergic reaction!

I went to My China on Wed evening with my CEO and several of his friends. I explained my food allergies of peppers, cayenne, chili powder and anything "spicy" to the waitress and was advised I could eat the fried chicken appetizer, rice and sweet and sour chicken.

The waitress brought the fried chicken wings and it was immediately obvious that it was covered in cayenne or chili powder with peppers on top of it. All of which I am very allergic to. The waitress apologized and promised that she would make sure it didn't happen again.

She brought out the order and promised it was fine as she had personally talked to the head chef and he was extra careful. I almost took a bite when my dining companions told me to stop because it had a ton of straight cayenne on it.

I waited for 5 minutes and went to find a manager, I spoke with another waitress who said she was on break and would come see me shortly and took the wings for a second time.

Our waitress came back apologizing again, and I reiterated my food allergies and that this was serious. She promised to make sure there was no more problems. She delivered the wings shortly after and the 3rd time, no spice, just incredibly over cooked. I assume the chef wasn't happy.

I hadn't received my main dish at this point while the others had been out for awhile. When it came, it was covered in peppers and appeared to have chili flake as well. The table tried it and reported it was spicy. At this point people were finishing up their meals and I was very embarrassed.  The group insisted on waiting until I had my dinner and ended up sitting there for 30 minutes until my food came and I finished it as fast as I could.

This whole experience was very embarrassing and is simply inexcusable.

P.S. The manager never came to talk to me.
author: Scott M.

description: Extremely excellent service! I held my boyfriends surprise bday party here and it turned out phenomenal. The hosts were able to accommodate 11 people and their heartwarming service made our experience the greatest. We were the very last to leave the restaurant and they never failed to make our night amazing!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Actually one of my go-to happy hour spots from I believe 3:30pm - 6pm.  Drinks and dim sum for about $5-8.  
The service is very friendly and helpful and the food is great.  I have tried many items on both their happy hour menu and regular menu and all were terrific...except their calamari.  The calamari was hard and chewy (more than once).  But their hand-pulled noodles, chicken, vegetables and dim sum were very good.
author: Christina C.

description:
Very disappointed. We heard about this restaurant when it was featured on a Bay Area restaurant review show, I believe it was Check Please. We were very excited to try it out, but really wish we had chosen any other SF restaurant or just had Chinese food at our local place. 

Cons: food was bland, service was awkward (was taking last bite of appetizer and the server was waiting to take my plate), the wok seared seafood had a slimy texture, way over priced, cocktails were tiny and pricy. 

Pros: pretty, clean, the cocktail was the best tasting thing there (tiny). 

For the price I paid, I could have taken my family out to any other Chinese restaurant 3 times and enjoyed the meal. Not worth it at all. We won't be going back.
author: Tab J.

description:
Should have 5 stars. Quick service, friendly waitress, authentic food yet delicious. 

A different kind of taste for a chinese food. Noodle broth is fantastic. Juicy dumplings is a perfection. Salt and peppers calamari should be salt and chili calamari, cause no pepper but chilies all over the calamari. 

Overall satisfied having dinner here, a pity we couldn't meet Martin Yan himself here!
author: Janoko W.

description:
I've eaten here on 2 occasions and both were outstanding.

First occasion: dinner. The must orders are the bang bang chicken wangs and spicy seafood dumplings, both of which were dressed in sauces I wish I had buckets full.

Second occasion: drinks at their bar. Try their old fashion because their take is unique. 

The restaurant is extremely clean. Their open kitchen is organized and I felt very comfortable eating there. Great place to take a date, your family, or to just enjoy a drink at their bar.

The only gripe I have with this establishment is I wish they were open later.
author: Nathan L.

description:
When I was younger, I grew up watching Martin Yan on "Yan Can Cook". So I had to come and check this place out the next time I was in SF.

This restaurant is located in the newer wing of the Westfield Center mall, near Bloomingdale's. I actually made reservations on Open Table (just in case).

AMBIANCE:
Trendy, nice decor, upscale

FOOD:
*Pork and black truffle juicy dumplings - I love xiao long bao (steamed soup dumpings)! I also love truffle too! They bring in a steamer with 5 red spoons, each filled with a dumpling. It's a different and nice presentation. Nice to not have to worry about the dumpling sticking to the bottom of the steamer and leaking the soup all over the place. I enjoyed this very much! Very flavorful. Just pricey at $18.

*Spicy seafood dumpling - Yummy! I love dumplings and seafood. I love how its wrapped in a green, spinach-based wrapper. I really enjoyed the flavors. You can taste the shrimp and scallop. This dish was $9. 

*Sugar egg puffs - Perfect dessert! Light, fluffy pieces of fried dough that were covered in powdered sugar. Basically tasted like a cream puff without the filling. They came out fresh and hot. This was $8.

Overall, a very pricey place to grab a meal at the mall. Nice option to have when I don't want to eat at the food court.
author: Lily Y.

description:
"If Yan can cook, then you pay Yan." I assume that must be Martin Yan's hard-earned motto since he was truly one of the pioneer celebrity chefs back in the 1980's. I can barely remember when Yan hasn't been on TV with his congenial gumption and frantic chopping expertise. I have to admit I came to M.Y. China with a great deal of trepidation because as good as his dishes looked on PBS back in the day, I thought he may have passed the point of relevancy when it comes to fine dining in a city with as much food gravitas as San Francisco.

However, Yan's elaborate operation on the 4th floor of the Westfield Shopping Centre holds its own in many respects (photo: http://bit.ly/11zPDlJ). It just fell short of what I was hoping it would be. Perhaps my expectations were escalated by the fact that I had experienced two failed attempts to dine here right after it opened - one time due to a private party, the other because they were just full up. I finally made it as a solitary diner and was seated at the end of the long noodle counter. The menu is not very complicated, and I knew from the hype that chef Tony Chu was known for holding the record of pulling 16,000 noodles in two minutes flat. Clearly this uniquely dexterous feat meant you had to try the noodles which I did.

Based on Michael Bauer's recommendation on sfgate.com, I went for the $14 Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, which were definitely the high point of the meal - irregularly cut handmade noodles tossed with shallots and Shaoxing wine (photo: http://bit.ly/12E0Kwm). I liked the rustic quality, and they were flavorful enough with the pieces of pork-like boar. I just wish there were more ingredients tossed in for a greater contrast in texture and flavor. Probably out of curiosity more than anything else, I ordered the $9 pair of Mu Shu Pork Tacos, which were a cheeky take on the standard Mandarin dish that comes with a stack of crepes.

What arrived was a pair of tacos held upright in a stand with the mu shu pork stuffed in soft shells that were definitely not tortillas (photo: http://bit.ly/ZLSoh9). The net result was tasty but sloppy as the sesame oil would dribble out of the taco shell and onto my arm despite the proper vertical head turning in eating them. My last dish was the rather ordinary $8 Stir-Fried Green Beans which I ordered to counter the carb overload (photo: http://bit.ly/15Dd8zr). The beans had the right snap, but they were on the saucy side with a slightly oily aftertaste. All in all, I liked the boldness of the dishes even though I found they still need more refinement in their execution to satisfy at least my palate.

FOOD - 3 stars...solid handmade noodles but the tacos were more a novelty and the green beans didn't need that much sauce
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...very dramatic, a good use of the space underneath the dome...but it did get lonely being the only one eating at the counter (photo: http://bit.ly/17TXZtf)
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite attentive and helpful, no problems there
TOTAL - 3 stars...if Yan can cook, then I pay Yan...simple as that
author: Ed U.

description:
Martin, oh, Martin, how you have disappointed me so. You were one of the first to successfully mix cooking and entertainment. But this slick-interior restaurant offers neither cooking nor entertainment.

We came here in a big group and were seated in a very nicely-appointed booth. The restaurant is LOUD, LOUD LOUD LOUD....  Couldn't hear anyone except those to my left and right.

So the good news first

PLUSES: interior - beautiful, modern Asian

And now the bad news 
MINUSES: Service
I am sure the wait staff are all very nice people, but I think they lack training of any sort. Several ordered dishes never came, our wine came out warm, plates were not cleared out promptly, and there was no attempt to explain our dishes when they were brought out. Even the wait staff appearance was slobby - the uniforms looked rumpled and unstylish. We asked to speak to the manager about our meal, and he arrived at our table looking like he just came from Gold's Gym - dude, put on a jacket, tight tees are so cheesy. The waitstaff and manager behavior are very "dude" and do not fit M.Y. China. 

MINUSES: FOOD
But the biggest problem with M.Y. China was this food... When I read the Yelp reviews I assumed the mediocre reviews were non Chinese folks who were not used to true,, authentic Chinese cuisine. I was wrong....  The poor reviews were because the food just sucks. 

MaPo Tofu - This is NOT mapo tofu, not at all spicy, but just soft tofu swimming in over corn-starched brown limp sauce. WTF.  It was a terrible, terrible joke. Grade: F

Kung Pao Chicken - WTF...  this was NOT kung pao chicken. Why were there big chunks of chicken breast blandly deep-fried and thrown with other individually fried, tasteless chilis?  A waste of ingested calories. Grade: D

Sweet-and-Sour pork - by the middle of the meal, we surrendered and started ordering American Chinese food. But unfortunately big chunks of fried pork with tasteless sweet sauce was yet another disappointment. Panda Express is better. Grade: D

Handmade green dumplings: ick. lukewarm swimming in a rather bland spicy, vinegar sauce.  Not sure what the filling was but the dumpling skin was WAAAY too thick. Grade: D

Skillet lamb: meh...  cut lamb stir-fried with green onions. I have had WAY better. Grade: C

Hand-cut noodles: weird.... slightly overcooked - just past al dente, again flavorless Grade: C

Fried Tofu appetizer - best dish of the evening. The tofu quality is great - soft and tasty...  This tofu was deep-fried and covered with a red chili powder. We ordered 2 of these as they were the only decent thing on the menu.  Though the tofu was delicious, the powder was not quite right  Grade: B

Wasabi Walnut Shrimp - the shrimp itself was plump and fresh. The mayonaise, wasabi sauce - ick. And why throw in the raw cucumbers.  Why?  Grade: C+/B-

I don't have a problem with Americanized-Chinese food - I can appreciate a P.F. Chang's, but M.Y. China was just so wrong. We had such high expectations for this restaurant - hoping it would be a higher-end Chinese restaurant experience. WRONG, the service is just not crisp, kinda "luan qi ba zao" (Chinese for lack of structure, "messy") and the food is worse than Panda Express.

The one positive of this restaurant is the ingredients. The quality of the ingredients seem very high - extremely fresh...  But it couldn't compensate for the lack of quality in the cooking and/or recipes.

One more thing... Martin, no more of the pull noodle chef dancing around the dining table with a chintzy iphone/speakers on his waist playing Gangnam Style. The dancing chef just isn't appropriate to the restaurant or Valentine's Day.
author: Madison W.

description: Love this place!  I work in the mall and I grab lunch here at least twice a week.  The shu mai, pork buns, and pot stickers, are amazing!  If you want a cheap snack their happy hour menu has great items for as low as $5!  It's also great for a meal with friends and things to share.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Overall, good food, 3.5 stars. Doesn't quite deserve 4. It's loud, and in the mall, but overall a good dining option if you're looking for decent food. Not too greasy, cooked well, they could have been more liberal with the spices though. 

- Service was great
- Ordered:
-- Mapa Tofu (delicious!)
-- House Pickled veggies (loved the papaya, never liked yams)
-- Crispy spring roll (good, but nothing special)
-- Scallion pancakes (leave it)
-- Everlasting Veggie noodle soup (bland, boring, don't do it!)
-- Pea shoots (eh)
author: Dimple B.

description: Service is Horrible. We got there at 5:30, with no reservation. Went up to the hostess, and said we said a table for two please. The place was pretty much empty, the hostess then says do you have a reservation, we say no. She looks at us, like she is going to have a heart attack, she tells us to wait. 5 minutes later, she says right this way. We sit down, and then we wait another 10 minutes, just so we can order a drink. We finally order a drink and our food. They bring us a soup, but no bowls or spoon so we can both eat, 5 minutes later we get the acknowledgement from a waiter to bring us some bowls. I am not exaggerating about the time here. We get our check after dessert, and it takes another 10 minutes for the staff to realize that we are ready to pay. We kept seeing everybody get red envelopes when they would get their bills, when we acquired about it, he said oops forgot to give you one. I am so disappointed in this restaurant staff, the food was ok. And I was super excited to try it, being that I grew up seeing Martin Yan cooking shows with my dad. But with crappy service totally not worth it. AND all this time the restaurant NEVER got full, to justify the hostess face that they were booked, and she would have to climb a mountain to sit us.
author: Sheyla A.

description: Food is always good (sodium plenty, but it is what I expect).  We have eaten here a dozen times since they opened.  My 7 year old knows the menu and enjoys many of the options.  Almost every time, the service has been poor.  Last night we arrived at 5 pm, it was not busy. We were seated immediately, 20 minutes later the server took our drink order, at which point I order 3 items.  When she brought our drinks 15 minutes later (mind you we have been sitting for 35 minutes), we ordered more food.  After ONE hour we had only received the last thing we ordered, when we asked for our food (we asked 3 different employees) we received apologies. Eventually we received all of our food.  They knocked $10 off of the bill because of the poor service.  Point being although the food is good, our family will no longer be dining here.  A total of two hours from start to finish. Ridiculous.
author: Suzi L.

description:
It was the service that cost M.Y. China a fourth star......

The cocktails were fabulous--The Monkey Prince and East Meets West reminded me of cocktails that you might have at Bourbon and Branch--especially the bourbon based Monkey Prince--I had 2 of those!
It took a while though to even get recognized or greeted at the bar by the nice barkeep.  It was definitely not intentional but he was just another example of a server who was absent in mind and spirit.  He couldn't even remember what scotch they had at their bar for the guy sitting next to me who inquired about single malts.  Not good. Not good.

We sat at the bar because we were told to wait there for our table by the pleasant but absent hostess.  She told us to wait there because we were early for our reservation but "not to worry" because she would come to the bar to get us when our table was ready.  On my way to the cool. unisex bathrooms, I counted 4 empty two-tops that we could have been seated at immediately.
We were on our second cocktail by then and I decided to recheck in with her to see if our table was ready.  When she asked me my name, I knew that she had forgotten us -and sure enough,  we were brought to one of the 4 empty two-tops.  The guy who seated us made sure to tell me that, "it wasn't intentional--they were so busy tonight.".  Guess what?  I don't care.  And, we had to settle our bar bill first--they wouldn't transfer it to our table.

Our server was so nice--she recommended that we only order a single serving of rice because of the amount of food that we had already asked for....but...guess what? --she forgot it!   Everything came out except the rice.  I had to walk over to her and ask her for the rice--she forgot to put the order in.

All of our food came out haphazardly except for the Dim Sum which came out first.
That was by far the best dish of the evening--we had the Pork & Crab Juicy Dumplings. 

We ordered two noodle dishes: Hong Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken and Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles.  Both were very good--I wished there was more of the wild boar though in that one dish.

From the wok, we ordered the Kung Pao Chicken.  It needed more flavor--the heat was nonexistent.  

We finished dinner with Sugar Egg Puffs.  They were served with chocolate and raspberry sauces in addition to vanilla flavored whipped cream.  These were a highlight of the meal.  They resembled large beignets coated in sugar that were supposed to be dipped into the sauces and cream.

Yes, I would love to go back to M. Y. China.  It's a very nice looking restaurant that needs to improve on service.
author: Thomas D.

description: Super Americanized Chinese food. I ordered dan dan noodles and it's nothing like the authentic dan dan noodles, like I have never had such a bad one. Dim Sum is ok but over priced.
author: Roddick M.

description:
I really only remember the drinks because that was what I did after sitting at the bar. There was eating too but that part is a bit fuzzy. 

They have a bunch of special cocktails, including ones crafted with sake, soju, or Chinese baijiu. However, the bartender needs to learn to understand Erguotou when I say it. If I just order "baijiu" (literally white liquor) as they understood it, it would be like me ordering just "whiskey". Which whiskey? Exactly. Which baijiu? Erguotou isn't even a brand; it's to baijiu like rye is to whiskey. 

Now that that is out of the way, I must commend them on including the famed Chinese liquor. I recommend trying a shot of it on its own - sip it and taste it. Most people dislike sipping it but then it can be said for some whiskeys.

The food was pretty good, as I remembered it. They were in nice presentations (for example, the individual spoons the XLB was served in), and I think it will please most people, while not being too pricey considering the atmosphere and the classiness of the restaurant.

If you're here without a reservation, do consider sitting at the bar. Oh, and we were told there would be a line when Martin Yan is in, so unless you're there to see him, don't bother when you see the line.
author: Alice C.
