description: the food was very yummy... The hot and sour soup, chairmans chicken, and various dim sum were excellant. service was impeccable.. the pricing was slightly on the higher side. My husband tried the Buddha beer which was good.. will go again
author: Das M.

description: Could not wait to come back here since my last visit when they just opened the food is exceptional! I most favorite dish is the shrimp fried rice which is uniquely prepared. Each dish has a special flare all its own. I suggest this pork dumplings, sound that chicken dish with sweet-and-sour.
author: Linda S.

description: Just updating my review for happy hour previously. Management was very responsive and able to address my concerns. I'm glad the restaurant takes customer feedback seriously. I have also had previous positive dining experiences here so I'm upping the stars by one. I think overall, my guidance would be to avoid the happy hour if you have more than two people. Better for lunch or dinner though.
author: Clinton L.

description: Been here three times at the bar and most recently for a dinner reservation to celebrate my wedding anniversary.  All four occasions exceeded expectations for one reason or another-for example, the bartender being super accepting of an obviously gay couple, or the staff being super amiable or the waiter being super attentive-and let's not forget that the cocktails have enough alcohol in them so that you feel it after the first one and the food is delicious.  Highly recommend this place!  Enjoy!
author: Ronald C.

description:
Under the dome of doom! Very noisy, not very spacious. We had reservation for 4 @ 11:30 am 7.19.15, we arrived at 11:00 am got seated right away and then the journey began. We ordered off the menu many popular dishes and dim sum and the food seem to have a lot of additional water in it, possibly from the steam pots, it made the dim sum wet and soggy to try and pick it up with chopsticks was a challenge. Using a fork was even more challenging because the won ton skins were falling apart all over your plate, you needed a bowl to catch the soggy skin falling everywhere but your plate, very amusing. Never-the-less $250.00 later we all wished we would have went to Scomas and enjoyed our lunch.  
V
Chuck this down as an experience and advise you YELPER's out their - Go to China Town and eat at the market place/court or the House of Dim Sum, you will get what you paid for and loving it!
author: Diana R.

description: Hands down favorite for Chinese food in SF -- It's weird to walk into a mall for a great meal, but this place delivers -- M.Y. is for "Martin Yan" and the food is excellent
author: Darryl N.

description:
Having passed by Martin Yan's restaurant several times on my way to the movie theater in Westfield Mall, I was always curious about this place. For Chinese New Year my family and I wanted to celebrate at R&G lounge, but unfortunately it was completely booked up the whole night. So we settled on with MY China instead. We made reservations online using OpenTable, and surprisingly it was completely open ended.

Arriving at the restaurant 15 minutes early, we were in for a different surprise. The restaurant was packed and there was no available seating inside the restaurant. We asked about our reservation for 7:15. The hostess asked us to please wait a moment. From my quick understanding it seems they were inundated with last minute guests and did not bother to reserve seating for the guests who made reservations. An automatic star downgrade in my book. The hostess made us wait for another 15 minutes. We asked again about our table, and she said oh what is your name? SMH, we've been standing here for 15 minutes and we just talked to you. They in between seated a table of 8 people who had no reservations. They offered to put us at a table out of the way and on the outside, after we complained lightly about getting the 5 minute wait end around.

With that out of the way, the service was a lot better. Our waitor Bolo, did a great job discussing the menu with us and treated us with great care. The food was all delivered to our table very quickly. Can't fault that table service.

The food itself was reasonable, but not spectacular or of great value. We had the following dishes:

+ Steamed Seasonal Fish - ***/5 - The portion was a bit too small. We wanted a whole fish with the head and tail in tact specifically for Chinese New Year, but they could not accommodate this because we were not a table of 6.
+ Wok Seared Beef - ***/5 - Pretty standard wasn't absolutely wowing me.
+ Whole Crispy Roast Chicken - ****/5 - pretty decently cooked, very moist cuts and everything tasted great, they even provided 5 spice dipping powder on the side.
+ Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles - **/5 - not a fan of this dish, not enough chunks of the boar meat, and the noodles were a bit odd in texture.
+ Garlic Pea Shoots (Dau Miu) - ****/5 - pretty simple, nicely done, and at standard.

On the outside, the restaurant looks very extravagant, modern and upscale. It just did not live up to the expectation that I had in terms of quality for the value. I understand that the place they are in is high rent for the sq/space. But I'm not sure I would come here again, if there were other dinner options for Chinese fare, but this was Chinese New Year. Happy Year of the Ram!
author: Michael C.

description:
We were people-watching and window shopping at the Westfield Mall when we happened upon M.Y. China. We just finished a modest lunch at Super Duper Burgers a little over an hour ago so we certainly weren't hungry. However, we decided to go in just for a quick bite of dessert. We ended staying 3 hours. Our only excuse is we had just seen the 3rd Hobbit movie at the Metreon. In the spirit of Bilbo and hobbits everywhere, we ended up having a second lunch. 

We ordered juicy dumplings and half a Peking roast duck. The dumplings were certainly juicy. The skins were very thin and delicate. We enjoyed the all pork filling more than the pork and crab roe combination but both kinds were delicious.

The duck served was just the breast meat. The fat was properly rendered leaving the meat moist without being greasy. The crackling skin was crispy and a delight to consume. At $20 we first thought it was expensive for just half a duck but because the duck was boneless and very meaty, we were able to consume the whole thing without any waste. It was a very good deal.

For libations, we ordered a mai tai and a Stella Artois cider. The mai tai was yummy and very well made. The cider was smooth and complemented the duck beautifully.

For dessert we ordered the sugar puffs or Chinese donuts and the black sesame ice cream. The donuts were warm and came with chocolate sauce, raspberry coulis and sweetened whipped cream. The ice cream was delicious and the flavor was a nice change from the ubiquitous green tea. Both desserts were yummy. We loved the thick, rich chocolate sauce but the best thing was when we stuffed the donut with the ice cream.  

The food was very good, not transcendent, but very good. What put M.Y. China over the top was the kitchen staff. We were seated at the chef's table. It is a counter facing the wok station of the open kitchen. Now I don't like sitting with my back to a room. I don't know, maybe I was a gangster or gunslinger in another life. My initial wariness quickly gave way to delight as we watched the busy cooks chop, fry and assemble food for the restaurant. 

Watching the food being prepared was actually what persuaded us to order more than dessert. We saw a fresh duck being pulled from the fryer. The golden, glistening skin just seduced us. The cook was also good at theater. We really couldn't carry on a conversation because the place is really noisy, but he really made a production of cutting and plating up that duck when he saw us watching him. Well after that private cooking demo, we just had to order that canard.

That same station prepped our dessert. By this time, we had been there for so long that a second cook had taken over the spot. We established a rapport and jokingly told him that while the donuts were delicious, serving 5 pieces really wasn't any good because it left an odd donut out. How would we divide this dessert fairly? The next thing we know, we were served a single donut stuffed with strawberry ice cream. 

Good companionship, great conversation, delicious food and engaging kitchen staff made this an awesome dining experience. The $$$$ bill didn't even phase us. (Well it did, we only realized afterwards that we could have save some bills by ordering from the happy hour menu.) The price will prevent this place from being a regular dining spot. We will be back, though I know it may be difficult, if not impossible to recreate the same conditions for another perfect meal.
author: Cece E.

description:
Food is on par, service way below.  

Food:
Get the HK style noodles and the Chairman Mao Chicken.

Service:
Well, bring patience.  The drinks will take forever to arrive, based on our experience, as well as the experience of the couple sitting at the next table, a mere 6 inches from us.  They'll also mix up orders, so prepare to be surprised.  The saving grace is that, at least everyone seems to be *trying* to do it right.  

Ambience:
Big fancy cafeteria.  Why do they pack people like sardines?  The tables are way too close to each other...reminds me of flying coach.
author: Kristen S.

description: Cancel my trip to China....I have found my spot for quality Chinese food! I'll be back...especially during their weekday happy hour!!
author: Hans-Peter G.

description:
I can't believe how tasty the food was. The juicy pork dumplings were perfect, and they gave us the Bang Bang chicken with no bones for our kids! I was reluctant to order the Roasted Chicken (seemed too boring) but it turns out that it was great too. The crisp of the skin and the extra seasoning on the side was remarkable. 

I have a new favorite Chinese restaurant.
author: Kaanon M.

description:
3.5 STARS

As a young girl, watching "Yan Can Cook" was the highlight of my Saturday mornings along with watching WWF's Hulk Hogan and The Bushwhackers.

What can I say, I was an odd one.

Fast forward, two millenniums later, Martin Yan is standing right in front of me at M.Y. China. He smiles at me and I clamp up.

Me: *Cheezing*
MY.: "You guys have the best seat in the house. Enjoy dinner!"
Me: *Still Cheezing*
MY: *Confuzzled*

Hmm, perhaps I should have said something to him huh? *Sigh*

Despite all the negative reviews, I had my heart set on trying M.Y. China because after all, I grew up watching MY. 

Expecting the worse, I was pleasantly surprised at how much they have improved since their earlier negative reviews. It was a packed house on Christmas Eve but service wasn't compromised. Unlike Hakkasan which opened on the same day (my review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/hakkasan-san-francisco#hrid:_fFgMsiWO9taQD3lLV-Z6w ), M.Y. China is for the American palate even though they're part of Koi Palace and their chefs are Chinese. But with no MSG after effects (thanks to old age, I've become highly allergic and they use none), I was able to enjoy Chinese food without getting MSG induced heart palpitations.

F O O D
Snapshot of all our dishes: http://bit.ly/UvOhI3

*Pork & Black Truffle Juicy Dumplings ($18) - 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/TDcQ7d
Sadly, the thin skin stuck to the spoon so the dumpling tore apart upon eating and all the broth leaked onto the spoon. *Sad pouty face* It was one juicy dumpling though but the truffle essence was very faint; almost undetectable.

*Shu Mai ($6) - 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/V7bNZa
Plump and tender, the shu mai tasted just like any I can get on Clement street or in Chinatown for a fraction of the cost. The same problem arose as the dumplings, the skin got stuck on the serving spoon.

*Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles ($14) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/UbcCz9
The best dish of the night, this dish was reminiscent to chow fun but with a freshly made gemelli-like noodle used. The noodle was al-dente with a toothsome chew and the tender wild boar was like a rich and porky with a slight gamey undertone.

*Honey Glazed Shrimp ($22) - 2.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/V7bX2K
My least favorite dish of the night, excess wet batter needed to be shaken off because the fried shrimp had a very uneven fried batter throughout. I wasn't fond of the pungent Chinese mustard in the mayo as it overpowered the delicate sweetness of the shrimp.

*Braised Short Ribs in Clay Pot ($25) - 2.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/YQGvLA
I love rustic Chinese clay pot short ribs but this was disappointing.  The ribs weren't in chunks but rather sliced like thin cuts of steak and needed to be cooked down more as there wasn't a melt-in-your-mouth tenderness. It was also very bland.

*Forbidden Rice ($8) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/V7QdDE
Loved this dish. The combo of brown rice, wild rice, corn and goji berries made it a savory and slightly sweet sensation.

*Purple Yam Croquettes w/ Almond Ice Cream ($8) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/10o33nr
Sweet purple potato with a sweet condensed milk center rolled in crunchy slices of almonds served with a nutty, creamy sweet ice cream? Can't get any better than that.

Skip the wine. Pours were stingy and my glass was less than 1/3 filled.

S E R V I C E
Our waiter was friendly and attentive and our food was coursed out. Food service was timely though not lighting speed as you would expect at a typical Chinese restaurant because everything is made to order and from scratch.

I loved that MY was overseeing the chefs in the kitchen and noting what needed to be improved in Cantonese (yeah, I was eavesdropping). He also was making rounds in the dining room talking to his patrons; what all celebrity chefs should do in my opinion.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Vegas meets the Bay, M.Y. China reminds of the restaurants you would find at the Wynn, Encore, Palazzo and Caesar's Palace with an enclosed "outdoor" dining for people watching, a beautiful dining room with a wall lined with gold Buddhas flown in from China and a massive open kitchen.

Make sure to sit at the "Chef's Counter" for a front row show of the noodle pulling action aka the "best" seats in the house (http://bit.ly/Vkgxx6).

P A R K I N G
Yerba Buena garage across the street on Mission/5th.

I will be forever grateful for MY...

Thanks to him, I know HOW to chop with two cleavers. 

Mr. NSS should be very afraid. *Evil laugh*
author: Cherylynn N.

description: They finally fixed their health score so I'm updating my review. Was very disappointed when that happened but we are trying to move past that and enjoy this spot again. Good food.
author: Jesus H.

description: This is one of my fav Chinese restaurants in the city. Sometimes a bit of a wait, so go early or late. I recommend the Hot & Sour soup, chairman mao' chicken, any of the wok noodles, and lobster dishes.
author: Philip T.

description: This place is always busy. Love the interior. Open kitchen. I recommend making a reservation. We had a little bit of wait even with a reservation for 7. We were seated at a large table in the middle of the restaurant. Plenty of room for more people. The waitress was very attentive and fast. We ordered bang bang chicken wings, calamari, pork belly bun sliders, wild boar scissor cut noodles, mushu pork, fried rice, lamb dish, Peking duck and chili lobster. Most items were small portions. I didn't really care for the wild boar scissor cut noodles. It was sort of bland. Everything else were tasty & delicious. We told the waitress we're here for a birthday occasion and pointed to the birthday man in the group. At the end of the meal, they cleared out our table and brought some egg puffs with a birthday candle. That was courtesy. For the expensive items ordered and price paid, I'm glad they gave us free egg puffs. This place is expensive. Overall, food & service were great. I would definitely come back again.
author: Amy H.

description:
Date & Time:  Tuesday December 11, 2012 @ 1:30pm
Dining Companions:  Mommy & Husband
Scene:  Small Groups of Ladies Who Lunch in Burberry Coats w/ Daughters in 3.1 Philip Lim Sweaters, Minis + Ugg Bailey Button Boots 
Music:  Cool Beats
Decor:  Luxe w/ Asian Influences.  Deep, Rich Hues, Ornate Columns, Open Kitchen w/ Marble Counter & Leather Banquettes
Service:  Polished & Professional
Imbibe: Oolong Milk Tea
Devour:  M.Y. Dim Sum Platter, Pork Belly Steamed Bun Sliders, Pan Fried Pork Buns, Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, Fried Chicken, Egg Custard, Sugar Egg Puffs
Total:  $82.72
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Great find in a mall. I the menu it says the owner is a James Beard Award winner. The flavorful food suggests that's true. Try the spicy seafood dumplings!
author: Nancy K.

description:
Wow....this is pretty authentic and quality Chinese food IN A MALL. It's a good break from Ctown when you just want to sit down after shopping and want Chinese food in a slightly upper scale place that's clean and have good and super attentive service. 

What we had: 
*Honey walnut wasabi prawn: excellent, perfectly made. Love that mild wasabi kick to it. 
*Wild Boar Noodles: good. Noodles are fresh handpulled and sauce was tasty but i prefer it to be dryer. The noodles could be a little more "bouncy".
*Spicy seafood dumplings: good. 
*Grandma's gai lan: good- extra plus that it has Chinese sausage in it. =D
*Sugar Egg puffs: needs work. If you've had good ones from dim sum, you'll know that the filling needs to have a light fluffy eggy dough in it - MY China's version lacks that. Their's have only the crust which makes it a bit dry and boring. 

It's a bit pricier than the typical Chinese restaurant, but not much more. I'd totally go again.
author: Huong V.

description: But Chinese food I have ever tasted in an upscale clean chic setting.  I loved it.
author: Rene V.

description: This place is amazing! We love eating here and our service has been great. The mu shu pork tacos are the best!
author: Eric F.

description:
Husband and I used to love this place.  Like, loved it so much we took our out-of-town relatives (my very Chinese cousins who prefer to eat Chinese food whenever they can) here for dinner, and they loved it too.  Sure, some of the items (and prices) are clearly catered towards the more westernized taste, but the wild boar scissor-cut noodles won everyone over, along with their juicy dumplings (xiao long bao).  We even had the pleasure of meeting Martin Yan on one visit and were thoroughly thrilled.

Fast forward two years, and we decided to come back here one night after my volunteering shift in Union Square ended.  We ordered the Juicy Dumplings (6 for $16), which yes, is expensive, but whatever, we expected that, the organic crispy tofu, wild boar scissor-cut noodles, and the wild boar rice cakes.  Slightly disappointed that they changed their menu and had gotten rid of some of our favorites, including this appetizer sampler, but we mostly came for the scissor-cut noodles.

Our waiter asked if we wanted the pork dumplings, and we said yes.  He took the rest of our order, and then the tofu came up first.  It wasn't that crispy; in fact, it was bordering on gummy.  Pro tip: don't lick your lips after you eat this, because your lips will be on fire, even though the tofu itself isn't that spicy.

We then received the noodles (still delicious), and when our dumplings came out, there were only 5.  I flagged down a waiter, who said that they had actually changed their menu and now it was 5 dumplings for $8.  So.. they changed it but didn't update their menu.. ok cool..  He said that our waiter was supposed to explain that to us, but obviously that never happened.

Pork juicy dumplings were too sweet, and they put it on a spoon, which the skin stuck to and broke.  At least the broth was contained in the spoon, but still, disappointing.  The rice cakes were also incredibly disappointing - overly sweet.  I took one bite and pushed the plate away.

Probably won't be visiting MY China again.  Sorry not sorry.
author: Tori S.

description: Good food --  but terrible service by our waiter.  Didn't get to us until 15 mins after we say down.   He wasn't very friendly.   Looks like he was overwhelmed with 5 tables.   One of our dishes came towards the end of our meal; we had to send it back.   We ordered 3 separate dishes and each came separate times.   Very odd services.
author: Vic G.

description: Everytime I return it's better and better. There were 12 cooks on duty ona recent Friday night. 7 pm res honored with a smile. Great service, amazing flavors across all 3 dishes. Can't wait to go back. Did I mention craft cocktail program will match pretty much anybody in town?
author: Mark P.

description:
Presentation here is quite nice but execution was not up to par. We tried the XLBs and I was extremely disappointed that the dumplings stuck to the spoon. As a result, the soupy goodness spilled out all over. What a shame! The spoons also seemed a bit large for the dumplings and were unwieldy for the diner to easy slide the dumpling in their mouth. But if the dumpling is stuck to the spoon....I suppose it does not matter.

The Beijing knife cut noodles were good though! They had great texture and were nicely coated in the spicy bean sauce. Come for the noodles but avoid the XLBs.
author: Schelly Y.

description:
While it is quite rare that I suggest going to a Mall during the Holidays, especially on a Saturday and for Lunch, I found myself doing just that recently.  Having had M.Y. China a few times on a weekday occasion and not been disappointed in the food, I suggested we go there because the Dome is cool and She always wants Chinese.

We walked right in and were seated right next a few other couples that were obviously recently seated as well, though I recall seeing other tables available.  So the inevitable happened; we were flagging down a very flustered waiter who was paying attention to the 2 large parties but we were flagging down Bussers just to get some water 10 minutes in.  Waiter was slammed (bad Host skills) but he wasn't doing a good job.

I ordered a Nixon's Visit and she had a Perseco and we would split a pot of tea with our meal.  The Tea came out first, then her Perseco immediately thereafter, whereas I had to wait for my cocktail until 5 minutes after our food arrived and She flagged down the Manager.

The food is good at M.Y. China for the most part in terms of the menu offerings but the execution was off today.  Boar Lettuce cups were way overdone compared to how they've come out in my previous visits. The Gai Lan (Chinese Broccoli) was really undercooked as was the Chinese Sausage that comes with it.

A different kind of problem we had with the meal was  that the "Crispy Organic Tofu" and the "Salt and Pepper Chicken wings" are heavily doused with the same exact seasoning, and with no indication from the menu or our waiter. On the Tofu we found it too spicy for the subtle protein (though we like really hot food), and it didn't add anything to the Wings, which were unlike any we have had before with the same title.  And we always get "The Wings" when we go out!

The Fried Rice is good though and was the saving grace of the meal but that's not really a compliment.  The Wok Seared Beef was also good and I liked the Arugula as an addition to the dish.

For $90 I felt like I'd been played like a Shmuck. I'd come back here in a pinch ( if it was not crowded! ) but it was not the stellar meal spot to kick off an epic day of shopping with the Ms. SO.  #NotMYChina
author: Lee S.

description: had lunch here on sunday just because even though its crab season, i wanted lobster instead(i love it here). its steamed perfectly and so sweet, yet garlicky & succulent. its piled on top of vermicelli noodles  to soak up all the tasty goodness. we also had roasted chicken, boar noodles, dim sum, pot sticker and ended  our meal ALWAYS with the cream puffs. once again Yan was our server, she's SO sweet! She remembered  us from our last visit and again she really took care of us! Ask for Yans table, she'll take care of you.
author: EmmettsGuRL C.

description:
Even though the gluten-free selections were few, they were excellent. 
It's a bit pricey, but I don't mind when I'm paying for such excellent, tasty, fresh food. Plus I had enough to take home for a second meal.
I had the Venison Chow Fun and the Szechuan green beans. They were both amazing.
author: Emily B.

description:
Wanted to try M.Y. China for a while & figured Sat 12/15/12 was a good enough time.  I went after 1pm & thought the wait wouldn't be so bad for one.  It was a horribly long wait!  I think over 1-hr!  Lots of empty tables maybe for people that had reservations, but I think they either should open up the tables with No reservations or seat people that can eat fast & not have to wait 1-hr!

Studied the menu before getting a seat at the counter where they are using the woks so I had some entertainment.  It does get warm there, so not the best spot to sit.

I got Veggie noodle soup $12 - it comes with green spinach noodle, I don't know if they make those there because I saw the guy making white hand-pulled noodles!  I should have gotten the beef noodle soup $14 instead.  Comes with a bunch of mushrooms, maybe 2 small tofu squares, & the green spinach noodles.  It was chewy & tasted ok.

Macau egg tarts 3 tiny ones for $6.  That's very expensive for egg tarts.  At Golden Gate Bakery larger, hot, egg tarts are $1.35 ea!  Huge markup here & they were nothing special.  Skip them.

Charge it.  Three separate unisex bathrooms in the back, trough sinks.

I might come back to try other things, but I'm going to Make Reservations & after the Holidays.
author: Ann L.

description:
01.19.13 | bookmarked 12.12.12

It's a fancy Chinese restaurant. In a mall. I know rent is high, but it was difficult for me to justify the prices.

We had the steamed bbq pork bao, the M.Y. dim sum collection, beef hand pulled noodle soup, and ended with the Chinese donuts. I appreciated the careful presentation of the dishes. It was also neat to see hand pulled noodles at the open kitchen.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2?select=Wot7kGiumSapEjRkNny9hg#Wot7kGiumSapEjRkNny9hg

It's not a place that I'd make a special trip for, but if I'm at the mall and hankering for noodle soup, I'm so there.

Total damage for two: $60
author: Jenny L.

description:
Before Food Network and all the celebrity chefs existed, there was Martin Yan.  He had his own cooking show on PBS during the weekend's called 'Yan can Cook" and his motto was "If Yan can cook, so can you!"  He was one of the original celebrity chefs back in the days... we just didn't label them with such a status back then...  And though I am Chinese and eat Chinese food and am Chinese 2nd gen, I always thought Martin Yan was cheesy.  But as cheesy as I think he is, I still wanted to eat his food.  With the opening of his restaurant, this was my chance to finally eat what he cooked up on PBS.

I talked my co-worker into going with me to eating dumplings here.  I felt some hestiation from her part but was glad she gave in.  Upon entering the beautiful mahogany modern and chic decor, we instantly noticed that real live Chinese people were staffed in the open kitchen! Yes, that was surprising to us and it gave hope that Martin's restaurant would taste authentic.

Here's what we ordered...

IMPRESSIVE:
Wild boar juicy dumplings (aka.  Xiao long bao) - it was hot, full of good flavor soup inside, good ginger vinegar dressing, great presentation.  But I'm not sure if wild boar tastes better than pigs ?!?  It's probably a marketing thing to name the dish after a boar instead of calling it pork.

OKAY:
Pork belly sliders - the pork melts in your mouth but I wish there was a side dish of hoisin sauce.

NOT IMPRESSED AND TOOOO SPICY:
Bang bang chicken wing - too tangy, too spicy, and definitely not my tastebuds style
Dan Dan noodles - served cold and I think it was missing salt because it just tasted like bitter vinegar.  And it was way too spicy!!  

DISSATISFIED:
Macau Egg Tarts - it was not hot enough, not sweet and creamy enough, and the crust was kinda soggy.  Macau egg tarts should taste similar to crembrulee in a buttery flakey crust and more importantly, served HOT. This was more like a regular day old Dan tat with an unsuccessful attempt to heat up in a toaster oven.

The waiter never came back to check on us. If she did, I think I would had sent the Dan Dan noodles back. And though I knew the prices are high and I knew I had to pay these high prices, I was still unprepared for the final bill... for the most part, we paid to sit around beautiful decor only.  Just like the Martin's television show, the food looks good and maybe that's where I should had left it... in TV.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Because Martin Yang's last restaurant chains were disappointing, therefore I didn't have high expectations when I heard of this new restaurant under the dome of Bloomingdale's in Westfield San Francisco Center.
I had the opportunity to give this place a try on a lunch gathering with my friend.  It turned out surprisingly impressive!  Nice ambient with vibrant bar scene.  I like the wide counter with an action hand pull noodles station behind it with the chef in demonstration.
I even did not expect to see Chef Martin Yang but he was there right when I walked by the counter when he was explaining to the guests by the hand pull noodles maker.  He encouraged everyone to touch the freshly made noodles to feel the fine texture, and he brought out the noodles on a wood stick to give everyone a closer look and photos opportunity.  It was a very nice treat.
We ordered the "Dim Sum" sampler consisted of varieties of steamed goodies:  4 kinds of dumplings, BBQ pork bun and sticky rice.  Braised beef with hand pulled noodles soup.  The "Dim Sum" items were good, the beef noodles soup was delicious, the beef was tender.  
While we were eating, Chef Martin Yang came to meet and greet a few tables by the mall.  We were very delighted to be able to chat with him and snap more photos with him.   When my griend mentioned anput the Dim Sum at Yeung Shing,  another upscale Chinese restaurant in downtown San Francisco, Chef Yang told us this restaurant attracts more Chinese customers than the other one for his menu has more authentic cuisines from different continents in China.  He explained to the table next to us about the beef noodles soup, not only the noodles were hand pulled, also it took 6 hours to slow cook the beef and the broth, that's why it tasts so good and the beef with such melt-in-the-mouth tenderness.  
When we asked him what was his recommendation  of a specialty om the menu, he suggested us to tey the crab meat with pork juicy steamed dumplings (shiao-lone-bao), of course we followed his advice to order one.  They were very delicious and I like each of the dumpling placed in a soup spoon because there was broth inside each dumpling and sure not to waste it.
Oh, you got to have one of the Oolong tea because it was a special blend that has a milky flavor but there was absolutely no milk in it.
Overall it was a very pleasant dining experience and of course the bonus was to meet Martin Yang. So even the food ws pricy, but it was not that bad considered in the high price location.  I would like to visit again to tey other items on the menu.
author: Patricia W.

description:
The dumplings: tso good.
I left wonton more dim sum.
Long noodles, long life.
author: Nish N.

description:
Holy cow on a flaming unicycle, all I have to say is mu shu pork tacos. Get in my mouth. Juicy, super flavorful, great textures, not ridiculous amounts of food, and a great price point. Where have you been all my life.

Oh, I lie. I also have to mention the wok-seared seafood that I got last time I was here. So delicious and fresh-tasting.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Generally enjoy dining here before a film. 

Need to remind myself not to order the sea bass and tofu with honey glaze. It's too gelatinous for my taste.
author: Karen R.

description:
There were no surprises for me at M.Y. China. 
I did my Yelp research beforehand so I knew that:

a)  they are located in a mall and

b)  it's a Martin Yan restaurant and 

c) the quality of the food was going to far exceed typical mall fare.

No reservation needed, just strolled in and got seated right away.
Not great ambiance or decor, at least not evident in the section we sat in.  

All the food on our table was delicious--except the potstickers.  Big letdown for me, especially given the fact that so many reviewers recommended these.  I spent 15 years living in Japan and as most of you probably know, they have their share of potstickers.  In fact, in Japan you can find restaurants that specialize in potstickers and that's all they serve. So I know potstickers. At M.Y. China, each potsticker comes in it's own oversized soup spoon - you know the white, plastic ones you use to eat your hot and sour soup.  First problem, they potstickers are dried and stuck to the bottom of the spoon.  So when you go to eat it, it rips.  Can you you say "epic failure"?  Then, problem number two is the filling.  It's this over-processed mush of a mixture.  The texture was so off-putting, I could only take one bite.  It had the texture of the meat balls that you find in pho - hard and rubbery AND GROSS. :)  Maybe I got a bad order?  I'll give them the benefit of the doubt since all the other food on our table was fantastic.  

CALAMARI (5/5)  LOVED their version.  Lots of tentacles.  Batter was perfect.  Could eat 6 baskets of these.

STEAMED LOBSTER W/FRIED GARLIC (5/5)  Maybe the most delicious lobster dish I've ever had.  That is HUGE for me to declare since I'm an Italian from Boston, born into a lobster-loving family and have been eating lobster my whole life.  If you are a lobster lover--try this dish.  I will return to this restaurant for this dish alone.

SHRIMP AND PAPAYA SALAD (5/5) My wife's order and she loved it. I took a bite and I liked it a lot.

POTSTICKERS (1/5) Sad, sad details above.  :)

We asked for hot sauce and they brought out a wonderful chili oil.  So good, that I wish I had the mind to ask if they sell it.  I bet they do.  

M.Y. China met our expectations and I don't think this place is over-hyped.  I've read a few Yelp reviews that go on and on about how it's not authentic Chinese food.  Here's what I think. If it's delicious, who cares about authenticity.  My wife is from India and we love authentic Indian food, but we love the Japanese version of curry rice.  It's completely inauthentic but it's delicious in its own right!  If all food had to be authentic, think of how many tasty, fusion-inspired dishes would be lost!  Instead of thinking of a food as "inauthentic", how about taking a chill pill and thinking of the dish as a different version.  

People who can't think out of the box are some of the most annoying people I know.

That officially ends my rant about Yelpers who cry foul over inauthentic food. :)

Completely and whole-heartedly recommend M.Y. China.  Would like to go there right now in fact!
author: Darien R.

description:
Coming from Toronto I have a high standard for Chinese food. This restaurant is decent but not outstanding. It is not something I would go out of my way to come back to. But decent enough that I wouldn't mind coming again if convenient. 

The har gao (shrimp dumplings) were decent, stuffed with a lot of shrimp, but a slightly thick skin. It was a little bland though, but do note that I did not use any of the sauce that came along side it. 

Green beans were ok, fresh and crisp. Well cooked. 

The deep fried tofu was pretty good! A little spicy but quite delicious! I recommend this. 

There was also a deep fried shrimp in a mayo wasabi sauce? That was decent too. Shrimps were well cooked, tender, springy and juicy with a crisp deep fried crust. 

Service is top notch and the decor and space is interesting and comfortable. You don't feel rushed here.
author: Derwei C.

description: Many vegetarian options- we especially enjoyed the crispy (spicy) tofu, spicy green beans, and the forbidden rice. My relatives enjoyed the chairman mao chicken. The Dan Dan noodles and Kung pao chicken weren't that special, but overall we enjoyed the meal. The portions were generous compared to a couple of other chinese restaurants we visited earlier in the week. Service was efficient!
author: S G.

description: The place's atmosphere and service was great. But I think the food is too hyped up and overpriced. Had their crispy roasted chicken and it was too salty. So salty, I left half of the plate at the restaurant and didn't even bother taking it home, despite the high price of it. Friend had their beef noodles and that was salty as well. Overall, I didn't find this place to be special other than being in an upscale mall and having a nice interior for a restaurant.
author: Cici C.

description: Always consistently great.   Food and service are awesome....attentive staff, great flavors and presentation.
author: Sean H.

description: This place isn't your run-of-the-mill Chinese restaurant where you can get a full meal for less than $10. This is a fancy restaurants in the middle of downtown San Francisco, so the menu prices will reflect that. It's such a fun and beautiful place. There are fancy cocktails, elegantly served dim sum and noodle dishes... even their restrooms are gorgeous. To top it off, I even met and got my picture taken with Martin Yan one of the times I was there!
author: Pebbles E.

description: Good Chinese option in Westfield/Union Square area. Even though we ordered only 2 dishes, I can see that the food here seems more refined than most Chinese restaurants I've tried in the Bay Area.
author: Lan-Anh N.

description: The location is ideal and easily accessible. The establishment has a stellar appearance, located Under the Dome on the 4th floor of the Westfield shopping plaza. You can be seated inside or outside. The service is top notch. You are made to feel welcome and that puts you in the mood for the food. The menu has so many delectable choices, you may have a difficult time deciding. I settled on the American Kobe Beef in a black sauce, my partner went for the Calamari. Both dishes were seasoned and cooked to perfection and I do mean perfection. Along with the side dishes i.e. rice and dumplings it was a pure delight. And the waiter had the ideal timing.Strongly recommend M.Y. China!
author: Jimmy L.

description: As a Chinese born girl, I love this place better than any other Chinese food restaurant in city... After dropping in during happy hour, we also had company lunch there! Very impressive dishes! A lot of wok food has been adopted to American flavor, but still tasty! I love their rice cake a lot. Although it is not the real shangahinese version, rice cake has flavor in it!!! Dim sum are still good and nice! This place will become my happy hour place!
author: Nina H.

description:
Summary: Too expensive for this level of service and quality of food.

Expensive tea steeped in nasty unfiltered water = bad tea

Excellent: pan fried pork bun: I would consider popping in for this as a snack.

Mediocre: knife cut noodle: Good ingredients put together poorly. Very dull and disappointing.

Service: absent and poor, bordering on terrible
author: Peter K.

description: Wow this place was very good. We went for a friends birthday. Large group and the staff handled it very well. Coursed out the whole meal and we ordered a lot! Very aware of allergy and keeping that food away. Great price, good food
author: Tedd R.

description:
Skeptical about quality of food from a place called MY CHINA in a Westfield mall, I was pleasantly surprised by both the taste and service of this restaurant! Came in on a busy Wednesday night during holiday season, called at 5pm for a same day reservation at 7pm and was able to get a table  even though open table says nothing was available. The restaurant was packed by 7pm. 

We ordered the green beans, the sea bass, and the duck. It was more than enough for two. The sea bass was amazing. Perfectly seasoned with the right amount of grease and tenderness. The duck was good, but subpar compared to authentic Beijing Ducks. The green beans were delicious. I recommend it as a green dish to be paired with anything.  The drinks were also reasonably priced - which is great for a light palate. 

Dessert time came and the Lychee Pana cotta was the winner of the night! It was sweet but refreshing - totally different than a typical dessert that'd knock you over to food coma zone. 

I was also impressed by MY CHINA's service. The manager took a dish back because it didn't have the plating as shown on previous yelp pics. 

I will definitely recommend this place to friends who want tasty Asian food in Union Square!
author: Vickie T.

description:
Came in on a weekday night for dinner and we stop by the bar while waiting for a table to open up for our party. Derrick the bartender was very attentive and nice! He welcomed our party and asked what he  can start us with.. Some guys ordered few drinks on menu but I didn't feel like ordering any and asked if he can make me something fruity which did and wow! It was one of the best cocktail I ever drank and I'll definitely come back to drink it again! He was very professional and friendly.

We got seated shortly after and I personally ordered: beef hand pull noodle soup which was very yummy! Definitely recommend that! My party was very satisfied and will definitely come back if we are shopping in downtown :)
author: Precious K.

description: I have only been here once, and I have to say, there is no excuse for bad Chinese food in San Francisco. I ordered the spicy hand cut pork noodles with wood ear mushrooms, and the dish was virtually inedible. The noodles were gloopy and egregiously over cooked, the sauce was thick and sweet, void of any spiciness and there were absolutely no wood ear mushrooms in the dish. I would not recommend this place for this particular dish. Now, on the other hand, my server was extremely helpful and attentive, and over all the service was very good. But honestly, this dish fell flat.
author: jamie h.

description: Traveling for business and read about this place prior to my arrival.  Sat at the bar and was quickly greeted.  Had the Hong Kong cripy noodles with Chicken XO.  My first time having this dish and it was quite good.  After seeing them, I also tried the pork filled dumplings and they were excellent.  I would come back just for those bites of wonder!!  It is located in the Westfield Mall but doesn't have the mall food court type of feel.
author: Owen B.

description: M.Y. China made it up to us and comped our new meal to get us to come back. It was fantastic and will be back again. The food was amazing!
author: Zac B.

description: Were looking for a nice Chinese restaurant during our trip to Union Square and must say that I am glad we came here. For a newcomer who uses google map to walk around, the place can be tricky to locate. It is in Westfield mall - at the top floor. We ordered peking duck and fish noodle and we really loved the food.
author: rakesh k.

description:
While this place may be pricey and some of the portions can be smaller than your standard Chinese food places, I think the quality of food you are getting speaks for itself. Not to mention that you are also paying for ambiance and location. I should also mention that I am an SF local who grew up both in the sunset district and richmond district and have eaten my fair share of authentic Chinese and asian cuisine so I am judging the place, not based solely on the price but rather how authentic the flavors and styles are. 

I have been here a total of 4 times, twice with my hubby, once with a friend and once by myself. I enjoy sitting where you can watch the chefs cooking the food. I should mention that I am familar with Chef Martin Yan, as I did grow up watching his cooking chows on tv and he was probably one of the first celebirty chefs on tv. I have yet to meet him myself but that of course would only be an extra special treat! ;)

So here are my personal recommendations:

*Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles 野豬刀剪面 14-
 Almost reminds me of a chow fun but with smaller, fatter noodles but that nice rich oyster flavor. I do think for the price it could use a bit more noodle and perhaps another vegetable.

*Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup 牛肉手拉湯面 14-
Although, I have had this soup at a few places already, what really made this one amazing was the tenderness of the beef and how it wasn't chewy or fatty, the noodles were perfectly chewy and the broth was well balanced (although, I wish there were a tad bit more broth than noodles)

*Sichuan Green Beans (v) 8-
Again, a common dish, however, I highly recommend this as a vegetable side due to the the green beans being perfectly crisp, not soggy at all and the sauce is delicious. This one is actually a decent portion where two of us were able to get full.

*Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders (2) 茶香豬腩包 8
Probably my favorite appetizer ever-perfectly steamed buns with just the right amount of tender pork belly and complimented with pickled daikon and veggies and a  slightly zesty peppercorn oil. I wish there were at least 3 of these included for the price though.

*Honey Glazed BBQ Pork 蜂蜜叉燒 10
My China's version of "char sui" and this one isn't the least bit fatty or chewy. It's thinly sliced, honey kissed and just PERFECT if you are into meat (which I rarely am but actually enjoy eating this) 

*Twin Scallops Fried Rice 双貝炒飯 10
I know this is just fried rice but they do it so well in this case and you do taste some of those scallops. It's a great "filler" dish if you just want to get full and save money.
I also highly recommend just pairing this with the "honey glazed BBQ pork" for a satisfying meal. 

TIP: Come here during lunch on a weekday for better service and no wait! ;)
author: Petra S.

description: We went there for lunch on Wednesday afternoon... conveninetly located inside the westfield sf. Not too crowded and overall atmosphere was perfect for lunch! Ordered dim sum collection and beef hand pulled noodle and both are excellent! Enough for two to share.. great quality dim sum!!! If you are in san francisco city, craving for chinese while shopping in westfield, check this place out! Highly recommend!
author: Suzy H.

description:
M.Y. China has some clean Cantonese eats.  Not overly salty or greasy.  

Enjoyed:
-M.Y. Dim Sum Platter, would totally order this again.  Fluffy buns and lots of meat.
-Green Papaya salad, I think they substituted mango?  It was rather good and lightly dressed

Downers:
-Little gnats hover over your eats
-Couldn't taste the black truffle in the soup dumplings, soup good, skin was too thick and smelled like wet towel.  YUCK.  $18 is PRICEY.  

Light and fun lunch with some champagne before some serious shopping.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
This place reminds me a lot of PF Chang's. Shnazzy American Chinese food on the top floor of a mall in the middle of San Francisco. I came here knowing that, and yet I was still quite disappointed at the end of the meal. 

Came with a friend who is not really versed in Chinese food, so we went with:

Sizzing pan fry pork bao: This is one of my favorite Chinese dishes, but they did not pull through. It was not crispy enough, the skin part was way too thick, and the meat was reallyy itty bitty and not very juicy at all

Hong Kong Crispy Noodle: They did an okay job of this dish, but it could have been more flavorful. And it tasted a bit on the heavy side, but I guess you can't really expect otherwise with a fried noodle dish. 

Spicy Seafood Dumplings: This was the star of the meal for me. The skin was again, too thick for my personal tastes. But, with that being said, the sauce that it came with was really tasty and the inside of each dumpling was fresh and juicy. This dish's spice has that numbing sensation that not everyone is used to, so just be aware. 

Overall, it's a decent spot to stop by, especially if you're in the mall already and hungry. The ambience is great, but if you're looking for authentic, look elsewhere.
author: Annie S.

description:
Simple, comfort, well made, good ingredients.

We had the "longevity noodle" which is vegetarian.  Excellent!  Good flavor, fresh mushroom, green noodles.  Then we added the fried buns and that's just OK.  We expect a raw bun to be fried in both oil and water.  Instead, they pan fried cooked buns.  It is still good, but a bit too greasy.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Came here after work with my friend. We ordered the small dishes and they were great.  There was a longer than expected wait at 8pm on Saturday... But we'll be back!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I had the beef noodle soup, and it was very savory and satisfying.  I wish there were more noodles, but that's always the case.  It was cool that Martin Yan came walking through the restaurant a few times.  I'm glad he still has the reigns on this place unlike many other famous chefs.  I was there for happy hour, not the best deal on drinks, maybe a buck off.  But the bar area was fun, and there is seating outside the restaurant too.  Yes, it's in a mall, but it's a very swanky mall, and it's on the top floor.

I
author: Michelle R.

description: Overpromised; under-delivered. Staff rushed us. Took away my appetizer before I was finished because my entrée was ready. Took my glass of wine away before I finished it. What's up with that? Pork juicy dumplings were great. Boar noodles boring: lacked flavor. I've had better noodle dishes from Pick Up Stix takeout with much more flavor. Seven spice pork ribs dry, dry, dry! Inedible. Who was running the kitchen that night? No noodle tossing despite that being discussed a lot on M.Y. China website. A diner seated next to me told me he'd been there numerous times and had only seen noodle tossing once. Nothing about this very disappointing but very expensive experience was like what was promised on the website. Will never return and will never recommend.
author: Trish H.

description:
Wait time without rsvp 55 mins...dear god..(looks over at other options on list)...oh hell no....(tosses directory list in the trash)

1)Bok Choy appetizers are perfectly steamed and not as greasy as what you get from typical chow fun orders in other chinese restaurants 5/5

2. (COKE) 20 mins from order to table ....they were way more slammed compared to that toilet-chain of a bakery la boulange....so it was understandable.5/5

3.Kobe Beef with vegetables; beef cooked to order on the more rarer side so it wasn't too dry or charred...turned out perfect 4/5

4.)Squid ink Noodles; no fishy or salty flavor but the noodles tasted the same in flavor as the veggies and beef that came with previous dish...very underwhelming..2/5
author: Eric C.

description: Quite a fan of this modern twist on Asian fusion cuisine. Imagine it as the "W Hotel" of Asian food, trendy, chic, creative. It's like Hakkasan but more welcoming, and more affordable. The chef is a famous food network guest, a recipe book author, and a talented creator. Enjoy its modern cocktails, AND mocktails, seasonal dishes (lobster world trip), impressive modern desserts, and secret performances with perhaps gangnam style
author: Dilys S.

description:
The best vegetarian noodle soup I ever had ! 
So delicious and such sophisticated palate.
Great service, slightest head turn on my end and someone comes to check  if everything is okay . 
Beautiful design and pleasant atmosphere! 
Loved it!
author: Natalya V.

description: I ordered spicy seafood dumplings (to share) and Kung pao chicken. They were both very delicious. The veggies in the chicken were stir-fry perfection. However, the chicken was a tad bit dry and there being no sauce to go with it, a tough swallow. Overall, I would love to come back and try other dishes.
author: Pushpak K.

description:
Solid Chinese food.  You have to know to not order the Americanized dishes.  Noodles are fresh and I likes the roast pork belly.  

Green onion pancakes portion was teeny tiny.  Service was courteous but slightly forgetful.  I'd bring my kids here.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
I really enjoyed this place.

Modern Chinese decor and an open air kitchen. The refrigerators are even see through so you can see all the freshness. 

Food was very tasty, but I wish I had more time to explore the menu. 

Worth stopping by..
author: Kenneth B.

description:
Mocha tiramisu is fabulous!! Highly recommend to all! Actually desserts are all good.
Peking duck is weird haha.
Not bad place :) 
service is okay...
author: Lorrr L.

description: Great experience at MY China. Dinner was excellent, the wait staff was responsive, friendly, and anticipated our needs. The Yang Zhou fried rice was delicious. The Beijing noodles were amazing!  The General Mou's chicken was very tasty and my friend said the hot and sour soup was the best he ever had. Especially with the sriracha sauce the nicest guy ever "found" for him. The tables are pretty close together but we had a nice conversation with the group sitting next to us so it was all good.  Will definitely return.
author: Kenya C.

description:
I went here for the first time about a week ago. I got to try a bunch of different dishes since I had a couple people with me. Everything I tried was tasty and well presented. The server was very friendly and efficient. All of our food came out fast and hot. The seafood dumplings were my favorite. They were moist and a bit spicy but I loved the zing they had. Spicy food is just so flavorful and delicious. I also liked my entree--Kung pao chicken. The chicken was cooked perfectly and the chiles were easy to spot so I easily ate around them instead of accidentally eating one and having my mouth be on fire like I've done at other Chinese restaurants. I also enjoy the calamari--it was nice and crisp and golden brown and there weren't too many of the octopus tentacles that I don't eat :). I stick to eating the calamari rings instead. 

Overall the experience was great and I will definitely be back to try other things. 2 things to mention though--at our table I kept getting drops of water on me every one in awhile. They were coming from the ceiling and I'm not sure why. I think their heater was having some issues with condensation and water was dripping off of it. I hope they fix it. The other thing is I would highly recommend a reservation cuz this place is packed!
author: Sarah H.

description:
This place HITs the spot every time! 

There's not a lot of good Chinese restaurants in downtown SF and you'll be surprised this mall restaurant is actually decent and authentic. 

We love coming here for happy hours during the week, the drinks are delicious and the pork dumplings, chicken feet and half duck are all very good. My boyfriend and I have tried almost everything on the menu and they are all very tasty. I would ask for chili sauce on the side if you like spicy. 

The ice cream and sugar cream puffs are definitely my favorite desserts of all time!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Thank you to Craig and Chef Tony for the amazing dinner for 50 of my team and clients this week!  I have organized two private dining events for work at M.Y. China and our team has been "wowed" by the delicious and authentic food and excellent service both times.    

We received rave reviews for the delicious food which means a lot since the majority of our clients were from China and Taiwan.  M.Y. China prepared a special 11-course Chinese banquet menu for our group of 50 for a great price and tailored the menu for everyone with dietary restrictions.  Our clients were excited to try all of the menu items and took lots of photos of each dish.  I was pleased that even our clients from Indonesia said they watched Martin Yan cooking shows at home and were happy to dine at a "celebrity chef" restaurant.  

The Monk Room is elegant and a lovely place to host large dinners.  The surprise dancing noodle show with Korean music was another highlight of the night and generated lots of buzz!  

We are so thankful to the M.Y. China team for the memorable dining events for our team and clients!
author: Kimberly J.

description: Chinese food can be exceptional! I was pleasantly surprised by how delicious each entree was. The food presentation was enticing. I highly recommend the spicy seafood dumplings, chili crab, and the lobster clay pot. Lastly, I'd like to thank Nu-Beer for making our first dining experience truly enjoyable. Wonderful service! I'm already looking forward to the next visit.
author: Som J.

description:
Martin Yan's Restaurant Rocks!

Surprisingly, my Pork Juicy Dumplings and Beijing Hand-Cut Noodles tasted pretty good. Well, the kitchen are run by Chinese people but the front end are run by caucasian folks. 

They served authentic Chinese Cuisine. It's decoration is mixed with modern/Chinese. They give you both chopsticks and fork & knife on placemat.

It's nice to have something decent at SF Westfield Mall.
author: Pokemon P.

description: I came here yesterday and all I can say is "oh this place is so elite". The food tastes so much better than the Martin Yan food joint in Santa Clara. Do not come here during the happy hour because you will wait forever. It sure beats the Cheesecake Factory any day of the year.I really hate that both the Santa Clara joint and CCF are all not worth the money. This place is the game changer because it makes any kind of dining worth it. Great place to take a GF or BF, boss or close friend. For me I really like how this place would make a great corporate or workplace dinner/lunch break place. I also recommend sitting outside if eating, the sun shining on you or the lights of the dome make a good eating climate.
author: Michael W.

description:
I have always been a fan of Yan's and I was excited when I saw this restaurant on Check Please. The food looked very good on tv and the atmosphere was inviting. My wife and I decided to try it today while shopping in SF and we ordered the Dim Sum sampler ($20) and the Beijing beef noodle ($12). The dim sum was tasty, but there weren't many pieces for the price; however, I was still fine with the dish. 

When the Beijing beef noodle came, I thought the waiter made a mistake and gave us a vegetarian noodle dish instead, as I did not see any beef anywhere. The sauce was ok, but nothing special. The dish was mostly noodles and with fine slices of carrots, cucumbers, and mushrooms. Finally, I looked closely at the dish and found several VERY SMALL cubes of beef, the cubes were the size of a dried raisin and there were only about 6-7 pieces. 

Mr. Yan, I hope you read these reviews and listen to your customer. It is not the price of the food, as I have no problem paying a higher price for good reasonable food, but the portion you gave us was RIDICULOUS. I cannot come here again until you give your customers what they pay for.
author: Jim W.

description: Service was excellent. Waiters were attentive but not intrusive. I have shellfish allergies which they noted and communicated to other waiters who worked our table. My wife ordered a seafood noodle dish which she thoroughly enjoyed. I also enjoyed my meal and the tea infused tiramisu desert.  Despite being located in the 4th floor of a shopping mall, the ambience was perfect.  Highly recommend and would return on my next visit to San Fran.
author: Dennis J.

description: The food was okay but not worth the price. Go to chinatown and get more bang for your buck. The staff is nice and attentive.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
On Saturday evening, August 13th, we tried to come in for a late dinner when the host/receptionist told us that they needed to slow down on service and could not provide us with a definitive timeframe when we could be seated. He did this without saying hello or extending any sort of basic courtesy or hospitality as you would expect from an establishment of this caliber.

He was abrupt and curt and completely devoid of any manners. He made it obvious that he did not want to seat another group of customers 1 hour before closing.

The food is great here based on past dining visits but with service as poor as this from frontline staff, I will think again before even attempting to patronize this restaurant.
author: Vicki G.

description:
What do you expect from Martin Yan's restaurants? Hopefully, you're ready for Americanized Chinese food that is not authentic.  Whether it's dim sum or the hand pulled noodles, it tries to imitate with mediocre results.  The food tastes okay, but it lacks flavor that makes you crave more.  The pork and truffle juicy dumplings were not memorable except for the shreds of ginger on top that is usually left in the sauce to neutralize the pork flavor.  The squid ink pasta has no taste whatsoever.  The peppercorn beef filet is just spicy without the taste of quality meat.  The saving grace of this place is the Forbidden Rice and Toasted Rice ice cream.  

Service is friendly and somewhat helpful, but I doubt they understand Chinese food or the signature dishes.  There must have been a couple of plates and cups broken during our service that disrupted our meal.  The ambiance and decor is clean and simple with a contemporary feel.  Parking is tough in the city, but there are garages.
author: Jenny L.

description: Consistently good food and service.  Their crab and noodle dishes are excellent.  Don't miss the sugar egg puffs for dessert!!  It was very easy to make the reservation through YELP!
author: betsy r.

description: I am normally not in the city as often, but since I was in the mall, and happy hour was going, thought I would stop on in. The service was a little slow at first since they were so busy, but once we got our waiter, the service was great. So no dings on service. Ordered a few cocktails, and some calamari. Wasn't expecting the spicy flavor of calamari, but it was a nice kick. Not to spicy, but not bland either.  The 2 cocktails and beer I ordered was great. 1st drink was called Buddha breeze, barely taste the alcohol, but believe me, it was there. Then the Big Trouble In M.Y. China, that you could smell the 112 proof shot, and boy was it strong. Got me going. Never had Lucky Buddha beer, but loved the taste so much I ordered a beer just on its own. Will have to come here for dinner
author: Andrew M.

description:
I like this place a lot. 

First, it's so pleasant to sit under the dome, enjoy the outdoor-dining feel while you're actually indoors. The decor is very modern and goes well with the "dome theme". 

Second, food is great! It's a little bit of fusion, but more towards the Chinese side. The food is tasty and healthy, at the same time maintains just the right amount of authenticity. 

I've been here 3 times, all my visits were really enjoyable. I've ordered a variety of dishes:

- Xiao-long-bao (pork, or crab): the spoons are really cool, but it's really difficult not to break the dumplings because they stick to the spoons. But then again, you have the spoon to catch the broth, so it's ok. I personally prefer Ding Tai Feng's dumplings, but that seems like too much to ask. 
- Squid ink seafood pasta: very nice! I had never had squid ink pasta in a Chinese style, so this came as a surprise fusion for me. Very tasty. 
- Forbidden rice: Amazing. Healthy with mixed grain rice, but has a very simple, harmonic flavor with the egg white and different chopped veggies. 
- Vegetarian longevity noodles: good combination of different veggies and 4-5 different kinds of mushrooms. Temperature needs to be hotter. 
- Tea infused creme brulee: definitely amazing
- Lychee penna cotta: also amazing

I still haven't gotten a chance to try their beef noodle soup - I'm picky about that one, so I'm looking forward to it. 

Prices are great considering the gourmet quality food, quality of service, decor, atmosphere, and enjoyment. Will come back!
author: Wendy K.

description:
Overall the restaurant has a nice atmosphere.  At first we were nervous when we discovered the restaurant was in a mall (recommended by a friend). When you check in and are seated, the atmosphere is such that the mall melts away and becomes transparent. 

The menu is extensive, several different styles of dim sum and other Asian dishes.  We ordered mostly steamed dim sum and shared the plates. The seafood steamed dumplings were amazing.  Honestly they all were delicious, just those ones took the cake.

The staff was polite and knowledgable and would give you a run down before ordering if you were unfamiliar. Worth a stop if you're in the area.
author: Kurt L.

description:
I was expecting an upgraded PF Cheng when I walked in. But I was wrong.

This place looked quite American from outside, yet we were surprised by the authenticity of food it offered. The Chinese style lobster is one of the kind, with scissor cut noodle assembling the flavor from a northwestern Chinese dish-"莜面". 

Only downside being the price. But I guess the lobster attributed to that.
author: Bing G.

description:
First time I came here was on a whim and second time was for Valentines day! Each time was delicious, service and atmosphere was great! Bathroom is interesting! It's like male/female together, but not really. It's cool. Make the effort to go check it out! Now onto the few dishes that I enjoyed and stood out to me :

Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles - I was a little hesitant because of the boar, but I saw really good reviews about it on Yelp, so I thought it'd give it a try. You can tell the noodles are freshmade, and cut. It has a bit of a bite, so it wasn't completely soft. Boar tastes like beef to be honest, but maybe it had a more game-y flavor? Not sure! Good noodle dish! Pretty large portions, very filling.

Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup - This is my favorite thing to get here. I got this each time I came here. Now, I'm not so sure if this is like legit Taiwanese noodle soup, but my friend says it's the best he's tried here. Broth is dark and flavorful. Noodles are handpulled and delicious! I'm not a noodle person, so it means a lot when I'm loving these noodles! Comes with some bok choy. But.. the meat is the best part of this soup. Super soft and tender, melt in your mouth. It's perfect.

Lychee Panna Cotta- chrysanthemum granita was very interesting, like a shaved ice. Panna cotta came in a nice presentation and sort of like a jello!
author: Carmen C.

description:
I expected the food here to be a lot more decent than it was. Yes, it is more expensive then your mom and pop Chinese restaurant, but that doesn't make it automatically bad in my book. I am happy to pay more for a quality cuisine and consistency. But you're not paying for that here. You're paying for decor and to sit under the festively lit dome of the Westfield Shopping Centre. My gripe about the food is that the boar noodle soup was lukewarm, the green beans were old (like, chewy, yellowing, sitting around for more than a week old), the dim sum, while I appreciate the sustainable sourcing, was mediocre and falling apart. The mapo tofu was criminally tasteless, and the the delicate green onion pancakes were least objectionable, but also nothing to write home about. 

Overall it was a very disappointing lunch. I won't claim to know all the great places to go instead for delicious, clean Chinese cuisine, but I would not waste my time here.
author: Viv D.

description:
Came for dinner on a Sunday night. The set up of the restaurant is decent, you get a nice and classy impression. 

We ordered their pork dumpling and crab dumpling combo as an appetizer, Westlake wonton noodle soup, Kobe beef medallions, Chinese broccoli, salt and pepper calamari and wild boar scissor cut noodles. 

-Pork/ crab row dumplings:
Pretty good! 3 stars 

- Westlake wonton soup:
tasted like edible birds' nest soup. Not too bland and not too overpowering. The wontons in this soup were really good. 3.5 stars

-Kobe beef medallions:
really tender and cooked medium rare. More on the rare side. A little sweet hint taste to it, but very tender and chewy. 3.5 stars

-Chinese broccoli:
Could've made at home. Nothing special. 1 star. 

-Salt and pepper calamari: 
Really soft, tender, chewy, and crispy battered!! Full of flavor and had a nice spicy kick to it. 4.5 stars

-Wild boar scissor cut noodles:
This was my favorite dish of the night. These noodles were hand pulled and not your typical skinny noodle. Extremely soft, fluffy and chewy and had a good authentic chinese taste to it. 4.5 stars

The bill came out to $121 for all these dishes. Overall
this restaurant has some pretty ok/decent food. The wild boar scissor cut noodles and salt and pepper calamari are definitely worth a try!
author: Amanda R.

description:
overall - 3.9/5
-----------------

food - 3/5
1) fresh dungeness crab meat and roe xiao long bao 

service -3.5/5

cleanliness - 4/5

location -5/5

experience - 4/5

---------------------
wait time: 0 mins (weekend, afternoon)
author: John V.

description: Excellent food, good pricing, pleasant wait staff
author: Stephen F.

description:
If you get there before 6 the happy hour menu is great! There is limited seating which I don't understand the whole restaurant is empty and they won't seat you in main dining room. If they do you cant order from hh menu. Very simple people just stop the hh at 6 and we will order the regular price drinks and food. 
The food is pretty good for mall food. The prices are probably 50% more than most Chinese restaurants. Compared to PF CHANG.
author: Alison W.

description: The food at this place is absolutely amazing. I highly recommend the noodles with chicken but you can't go wrong with any new noodles dish . Our server Jackie was fantastic! Will definitely be visiting this place again
author: Reggie E.

description: Very awesome decor, great atmosphere. Food was also really solid. The 小笼包 is not bad. Also get the spicy chicken.
author: Tony W.

description: Possibly the best Chinese food I've had in years! Don't think I could ever go back to lower quality restaurants after this...
author: Ivan C.

description: Chicken wings are the best I've ever had. Sweet, crisp, and perfect! It's a must order!
author: Ameera D.

description: DISGUSTING! We saw a live mouse running in the restaurant. Alerted the manager who didn't seem fazed at all. He said it's an issue in the mall and all the restaurants deal with it. Will not be eating here again. If I want to see mice in restaurants I don't have to spend $100.
author: Natalie C.

description: Absolutely delicious.  Even though it seemed like the place was packed with clumsy waiters the day we dined, the food was out of this world.  We had a large group so we ordered a variety of dishes from squid ink noodles, assorted dim sum, a whole fried fish (which takes about 30mins to cook), and a spicy chicken which everyone at the table loved.  Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area.
author: Nabeel N.

description: Hands down one of the best Chinese restaurants I have eaten at. We got to meet the chef truly amazing food. We will be back ! The chow mein with boats head was great
author: John S.

description: Awesome veg tempeh sliders and mushroom in hoisin sauce! Got some Oloong ice cream to round up with a bang!
author: Priyanka L.

description:
I love this place. 
I love the shandon beef rolls.
I love the wild bore scissor cut noodles. 
I love tony Wu the head chef
author: Josh L.

description:
Lunch, New Years Eve, 2012.  Figured Chinese food was the thing todo after watching the early show of the Hobbit.  3 hours of sitting works up an appetite. My friend and I sat at the noodle station...saw them being made.  It's mesmerizing.  Hypnotic.  Like that little kid watching the static TV in Close Encounters.  

So for eats, crab dumplings, beef noodle soup, and kung pow chicken.  The dumplings were nicely done.  The noodle soup, while the noodles were really good and fresh, was in a very sweet broth - too sweet for my liking.  The kung pow chicken was fantastic.  I really don't know how 'authentic' or 'american' this wok dish is, but this was just great.  I devoured it.  Even to the point of eating the peppers.   

Bonus points, Martin Yan was in the shop.  You'd see him saying hi to tables, talking to the kitchen chefs, and bang a spoon on a pot to draw attention to the noodle guy.   Really dug how he just disrupted the vibe of his own place.
author: David S.

description: I honestly don't know why i keep coming back to this place.   The food here is average. I do like coming here for happy hour. You can get some of the dishes for just 5.00  I've had the XLB and potstickers here a few times.  I like how the vinegar sauce had a spicy kick to it.  The dimsum platter was ok, i didn't like how my har gow dumpling had a very sticky skin.  The peking duck was not bad, but it wasn't too special.  There was still a lot of fat attached to the duck, which in some places they remove they fat for you..  The hand pull noodles were very average, i prob will not order this dish again.  For drinks, my favorite was the Singapore sling.    I would come back again for this place, but only during Happy Hour, for more reasonable prices.
author: Belinda C.

description: Taste good. Honey glazed walnut shrimp - there is wasabi flavoring on the shrimp, an unconventional addition. I'm not a big fan of wasabi flavor, so I didn't like it very much.
author: Xiaobin Z.

description: A man waiter who tie his hair sometimes had a offensive conversation with us but overall food is good so I use Caviar to deliver a lot.
author: Howard H.

description:
Great service...and excellent food!

Pork Sliders = 5+
Green Beans = 5
Chow Fun = 5

Loved the food. Love Martin Yan. Love PBS when I was a kid...if Yan can cook, so can you...not sure I could make the awesome noodles we had, but glad M.Y. China is a short walk from my place so I don't have to.
author: Amy O.

description: We ordered hot & sour soup, Claypot Eggplant, Peppercorn Cauliflower, How Gow, Dan Dan Mien! Love them! Will be back again and again and again.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: Been here several times and always enjoyed the food. But yesterday after spending $100 on food and drinks for two people, we saw a rat climbing up the wall. Sooooo gross! And to make matters worse, the manager told us that it is an ongoing problem as if a rodent infestation is completely normal. Never again MY China. Never again.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
What I got:
M.Y. sweet and sour pork
Yang zhou fried rice
Wonton soup
Dan dan noodles

What I thought:
So my family came to town and thought we'd take a stroll down union square during the afternoon. They were feeling some Chinese food so this popped up on my yelp and I thought we should try. Giving this place 2 stars for a few reasons. 

I wanna start off by saying in terms of flavor 2/4 things were decent. The sweet and sour pork and fried rice were probably the only two things I would even think about ordering again if I came back. 

Dan dan noodles weren't that great. Tasted just like a shittier version of Vietnamese vermicelli noodles. 

The wonton soup was so plain and the broth that it was in was basically just water. 

On top of that, the portions were like portions for ANTS! Sure we did family style, but even if we didn't, I honestly think it would have taken at least 2.5 plates to get even close to full. 

Oh yeah and did I mention our waitress wasn't the friendliest? Apparently, they changed waiters in the middle of our meal and didn't even tell us. When we ordered additional food she said rudely that she'll "tell kevin." Whoever that is. Pretty expensive "chinese" food. Not even close to PF Changs if you want to compare. Definitely not coming back here and I think you shouldn't either.
author: Tony V.

description:
It was a first night in San Francisco, and one of our family friends invited us for dinner. He asked if we were up for Chinese, and of course like anyone we gladly accepted. I was very surprised at the location. It was located on the fourth floor of the downtown Westfield Mall that were also surrounded by other restaurants. I first stepped in the restaurant  I noticed the decor; it was a more classy type of setting. The restaurant was had a nice and vibrant ambience, to it. It had its Chinese influence on the decor, of course but it still had a nice modern feel to it. It was brightly lit but then it was off set by the darker shades of the tables and the chair. Overall, I do really like the aesthetic of the restaurant because it is very pleasing to see. Our waiter was very attentive and nice. 

 Spicy Seafood Dumplings (9)
      This was actually the section of the menu that caught my eye since usually Dim Sum is not served during dinner. One of the menu items that we decided to order were the Spicy Seafood Dumplings. The dumpling wrapper is made out of spinach that stuffed with scallop and shrimp. The sauce was light and it did add more flavor to the dumplings. Although, I would add just a touch of more seasoning on the sauce. The spinach wrapper had a great texture since it still had a little bit of chew to it. On the inside, the scallop and shrimp were very tender and I liked the fact that it wasn't overcooked. The seasoning in the dumpling was perfect. If they did more, I felt that it would overwhelm the dish and destroy the delicacy and daintiness of the dish. I would definitely order this dish again.

 Juicy Dumplings w/ Pork or Pork & Crab Roe - (9)
The other item that we ordered off the Dim Sum menu was the Juicy Dumplings with Pork or Pork & Crab Roe. You had the choice  of either getting three with pork and three with pork & crab roe. We decided to get three of each. When it arrived, we opened and I really loved the simple but traditional presentation of the Juicy Dumplings. It was my first time trying this type of dumplings that had soup inside, so I was very excited to try this! I only tried one which was the one with pork. I enjoyed the fact that its own spoons so you really could savor the soup and all its deliciousness once when the dumpling breaks.  The pork had a really nice flavor to it. After that I drank the soup, and it had a sweet note to it from the combination of the pork and other seasonings. I really liked the dumpling because of all the savory flavors and the hint of sweetness to it. The whole dish itself was mouth watering!

Seven Spice Pork Rib (18)
   The first this dish that we ordered from the Wok Section was the Seven Spiced Pork Ribs. The presentation was already stunning, the  medley of colors from the scallions, onions, and herbs. Also, the Seven Spice that was set on top of this meat made it already mouth watering. When I first bit into it, my taste buds were already doing the salsa since the spices were so delicious! If you eat with all of the topping of the spices and the vegetables, it is very flavorful. Although, if you eat the meat itself it is kinda of dry and tough. I wish the rib was cooked down more. That would be the only thing that I would change about it. I would rate this dish a four out of five.

 Wok Seared Beef- (19)
   This dish was actually recommended by a family member that has eaten here numerous times, so therefore I was ecstatic to try it. In the menu, it describes that it is seasoned with Sichuan peppercorns and laid on a bed of arugula.
