When I first bit into it, the meat was already so tender, that I just had to eat over and over again. The Sichuan peppercorns were just beautifully paired with the meat. It gave an extra something to the dish which I have been looking for while eating here. I loved this dish so much!

Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp-(22)
      One of my favorite dishes is the Honey Walnut shrimp. To see that now it is on the menu, I wanted to order it. It arrived and it looked like your typical honey walnut shrimp. I really enjoyed the glaze since it was sweet, but it had a twist to it. There were hints of wasabi, which provided it be kind of light. Also, it had the some fresh cucumbers with it which provided another dimension to it. I really liked the fact that they added wasabi since it was just something then ordinary.

Hong Kong Crispy Noodles w/ Chicken X- (16) 
This was my favorite dish since it had the right balance of flavors. At first it seemed like your typical crispy noodle dish, but then once it enters your mouth it is excellent. The crunchy part of noodles was just right and it wasn't too hard or too soft. Once you mix it in with the rich, and creamy sauce the noodles start to soften, and it just become delectable. The vegetables were not mushy and they still had a nice crunch to it. Also, the chicken was very moist and juicy. I just kept going back to the dish more and more.
author: Aleia P.

description: I enjoyed my  dinning experience at this restaurant during my birthday celebration. The food was delicious!
author: Kimberly J.

description: Very kind servers... fun spot with tons of  energy! Bartenders are really friendly and the chefs are fun to watch. Stand out dishes are the beef noodle soup and the fantastic chicken soup!
author: Laura G.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place. I came on a Thursday evening about an hour before they closed. the mall was already pretty empty and the restaurant was about half full.

Let's start with the negatives and end on a good note. 

We were shown our to our table but because of the way the long table is set up in the middle, it felt more like a cafeteria table with small gaps in between. It's hard to describe but I didn't feel like I had my "own" small table. Not very intimate, is what I'm going for. It's either that or you can sit at the bar or along the glass seeing the chefs prepare the food. 

Once seated, it took nearly 10 minutes for the NON-busy restaurant to come take our drink orders. She asked if we had questions about the menu. I'm a fairly slow reader but I had already read the entire menu 3 times by now and was already feeling ignored (read "neglected"). I politely told the waitress that we were ready to order, she responded "okay". I begin my order: spicy dumplings, and beef hand-pulled noodles. Before I completed my second word (which was "dumplings"), she stops me "oh, I forgot a pen"... and then walks away from the table. 

Service and experience: 2 stars. The ambiance was pretty cool in that you can see that the noodles are definitely fresh. 

Now, the food: the spicy dumplings were pretty good, just a small amount of kick to it, but I felt that it had a little too much soy-sauce which just turned the entire dish salty. 

Now, the pièce de résistance... overcooked. The noodles were overcooked!!! After all that, the noodles felt mushy. They definitely tasted fresh, but the noodles were not run under cold water as it is traditionally done in traditional Chinese restaurants when dealing with fresh noodles. The cold water stops the noodles from cooking, and the hot broth keeps the noodles warm before eating. These noodles were "hot" and fell apart to the touch. Trying to serve two bowls became very difficult as the noodle would break off. 

I must admit though, the beef was perfectly stewed and essentially melted in your mouth! The baby bok choy was also very fresh and crisp. 

Even so, I'll give the food 4 stars because it is hard to make beef that soft! The noodles, I'm hoping was just a fluke.

I plan to be back to give them another shot, but I'll wait a little while before I pay someone to be ignored. 

So, average 3 stars is all I can muster. Hope your Yelping experience is better than mine!
author: Charles K.

description:
I had the best meal at M.Y. China.  The only reason I only gave it 4 stars instead of 5 stars is that it fills up fast after opening for dinner and it can be difficult to get in.  

I had the gluten-free (yes, they do have gluten free items) Wild Boar Lettuce cups as a starter followed by Venison Chow Fun.  Absolutely delicous.  Highly recommend.  This is high-end Chinese food and they have quite a selection.
author: Catherine L.

description: We stopped by this place after checking out the NFL Superbowl Experience.  Just so happened it was Chinese New Years celebration.  Owner Martin Yan was there stopping at tables to chat.  It was a pleasure to meet this great chef.  We had a bunch of different things to eat but the 2 that stood out was the spicy dumplings and the eggplant tofu.  The spicy dumpling was the right consistency and the sauce they dressed it with was a perfect compliment.  The eggplant tofu came in sort of a stone pot so some of the veggies got "browned" and made the dish even tastier with the different textures.  Will definitely head back when in SF.
author: S A.

description: When I decided to come back to M.Y China, I was  skeptical in coming again. I was invited back and by far exceeded my expectations. From the beginning to the end everything was exceptional. The food delicious and the service was amazing. We ordered spicy seafood dumplings, salt & pepper lobster, scallop fried rice, fish noodles and chairman mao's chicken. Everything was absolutely delicious and very fresh. We were greeted by sam who checked up on us during dinner and had a lovely waiter who I cannot remember her name but she was very attentive. Dinner was great from the beginning to the end. Will definitely be back when in town.
author: Ella P.

description:
We came here on Saturday afternoon for lunch, after going by many times and checking out the menu (which had several veggie options for me). We were excited and decided to get a few small things (Dim Sum + Appetizers). I was also really pleased with the wine selection, so we wound up ordering the roast chicken boa, pan fried pork bao, veggie spring rolls and sichuan green beans, as well as a beer and zin from the drinks menu.

The place is a bit fancy for lunch and was pretty busy when we sat down but our food came out pretty darn quick (in stages, which was good too, because it meant everything stayed hot). We both loved the green beans and I'm a huge fan of the spring rolls. The sizzling pork bao gave off a delicious aroma and I was assured they were good. 

Ask can be expected, the price was a bit up there, especially since we ordered drinks, but we left feeling just full enough.
author: Cassandra J.

description: My husband wanted to eat here because he saw a review on the TV about this restaurant. We came to Westfield to return a couple of Warriors T-shirts and decided to try it out. We had the WOK seared beef, dumplings, and a couple side dishes. Everything all in all tasted good, but service was slow. However about a few hours later when I got home my stomach started cramping, I wasn't feeling well and I asked my husband if he felt weird too. He said no. I woke up the next morning and had the worst, TMI, diarrhea and it lasted for a couple hours. I usually wouldn't write a horrible review like this but this is not good. I think I got food poisoning.
author: Claire C.

description: M.Y.China should have been great as it seems that considerable thought went into the dishes featured on the menu  and when executed as Martin Yan presumably intended the results are likely spectacular - the components of the wok seared seafood were obviously extremely fresh and the favors were both subtle and harmonious. The Peking duck that followed which should have come with slivered green onions and cucumber came instead with coarsely sliced onions and actual chunks of cucumber. The accompanying hoisin sauce was too salty and had a slightly unpleasant aftertaste. The duck was dry too. Deserts were a bit mixed. A lychee panna cotta was so full of gelatin that it was more like a hockey puck than the tremulously wobbly fruit custard it's supposed to be so it was sent back. Our waiter said it would be taken off the bill but it wasn't until we'd asked again for it to be done when the bill eventually arrived. The egg custard buns (described as molten egg custard lava buns) were fine, as they should have been for the price! I'd driven up from Los Angeles to have dinner with my eldest son who was in town for a sudden two day conference. I've been away from San Francisco restaurants for a while and found M.Y.China from an Internet search. Silly me! I'd promised him a really good Chinese dinner which the beautifully envisaged menu and Martin Yan's reputation should have allowed. Unfortunately mediocre execution and lackluster service from a staff who either aren't properly supervised or just don't care failed to provide the experience that the prices promised. In a town full of great Chinese restaurants isn't one of them.
author: Howard C.

description: Food was good.  Waitress was very helpful.  However......  I had a noon reservation for 2 under my name to meet with someone for the very first time.  I got there early (about 1145am) and was seated.  When my guest arrived and asked for my reservation, the hostess told her there was not a reservation in my name.  My guest had to sit in the bar area for 15 minutes thinking I had not arrived.  What a mess.
author: Patrick L.

description: The green dumplings were absolutely DIVINE! Wings were fairly good, the other dumplings were also good in the little red spoons. Had a Lucky Buddha beer which was quite pleasant, mild, and came in a very cool bottle. Monkey Prince was like an Old Fashioned, extremely smooth and velvety. Green beans were crunchy and um AMAZING!! Wild boar cut noodles were my favorite (but it's SO flippin hard to decide), honey glazed walnut shrimp was very good (caution it comes with a mayonnaise sauce), and the snap noodle was AWESOME; chewy and very good!!! Each dish brought it's own distinct taste and was very unique, adding to a harmonic blend of tastes for my mouth to savor...I know this will sound extreme, but honestly this is THE best Chinese food I have ever had! (And yes, trust me that is saying something). Please ignore the fact that it's inside a mall and give this a shot. You WON'T be sorry! No regret 5 star. Scrumdiddlyumptious. P.S. the M.Y. China egg puff dessert is light and a great finish.
author: Alex B.

description:
Been here two times in total. First time i visited, i actually saw the chef (my china .. The chef on pbs). It was the first week it opened and the food sucked. I absolutely hated it. I have seen lots of patrons visiting and eating on the occasions i have walked by when in the mall so i felt compelled to give it second chance. TERRIBLE!!
1. East meets west cocktail is like drinking soap water
2. Main entree was soggy and gross
3. Appetizer was some dried over sauced beef in a hard carb shell... It was nasty!! Mark my words... My curiousity as to why people eat here is oveeeer.. Rover. Bye!
author: Lilly S.

description:
We came on a Sunday afternoon and were surprised at how many people were also eating late lunches. Not crowded, but bustling, which is a nice vibe.

We started with drinks. I got the Nixon in China (a cucumber and...I can't remember, but it was delicious) and my husband got a Singapore Sling.

You can take a couple different approaches to ordering. Dim Sum is an option, as well as small plates, noodles, and wok dishes. We went for a couple of small plates (salt and pepper calamari and pork belly sliders), the Kung Pao Chicken from the wok menu, and the Beijing Noodles with pork and mushrooms. 

Not a miss in the bunch. Calamari was perfectly seasoned and not at all chewy and came with a sweet chili dipping sauce. The pork belly was flavorful and tender, and the two mains were delicious and well seasoned/spiced. My only complaint is the the chicken was slightly (not bad, but slightly) dry. 

They have an open kitchen where you can watch them making the noodles by hand, and it is quite a show. Stretching, pulling, clipping, tossing - it looks like taffy at times. 

Would love to go back for both Dim Sum and to try their special lobster menu. The waiter mentioned the Lobster Hot Pot and I've been thinking about it for the past week.
author: Amanda H.

description: Food safety warning real. Ate here over the weekend and got food poisoning as a result. When i called to let the management know what had happened, i was rudely told off by the manager Julie C. that their establishment had a good health score. Funny because when going on yelp to complain about them.... i saw the warning from yelp. I wish i went to yelp first before eating here. Julie C. you should be ashamed of yourself!!! Lies
author: Keo Y.

description:
Competently done Chinese.  I ordered half a peking duck, not as flavorful as others I have eaten but I am asian.  The Hoisson sauce was too salty so I needed to avoid it, this takes away from the usual contrast of flavors in the dish.  

I also ordered Szechuan green beans and asked for not spicy which the chefs adjusted the recipe to a sweeter one which was much to my liking.  The beans were crisp and good temperature (cooking hot not spicy hot).  The white rice was surprisingly cold and not good temperature.   

Overall satisfied with the meal.  Service was nice, food presentation was nicely done.  See photo.  Probably enough food for two people but I ate alone.
author: Steven C.

description: We walked in for early dinner. The food is absolutely disastrous! We ordered a Wok Seared Beef that's way tooooo salty (I think they poured at least half bottle of soy sauce into it) and the portion is unreasonably small for a $19 dish. The Garlic Pea Shoot is not flattering either. The pea shoot is simply unchewable and I had to spit out most of it. Service is poor as ... overall this place overcharges you for very low quality food. DO NOT COME HERE!
author: Nancy Yannan L.

description: I don't know what part of China cuisine this place makes but this type of Chinese food is my favorite.. Sercice was really good and we requested some changes when ordering from the menu..my mom had sweet & sour chicken (originally it was with pork), I had beef noodle (original was with pork) and my hubby had Mao's chicken (spicy!). Everyone liked their food and I can say that noodles were homemade and was really good. Don't forget to end the meal with Super delicious egg puffs mixed with chocolate and berry sauce!
author: Merve A.

description:
I had reservations for 1/10 8pm for party of 5. It was to celebrate my birthday with my girlfriends. Two of my friends had arrived early and had already checked in at 7:30pm. The rest of us arrived at about 7:55. The host that was working was really misleading and not helping. If I had made reservations weeks in advance aren't you suppose to leave a table open to make sure it's available to accommodate ?? There was a party of 4 that was a walk in and was seated before our party was. We ended up seating at 8:30pm and that's only because one of my friends started complaining to one of the managers. I mean what's the point of having a RVSP option if you don't follow through with it. I understand restaurants are busy and they can't always make people leave, so 10-15mins late I can understand. But I think it might have taken us longer to be seated if my gf hadn't complained about the wait. 

If I can rate this review on the manager that was working at the time I would give it 5 stars. Matthew was extremely accommodating and nice. He was the manager on the clock at time and got us a table set up right after my friend complained. He also threw in the first round of drinks on the house. Not only did he put out the fire, he made sure we were happy campers and he even came around to check in with us a few times.  

Overall service by the waiters would be a 3 . Weren't all that friendly and didn't describe all the dishes when they brought it to our table. Weren't very attentive either. 

Food- average. Everything was good but not great or "omg" . For the price you're paying for Chinese food I expected more. 

It was my first time here and I been meaning to try this place. Would I come back? Probably not. I rather go r&g lounge. Would I recommend it ?? Probably not. And if Matthew hadn't been there that night I would've probably end up giving this review 2 starts rather than 3. 

THANK YOU MATTHEW RYKKEN FOR YOUR GREAT SERVICE !!! (=
author: Karen M.

description:
XLB and seafood dumplings were amazing appetizers! 5 stars

Rice cake with wild boar and cabbage was bursting with flavor and very generously portioned :P 5 stars

Cumin lamb was just ok. The chunks of lamb were a bit too big and could have been more tender. 3 stars

Overall, a great experience and perfect pre-movie dinner spot.

Request "outside" seating for a beautiful view of the dome.
author: Jia H.

description: Reservations were easy to make through yelp. Place was pretty crowned on a Wednesday evening so I suggest making reservations. Food came out pretty fast and my husband and I thought it was good. Staff were pretty friendly but our waiter was just okay.
author: Javon J.

description:
As a Chinese person, it's tempting to be critical about how I can go elsewhere, order more/less the same dish(es), for a less expensive price.  Then again, I chose to try this place so, in terms of price, I knew what I was getting into.  M.Y. China, is owned by chef Martin Yan, whose TV show "Yan Can Cook" is well known by many.  Because of its location in Westfield Mall in Union Square, I went in with the expectation that I will be getting authentic Chinese cooking with a Western flare.  I was right.  The menu caters to the Western palate as true Chinese cooking doesn't include cold salads.  My friend and I ordered the Peking Duck (a dish of crispy roasted duck skins and meat tha includes 8 housemade buns in a bamboo steamer), Grandma's Gai Lan w/garlic & Chinese sausage, and Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles. Highlight: I know the Chinese side of me was coming out because when the broccoli dish came out, and as much I liked the crunchiness, I really wanted oyster sauce to compliment it; I asked our waiter for some, she looked confused/unsure and had to ask around.  Good thing, though, one of her staff members came through and gave us a small dish of oyster sauce...lol.
A plus for awesome service, decor, and the food being tasty, but, I personally, may dine here less often as I can order the same food at a different restaurant for a lesser price.  Of course, as I said, the price does fit the environment in which it's located.
author: Jessica S.

description: Total joke. Went after reading Michael Bauer's top places to dine near Union Square because I was in town for a conference. Two of his other recommendations were outstanding so I decided to give it a shot even though mall restaurants aren't my thing. I went with a noodle dish because they are known for making handmade noodles. The noodles were overcooked and flavorless and the seafood was not fresh and overcooked. Avoid this place. You could walk into just about any place in Chinatown and find more interesting food. Would give 0 stars if that was an option.
author: Nancy A.

description:
Been here more than 5 times - never been disappointed! Bang Bang Chicken wings are the best and the squid ink noodle dish is our favorite. Tried something different today -
Wild Boar - awesome as well!
author: Bob D.

description: This is my 2nd visit to Martin Yan's MY China.  The beef noodle was excellent as was the xiao loong bao.  Dim sum collection was also good but I had mixed feelings on the multi-grain rice dim sum.  Definitely more healthy but I prefer the sticky rice.  We came during a busy period but the service was fine.
author: George F.

description: Love the food! The host was so nice and accommodating and our server was just amazing
author: Claudia L.

description: Super delicious place.  We ordered a few dishes, all of them are super yummy.  The best thing is the dessert, the matcha tiramisu tastes like heaven.  It includes heavy taste of tea leaves, and not very sweet.  You really should try this place.
author: Lexi L.

description:
I honestly had used yelp to determine if the restaurant was worth it mind you I normally don't always follow reviews but since it had such a good rating I went in with friends. The staff was friendly and seated us quickly. They didn't rush us, the menu's were clear of what was In their food. They had prices for their alcoholic drinks which a lot of places fail to do if you ask me.

Anywho. Long story short, we ordered basically something small but fillingZ I ordered shrimp won tons which honestly helped me deal with until we got to dinner time which is good. For the price, it was fairly good given the atmosphere. 

Just a tip: the tea's which are 7 to 8 bucks is for 2 people maybe 3 or the whole table. 

Overall friendly staff, nice dining. I would go there again for lunch if I was in the city
author: James T.

description:
This place just seethes of Westfield mall - overpriced, with a haughty and superior veneer that's not worth it. They hire servers of different ethnicities - but they're all slim and pretty-faced, with a vibe that screams disingenuous. They want a generous tip, that's all. And they're probably used to getting it, being pretty and desirable-looking. 

My server obviously didn't enjoy serving me - I could feel it. He seemed more neutral about the others in my party, though. I ordered an item that sounded interesting. But when it came, I was disappointed - it was something that I really disliked. I asked the server to describe it before I ordered it, but he didn't describe it all that well or accurately, so I didn't know exactly what he was talking about. The menu should describe items more fully. And pictures of all the entrees would help, too. I never send stuff back, but I really disliked my entree, and it was expensive, so I sent it back and ordered something else instead. Unfortunately, that other entree was pretty bad as well. They weren't real noodles, as I was expecting - they were odd, spear or worm-shaped "noodles." Not too appetizing. The overall flavor of the dish was really meh, too. My party also ordered a sweet and sour soup that we shared, and it was very meh as well. 

I don't get this restaurant. Is it Asian or Chinese fusion? Chinese with an American, Hong Kong, or international flair? I guess it's like Slanted Door, except more Chinese instead of Vietnamese. The pretentious restroom, which I believe was unisex, definitely reminded me of the Slanted Door's. Same builder/architect? 

M.Y. China, like the rest of the mall, is all about a trendy veneer, and lacking in real substance. It was $30 for each of us for a very mediocre meal - worse than a $5 one you can get in Chinatown. Martin Yan, geez. I thought you'd do better than this.
author: S F.

description:
Have always enjoyed my meals here. The dan dan noodles were a bit too spicy last time, but other than that, always really good even if it's a little overpriced. 

The decor in the actual restaurant is nice and even the bathrooms are pretty
author: Emma M.

description: My favorite Chinese experience in SF! I live next to Chinatown and always prefer this restaurant for the quality of the food and the show! Open kitchen and they make everything from scratch. What you would expect from James Beard chef! The fresh crab and lobster is always a gem, Peking duck and homemade noodles. Best cocktails ever!
author: Ann K.

description: Lovely space in a convenient location on the 4th floor of Westfield Mall at Union Square in San Francisco. We went for a birthday lunch. The freshly made noodles were delicious and the Peking duck with little buns was exceptionally succulent. We ordered the eggplant clay pot and cauliflower and portobello vegetable dish -- tasty and the vegetables were cooked perfectly. Delicious Shanghai dumplings are served in individual red Chinese spoons -- cute!  The service was attentive but not intrusive. The restaurant provided complimentary dessert "donuts" for our birthday celebration. Nice touch! So M.Y. China is nice gathering place to enjoy a wonderful meal and is close to great shopping and accessible by public transportation (BART).
author: Joyce H.

description:
Sort of like P.F. Chang's but not. 

We ordered an appetizer, a chicken dish to share, a side, and some rice but the side dish came to our table before everything else did. Sure, the other food came out at a decent speed but you don't send out food in the wrong order. Is anyone paying attention?

There's something to be said when your waitress goes to every table around yours to check in but doesn't check in with you until after your table was cleared and you asked someone else for the check. I didn't want to tip more than a dollar or two because really all she did was write down our order and pour a glass of water, but my boyfriend is nicer than me. 

I know this is a mall restaurant and I didn't have high expectations, but there are some standard expectations a patron has and the staff should deliver on that or get out of that line of work. 

I will not come back.
author: Amanda M.

description: Nice location and very nice ambience and good service Food is ok as compared to other Chinese places nearby and is a bit expensive for the quality of the food.
author: Vish E.

description:
I would have given them 5 stars if I stopped with my waiter's recommendations but only three stars based on what I ordered on my own, hence my 4 stars.

First, the good.  Spicy seafood dumplings were great.  Spicy but not painfully so, the seafood was perfect and not too fishy.  Portion size very ample.  Mu Shu Pork Tacos also great.  Great combination of flavors, again nice sized portion.  Finally, the shandong beef rolls were incredible, one of the best small dishes I ever had.  It was a lot like Japanese negamaki surrounded by crispy goodness with a nice sauce.  As I said earlier, if I ended here, would of been very happy.

Unfortunately, ordered a couple other dishes on my own because they sounded so good.  First, the roast pork.  It was not bad but really nothing tasty and I often get better roast pork at strip mall Chinese restaurants (this was probably higher quality meat the taste was not superior).  The biggest disappointment, though, and what almost knocked it down to three stars, was the sizzling pan fried savory pork bao.  I love pork buns but these were almost inedible.  They looked great but were primarily dough.  The meat was like a solid pork meatball that had weird texture and was not particularly good.

Overall, would go again but this time take the advice of the waiter.
author: Lloyd M.

description:
Highlights:
- Martin Yan was in the house the night that I came and he was so friendly. Always coming over to our table to check in on us and introduce his dishes. 
- I love how everything tasted so fresh and incorporated a lot of vegetables. 
- Squid ink pasta was so unique and it incorporated brussel sprouts.
- Duck was my favorite and the best I have tasted. Came with buns, all fat was removed: LOVE!, cucumbers, chives, and hoisin sauce. 
- Beef fillet: tasted fantastic and I enjoyed the presentation with the bed of arugula.
- Beef hand pulled noodles. Just the right amount of vegetables, beef was so tender and tasty. 
- Nice decor, friendly staff, beautifully laid out restaurant and restrooms.

Improvements:
- None that I can think of. Service was great, food was delicious, I wish I had more space in my stomach to try more dishes.

Tip: Make a reservation.
author: Tracy T.

description:
A nice place for a nice occasion. It's double the price of regular Chinese restaurants for similar quality food, so it's not somewhere I'd go for a normal meal. But apart from that, I liked it. 

Definitely recommend:
- Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup
- Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles 

Quite good also:
- Kung Pao Chicken
- Sautéed Green Beans

Sometimes the chefs walk around and spin the hand pulled noodles in front of you, so that's always neat.
author: An Y.

description: We had dinner here and the food just okay nothing special. Maybe we expect too much as the reviews giving very good rating. We ordered the Siao Lung Pao, the dumplings, Kung Pao chicken, fried noodle and honey pork. All just ordinary nothing special. Service was okay too. The dessert all western nothing Chinese.
author: Suria N.

description: After everything we'd heard, I have to say this was a bit of a letdown.  Food was ok but far from outstanding.  The juicy pork dumplings were beautifully presented, but the lowly Ark in Alameda has much tastier ones, by far.  These were rather insipid.  Same problem with the Moo Shu tacos.  The crispy rockfish was good, but swimming in grease to the point of being a turn-off, and covered in what was basically barbecue sauce, very one-dimensional and no subtlety.  Perhaps the best item we tasted was the baby bok choy.  We won't be going back; it's too easy to get that quality, at a much better value, all over the Bay Area.
author: Clemencia C.

description:
There is a school of thought that owners should try to "manage" negative reviews on Yelp with a show of solicitousness and concern.  Management at M.Y. China tried to do just that by publicly paying lip service to the possibility my wife and I were served a bad meal, and asking me to email more details.  I have pasted my entire email below.  I never heard a single word in acknowledgment or response.  This suggests that management cares less about the experiences of its customers than it does for creating a public perception that it cares.  

Not my kind of folk.

  * * *

Dear Carol,

Thank you for your kind note - I appreciate your reaching out.

I asked our server to take the rice off our tab, and he cheerfully did so.  We did not complain about the dishes, but left large portions of two uneaten.  It is conceivable you have other patrons who would enjoy pork dishes as sugary as those we were served, but I would be quite surprised if there is anyone who would enjoy that soup.  My wife is partial to hot & sour soup and we have had it in dozens of restaurants in CA, and she remarked that it is the very worst she has ever had.  I'm hoping this was a qc problem -we'd be quite surprised if it came to us as the chef intended.

Best regards,

Charles R.
author: Charles R.

description:
We have visited the Westfield location in downtown SF a number if times now & on the whole have found it to be very good. The standout dishes we love are:

-Wild boat scissor cut noodles
-Seven spice pork ribs (kind of like a light flash-fry...so unique)
-Kung pao chicken &
-Sichuan green beans

The service however has always been spotty...& each visit we notice it's not just our table looking around trying to find a server & get their attention...which is pretty frustrating. We always request some chilli oil as some of the dishes need an extra 'kick'.

A great restaurant with a nice ambiance located in a shopping mall.
author: Nicole E.

description: Delicious from start to finish. Loved the pickled veggies, wheat potstickers and the scissors cut noodles were fresh and tasty. The pork ribs were dry but still very tasty.
author: Rosaly F.

description:
We are visiting from L.A.
We are so happy to have tried the dim sum. 

We were so happy with the spicy seafood dumplings. 

We had such great charismatic service from the manager Daniel. He sat us so politely and cordially. 

Thank you for setting such a great service culture. Cindy was a great server. She was poised and so attentive. 

Will come again, when there is another raider game.
author: Oscar M.

description: I can't help but think how Trump via Alex Baldwin would pronounce this restaurant name and it makes me laugh. They were very gracious to get us in last minute for Christmas eve reservations and the service was great. We had the calamariwhich was excellent but very small portion. A couple of other rarely traditional dishes but one thing to remember they're definitely smaller than traditional Chinese fare. Great alternative to mall food.
author: Misselayneous M.

description:
Nice restaurant in Westfield Mall.....average food except the "eggplant & tofu claypot"......that is amazing!!!
Also had the salt and pepper calamari, string beans, and noodles with wild boar. Not noteworthy.
Between 3 & 4 stars.
author: Sharine d.

description:
Thoroughly enjoy the delicious food at MY CHINA!!
I have only one complaint.  I do not like your UNISEX restrooms.
author: Elaine T.

description:
Touristy, but excellent food & nice atmosphere...

Had a friend in from out of town so we paired a visit to the Asian Art a museum with lunch at M.Y. China.

First of all, it's in a mall... A large, crowded, shiny, sticky, perfumed-riddled mall. M.Y. China is on a higher floor through the Nordstroms ( based on the entrance on Market). Happily, it does feel separated from mall craziness once you are inside. 

This is a fun- guest from out of town, it's your birthday lunch- type of place. You walk past the open kitchen (pretty warm spot) where you can sit & watch the spectacle of noodle making. We decided to sit in one of the dining areas where a dark toned, fairly sophisticated dining room awaited us. Has a corporate restaurant feel, a little tight on the two seater benches. 

Service was professional, but not flawless. We did have a lull at one point and we were looking around. 

Food was lovely. Noodles and tofu are stand outs here! We ordered the pork tacos (a take on pork mushu) which was a tasty beginning. Then the long life vegetarian noodle soup, the garlic pea shoots, and the dim sum dumplings. All were delish!

Dishes for us averaged about $16 each. Easy to spend $60+ for two people for lunch. 

Will definitely go again!!
author: Suzanne D.

description:
Stumbled upon this place on a trip to San Francisco. And wow. It's really good! 

The food was awesome, like super good. Not the super traditional Chinese food. But it's so good! 

We ordered quite a bit of food. And it all came out in courses which was nice! 

It's also quite pricey, about 120$ for two.
author: Sean H.

description:
For this Father's Day i kindly let my missus off the hook and booked this place myself.

Had seen it on Check please, a Bay Area TV show where people showcase their favorite restaurants. I knew nothing about it or the chef until it aired. Even though I'd vaguely seen something about the chef, I had no idea he was a James Beard award winner. 

As an Asian themed Father's Day this was the prelude to a viewing of "28 artists" at the Asian art museum. ( eat the food, see the art, drive the car)

The best way to get to the restaurant is through the Nordstrom entrance. They apparently give partial validation at Nordstrom but the lady on the line couldn't confirm the amount. Nice if they would actually know when calling.....

You can either take the uniquely angled escalators or a lift that bypasses all the levels to the 4th floor.

Once there we were seated at a circular table on the outskirts of the restaurant with an excellent view of the restaurant and of the passing trade.

We could see the noodle maker plying his trade but alas none of the sexy noodle action I'd seen on the TV.

Bathroom surprisingly small and unisex for this large restaurant. Maybe there was another but I could not see it.

The waitress was an pleasant lady with an exceptional memory. No writing down of orders even though she must have been serving 10 tables.

Drinks came quickly with a good selection offered by the glass.

Food came shortly after, attractively presented. 

Amongst 4 of us we ordered( and I'll probably get a couple of these wrong)

Bang bang Chicken wings 9/10
5 spice pork ribs. 10/10
Hand pulled beef, book chop noodle soup ( with all the book chop left by my son, but the rest enjoyed thoroughly )
Walnut chicken(8/10)
Peking duck with the skin beautifully separated and bao buns as soft as a baby's bottom (10/10) extra buns available for 50c each.
Spicy calamari (9/10)

Really fresh ingredients, fresh oil, great service, and a La Boulanger next door for coffee afterward ( though alas not for much longer ....)

Well worth the visit to this slick, well run restaurant in this surprisingly attractive venue.
author: Pantera W.

description: Top of the line Chinese Food in a modern pleasant setting . Friendly staff, amazing cocktails. Our group of 7 last night thoroughly enjoyed it . Sorry about Duffy .
author: Dan M.

description:
It's great to know that a decent Chinese restaurant can be found in a mall near my work! I got the soup dumplings and wonton soup recently and both were very good. The dumplings were bigger than I expected, too... Only thing is, they came in a spoon atop pickles. This is the first time I ever had juicy pork dumplings with pickles, and I think it's unnecessary. I don't particularly like the flavor it added so I ended up taking it out.
Otherwise, I really enjoyed my small meal for lunch on a cold day in SF.
author: Mariecar M.

description:
Most unfortunately, for the first time, I got bored with my all time favorite honey walnut shrimp, both with and without wasabi. I didn't finish it at all.

The entree was served on a long dish but only halfway. There were cucumber chunks that didn't blend well with the shrimp. Yes, it was not over-breaded or over-mayoed like others, but the honey walnut didn't make a difference. Instead was covered with sesame seeds a plenty.  

Service was okay. Convenient location. Has good ambiance. Note, on the pricier side with tea, soup, salad or appetizer, approximately $50 pp for dinner. 

It's my first visit. Authentic Chinese cuisine is only few blocks away. I just thought this place was gonna be better than PF Changs.
author: Romella J.

description: This place was good. Came here for drinks and bar eats. Dimsum sampler was yummy.  Soup dumplings were delicious but the wild boar noodles was the best! I even ordered one to go! Very crowded at lunch time but of course it's the holidays and it's inside the mall.
author: Emma G.

description:
I went here with my parents who are visiting from NY. They, like me, like Chinese food, and fusion as well. Given the 3.5 stars on Yelp, I was expecting decent, but not super great. But it was super great. Some of the best fusion Chinese I've had, ever.

We got "Chairman Mao's Chicken" which is a lighter, but just as spicy version of "General Tso's chicken." It was delightful, with great sauces, and very nicely spiced and flavored. We got the "Seven Spice Ribs" (I think it was called that) and they were tender, and crunchy in a great way, and really, fabulous. We got string beans - also nicely spicy and flavorful.

It's not the cheapest, but it was totally worth the price - the food was fabulous, and there was enough for 3 (2 entrees, one side dish, and 2 rice orders.) My parents, who go out to eat a lot in NY raved about it. The service was attentive in just the right measure.

I'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Maxwell P.

description:
First place I stopped by when I arrived in San Francisco. Definitely try their Mu Shu Pork Tacos. Incredible! Their cocktails are fantastic and their staff is very friendly, although the bartender was kind of pushy. If you have time, check out their decor. Much of the art is imported from Beijing! Andy Correa (the manager) was a great tour guide. (A)

Spanish:
Este fue el primer lugar donde comí cuando llegue (esta vez) a San Francisco. Recomiendo que prueben los tacos de Mu Shu Pork. Son deliciosos! Si tienen la oportunidad, admiren la decoración. Muchas piezas fueron importadas de la China y son muy bellas. Andy Correa (el gerente) me dio una gira rapida y es muy amable. (A)
author: Valentino C.

description:
Would never return to this place again. If I could give this place zero stars I would. I would recommend to steer clear from this place. Save yourself from being ripped off by tasteless, way overpriced food and awful service.

My aunt came from Sacramento to visit and she really wanted to try Martin Yan's resturant. We came here on a Sunday night with a big group. The service was so slow. After being seated it took our waiter forever to come back and take our order. We ran out of water and had to flag someone else down to get them to bring us more. If I were the one that had to pay for this bill, I would not have even tipped him. It's really frustrating when you have a slower waiter, that just doesn't seem to care.

I asked him for a recommendation when ordering and he just pointed to one thing - the crab, which didn't have a price but was probably the most expensive item on the menu. I wasn't in the mood for crab and he didn't continue. I had to ask.. so what else is good?? 

I ended up ordering the duck. It was SO dry. Worst duck I've ever eaten in my life, and I have eaten a good amount of duck. I wanted to send it back, but the rest of my family just wanted to get out of there.

We also tried the dimsum, it was ok. Lots of places to go where you can get more delicious dim sum for cheaper.

The beef hand pulled noodles... was awful. Soup was too salty. Nothing impressive about it.

For everyone who gave this place a 5 star rating... have you ever tried legit chinese food before? Other than at Panda Express or P.F. Changs??

We had our cars valet and was unsure if we needed to get our parking validated. We had to ask two different people working here if we needed a stamp for our parking validation. Their answers- "Um I dont know..." Clueless.

My conclusion for this place... Place is a total sham. They have nice decor, high prices to match, and Martin Yans name on it. They also put on a show for you, probably to distract you from realizing your server has been gone for awhile and your food tastes so bad. This place charges A+ prices but serves D- quality food.

Two words: RIP OFF
author: Jessica S.

description:
I am not a fan of Chinese food.  At all.  I find it usually way too sweet.  I know the sweet stuff is usually American/Chinese food but I made it a rule not to eat Chinese if I can help it.  Today I gave in and I'm so glad I did!  Wow.  It was good!!!

We started with Potstickers which were really, really good!!  We moved on to a beef and chicken dish with white rice and the spicy green beans.  It was all delicious!

Service was excellent.  Our server was attentive and made some great suggestions!  My ONLY complaint was how close together the tables were.  The restaurant is loud to begin with but sticking the tables so close together makes having a conversation a challenge.

i would go back but ask not to be seated in an area packed in.
author: Jen C.

description:
I like this place, okay? I usually stray away from bigger fusion-like, places like this and P.F. Chang's. BUT, M.Y. China is pretty darn good and everything always tastes fresh. I do recommend making reservations ahead of time, even only a couple of hours before. Be assured that if you show up for dinner time without any, you will wait. 

Their baby chrysanthemum tea is delicious, as is their blossom..but the previous is the winner between the two. 

Their calamari is tasty, not too salty or breaded. It is a pretty small portion, however.  The crispy tofu is yummy as well and has a bit of a spicy kick to it. These two are some of my favorite appetizers, although their won ton soup doesn't stay behind. 

I've had the squid ink noodles and their wild boar hand cut noodles. Both are delicious, chewy, and quipped with the right amount of meat and veggies. I would toggle between both but the wild boar noodles are just so fun!

The rockfish was recommended by one of their waiters the first time I went here and I never did look back. It is probably one of their most awesome dishes, but it is about $30. It's a halibut, I believe, with a crispy/friend skin and doused in their sweet and sour sauce served along a rainbow of peppers. The meat is tender and falls right off the bones. 

Chairman Mao chicken is good, but nothing spectacular. It's a pretty simple dish with plenty of spices, though certainly not the best chicken I've had. Probably try something else next time.

Honey Walnut Shrimp is more like wasabi glazed shrimp. When they mention wasabi in tiny print, they're not kidding! Do not expect the typical sweet kind. My family was not too fond of these, but I weirdly liked them... just know they're not going to taste like the usual ones. If you take a bite with the walnut and cucumber at the same time, you kinda get a feel for what the chef wants you taste. MIGHT get them again. 

I think this is a good place to go with family. Probably not for the high-ho foodies out there, but it's one of my guilty pleasures at the Westfield Centre... and probably one of the better dome restaurant collections.
author: Josselin A.

description:
Expensive.

Inauthentic.

And absolutely delicious.

I was primed to hate this place.  It's in the mall.  It's several times more expensive than the City's numerous legit dim sum places.  It's a celebrity chef driven spectacle.  It's in the mall.

But my taste buds don't lie.  Every dish was a winner.  I was in a party of 8 and we over-ordered with no regrets.  The lobster scallion claypot was the most memorable dish but really, they were all tasty, from the dumplings to the noodles.

M.Y. China's no Koi Palace, but it ain't P.F. Chang's either.  It's about a 5 out of 10 on the authenticity scale.  If that's going to be a dealbreaker for you (you know who you are), then by all means, do not eat here.  If flavor is more important to you than exact replicas of traditional Chinese cuisine, this may be worth a visit next time you're at the Westfield.
author: Olivia W.

description:
They say you learn something new everyday- today I learned who Martin Yan is. I never really watched cooking shows growing up (I was a Cartoon Network and Nickelodeon) guy so I was never exposed to his existence. Found out who he was when a friend who got here earlier than the rest of us let us know Martin was in the house. Have to say- I'm quite the fan now! 

Not only was the food pretty good but he and his chefs can put on quite a performance. The kitchen is open for all to see and occasionally you'll see the chefs handmaking noodles. For those that don't know, it involves the chef basically taking a load of dough and just slapping it around and pulling it into lots and lots (possibly thousands?) of individual noodle pieces. This was the first time I've seen chefs performing this in America. I've always enjoyed watching them do it in China and I was just as amused and impressed here at M.Y. China. 

You won't get an authentic Chinese experience here so I probably wouldn't bring my parents but it's a great spot to grab a fancy dinner with friends. They've got a list of unique and not-so-unique cocktails - like mai tai's - which help spicen up the evening. Get the drinks flowing, whet your appetite with some soup dumplings, and order up some more dishes (don't forget the noodles!) and you're in for a fun and delicious evening.
author: Philip W.

description:
My fiance and I happened upon this restaurant inside of an indoor mall while shopping in downtown San Francisco.

A very nice menu and great decor.  My fiance is originally from mainland China, and he also thought that it was tasty and authentic.  

We had the Kung Pao chicken, Wok-seared beef filet and steamed rice (with both dishes).  The food was good, but we found a small worm in the side salad.  Eek.  Needless to say, we were comped for that entree.

Good selection of drinks and cocktails.  

Nice service--but too many customers for the limited number of staff that were working.
author: Terry F.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with my meal at M.Y. China! As a Chinese person who typically eats authentic Chinese food, I didn't have high expectations for Martin Yan's restaurant.  However, because it IS Martin Yan's restaurant, I had to give it a try.

A lot of items off of their menu jumped out at me, including their 2 prix fixe menu's for 2, dumplings, Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup, and Lamb Chops.  But we decided to go with the Juicy Dumpling Trio, Wild Board Scissor Cut Noodles, and Dan Dan Noodle.

I would have to say, if there are items on a menu that are highlighted on the restaurant's Yelp listing, you really can't go wrong with them! While it was nice to try all three flavors of dumplings, call me traditional, but I really enjoyed the wild boar, and pork and crab. But props to the restaurant for serving the dumplings on soup spoons.  This way, you'll never lose the juices! I also really liked the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, which was one of the top highlighted items on the Yelp listing.  Overall, the dish was just very tasty, well seasoned, and it had a good mix of textures between the thick pieces of noodle, meat and vegetables. While I generally like Dan Dan Noodles, I wasn't particularly fond of the flavoring of this. It wasn't bad, but it was just more vinegar based than I had anticipated.

All in all, it's over priced for what it is, but heck, you're inside the Westfield SF Centre, what would you expect? And..Yan CAN Cook!

What would have made my day? A sighting of Martin Yan, but alas, that didn't happen. Maybe next time...
author: Audrey C.

description:
I went upstairs for coffee at La Boulange, but realized I was becoming hangry, which no amount of croissants and soup would ever satisfy.  Before the hunger kraken got released, my husband suggested M.Y.China for dinner.  There was no wait at the noodle bar, where we could watch the hand made noodle action.  

The M.Y. Dim Sum Chef's Choice of 8 dumplings was OK- not bad, just a touch greasy.  If you are not a pork fan, pick something else.   

The Hong Kong crispy noodle with chicken + XO sauce was good.  Mix it around the sauce if you want to soften up the fried noodles.  It was really good as leftovers when I added Trader Joe's garlic linguine noodles (reminded me of lo mein in the East Coast).  Sorry if that offends the chef, but just sayin'! 

To the left of me were a tourist couple who barely spoke to each other and were paying more attention to their Tsingtao beer.  

To the right of me were 2 tweens in trench coats and Kate Spade bags, gossiping about mutual friends and evaluating them on their life choices and boyfriends' jobs while slurping deliciously on noodles and truly enjoying their cocktails.  Good food tastes better with judgmental gossip.  Ahhh, reminds me of post college years.
author: Miran C.

description: Tasty dinner here. We only tried vegetarian type foods. Hand pull noodle soup with tofu, pepper snapper tofu, stir fried green beans, and green tea creme brulee. Excellent flavor on the entrees. Soup was a little salty. Restaurant was clean and bright located in 4th floor Westfield Mall San Francisco. Easier if you took BART instead of trying for the public parking lot on 4th/Mission. Items were a bit pricey, but this is a shoppers / tourist location. For two persons about $85 which includes SF mandate 4%, tax 9%, gratuity 18%. Not bad for roughly $30/person, no wine.
author: Clifford W.

description:
2 hour gaps between classes means checking out all of the happy hours in the area! Second on my list is M.Y. China.

Interior is clean and very pretty.  In the middle of the bar, there is a bell hanging over a circle of bottles, making for an eye-catching centerpiece.  We opted to sit inside, but there was plenty of space for happy hour patrons both inside as well as outside. 

Between the 4 of us, we had 6 of their Happy Hour food items.

-The BBQ pork buns were way underseasoned and bland. It was missing the sweetness that is characteristic of the buns.
-Flavoring on the chicken wings more than made up for the blandness of the buns. Nice and juicy and covered in saucy-sauce.
-The chicken feet were decent, not as flavorful as they could be but decent.
-Although you would never see whole-wheat potstickers at a dimsum restaurant, they were surprisingly really tasty, nice and crispy on the outside, just the way I like it.
-Har gow was also delicious, though there was only three :c
-Their version of Xiao Long Bao was ok as well, sauce was meh.

After all of that, we decided that we were still hungry. My friend REALLY loves the buns that come with the peking duck, so we ordered half of a duck. Duck was juicy, skin was crispy, what more could you ask for? It actually came with cucumber sticks, which is not traditional, but it was different; not bad.
author: Monica V.

description:
I take my son here as a gift several times a year.
He loves loves lovws there wild boar dumpling soup. He is very picky.I'm not a picky eater but he says next to my boyfriends chicken soup with the feet this soup is the Bomb. 
For a 12 year old that says it all.
I can't afford to eat here often but it is always a treat to come sit out and enjoy a chinese yumi salad glass of lucky budah beer and watch my Beautiful Boy Smile as he slurps that soup.
Thanks my China
author: Connie B.

description:
If you've come here expecting your neighborhood Chinese joint, think again.  Although a few favorites might be on the menu, most of it will have you wanting more.

The food was good but it lacked it's soul intent - to sell to the masses within the mall.  Although it ads a bit of "class" to the upscale side of the Westfield it's lack of patronage is evident. 

Tip: Check out the wheat potstickers. You'll never know.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Sitting in this place, you kind of forget you're in the Westfield Mall. When I think of mall food, i think of food court, and when I think of food court, I think of Panda Express (Don't ask why, I just do)

At first, this place seemed a little disorganized. They take reservations, but they won't take your name for walk-ins, they just have you stand to the side and they'll get you when there's an open table. I didn't find it efficient, but it seems to work for them.

Interior of this place is nice, dark walls,  dark floors, dim lighting, a very modern rustic feel to it, and oddly, I found their bathrooms to be beautiful. 

Enough about the restaurant itself, let's get to the food. 

Between the four of us, we shared the House made Pickles trio (sour daikon, sweet squash, spicy papaya), Salt & Pepper Calamari w/ chili peppers, scallions, and the Hong Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken XO and house made X.O. sauce. Everything was delicious, my only critique for the food was the Crispy Noodles seemed to lack something, a spice of sorts, or maybe a little bit of hot spice, the calamari was good, but i would've preferred more rings to tentacles, but despite this, it was all delicious!

BUT WAIT........ our favorite part of the meal was dessert. Went with the Sugar Egg Puffs w/ chocolate fondue, vanilla bean chantilly cream and raspberry coulis. I'll be honest, when I think of sugar egg puffs, I think of the little puffs you get at Genki. Not the case here! these suckers were huge! Wish I had taken a photo, but they were gone before I even got a chance. 

All in all, great little place if you're on a date, or just want a quick bite before a movie, or mid shopping lunch, a little pricey, but then again, its in a mall.
author: Laurens D.

description:
Love. I'm Chinese myself, so I am extremely opinionated about Chinese food.  This is definitely not mall food.  The quality and flavor is pretty authentic.  Everyone that I take with me agrees.  I noticed that all their chefs are Chinese and not Mexicans, which confirms the authenticity.  Their Bok Choy is a perfect example of a simple well cooked chinese dish: crunchy and has so much flavor after each bite.  Veggies aren't hard to cook, but most Americanized chinese food restaurants will overcook it and make it all mushy.  My favorite dish on the menu is the Seafood Squid Ink Noodle ($18).  Bomb. 

The bartenders are the reason why I am always there.  They always make me happy with excellent service and their drinks are just so creative.   I suggest always sitting at the bar if your party consists of max 2 people.
author: Savinie L.

description:
This place was such an unexpected treat.  We read about this place in the SF Chronicle for places close to Union Square.  We were so happy to try it because it was excellent food, and the setting was very nice for Christmas too.  It's located in the Westfield mall on the fourth floor under the giant dome.  They were even projecting Nutcracker on the inside of the dome and playing the music from Nutcracker too.  So, a pleasant atmosphere for a dinner.  

We didn't have reservations on a Saturday night and expected to wait, but my wife and I were seated within two minutes of arriving at about 7:00.  They were busy but the hostesses were very gracious and accommodated us without problems.  

Our waitress was friendly and informative.   She confirmed our choices were good and offered some great opinions as well.  

The food was great.  My wife and i are not big eaters so planned on sharing a few items and we started with scissor cut noodles with wild boar and veggies.  This was pretty spicy which I don't mind, but my wife is more sensitive and it was a little much for her taste.  Despite that we loved this dish, and ate it all.   We ordered fried rice because I always like some rice with Asian food, and they brought this dish out next.  It ended up being the highlight of a really good meal.  I can't say enough about how good the fried rice is.   Balanced flavors and it complemented our last dish so well too.  Our last dish was General's chicken, which was again quite spicy, but I like that....my wife not as much, but again, it was so good that it didn't bother her that much and we just ordered up another beer to cool the heat...

Overall, we loved our meal.  It might be considered pricey by some, but to me I would gladly pay the extra to have this wonderful food again. We will return next time we are in SF.
author: Paul B.

description: We came there by accident, but it happened to be very lucky one.  We absolutely loved the food, Esp dumplings. The place look really nice, the waiter was really  friendly.  I loved sweet and sour pork a lot. Thank you. Will be back for sure.
author: Oxana B.

description: This is our go-to Chinese. A fave for dim-sum brunch on the weekend or a quick pre-movie dinner.  The duck there is so good as are the hand cut noodles. Lots of special treats in a clean and convenient environment.
author: Farah M.

description: Love this spot. Highly recommend the King Paco Chicken. Clean and fresh Chinese food. I think some of the best in the city. Of course, it doesn't come cheap. Oh, and if you can come over the holidays, sit "outside" to watch The Nutcracker on the dome of the Westfield mall.
author: Avand A.

description:
First and foremost, let me establish that the food is pretty good. Is it wholly authentic Chinese cuisine? Well, no. Is it Chinese fusion? Yes. Is it delicious? Also yes.

I came here several weeks ago and never remembered to write a review, so allow me to make up for that. I don't remember all of what I ordered though, so bear with me. The SQUID INK NOODLES, are DELICIOUS. Maybe it's expected of me to enjoy this dish the most, because I like squid-inked anything. But I enjoyed the texture of the little noodles, and the seafood was mostly fresh. The shrimp was a little sad, but you can't win at everything. 

I believe that we also ordered the Honey Glazed Pork , or something along those lines? Pretty good; flavorful and sweet. Tender for the most part, but the leftovers get chewy the next day, as leftovers do. 

So I obviously don't have a problem with the food. The service was a little subpar; I may be a imagining things, but the waitress that served us seemed to lack a little in respect, especially when compared to the attitude she had when serving another table. Maybe she knew them or something, giving her the benefit of the doubt. But if you asked me, she didn't seem to like us very much, so we went out of our way to not ask anything of her.
author: Natalie F.

description: Sorry to give only 2 stars. I was disappointed with the food and service today. I have not been there for a while, and even though the food has improved since opening, the presentation is less than desirable and food was oily when we requested less oil. The soup dumplings came out in spoons placed haphazardly in the steamer, and my dumpling was actually upside down! Hello... You are supposed to pick it up from the top curly cue!  When we ordered the dim sum, the waitress did not even remind us there are only 3 in each order and since we were 5 people would we want to order 2, little things like that bugged me. There was also no difference in taste between the Shanghai fried rice cakes and the ink noodles. They used the same condiments to flavor and cook. I could definitely get a better meal elsewhere.  So sad.
author: Darlene B.

description: Food was good, but small portions and very over priced for good Chinese food.  Chinese food can't be upscaled, I guess your paying the ambiance.  Restaurants in San Francisco can't or don't know how do food pricing to included employee's salaries.  They need to have the city add a tax for that.
author: A M.

description:
Got the venison chow fun and beijing knife cut noodle. Venison was very tasty. The beijing noodle was good but portion was a bit small and not much meat or meaty taste. Had the real beijing knife cut noodles in Beijing before and I am not reay impressed with this noodle here. The chow fun was kinda plain despite the tasty venison. Bonus point for venison but minus 1 star for the beijing noodle.

Service was kinda slow. Waited almost 10min for our cocktail, 10min for the beijing noodle and 20min for the chow fun. The waiter did check with us once in a while though. Minus 1 star for the service.
author: Aki J.

description:
Unclear to me why this is not rated well on Yelp. Food was fantastic, decor is awesome (unless you're outside in the mall, which is admittedly weird).

Noodle dishes were SO good. Really thick, chewy noodles in the squid ink noodles and wild boar scissor cut noodles. If we come back we'll definitely get both again.

Sweet & sour pork, peppercorn filet, spicy seafood dumplings were all just so flavorful, without being overly greasy. Loved all of these.

The two so-so dishes we got were the five-spice ribs (fried...which made them feel just a bit too greasy/heavy and not actually that tasty) and mushu boar appetizer, which was served on a flour tortilla and had too much cabbage and not enough boar or flavor.

Kind of wish it wasn't in a mall, but overall, great food and atmosphere (inside).
author: Adam W.

description: This place has the best dim sum + hong kong noodles + the tacos which is on the happy hour menu but could be on the appetizer menu (not sure). YUM. Love this right beneath the dome at west field. Staff are proficient and funny. Good energy
author: Heba A.

description: I'd give this restaurant 2.5 stars if possible. It was far from "A-OK", so don't feel good about a 3 star rating. Wait staff were all very nice; but fairly disorganized. We were served food we didn't order. Drinks on a couple of occasions took a while to arrive. Overall the food was unimpressive including the recommended noodle dish. The dim sum was quite generic. The clay pot crab was seasoned nicely but not worth the work. Oh, and only 3 gender neutral stalls in the bathroom are not adequate for a room that size. I might go back to give it a second chance...maybe.
author: j d.

description: Not great. We chose this restaurant for proximity to hotel - bad idea. With Chinatown so close, we messed up. It's not bad, it's just boring and uninteresting. No complex sauces, pork overcooked; I've had far better.  Don't waste your time here, go to Chinatown!
author: Kristin W.

description: Best hot and sour soup I have ever had. If you like spicy then you will love it. Most hot and sour soups are that brown color and bland.. but this, this truly is an explosion in your mouth. The spicy and sweet chicken was good. The service was ok. The wild boar dish was tasty. All and all a great meal.
author: Allie P.

description: I've been here three times for large group dinners with clients and it is a great location and space. Food is good and service is friendly. Walnut shrimp is great.
author: Jane Z.

description:
SERVICE: 
Bad service.  I'm from the south and we hardly ever wait for the wait staff to come by and offer assistance . In some places it's almost too much. If you are a person who likes to sit there alone and not get waited on, then great. If not, then avoid this place. 
FOOD:
Juicy pork dim sum was good. Bok choy was ok. But I'm not a big fan of dish where ever I go. Bang bang chicken was good. 
AMBIANCE:
It's in a mall under a dome. I don't know what was worse. The service or the teenagers in the common area raising hell...argh.
author: Daniel C.

description: Food of small quantity and little taste. Environment ok but not served well. Anyway if you have an authentic Chinese tongue, better not co
author: 雯婧

description:
Loved the food especially the egg puff desert. Awesome.

Only wish they had more panfried noodle dishes AND the same noodles available as a side.
author: Anthony P.

description: This was not my first visit to the restaurant.  Ive been to China a number of times and have tasted the local cuisine so I know what's what.  Normally I love their dim sum, noodles and duck but this time some of the dim sum were not up to par.  The Peking Duck with buns was excellent but the Siu Mai was dense and hard.   I didn't care for the chicken wings either. he service, as always, was great.
author: David S.

description: It is in the Westfield San Francisco Central Mall. A friend highly recommended the restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. We ordered Da Dao "big knife" fish noodles, Sichuan Green beans, wok(beef, tofu and eggplant). Really delicious. You should have a try.
author: Nancy S.

description: We have eaten at MY China many times.  The Peking duck is fabulous with luscious skin.  The soup dumplings are very flavorful and the walnut shrimp has an unexpected heat.  The service was very attentive.  We really enjoy eating here when we go to the Golden Gate theater, since there are not very many eating establishments nearby.
author: Joyce K.

description:
I wasn't totally sure what to expect. Martin Yan is a bit of an icon, but I was worried this would be bad food in a mall.

Well, good news! It's really good food in a fun atmosphere and you can watch the master chef make noodles by hand which is pretty incredible. The peking duck was very good as were the beef noodles as you would expect. Dishes were good too, it's a little pricey, but a fun place to go.
author: David L.

description:
I love this Restarant because it is very clean, nice, has open kitchen..... And Happy Hours!!!
The bartender andrea and food runner veronica were very very nice. I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone.
author: Yelena T.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by M.Y. China! Being located in the Westfield Mall, I expected food quality to be average. A friend and I stopped in for a shopping break and some sustenance. We ordered the twin scallops fried rice as well as salt & pepper calamari...yum and YUM!! the calamari was some of the best I've ever had. I saw other lots of other tasty dishes being delivered to other diners' tables and vowed to come back and try more.

As a bonus, you can see the cooks preparing your meal behind a glass food preparation area. There's one guy who hand rolls and cuts noodles like a ninja. Seriously, I don't know how he manages to do it so effortlessly and quickly. I couldn't stop watching him make noodles. File for future tricks to learn.
author: Michelle E.

description:
Wandered in with my boyfriend for a late weekday lunch while Christmas shopping and found that the poor service took away from what could have been a good meal. 

After being seated immediately, we waited ten minutes before flagging down a server to take our order. While he brought our food within a reasonable amount of time, he was otherwise inattentive and didn't stop back to check on us during our meal. Once we'd managed to get the bill, we again waited several minutes before I flagged down a different server to run our credit card. Overall I got the sense that the waitstaff was either poorly trained or simply unprofessional. 

The food itself was good though generally not exceptional, especially for the price. The crispy tofu small plate was delicious (and won approval from a dedicated carnivore) and the lamb wok and pan seared mixed veggies were fine but didn't pack a great deal of spice or flavor. We tried the lychee panna cotta for dessert and couldn't figure out why it was topped with something frozen (a half-melted sorbet, perhaps?).
author: Amy P.

description:
The Boyfriend & I were catching a movie after work & we had some time for dinner beforehand.

We started with the Pork & crab roe juicy dumplings. The serving in individual spoons was a very nice presentation but it wasn't very practical since the dumplings were stuck on them. The actual dumpling was too sweet & I couldn't find any crab roe. We got the Honey glazed BBQ pork which was very tender but it was way too sweet. We also shared the Beef hand-pulled noodle soup. The noodles had great texture, the brisket was tender, but the broth was, again, way too sweet. My favorite item from the night was the Mint jasmine collins; it was so good I think I am going to try & replicate it at home.

The service was quick & friendly. One final note, the bathroom set-up is a little funky. There is one big open "room" with sinks with 3 smaller unisex bathrooms. It's really not all that weird but it surprised me a little bit when I opened the door & saw a man standing there.
author: Karen S.

description:
Great to come with a group of people, friends or family. 

Most importantly, share. Order a bunch of appetizers, some duck, some rolls, and share. These entrees are made to share, and the experience is much better.
author: Antonio B.

description:
One of my coworker constantly talks about eating here at lunch all the time and after million attempts ending with a failure, I was finally able to try this place.  

Ordered the pork belly sliders, wild board dumplings, and the wild boar scissor cut noodles.

My faves were definitely the pork belly sliders and the dumplings.  The noodles were an interesting shape but it wasn't too fantastic.  I think next time I come here, I'll probably just order the small bites because those seem to pack more taste to them.  

oh dear lawd. the pork belly sliders were just amazing.  The flavor was on point and I love that they use white steam buns. So yummy! The dumplings were like shao long bao which I love.  There's fluid on the inside so be careful when you take a bite because it's hot! 

The reason why the took two stars is because it took FOREVER to get someone's attention to give the orders.  I went during my lunch time at work and I only have an hour so I can't wait forever to get someone's attention.  But the waiter who help us was nice.  He only took our orders and when these other girls sat down, he asked them about what they wanted to drink, what the specials were and I'm just like, dude.  Why didn't we get that treatment? 

Whatever.  hopefully next time we come back, the service won't be as half-assed.
author: Lisa L.

description: Reading the positive reviews of this dump confirms once again that most people don't know the first thing about quality. Anyone who has been around will know instantly that this place is low class and poorly run. Before you rely on any writing about this or any place, check the reviewers' backgrounds if they have posted them.The bar did not have the normal standard brands and got our simple order wrong. The food, which was not hot when served, is mediocre and the portions are small. The service by obviously untrained personnel was bad. The dishes were served out of order and "thrown" at our table of four. The dining room was filled with a back-packing tour group in tee-shirts. The unisex bathroom was filthy. The noise level was punishing and aggravated by a banging live band in the mall. This restaurant is entirely open to the noisy mall. You can get good Chinese food all over San Francisco in much nicer environments and with considerably better value. If you are a back-packing, tee-shirt wearing tourist who is impressed with celebrity chefs but cares little for quality and likes being led to a trough by incompetents while being skinned with high prices and getting your ears slammed, this is the place for you!
author: E Dennis B.

description: The service was great, the food however was only ok. We ordered the Kung pao chicken and it was salty. The spicey seafood dumplings weren't steaming hot like most dumplings should be. My daughter actually complained about white rice, said it was rough. The atmosphere and decor of the restaurant was good but felt the food was overpriced compared to the taste of the food.
author: Tina T.

description:
I came here with my parents and some friends for an impromptu dinner and got seated really fast. We had a bit of a time crunch since we were trying to make it to the Warriors game but the server was really understanding and actually rushed our order of Peking Duck. The dishes aren't super traditional but not quite as Americanized as PF Changs to me. We got:

Spring rolls: crunchy and flavorful. 

Shumai: very fresh and came in clever little silver spoon-like things. 

Peking duck: pretty standard Peking duck, even compared to ones at a traditional Chinese restaurant. They definitely don't jip you on the meat or buns.  

Beijing noodles: My favorite dish of the night, by far! The noodles are freshly made by hand (you can actually see the chef pulling them apart in the kitchen) and the sauce was amazing. 

Kungpao Tofu (we had a vegetarian with us): Not bad but not super memorable. 

All in all, it was a good meal and I would come here again when I'm in Westfield mall. Probably wouldn't make a separate trip out to it. 

Oh and the bathroom is unisex. Just a heads up since I definitely thought I walked into the wrong bathroom!
author: Lina H.

description:
After hearing a friend rave about this place and repeatedly attempting to dine here but failing due to the restaurant either being booked or hour-long waits, I was pleasantly surprised when we, on a whim, decided to stop by and were seated at a table within 5 minutes of arriving around dinnertime! The interior is very sleek and the ornate lanterns hanging from the ceiling were especially impressive. You can even see the chefs hand-pull noodles in the open kitchen and one of them even walked around performing in front of us!

What we ordered:
- Crispy veggie spring rolls ($6): toasted taro, wild seasonal mushrooms http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2?select=ZWSY8eRcF_LRJls_iqgFpA#ZWSY8eRcF_LRJls_iqgFpA
- Vegetarian longevity noodle soup ($12): wild seasonal mushrooms, braised tofu, Sichuan pickled vegetables http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2?select=ZWSY8eRcF_LRJls_iqgFpA#mNctyYFc2JbVW5M6ctlwFg
- Squid ink snap noodles with seafood ($18): shrimp, scallops, calamari, Shaoxing wine http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2?select=ZWSY8eRcF_LRJls_iqgFpA#YkvIGmI1-WjdauECURYGtg

There is complimentary still or sparkling water and of course, I opted for sparkling. While the number of vegetarian main dishes is limited, the waitress informed me that some of the noodles could be made vegetarian with tofu instead (I will try this next time!). We started with the spring rolls which were perfectly crispy and delicious! They also came with a red dipping sauce which was nice. 

I don't order veggie ramen or soups that often because most of the time, they contain some kind of meat or fish broth, but this was not the case here and the vegetarian longevity noodle soup was amazing! The broth was light yet flavorful due to the fried garlic and green onions, the noodles were thick and chewy, and the silky tofu and plentiful veggies completed the dish. So many different types of mushrooms too! This might just be the best noodle soup I've ever had! The squid ink noodles had quite an interesting appearance (not your typical looking noodles!) and were apparently very tasty also.

Overall, the food quality is great and prices are pretty reasonable for it being a Dome-level restaurant. I wouldn't hesitate to come back here again when I'm around downtown SF!
author: Jessica C.

description: Great looking restaurant.  Loved the wall of buddhas and the cabinet of snuff bottles just outside the unisex toilets.  The toilets were huge and yes its for men and women. Waiters were really warm and friendly all the way.  Nice of the waiter to mention that still and sparkling water were complimentary.  Went there for lunch with a friend who was visiting.  She was still jet lagged, so we ordered pork sliders, $8 for two. Then we had the beef with soup noodles $14 and the cold Dan Dan min $12.  The beef noodles was really flavorful, the meat was tender and the noodles tasted freshly made. The Dan Dan Min was refreshing, a little spicy but good.  The bill came to about $47 with tips. A bit pricey for lunch but on the whole very satisfying.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Used to love this place.  Went in for lunch today and was very disappointed.  The place looked empty,  unlike before.

There were people outside passing out flyers saying that health department found slimey residual thingy on the water tank for live seafood and on the soda gun at the bar.  

Ordered spicy pork dumpling,  wild boar cut noodles,  and sweet sour pork.

1.  Spicy pork dumpling:  ok.  Spoons were hot to hold and the sauce inside the dumpling were hot.  We had to wait like 10 minutes before eating.

2.  Wild boar cut noodles:  bad.  I used to love this dish.  Now,  they just drenched it in oil.  The server said it always comes out like that.  

3.  Sweet and Sour Pork:  not worth it.  It is a $17 dish but man they are cheap with the amount of meat.  U get like maybe 10 pieces of meat.  Little bit bellpeppers and sauce.  Again,  NOT WORTH IT.  You can go elsewhere to get more for less.  

Not only food has gone downhill,  the service has plummeted as well.  Our server was okay.  She did catch our seafood allergy so nice job!  Nevertheless,  I can understand when your food sucks,  there isnt really much you can do as a server to improve the situation.
author: Hans D.

description:
My brother repeatedly spoke about the pending opening during the holidays.  He generously invited the family for Chinese New Year's dinner on the Saturday night.  Due to other engagements, our party only consisted of six as we were seated at the restaurant's edge table (between the inside dining room and the mall atrium "outdoor" seating area).  After the Hakkasan experience, my expectations were tempered; however, there were some expecttations after reading Genevieve's early review and photos.
