Coincidentally, Michael Bauer recently wrote a review which I read earlier that week. Here's what we had:

Wealth menu - $88.00 for two people

1) Juicy Dumplings Sampler (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=VedCBrcp6hZ32dWUI2PNkA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Two each of Wild boar, pork and crab, and pork with black truffle.  Hard to distinguish the flavors between the three as it was subtle.

2)  Peking Duck (1/2 duck), Two Tastes 
     a) Skin in sliders (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8ntva7sTilssddgpxBjArw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Nicely prepared as the skin were indeed crispy.  Nice having this pre-constructed.
     b) Stir-fried meat in lettuce cups (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oYwG8RzP__8pHeIZMGMhqA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - One serving per person and, like the sliders, convenient to eat and tasty flavors.

3) Seafood Treasury (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=ByUHGWOvOL5XyTGJtHzGHg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Shrimp, scallop, calamari with mixed greens and mushrooms in a "bird's nest' basket, the flavors were just okay.  The 'bird nest's basket' was my favorite aspect of this dish.

4) Stir-fried Longevity Noodle with Shredded BBQ Pork (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3Rp8jAoGmkh1D0H-f3g5Bg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Good wok breath, but the flavors did not really wow.

Dessert
5) Sugar Puff with sauces (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wowD-sWh0VqChon4tAgeQg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Think Beignets with chocolate and raspberry sauce.

Shared - Supplement

1) Roasted chicken, half order (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=1TQqleBP3HpcqtgXsHac-g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Mentioned in the newspaper review, this dish caught my cousin's eye and did not disappoint.

2) Scissor cut noodles with Wild boar (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=aPOSmbGf1URMz4We6M3Ctw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Better flavors than the Longevity noodle and the uneven cuts of the noodle confirm that they are freshly made.

Overall, the meal was pretty good, as my father complimented the kitchen for its cooking skills on most of the dishes; shortly after this, the noodle person popped up behind him and started pulling noodles.  Our waitress was very accommodating to our needs, starting with our party reduction and the servers announced each dish as they brought them out and quickly cleared the empty dishes from our table.  The atmosphere is very interesting as you can get probably four different vibes dining here, depending where you are seated.  Besides where we sat, there are three other dining rooms, one with a series of communal tables next to the open kitchen with several counter seats, a more secluded, quiet dining to the left with a display wall decorated with various Buddha statues (for those who grew up in Chinatown, this reminds me of the original Imperial Palace, the Grant Avenue restaurant with the doorman), and the bar to the far right, adorned with a large bell.  Our table gave more a mall atmosphere with nearby outer tables and high ceiling atrium feel.  Coming in later that week for lunch, we sat near the open kitchen which gave more of a cafeteria vibe.  
For mall food, this is a bit over-the-top, but guess that's consistent with the San Francisco dining scene these days.  Yes, I came back for lunch (beef noodle soup being the last sampling - broth a bit on the sweet side, too much star anise or cinnamon?) and, yes, I will be back again when friends or family have a craving for Chinese food near my office.
Thanks to my brother for welcoming the Year of the Snake!
author: Mike C.

description: My go-to happy hour spot in Westfield. Definitey get the Peking duck, and the Apple smoked negroni
author: Jeff F.

description:
Not too bad. I thought this place would have been an overhyped tourist trap due to its location in the mall. Also it's one of those under the dome restaurants= pricey. Ok so yeah it was pricey and the portion was a lot smaller than I was used to..but the food was good! I got the boar cut noodles and my friend got the beef noodle soup. We ended up swapping our dishes cuz I liked the beef noodle soup way more. I don't usually like beef noodle soup but the soup in this one was good! It was spicy surprisingly. It has a nice little tang to it. 

I was surprised to be filled up by the plates but I did feel full so that is all that matters. Servers were nice but I didn't feel like we got checked up on too often. I wish they did a little bit more. 

Not that this is relevant to the review, but I saw Martin yan once in Bart! Guess he still rides the peasant train even though he's a celebrity..hahah!
author: Stephanie W.

description: Food is sometimes very good, other times just alright. Used to have a very reasonable Happy Hour menu but recently raised the happy hour prices by  30% so not a good deal anymore.
author: Jeff Z.

description: I always have a wonderful time dining here! Love this classy restaurant!! Our server is Helen, she is awesome and super friendly :)
author: Edric H.

description:
This review is for bar service only as the food was good, food was served fast.. But a bit overpriced. 

My friends and I went to My China because our usual goto place closed.  Got there early and sat at the bar.  The bartenders were still preparing so we waited.  Finally got tired of trying to make eye contact and asked for water and a Bloody Mary.  They don't serve bloody Mary's.. Ok ordered my next go to, vodka tonic with Chopin ( yes I can taste the difference even with tonic).  No Chopin.. Bartender recommend another vodka, it was ok but a weak drink. Next I noticed my plate had food dried on it and had to almost get rude to get attention to have it replaced.  First drink down.. Now we are hungry and trying to order food.  Empty water, empty drink, menus out of the way but nobody is paying any attention.  Once again had to try hard to get attention. This happened the entire 2 hours we were there until we were ready to leave, but now.. they are filling water and asking if we want more drinks.  This was the first time any of us visited MyChina so We were not sure if they were under staffed or what, but I recommend to management to have a dedicated bartender to take care of the patrons at the bar. A very disappointing start to our girls day out... But it got better.
author: Suzie K.

description: The food looks pretty, but even the supposedly spicy dishes were bland (kung pao chicken especially).  The chicken on crispy noodles was tasteless.  Service was slow.  The location is convenient if you're in the center of SF, and the restaurant is attractive. But in the future we'll walk a few blocks and go back to our Chinatown favorite, Hunan Homes, which is much more consistent, more flavorful, and half the price.
author: Susan L.

description: Lovely seating under the dome, attentive waitress, decent food. Not exciting, but fresh, good. My friend and I split a squid pasta seafood dish and the Asian taco appetizer. For $18, they could have put a few more pieces of seafood in it. The Asian taco was flavorful. I do enjoy watching them make and stretch the noodles. Knowing they are made in- house is worth a few extra bucks. We also had the lychee semifreddo with chrysanthemum granita. Now that was outstanding: I wouldn't make that at home.
author: Patti H.

description: The Peking duck was absolutely amazing! Not only was the duck super delicious, but the steamed buns that comes with it was just as great.  Definitely will be come here again as their service, food, and atmosphere was well worth it.
author: Miya S.

description: Second trip here and we were back for the Beijing Duck.  We tried the scissor-cut noodles.  We ordered a whole duck and enjoyed it immensely.  The scissor cut noodle with boar was good. I was disappointed that there wasn't too much boar meat but the noodles were very tasty. Definitely will be back again when we're looking to get a fix on the Beijing Duck.  I was disappointed that the egg tarts were not offered on the dessert menu but will be back to try other items off the menu.
author: Susan C.

description: Food really excellent. We live the lettuce wrap, the hongkong style crispy noodle, the peking duck, sweet n sour pork, the spicy string neans, The sea bass, the juicy pork dumpling and many more. I brought friends from all over the world and the verdict is good. The food not greasy, oily nor salty and desserts are good too. I eat here a lot and in the top list of my favorite restaurant!
author: Nene L.

description:
Good atmosphere, good service. Nice decoration. The 4th star is for anything except the food.
Food is ok. We ordered noodle mostly. The taste is pretty good. But they do have a big selection of other entrees and wines. I'd like to go again to explore a bit more on the menu and try their other options.
author: Julia Z.

description:
When I walked by the restaurant before it opened I knew I wanted to check it out since I'm a fan of Martin Yan.  After all, I grew up watching him and since he's Cantonese too!  =)  Bf & I finally checked it out this past Saturday night & were lucky enough to get a 6:45 reservation with only an hour notice through Opentable.

We have both heard mixed reviews on the restaurant and weren't honestly expecting much, but boy were we wrong!  We had to wait about 5 minutes or so pass our reservation time, but at least we got a photo opp with Martin Yan himself while we were waiting by the front.  He definitely knows how to entertain as he was explaining the noodle making process to part of the restaurant.  And he walks around to some tables as well (including ours a couple times).  Gotta love that!  

For the appetizers we got  pork belly bun sliders ($8) & crab & pork dumplings ($12).  We also ordered: wild boar scissor cut noodles ($14), claypot braised beef short rib ($25), and da mieu (pea sprouts) ($16), one bowl of rice ($2), and for dessert, sugar egg puffs ($8).  

The pork belly bun sliders were so tasty!  The meat in his was quite a bit fattier than mine however.  I prefer these over Chairman Bao!  For the dumplings we got 4 & like Cherylynn commented, they were served on ceramic spoons in the steamer, which caused the dumplings to stick and most of them were also served punctured already, so we slurped most of the juice from the spoon directly.  Though it was aesthetically pleasing, this presentation makes no sense because the spoons were so hot and because the dumpling sticks to the spoons making it hard to get out.  I tasted the crab, while he said he couldn't.  I guess that was a trade off since he got one dumpling that wasn't punctured!  We loved the wild boar scissor cut noodle because of it's lightness and I'm always a sucker for my noodles.  We just wished that the noodles were a little longer.  The taste of the  boar was light too, which was a plus.  The short rib was tender and plentiful.  I loved the onions and the herbs and sauce, everything tied together so well and had that little bit of heat.  Da Mieu is pretty standard everywhere I've had it, with no complaints here either!  Last but not least, the sugar egg puffs!  We liked how they weren't as covered in sugar as the traditional Chinese places we've had them at does it.  However, they were greasier than what we're used to.  But, a plus here are the dipping sauces!  We loved the raspberry the most, but the chocolate fondue and vanilla chantilly creme are great as well.  

Service was pretty good and polite, but the restaurant was so busy that I think refills on water were overlooked for our table and our neighbor's.   The ambiance is eclectic mod Asian.  The bathroom is in the corner and has no door (it's unisex) but with several ceiling to floor stalls for some privacy!  The food portions, minus the appetizers were pretty generous.  We did have leftover claypot.  All in all, $102 for all that food plus one beer isn't bad.  It's a little like PF Chang's, but definitely more authentic, actually tasty & almost the same price!  We definitely will be back.
author: Cat C.

description:
In the West Field Mall which most people think of for the food court which is better than any mall I've ever been to. 
This is a step up in quality and service with Dim Sum @ $5 
Overall everything was very good, will go back.
author: Frank H.

description:
Roasted chicken and bok choy!  Yan Can Cook!!  I love the convenient location of this restaurant right in our loved San Francisco downtown mall.   You shop, you get hungry, you eat yummy Chinese food that is so well executed, tasty and comforting.  I loved the open window into the kitchen as you watch the crew cook up wonderful dishes, throw noodles (one guy stretched noodles in front of patrons on the main floor) - nice classy ambiance with dark wood decor (and a Ally McBeal unisex restroom with cool artifacts as decor accents).  Love!  My friends were in town so this was a perfect time to try it and entertain.  

Dishes I definitely want to order up again are the pork and crab soup dumplings, bok choy cooked with big garlic cloves and bits of fish, roasted chicken with awesome crispy skin, spicy beef with fresh noodles and sweet and sour soup.  Sip a cold beer and you are set!  Cocktails are yummy here too!  

I want to come back very very soon!  Mr. Martin Yan, I would love to see you!
author: Maile N.

description:
Spectacular! Not only was the service fabulous, the food was equally as impressive. We had the Vegetarian Longevity Noodle Soup and the Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp. The soup was huge and the tofu and broth were especially delicious. The shrimp, along with the candied walnuts and wasabi aioli, were phenomenal. 
Our waiter Justin was more than polite, he was extremely interesting to talk to and offered us recommendations around the city. All around spectacular restaurant.
author: Zak C.

description: Finally a place that serves soup dumplings like the ones you find in Shanghai. What I really liked about these soup dumplings is that actually came in individual spoons so you can eat them without breaking them. I always have a tough time and they end up breaking in the bowl and losing all the soup. This place is expensive though so if I wanted to get great Chinese food would probably go to Chinatown if seating or the ambiance isn't important. Portions are very small as well.
author: Viroopa V.

description:
I kind of wish I liked this place..... I ordered the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup (Niu rou mian) but it was just really bad.... it's pretty hard to mess up this dish.. but they somehow managed to. The beef however was good, but one sip of the soup and i felt like i was drinking salt water. 
The noodles tasted like pure salt (kudos for making it themselves) but they really need to lay off on the salt. Waiter had also disappeared a couple of times... My friend and I were sitting there for a good 10 minutes without drinks and knowing who our server even was.
author: Carolyn T.

description: I wanted to love M.Y.China, but it fell short!  There are much better Chinese places in San Francisco to eat!  Just go to China Town.  I guess because it's a touristy spot.  I know that if Martin were here the quality would be up to his standards.  MY Dim Sum Collection was way over steamed and lacked flavor.  The Hong Kong crispy noodles had way too much sauce and the chicken and bok choy were in huge cubes.  No at all happy with M.Y. China.
author: MaryAnn H.

description:
My family and I had dinner here and Kara was our server. May I just say she was just awesome!  Very informative,  gracious and genuinely nice. She was simply the best!

Food was good but the 5 stars is basically because of her excellent service!

Thank you Kara.
author: Jinggay D.

description:
I went to this place alone and I ordered only two dishes. So I considered my review a tad biased due to the small sample size.

The decoration and atmosphere of the restaurant are generally good. Unfortunately I was seated in the chef's bar area, which I don't really like. The kitchen was extremely busy and I didn't like seeing people rushing and running in front of me when I just wanted to relax and have a nice dinner. So avoid that area and ask for the bar seats if you were alone.

I ordered the Da Dao noodle and wonton soup. Taste of food is very good and authentic. Da dao noodle is a fancier name. I had similar dish in Irvine, where it is called XO seafood lo mein. MY's version is excellent in the Wok-qi and seafood processing. I like the tender juiciness of fresh seafood blended with slight spiciness from sauce. If the chef can make the noodle more "Q" instead of soft that would be a perfect dish. Wonton soup is just awesome and delicious. Exactly the flavor I missed everyday from the top chefs in Taiwan and Hongkong.

Overall this is a good restaurant, however, I'd come back next time with more people and hopefully get a better seating.
author: Arthur H.

description: I liked the tacos a lot. The lychee flavored iced tea also was excellent not too sweet.
author: Josephine W.

description: Great service, nice ambiance. Food was lovely, not outstanding. Will return next time I'm in town on business.
author: Kish S.

description:
We came here for a private party and were able to try a large variety of menu items. ALL appetizers were fantastic, especially the dumplings & lettuce cups.  Definitely get the wild boar scissor cut noodles, sichuan green beans and Kun pao chicken (spicy). 

Great atmosphere and friendly, knowledgeable staff.
author: Shana V.

description:
MY CAN COOK!

Came here on a Friday night after scooping up a last minute reservation on Open Table! The restaurant is located on the top floor of the westfield downtown mall in SF. There is a bar seating area, and a restaurant dining area and the decor has a modern Chinese style too it. 

FOOD:
We ordered several appetizers:
Tea Flavored Pork Belly Sliders - Fantastic taste. It comes wrapped in a soft fluffy steamed bun with pickle onions and juicy pork belly inside. Great start to the meal.

Juicy Pork Dumplings - The dumplings came in a giant red spoons. Great idea to hold the soup after taking a bite! Downside is that after a bit the bottom would stick to the spoons so the dumpling would automatically rip apart! The meat was still amazingly delicious.

Beef Noodle Soup - Well balanced flavor to the broth. It is very different from the classic asian restaurants in San Jose as the broth has a rich yet subtle taste. Definitely can tell the soup was quality made as it wasn't heavy and wasn't filled with oil and  flavor enhancers. The meat was also the best beef noodle soup meat I have had. It literally melted in my mouth and was not tough at all.

Wok Roasted Lobster - Another must get dish! The lobster was perfect and cracked so it was easy to get all the meat with out much of an effort! It was flavored with the usual Asian herb, and lemon seasoning. The lobster was extremely fresh and cooked the right amount.

Sugar Egg Puffs - Pure heaven. I think I could of ate 10 of these even after eating all the appetizers and entrees. The egg puffs are perfectly sugared and not too sweet at all. There is also a milky pudding texture inside, and the egg puffs come with vanilla, chocolate, and raspberry fillings.

Overall the food is excellent quality and I don't think it is Americanized at all and brings out how Chinese food can be well balanced quality food.

Additionally the plating of the dishes were all brilliantly placed and even the tea we ordered came in small circular bows to drink out of.

SERVICE:
The waiters were extremely attentive and came by our tables on several occasions to ask how the meal was. Quite impressive given how busy the night was!

Martin Yan has made a great hit in SF!
author: Stephen C.

description:
I came to M.Y. China last week after everything else was closed in the mall.

I left disappointed. The waitress forgot to input our food in the computer system, so we were waiting FOREVER. She didn't even offer an apologize or comp any drinks.

When she finally recognized the error, the food did come out promptly. However, it was way too overpriced for the quality.

Oh well.
author: Justin A.

description: Hard beef and good sea bass. I have high expectations for Chinese food because I come from Asia and eat at Hong Kong every year. Decent food at an easy to access location.
author: Sean G.

description:
I guess seeing M.Y. China on the 2014 Bib Gourmand list gave me the idea to finally stop by here and see what's the buzz all about.

I came here with two others, we decided to just order our own plates and perhaps share some appetizers or dimsum. My biggest expectation was double what you would pay for in Chinatown and half the size of what they serve in Chinatown. It's very tough for me to try westernized Chinese food, just for the fact that there could be so many wrongs coming out of these places. Sometimes either fusion screws up a traditional dish, lacking certain flavors (especially spiciness), but sometimes it works pretty well in terms of food presentation.

So we ordered beef stew hand pulled noodles, spicy seafood dumplings, and HK style pan fried noodles.  (ERMAGGERD, NOODERS!)  The hand pulled noodles was alright. Portions were pretty good, reminded me of Noodle Asia in Venetian. The hand pulled noodles were okay, but I liked the ones from Imperial Tea Court in Berkeley more for that chewiness in the noodles. The soup base wasn't overly empowered by MSG and salt, one of the few times where I drank the whole thing.  What I enjoyed most was the beef, good quality beef and slow cooked to the right time. You don't have to gnaw on the beef chunks like you are a cow eating grass. It's actually very soft and falls apart inside your mouth.  

I personally hate pan fried noodles because the dish is too indecisive on its texture. It's either too soggy from soaking in the sauce, or too crunchy because the noodles were burnt. I didn't recall seeing burnt noodles. I only tasted the sauce, which was slightly sweetened, as if it used chicken stock for base. The chicken pieces used surprised me a bit; I guess I was too used to eating chicken covered in thick batter before frying, I didn't expect to get to the meat so quickly. 

The spicy dumplings were just okay. I was expected the dumpling skin to be more chewy. It's definitely pretty thin and it doesn't break when it's being picked up. Again, I'm not used to eating a big chunk of shrimp in the dumpling. The sauce was a bit overwhelming in the saltiness and there's no depth in the flavors.  Probably not going to order this next time.

I guess if you want to try this place but got scared by the pricing. Look, you pay for what you get, you pay more for your dimsum, you get a bigger piece of shrimp!  And you do get better service, unless you like to pay for rude services, then Chinatown is not too far away.
author: Connie C.

description:
My M.Y. experience was a little more like a Chinese Benihana than I'd probably like.  

Now don't get me wrong: I have a place in my heart for Martin Yan: despite the fake accent, the guy has been a mainstay on TV for more than thirty years, and I absolutely loved watching his show as a kid.  I hope he crushes it with this current venture, but there's too much "show" for my taste since the substance is perfectly fine. 

It's like a "best hits" album from the 80s: sweet and sour pork, kung pao chicken, lettuce cups... the good news is that the food is perfectly enjoyable.  I'd go again for any of the dishes I tried: the salt/pepper calamari, the onion pancake beef rolls, the har gow, and the shanghai dumplings.  

(Special note for the bartenders: any chance you can use fresh pineapple juice instead of pouring directly from a big can of Dole's?  You also might want to kick up the alcohol content in your drinks a notch or two!)  

So, come for the high cheese factor and the show, but don't bank on a unique Asian dining experience.  It's in a mall, after all.
author: Laurence W.

description:
These guys are crazy!  Pure entertainment and a ton of fun.

I've never seen how noodles were made before.  Who knew that they were twisted, thrown around, turned and wrapped around just about everything.  Those dudes were like noodle ninjas.  Though I will say that I did see one dude sweep the floor with the noodle and just keep going like nothing happend.  (THANK GOD I don't like noodles!)

That said, the entertainment far outweighs the food.  It wouldn't be a stretch to say that the food is a little better than average Chinese food. But for some reason, it all works.  I'd totally walk into this place after a long day of shopping.  Have a cocktail, watch the noodle guys do their magic, and chill out with a nice bowl of NOT noodle soup.

Makes for a perfect day at the Westfield.
author: Angella S.

description:
It looks like this is one of those places that you probably love it or hate it and much of it may have to do with the expectations you have going into it.  So this is a classic example of when reading other Yelpers reviews can help with that experience.  I went in expecting higher than normal price tag for Chinese food and some select "must tries" that I may not find at cheaper Chinese restaurants.  

With 4 of us, we were able to try a variety of different dishes which is a great way to go.  

We started off with all the dumplings - wild boar, pork and crab, pork and black truffle, and spicy seafood.  The first 3 are made like xiao lung baos served on a spoon to catch the juice that runs out and were very tasty with the wild boar being our favorite.  

Crispy Organic Tofu - Perfectly cooked crispy on the outside and smooth and soft on the inside  
Bang Bang Chicken Wings - This was probably my least favorite as the sauce was a bit too overpowering for my taste - save the $9 for another order of wild boar dumplings
Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup - The menu said it was a slow simmered rib eye but with the preparation, it could've been another cut without a big noticeable difference.  It probably would've been fun to see them pull the noodles for the dish if we sat at the counter though
Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles - We really enjoyed the noodles in this dish which were short (about 1 1/2 - 2 in long) that you almost don't realize those were noodles.  But it was flavorful and well prepared.  

Overall, it was a good experience and found the food flavorful and well prepared without MSG proven by not needing a gallon of water to quench our thirst an hour later.  We had no problem with service that some others had but it may be because we were there right when it opened at 11 so something to consider before heading over.
author: Joyce Z.

description: We managed to get a table immediately for dinner despite the fact that they were busy so that was good. Service was a little patchy (they forgot a few items for example). I was also worried due to yelp's info on the poor food safety rating. I didn't want to eat here but my family wanted to stop. I'm happy to report the food looked and tasted great and I'm still alive this morning and felt well all night! I would eat here again and I highly recommend.
author: F S.

description:
This place is a joke - ultimately it's a glorified P.F. Chang's! But I guess that's why it's in mall...

Finally went to check this place out and sat at the bar only to experience the sh!t show that ensued. Although both bartenders were friendly enough, they sorely lacked in service and would rather chat up all the servers than wait on their customers. I never did get a place setting or even water from them and had to flag down the bar back for both 45 minutes after sitting down when our food finally started arriving. 

The food came out all at once and really quickly after I was finally able to get an order in. This makes me think that everything is already cooked and plated and just sitting in the back waiting to be dumped at your table. None of the food was very good, just loaded with salt and dripping in grease. 

After we had had enough with being ignored and unable to order more drinks, we managed to flag the bar back down again so she could get the bartender's attention and bring us our check. What should have been a quick, fun meal at the bar turned into a 1.5+ hour long torture session of "try-to-get-service" and "dodge-the-food-you-didn't-order-being-dropped-off-at-your-table". 

The food prices are decent, I'll give it that but the cocktail prices are a tad high for what you get.
author: Vicente G.

description: Simply put, they make good food. The dim sums were awesome. But there was nothing special about this restaurant; hence the missing star. A nice place to go to for some good food; nothing more.
author: Ganesh K.

description:
I was curious about this place mostly because of the noodles. We came here for a work lunch and ordered a bunch of items to share. We tried out a few of their dim sum dishes, they were pretty standard (shrimp dumplings, xiaolongbao, shumai), but way over priced.

We tried out the pulled noodles and the cut noodles. I was pretty disappointed because the texture of the noodles weren't all that different from the regular chow mien you get at run of the mill Chinese restaurants, and I thought it was too salty.
author: Alice W.

description:
Live really close to the mall so been excited for this restaurant to finally open up. The decor is actually quite nice (like an upscale PF Chang's) so when my sister and brother in law came into town we came to try this for lunch. 

Service was prompt, complimentary sparkling water so all that was a plus.

The food though can be improved. The dim sum platter for 9 pieces of dim sum (which includes two pork buns) was passable but pricey for what you get and the pineapple fried rice was flavorless and very soggy.  

I will say I did enjoy the beef noodle soup albeit pricey but I thought the flavor of the broth was good, the texture of the hand pulled noodles were good, and the beef was very tender.

I would suggest to the manager to have someone check on the bathrooms more frequently, when I went I was a little disgusted by all the trash that was coming out of the little trash receptacle, not a very welcoming site after eating lunch.
author: Betty C.

description:
Oh martin yan, how overplayed you have become. just because u are rich chinese man and can make money off anything...doesn't mean you have to rip ppl off!! but i guess i would too if I could. 

came around noon with a friend, the area looked fancy, open restaurant, was kind of confused where the entrance was. seated quickly, tables were kind of too close together.

we ordered...

dimsum combo plate-.....$19? it's good dimsum, but not freakin 20 worth!! rip off much.
crispy noodle with chicken?- $16...pleaseee put the chinese names so we know not to order this ever again because you can find this anywhere in china town for $4! it was good yes, but c'mon....
tea-$6 for a pot..fml

most expensive tiny chinese meal ever! $25 per person. never again unless someone else is paying, but even then! I'd go to straits, at lease they have HH

the food is good, yes, price no, for tourists, yes. sorry Mr Yan, I am passing!
although I do want to try the hand pulled nooedles..darn you
author: Christine M.

description:
The ambiance was average considering we were sitting in the middle of a shopping mall (not much of a view) but it definitely had a classier and more upscale vibe. If I were to weigh the pros and cons of my dining experience, it would be simple. 

Pro - the food. 
Con - the service. 

The waitress failed to smile at us during the entire hour we were there and the worst part was that she continuously called us 'kids.' I don't know about you but being 20 years old and having someone refer to me and my friends as 'kids' is somewhat offensive and inappropriate. 

Now moving onto the better part of the experience - the food. My oh my was the food delicious. I ordered the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup with slow simmered short rib and baby bok choy. The noodles were so perfectly uniform that I questioned if they were actually hand pulled but this skepticism was addressed when the chefs were walking through the restaurants pulling the noodles right in front of the diners. The beef was incredibly tender, the bok choy brought the perfect amount of crunch and the broth was the star of the dish infusing it with so much flavor. And after seeing the dessert menu I knew I couldn't end my meal yet. We, as a group of 4, split two desserts - the Lychee Panna Cotta with chrysanthemum granita and mint essence and the Tea Infused Crème Brûlée with whipped cream and gaufrette. The panna cotta left me speechless and it was the most refreshing and light dessert I have ever had - the perfect palette cleanser. The creme brûlée was great as the tea flavor was subtle but stayed true to the overall theme of the restaurant and the meal. All in all I am over the moon with how great everything tasted and looked.
author: Cassie X.

description: If I could give a zero star, I would. Not a good Chinese restaurant. The price of the food is hella expensive and does not even taste that good. We ordered chicken and pork dishes and both were so dry! It is literally sucking up all my saliva. Other than the location being convenient for shoppers, I think it's better to go somewhere else with better quality and priced food. Lastly, it seems like all the Asians are sitting outside and non-Asians are sitting inside the restaurant.
author: Crystal T.

description:
Update 2015 

Still good food !!! I freaking love this place. Bottom line is that I don't care if this place is Chinese or what ever or if the food is authentic! What I care about is that I love this food and I will continue to come as long as I'm alive ! My favorites Hong Kong crispy noodles and wild board's (not sure of how it's spelled it) also shirp dumping OMG I Love it  I should be like  A VIP or something
author: Doris F.

description: The best Chinese meal I've had in Bay Area! Super recommended from a picky Chinese! We had dim sum collection,  BBQ pork and twin scallop fried rice. The chef must pay attention to every detail, they taste very Chinese and delicious!
author: Jiawen M.

description:
A taste for Chinese food brought me to M.Y. China, but the food and service will keep me coming back!
First I must say our server Bianca was so gracious and knowledgeable that it was fun to ask her questions, I'd come back just for her.
But the food, YUM! I had the wild boar and scissor cut noodles. My friend had the seafood noodles. Also the spicy dumplings app., and delish green tea iced cream for dessert.
The mix master behind the bar, Derek I think, served up some well balanced cocktails and rocked my thoughts on a simple gin and tonic. 
"Chinese food" will never be the same again after the wonderful dinner we had at M.Y. China.
Keep me a table folks, I'll be back soon!  Thanks again, Eric
author: Eric S.

description:
Wow! This place has some if the best service I've experienced!  If you are even contemplating that you need something, someone is already coming to your table. Maybe they time how long it's been since the last time they came by...but whatever it is, it works!

Fantastic food, properly spiced and cooked. We had a huge party of about 20 people, and all of us loved it. Martin Yan was there, and went around from table to table suggesting a wine, or dessert, or drink that would go well with your order. A very great experience,  and highly recommended!
author: James D.

description:
After seeing Martin Yan cook at the 9th annual Asian Heritage Street Celebration, I had to come try out his restaurant by the end of the festival!

I'm giving M.Y. China five stars for the excellent food and fast & professional (mostly) service. Growing up in SF, and coming from an Asian background, I've been to a lot of Chinese-American restaurants in the Bay Area that either excel or disappoint. M.Y. China definitely excels on most points. The food was as expected, Americanized Chinese food, so my parents and I weren't expecting it to be authentic. We did have good expectations for the quality and flavor--both of which were great.

We had a meal for three for under $40, which is a great value considering the large portions and rich flavors.

The decor is sleek, modern and just the right mix of Oriental and Western tones. The setting is intimate. Needless to say, the dining experience was very comfortable.

However, I have to agree with reviewer Raj P. about the waiting staff. The people at the front desk were very nice and helpful. On the other hand we felt our waiter was, as Raj P. said, half-hearted, fake and disinterested. He simply didn't show a bit of enthusiasm or care. In short, he had no emotion. Is there a way we can get in contact with management? Because it looks like a lot of people are complaining about the same server.

I would have given a rating of 4, maybe 3, stars were it not for the bussers. The bussers, who are often overlooked, were amazing and deserve to be recognized. They were very kind, patient, attentive and quick. Bravo to the bussers!

I'll definitely come back to try out other dishes on the menu!
author: Alfred S.

description: Came here today with my friends and was disappointed with the food. We were excited to try their noodles but it came out to be a bit stiff and super oily. The tea infused creme brulee sounded great but tasted bad. Might I add, whip creme and rice crispy does not go well with the creme brulee. Only thing I liked was the tofu since it was soft, tasted fresh, and spicy seasoned. Service was ok. We spent about $115 including tax and tips for party of 3 for Chinese food that probably tasted better at a mom and pop shop. Sorry Martin Yan. You're great and respected but the restaurant needs work.
author: Amy T.

description:
My options before watching Interstellar tonight were simple...grab anything around the theater. Ideally, that would have been Chipotle, but people figured that this would be a good compromise. False.

We attempted to make them conscious of our time crunch, and the following ensued. We got decent Shanghai Dumplings, overly battered Sweet and Sour Pork, completely bland Scallop Fried Rice, and Beef Noodle Soup that had great ingredients (beef and noodles) with a mediocre-almost-underflavored broth.

In terms of service, we were utterly baffled by the fact that it took an eternity (everything else was already received and finished) to procure the underseasoned underwhelming pile of food that they called Scallop Fried Rice. I mean, the ingredients including rice, string beans, scallop, and egg should have essentially all been sponges for flavor. Unfortunately, painting a blank canvas with clear paint doesn't really get you anywhere...it definitely doesn't make you a painter who can open a gallery to sell err...paintings? In an attempt to salvage this round of sustenance, we requested chili sauce to, you know, spruce things up...but that request was tabled so that the waitress could chat with a nearby party, take drink orders, bring said drinks, chat them up some more, then after being reminded again, she said "I was just about to grab it".

Overall, it was a lackluster experience quite fitting for the pedestrian mall setting it has complacently nestled itself into.
author: Nick W.

description:
I would have given this place 4 stars or 4.5 stars if it wasn't for the kind of service we got that night we went here 3/13/2014. 

-Food was better than I expected. Will definitely come back here for Wild Boar Juicy Dumplings, Beef hand pulled noodles, and Crispy Chicken. 
-Ambience was good.
-Service was a little disappointing. Not blaming the server for everything though, she might just had too many tables on her section. And it was packed that night as well so maybe that's why it took a little longer for her to get our orders altogether, (two other servers were serving us our food and didn't bother to ask who ordered what). Plus she never did ask if we were doing okay or if we needed more of something. Then again she'd refill all our water glasses every so often. Maybe she's not a talker...? I just didn't feel a connection with our server at all.

- Overall, their food had all the redeeming qualities they need to keep people coming back!
author: Edzy C.

description: What a great place. The food and staff were terrific. We really enjoyed the atmosphere and the entire experience.
author: Tim T.

description:
After hearing Martin Yan had opened a restaurant and since I had just moved to SF, it was perfect timing. I loved watching Yan Can Cook as a child and I was excited to have the opportunity to see what his restaurant had to offer. 

The wild boar scissor cut noodles are a must try. They are so flavorful and have that nice "wok" flavor to them. It can be a bit salty to some palates but it goes well with the entrees. The Beijing knife cut noodles are also worth trying. They are cooked well and are a nice vegetarian option. The beef hand pulled noodles are also good. The presentation is very neat and the broth is quite tasty. But I would recommend trying the dry noodles to the noodle soups are you can taste more of the "wok" flavor and it's much easier to share. Also, the chefs sometimes put on a show as they pull the noodles right in front of your table. 

My favorite entree has to be the five spice pork ribs. Don't let the word ribs deceive you into the dish being messy and hard to eat because it's quite the opposite. The meat was so tender and fell right off the bone. The pork ribs I presume is slow cooked and then fried a bit on the outside to give it that crispy golden color and taste. It's so delicious that you must try for yourself. The lamb chops are also on the top of my list. It's seasoned with cumin and chili powder and tastes so flavorful and juicy. Also, you can give the Peking duck a try. It's not the best Peking duck but it is still good and satisfies the craving. 

From the small eats, the tea smoked pork belly sliders are wonderful. They are tender and goes nicely with the bun. But I have to say I've had better as the pork belly wasn't melt in your mouth. 

I've made three visits here already and have loved the food and experience here each time. It's situated right under the dome at the Westfield and it's a perfect place to grab dinner and a movie. I love this place and of course I'm planning future visits.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I've been coming to this place for 2 years, and always came with my family, and the service was also good and consistent, the food delicious, though there was a MAJOR flaw. The food rating. The rating is so low(63) it shocks me. For such a well put together  restaurant, you would think they would put some effort handling their food. I mean I have seen more crummy restaurants with higher scores! I haven't checked the rating until recently and was stunned. I don't think I'm heading back anytime soon, unless they fix their situation. Don't get me wrong though, these guys food is so good it kept me around for at least 2 years. The reason why I gave this place a 2 star is because of sanitation/Food Rating and Handling. For me, it doesn't matter how good the food is, because I want to know that my food is healthy and safe. If you didn't see the rating it tastes good! So go at your own risk. I'll list some good dishes that you should try.

1. Chairman Mao's Chicken- Has been my personal favorite, with crunchiness and flavor! Has a bit of spice to it, so BEWARE people who can't handle the spice.

2. Squid Ink Noodles- Very delicious noodle dish with vegetables and some seafood. 

3. Green Tea Tiramisu- Be warned of extremely yummy and delicious green tea tiramisu! One of the best have ever had.
author: Ethan K.

description: Just bad. Was craving noodles after seeing this place on an episode of Check Please Bay Area, and was sorely disappointed. Noodles were overcooked and soggy and the sauce was so salty the dish was inedible. Eat anywhere at the mall but here.
author: Amy M.

description:
Nice and clean restaurant. Also, very nice staffs. 

Did NOT like:
- Assorted Dimsum 
- Green onion pancake

Like:
- Wild board scissor cut noodle
  (Pan fried thick noodle. Loved it!)
author: Yoona S.

description:
Waited and waited, walked by but it was too busy, until today. April Fool!

but wait, no fools we, there's a 4 some waiting at the host stand, they're told to wait nearby, but us, a 2-top, right this way...

to a long 2 sided table with a view of everything, the Buddha's over there, the big bell over there, the folks in the rotunda, over there.

Prompt service, glasses of water and bottle. Menus greeted us, lots of small and large plates.

so we order 2 pork belly sliders, beef and boar noodle bowls, beer and wine.

Folks on either side are digging into their dishes, exclaiming "oooo goood' and now we're ready.

Beer and wine show up, nice selection of both available, nice prices.

The sliders show up, very tasty but a bit ho-hum, no zing. Having had this dish with scallions and shiso in Hawai'i recently, this version is kinda bland but tasty.

The beef noodles are overwhelmed by star anise. Way too muchly. 

The boar noodles are tasty but not much boar meat for $18.

Very good service in a very busy room.

Interestng place, it all works well. Bring an appitite because the portions are big.
Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: Came to MY China for Mother's Day dinner.  The decor was nice, kind of contemporary with a Chinese touch.  We ordered: pork dumplings, pork belly sliders, squid ink noodles, green beans, and garlic steamed Dungeness crab.  The pork dumplings was good as I really liked the richness of the pork inside.  The pork belly sliders were just ok, not too much flavor and the pork belly seemed quite lean believe it or not.  The squid ink noodles were great!  Probably the best dish we ordered.  Green beans were average, as I've had better in other much cheaper Chinese places.  The crab was really disappointing!  It didn't taste too fresh according to my wife, and she's a crab expert.  For $48, I would have skipped it.  For dessert, we got the lychee panda cotta, which was really good.  The added chrysanthemum bits is what separated from ok to great.  Overall, the experience was ok, with the pros being nice decor, but if you want good food, I would not come here, especially considering the price.  For $110 not including tips, I can go to R&G Lounge or Koi Palace and get better quality Chinese food, although it will be without the ambiance.
author: Mark W.

description:
I grew up watching Martin Yan on tv so of course I wanted to come try the restaurant. I didn't have much expectations walking in. It looked like typical over-priced, Americanized Chinese food. That being said, it is all those things, but done well. If you take this restaurant for what it is, then I think you will be happy with the meal you get here.

We ordered the XLBs which comes steamed in individual spoons. Looks nice presentation wise, but the spoons were too hot to pick up the first few minutes and the XLB sticks to it even though they do put a little slice of carrot on the bottom. Luckily the spoon catches most of the soup that spills out. The filling inside is very fatty and tender. The soup inside could have been a little more flavorful.

The best item we got were the ribs. They were super fall off the bone tender and flavored with lots of spices. 

Would pass on the beef noodle soup next time. It was very average to below average. The meat that comes with it is tender but the broth wasn't that good and noodles were just OK as well.

We ended with the lychee flan. This one was very good, loved the chrysthanum sorbet that comes with it. Very nice way to end the meal. I have to say, if I'm in the city again, I just might come back for more ribs and flan.
author: Diana Y.

description: This place serves wonderful Regional Chinese cooking in attractive facility with lots and lots of Buzz. A particular hit were the shu mai with scallops in a sweet and sour sauce. Absolutely outstanding. I also had the best Yang Chow fried rice I've ever had. Highly recommend this reasonably priced upscale Chinese restaurant
author: Mark G.

description: 3:00pm Had a beef noodle soup here, since my coworker recommended here, overall it's good but very salty and spicy (asked for little spice) but price is a bit expensive.
author: HL W.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to try this restaurant on a Saturday evening around 5 pm. They showed us a really small table. That would be ok for me but i requested a brighter spot as my boyfriend has a severe visual disability/partial eyesight. They said we can either sit at the counterside or that table and when i pointed out all the empty tables around which i assume maybe 6-7 tables
were empty, they said they are for reservation. On a saturday evening, around 5, what reservations are you talking about?? Is this how you act when a disabled person come in???
author: Bike K.

description: American Chinese food. The Peking duck is the driest one I have ever had. Plus it's not freshly cuted.
author: Jing Z.

description:
I took my parents here for lunch during the weekend. I liked the ambiance and open kitchen, but  I found the food to be very average..

The Dan Dan noodle was a bit too sour and way too salty.  The wild boar lettuce cups were also packed with too much soy sauce.  The pineapple fried rice just wasn't very good.  

Maybe we didn't order the right things but I am not sure I will go back.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Beautiful decor, good service, love the fact that one can look into the kitchen and look at dim sum being made and woks being fired up. But there are thousands of restaurants that can boast this, and what M.Y. China has over these places is that the food is GOOD. I have been searching high and low for a dim sum restaurant that doesn't serve oversized har gau that taste like tapioca starch, and shrimp caked in old pork oil (gross, right?) and this is the place. 

The shut mai were delicately filled with shrimp, pork and a light touch of caviar - exceptionally well balanced, the outside skin was the perfect ratio to the protein inside. No weird bits and pieces that you'd normally get from the gargantuan, frozen shu mai of most dim sum restaurants. 

The wonton soup, unfortunately, wasn't as nearly exciting. The broth was bland, and while the filling of the wonton had no offending flavors, it was because it was on the opposite spectrum - bland. Nothing to write home about. 

The hand-pulled beef needles were a joy - the noodles were fresh, and had that light chewy texture only freshly pulled noodles can have. The beef was melt-in-your-mouth tender, and was a balance of meat and fat. Most restaurants like to cut you short on vegetables, but not in this case; the bowl had a beautiful mix of greenery to offset the salt and starch. Lightly spiced with a deep, dark rich beef broth, this soup was rejuvenating. 

Overall, good food and excellent dim sum. I have yet to find a place that served such quality dim sum pieces and will return.
author: Chau L.

description:
On Saturday, 10/4/14, my girlfriend and I ate at M.Y. China for lunch. Back in March of 2013 was the first time my girlfriend and I ate at M.Y. China. We had a really good experience and thought the food was excellent.  The second time we ate at M.Y. China was in September of 2013. We didn't have a good experience. My Sweet & Sour Pork was horrible. The pork tasted old and was very chewy. The Scissor Cut Boar Noodles weren't good either. The Boar was very fatty and chewy, literally inedible. The noodles were burnt as well. The only dish that was good was the Potato Pancake appetizer. I must say the Manager on duty at the time handled the situation very well. She offered to have the dishes remade or anything else we wanted on the menu. She ended up comping our entire bill and brought out a free dessert. She was very professional and handled the situation perfectly. 

My girlfriend wanted to give M.Y. China another shot. I kept telling her that I have a feeling it's not going to be good. We ended up going anyways and here's how it all went down. 

Atmosphere/Decor:

The restaurant is very nice. The open floor plan makes the restaurant look even larger than it really is. There's a really nice bar area located to the right once you enter the restaurant. I like the Chinese decor and design throughout the restaurant. The open kitchen is pretty cool because you get to see the chefs prepare dishes along with stretching long noodles. 

Food:

I ordered the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup (slow simmered short rib, baby bok choy.) The soup was mediocre at best. The beef short rib tasted like old pot roast. There was a ton of fat on the short rib. The noodles tasted okay. I didn't like the taste of the spices that were in the soup. They were too overpowering. The baby bok choy tasted good and fresh. About half way through my soup I noticed something disgusting! I was using my fork to grab some more noodles and noticed a hair in the broth! The hair ended up on the side of the bowl! It looked like an eye brow hair or eye lash. I was turned off at that point and couldn't eat anymore. 

My girlfriend ordered the Yang Zhou Fried Rice (barbequed pork) and the Peking Roast Duck (green onions, cucumber, hoisin sauce, house made buns.) We thought the fried was average. It tasted like your regular Chinese fast food restaurant fried rice but with less soy sauce. The pork tasted old to me. My girlfriend thought the duck was good when you add the sauce and put everything into the bun but by itself it lacked flavor. She also thought the duck was a little too dry. 

Service:

Our waitress Chelsea was very nice. When I showed Chelsea the hair in my soup she immediately apologized and said she will let the manager know right away and the manager will come over to talk to me. Chelsea offered to bring out a new soup. When I declined and told her no thank you Chelsea asked me if I wanted anything else on the menu. I told her no thanks. The manager never came over to our table to address the hair in my soup. I think it's very unprofessional that the manager didn't come over to our table and literally take a few seconds out of their day to address the issue. This is how you lose customers because to me it clearly shows that the manager didn't care or even think it was a huge deal that there was a hair in my soup. Any time there is a complaint or any discrepancy in a restaurant by a customer it is normally standard protocol for a manager to handle the situation accordingly. The manager at M.Y. China failed to do that! Of course the soup was taken off of our bill. 

Overall:

After having two bad experiences at M.Y. China I can definitely say that my girlfriend and I will never eat there again! M.Y. China must be losing a lot of customers especially if a manager can't take a few seconds out of his or her day to come apologize for a hair being in a customer's soup! M.Y. China has fallen off our go to list of Chinese restaurants. 

****ATTENTION!!! Martin Yan, if you're reading this you need to go back to this restaurant and regulate on them! If you don't I guarantee you'll be losing business on a consistent basis. I think you're an awesome chef and I know they're not producing the quality food or service that you represent.
author: David R.

description: We had our team lunch here. The service was friendly and quick for a party of 20 people. The food was great too !
author: Moses P.

description:
Martin Yan can still cook. I remember his shows from when I was a kid and it was cool to pop in for dinner. We arrived 30 min before closing and the place was still hopping.
The fact that it's in a mall is a little weird but once we were seated it felt like an actual Resturant. The decor was Asian Modern and the tables running down the center were creative in the ways that can be reconfigured. Lots of ways to seat large parties. 
Love the big open kitchen and watching everyone hustling around.
We shared our order and there was plenty for leftovers if that's your bag.  Our water glasses were never empty! We started with the Juicy Seafood Dumplings. They came out crazy hot and filled with flavor. The wrapper was a little thick. The Dumpling sauce was spicy and tangy. For dinner, we had the Szechuan Green Beans and the Chairman Maos Chicken. It was excellent. It was spicy and had loads of vegetables. The chicken was in big chunks and really moist on the inside. The exterior was lightly coated and not greasy. It was a great way to enjoy this dish.  
To top off this meal we ordered the Sugary Egg Puffs that were served with a bland Chantilly Cream, Chocolate Dipping Sauce and a perfectly complimentary Raspberry Coulis.  These deserts were light and fluffy and the perfect finale. 
Would definitely go back as the experience was great and food properly spiced and arrived hot.
author: Marti C.

description:
Came here today on a whim and ordered about 7 dishes split between me and my date.
We ate all of the 7 plates and were still hungry... So the portions are quite small compared to other places but the taste was very good and clean... for the most part. Our bill came out to be about $92 after tax and before tip.

We ordered the Big Knife Noodles, Wild Boar Lettuce Cups, the pickles trio, the wok lamb, hot and sour soup, spicy mango sorbet and the lychee panna cotta.
The lamb was ok... I definitely had better tasting lamb at other restaurants. It was also a little salty. 
The big knife noodles were good, the noodles itself were very good and it had a good amount of shrimp, scallops and mushrooms. The egg in this was salty for some reason. The pickles trio was really good! I enjoyed eating that in between eating other dishes. The wild board lettuce cups were pretty good too! I was sad they only come in 2. For dessert, definitely try the lychee panna cotta! If you're a fan of chrysanthemum... you'll definitely like this! For me, that was my favorite dish. The spicy mango sorbet was just OK... It tastes like mango sherbet from Talenti... the taste is quite similar so I wasn't too impressed there, yet it was still good.

BTW, the bathrooms are bit weird. So it's co-ed... I felt a little weirded out to share a sink with a man but the bathrooms are clean and the towels are so soft. Hah! 

Will plan to come back to try other dishes and during happy hour!... but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Christine N.

description: We had the GF items and they were very good.  Service was slow at first, it seemed like he had too many tables to cover.  Great location in mall and one block up Market to Golden Gate Theater.
author: tom d.

description: Location is convenient, drinks are good, but food is lacking. This is SF, so many better Chinese restaurants. Very bland.
author: Tinou B.

description:
The first time I went here I thought it was pretty good so the next time I went I was excited. Unfortunately, I was disappointed except for the forbidden rice--that is very good.  First, off what I like about this place is the location and the décor.  We sat on patio area under the dome and I love it there.  Now I must say my review is based on the vegetarian options more specifically the mapo tofu.  I got that both times, but the last time I went it was gooey and looked uneatable, but I was hungry so pushed through it.  The tofu was good, but the sauce just did not look right and it was way too salty for me. I think next time I will just get the green beans.  I was also disappointed that they use some chicken powder in the sweet and sour soup grr.  I actually got it last time not knowing that and it was good lol.  However, this time I realized it was not vegetarian so couldn't knowingly get it.  Oh well.  I'm sure I will give this place another go.  Perhaps next time will be better.  I will say that our sever was very attentive and sweet.


I've been back a few times after my last review and I will say it has improved so I gave this place one more star.  Recently, I've had the vegetarian claypot and tofu poppers--both were good.
author: Megan M.

description: Love the food and the beautiful presentation of the food. It is like enjoying the art to me. I like the fun energy of the Restuarant!
author: Zoe Z.

description: Came here with a group of 6 after a long day of travel. Our waiter took the time to explain the menu and offer ideas on how to mix and match starters, small plates, entrees and sides to keep all 6 of us happy. The hits for the night were the ribs, spicy seafood dumplings, seafood noodles, wild boar noodles, and Szechuan green beans. The only wish was for more variety in the veggies - lots of bok choi and celery, not enough "non-green" veggies in the noodles and veggie sides. Value was very good for the price, at least in San Francisco.
author: Craig D.

description: Popped in to see how bad could this place really be because reviews weren't that great to begin with. I must say I was stunned by the quality of food. It did give me motivation though that if places like these can stay in business, then I should open a place of my own. I definitely cook better than these guys. Horrible is an understatement for this food. I wish I had a better vocabulary to describe really really bad food but I don't. I know food is food but this was truly shit!
author: Ric D.

description:
Overall I liked the service, interior, and ambiance.  All the staff are helpful and friendly.  The food however was too salty for my taste.  Their water glasses are cute!

Pork and Black Truffle Dumplings- They were delicious, but I couldn't taste the black truffle, thus I don't think it was worth the price.  

Pork Belly Sliders- This was delicious! I love pork belly and the combo of the pickled radish and sauc. 

Forbidden Rice- Amazing texture and delicious taste, although it was a bit oily. 

Wild Boar Scissor Noodles:  I love the texture of this fat and chewy noodle, but Boar just tastes like regular pork to me!! It was my first time eating boar

Honey Glazed Lambchops- My favorite dish!!!! Meat was tender and juicy!  love love love it!

Shrimp with Gingko Nuts- Too salty, not that special to me. 

Mushrooms cooked in Duck Fat-  I could make this at home.  It did not taste special at all..

Sugar Egg Puffs for desserts- This was pretty good, it comes with a combination of three different dippings.  The cream is my favorite!!!
author: Emi K.

description:
Decent food, nice variety on the menu, and convenient location in the Westfield Mall. Reminds me of P.F. Changs, but a bit pricier (I guess you pay for location / convenience). I liked a few of the dishes, but I think you're better off paying for a cab (or Muni) and going to Inner Sunset for more authentic food.

Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup ($14) - A tad bit salty on the broth, there was enough rib eye, but I don't think I would get this again. Just okay.

Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles ($14) - Again, probably 30% more than what you'd pay at any other Chinese restaurant for the same taste. The noodles themselves were great and chewy - this was my favorite dish. I wasn't sure what wild boar was supposed to taste like, the meat tasted like regular pork to me.

Wok Seared Beef Filet ($16) - Honestly, I can't remember what this tasted like, it wasn't bad but it wasn't great. I don't think I'd get it again.

Stir Fried Green Beans ($8) - These were good and spicy. You can't mess up stir fried veggies + sauce too much.

If you like P.F. Chang's, you'll probably like this place. If you want something more authentic, go elsewhere. I liked the noodles the best, so I think that's probably a good bet. Everything is a tad overpriced (but if you're shopping and in the mood for Chinese food, and a sit-down place with nice atmosphere, this will do). I had higher hopes for this - sadly, I'm not itching to go back here.
author: Christina L.

description: Bad Service Ever！！！No body help when u need help！！！I ordered a drink，but I waited for 20 minutes！！！even when my friends got drink since they asked later than me，feel badwill not come here anymore!
author: Yuting Z.

description:
Who doesn't know Yan? I grew up watching him! I don't know why I never made any of his dishes? He was my favorite TV chef for years!!

I was shopping at Westfield. I hate shopping. It drives me to madness in 15min flat. I was hungry, too. That drives me to delirious spasms in 5 minutes flat!  On passing the restaurant I could smell the warm, savory scent of deliciousness coming from their open layout dining area. It was decided. 

My homegirl and I sat down and had a surprisingly delicious dinner! I mean, we were in a mall. Despite it begin in DT San Francisco I don't really think highly of mall restaurants. My China was lovely, the decor is dark and comfortable and the service was attentive and well paced. 

We ordered;
The calamari - spicy, crunchy and lightly battered. WIN!
Seafod Noodles- abalone, shrimp, egg and thick delicate noodles in an amazing sauce!
Peking Duck - DUCK TACOS!!!! So good. 

It was a lot of food for two and def worth the cost so I was completely satisfied. I'm going back.
author: Jay H.

description:
We returned for lunch at the invitation of the management, and enjoyed a much better meal than last time. We re-ordered the two noodle dishes from our last visit, and one of them - the Venison Chow Fun - was much better, with larger chucks of meat adding good flavor to the dish.  The other - Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles - was still pretty bland, with only small unevenly cut pieces of shredded meat.  Both these noodle dishes need much brighter flavors.

We tried two new dishes that were both very good - the Seven Spice Pork Ribs (generous serving, aggressively spicy) and the Stir Fried Baby Bok Choy (generous portion, good flavor, with prominent garlic taste). The Shiu Mai were fresh, hot and good as before - still had to request soy sauce!

In two visits, we've managed to try a sufficient number of good dishes to constitute a full meal, so perhaps we'll return soon.
author: Randall F.

description:
The xiao long bao here are excellent and are served in cute individual porcelain spoons which also serve a functional purpose of holding any soup that is spilled while you are eating them. Experienced xiao long bao eaters may call this cheating in the authentic sense, but in the end I'm all for innovation, why not give the rookies a way to eat like the pros.

The beef noodle soup here is also a good choice. The broth is a bit too salty for my taste but the noodles are legit, hand pulled and very chewy. They use high quality rib eye for the braised beef which adds a lot of tenderness to the texture and is a nice touch. 

Until Din Tai Fung opens up a location in downtown San Francisco, this will be my go to spot when I'm in the area for high quality xiao long bao along with northern style beef noodle soup. Looking forward to bumping into Chef Martin Yan for a photo next time I am I back.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Came here because I was in the neighborhood and wanted to try their hand pulled noodles.  The soup was very savory, similar to what you find from a Taiwanese Beef Noodle soup. It had just a hint of spice to it, which I enjoyed. The noodles were nice, but not fantastic.  The meat was decently plentiful.  However, I can find a lot better ways to spend $14.  Also had the Wild Boar dumplings.  So this was supposed to be like a Xiao Long Bao, but with boar meat.  Well I enjoyed the flavor of the filling, but the soup was lacking and the skin was atrocious.  It fell apart and didn't have the chewiness to keep it all intact. Needless to say, when you try to pick the dumpling up, it falls apart on you.

Place has a very nice ambiance, and is definitely geared more towards westerners.  I'm one and done here.
author: m k.

description: Yan can cook!! Enough said .
author: Matthew R.

description:
I came by today to meet up with a friend and I'm slightly disappointed with the customer service.  There's 3 bartenders working and 2 of them is slow and obviously not paying attention. Thankfully my favorite bartender Jackie is working but she's obviously the only one running around. Since I see her running back and forth, I was hoping the other 2 bartenders would see that I'm ready to submit my order and there's other patrons here that would like to receive service.

I get that working in the service industry is hard, but if you're going to goof around, maybe you should look into working in a other field. I think I'll ask Jackie when she's working so I can come here only on those days and hopefully avoid these 2 goofballs.
author: Lo L.

description:
M. Y. China is one of those high-end, sanitized Chinese restaurants that you might go to if you have an important business meeting, or you want to take your parents somewhere with interesting food, but (borrowing from the Will & Grace Dim Sum episode), not "too interesting".

All these unremarkable qualities aside, my biggest problem with the restaurant was that it was mostly open-air to the 4th floor of the Westfield mall, and as a result was super-noisy, for what otherwise looks and feels like a high-end restaurant. So you get all the appearances of an expensive meal without any of the calm, relaxing atmosphere.

The food, it should be said, is quite good. We ordered a few different noodle dishes, some heavily-cumined lamb chops, some fresh-tasting pea shoots, and some excellent roast duck with all the trimmings. My soup dumpling had a hole in it, but was otherwise very tasty. The service was friendly and efficient. The noodle-swinger (yes, this is SFW) is hypnotic. I can verify that the scissor-cut noodles are, in fact, cut with scissors.

So in conclusion, if you're a traveler with an expense account, eating on your own (or maybe with a coworker), and you don't have a lot to talk about, this might be a good spot to try.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I was really excited about this restaurant and I finally had the chance to go and it wasn't all that great. The drinks were good but the dishes were nothing special. We ordered the following:

Drink:
-East Meets West - baby chrysanthemum infused with vodka, honey, and lemon juice
      -this drink was delicious! 

Appetizer:
-Tea Smoked Pork Belly Slider - Good, but I didn't get any tea flavor
-Chilled Eggplant - Best appetizer, especially since I love eggplant!
-Pork and Black Truffle Juicy Dumplings - This is the main reason for 3 stars! The most disappointing appetizer! Minus only getting 5 dumplings for $18.00, you cannot taste ANY truffle at all! I could see black specs inside the dumpling but even when I picked out the black chunks, I couldn't taste any truffle! Very disappointing!!!!

Entrees:
-Five Spice Pork Ribs - This was a good dish except the ribs were a tad overcooked and slightly dry
-Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood - This dish was a good dish with seafood and black colored noodles from the squid ink

It's not a bad restaurant but it's also nothing really special.
author: Tammy W.

description:
I recently ate at MY China w/my GF prior to a performance at the Golden Gate Theater.  I hesitate to give it only 2 stars but it is really all that it deserves.  Here's why.

I did not expect MY China to prepare "authentic" home cooked Chinese food but I did expect them to prepare an elevated version of Chinese dishes that would justify the high prices they charge at this restaurant and IMO they failed to do this.

First off, I must say that we had a very pleasant server who accommodated our request for a change in tables but she was not very well trained.  She did not know what a Blue Sapphire Martini was and another server had to come to our table w/her for clarification about the drink.  She also could not answer some questions that we had about the menu. She got the answers for us but had to ask, which I think is an indication of lack of training.  

Not the fault of the server but one of the answers we got was unacceptable for a restaurant that aspires to be a high quality restaurant.  I was interested in the steamed fish and asked what kind of fish it was, how large the fish was and whether it was fresh or frozen.  I was told it was sea bass, that it was only a 6 oz portion and that it was FROZEN.   You can buy a fresh 2 lb sea bass for about $10 at the fish market and, even if MY China doesn't have the room for a fish tank, they can certainly source FRESH fish for a $32 dish.  Obviously, we passed on that.

In order to get a feel for the type of food MY China offered, we ordered the Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders, the Mu Shu Pork Tacos, the Salt & Pepper Calamari and the Abalone in Oyster Essence.  We also ordered the Kung Pao Chicken, Big Knife Fish Noodles and a side of Sichuan Green Beans.

Let me start by saying the BEST dish that we were served was the Abalone in Oyster "Sauce."  It was the closest thing to REAL Chinese food that we were served and it was EXCELLENT!!!  Well worth the $18 for the roughly 3-4" long abalone that was served whole.  It was tender and succulent dressed in properly seasoned oyster sauce. 

However, the rest of the dishes were either uninspiring or totally off-putting.

The pork sliders and mu shu pork tacos were just ok.  I like bacon and pork belly and was hoping the sliders would be unique. There was nothing particularly WRONG about them, they were just bland and uninteresting.  

The Mu Shu Pork sliders was what you'd expect from MY China -- a modern take on the classic mu shu pork dish.  It came w/mu shu flavored pork pieces in a bun (thicker than you'd get w/a normal mu shu pork dish) but it didn't have the same taste/texture of mu shu pork that is commonly served.  I particularly missed the slivered green onions and hoisin sauce that is typically offered w/mu shu pork.  It may have been in there but I didn't notice it.  An ok dish but again relatively bland and uninteresting.

The Salt/Pepper Calamari was NOTHING like the salt/pepper calamari you'd get at a typical Chinese restaurant. For one this, it was VERY greasy.  I liked that they included the tentacles, which many Americanized Chinese restaurants leave out because some people can't handle the sight of them (let alone eat them), BUT the  tentacles and other body parts were very large and not bite sized.  The coating on the calamari was also so soaked in oil, it did not have any "crunch" which you would normally get w/fried calamari and there were really wasn't much spice in the dish.

Kung Pao Chicken is a very common dish served in almost every Chinese restaurant, whether it's Cantonese, Mandarin or actually Szechuan where it originated.  The dish we got had very large deep fried pieces of chicken in it; I prefer it stir fried.  Like the calamari it was VERY greasy and, although it had a lot of dried red chilies in it, it oddly did NOT taste very spicy

The Big Knife Fish Noodles was basically seafood chow mein, which supposedly included scallops, shrimp and calamari along w/shitaki & enoki mushrooms in XO sauce. Saw the shitaki/enoki mushrooms but didn't see much in the way of scallops or shrimp. This dish was also VERY greasy and, despite the XO sauce, seemed bland and not adequately seasoned.  

Lastly, read good reviews about the Sichuan Green Beans on Yelp which we thought would be an appropriate companion w/the chicken and seafood.  However, there was really nothing special about this dish either, except that it was also VERY greasy and lacked spice, which one would expect w/a Sichuan dish.

All in all a GREAT disappointment given the generally poor quality of the dishes we received and the cost - about $160 including the tax/tip, the martini (which was very good) and a bottle of Prosecco (which was also acceptable although an ice bucket was not available to chill it.

If I were to eat at MY China again, which is unlikely, I'd sit at the bar and just order from their discounted Happy Hour menu instead.  Unfortunately, I think anyone else eating/drinking there would fair much better doing that as well.
author: Martin C.

description:
There's folks out there that would contend that you could find lots of places serving Chinese food of equal or better quality at a fraction of what M.Y. China charges.

To which I say, they are probably absolutely correct.

But out of those places, which ones offer a full bar, specialty cocktails, and excellent service? There's probably very few options remaining that meet all those criteria.

If you're like me and feel like having a delicious cocktail and some nice ambiance with your Walnut Shrimp and Hand Pulled Noodles once in a while, then this place is for you. 

Other than the fact that it's inside of a mall (which probably only adds to the premium you're paying for the food), I think this place is pretty good.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Dinner date with hubz. Went here for the second time & enjoyed their food, wine & dessert. A nice place too!
I recommend that you should make a reservation since they seem to be always full & busy.
Try their forbidden rice, seared beef & the dimsum. Don't forget to order wine, i specifically love the grawerstraminer great dessert wine. Will come back here for sure. :)
author: Kc A.

description:
The one thing I really miss since moving from the Sunset to SOMA is good and inexpensive Chinese food. I had a random craving and was going to have dinner with my sister, so I decided it was the perfect opportunity to try out Martin Yan's new restaurant! I knew it was going to be a bit pricey since it is Martin Yan's restaurant and it's in the mall where a bunch of tourists go shopping, but I was willing to suck it up just to try it at least once.

Walking in, we had no problem getting our table (I made reservations online just in case). Upon being seated, we were asked if we wanted complimentary still or sparkling water. My sister and I both requested sparkling water and a bottle of sparkling water was brought to our table. Since it's nearing Chinese New Year, they had a special menu that started at $68/person. Definitely not what I wanted to spend on a casual dinner, so we opted to order ala carte.

A waitress introduced herself to us, but then for some reason, once we were ready to order, another guy took our order and ended up being our waiter for the rest of the meal. 

Anyways, we ordered the whole wheat pot stickers, the walnut shrimp, and the hong kong style crispy noodles with chicken. We asked if they could do the scissor cut noodles with chicken instead of wild boar and they wouldn't do that substitution (fail!).

We got our pot stickers to start and while they looked pretty, they lacked flavor. Even the dipping sauce that appeared to have chili flakes in it wasn't very spicy or flavorful. When our entrees came out, the walnut shrimp came out first and then about 3-5 minutes later, our hong kong style crispy noodles with chicken dish arrived. The waiter promptly came to our table and apologized a few times, saying that he had no control over when the dishes came out, regardless of how it was written on the ticket. This was both a bit awkward (I honestly didn't care about waiting the few minutes for the second entree, yet he kept apologizing) and telling of the gaps in their service. Regardless, this is where I really got disappointed: the noodles, although nice and crispy, didn't have much flavor from the sauce. Additionally, the chicken's texture was a bit odd to me.
