I loved that they didn't skimp and that they were bit chunks of chicken breast, but when it was lacking in taste, none of that mattered. I think I picked out the mushrooms and baby bok choy to eat in hopes of using the textural differences to make up for the missing flavor. The walnut shrimp wasn't the walnut shrimp I'm typically used to and was definitely disappointing. Although the quality of the ingredients was known by the size of the shrimp, they almost seemed a bit dry. The sweet, fatty sauce that usually coats the shrimp was nearly obsolete! There was also plenty of sliced cucumbers accompanying the shrimp, but very little of the candied walnuts.

To be honest, the restaurant design is both aesthetically pleasing and functional. Tables that slide together and apart to accommodate parties of various sizes and an open kitchen that allowed you to see the chefs make the noodles from scratch were some of my highlights. Additionally, the staff seemed to be on par with quick, efficient, and professional service. The food, while it was obvious it was prepared with quality ingredients, lacked flavor. For the price, I would expect something much more tasty, wanting me to devour it all, rather than leave half on the plate.
author: Leana L.

description: I have been to San Fran at least 50 times.  I have crawled all over town searching out alleged great Chinese with 2500 yelp reviews, to alleged hidden gem store fronts.  None have been better than here.  A lifetime ago, before the Food Network, and even BC (before cable) Martn Yan had a show on PBS--Yan Can Cook.  This and Julia Child were the only cooking shows to watch.  His namesake place, in a mall on Union Square is the last place i expected GREAT Chinese food.  From the handmade noodles. to the great wine list everything was excellent.  We ate here twice in 16 hours.  Dont judge a book by its cover
author: AV G.

description: Went for a last minute holiday celebration with friends.  Good service and food was better than expected.  Not quite used to co-ed restrooms though..
author: G W.

description:
I was going to write a generous 4 star review for this place but something happened with one of your bartenders that made me lower it.   

So, mothers day.  Parents decided to celebrate here since they've always have gone here before with no fuss or problem.   My dad arrives early at the bar before our reservation.   We sit at the bar for a good 5 to 10 minutes until the bartender finally takes our order.  He notes it, takes it down (in a hurry mind you) and IMMEDIATELY starts chatting with some customers he was familiar with.   So  this is the part that pissed me off, royally. 

1.  We just ordered two drinks, a cocktail, beer and an appetizer- nothing special.  He not only hurries with the order but manages to cheese it up with customers he knew. 

2.  10 minutes have passed and we're still wondering where our drinks are.    The bartender has already served his "favorite" customers and here we are still wondering where did our measly three orders go.  

3. Finally 15-20 minutes have passed and this bartender was still socializing with customers while NEW customers were coming in and their drinks were also being served with haste.  

4. Fearing that this wait for our order might make us lose our table, we finally we decide to just cancel.  We ask the bartender what happened to the order and all he can say RUDELY and BLUNTLY was "oh okay i'll just transfer it".  

No apologies, nothing.  Like as if he were taking away from his social hour.  

And continues to socialize some more.     

This bartender needs work
We were avid fans of this restaurant but now not so much.    

***Although this experience was pretty bad especially for mothers day, your floor manager Christopher and our server, Daniel made an AWESOME  job with the service.  (Gave extra tip)  Much props for these guys.   


So the take away:  the food is good but your bartender needs to work on expediting and customer service/satisfaction (or just let him go, seriously).    He might've not been aware but still, it affects customers greatly.
author: Geo D.

description:
A new hip Chinese place in the mall near Bloomingdales on the 4th floor.  Very nice decor.  We got there around 4pm, so they were only serving at the bar with drinks and snacks.  So we didn't get to sample the full menu.

The drinks are pretty good, can't say what I had (East Meets West) awed me, but it wasn't bad.  My two other friends had drinks and liked it too.  The Mai Tai was really strong.

The food was pretty good.  The green beans was very flavorful.  The Bang Bang Chicken Wings are the right crisp and and flavor, will definitely go back for this.  The other thing that was pretty good is the Wild Boar Juicy Dumplings.  It came out individually in their own spoon, which was useful and all the juices are definitely there.  

I think I would go back and try the full menu sometimes. Although I think it is a bit pricey.  And who doesn't like how it is right next to Bloomingdales, Mango, Zara?  Perfect lunch and shopping afternoon place.  :)
author: Lilly W.

description:
This has become one of our go-to places to eat in SF.

I really enjoy getting the beef noodle soup here.  The beef is flavorful, there's a good mix of vegetables, the noodles are a good texture, and the broth is rich and flavorful.  It's not necessarily like other beef noodle soups I've had, but it's one I thoroughly enjoy.

Aside from the noodle soup, the restaurant has a rather diverse selection of items to choose from, and they are all a cut above your standard chinese food fare.  The dessert menu is great as well.  Be assured ... if you order the Peking Duck or Crab, you will get a lot of food!

The weakest item I've had at M.Y. China was the Kung Pao chicken, which is surprisingly bland and dry.  I usually judge restaurants by the Kung Pao chicken, but, in this case, it's the exception and not the rule.

Of course, to top things off, this place is not cheap, but not very expensive either.  There's also a lot of seating so I've found it hasn't been hard to drop in and get seated.  To sum it up, I can always count on a solid meal when I come to M.Y. China.
author: Richard K.

description:
I had such a bad dining experiene in this place, it was actually COMICAL. But I can only imagine the disappointment my boyfriend felt having such a terrible experience at a restaurant owned by one of his culinary idols. 

We ordered the bang bang chicken wings, hong kong crispy noodle and wok seared beef. The food was ok, though, the bang bang chicken wings was actually quiet delicious - but the service? HORRIBLE. 

It is one of our pet peeves when our main entrees are served before our appetizers. The seared beef was served before our appetizers, and without the side of rice. We stared at the beef while we waited for our appetizers and the rest of our food. Our cripsy noodle then comes - and we're still waiting on our appetizer. I flag down the waiter to ask where it is.. apparently, "amber forgot to punch it in" OK. 

The crispy noodle was good, but the chicken that came with it was BLAND. So we asked for some chili paste, 10 minutes...30 minutes .. no chili paste. Then the waiter comes to refill our water and says "ohh you guys wanted chili paste right?" 10 minutes..30 minutes later.." STILL NO CHILI PASTE. We finished our food, still no chili paste. Then another waiter comes around bearing some chili paste and serves it to  the guests a couple of tables over. Confused,  the customer rejects it. The waiter then YELLS around  "did anyone order chili paste?!" When we tried to call him to let him know we asked for it  but we didn't need it anymore (Since we'd already eaten our food), he'd already walked away. 

The entire time, my boyfriend and I just watched as the joke of a service they had in the surrounding tables continues. Food and drinks were continously served at wrong tables. The table across us had a mother andher son impatiently waiting to get attention from a waiter.  The funniest thing was watching a waiter clean a table and as he walked away with the dirty dishes, a chopstick falls on the floor - instead of picking it up, he kicks the chopstick around on the floor. LMFAO, my boyfriend and I couldn't help but laugh. The service was such a joke that at one point, I forgot I was at Martin Yan's restaurant. If it wasn't for the cookbook with his face displayed all over the place, I would have thought I was in some random chinese restaurant, but then those restaurants would probably have better service. 

Our waiter comped the bang bang chicken wings and was eventually served once we were done eating. If it wasn't for the those delicious chicken wings, I would have left the restaurant so annoyed. 

Our waiter was nice and he offered us comped dessert which we didn't take as we were afraid it would take a long time to be served. I understand they were busy but we expected better trained waiters. 

Later that night, I asked my boyfriend if he still considered Martin Yan as one of his culinary idols - he looked at me with such disappointment and with a sigh he says "After that experience, not anymore".
author: Joey D.

description: One of my favorites in SF.  Small plates, fried rock fish, original style cocktails.  Happy hour !  A must go to at least once. Then of course it helps that Martin Chan was one of my moms favorite cooking show. Loved it that they had one Top Chef challenge here!
author: Diane V.

description:
I really liked this restaurant. It is aesthetically pleasing - no detail was overlooked! The open concept kitchen was also really cool because you can see your food being made. You can taste that everything is homemade and really fresh. The dumpling sizes are huge, too! The service was really great! 

My only qualm is the tables for two are pretty close together, so there is no room to put shopping bags. But it's neat that those tables can slide together if you have a larger party!
author: Rachel H.

description:
We decided to give the Peking Duck another try. The new presentation was very nice and we really enjoyed it. It seemed like much more skin than before and the extra serving of meat added to the dish.
 
The other dishes we ordered (five spice pork ribs $18, Shandong beef rolls $9, and wok sauteed mushrooms $11) were all very good too. 

Wish the size of the table was bigger. It was way too small to accommodate all the dishes we ordered.
author: D'Andy C.

description:
This place is busy. The wait is long unless you sit at the counter and watch the cooking action. Had the hot and sour soup, seafood and pork dumplings, scissor cut wild boar noodles and honey walnut prawns and milk oolong tea. 
Sitting at the counter is like a dinner show. All of the chefs and the flaming woks. Service is great bringing dishes out , refiling water and tea. 
The hot and sour soup is different with lots of vinegar and spice. It was too spicy for our spice wimp. 
The seafood dumplings come in a green wrapper but very good. These are spicy as well. Not as hot as the soup. The pork dumpling come on a spoon in the steamer. They are very tasty with the broth on the spoon. 
The scissor cut noodles are on the thick side but are great with the sauce and wild boar. 
The honey walnut prawns have a twist. The mayo sauce is mixed with wasabi. Its a very nice flavor combo.
The bathroom is funky. One sink area for unisex stalls.
author: Bacon G.

description:
MY China, you outdid yourself!  After my review about our last experience there, I received a message from their management inviting us to dine there again, on their dime!  What a generous offer!  My partner and I happily accepted, and we could not have asked for a better time!!  We went back for dinner last Tuesday.  Our server, Victoria, was very personable and genuine.  The food we ordered was just as top-notched as the last time.  And we received our leftovers exactly as we expected   

My China, you've earned yourself a couple of fans!
author: Yvette F.

description: Fantastic food, great service and very well priced even though it has the "expensive" look and feel to it. Would definitely recommend :-)
author: Chad D.

description:
We had seen this place on Check Please Bay Area and this season on Top Chef so we decided to try it today after shopping in Union Square.  It was tasty! High end Chinese, by Yan can cook himself, Martin Yan, tucked away in the fourth floor of the mall.  

The vibe is classy, bustling, families and date night (it being close to the movie theater). We got a seat right away at the counter with a view of the open kitchen- hopping on a Saturday night. Service was quick, attentive, and very knowledgable and accommodating of my food allergies.  

We ordered somewhat randomly, but all was great in the end-  Honey BBQ Pork, seafood dumplings with spicy soy sauce (hot with a touch of citrus), and Grandma's Gai Lan with Chinese sausage (because it looked so great on our neighbors' plate). The pork was not what we were expecting, but very good- sliced BBQ cured pork In a light, sweet honey glaze sauce. Seafood dumpling were steamed, in a spinach noodle wrapper, and delicious. Gai Lan (Chinese broccoli) was a highlight, just crunchy enough, with lots of lightly cooked garlic, and just curling slices of sausage.  All that and a Buddha beer in a beautiful Buddha molded green glass bottle. Prices are on the higher side for Chinese, though matched by quality and service for sure.  Next time we'll try some noodles!
author: j-mo h.

description:
So initially my wife and I happened to be seated in the coldest, most loud, crampiest (I'm positive that should be a word) section of the restaurant, but after just a few moments the Manager Matthew came to our rescue. He was polite, professional and genuine. 

Daniel our waiter was really amazing as well.

Thanks to you both for everything
author: David A.

description: Chinese food try to be "fancy ". Lmfao. Horrible place, food, serves. Don't get attracted by the decorations.
author: Arafat A.

description: The food was great and the place was packed.  Better to make a reservation like we did.
author: Peter G.

description: This place is amazing.   One of the best lobster dishes I have had in a restaurant.  (salt and pepper lobster) We are still talking about the meal that we had two days ago! Also had the duck (my go to at this restaurant).  The staff is exceptional and go out of their way to make things right. During the holiday season you cant go wrong with Santa on the 4th floor right outside the restaurant.  This place is special for any occasion.  The decor and open kitchen make it a great place to entertain. Great wine list too!  It's nice to be able to get wines that aren't just CA wines, and also to be in a Chinese restaurant and have a well balanced wine list that compliments the food!
author: C B.

description: Sat at the bar on a Sunday afternoon for lunch because they were busy!  We ordered a few things to share: honey walnut shrimp and the pork tacos (which are a MUST).  In hind site I probably would have decided to get two orders of the tacos.  Tacos at a Chinese restaurant?  Trust me, they're yummy!  Verdict?  The food is good, a little on the pricier side.  Would go again for the tacos.
author: Cass H.

description:
As a person who grew up eating chinese food, I think this place is great... So good, in fact, that I've been here at least 6 times and have ordered pretty much everything on the menu.

Things I love:

+ Squid ink noodle
+ Dim Sum
+ Shanghai dumplings
+ Spare ribs
+ Mushu tacos
+ Sugar Egg Puffs
+ Their hot sauce
+ The atmosphere
+ And above all, being able to watch the chefs make their noodles from the kitchen

Things to watch out for:

+ Service can be spotty, but no one has ever been rude
+ Prices. Well, that is if you're being cheap. Sure, it's more expensive than Chinatown food, but you're paying for the location and atmosphere. I didn't find it any more expensive than a comparable American sitdown.
author: winnie t.

description:
LEGIT beef noodle soup. Right portion, right thickness of noodles, delicious cuts of beef, and yummy broth!

The kitchen is open so it's also fun to watch them stretch the noodles.
author: Den Y.

description:
Wow this place is sooo good! Forbidden Rice was the best fried rice I ever had! 
The atmosphere and service was great, the prices of everything I felt was about a good $3 over priced. Considering the atmosphere, food and service I understand why it is pricey, but I just thought that it is still inside a mall and it wasn't mind blowing. If everything was $2-$3 less I wouldn't feel like I overpaid so much and this place would have a strong 5-stars.
author: Tim V.

description:
An example of McDonald-ization of ethnic food gone bad. I came here for a celebration lunch with my coworkers and will not be returning. We ordered: 

-Hot & sour soup
-Shiu mai
-Steamed bbq pork bao
-Har gow
-Wild boar juicy dumplings
-Hong Kong Crispy Noodle With Chicken
-Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles
-Stir Fried Green Beans
-Forbidden Rice

I was not impressed with the food whatsoever. I'd rather walk an extra 15minutes to Chinatown and get some really authentic Chinese food. I could sum up the food in 2 words: overpriced and underwhelming. 

What made things worse was the service. Our party ordered sparkling water and they would refill with still water. We ordered rice and asked that it be brought out immediately and it was brought towards the end of the meal. We all ordered different teas and drinks and all the drink orders were mixed up. The one hot tea that we ended up receiving was so flavorless that we actually thought we were drinking plain, boiled water without any tea in it, but there was tea in it. 

What you pay for here is the well-known name (Martin Yan), nice decor, and convenient location (underneath the rotunda at the Westfield mall). Is it worth it? Maybe if you're shopping in the mall and want a quick Chinese food fix. Would I ever return? No.
author: Monelle A.

description:
For starters, I only sit at the bar. I know that has something to do with my higher review marking; if I need something, someone is usually there to take care of my requests pretty quickly. Since my last review, I have become a "regular" here.

Wok Seared Beef - I am a huge fan of this salad (look under Wok items)  - I love the combination of the bitter arugula with the sweet, tangy beef. I also get a side of vinegar to ease the sweetness. 
Last time my beef was more on the well-done side, which is overcooked for me, but it was still edible.
Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles - I liked the noodles, and the few pieces of boar, but didn't care for the rest of the dish. 

This time, my Wok Seared Beef was perfect. 
Beijing Knife Cut Noodles - I got this after asking for a recommendation. I liked the butteriness of the noodles which reminded me of Alfredo flavor. However, I didn't really like the combo of the noodles with the rest of the dish. I think if it was separated I would liked them more..

The friendliness, customer service, and food quality has been consistent since October 2013. A couple hiccups, but nothing horrendous. 

Lastly, I am usually entertained as I sit at the bar - watching the people outside in the dome area, or the cooks behind the glass, or watching the bartenders as they make fancy cocktails.
author: Anisha G.

description:
Having never heard of this place, I didn't know what to expect when I came here for a small get-together with some former colleagues...except maybe that this place serves Chinese cuisine (just a lucky guess from the name). (; With such low expectations, I was definitely in for a pleasant surprise (especially after finding out M.Y. stood for Martin Yan)!

This is not your typical hole-in-the-wall, bad-service Chinese restaurant. In fact, far from it! Upon entering through the front, one of their hosts greeted me by my name when I told him that I was meeting two former colleagues for dinner and then he proceeded to escort me to the table. My immediate thought was: 'Whoa! What just happened here?! What kind of Chinese restaurant is this?!' 

As we walked through the restaurant, the second most striking difference was their décor; it was sleek and modern yet elegant and tactful. Not only was each table covered with white, fancy-looking linens, but each table was also decorated with classy dinnerware. Needless to say, I was impressed by their exceptional customer service and decor, especially since I'm so used to the negligent customer service I receive from most Asian restaurants.

Though the menu is reminiscent of your typical Chinese restaurant, it won't come out looking like your ordinary Chinese food. All of the dishes that we ordered were creatively designed to include many bright-colored food and beautifully arranged on modern plates or bowls. The food presentation was absolutely amazing! It certainly deserves a picture-taking moment.

Their food tastes just as delicious as they look! We ordered...
+Spicy Seafood Dumplings: This appetizer includes six dumplings perfectly wrapped in a bright spinach wrap and stuffed with scallops and shrimp. The sauce gives the dumplings a kick of flavor without being overpowered with the spiciness.
+Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood: The squid ink snap noodles are sautéed with vegetables and a variety of seafood, including shrimp, scallops, and calamari in a creamy sauce. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this dish! It's absolutely delicious.

(Note: When they presented us with this dish we were confused and thought they had given us the wrong dish because we were expecting to see long noodle strands. So, imagine our surprise when we saw short, dark, doughy-looking pieces of something that looked really foreign to us. Yes, those foreign things are in fact the squid ink noodles.)

+Stir Fried Green Beans: These crunchy green beans are sautéed in a light, somewhat spicy sauce, and are a wonderful complement to the entrée dishes we ordered.
+Kung Pao Chicken: This dish includes a combination of stir-fried chicken, jalapeño, peanuts, and crunchy red dried peppers. The crunchy red dried peppers will surprise you!
+Forbidden Rice: This is a combination of red rice, brown rice, barley, and wolfberries. With so much flavor and texture packed in this rice dish, it certainly didn't taste like my usual, healthy brown rice dish. Definitely a nice addition to the other dishes!
+Sugar Egg Puffs: Four huge egg puffs filled with a custard cream filling served with three different kinds of sauces, including dark chocolate, vanilla bean Chantilly crème, and raspberry coulis. It tasted delicious with or without the sauce.

I must admit that the portions are much smaller than what I had expected, especially for the price we were charged. But, the phenomenal presentation and delicious food, accompanied with the great customer service and beautiful décor do seem to justify the higher prices. Overall, it's a great place to enjoy great food with great company! (:

Highlights:
+Fantastic customer service
+Beautiful décor and food presentation
+Delicious food
-A bit pricey
author: Jacque C.

description:
We enjoyed our lunch we had at M.Y. China but like everyone says it is expensive. As long as you know that going in you should enjoy.  We started out with the steamed BBQ pork bao and the jasmine pearl tea.  Both were really good.  For the main meal I had the beef hand pulled noodle soup which was the bets thing out of the meal.  My wife had the honey glazed walnut shrimp which were good but not excellent.

The service at the beginning was not very good but we got a new waiter when they saw that we were looking to order and after that the service was great.  The decor is very cool for a restaurant in a mall too.
author: Blake B.

description:
I encourage you to go elsewhere. Please support the mom and pop chinese restaurants and you'll save some money too!!! Also, I think this place caters to tourists who dont know that chinatown or Panda Express is close :)

For more, please read on: --

My friend and I decided to try this restaurant out because 1) it's in the mall and we love the mall and 2) we love trying new places to eat. 

We didn't have reservations. It was a Sunday night at around 7pm and we were seated right away. There were empty tables in the room. I guess that should have been the first sign since 7pm is primetime. Try getting a primetime table at an awesome food place, like Slanted Door, good luck with that!  :p

The waiter didnt know what he was saying or doing for that matter. I think maybe because its a new restaurant. We asked for recommendations and he had to look at the menu to see what was in it. Eh, really?? 

We ordered 2 dishes: 
(1) The scissor cut noodles with boar. 
(2) [the raved about] squid ink noodles.

First of all, they told us the meat was boar in our scissor cut notes, but I swear it was like meat that would have come out of a $4 noodle dish in Chinatown. It was not like any 'boar' i have ever tasted. The dish was tasty but not for $14 freakin bucks!! I would order it again if it was $6/7 max (and I'm being generous). We thought that they gave us the wrong dish because the boar was so 'cheap' tasting and you dont even cut the noodles with scissors like the waiter said. Not convinced? See for yourself but dont say that I didn't warn you. 

Then -- the squid ink noodles is NOT noodles (see below). It's like square pieces of pasta. My friend and I were really excited to swirl our forks around some noodles. Nay! Didn't happen. Disappointment once again. It's misinterpretion if you ask me.

NOODLES, by definition, is the following as per dictionary.com:
a narrow strip of unleavened egg dough that has been rolled thin and dried, boiled, and served alone or in soups, casseroles, etc.

I mean it was tasty, but not $18 tasty and its not even noodles.

So basically you get my point. I didn't like the place. I mean the food was tasty and edible, but not worth the price. I really wish I went to Chinatown instead, which is a 20 minute walk from the mall. I would have gotten 'noodles' AND saved alot of money. Next time I will.
author: Cicely T.

description:
I went in on Sunday and was seated right away, with a reservation of course :) 
I was in and out in a little less than an hour, & I was never rushed. 
I have recently taken to dining by myself, so I ordered several small plates in order to have a greater range of foods to try, as opposed to a single entree. Anyhow this is what I ordered: 
CUP OF HOT & SOUR SOUP $5
       *too spicy to finish, and I'm from mexican descent ! I can handle spicy, 
        however I couldn't handle that soup.
BAKED ROAST CHICKEN BAO (2)  $5
       *absolutely delicious, and perfectly sized.
PORK DUMPLINGS (5) $8
       *soup, dumplings, which Gianna informed me of, however these things retain
        heat for an extremely looooong time, and I almost burned myself. 
WILD BOAR SCISSOR CUT NOODLES $14 
       *absolutely delicious. Thick noodles, perfectly sautéed, and seasoned, and a
        huge portion, enough for left overs!
                                                                   total: $34.80 + tip
I was too full, so I have to come back to try their drinks + desserts.
author: Ericka M.

description: ALWAYS ON POINT!!! This time my lady and I sat at the bar and Zhen, aka Derrick was a smooth operator.  Very gracious, energetic, quick on his feet, professional and knew what we wanted to order. We are coming here again and again!
author: Ed F.

description: Pretty pricey, but the food here was pretty good. My mom really wanted to try this place so I took her here along with my brother and his gf. The brother's gf is vegetarian so she had the longevity noodles. According to her, the portion was small and the noodles were bland. She was still hungry afterwards, and I felt bad for her. But, everything else we ordered was very yummy. We ordered the fish noodles, beef noodle soup, Hong Kong style crispy noodles, wild boar scissor cut noodles, and beef rolls. Everything was very tasty, and I especially liked the wild boar noodles and beef noodle soup. For dessert, we had the Macau egg tarts and sugar egg puffs. The egg tarts weren't very good, but I really liked the egg puffs. They even put on a little show with noodle pulling. My mom was a happy camper.
author: Karen L.

description: Lively place with lots of energy.  Good for groups. And try lots of things. Our waiter was very good.  Very personable and attentive. I thought the servers (people who brought the food) could use some etiquette lessons. For a nice place like this, these servers still act like a greasy spoon diner in Chinatown.  They just throw the dish anywhere on the table, no matter where it is.  They don't even try to make room in the middle. I found that annoying, this my 3-star rating.
author: Neal H.

description:
A wonderful place to visit if you're in the Westfield Mall.  Travel up to the top level to visit this Martin Yan restaurant featured on the PBS show Check Please Bay Area with Leslie Sbrocco. 

My experience here was pleasant.  The host greeted and seated me politely and promptly placing me in front of the chef's window where I got to observe the cooking process.  I opted this visit to stick to happy hour specials to accompany my cocktail and to my surprise everything was excellent.  I had the fried chicken wings, fried tofu, scissor cut noodles and an excellent bourbon cocktail that was to die for. 

I will definitely come back for dinner.  Care to join me?
author: Dan R.

description: I have been to here two times. Good dining environment, delicious food,and great service. I feel comfortable in here. I think it's a great place to have a party with your friends,cuz many kind of drinks you could try.
author: Maggie T.

description:
I used to watch Yan Can Cook growing up and I met Martin Yan at a cooking demonstration during my freshman year of college, and I went here for dinner on NYE. So to say I had high expectations would be an understatement... but somehow they totally lived up to them!

I was the first one of a party of eight to check in. The hostess and host were very friendly and offered me the option of waiting outside, at the bar, or sitting at the table. I sat at the bar and watched the bartender make a few drinks before deciding on Pimm'yin Cup No. 1. It was a very good cocktail. Once the others arrived, I also got to taste their choices of Under the Bronze Bell and East Meets West and those were also pretty tasty.

Once we were seated, Chef Chen came over with one of the other chefs and showed us his noodle dough stretching skills (it's somewhat similar to watching the guys in a pizzeria toss the pizza dough). Our waiters were really friendly and were happy to offer suggestions on the menu. Since we had a large group, we got to try most of the menu. My favorites were:
Spicy Seafood Dumplings
Hong Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken
Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood
Purple Yam Croquette
Sugar Egg Puffs

These were good with minor flaws:
Har Gow (the dumpling stuck to the bottom of the steamer)
Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp (slightly more breading then I would like)

But these were really tiny faults and they would have gotten 5 stars, except that I ordered Chairman Mao's Chicken that never appeared. It wasn't a big deal since we had more than enough food but still would've been nice to try...
author: Dani D.

description:
Lunch was amazing. We ordered Baby Bok Choy, Shanghai Dumplings, Chicken Feet, Pan Fried BBQ Pork Buns, Pork and Shrimp Fried Rice, Vegi Spring Rolls, Green Onion Pancakes and Shrimp Dumplings. 

Everything was hot and tasty. Will certainly be coming back.
author: Caine H.

description: Definitely a must! My friend and I came here while touring around San Francisco. The restaurant is beautiful! We sat up at the bar and was approached by an extremely friendly bartender who suggested a few starters and entrees. We started off with the potstickers which were out of this world! The sauce for it was phenomenal. I was dipping my chop sticks in the sauce once the potstickers were eaten- that's how food it was! We had the chow fun noodles for our entree. Everything was perfect size, great flavor, and excellent service. Can't wait to come back here again!
author: Zoey O.

description:
We saw a rather large mouse in the dining room and the staff seemed way too nonchalant about it for my liking. Plus Yelp now mentions this place scored in the bottom 5% of SF restaurants on food safety. 
Our family was having a pretty good meal until my daughter exclaimed, "there's a real mouse!" And sure enough there was a mouse climbing the curtain in the dining room towards the ceiling. We told an employee, who didn't seem to believe us, and then another table also mentioned it, and eventually a manager came over to our table. His explanation?
"It's something about the Westfield- there are mice everywhere and it's been an ongoing battle for us. I assure you they haven't been in your food."
That was it. A smile and a completely dismissive sleight of hand at a restaurant charging $20+ per plate. If I wanted to eat an adventurous meal, I'd head over to the Sunset and pay 1/2 the price, but for me this is just unacceptable for a place trying to present itself as higher end. 
Needless to say, we won't be back. And if the place had any integrity they would shut down until this issue is remedied. 
Oh and one other thing - Yelp now mentions this place was in the bottom 5% of SF restaurants on a recent food safety evaluation. Again, not OK for a place trying to pass itself off as higher end. Wish I'd seen this sooner but hopefully others will be cautious before giving this place a try.
author: michael t.

description: Not your ordinary mall food. Good happy hour with a mix of traditional items. The hand cut noodles were tasty. Set at the bar and service was good.
author: Cen'Cere C.

description: Oddly enough, my favorite Chinese food is at the mall.  M.Y. China has great dishes that you will not find at other places.  My favorite entree is their boar noodles.  Noodles are made from scratch and tossed in front of you from their kitchen (amazed).   Whether you decide to have their chicken, beef, or seafood it will certainly be of best quality
author: David W.

description:
M.Y. China. I'm a bit iffy about eating Chinese food something my mother didn't ate or approved of, and eating at Martin Yan's China was a big risk.

I went with a party of three, and not knowing what I was getting into, expect upscale Chinese food, not Asian-fusion. Decided to go with something seafood, the shrimp with gingko nuts and a pot of milk oolong. My friend was wondering about why the pea shoots were $16, asked the waitress who served us and was told that only the top part of the shoots are used, hence why they are so expensive.

Shrimp wasn't too bad; not overcooked with a light glaze. Tea was VERY creamy, something I don't taste everyday and was a complete change from my usual tea outings. And the pea shoots? Nothing too special

We did order dessert, following our waitress' recommendation, the sugar cream puffs with three different kinds of toppings. Again, nothing really special with the puffs.
author: Tom T.

description:
I ate their recently but they give you less food than before.  I had eaten here a year ago and it was okay then.  this time, I ordered the beef roll and hardly any beef inside. I ordered the won ton soup and it was way to salty with only a few won tons inside,   terrible.  I also ordered the hong kong crispy noodles with chicken and xo, the chicken was horrible and tough.

also the service was terrible, i asked for ice water and hot water for my wife, had to nag the server and they finally brought it out.  

I will never eat here again.
author: Joe M.

description: I was pleasantly surprised at how good the service and the food was. We sat at the low bar in front of the kitchen and it was fun to watch the sous chefs make the noodles. It's little overpriced since there's tons of really good and cheap Chinese restaurants all over SF.
author: Julie K.

description: There were just 2 of us and this was our first time dining at M.Y. China.  Unfortunately, we had theater tickets so didn't have time to try more things.  We each had a different noodle dish and loved the food.  I will definitely come back to try more things in this beautiful, upscale setting on the top floor of the mall.  Our waiter was very friendly and energetic and took care of every need.  He even gave both of us tastes of wines before we chose which ones to have.  Lovely place and great food.
author: Beverly K.

description: It was my birthday. They treated us like v.i.p.'s They walked us around the place. The manager told us about the special aspects of the menu and brought us complimentary sparkling wine. There was a pink orchid at our table (and only ours). The head chef made us a special treat. And moreover, the food was amazing. It was real Chinese food like the family I used to stay with made. This restaurant is proof that good things can happen in a mall :)
author: Kris R.

description: A Matter of Ginger: The food was good however, the server that we got had a little bit of an attitude. We ordered the Shanghai dumplings, which traditionally comes with ginger and vinegar. We did not receive the ginger and politely asked for more ginger. We ordered another order of the dumplings and again asked for ginger, they gave us a smaller amount this time, so we asked for more ginger and our server ignored us. We then politely asked for more ginger and our server promptly responded annoyed that "it's getting to the point where we will have to charge you." It's three dollars(!) for extra ginger, and that will be fine. We apologetically explained to her that we loved the dumplings and that we traditionally eat them the Chinese way with a lot of ginger and she defensively told us "well our thing is the vinegar". Yes, we understand, that's why we asked for the vinegar WITH the ginger. I didn't know that the policy here was BYOG--bring your own ginger, otherwise I would have brought like 5. What happened to the customer is always right, especially when it's her birthday and we had humbly asked for just ginger and already decided we would pay for it. Get over yourself girl, it's just ginger... at a restaurant... in a mall. For something so small, you could have graciously made this a great experience, instead you left us with a bad taste in our mouth...one that needs more ginger.
author: Tina P.

description:
It's over price Panda Express.  

I came here with my wife thinking we where going to eat true Chinese food, but ended up with overly sauce chicken with over cooked rice.  My wife even said she could cook better, and I finally agreed with her, even though she burns toast.
author: Sammy S.

description: Fifth day in US. I missed Chinese food. This place is great in general. I love the five spice pork ribs and spicy seafood dumplings. Must try the dumplings. The sauce is  not authentic Chinese but turned out to be a big pleasant surprise.
author: QL M.

description: Used Yelp for dinner reservations and was glad I did. There were several groups of people waiting for a table and we arrived on time and was seated immediately. The wait staff were friendly but made expensive recommendations. My wife eats gluten-free and the waiter said they could make her selection GF if she wished.  My food came and it was delicious, but it took over 20 minutes after I had my dinner that we asked about her food. The waiter neglected/didn't realize....It would take longer. When her plate finally arrived the manager came by the table to speak to us and apologized for the inconvenience. He made it right and we left happy customers.
author: Bert A.

description:
M.Y. China M.Yass
Ambience; Hipster Dufus    
Price Range; Price per person; Splurge, Over $61 $ 
Good for Kids; No, Hell No!    
Attire; Dressy 
Good for Groups; Yes.
Good For;  soso food but expencive-brunch, soso food but expencive-lunch and soso food but expencive-dinner
Noise Level; Average

I don't think this Yan can cook. 
But very expensive! So as Wako on Clement.

The "Bang Bang Chicken Wings," Bang Bang? Man! Really? which cracks me up every time the waitress said.
The steamed bbq pork bao was just ok.
Potstickers, which were okay, but not as hot as we would have liked. It tasted like it had been sitting around.
The honey glazed bbq pork.  The promised tastes of five spice and sesame were nowhere in evidence, probably because the meat was extremely sweet. If that weren't enough, the pork came covered with honey. "Honey glazed" and doused in honey are two different things.  Our pork was both, and it was bad in both ways!
The hot and sour soup.  Please, Do not order this under any circumstances, that likely would have meant that we would have eaten even less of this lamentably sour brew.  The tastes of tomato and vinegar drowned out anything else that might have been going on, but at least there were a few dainty little mushrooms to please the eye.  Do not order this under any circumstances.

Maybe we should have ordered different things, but everything we had was to varying degrees pretty bad.  

Service was very so slow, and they were all confused. It seems like they screwed up orders every where. 
I don't know this Yan can serve either.
But, this is a mall in downtown, rent is too high, it doesn't matter this Yan can cook or not.
You will pay a lot for soso C food cook by this Yan.
I think you pay $30 here, equivalent to...... $10 in outer Sunset, Daly city and SSF.
That's pretty bad.
This was a pretty poor meal indeed.  M.Y. China sure as heck aint my China.
Poor meal but expensive.
That's Wako on Clement.

How about freedom of speech, a bit.
Remember the Tank Man? June 05 1989.
I do, vividly.
44 years after WW2.
Only 26 years ago.
I've heard that most Chinese don't even know the Tank Man.
That's still freaking me out.

http://www.cnn.com/2015/01/16/world/china-food-safety/

M.Y. China M.Yass.
They have a very strict rule that the Happy Hour is only for people at the Bar, even though your table is a few feet away. They demanding the rule, and give you a face.

Btw, the business manager old lady Carol, never replay your detail e-mail back to you and take care of the business.
Get this, "There is a school of thought that owners should try to "manage" negative reviews on Yelp with a show of solicitousness and concern.  Management at M.Y. China tried to do just that by publicly paying lip service to the possibility my wife and I were served a bad meal, and asking me to email more details.  I have pasted my entire email below.  I never heard a single word in acknowledgment or response.  This suggests that management cares less about the experiences of its customers than it does for creating a public perception that it cares.  
Not my kind of folk." This is from Charles R. from Berkeley, posted on 05/16/2015

M.Y. China M.Yass.
You not gonna change.

Well, I am very sure that this review will be removed only because telling truth.
Because I am real and writing the most real honest review.
author: Nobu K.

description:
First of all I came in with low expectations as I see this place as another Americanized Chinese food corporate chain restaurant type place.  Their location makes it convenient - after a whole afternoon of shopping the family does not want to leave the Centre and eat at real SF standalone restaurants - mall food is mall food.  

We've eaten at other Martin Yan places and it was pretty bad.  This place was a little better.  Noodles were good, hot sour soup was not bad and, surprise surprise - sweet sour pork which I typically hate but was forced to order because of my kids - was not bad!

Service was good but a little on the attitude side (typical for SF waiters who think they should be doing something else other than waitering). 

This is sort of a Chinese Cheesecake Factory - definitely not a destination restaurant but not bad either.
author: MJ J.

description: My friends and I had a most amazing lunch at MY China today. The noodles and braised beef were classics and they stood up to test every time. But today we were treated to some very special dishes that were not in the menu yet: XO Surf & Turf, Sea Treasure Cup and a Fruit Tart. They looked so fantastic and several tables next to ours immediately wanted to order the same dishes. We were told that there will be many more specialty items that may or may not appear on their regular menu. But all you have to do is called and talk with executive chef Tony or one of their managers (Like Julie Chu) ahead of time and they will arrange something especially for you and your party.
author: Ellen D C.

description:
It's strange to me why they would put such a good Resturant in a mall. I've walked by so many titles thinking, yea.. I'm not eating mall food, and finally gave it a try. Everything about it was good. Food and service. Had a bunch of appetizers and some wild boar noodles and everything was really good. they have Buddah beer which is awesome and in no way does it feel like you're sitting in a mall eating dinner. I hope they open a location somewhere else in town. 
oh, and it's incredibly reasonably priced.
author: Adam O.

description: My second visit here.  my first visit was awesome, food was good and service was excellent. Must say highly disappointed with my second visit. The first time I was here, we did their special dinner for 2. We had the dumpling appetizer, it was awesome. Came back to have that and they didn't do that anymore.  Instead we order the Chef Special. Various dumplings, nothing special.  The fishermen dumpling was just plain nasty. Bang bang chicken was soso. The calamari was OK, the really smoke pork belly sliders were a Tad bid smoky. Even the wild boar with scissors cut noodles bland. Service was only soso..must say after this visit,  don't think I will be back again.
author: Alicia A.

description:
The Best item ordered, hands down, was Mu Shu Tacos.  Yum!  This dish I would eat over and over again.  Hot and Sour soup and Angel Wings were excellent.  Got some Beef rolls, they were cold, and should not have been.  They also took way too long to come out.  It was a busy night.  Thus the 4 stars.  For dessert, we had the puffs.  Delicious also.  This was slightly more than 2 people needed to eat. 

Sat at a bar that faced into the kitchen (Thick plexi-glass between us and the woks), which made for a fun show and a warm space.  I had a great time, partially due to the company, I am certain.  The server was good, but not great.  It was a very busy night.  I will go back just for a full order of the Mu Shu Tacos (I made the mistake of sharing)!
author: Cindy M.

description:
I made dinner reservations for my sister's birthday and ordered flowers via Opentable.com's florist link and called the restaurant to alert them.  I spoke with Craig, the General Manager who said he will make a note on my reservation and will check on confirming the order.  We arrived at the restaurant early for a drink and Craig called to tell me that the flowers have not arrived. He then located us at the bar and introduced himself and said not to worry, if the flowers did not arrive, he would put an orchid on the table for us.  He told me not to stress over it.  Well, I am a true Type A, stress is in my bloodstream, but he actually was able to calm my nerves which is a true feat.  I grudgingly put away my cell phone and enjoyed my glass of wine.  

From the moment we walked into M.Y. China, Craig gave us the VIP treatment and made us feel special.  He introduced us to the head chef as if we were someone important, took the time to chat with us and checked in with us throughout dinner to make sure everything was fine.  He provided exceptional service and made my sister's birthday and our dinner a very special and memorable one.  

Ok, now let's talk about the food!  We had the Mu Shu Pork tacos that were amazingly delicious.  I can eat them all day.  The Peking duck was tasty as well and we were glad we only ordered half the duck since it was only the three of us. We also had the chicken wings, lobster, green beans, and pulled noodles. Everything we ordered we enjoyed and we plan on going back regularly to try different items. Also, they have Happy Hour!      

The restaurant is amazing along with the decor, but Craig is definitely the star who made a lasting impression on us.  We have dined at many restaurants in the past, some Michelin starred, but never had experienced the VIP treatment we experienced at M.Y. China.  Craig made our dining experience one we will never forget.  Kudos to Craig, to the chefs and team at M.Y. China!
author: Gina Y.

description:
The first time I came, I sat at the kitchen bar and watched the noodles that were in my wild boar scissor cut noodle dish made, and I was entranced! 

This time, I came with the family, and we sat outside in the rotunda. The noodles were delicious yet again. We had the wild boar dumplings and sizzling pork bao to start...Yum!

Cocktails are also interesting... My fave is the "fire in the wok", it has some heat!
author: Laurence B.

description:
We were able to grab a late reservation on valentines evening, amazing. I think someone must have canceled because its normally packed and it was valentines. They didn't have a crazy pre-fixe menu for the romantic cash grabbing day, thank you for that. They did however have a special menu to celebrate Chinese new Years. It looked great and it was reasonable on the wallet, we passed however due to the fact we wanted to try a different selection of offerings. 

The ambiance, chef pulling noodles putting on a show for some of the guests held my attention for a few short moments. The servers were all super attentive and well behaved. 

The food was great. We tried the Pork & Black Truffle Juicy Dumplings and while they were great we have definitely had better. the Har Gow was amazing as well as the Pork & Crab Juicy Dumplings.
The Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup was the best I have had anywhere in the US, so so good! We also tried the M.Y. Sweet & Sour Pork, more out of novelty, I just wanted to see what Yan's sweet & sour pork was like, it was very tasty. 

Over all this place gets the good right on target. The food was super fresh and tasted more healthy than your average Americanized Chinese food. I have no complaints at all. I will have to go back and try some of the other things that yelpers are talking about, mainly the forbidden rice. 

Its not your take out Chinese solution, its more of a nice dinner out.
author: Ben M.

description: I have a bit of a mix feeling for this place. I know this is more of a fancy Chinese restaurant in a mall, and was expecting pretentious Asian fusion style food and not authentic Chinese food. We were a large party so we got to try a lot of menu items. The first few appetizers we ordered were disappointing, way too spicy and they all tasted the same (calamari, garlic spicy chicken wings, and deep fried tofu). The portions were small as well. However, the entrees redeemed themselves. The fried rice, garlic pea shoots, cod fish tofu casserole and Peking duck were excellent and surprisingly authentic. We also had the wok fried lamb but it was just ok. Overall not bad, but given the price and small portion, I feel I can get a better deal and same good food elsewhere.
author: Lily T.

description: Usually a great dining experience, but last night's meal was just okay: the forbidden rice was hard and the sweet and sour pork was overcooked. On the plus side, the tacos  and the green beans were delicious and the service excellent.
author: T G.

description:
Hard to eat clean dim sum in SF without wondering exactly what's in it. And, hard to find one that isn't 2x the price it should be.

At MY China, you get both: perfectly priced items for great ingredient made meals. Came in on a Saturday for lunch and sat right down; no wait at all!  Had the green onion pancake, (my fave of the day), farmer's dumplings, shumai, seafood dumplings, shrimp dumplings and pork steamed buns. I'm Asian and have eaten a lot of dumplings in my time and I have to say that MY's dim sum fare is the best I've had. I wasn't the least bit skeptical of the meat in the buns or dumplings, they weren't soggy and soft and the potstickers were not greasy whatsoever. For $40 for 2 people, i definitely will be returning. 

Next on the visit: hong kong style crispy noodles and custard egg tarts! :)
author: Joy A.

description: Great food, Lousy service.  Hot soup grew cold as  we were without bowls and spoons.  Food trickled out slowly and indecisively.  Server unaware of what we were still due.   Dessert took 4 ever so we left without it.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
My sister and I came here for dinner on a Friday night after a relaxing afternoon at the Burke Williams Spa upstairs.  The restaurant was packed- from the dining room - to the bar seats - to the kitchen bar seats.  There were people everywhere! The service was fantastic and our server shared his favorite dishes with us. 

The food was more like a two-star but the experience was the game-changer.  We ordered spicy shrimp dumplings, Bejing knife-cut noodles, Chairman Mao's chicken,  the Seven Spice Pork Ribs and the Chinese-style egg custard donuts served with chocolate and raspberry sauce (which were the best part of the meal).  All were acceptable but I was expecting more nuances in the flavor. Chinese food can be savory and complex without all of the dishes tasting the same.  Great concept restaurant but I think that the quality of the food is diminished by the quantity of food that is churned out for the crowds
author: Ronita J.

description:
I came here tonight for dinner and sat at the noodle bar. It was interesting to see the cooking and behind the scenes of the kitchen. The head chef also showed some of the other bar diners some pretty neat cooking techniques. Also felt some of the heat from the cooking flames which I didn't mind. 
I ordered the Wild Boar scissor cut noodles. Overall the dish was good but it tasted just like a typical pork chow mein (flavorful and greasy). I did like the hand pulled noodles though, they were thick and tasty- wish I had more!
Service here was not bad, I found the host staff to be more friendly than my server was. Had to flag him down and he didn't seem to pay too much attention to how I was doing. 
Overall, wouldn't mind trying M.Y China again, some of the other dishes looked good and prices were reasonable for the location. Nice decor also.
author: Miss H K.

description: I often come here after walking around the mall, the restaurant looks nice inside and out.  The food is yummy and fresh. I've tried a lot of dishes off the menu and no complaints! Must try the East meets West drink. It has chrysanthemum =)
author: Karen Z.

description:
I'm absolutely shocked that michael bauer rated this place higher than Hakkasan. Bottom line is I'll go back and focus on their dumplings and vegetable dishes. In addition, I have yet to try the noodles (which I think is Tony Wu's specialty).

The excellent:
Garlic pea shoots ($16!)
Watching cooks at the dumpling and noodle stations

The OK:
Peking Duck (sauce is a little off)
Sauteed mushroom side dish
Setting and service
Truffle dumplings, crab dumplings, etc.

The bad:
Wild boar is practically inedible. It's so chewy and salty. It comes with lettuce cups.
Hot and sour soup is just gross. I'm not sure what that bizarre flavor is.
Wok Seared Beef Filet tastes worse than Panda Express
Hong Kong Crispy Noodles with Chicken. Indescribably gross.
author: Marina N.

description:
Came on a Saturday. Seated outside so nice people watching and the view of the dome. The tables were close together so we were practically having lunch with this creepy couple next to us. Would be nice if they lost a table and spaced things out a little more. 

As for the food we ordered a bunch of dim sum items and the wonton soup. The waiter forgot my soup, so while my bf enjoyed his I just sat their listening to the couple whispering in Italian. Sure, whisper it's not like I would understand you if you screamed.  

Anyway my soup came. Decent flavor, not overly salty, wontons big. 

The dim sum was good, pretty comparable to dim sum in Chinatown. Except the farmers roll or whatever it was called. Terrible flavor. 

The service was really lackluster. The server brought the check with the food. Guess he needed the table? 

Overall if you're in the mall and want a break from shopping and you want decent dim sum this is your place.  If you're not in the mall stick with the places in Chinatown or the Richmond.
author: Timoteo K.

description: The food taste like its from a food factory, staff service is horrible, no sense of customer service. Do not recommend! Worst than food court
author: Ke W.

description:
This is the most expensive Chinese restaurant everrrr... but great! The hand pulled beef noodle soup and ginger fried crab and xlb soup dumplings were all some of the best I've had. 
I think there is a certain amount of prestige being inside the mall and this restaurant certainly lives up to the standards of class which the neighboring restaurants have set. Everything from the chopsticks to the decor to the soda water to the classy service is well refined and gives off a sense of elegance. As westernized as the facade is, they window off the kitchen for viewing to proudly display the Chinese chefs for a sense of authenticity in the food. The best part is, every once in a while this chef comes by for a little pulled noodle performance, showing you how they... Pull the noodles. And if you ask him, he'll actually let you do it too!
author: James T.

description: Fairly good. This is not a whole in the wall restaurant, it's a nice dining room with quite a bit of money spent on decor. They actually execute the  classics  well. Egg puffs and Peking Duck were especially good. Scissor cut noodles were OK, nothing special. Seafood dumplings were very good, if more expensive than your typical dim sum joint. Few of the servers were Asian, but surprisingly, many of the diners were. Don't be scared of the Martin Yan name and mall location and you will likely be pleased if you order correctly.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I have a lot of nostalgia about Martin Yan and Yan Can Cook so naturally I've been to M.Y. China a few times.

I went yesterday for HH. $5 plates, $6 wine,and $7 cocktails at the Westfield, not bad. The Buddha Breeze was refreshing and I particularly enjoyed the Tempeh Sliders.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Ever the skeptic of Chinese restaurant cuisine, I admit I was pleasantly surprised by M.Y. China.  Despite reminding me of P.F. Chang's in certain ways, M.Y. China is an enjoyable eatery that is charmingly similar to Martin Yan.  M.Y. China features authentic and flavorful, yet unpretentious, Chinese food in a sleek and spotless setting that lies somewhere between chic and kitschy.  I enjoyed their refined version of Taiwanese-style beef noodle soup, which features hand pulled noodles and generous cuts of beef short rib (rather than the traditional beef cut that is as challenging as it is chewy and often leaves remnants stuck between one's teeth).  The noodles were a bit too soft, but the rich broth was was beefy and bold with just enough heat.  I also enjoyed the gailan (Chinese broccoli) with traditional Cantonese sausage and slices of sauteed garlic.  Lunch time seems busy, but we were able to sit at the counter without waiting.  

As an added bonus (some might say), we were treated to a performance of the resident noodlemaker pulling and lassoing noodles, and bopping to "Gangnam Style," which was blasting from speakers attached to his apron.  The momentary show was awkwardly charming.
author: Chris T.

description:
Had a really great meal here for CNY.  They had a special prix fixe for the new year $88 for 2ppl with a selection of dim sum (2 siu mai, 2 had how, 2 seafood dumplings), 4 peking duck pancakes and 2 peking duck lettuce cups, hong kong noodles, rib eye beef in crunchy noodle bowl, and beignets.  The waitress dropped us a hint that it was probably enough food for 3 vs just the 2 required, so with 4 people we got that and added a few dishes (salt and pepper crab, snow pea sprouts, seafood fried rice, and the chicken wings).  The salt and pepper crab was really tasty (only ~$40 market price), but I still slightly prefer R&Gs or ABC's salted egg yolk crab. 

Everything we had was delicious and while done up a bit, still also satisfied my craving for authentic chinese food.  The highlights for me were the chicken wings and the rib eye dish, but really everything was good.  We left very full and with leftovers and a bill of only $177.  I would highly recommend this place if you want an upscale chinese food experience and less of the hassle of getting into R&G.
author: Aaron W.

description:
My husband and I made reservations for a weekday night but upon entering the  restaurant found that most tables were still available. Throughout our meal the tables filled up though. Thus, it's hard to say whether reservations are needed. 

The atmosphere of the restaurant is good. It's not too commercial or cold as is sometimes the case with restaurants located in shopping centers. 

Both of us ordered the hot and sour soup. We then shared an order of the juicy dumplings and the Da Dao Fish Noodles. The soup was good, the dumplings great, and the noodles fantastic. Our favorite spot for Xiao Long Bao is Din Tai Fung. Sadly there isn't one in San Francisco, but for now we are very happy with the M.Y. China soup dumplings. They were fresh, full of flavor, and came our steaming. The noodles, however, were our favorite dish at this spot and perhaps my favorite Chinese-style noodles overall. The veggies, fish, and noodles  are sautéed perfectly and have a delicious smoky flavor. The dish isn't too oily either which sometimes can be the case for noodles of this kind. 

The service was good, but a bit slow. All in all, we were very happy with the experience and will definitely come back and order both dishes again.
author: Emma E.

description: M.Y China will always have a special place in my heart. I came here twice and enjoyed my experience both times. The food was really good and the decors were very pretty as well. They serve Chinese fusion food. Although it is more like Americanized Chinese food, it still greatly satisfied my taste bud given that I am very used to having authentic Chinese food. To be honest, who cares if it is authentic or not, as long as it tastes good, that's all that matters. Everything we tried were pretty damn good but I was most impressed by the Spicy Seafood Dumplings and Lychee Panna Cotta. The Spicy Seafood Dumplings was HELLA BOMB!!!! It was so flavorful and the spiciness was just enough. SO GOOD! The Lychee Panna Cotta was a unique dessert, which has chrysanthemum essence in it. It's a light and refreshing dessert, which is always a good choice after all the entrees. It's more like a two and a half dollar signs restaurant and the portion is on the smaller size, but for the ambience and taste, it's totally worthy!
author: Siian X.

description: Pork and Carb juicy dumplings- so juicy and yumm, hot and sour soup - the right amount of hot and sour, Chicken wings, Hong Kong crispy noodles - yummm, Chairman Maos chicken - the best among all the dishes, lychee pana cotta - the worst(will never have this ever). Overall , we really liked the food. Service was okay - they were kinda rude. But we'll come back again for the food.  3.5 is a fair rating but Yelp doesn't allow 3.5, so giving a 3.
author: I Love Good Foo D.

description:
There is an attitude, mostly shared by people without kids, that once you have children you shouldn't be out in public or go out to eat at nice restaurants until they are about 14. The other side of this is that any parent who takes young kids to a nice restaurant after 6pm deserves whatever happens to them. Keeping this in mind we went as a family of 4 (with an 18 month old and a 4 year old) to M.Y. China last week because we thought it would be a fun experience for the kids to see noodle pulling while the adults got to eat decent food. 

Even though the meal was rushed because our 18 month old loved the restaurant so much he wanted to run around, climb on everything and watch all the action behind the glass in the kitchen, it was a good experience. 

It started off a little weird when the hostess had to go ask someone for special permission to seat us in a corner booth, which seemed like the best choice for  family. But we warned our server right away that we would have to eat quick because our youngest gets restless after about 20 minutes. I really appreciated that they had a good attitude about the kids and they brought out the food incredibly fast. We ordered a lot of different dishes and enjoyed them all even though we were rushed in eating them. The kids both loved the wantons in the soup and the wild boar scissor cut noodles. We tried the 3 different dumpling sampler but couldn't tell the difference between them, which again could be because my wife and I were taking turns taking our youngest out the restaurant to watch the light display on the ceiling. 

The one thing we wanted to see was the noodle pulling. Since it was earlier in the dinner service they weren't going around and doing it in the dining room. I mentioned to the server that the kids would want to see it and he said he would be sure to tell us if they pulled some noodles in the kitchen. A few minutes later someone who I assume was a manager came out and actually made a point to tell us what time they would start and that he would make sure he came back and got us. I was really impressed that they took the time to make sure we had a good experience.

I don't feel that I can give a really detailed analysis of the food because it was a rushed dinner but M.Y. China does deserve recognition for the level of hospitality they extended to us. I would love to go back again as a family, when our youngest is a little older.
author: Tim C.

description:
Service - 5 stars
Hostess -  0 star
Food Quality - 3 stars

It was supposed to be a fun dinner but the hostess almost ruined it for us.  Glad that our waiter was superb.   Food was okay.  Hence, three stars only.
author: AH C.

description: My aunt and I came here for lunch, it was our first time here. It was a great experience. All of the staff is super friendly and attentive. We were seated at the bar because it wasn't very busy. Matthew was our server and he was GREAT. All of our food came within 10 minutes, and we ordered about 5 dishes (veggie spring rolls, mixed greens with papaya and grilled shrimp salad, twin scallops fried rice, jasmine pearl tea, and seafood dumplings).  Great customer service. The jasmine pearl tea is amazing too, best tea I've ever had honestly. The best thing here is their fried rice, it's so fluffy and fresh and it tastes like HEAVEN. All of the food is amazing, you can just tell that it's high quality food. Matthew was so kind that he gave us our tea on the house. Great staff. Will definitely be coming back here frequently.
author: Leila T.

description: The food was good; however, I asked the waitress THREE times for a beverage and I never received it.  She said okay each time, but she never complied.
author: Sherry S.

description:
I've been here twice and have enjoyed the dumplings, and a wonderful prix fixe menu during the Chinese New Year.  

My experience last Saturday made me deduct 1/2  star for spotty service.  We sat at the glass kitchen counter section and the server took a while to greet us.  My friend had her meal served first and mine came more than 5 minutes later.   The cooks were busy but not overly crowded to justify the tardiness.

The other 1/2 star was for the unisex restroom.  Not knowingly that it was unisex, it was embarrassing for my friend when she asked me for a tampon and a man comes out of a stall.  I've never seen this before and would think that it would be uncomfortable for both sexes.  The only men I would share a bathroom with are my immediate family.  And even then it's sometimes disgusting when guys make a mess!
author: Charmaine W.

description: Had the highly touted "Wild Boar" (pork) noodles for lunch, the dish was bland and completely lacking in spice or flavor. The noodles were indeed house made and fresh, but I would have to say the food at this place doesn't live up to the hype.
author: Andrew M.

description:
More like "Meh China."

Food was OK, really just a knockoff of P.F. Chang's (and a bad one at that) - even the derivative name itself is a hint that you're getting a copycat. "M.Y. China?" Really?

It's not even worth writing a detailed review, as everything we ordered (a group of 4) was sup-par to what you'd get at a P.F. Chang's.

Service was fine - from what we actually saw?

I say this because we had a fair amount of food left over, and were asked if we wanted it to go. Sure, we said. When I got home, I saw that there was a paltry 1 prawn and 2 chunks of chicken (but of course, all the rice!). It was bizarre - we would not have gotten it to go if there was so little left. It was easily just 1/3-1/4 of what we had left over.

So what is it - are they skimming leftovers in the kitchen for themselves? Are they just tossing most of your leftover food out of spite? Very odd.

So I felt this place is a little shady / dishonest on top of the knockoff name...
author: Ches W.

description: Absolutely love this place! If you can get a corner couch seat that's the best! Besides the people watching, the food is super super good and the drinks are to die for! I love how there is no wait and the waiters are super attentive. I wish we had one closer to home! I would eat there all the time. Keep it up!
author: Melissa Y.

description: I didnt get mycredit card back yesterday friday 2/19/16 please call me back the food was good tho
author: Yongming H.

description: Pretty good cocktails, although the specialty martinis are on the too-sweet side. Good dumplings, we had the spicy seafood and the crab pork ones. Had various chicken, rice, and crispy noodle entrees. All just ok. Our server was kind of friendly but seemed crazy rushed and couldn't even with our indecisiveness. He would just bail at every hesitation and come back like "you ready?"
author: Chris C.

description:
Fortunately, my birthday and the one year anniversary of the opening of M.Y.China fell on the same day.  We were treated to a live appearance of Martin Yan.  He even sang happy birthday at our table.  He also show cased the hand pulled noodle.  The place is foo-foo looking but since it being in a mall, everyone varies in their dress attire.  The wait staff was nice and attentive.  

The food was good. Everyone complains of the price but if you take into account the location and the ambiance, its a decent price. The food was good tasting and enough where we were content but not in a food coma.  The buns for the Peking Duck were so moist and soft, we ordered more.  The dim sum was decent, the usual staples.  The hand pulled noodle was good too.  Worth a try and I'd probably go back.
author: Charles M.

description: The folks at MY China reached out after reading my last review (really unfortunate service incident) and offered to comp a meal as an apology - very reasonable and kind. Just like I noted in my last review, the food is really delicious. I will def be going back for the Peking Duck. It was incredibly delicious, and the smaller portion was very generous. The service was exceptional. It was really kinda of them to reach out after an exceptionally poor experience - it is refreshing to see a restaurant own up to mistakes a fix them.
author: Laura G.

description:
During the quiet work week before Xmas I rounded up the gals in the office and headed over to the Westfield dome to Martin Yan's new restaurant. Lot of seating during lunch. We got a big table in the back and split the following:

* wild boar noodles - 4 stars, nice chewy noodles

* beef noodle soup - 3 stars, seemed a little boring for a beef noodle soup, usually more interesting flavors, this was just straight up beef with no spices

* map tofu - 3 stars, not that interesting

* five spice ribs - 4 stars, huge ribs but super tasty

* fried green beans - 3 stars, hard to screw these up

Mostly the food was suburban Chinese food - not much different than Straits, or dare I say it, PF Chang. Standouts were the hand pulled noodles and the ribs. I'm not sure I would come back unless someone else was paying. Though not for the cost because it was only $13 per person (without tip) for the 5 of us.
author: Jean K.

description: Food is good and service was awesome!  We ordered the peking duck and hand cut noodles.  Noodles were freshly made and delicious.  For the Peking duck, I was amazed that most of the fat was rendered.  One of the best peking duck I ever tasted.  Definitely would recommend this place.  Keep in mind that this is not the typical Chinese restaurant menu as there are only about 30 items on the menu, and not hundreds of items as in an authentic Chinese restaurant.
author: J. M.

description:
Having recently spent a month in China, I can truly say that this is the best Chinese food I've had in a long time, here or there! 

It was served promptly and graciously, and was delicious. Be adventurous with what you order; you can't go wrong.

If you're shopping in downtown SF, find your way to the 4th floor of the Westfield Mall on top of Bloomingdales, near Nordstrom and a short walk from Macy's on Union Square. It's well worth it.
author: Princess J.

description:
My friend and I had lunch here on a weekday. The restaurant is very clean, nice with very good service.

We ordered Seafood Dumplings. They were good and savory. However, I was not impressed by the Vegetarian Longevity noodle soup. While it is great location to experience, I would not recommend it to a vegetarian.
author: Sid P.

description:
My pregnant friend was craving this spot and I'd never been...so I was game. Everything was SO good! Staff was eh....but I was too busy inhaling my salt & pepper calamari, kung pao chicken, and honey walnut shrimp. YUM.

I was a little apprehensive about the shrimp, since they add wasabe to the sauce...but the heat was perfect! so delish.

Went a 2nd time with a different friend a couple days later, and if possible the experience was even better. Staff was uber nice! They helped us with recommendations and were really attentive. We ordered soooooooo much food and somehow managed to almost eat it all. lol. on the plus side, Martin Yan was there! we watched him give a little tutorial thing while someone was making the noodles by hand. Really cool actually. 

Had a great time and definitely adding this spot to my list of "where to go when I'm not sure where to go!"
author: Maritza D.

description:
I give this restaurant 3 stars for food only.  
I went for an early birthday dinner with a friend.  I enjoyed the food we ordered, but the service was horrible.  I really had to work at getting a waiter (we had 3 that served us - it did not seem like anyone was assigned our table) to order items after the appetizers and when I asked for water it never arrived by the time we started attempting to get our check so I gave up.  It might have been just an off time or something, but it did taint my experience.
author: Debbie G.

description:
I've had two experiences at M.Y. China one good and one okay experience. The difference is the service, so I'll start there. 

The first time I went to M.Y. China the service was terrible. It was lunch time when the mall is really busy. There was a lot of waiting. It took a long time for our waiter to take our order. It took a long time for our order to arrive. It took an extremely long time to get our check. We stopped counting at 20 minutes. Because we did so much waiting we did get a discount on our meal. However, I would have preferred to have paid the full price and not have done so much waiting. 

The second time I went to M.Y. China the service was good. The restaurant wasn't very full Tuesday night for dinner. Our waitress took our order quickly. We got our food in a timely manner. We even got the check quickly too. It was the opposite of my first experience earlier in the summer, so maybe they've worked out the kinks or maybe it's because there were a lot less diners. 

Now, let's talk food. 

Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders - the pork is really good. You can taste the tea flavor. The bun part is just okay. 

Crispy Organic Tofu - I really like this dish. It's crisp on the outside, soft on the inside and the flavor is fantastic. 

M.Y. Hot and Sour Soup - I'm a hot and sour soup fan and I thought this was pretty authentic. Silken tofu instead of xue tofu.

Bak Choy - decent. 

Beijing Knife Cut Noodles - I really enjoyed eating fresh noodles. It reminded me of when I lived in Beijing. 

Tea Creme Brulee - yummy. The tea flavor makes it very special. 

The sugar egg puffs look really good. I'll have to make a return trip here to try them.
author: Kelly H.

description: Craving fantastic Chinese food without the negatives of small spaces and scary health food scores. Traveling with two young children and we couldn't be happier that we came across this restaurant. A short 10 min walk from Union square, it's located inside one of the fanciest malls in SF. The greats: easily accessible with our stroller and 2 kids in tow, call ahead/on line reservation, comfy/large seating space, friendly staff, and amazing food! Special thanks to the hostess Sigourney for seating us quickly and honoring our request for a corner booth for our family. Also to our amazing waiter Bolivar (Bolo) for being so attentive. We've had our fair share of less than friendly looks when arriving with 2 young kids, a stroller, a backpack, and "were exhausted and hAngry" parent faces  and it was so refreshing to get such genuine smiles and kindness from both Sigourney and Bolo. Thanks so much guys! Your kindness meant all the difference to our family. Loved that our girls also got a chance to see into the kitchen as the staff freshly prepared their food! Amazing! Will definitely be back!!!
author: Rodney Ami F.

description: Decent Americanized expensive small serving Chinese food.  Excellent setting with impeccable service.  Daniel (Lenny Kravitz look alike) was great.  Service was extremely slow due to the kitchen staff.  Daniel was very apologetic about the tardiness.
author: Joel M.

description: Unimpressed by food, service and ambiance. Had appetizers, sides, noodles, duck, etc. I'm so underwhelmed I can't even write anymore. This is a "captive audience" restaurant.
author: alex f.

description:
Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders ($8) - Smoked flavor might be a bit strong for some, but I liked it
Peking Roast Duck ($20 half) - Served with steamed buns (vs wraps). Duck meat was flavorful. Usually I only notice the skin.
Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup ($14) - Tender meat; thick, long, hand-made noodles. Complex broth.
Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood ($18) - Tasty, with a bit of spice. I'd prefer more noodles though, and the bell peppers should be cooked longer I think.
Sichuan Green Beans ($8) - Flavorful, but a bit too salty.
Mapo Organic Tofu ($8) - Good, prefer spicier.
Grandma's Gai Lan ($12) - Gai lan was good, not bitter. Good balance with sausage and garlic.
