Steamed Rice x2 ($2 each) - Fine. Would like to see a sticky rice option.
Sugar Egg Puffs ($8) - Like donuts but lighter. Quite good. We were comped this :)

I'm picky about Chinese food, but I'm pretty impressed with this place. Everything we tried was solid. I like how they don't try to put too many items on their menu, like many Chinese restaurants.

Service was good, though we had to wait a while for rice (we asked for it after ordering). The waiters should remind people to order rice. They seemed a bit understaffed when we got there a little after 8pm.

I liked the modern asian decor and open kitchen a lot. A bit noisy though. Also I wonder if having Buddha statues and serving meat makes sense?

Price is reasonable. We got full on about $25 per person (table of 5, no drinks).
author: Peter T.

description: Let's start with the acoustics in this place..., you can't hear each other with out feeling like your shouting. With that said, the wild boar noodles were exceptional! However, the Kung poa chicken was more like a spicy sweet and sour without the sauce, not a fan. The service was good, and we would go back for a quick lunch for the noodles. Next time I would ask to sit outside the main dining room, which is irritatingly noisy.
author: Laura R.

description:
We had lunch at My China today. It's a really clean, modern restaurant in the Dome of the Westfield Mall in SF. The food is pretty good and the servers aim to please. 

We were seated right away and was attentively served. I think people may have a problem with the prices. We previewed the menu before we decided to dine so we didn't have the sticker shock like some might.

I liken this place to PF Chang's. Your paying for the ambience. The food was good. We ordered Dim Sum to start....the barbeque baked buns as a starter. They look more like muffins but they were good. We also ordered fried rice and Kung Pao Chicken.

I would say that the price and food are very similar to PF Chang. But the place is much smaller and has better service.

There are many shoppers at this mall so I have a feeling My China won't have any issues getting customers. Luckily for them, there's not too many other chinese restaurants in the mall. I think there is one in the basement food court.

My experience was pretty uneventful, which is a good thing. Nothing really stands out about being too good or too bad. If I think of anything else I will ammend the review.
author: Emily C.

description:
Been back twice taking different friends.   Martin Yan himself was there once and chatted with him for a few.  He was friendly and knowledgable about the food, and we even had a nice discussion about Hakkasan which opened a week before MY China.   

  The restaurant seems to have resolved the timing pacing issues with the dishes since not everything comes out at the same time like last time, and we were asked if we wanted the food to come out in a particular order or when they are ready (which was fine since we were mixing around appetizers, small plates and main in a large talbe).

We sat at the noodle bar once and in the big table on the edge of the mall for larger group.  Service and food was fine both times.  Tried the squid noodles and other kinds of noodles and they were all fresh and well prepared as expected.

Did notice one or two  kitchen/staff mis-que on special orders (most likely due to langugage barriers) but the restaurant is still new and the staff need to gel more.  Also good to ear that the restaurant is recruiting culinary school interns to teach them chinese food preparation and noodle techniques.

Already made the reservation for next time to try the duck and the crab.
author: Kenneth L.

description: Excellent place for romantic dinner date. Late review but better late then never! ;) Top notch service and exquisite food! =)
author: AJ J.

description:
Dinner and a show at the Curran Theater on a Friday night.  As a precaution my husband and I reserved a table.  We got there early, so we hung out at the bar for a little while.

Things That Were Awesome:
+++Under the Bronze Bell (drink).  I really liked how light it was.  It felt like a palette cleanser
+++Wild Boar Soup Dumpling.  Gigantic soup dumpling spoons.  Filling and satisfying.  I should have asked for two orders.
+++Fresh noodles.  You can see the cook staff make them while you wait for food.

Things That Were Not So Awesome:
---Busy!  Well it just opened and it's the holidays.  I can't completely blame M.Y. China for that.
---Food service.  Apparently it was a 'backwards' food presentation.  Somehow my appetizer (wild boar soup dumplings) came out last and my main order (beef noodle soup) came out first.
---Beef noodle soup.  Noodles were amazing.  The broth reminded me of something I would eat at a cheaper Chinese restaurant or even King of Thai.  Broth was still good, just not the mind-blowing expectations that I had from a Martin Yan menu.

Random Note:
Did someone just line up and say 'Party of 15' on a Friday night in downtown San Francisco with likely no reservations?  Yes, someone did that while I was waiting for my table.

Sit at the bar area facing the kitchen.  Watching an army of cooks create dishes is an awesome way to pass the time.
author: Christine L.

description:
To me, the Westfield Shopping Center is the closest thing San Francisco has to hell on earth, so when I'm there, my goal is usually to get out as quickly as possible, not to stop in someplace for a meal. Recently, though, I saw M.Y. China featured on Check Please Bay Area; it looked pretty good, so we decided to check it out. 

We have Chinese food quite often so we have a lot to compare this with, and our meal here was really very good. We had the hot and sour soup (as good as any I've had in the city), crispy fried tofu with sweet and sour sauce (too spicy for my husband, but perfect for me); Beijing knife cut noodles with pork, mushrooms and a spicy black bean sauce; and scissor cut noodles with wild boar and julienned raw vegetables. We liked every dish, but the noodles were a special treat, both because they are not the run-of-the-mill noodle dishes you find at every Chinese restaurant and because they were *super* delicious! 

Our server, Daniel, was extraordinarily attentive, bringing us tastes of wine and giving us many useful recommendations about the menu. 

A number of reviewers have commented about the prices. The check for the two of was about $50 not including drinks. (It would have been higher if we'd had the kobe beef, crab, or lobster.) It's surely true that you can have delicious Chinese food in San Francisco for a lot less (though not in this location). The food here was very good (especially the noodle dishes), and the service was also very good. We felt the prices were in line with the quality of the food and the dining experience, and we will happily return to try a few other dishes.
author: David K.

description:
A very wise and experienced Hong Kong food critic said it best.

"Western folks value decor and service more than food at times, and factor those into the dining experience criteria. But it is the opposite for Chinese people...so long as the food is first and foremost excellent, the rest do not matter." Basically a restaurant can splurge several fortunes into making a place look snazzy that would make cougars proud to be partaking in Happy Hour before dragging conquests back home for some happy endings post Happy Hour, but if  the entrees and main courses don't deliver, what is the point of eating there. 

Luckily for many of us in the SF Bay Area, MY China in a way has both, but done in a way that it satisfies everyone.

I know what $trait$ Restaurant represents, and their approach I do not agree with.

This time round, I think I enjoyed the experience just a slight more than prior.

Wild boar lettuce cups (Appetizer) - this is a bit of a remix on the tried and true minced squab lettuce cups with hoisin sauce. The addtion of fried bean thread like vermicelli added an extra layer of crispy textures, and with the julienne wild boar that was nicely stir fried and juicy, made this a real winner. Two cups per order, enough to share. Would that be Two Girls One Cup, One Dude Two Cups? Dunno, but these B Cups were awesome. B for Boar, that is. 

Wild boar scissor cut noodles - we sat near the counter and saw one of the kitchen staff carefully use scissors to cut a ball of dough. He was clearly taking his time, and each piece of noodle looked pretty thin. Thus we were guessing if he was practicing and whether we would get the trial art and craft project stir fried (and he seemed to be taking his time doing so, versus first visit when the scissor cut noodle chef was slicing and dicing the dough at breakneck pace). The decision to request "less salt, less oil" was a good one (although somehow it became no salt no oil for some lost in translation reason). This arrived piping hot and very nicely stir fried. It was almost like a properly done moo shoo (luckily not moo shoo poo poo, that's something else entirely like uhm... PF). And this is where it is crucial to kick things up a notch and get some house chili sauce, which definitely elevated this. In retrospect, I should have asked for some XO sauce to try. Definitely the Chinese version of Cinghiale pasta, but stir fried.

Honey glazed BBQ pork (cha siu) - It's $10 a plate, and while you can get half a pound or a takeout box for that much at the run down roasties deli shop, it is always fun to try a plate of this at a high end restaurant. It's a good taste tester for the kitchen, and a very welcoming popular BBQ item (honey glazed BBQ pork, what is there not to like unless you are a meat hating hipster but craves bacon wrapped sausages once in a while?). Generally lean for the most part, yet each bite was tender and juicy all the way through. A very delicate marinade, although the final roasting process probably had a tad too sweet of a molasses splash. The best part? Picking up a random slice (closer to the edges) thinking it's all lean, and when you bite into it, there's a portion of fat that somehow crept in. It melts in your mouth like warm sweet butter and honey, and suddenly you feel like you were shot into the skies. Or akin to eating at your favorite sushi bar, and the chef gives you a run of the mill looking item, and when you eat it you discover there's toro, uni, and wagyu in it. So yeah, this cha siu is great...yet subtly pornographic...like reading a novel called "50 Shades Of Pork".   

So no, ordering BBQ pork appetizer plate at a nicer Cantonese Chinese restaurant during dinner, is not an unusual thing. We don't have restaurants like Tin Lung Heen in Hong Kong that take Spanish Iberico black pig and use premium cuts to make cha siu.l...so places like Koi Palace and even MYC offering something like this that may be above average for expats, and very decent according to "King Of FOBenese Food", ain't so bad.

Stir fried bok choy with salted fish - when this arrived, it was as if the veggies were quickly clear stir fried with very little to no oil, and was very bland. Turns out our waitress misheard my "less salt less oil" and thought we meant "no salt no oil", and the kitchen withheld the salted fish (which she said was oily). We had this taken back and what a difference it made afterwards. The salted fish quantity and enhancement was not strong, but did make the dish taste better. Was half the price of large pea sprout with garlic ($16), so if you want your greens on, this is a safe choice.

4 dishes for two, came out to a shade over $50, which is not unreasonable for the location, quality, and to factor in décor and service. Plus you get some free shows of hand pulled noodles every now and then, plus scissor cutting of noodles.

Too bad Martin wasn't in the house. Would have told him his BBQ pork was quite pornographic in the fatty areas.
author: Ken K.

description: The spicy seafood dumplings tasted so delicious!!!!!! The drinks were special and cute!
author: Kiko H.

description: My husband and I had been to M.Y. China at Graton Casino when it first opened. It was delicious and wanted to return this year for Chinese New Year. Apparently it has closed. So, instead, we made reservations for SF on a Monday night, 2.15.16, when Martin Yan was in house. We ordered Chairman Mao Chicken, Wok Seared Beef, Sichuan Green Beans, Beijing Knife Cut Noodles and Jasmine Pearl Tea. The green beans and tea were good. The chicken and beef dishes were overcooked and dry. Chicken came with a tablespoon of two different sauces on the side. asked for additional sauce, it didn't help. We had high expectations for the noodles, but they were bland and mushy. Martin Yan even came to our table to toss the noodles and serve us. That was very nice, but, unfortunately did not improve the dish. I truly wish I could give a rave review, but I just can't.
author: Susan S.

description:
We had a fantastic server; very nice; wonderful and he deserved the 20% tip i gave, but the food disappointed.
Steamed bok choy and the pumpkin dumplings were good; however the onion pancakes tasted like packaged pie crust, inedible.
The tea was served in an unpleasant dark metal cup and pot; tepid; unpleasant.
My guest had lobster and requested that it be easy to eat; it was not.
She was served a chopped up lobster, still in the shell, greasy!, it looked like a pile of garbage and not an expensive entree, head, feelers, stomach - it was an unappetizing presentation, mess. We could not find the tail, which is her favorite; at $58, most was left uneaten - yucky.
I  had high hopes that there would be one dining spot in the mall with fresh food; besides the bok choy; the food was bad.
author: becke a.

description:
Ridiculously overpriced Chinese seeming food. 

While I can handle mediocre Chinese like food, the prices are shockingly, jaw-dropping high. 

2 star food for a 5 star price doesn't get my vote. 

Never again.
author: Jim O.

description: This was my 2nd.visit to M.Y. China. We started with the assorted dim sum basket then proceeded to their entrees , which they are famous for. We ordered the hand cut wild boar noodles (a must), sauteed pea shoots (a little too overcooked). I would order the string beans instead. My husband ordered the glazed walnuts and shrimp which was a generous portion and so yummy. My friend ordered onion pancakes. I ordered sichuan peppered beef (very tender and succulent on a bed of arugula and steamed bass which was tasty but expensive for the portion. The fish was visually overwhelmed by the large stalks of Chinese broccoli and slices of bacon. I'm used to the fish being the "star" of the show. We, of course shared all the dishes. I would forego the dim sum because there are so many excellent dim sum houses all over the Bay Area. Yes, this was an expensive lunch but it was for a very special occasion in a modern, comfortable airy setting as we sat towards the outside. M.Y. China is convenient for those who wish to travel by Bart (25 mins from the peninsula) and 30-40 mins from Walnut Creek. This review would not be complete without acknowledging our excellent wait person, Bianca. She is knowledgeable, efficient, attentive without being obtrusive and friendly. Towards the end of the meal she presented us with a treat of light beignet type egg puffs with a trio of dipping sauces (whipped cream, chocolate and raspberry). What a perfect ending to a special luncheon
author: Gloria M.

description:
After reading mixed reviews on yelp of this place, I was hesitant to even consider MY China for dinner on a Friday night. It was a toss up between MY China or Hakkasan. But did I really want to spend $$$$ for my two boys?!  Love them, but not really. At least not that night.  I was surprised I was able to book a last minute rez on a Friday night at 8pm for my family of four.  It should have been a sign....

So after being seated in their "patio"-which is just their space outside the restaurant facing the shoppers passing by- we waited, and waited, and waited for other tables to get served and refilled their drinks, and it almost got to the point where I was going to the front of the restaurant and ask for the manager. But I'm glad that point never came. It would not have looked very good.  Our server finally showed up.

Needless to say, we were ready to order. Considering we ordered appetizers, noodles, fried rice and a salad, the timing of the food was all out of sorts:

The first entrée that came out wasn't our appetizers, it was our wild boar Scissor Cut Noodles. Delicious!  My boys (age 8 and 12) didn't have enough of it!  But was it wild boar? I'm not sure. I've had boar in previous meals before but the meat was so thinly sliced, it could have been beef tongue for all I know!

Next entrees that came out was the fried rice. My little one wanted pork with the fried rice instead of the scallops. Again the meat was so small, you could barely make out the meat. But I was really disappointed with the egg whites in the fried rice. Should have paid better attention to the menu. Anyway, this was by far the worst fried rice I ever had!  I'm still cringing at the thought that I paid $10 for this side dish.  Arghhhh....

Ok, moving along.... apparently appetizers of bang bang chicken wings came out boneless. Not sure if we got someone else's order or if their ordering system really translates "sauce on the side" to be "boneless" like our server stated. But I didn't want to send it back to try and figure out what it would even taste like without the orange chicken like sauce. And my pork belly sliders were on the mediocre side. One of my sliders was actually wet. Hopefully from the steam and not something else.

Next entrée that came was Chairman Mao's chicken.  I'm not sure where the sweet and spicy sauce is but there was a lot of red peppers. Like a lot!  For a table that asked for it not to be spicy, I think their ordering system mistranslated my order.... Again!  

At this point, we're stuffed and guess what comes out last?!  The mixed green salad with papaya and shrimp. At least that was good compared to everything else that came out of the kitchen before it. And looking at the salad, I'm glad their ordering system didn't mistranslate this one!  

Overall, I'm glad I came in to check it out and happy that my boys can say they had wild boar. Loved the ambiance and the antiques.  Aside from that, I don't think I'll return until their ordering system passes an ESL course.
author: Mey S.

description:
Came here on a whim while shopping. Passed by it a few times thinking what kind of name is MY China... and it took me a long time to figure out that MY stood for Martin Yan. My mom always watched his cooking show so he's kind of a figure in my childhood. It looked like a fancy place ($$) and the bf and I were excited to try it.

I had the wild boar scissor cut noodles and I thought wild boar was going to be such a new and exotic meat. It really wasn't. The texture was a cross between chicken and beef because it was soft and a little chewy. The meat to noodle ratio was really off and I barely had enough scraps of wild boar to even let the bf have a decent taste. The flavors were good though, but the overall dish is not worth the price. I understand the celebrity aspect of the restaurant, as well as the location, but it really was a one time thing for me. I think my expectations might have been too high.
author: Rita L.

description:
I honestly cannot fault this place!

The food is always amazing and I highly recommend trying the Chairman Mao's Chicken. It has the right amount of spice and the chicken breast is juicy.

I have been here 4 times and on each occasion service is always provided with a smile. Along with also being prompt.

Also, don't pass up the amazing Jasmine Tea!
author: Sarah J.

description: Don't know if it's a quality control or recipe issue, but all of the dim sum we tried was bland and nothing we'd return here for. Service, however, was quite good.
author: Maxine S.

description:
What a great place and an amazing experience. Joint Birthday - Anniversary evening, we were taken real good care off. 

The staff have taken some criticism in some of the review below, not the case. The staff were very attentive when they had to be. 

Regarding the food? Probably some of the best Chinese food and restaurant experience in San Francisco. 

We had the Peking duck as an appetizer, instead of pancakes, they had steamed buns that you made sliders with - super stuff. 

I had wht wok seared beef, super tasty and tender, no chewiness at all. Top Marks

My wife had the Chairman's Chicken, a dry dish but served with a couple of great sauces, unusual ones but great none the less. 

Bottom line, we live down the peninsula but cant wait to go back. 

Totally recommended.
author: D C.

description: Second chance success! The dumplings and sweet shrimp wok dish were standouts. I wasn't as much of a fan of the wild boar noodles as apparently others were. The Nixon cocktail was clean, crisp and not too sweet. Redemption.
author: Rudolph R.

description:
Maybe "Yan Can Cook" but I wonder how talented he is now that I have tried this restaurant and another chain he owns. 

This place has GREAT ambiance. But I much prefer the Chinese food I get at a traditional Chinese restaurant or PF Chang / Panda Express.  The food is just not flavorful.  We ordered the Spareribs and Beef and both dishes lacked a lot of flavor.  I felt like they could have added a bit more spice to the dish. The potstickers were mediocre, and I think 80% of the Chinese restaurant in South Bay or the city can serve the same thing, if not better.

The knife cut noodles are not the ones you get in China.  They don't slice noodles from a dough.  the knife cut noodles were long and stringy.  It didn't have the "chewy" texture that traditional knife cut noodles have.

If you are craving yummy / flavorful Chinese food, I urge you to go to a proper Chinese restaurant and forgo the décor.  This place looks great on the outside but lack substance on the inside.

The service, free sparkling water, décor and location makes this place a three star.  But I left disappointed with the food
author: Wendy K.

description: One of my favorite Asian Fusion restaurants in SF. The kobe beef is to die for! I would also highly recommend stopping by for lunch, its less crowded and more intimate. The Jasmine Collins is super refreshing.
author: Lilly K.

description:
I had high expectations for this restaurant since it's opened by Martin Yan. I think the standout dishes for lunch are the Beef Noodle Soup and the Crispy Quail. 

The rest of the dishes were a bit bland and flavorless like the Green Onion Pancake, Shandong Beef Rolls, and Shui Mai. Some of the dishes were reminiscent of street food like the Mu Shu Pork Tacos and Pork Belly Sliders gave an impression of being too expensive for what you get. 

The service was great and the atmosphere was a bit noisy even if the decor was quite swanky. A solid Chinese restaurant, but the dishes could be improved to really knock it out of the ballpark.
author: Jess W.

description: Great food! But the service can be a bit tricky. Sometimes the waiters that serve the food can be rude. Overall, great atmosphere! If you have Asian friends that appreciates Chinese food, then you should definitely take them there:)
author: Sarah J.

description:
Looked at this place several times, seems to be empty all of the time, the decor looks nice so I asked for a menu to take with me as we were not hungry at the time. They did not have one-- seems like a good way to get new customers to me?
They did refer me to their web site and their PDF menu only option to view the menu did not work for me. I give up, from the reviews here it looks overpriced and not so great, little surprise the place is empty.
author: K. K.

description: The food here was very good. I'm not a spicy person, but they cooked the food so well, it wasn't a bother. Our waiter was nice and very entertaining. Happy hour prices are very reasonable. The rest of the menu was kind of expensive, but you have to pay a little extra for good quality.
author: Patti R.

description:
Pretentious image. Always crammed, hosts sit customers squeezed in between tables, hosts are reluctant to sit customers where there is some decent, roomy space. Martin Yan adds to the pretentious image by asking us to see how "skillful" his cooks are (what a brat!). That REALLY turned me off!! Also, their floor is filthy with food particles and oils that fall on it as busy servers and dish bussers busily run back and forth with their trays. The unclean floor is a major turn-off to me, though, because it does not fit the image that this restaurant tries so hard to portray.

The waiter brings--or is supposed to bring, if he/she turns out to be one of the distracted ones--water nicely bottled by the house, plus the customer has the option of getting complimentary sparkling water, which, I believe, is a big plus. Their portions are generous--any dish can be shared by two--which makes it, really, a not expensive restaurant. Their service inconsistent: sometimes fast and attentive, sometimes unprofessional--some waiters get distracted, some others are overly casual (remember: overly casual equals unprofessional and may mean something worse). The ambiance is pleasant, not that noisy, since the place has good acoustics--the ambiance noise in the restaurant doesn't get amplified, therefore one can always carry out a conversation, as crowded and busy as it always tends to be. 

My favorite dish is the Forbidden Rice and my favorite cocktail drink is the East Meets West. Even though their noodles are home made, they do not impress me. However, their fresh teas are superb. And the desserts are exquisite!

The food is very clean and very fresh, for the most part. But its flavors are waaaay too average for what this establishment pretends and claims to be with all its unnecessary or even deceiving hype.
author: Raymond F.

description: This restaurant is verrrrrrrrrrrry good and quite posh. I hate to give 4 stars but I will admit I think we did some poor ordering. To start with the FANTASTIC, their shui mai dumplings will literally knock your socks right off right there at the table in the middle of the Westfield Mall. The sauce that comes with these dumplings I literally want to carry it in my bag for emergencies. It's outrageous. The onion pancakes were also incredibly tasty. Anywhere else I've ordered onion pancakes they usually come with some type of sauce and these didn't which I found strange but we used the dumpling sauce and literally just unlocked the gates to flavour town. We ordered pork bao and they were fine but again no sauce and those bao are a little dry without a sauce. Now to things I would do without next time- the wonton soup and kung pao chicken. I ordered the wonton soup because I'd been sick and it really sounded like a good idea at the time but honestly it was just broth and two wontons and some scallions and I just didn't feel strongly about it. I do still  feel strongly about how much I hated the kung pao chicken though. It was so dry and don't come with that sweet and sour glaze and it literally was just like eating sandpaper without it. I literally had one bite and we packed it up to try to give away to a homeless person but I literally couldn't have more than one bite. I think next time we'll stick to ordering only off the dim sum menu- I'd like to try a lot more of their dumplings. I would love to give this place 5 stars because it's a very nice atmosphere but I just really didn't vibe with 75% of our meal so I can't. Moral of the story- order the dumplings
author: Maddie O.

description: The food is amazing here, I enjoyed all the dishes I had. I loved the crab/pork dumpling it just melts in your mouth. Decorating is good and good for a family dinner or for a date as you can hangout at the bar. The only thing lacking was service had to wait little too long for dishes but I think it was worth it..
author: Jagan B.

description: I enjoyed it. We had a slow leisurely, multi-course meal (we did the pre-set crab and duck meals for 2) and it was all good. Highlights were forbidden rice and Peking Duck. Crab was messy but yummy. Shrimp could have had a lot more flavor. My friend loved her cocktail. It was a pretty place, in an unlikely location. Fun to watch the chefs play with the dough too.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Kung Pao chicken was good. Interesting red dried peppers brought a nice crunch to the dish.
We have tried 6-8 dishes and everything was good. Everything was very well done with knowledge and care.
I would say it is an excellent addition to that beautiful shopping mall.
author: Xela H.

description: Bump to 3.5 for the quick response and reasonable solution by Heather... will update when I get a taste of the old recipe again!
author: Erika C.

description:
We decided to give Martin Yan a try after a day of shopping. It was about 8:15 on a Wednesday, and the restaurant was half full. 

We went with the more expensive pri fix menu (around $100). We chose the dumpling sampler, Kung Pao Dungeness crab, crab fried rice, pea sprouts, and Chinese donuts.

Wild boar dumplings were wonderful!  Pork and truffle pork were okay. 

Kung Pao dungeness crab blew my mind. Comes beautifully prepared on a pile of red and green peppers, peanuts and Sichuan peppers.  Thank god for our waiter who encouraged us to eat the Sichuan peppers. They're not hot at all and are wonderfully light and crisp!  You have to eat them!  Yes I'll say it -- I think Martin's crab is better than R&G lounge's. 

The crab fried rice was very light - so light in fact that it lacked flavor, and we couldn't find the pieces of crab. 

Garlic pea sprouts were good. 

The Chinese donuts were very good and came with whipped cream and chocolate sauce. 6 generously large pieces.  

Minus 1 star-- Our waiter was extremely courteous and earnest, but the food came out too slowly. A couple sat down next to us, ate and paid their check before we got our dessert!

Overall: Dinner was solid, even though the prices make me grimace. I left happy enough to want to come back. Next time - noodles!
author: Jennifer I.

description:
Our go-to place for Xiaolongbao - those juicy little dumplings one of my kids is obsessed with.  They are bigger and thicker-skinned than I'd like but they are better than the ones you can get at Yank Sing (tiny and not juicy) or Shanghai Dumpling King (way too porky and not in a good way) for example.

Till Dintaifung opens in SF (please please please), this is where we'll get them.
author: Suji O.

description:
Made a reservation and were greeted and seated promptly on arrival by very friendly host staff.
Started off with Shandong beef rolls. Phenomenal. Hoisin sauce is a must. If you have any more than 2 people, you will need more than just one order.

For dinner, I had the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles... This dish was the highlight of the meal. The noodles were perfectly cooked, the boar and the mushrooms complemented each other wonderfully, and the whole dish was exceptionally well-seasoned.

My friend ordered the Kung Pao Chicken and we both agreed that the chicken, though quite tender, was under-seasoned. Also, it didn't have the kick he had expected since the Huang Fei chilies were more salty than spicy. He also had a side of Steamed Jasmine Rice, which was neither impressive nor disappointing; it was pretty standard rice.

Throughout the meal, we both enjoyed the Milk Oolong tea which is sublime. I can't get enough of this tea. I also enjoyed an East Meets West with my entrée - the tangy sweetness of the drink was a great accompaniment to the understated saltiness of the noodles.

For dessert, we shared Sugar Egg Puffs (which the waiter called Chinese donuts). They're large though light & airy, and have an inner texture reminiscent of a crueler. The outside is dusted with sugar and despite the inclusion of chocolate fondue, vanilla bean chantilly cream, and raspberry coulis, we preferred the chocolate to the point of exclusion of the other two.

The wait staff was friendly, efficient, invisible when nothing was needed, and immediately preset whenever they sensed something was needed.

I will certainly be eating here again.
author: Jonathon W.

description:
Every time I visit San Francisco - M.Y. China is an absolute must for my husband and I. We recently took my parents with us (picky eaters) and they loved it too.

They have absolute best seafood dumplings I've ever had. I literally dream of them. We also always order the spicy green beans as a side dish and scallop fried rice. Those 3 dishes eaten together are heaven on earth.

Can't recommend it enough!
author: Alexandra P.

description:
Not a bad experience, but for the price I couldn't recommend it. You're definitely paying for the ambience and service, so if the only way you can enjoy Chinese food is in a very upscale atmosphere then come on in. 

The decor is beautiful, with historic Chinese artifacts, including some moon cake presses that took three members of the staff to explain to us. The service is friendly and prompt, and very professional.

But this just set the stage for higher expectations on the food, which for me were unfortunately not met. The avocado and shrimp spring rolls sounded like an exciting combination, but lacked fresh herbs and was in fact mostly rice noodles. Bland. For the price, I would expect something special, and at the very least a little fresh mint. also, it was served with a mustard dipping sauce (I hate mustard). Unless you really believe you're improving nuoc cham, leave well enough alone.

I love handmade noodles, but the scissorcut noodles with wild boar was just so-so. I finally just added sauce from the mapo tofu to give it some much needed flavor and heat. 

The pork belly buns were tasty, but again, for the price, give me two pieces of meat in the bun so I'm not tasting mostly bread.

The most flavorful thing we ordered probably was that Mapo tofu. It seems to have some real Sichuan peppercorns in it, and it was quite spicy. Kind of skimpy on the tofu though, and I don't know why you couldn't give me a little more since tofu is not really super expensive.

In summation, this place would be a solid 3.5 stars if the price were about 30 to 50% less than what it is. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind paying a lot for and meal when the food is unique, flavorful and delicious, but unfortunately the food at MYChina isn't special enough to merit its special prices.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Everything is sooooo good there!! They make their own noodles and their own dumplings (baos) by hand! Love!! Would recommend!! The restaurant is located on the 4th floor of the Westfield mall in San Fran next door to Nordstroms. Ambiance is very fun as well great date night restaurant!
author: Jeanie H.

description:
I have eaten here
 numerous times since they have graciously received and acted on my feedback.The food has been consistently good quality and staff has been polite professional and efficient.Good job to all involved.
author: Victoria S.

description:
This feels like a PF Changs version 2.0
How do I put it.. the food was nothing to rave about and the service was a bit lacking ... Maybe it was the fact that we came in for new year's eve dinner and perhaps it was an off day for the chefs..

Anyhow we ordered some $68 set menu for two. Lets start with the appetizer 6 dumplings.. what I assume are xiao long bao. This was perhaps one of the better dishes. But the skin was a bit too thick and I really only liked the one stuffed with crab meat.. (definitely pales in comparison to Din Tai Fung's Michelin star but that isn't really fair to compare thr two)

-PEKING DUCK.. this is one of the worst peking ducks I have ever had. I was expecting nice flat crispy pieces that glistened under the light but what we got was something quite different.. in fact the skin looked rough and dry. And oh man was the duck salty... I felt like I ate a tablespoon of salt everytime I took a piece of that god awful duck. 

-fried wonton bowl with what I assume is sweet and sour sauce... Meh.. it had chicken, beef, and shrimp. But again I am not sure why it was so dang salty!! 
 
The forbidden rice was better than I thought it would be. But it doesn't really help balance the other two saltastic dishes. And at this point my expectations were pretty low.

Overall:
Pros: decor (check out the 18 buddhas) and the snuff bottles near the restroom. Presentation of the dishes was ok..

And the other things: 
1.chefs probably mistakened that salt shaker for the msg powder..
2. hey guys (my china waiters) ever wonder why many asian restaurants provide smaller bowls for rice plates?  Cause it is mighty uncomfortable eating rice from a plate using chopsticks!
3. Where is the toilet paper or seat covers? Hey maybe have someone check the restrooms every so often..

You can definitely find better food in Chinatown (funny thing here is that I am really no fan of Chinatown.. what can I say I guess I have stayed in Hong Kong for too long) Anyways if you want better service go to Hakkasan. Better food I would recommend R&G Lounge.
author: Norm L.

description:
Food was ok...not worth the price and portion size.  You are truely just paying for the atmosphere which I don't mind sometimes.   But after awhile,  it will get old.  

My only compliant was the to-go box.  Because I've been here before, I knew of their portion sizes so I ordered a few more dishes.  We had a little left of each dish and they packed it in a huge box.  Really...you have one size to-go box!
author: MickYee M.

description:
Two of us came for an early dinner-late lunch at 4:30. There is an entrance on Market where one can take an elevator to the fourth floor.  Arriving at the restaurant by this approach minimizes that one is in a mall. Can't tell at all from the outside and certainly not from the inside.

Of course once arriving at the restaurant and describing the goal is to have small bites the staff could not have been more pleasant. Seated us immediately. Asked them for a good place to sit and they found the perfect place. Not noisy.  Wait staff outstanding.  Food memorable.  Recommend seafood dumplings which were tasty and finished quickly. Soup portion plentiful. Beef Rolls disappeared almost as fast as dumplings. Calamari was fine too-- a little salty and did not disappear as with the other selections.

Given the location this is as good as it gets--no hesitation--will come come again. The staff was outstanding the food was great.  Couldn't think of a better place to go in the neighborhood.
author: Steve L.

description:
Yums. Excellent chinese food at above average prices. Prefer it so much more than the food court. You can have lunch for about $20 eating in if you keep it to one large dish with a side of rice or two dim sum options (I chose while wheat pot stickers and lotus leaf mixed rice). Server said my pairing was "interesting". LOL.

A great fun date spot if your bf is paying. I'd go broke if I became a regular.
author: Deb B.

description: This place was a surprised for us. Tired from shopping we stopped in for a meal. Lo and behold I did not know it is Martin Yan's resto. I enjoyed the spicy calamari and the roast chicken. Brought me back to Hong Kong with its side of five spice. The food is very clean and prepared well and the prices are reasonable specially for San Francisco.
author: G D.

description: Jasmine tea sea bass, boar scissor cut noodles, and spicy dumplings very good. General spicy chicken, Sichuan green bean, and eggplant tofu clay pot good
author: Duke A.

description:
Pleasantly surprised here. My friend wanted to go and I gave in because she just wouldn't take no for an answer. I just didn't want to pay too much for mall food,  but the food here is actually ok. 

Scissor cut noodles were just the right consistency. Dan dan noodles were good but a little vinegary. That's ok, dandan is one of those dishes everyone makes different. 

The xiao long bao were a disappointment, served on a spoon so you can get all the juices (I guess this is for Midwesterners and foreigners who don't get the concept of soup dumplings) but it had sat on the spoon so long that the spoon was scalding hot!  Also the dumping stuck to the spoon. 

I also wasn't a fan of the dancing noodle guys but the older people and kids seemed to enjoy it. 

Overall a pretty good place,  considering what you usually get in a mall.
author: Victoria W.

description:
Huge fan of their food (both dim sum and dinner) but way down on their service.  Hence the 3 stars (otherwise i'd be so high on this place)

My kids are huge fans of their dim sum so i find myself here at least once a month on average.  Some faves:  beijing dumplings, bbq pork buns, cured pickles, spicy chicken filets, beijing knife cut noodles, dan dan noodles, sweet & sour pork.  Almost everything here is very fresh and tasty.  

Onto their service and staff.. I have to say the service was far better when this place first opened.  It's deteriorated since about six months ago.  

HOSTS are the worst.  Most are rude and act like they can't be bothered.  I asked the host on my recent visit as she was walking by our table if we could get our water bottle for the table refilled and instead of takiing the bottle off the table to refill it herself or having someone else take care of the request, she rolled her eyes and said someone would be by our table shortly and we could ask.  Never mind that the only reason why we ended up having to ask the host is because no one had walked by our table for a long while!  

SERVERS are slow moving - not sure if it's a function of each of them having too many tables or if they're just lackluster slow.  It's not unusual if we have to wait 5-10 min after first sitting down to have a server come by.  THen another 10min for the server to come back for drink orders and questions on the menu.  I have it down now where i order drinks as soon as we sit down and the food when they first come to the table.  Then the server normally comes by unsolicited once (sometimes twice or thrice if the server is actually good) during meal service.

INATTENTIVE AND SUBPAR SERVICE OVERALL.   

If they are trying to pull off the higher end Chinese restaurant image, they are headed in the wrong direction with the caliber of their staff.
author: ellelle l.

description:
After having a horrible experience at Straits Restaurant (next door), I thought I would never eat at a fancy mall restaurant again. But being human, I forgot and went to M.Y. China. 

Spicy Seafood Dumpling (6) - interesting, but would not order again.
Forbidden Rice - why is so popular? It's just fried brown rice with no flavor.
Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles- salty and nothing spectacular. where's the meat? 
Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup- "so salty i'm gonna die from sodium overdose"

I just don't get it.. what's so special about its noodle? Just because it's hand pulled? Hmm... All I remember about this dinner: SALTY SALTY SALTY.

And overpriced as always. Just save your money and go to a legit Chinese restaurant somewhere else. This is basically a fancy PF Chang.
author: Sunny K.

description: Dim sum with a twist and a price to match. I judge my   Dim sum by steamed pork bun and har gar and they delivered with both. Pork bun savory not sweet, fluffy moist but not wet dough. The shrimp ball was all shrimp with a hint of something aromatic and a glistening thin rice wrap. Pea sprouts were excellent although I prefer a younger sprout , but well cooked with savory garlic. Service top notch. But once again it's just so hard to drop $100 on a few dim sum pieces even though they were really good. I grew up hitting Clement street's cheaper eats, survived my student days on a tray full of tasty morsels for only $15. It is still possible.
author: Matt A.

description: We came back today and tried four different dim sum dishes for lunch and we were not disappointed.  We had the shrimp dumplings, Beijing dumplings, boar soup dumplings, and Shi Mui.  Everything was so hot that we had to wait for it to cool off before eating.  I was offered free sparkling water with my meal.  Our waiter Ryan was excellent and made us feel very comfortable.  Everything was fast and friendly.  I can't wait to come back. The only drawback is that M.Y. China is so busy during the holidays that I couldn't hear my companion so it was really hard to have a conversation over lunch.  I'll be back right after the holidays for another nice meal. Thanks Heather for reaching out to me!
author: Lorissa W.

description:
4.5 Stars.  So good!

The only thing that keeps M.Y. China from getting five stars is the crappy seating arrangements.  Most of the two-top tables are scrunched together so that you can't help but eavesdrop on the conversations to your left and right.  My husband and I kept laughing at the snippets of conversation we couldn't help but hear. 

On to the good stuff.

We tried the spicy seafood dumplings, which were indeed spicy and delicious.  The forbidden rice sounded intriguing.  Wolf berries?  I have never heard of them.  I still don't know what they are, but the rice was very good with a nice chew to it.  My husband is a sucker for honey walnut prawns.  These were good, though much like any other honey walnut prawns you might find.  The stir fried green beans were perfectly cooked with just a bit of crunch and a nice, light spiciness.  I ordered the Peking duck and it was heavenly!  I exercised a little restraint so that I could take some of this home for the next day's lunch.

Drinks here were a bit expensive, but good.  Service was very attentive.  I hope to come back, maybe with a group of four?  The larger tables seemed to be spaced out a little better.
author: Raina S.

description: Good, but not worth the price. Definitely better places out in Chinatown for a way better price. Each entree runs $10+ and are tiny portions! Kevin, our waiter, provided terrible, if any, service... Would not come back.
author: Andy V.

description:
It took several visits before my boyfriend and I realized M.Y. stood for Martin Yan, from Yan Can Cook.  We've always enjoyed the hand-pulled noodles, that is a definite must-try if you are dining their for the first time.

Our last visit, we had the pleasure of catching one of the noodle demonstrations.  It was really amazing to see the chefs perform their techniques for making snap noodles, angel-hair-fine pulled noodles, and even "dancing noodle", which looked a lot like ribbon dancing with food!

A word of advice, they only open for dinner right at 5:30pm, and they will usually have a line of people for walk-ins.  Get there at 5pm or earlier, otherwise you're going to be waiting a very long time.
author: Addi M.

description: was very excited to try the food here, came here on 3/30/16 mid afternoon,was dying to eat the noodles and everything else! got seated in front of kitchen, maybe 4-5 tables busy,lots of workers standing around. I ordered dumplings , almost 1/2 hr later I got them. prob was no one EVER came to take my order ( and they knew the dumplings weren't my main course!). so, got the dumplings, watched the lady employee peel off lettuce cups,wipe her nose and forehead,fix hair, and touch all the produce.again .oh, and again.watched the tall kid with long hair tied back, but not properly secured ( it was swinging everywhere!)-yuck. So, they delived the dumplings,i let them know politely I never got a order taken, the girl proceeded to *tell* me dumplings take that long. ok.........so what about taking a order, checking in with me, hello? Really wont recommend here, sub par and careless employees who saw I was looking around for someone forever, but no one cared. It was a party of 1 , seriously. get it together! someone needs to work on *a lot* of issues, starting with management being ignorant.
author: Aubrey P.

description: Great sea bass dish and peking duck was good too. Grandma's gai lan was so-so. And the appetizer pickles were meh. Good cocktails. Nice ambiance.
author: anna j.

description: Modern Chinese food done right. Highlights- soup dumplings and crab with scallions and ginger served in a clay pot. The 'puff egg' dessert was also delicious! Peaking duck was good but small portion. Braised beef and noodle soup was tasty. Crab fried rice was very bland and not much crab if any. Forbidden rice was different but not my style. Overall excellent experience and friendly wait staff!
author: Christina C.

description:
I really like this place and its food.
The setting is a bit dark to my taste but it is quite beautiful.
The food is amazing. Considering it is a restaurant above a shopping mall, the food is so much better than those "authentic" Chinese restaurants in China town. I would recommend their dumplings and noodles.
author: Anonymous R.

description: The staff was great, very friendly. And the food is reasonably price, and f*cking amazing, I highly recommend it.
author: Brandon B.

description: When my friend suggested this restaurant, I was  kind of hesitate to go since it looks like some kind of Americanized Chinese food to me. However, I was impressed. The roasted duck and chicken are great! The lobster was nicely prepared! I wouldn't say it is the most authentic Sichuan food, but it was very tasty! Will definitely come back when I visit SF.
author: Shawn G.

description: Nice ambience with soft lighting...not easy to achieve in a mall. Friendly, efficient service. Entrees were fresh, tasty but not memorable. Not happy, however, about $16 for a "side" of steamed peashoots.
author: Jesse W.

description:
I am so glad that I broke my rule about eating in a mall.  But then again, Westfield isn't just a mall - it's a destination, or so the commercials say.

MY China is very pretty inside and the service was impeccable.  It's always a pleasure to eat somewhere where they know how to do it right.  Our server was very helpful and made several spot-on suggestions.  Our plates were removed promptly between courses, and any time my glass was empty, they refilled it without me having to ask.  The restaurant queen in me (my husband's description) appreciates great service!

We ended up sharing several items, the first of which was the avocado shrimp spring rolls.  They were kind of a disappointment since the filling was pretty scant.  I was much happier with the dumplings that we had next.  The skin on them was fantastic 0 just the right thickness and a wonderful texture.  And the stuffing was dreamy, especially since each bit was accompanied by the juice that was contained inside.  I ended up with wild boar noodles and my friend had the Dan Dan noodles.

I was a little skeptical of the wild boar at first since my initial bites came up kind of gristly, but after that everything smoothed out.  The noodles were chewy and toothsome (I love using that word) and the combo of the wild boar, scallions and sauce was perfect.  My pal's noodles were also delicious, and I loved the taste of the peanut sauce.  It had a nice heat to it.

I will be back again and again.  

Recommended!
author: .Hon H.

description:
I was skeptical for very many reasons but I was pleasantly surprised. Honestly I was expecting over-priced Panda Express, which is a common theme for hip-looking Asian restaurants.   There is a level of authenticity to it and it's nothing like P.F Chang's (which is a Fusion restaurant).  I had quite a good experience overall:  service, food and ambiance.  

I won't mind eating here again :)
author: Caroline P.

description: Straight up DELICIOUS!!! I actually ate from this place by a mistake because the company who we originally ordered from did not deliver so as a courtesy we got this place. I order some noodle plate, I don't know what it was but it was to good and I had ordered the "bang bang wings". Oh my lord they were superbbbb! I would say they are affordable enough to feed 2 or 3 if one person is picking up the check on a random night, so yes that included date night (would actually surprise your date). But definitely go here!
author: Jaleel S.

description:
Came for lunch with a friend last month because while she was visiting from out of town. 

Service overall was good and decor was nice. We ordered the salt and pepper calamari, lobster and scissor cut noodles (it came with the lobster). I'm not a big fan of lobsters but wanted to try their lobster from different province promotion. I really liked the lobster dish but the noodles not that much. Loved the calamari, it was crispy and seasoned to perfection! 

I'm not sure if I like the concept of eating "fancy"/ expensive Chinese food in the middle of a mall (not a food court). It felt a bit weird but maybe that's just me! 

Overall enjoyed the experience but need to try another of their noodle dish because wasn't impressed with the one we had!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Recently had dinner here with some family and friends. Hostess was prompt and courteous. Wait staff was just ok. Food overall was a surprise, as it was all pretty decent. Soup and dry noodle dishes were very good, vegetable and fish dishes were tasty and well prepared. Prices are expensive, but this is a tourist area in a mall so not unexpected. If it stopped here, they would get 3.5-4 stars.

But, the hot and sour soup was poor. This is a staple at most Chinese restaurants, and this one was super spicy but blah overall. I've had much better versions elsewhere all over SF.

Here is where they lose 2 stars though. Late afternoon until about 6:00 they have a Happy Hour with drink specials and some appetizer specials. Signage is up and the sign has no restrictions.  We sit down a few feet from the bar for dinner, but are told No, we cannot order Happy Hour drinks and that Happy Hour is only for people at the Bar. Did I mention the Bar was a few feet away?!?!  So because we are patronizing your restaurant for dinner and are going to spend 5x as much on food, versus patrons at the Bar, we are penalized?!?!  Management needs to get their head examined for this one, you will lose customers over this and I have never had this issue at hundreds of restaurants.
author: Bentley L.

description: Decent food but priced above its weight. Too bad. I like Martin and his lower scale restaurant.
author: Jody B.

description:
So where do I begin. The food is pricey but that's expected from a restaurant in sf. Small selection of dim sum, if that's what your looking for. However the selection they have is good. My wife and I had the dan dan noodles. It was good but not great. We also had the bang bang chicken wings, they were good. We also had the pork ribs and weren't too impressed. They were a little dry. Nothing special. The staff was friendly and helpful. I give them four stars cause the food was good and the staff was friendly. I really do hope that they add more selections of dim sum in the future. 

The final question is, would I return? Answer is...... Sure why not.
author: Marvin G.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurants in US!!
Most of the restaurants located in the shopping centers are mediocre when it comes to the quality of food however this restaurant is one exception.
I have been there numerous times and i have never been disappointed.
I highly recommend it. 
It is not your average Chinese restaurant!!
author: Alex K.

description:
Very impressed.  Sitting in the Restaurant Collection at the Westfield mall, M.Y. China has great ambiance, decent service, and outstanding food and cocktails.  It is a perfect place for a good and classy meal when seeing a show downtown.  Make reservations.

Our party of three started with cocktails and I recommend all of them - East Meets West, Mai Tai, and Under the Bronze Bell - and then shared the Peking Duck Dinner for Two along with the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles and Mapo Organic Tofu.  The Peking Duck Dinner for Two was outstanding...every dish, especially the Forbidden Rice, Peking Duck, and the Sugar Egg Puffs (for dessert).  I would also recommend the Wild Boar Noodles but pass on the Mapo.
author: Chad S.

description:
My boyf and I were thrilled and excited to try out this new place at the top floor of Westfield Mall, right after i get my shopping done and right before we enjoy our movie. Such a perfect location!
Based on Yelpers recommendations, we ordered the juicy dumpling trio, Wild boar scissors cut noodles, forbidden rice, a cocktail, and the M.Y. China dessert. To us, the food was super delicious, all of them. Especially the very special M.Y China dessert (the one that you take a sip of fermented rice water and swallow it together with ice-cream), never had something like this before and glad that we gave it a try.

The pricing is definitely higher than a regular chinese place, but given the location and atmosphere, I thought it is reasonable. It is more than a regular chinese place, it is more like a classy upscale place to dine in, i would say.

Everything was perfect, the only part to pick on was: still or sparkling water?
I mean it is great that, unlike other restaurants, M.Y. China provide complimentary sparkling water, but it took us a few second to understand what our waiter was asking. =D

We really had a pleasant time dining here and are already planning for our next visit!
author: Ying L.

description:
I think this is one of the best vegetarian Chinese places in the city. I'm a big vegetarian ma po tofu connoisseur and there's is one of the best I've ever had. Seriously, I order ma po tofu everywhere it's offered. And, this place has one of the best. It's spicy, savory, and delicious.

Also, don't be deterred by their seemingly meat heavy menu. They've actually got a ton of vegetarian options. Just ask them. I don't know why they don't have a separate vegetarian menu. 

Their vegetarian noodle soup is absolutely delicious. The broth is great and the medley of mushrooms is scintillating. 

I had their spicy cocktail which was also fantastically refreshing. It wasn't as spicy as the waiter threatened, but it was a great not-sweet cocktail.

I'm definitely going back and if you're a vegetarian looking for a great Chinese place in SF, head to the mall. (I know. That sounds wrong, but this place is so right)

Why not 5 stars? It's in a mall. I just can't get myself to give 5 stars to a place in a mall. Any foodie I know would de-friend me in a minute.
author: Neal V.

description:
Expected less from a mall restaurant, were very pleasantly surprised. Sever Daniel was perfect. Food was flawless and we (non-Asians) are not inexperienced and well-traveled. Had come from the Fancy Food Show and were vegetable deprived and sugar saturated, needing some veggies and light fare. The menu, decor and service fit the bill. I am sure, you can find better Chinese if you know where to look, better service if you are willing to pay, but for us, on this evening, it was just perfect.

Did not know it was Martin Yang's restaurant until we went to the Yelp page.
author: James K.

description:
I am philosophically at a struggle with MY China.  It irritates me to no end to see unauthentic Chinese food in America.  And MY China is no exception.  Northern noodles are mixed with Shanghainess dumplings on the same menu as hot and sour soup and har gaw, each missing some component of authenticity.  Shanghainess dumplings aren't served with the right vinegar.  Noodles are missing the complex spices that often appears on these regional dishes. 

Alas, I am in Martin Yan's world. He already made it pretty clear that this MY's China.  He never claimed that it's the real China. I mean, the menu isn't even written in Chinese. So who am I to complain?

Okay. So I block out the part of me that yearns for the real thing, and eat like a person who's learned to forgive Panda Express. 

The good: steam buns may come with Americanized fillings like Mongolian beef, but the buns themselves are made beautifully, well risen into a perfect dome.  The BBQ pork is pricier than your local char siu shop, but you can see the quality.  Scissor cut noodles come with chewy and dry boar meat, but the noodles themselves are really chewy in a nice way.  

The great: the hand pulled noodle soup was the highlight.  Beef was done perfectly, tender, flavorful.  Talented Taiwanese mothers may beg to differ on how it should be made, but as long it's a good bowl of yumminess, we can forget about authenticity for a minute. 

The dishes with room for improvement: Shandong beef rolls had great flavors, but the pancake part was too hard. Like my dad said: Either make it crispy or soft, don't try to do both!

The crispy spring rolls were really average. 

All in all, I would come back again.  I like the decor, the service, the idea of a Chinese restaurant with ambiance.  And I don't have a gazillion dollars in my pocket to eat at Hakkasan every time, so having some dim sum at MY China is a nice alternative.
author: Candice B.

description:
I eagerly await any new restaurant that has noodles. I am a noodle whore. When I learned that Martin Yan had this joint hooked up in the mall, I said it was to good to be true... When my noodle partner in crime suggested we make a date of it, I quickly agreed. We had a whole day of pampering and shopping and treating ourselves to yummy lunch planned.

It's quite spacious inside - I didn't feel like I was inside the mall at all. Ok, minus the giant table of tourists and baby strollers and shopping bags....maybe I could forget I was in the mall. Our server was sweet and attentive. I had a simple pinot grigio since I'm a lady who lunches (and drinks) and we started with the spring rolls and crispy tofu to share. Needless to say, we gobbled them up quickly. The spring rolls were veggie and I'm a sucker for a good sauce - this did not disappoint. The tofu was fried goodness - how can you go wrong?

I settled for the hand pulled wild boar noodles since that I really wanted something to sink my teeth into. I love the consistency of the noodles and the boar was flavorful. We also shared the garlic pea shoots -- which are like crack -- they were so tasty. What do they put in there?! I forget the name of the cocktail my pal ordered, but she loved it. It tasted like a kicked up manhattan. Their drink list is definitely something I want to revisit - especially since they have a drink called Big Trouble in My China. If you know me at all, you know I have a weakness for the movie Big Trouble in Little China...but I digress. I have green eyes.

I docked one start because it was so salty. I don't know if MSG was a culprit, but we seriously walked out of there puffed up, hands swollen, sweaty and with the thirst of someone who feels like they have the tongue of a cat. No joke. That's the only negative I took away from this place. Well, that and it's pretty pricey if you compare it to food court snackage - but this is a restaurant, not a dingy tray/table establishment. You won't be disappointed. There's much more I'd like to sample and the fun noodle pulling show (get your mind out of the gutter) was hilarious to watch.
author: Jessica P.

description:
This was celebrity chefing at its worst. The menu looked pretty great- though expensive- and I was looking forward to coming here with my husband.

Our dinner was, overall, rather bland and sweet. The mint jasmine Collins was terrific- my favorite thing to the night. Of the pickle trio, only the daikon was good- the daikon were great, actually. The other two pickles were not great. The winter squash was far too uninteresting syrupy sweet and the last pickle had so little flavor I can't recall what it was. The tacos were tasty, but my husband said his had way too much raw onion and mine had very little/none- consistency issues? Dan dan noodles were okay but not made there, which was disappointing with all the other house made noodles- and it was simply not that flavorful. The saddest was that the sugar egg puffs were very disappointing. Real Chinese puffs are eggy, tender, soft inside and crispy crunchy outside, served freshly made and hot. These were just pre-made cream puffs, without the filling, rolled in sugar. As a cream puff, it's great! But I was expecting eggy tenderness, so that was disappointing. It was like asking for a frozen custard and getting a nice frozen yogurt instead. It sorta doesn't matter that it's a nice yogurt, when it's supposed to custard. And it was way too expensive for the quality and taste. 

I really like Martin Yan, so I wanted to love it here. Bummed that I don't.
author: M B.

description:
Popped in for a quick pre-movie bite to eat and were delighted at the wonderful taste sensations we received. We were munching on the fabulous pork and crab juicy dumplings (akin to shanghai soup dumplings) when I looked up and saw Martin Yan  himself, warmly chatting with guests at a nearby table. He made his way around the room, asking how we were enjoying our meal and it was such fun to meet him in person and tell him we LOVED the wonderful foods he inspired.  

We loved the Dan Dan Noodles (cold noodles with pork and peanuts in a spicy sauce), Sichuan Green Beans, and Kung Pao Chicken, which came with some really interesting hot chili pepper pods that we could actually eat without scorching the lining out of our mouths.  Service was speedy and our waitress deftly guided us in our menu choices.  We unfortunately ran out of time and had to get to our show but promised ourselves that next visit we'll try the delicious looking Sugar Egg Puffs (looked like sugar-dusted) with a variety of dipping sauces that were served at a nearby table. 

Pricing is on the high side, but what you'd expect at Westfield Center next to Bloomingdales. They have a full bar and an attractive lounge area, and stock some interesting Chinese beers.  

I look forward to visiting again soon!
author: Bevy M.

description: Bad service, we didn't get half of the good that we ordered. We had almost no service. We didn't know who was waiting on us half the time. We couldn't even get water and the place wasn't that busy. We made a comment to the manager and that didn't help. Finally another manager came and we let him know that we hadn't gotten our water or rice and we were almost done. Not to mention we were missing a whole entree. The meal ended up being free but I still wouldn't waste my time.
author: Jenna M.

description: "Can Yan cook?" is a question you may find yourself asking, when faced with the choice to visit M.Y. China, his San Francisco restaurant. Let's look at the evidence: A convenient, beautiful location under the dome of the Westfield Centre houses a restaurant best termed Asian Fusion. The food came out at weird times (one entree before the appetizer, before the rice which was at the end). But don't knock off stars yet. Because once you taste the excellently cooked meat, perfectly seasoned, and nicely complimented by the vegetables, you will enjoy your meal. My party shared the sweet and sour pork, lamb stir fry, chairman Mao chicken, and we started with the beef rolls. All was excellent. All dishes are recommended, and lead to a resounding answer to this reviewer's founding question: Yan can cook! He can cook very well. And you should see so by patronizing this place.
author: Joseph K.

description:
I will name my encounter at this singularly outstanding restaurant: "Feast of an eternally happy and infinitely delighted hungry California bear." What else can you come up with in English that will reflect just how ecstatic and satisfied you were when you (very hesitantly and almost apologetically) walked out at the end of a well-spent 90 minutes?  There is the kind of satisfaction the Rolling Stones sing about and then there is this no less decadent fulfillment. The pleasures of the flesh start with the stomach. Mick Jagger would definitely get satisfaction here. I know I did.That is the conclusion I reached today. The emperor can have his concubines if I can have just one more meal here. I don't know what to review since everything we ordered (party of five so with appetizers we had about 8 items) was superb, sublime
and spectacular. The freshly made noodles are particularly noteworthy. The service was excellent from start to finish. The staff were courteously and attentive but did not pester you with needles intrusions.This is a finely tuned machine. You will not be disappointed. You will be stupefied by how deliciously textured and refined Chinese based cuisine can be. You will be licking your fingers and the bottom of your plate from start to finish.
author: Jahan T.

description: Was really looking forward to trying this place. Unfortunately it wasn't great. The service was very slow. I ordered the wok fried beef- it was completely tasteless, it came on top of a plate of arugula that had no dressing. No taste and odd combination. My friend ordered a vegetarian dish that was way tastier. I don't think I'd return. It's a pity, the location and decor are very nice.
author: Cate H.

description: I recently made a return visit with a few friends from work. I had the same reaction as before, and my colleagues (most of whom are also foodies, and well-acquainted with Chinese restaurants) had similar reactions.
author: Jethro B.

description:
Food was great - service needs more training.   There's too much 'checking in' ('Did you like the scissor-cut noodles?  how do you like that Buddha beer?') when it's not really needed -- but not enough when it IS needed.

We noticed the Dine About Town menus so tried one of each for lunch.  One was soup and wild boar scissor cut noodles - the other was mixed dim sum- both with dessert.  

Soup came.  Really nice.  Noodles came.  Noodles half consumed.  So one person is halfway through lunch -- other person hasn't been served anything to eat yet.  

Someone came by to see if the person who was eating would like another beer.  To which he replied:  "No, I'm fine, but I was hoping my wife could get lunch sometime.'  

The staff explained the food is all served family style and comes out when it's ready, and apologized that no one had explained this.  That's fine -- but then the Dining About Town lunch options don't make any sense.  

BUT!  putting aside the fine-tuning on the service side -- the food is really, really good.  I will definitely come have some noodles or dim sum before or after movies or shopping.  Everything we tasted was made with high quality ingredients, and was nicely seasoned.
author: Jaina S.

description:
Extremely disappointing! Spare ribs were coated is a thick horrible crust. Shrimp was covered in a thick horseradish sauce not even listed in the description.
Noodles were covered in greasy hot pepper oil. Only bad food that we had in our week long visit to the Bay Area. A huge waste of $134.00 & terrible service as well!!
author: Nanci M.

description:
The first Martin Yan restaurant I tried was Yan Can Cook that was located in Pleasant Hill, CA (but has sadly closed). Unfortunately, I wasn't impressed with what Martin Yan had to offer there, so when my family decided to try his newer restaurant, I didn't have very high hopes for it.

We ordered the (1) Juicy Dumpling Trio, which consisted of three different soup-dumplings (wild boar, crab, and black truffle), the (2) Beef Hand-Pulled Noodle Soup, the (3) Chairman Mao's Chicken, the (4) Five-Spice Pork Ribs and the (5) Honey-Glazed Walnut Shrimp.

(1) The Dumplings were tasty, and I like how they're served on individual soup-spoons. The spoons are also colored to indicate which of the dumplings are what (sadly, I can't remember which color pertained to which Dumpling at the moment...).

(2) The beef in this soup is very tender and falls apart in your mouth. The broth is great, yet I felt as if it were missing a spice to round off the dish.

(3) The chicken pieces are bite-sized and are crispy on the outside, but juicy on the inside. It comes with two sauces (a sweet AND a sour sauce, not just sweet and sour, if that makes sense).

(4) The Ribs were by far my favorite entree from the bunch. They're definitely coated in Five-Spice, and the ribs are much like the chicken; crispy on the outside yet juicy on the inside.

(5) Normally, I love Honey-Walnut Shrimp, but they serve it with a Wasabi-type glaze, which threw me off the typical sweet Honey-Walnut Prawns I order from other restaurants. I commend them for the different approach, but I firmly believe in the saying, "Don't mess with a good thing".

Overall, the dishes here were much tastier than the dishes I had at Yan Can, but they were definitely not worth the price. And although I loved their Five-Spice Ribs, I feel as if my parents could make the same ribs at home for half the cost, and in greater quantity. My final verdict: Good food, but DEFINITELY not worth the price.
author: George T.

description: Really great food with quick service. Highly recommend this place for good quality food. The noodles are amazing.
author: Chloe G.

description: Came here on a Saturday night without a reservation after our first plans fell through.  With a wait for a table, we opted to sit at the bar immediately.  We had very friendly, attentive bar tenders who took our orders and the food served in less than 5 minutes.  Interesting house specialty drinks.  The food was really great, mu shu tacos, pork belly sliders, dim sum sampler, and wild boar lettuce wraps.  We will definitely be back and would recommend trying it.
author: Steven B.

description: Best shumai ever! Great happy hour starts 3pm on weekdays. Love their preparation of soup dumplings as well. This place just keeps getting better.  I also recommend the milk oolong tea.
author: Meredith G.

description:
M. Y. China was a complete disappointment!!!!!!  There was three of us eating for lunch and interesting enough all of our entrees came ten minutes apart!  We did not get to eat together.......it was the weirdest thing ever!  My husband ordered wonton soup and when it came out we were all in shock.  It was a white mucous broth with four dumplings in it........it looked like the leftover water from poaching eggs!!! The flavor was worse than it looked........need I say more?
Never, never, ever again!!!!!
WARNING:  DO NOT EAT HERE!
author: Discerning T.

description:
My work colleague picked this restaurant, and for the most part, it broke practically every rule in my book, but the 2 most important: A) Don't eat in a mall.  B) Don't eat at a Chinese restaurant with white waiters.  

My fears became more evident, as I sat down and thought to myself... did I just sit down in a more expensive version of PF Chang's?  My fears were further compounded when I noticed black truffles as an ingredient in soup dumplings.  Really?  I know we're trying to be "creative" here, but really?  

While there was one reasonably bright spot, M.Y. China completely fulfilled my expectations.  The hot and sour soup was a little too aggressively sour (and expensive).  My boss put his bowl down and "graciously" offered me more.  The Sichuan green beans (gan bian si ji dou) were not "gan bian" at all.  My knife cut noodles, the ONE thing I was looking forward to, did not have the familiar QQ texture-- they were thin and overcooked, leading to soggy and soft noodles.  The noodles that did have the appropriate texture, were the scissor cut noodles... ironically noodles I've never come across in Chinese cuisine.  Those, I would consider coming back for, but the meal in its entirety was a disappointment

With a final bill that would be more appropriate at a nice French place, it all kind of felt like a sham... though, thankfully... it was not my choice, and the company paid.  Otherwise, I'd be super bummed.  I think this restaurant tries really hard to spruce up Chinese food, but in doing so, messes up on technique and flavors.  In hindsight, my rating may be slightly harsh, but the value factor ultimately aids in M.Y. China's demise.
author: Jeff J.

description:
Food was different and good. Not good enough to repeat mainly due to the horrible general management and service.

I like Martin Yen, so wanted to eat here since he is an entertaining and seemingly great cook. It did not live up to it because of the front end and waiting staff. It may have been just our waiter because the "helper waiters" were a lot more friendly and genuine.

While I believe it is a newer restaurant, they should have their act together by now. We had a RESERVATION and waited for 30 minutes from the time of our reservation time and were seated. The host promised a free round of drinks once we sat down. A smarter move would have been to bring drinks to the lounge area we were waiting in to keep us less upset about waiting for THIRTY minutes when we had a reservation and were on time.

When we got to the table, the fake/pretentious waiter gave a half hearted sorry for the wait. He wasn't aware of the complementary drinks promised to us and had to check - the host should have told him.

The waiter was half hearted and fake the whole time which added to the negative experience here.
author: Raj P.

description:
I wasn't expecting this. 

One of our most frequent Saturday lunches is Dim Sum at Yank Sing. We were out and about and decided to give MY China a try. We had to go to the mall anyway so what the heck. The place was busy but certainly not packed. There were tables. Nonetheless, we were seated at a bar just a few inches away from the kitchen. Staring through the glass wall it was apparent the kitchen enjoyed what they were doing. The staff was smiling or laughing and exhibited ease with the tasks at hand.

We started with Steamed BBQ pork Bao. Now, this is one of (and maybe the) our favorite dishes at Yank Sing. This was better than theirs. The dough was perfect. The center not as sweet but richer. Great start. We followed that with Wild Boar Juicy Dumplings which is their take on Shanghai dumplings, our other favorite dish at Yank Sing. This time it was closer. Call it a tie. Delicious.

From Dim Sum we went to entrees. First was the Wild Board Scissor Cut Noodles (with  woodear mushrooms, scallions and Shaoxing wine). Awesome. The noodles were firm and thick and chewy. Terrific preparation. Finally we went traditional with Kung Pao Chicken (with Huang Fei chills, jalapeño and peanuts). The flavors were terrific, the chicken cooked just right and the Huang Fei chills, something I hadn't had before, were delicious. (The one piece of constructive criticism I would offer would be to cut the chicken into chunks half the size to make it easier to eat. It would also appear to offer more chicken on the plate.)

There is no way I thought this place could give Yank Sing a run for it's money and here they were beating it. Just a great surprise. We'll be back for sure.
author: Gary C.

description:
Ah, it's been over a year!  I was back with a friend and we both wanted Dim Sum.  I think it was the sampler. or "Collection" on the lunch menu.  

This is the best thing to get for two for afternoon "merienda" or a light lunch.  You can have a bit of everything, and it is worth every penny.
author: The W.

description: Greg my server was very attentive and courteous had a professional experience and dealt with all requests perfect. Food was awesome and fair price fasho will be coming back loved it.
author: Ben W.

description:
I was hanging around in the heart of town and came across this place and was amazed! Let me just say that it is a bit pricy, but it's never a crime to be good to yourself.
