The minute that I was given a table the server came over and treated me like we had been friends for years. They offer you a choice of regular or sparkling water. They bring it to you in a glass wine bottle and they are constantly topping off your glass. 

I ordered the Kung Pao Shrimp which is NOT even on the menu and I highly recommend the scallop rice (It has real chunks of scallop in it!!!!) Everything came out right away and tasted quite flavorful. PF Chang's has got nothing on M.Y. China, and I'll be back for another great experience.
author: Nicholas M.

description:
I've been here three different times already. The first time I went here, I had an array of desserts with a friend for dinner. They have very cute deserts and they were delicious! The second time I went here, was with a few girlfriends and we had their wonton, scissor noodles, and desserts to share. They always have understanding and great servers that recommend different types of dishes. The third time I went here, I knew what I wanted to order from the past two different times I visited. 
Their SCISSOR NOODLES are amazing!! 

I will come back soon. Definitely one of my go-to chinese restaurants. Love the ambiance and environment!
author: Tessa A.

description:
The Dish: If you're on lunch break, this place is quick (in & out within 30-40 minutes). I definitely recommend the Beef Hand-pulled Noodle Soup. It's very flavorful and the meat is perfect. It's tender and sort of just melts in your mouth. We also ordered the much-raved about Wild Boar Scissor-cut Noodles. I didn't think it was that special, but it's an average dish. 

Ambiance: Very classy and nice - especially for inside the mall. The waitress wasn't constantly at our table (so that's good) but wasn't MIA either - so it's pretty decent service and you can take your pick between sparkling water or still water. Good service, good food. Definitely worth it for those who work around the area - for a lunch break.
author: Gina T.

description: 2 stars cause the waitress was good. When this place first opened everything was delicious. Now it's tatstless and shitty.
author: Cheryl S.

description:
In Yelp, there are no zero stars, so I will give Martin Yan's food a single star. It deserves less. 

I love M.Y. China's interior -- it is completely inspired! I especially like the open view into the kitchen. Its such a fun setting to dine in.

The problem, on the other hand, is that when dinner is served you realize that MYC's dishes completely lack inspiration. After having experienced renown restaurants across China, I had great hopes for this restaurant and tried numerous times to have a great meal there. I'm convinced now that the food is bland, boring and not worth it.

I'm hoping that MY reads these critical yelp reviews and gives his menu some love. I'd really like to be able to enjoy his restaurant for more than the aesthetics.
author: Soren D.

description:
Food is delicious! My boyfriend and I made a last-minute reservation here on a Saturday night and we ordered Pork Belly Sliders, Wild Boar Lettuce Wraps, 5-Spice Pork Ribs and Chairman Mao's Chicken. So yummy!

The service was a bit slow.. we had to wait a long time for drinks to come and we weren't checked on too often but overall we would come back.
author: Kandace H.

description: One of the worst Chinese restaurants in town. Mediocre service, poor quality of food and overpriced menu. None of the dishes I ordered met my expectations. The wonton soup was barely edible - it's flavorless and the soggy wontons were basically all dough and no fillings. Other dishes didn't fare much better either. This place is overhyped and very disappointing.
author: Mary L.

description:
5 stars for the glazed lamb chops.i can just eat it all day everyday.lol.
Stars for the desserts too :) 
it gets a little bit pricey for a meal but it's definitely worth it.
service is very good.waiters were nice and checks on you time to time.will definitely go back for some chops
author: Enah N.

description:
My friends and I had a wonderful lunch experience this past Saturday right before we went to see The Great Gatsby in 3-D!  We were seated as soon as we walked in and got a table in the back, which gave us a great overall view of the restaurant.   The spacious interior and tastefully designed space also gives M.Y. China a really comfortable and relaxing ambiance.

The service we received was impeccable!  Trent + staff were polite, friendly and very attentive.  I just couldn't get enough of that chili sauce! ha

Everything we ordered was really delicious, but my faves were the Bang Bang Chicken Wings ($9), Stir Fried Chang Fen ($7) and the Salt & Pepper Calamari ($8).  All 3 items were very well seasoned and bursting with flavor!  Absolutely mouth-watering goodness!

I'll definitely be back to try everything else!!!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Well, we were excited to try this place and maybe because it was memorial day that the service was super slow and the place was packed. The host promptly seated us for lunch but we were forgotten for 15 minutes (even without water) as servers whizzed by us and served the two tables next to us. We were about to flag someone down but overheard the server profusely apologizing to the couple next to us for the slow service. We decided to leave knowing that it was a lost cause. 
We might have stayed if someone acknowledged us, made eye contact...something....?

Will try to make it back the next time we are at the mall to see movie but not hurrying back for an update to this review.
author: Maria C.

description:
I just got back from M.Y. China after a wondeful meal and a great day of shopping in downtown SF.  After spending close to 5 grand on gifts today, my babe and I decided to try this new Chinese Restaurant for dinner......when we arrived, we got a great table/booth in the mall area where we could people watch and check out the light show in the Nordsrtrom Centre Mall.  

The ambience is very up-scale and trendy..........a very modern look.

For dinner, we tried the Pork Belly Sliders, Potstickers, Truffle Juicy Dumplings, Noodle Soup with Beef, Shortribs, Hong Kong Crispy Noodles, Bbq Pork and Roast Chicken.  

All the dishes were outstanding.....the Noodle dishers were super fresh, the Shortribs Potstickers, Dumplings, Bbq Pork, Roast Chicken Pork Belly Sliders were all so yummy!

For 275.00......this was a very expensive Chinese dinner.....but I enjoyed the beautiful dining room and mall surroundings.....so I don't mind paying $$$$$ for the experience.  I will be back.  MY China rcoks!!
author: Raider J.

description: A rare spot of handmade noodle. I've been looking for authentic Chinese noodle all over so and this place was the only one that I found this far. It's a but pricy but so worth it. Try the hand cut noodle with boar.
author: Olivia C.

description:
I want to give it 3.5 stars. The restaurant is located in the Westfield mall. We came on a holiday for lunch and there was no wait for a table. The restaurant and decor are nice. It's not the best Chinese food I've had, but it's pretty good (not too greasy) and nicely presented. The dishes are pricey though. 

I wished there was more noodle in my crispy chicken noodles. And $16 for pea shoots is a first for me. The wild boar dumplings were good. Pork belly sliders were ok. The dan dan noodles were lighter and spicer than I'm used to. Shandong Beef Rolls were so so.

The service was ok. The waiter was quite busy and we kept needing refills for our tea because the pot was small so it ran out of water very quickly. I liked the milk oolong tea (note: there's no milk in it, but tastes milky)

If you're lucky, the chef may come out and dance gangnam style with his noodles. That was a real treat.
author: Ali F.

description:
Having just gone to Hakkasan a few days ago, I was curious to see how M.Y. China would stack up. Verdict: M.Y. China is really high quality standard Chinese fare, whereas Hakkasan is more gourmet fusion-ish Chinese food (aka Chinese food.. but with truffles!) I like the more no frills approach M.Y. China takes since I'm a purist/ traditionalist when it comes to Chinese food, plus M.Y. China's prices were much more reasonable so I'm more likely to return here. Actually I will definitely come back for the beef noodle soup!!

***Excellent***
Beef Noodle Soup -- my dad who is from Taiwan (beef noodle soup is to Taiwan what hamburgers are to America) gave this a 9 out of 10. when i asked what the missing 1 point was, he responded, "there is always room to improve" -__- (welcome to my childhood)
Boar dumplings -- the skin broke pretty easily, but luckily it was served in a spoon... crisis averted
Bok Choy -- surprisingly good, cooked with garlic, ginger, and anchovies. 
Sugar egg puffs -- SO good. generous portions. and better than Beard Papa in foster city.

**Good**
Dan Dan Noodles -- what came out wasn't what i expected at all, but not necessarily a bad thing. it tasted more like sweet & sour noodles, not the traditional dan dan noodles. still good.
Scissor cut wild boar noodles -- yummy. not as good as beef noodle soup though.
Beef Roll -- beef wrapped in scallion pancake -- very original!
Mapo tofu -- tofu was too soft and it tasted a bit more americanized than i would have liked, but good flavor

*Meh*
Kung pao chicken -- maybe just not a fan of this dish in general, but it wasn't the best
The service -- had to ask for white rice a few times, which is annoying. also the waitress should have recommended that we order white rice with the mapo tofu, which we forgot to order. usually at chinese restaurants, that's something the servers will ALWAYS ask you at the end of your order, since it's so standard.
author: Jessica W.

description: As with Martin Yan, the dining experience is a combo of food and entertainment.  The food is a blend of  Cantonese dishes cooked in Northern (spicy) style.  Many of the dishes were very good: Bang Bang Chicken wing, salt and pepper calamari, and noodle with wild boar meat.  The fried oyster, however, has too much batter and is not very fresh. The entertainment is centered on an open kitchen where the noodle chef puts on an acrobatic show/dance.  Great place for a large party or for small groups looking for a casual and fun evening.
author: Eric T.

description: Our family was looking for a Asian restaurant and chose M.Y. China on our first day in S.F.  Big mistake.  This was just an awful experience. We were seated quickly but it took 15 mins before a waiter came by to greet us.  I then said something to a staff person and her reply was "let me check as soon as my shift starts".  What a joke.  The food was average at best and expensive.  The waiter was a nice guy and offered to comp us for desert but then it took another 30 mins after they cleared our dinner plates to bring desert.  On top of that, another server brought us a second desert by mistake.  Also, when we initially placed our dinner order, our waiter said it would be faster if they brought  our food as soon as it was ready, however, we didn't expect them to just start dropping plates on our table in a haphazard manner.  Overall, this was one of the most disappointing meals I have ever had anywhere.
author: K A.

description: Came here last week with some family visiting. It was crowded but we had reservation so we got to table very quick. The food might be a bit expensive and less portion but they tasted good. I loved the Peking roast duck, def recommend that yummy dish to anyone. The staff was good to our table but messed up some order from the next table...over all it was a good experience.
author: Pete H.

description:
Where's the 3.5 when you need it ? We just had some of the starters so feel I can't really judge it properly. Here's what we had and opinions:

- Spring rolls: Well above average for me. Crunchy and yummy.

- Pork taco: Nice and light with some added crunch from crispy noodles.
 I think this was my fave.

- Wild boar lettuce cup: Very similar to the pork which isn't that surprising. Substitute "taco" with salad, and wild boar instead. Problem with the boar was that since you have a sweet (but nice) sauce, some of the gaminess of the boar got lost.

- Charirman Maos chicken: Nice and crisp deep fried pieces of chicken with peppers and onions. A touch of nice spicy sauce on the veggies. Chicken could perhaps had more taste, but moist and well prepped. The sauces served on the side was nice. Regular "red roll sauce" and a darker sweet and spicy sauce.

Didn't have Andy drinks, but the tea was nice (6 dollars though). No complaints on the service, and the place looks very nice. 

I just felt that the food could have been more ... spiced up ? Wow-ish ? Idunno... We saw some other stuff that looked nice though, and I'm sure well be back to try other things. I'm have a sneaky suspicion ill bump to 4 if I get to try some other dishes.

Oh, and very open kitchen so if you've never seen noodles being made, this is a good place to do that. :)
author: Niklas M.

description:
I love this place and go as often as I can. The food is delicious, the ambiance is elegant, yet relaxed and best of all, the staff is professional and charming. I have to walk through Chinatown to get to MY China and it's better (and much cleaner) than anything I walk past. 

I'm a creature of habit and usually order the Sichuan Green Bean as an appetizer and the Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp for my main course, but everything I have had is fantastic. If you have any room, order the Sugar Egg Puffs for dessert. 

I can't speak highly enough for the staff. They are friendly and professional. Cara is my go-to server and does a fantastic job. Props to Craig the manager too. He does an excellent job of running a large, busy restaurant, but always comes by to see how my meal is. 

When you're there, ask them to send the noodle guy around to pull noodles in front of you. It's a real treat and the out-of-towners love it.
author: Patrick R.

description:
A couple of the items were indeed good food.
However our service was SO BAD.  Our waitress was rude and inattentive.  The table next to us had to correct their order and ask for undelivered items several times.
We had to go to the bar to get water.
Put in a request for a client's birthday, not a word was said about it but was for other tables.
Seriously, this place is obviously cutting back on staff quality to pay mall based rent.  I see int he reviews that someone from the company is responding to these and bad service is mentioned more than once so I have to assume they know and are not rectifying any problems.
If you make this restaurant part of your destination plan you will be disappointed.  We were.
author: Scott F.

description:
The only star is for the fact that the bathrooms were clean. However the buck stops there. I'm the first to admit that being Asian, I should've known better going to a place like this. I know better than anyone else I can get some amazing Dim Sum and noodle dishes for $20 on Clement Street and have left overs. Let me preface this review before I continue that I had the WORST food poisoning of my life after eating here. I know that this was it because I hadn't had breakfast and after eating ONE item here i was unable to eat anything all day. I had never felt so ill than after eating here. My cousin who I was also with that day was miserably ill and had to get fluids from being so sick. 

Aside from the aftermath of it all, we walked in and it seemed interesting and seeing Chinese people in the kitchen was comforting. However when we pulled up a chair at the bar it took us forever to get service. Upon looking at the offensive menu we ordered the least Chinese thing on the menu, the mu shoo pork tacos. When they came to us not only were they completely oversalted, sauced and hard to eat, we found a hair in it. I also am highly suspicious that they use MSG. Regardless it was completely over salted but as someone who's allergic to MSG i experienced reactions to it.

After we ordered we were scanning the menu only to find reasonably offensive images. "We Wok hard for your food"? Really? The "We Got Cha" was clever and the "Our buns are steaming hot" are lame and mildly inappropriate but really? And of all people who oversee these operations, Martin Yan thought that this was ok because he's Asian? I'm embarassed for Mr. Yan that he thinks it's funny or cute to perpetuate that stereotype. It's offensive and it's rude. I am never going back and highly reccomend no one goes either, if not for it being disgracefully presented food, for the fact that you will undoubtedly get sick.
author: Kristen R.

description:
Enjoyed lunch here today very much!

King pao chicken, wild boar noodles (hold the wild boar, sub mushrooms ), side of string beans and the spicy sea food dim sum


Was all excellent!

Nice services

Complimentary sparkling water.....

1-18-15
Bang bang chicken - excellent
Onion pancake - good, but itty bitty portion, super thin, not worth it
Spicy wok beef on arugula -very good. Small portion, mostly arugula
Spicy seafood dumplings - our favorite.  Made with spinach dough
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I had a pleasant experience after a much-anticipated visit last week. The staff were friendly, bumping a three-star food experience to a four-star overall restaurant experience. 

We were seated promptly. They were out of Tsingtao Beer and recommended Laughing Buddha instead, which my boyfriend enjoyed, but was lucky to get because apparently it was the last one they had. Good thing he was ok with one beer for the evening!

We ordered the pork belly sliders, wok seared beef filet, and Hong Kong crispy noodle with chicken. The sliders were great, every ingredient fresh and tasty. The beef filet was also quite good. The chicken was a serious disappointment and next time I will not order crispy noodles. 

We were pretty full but the waitress' recommendation of the house-made doughnuts sounded too good to pass up and it was. They were pretty fantastic.
author: Shushannah A.

description:
4.5 stars rounded up 

Let's get two obvious statements out of the way before I describe M.Y.'s eats:
1) I like white people Chinese food, which is what this cuisine *should* officially be called (but that's just my opinion)
2) gorgeous restaurant+prime real estate+celeb chef=prices that would make yo' Asian mama smack the shit outta you for paying (my mother rolled her eyes & gave me a disapproving look 'cuz she isn't about the violence)

Onto the food: 
-- fresh spring rolls ($7): shrimp, avocado, noodles, lettuce tightly wrapped in rice paper. Delicious peanut dipping sauce. Two to an order. Very refreshing! 
-- whole grain potstickers ($7): 5 to an order. Loved the flavorful skin. Pork filling was a little too finely chopped. 
-- har gow ($7): 3 to an order. Yummy! Succulent shrimp. Again, soy dipping sauce was magical. 
-- Hong Kong crispy noodle w/ chicken ($16): large portion, not drenched in gravy, generous w/ the baby bok choy. 
-- honey glazed pork ($9): did not try. Bf said it was too porky. Didn't have the BBQ pork flavor he was expecting. He would not order again. (Boooooo!) 
-- chairman mao's chicken ($9): loved the seasoning & crispy batter. But probably wouldn't order again b/c it is dark meat chicken pieces. 
-- sugar egg puffs ($8): 5 to an order. Sugary, fried, crisp. Three 'fillings' on the side: raspberry sauce, chantilly cream, a thick chocolate mousse (my fave.) 

Host Sebastian was sweet & polite as could be (thank you, Sir!) Our waiter presented dishes with enthusiasm & flair-loved him! 

Try to grab a seat near the kitchen. It's like dinner theater watching noodles be hand pulled & hand cut! 

Unisex bathrooms (3 stalls)--very modern! 

I'll be back to try different menu items.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Siu Mai was good... that's it.

Everything else was very disappointing.

Hot & Sour soup was instead sweet and sour soup.
Hand pulled noodles needed more alkali, too doughy, no bite.
Chicken wing marinade was too strong, taste did not agree with me.
Peking duck was super fatty, and the wrapper was a thin, dry sheet that was like eating paper.
White race was of a cheap variety?! 
Kung Pao chicken was on the salty side.

To make matters worse, everything came all at once. 

And that drink called Big Trouble in M.Y. China has no business being on the menu. It's 1 oz of 112 proof Chinese liquor with a Tsing Tao beer. I can't see that liqour pairing well with anything. 

I want my Friday night back.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Martin Yan did you ever tried your own restaurant because this restaurant was a huge disappointment. The food was alright, but I got FOOD POISONING. Couple of hours after eating here, I was non stop vomiting all that I had ate for dinner. Food wise, strange everything came out lukewarm or cold. Breakdown of what we had:
1) Five Spice Rib: The fried topping was good, but the rib itself had no flavor. Came out cold.
2) Beef Noodle: Came out cold. The noodle, which are supposed to be a specialty, were a varying degree of thickness. The chef didn't do a good job of pulling the noodles. Flavor was ok, but on the sweet side.
3) Forbidden Rice: It came out cold, but I actually liked the flavor of this dish.
4) Potsticker: A disappointment. The filling had no flavor. While the skin was nice & thin, the top dough portion of the dumpling was raw.
5) Hong Kong Noodle: The best dish of the night.. The noodle was crispy enough, and the toppings had enough flavor.
6) Pork Truffle Juicy Dumpling: This was the worst designed dish ever. Why would anybody think that steaming Pork Dumpling like this is a good idea. When the dish came out the skin was already broken, therefore we had to pick up the spoon to eat the dumpling. Bad idea. This was the one dish that came out hot and my friend burned his fingers. Thus started our hilarious attempt to eat the dish. The spoon was too hot to take out with your bare hands, but too large & unwieldy to take out easily with the cloth napkins. The filling was tasty, but the skin was nasty, stuck to the bottom of the spoon. Worst part: The last one I ate, the filling was RAW. Plus it was served with the wrong type of vinegar. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m-y-china-san-francisco-2?select=ychnX-Po2g9pE5y3Tc9pdA#ychnX-Po2g9pE5y3Tc9pdA
7) Sugar Puff: It was good, but WHY IS IT COLD!
8) Lemon Egg Tart: Nothing special.
Service: Person was nice, but a bumbling mess. We ordered coke and water, only the coke came out. We asked about the crab, the person said they will check if there is any, but we never heard again about the crab. We requested the dessert menu, the table next to us got it, while we had to request it again...e.g.
Summary: Don't waste your time here.
author: Erica B.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for the first time last week. It's best to have reservation to guarantee good seats. We got lucky when we walked-in without a reservation cos one of our options was to sit by the bar facing the kitchen :) which was what I really hoped for cos it gave us a chance to see how they make the food. Really fun! 

I ordered the braised beef which was DELICIOUS. and then the Wild fried rice and the wild boar dumplings... Yum!yum!

My bf got the fried chicken, pineapple fried rice, and pork dumplings, which were all SO GOOD :Q______

And the service, oh so great!!

I highly recommend this place.
author: Jensine G.

description:
This was my second time at M.Y. China, once for the soft opening and second time with my friends.  I had to write a review because our waiter was very friendly, half of our party was 40 minutes late, due to construction on market st.  They still seated us early and were very patient with our party.
Food is deeelish, authentic dishes w/ freshly pulled noodles.

They put on a show where the chef comes around your table and swings around the noodle, pretty entertaining.

Thanks M.Y.!
author: Jason Y.

description: Drinks were good. Service was excellent. Food lacked flavor even though used high quality meat. I was expecting more based on other reviews of this resturant.
author: Rhonda S.

description: Probably the best non hole in the wall Chinese food. And it's clean ASF.  No gas coming from this guy at night. Try the FROLIC drink, tastes good....
author: Nasty T.

description: It's so far away from Chinese food I don't even know what it is. The kung Pao chicken is anything but a Chinese would call kung Pao chicken. I just feel so sad for people who think this is authentic Chinese. I mean, if you don't see many Chinese in a Chinese restaurant, its definitely not the best.
author: Hongyang L.

description: Came here for dinner with my girlfriend, and enjoyed everything about this place!!! Great ambiance, delicious food (try the new vegetarian mushroom dish with sesame), and great service. Thanks Sarina, you rock!!!
author: Justin F.

description:
The best Chinese restaurant I've ever experienced in North America. I am from Canada and I went to high quality Chinese restaurant in Vancouver too.
This is the best one I found. They keep a good balance between Western style and Asian style. Very nice atmospher and not a bad service. Their dimsum and noodles are Fanstastic. Cant wait the next visit!!
author: Chelsea K.

description:
What do you think of when you think Martin Yan?  Definitely not delectable food but more of a showman since he's done the most cooking shows (episode wise) I think.  So what would Martin Yan and the team at Koi Palace come up with.  For the longest time, my fiancee and I were thinking over priced Chinese food that caters only to the non Chinese crowd since it is in the mall but we were wrong.

MY China upon walking in had the beautiful aroma of an authentic Chinese restaurant as if you were in Hong Kong.  Maybe it came from the open kitchen but there was a distinctive smell that gave me that feeling.  The restaurant has an old school Chinese feel with modern touches (open kitchen/music).

Onto the food and drinks.  One of my buddies told me the cocktails were good and my fiancee got one and was it delicious.  We ordered beef noodle soup, wild boar noodles, sichaun string beans, baby bak choy, sweet and sour pork, bbq pork, pork belly sliders, and for dessert yam croquette and my china rice bowl.  My only complaint was the bbq pork had too much honey making it too sweet and there wasn't a need for the sesame.  Everything else was very good and authentic I would say and how do I know that?  I've been in the Chinese restaurant biz for over 25 years so I may know a little bit.  Anyway  I would highly recommend everything that we ordered.

Why am I giving it four stars and not five stars?  Well for starters the cocktail was very small and for $12, I felt it could have been a little bit more.  Second thing is the bbq pork had too much honey.  Both of these are minor details.  The food at the end of the day is pricier than other Chinese restaurants and the portions don't necessarily reflect that (not to mention a limited menu).  However you have to know you're paying for the ambiance, good service (which we got) and a little bit of entertainment in terms of the chef pulling noodles in the open kitchen.  It's nice to have another restaurant in a mall that I can come back to over and over again.
author: Pierre L.

description:
Usually I stay away from Dim Sum and Chinese restaurants... I was never a fan. I'll eat it, I'll say I like something, but still won't be a fan because It's never my first choice, second or umpteenth choice. 

But after a long morning of shopping, I was hungry and M.Y China was right in front of us. My shopping bud thought it was too pricy for Dim Sum, very true but it was "up scale" and "modern" and we were too lazy to look somewhere else.  And this was Martin Yan's restaurant... i grew up watching him on TV and wishing i could chop like him.

Spicy Seafood Dumpling (Scallop, Shrimp, Spinach wrap) 6piece for $9- My Fave, wish there was more. and more scallops. one of my dumpling had no scallops at all.

Wild Boar Juicy Dumplings (Ginger, Garlic, M.Y. season salt) 4 piece $8- The dumplings sits on top of a slice of carrot on a spoon with a bit of soup. pour little vinegar sauce on it and pop it in your mouth... watch out it's steaming hot. it was good. 

Venison Chow Fun (onion, green onion, bean sprout, gluten free flat rice noodle) $17- Tender juciy, not too gamey. The noodle was a bit on the bland side so we asked for some hot sauce. 

I have to say I was A-ok with everything. the servers were nice, thought the food took awhile to come.
author: Lynn T.

description:
I read a lot of review and saw it on Checked Please! show so I thought I should at least check it out. Most dishes are ok, not really authentic but not too too Americanized.

One dish that is sub-par to other things I tried was the Mapao Tofu. It came in a sea of brown sauce. Definitely not close to being authentic at all. We sat in front of the kitchen and saw this cook pouring two plastic jugs of soy sauce into a wok and stirred for almost 30 min. He then poured the gallons of brown sauce into a plastic tub on the counter. Voila - we now know the source of the "brown sauce" for Mapao tofu...

The Wildboat scissor cut noodle was interesting and I would try again. The green beans were fried instead of wok stirred but was ok. Yang Cho fried rice was non-descript so I would avoid it.

Service was good. But I would not go again... $6 for tea is the most expensive I have ever seen in any restaurant, here or overseas, in any type of restaurant
author: F.H. H.

description: Food is great but the service sucks,, our food got delivered to the wrong table and no apologies from the server. First and foremost he didnt even introduced himself or even asked if it was our first time! Not looking forward to come back or recommend to family and friends!
author: Ar L.

description:
I had really high hopes for this place. I heard about the freshly pulled noodles and about the authentic flavors without the grease. 

We were lucky enough to see a show.... three of the chefs (?) came out into the dining room and put on a show. They pulled the noodles and pulled and pulled. They choreographed their movements and it was fascinating to watch.

We ordered the crispy noodles with chicken, and the broccoli with sausage. Both were really good. The dishes were not very greasy. We felt good after a chinese-food meal.

The food was good. It wasn't fantastic, and by no means will I be clamoring to come back anytime soon.... let's face it... Chinatown is a few blocks away.

BUT.... for a date... I would recommend this place.
author: Mar A.

description: This is one of our favourite Chinese restaurants in SF! Love the food and the service. They always make changes to accommodate what you like, which is great. The forbidden rice, ma po tofu, greens, sweet and sour chicken, dumplings ... We love it all!!!
author: Prerana D.

description:
The restaurant and the service are the only thing that is good about this restaurant. The food was tasteless. My friends and I ordered many course from the menu, The dumplings were okay but the rest was not tasty at all. 

I am not coming back to this restaurant.
author: Natasha C.

description: Everything was delicious. I recommend you come with a large group so that you can taste everything   The gluten free chow fun had great texture and flavor. The mu shu tacos were a great starter for two people.  We will be back when we are downtown.
author: Jerry W.

description:
I guess I wasn't feeling it previously, or squinting at the tiny print menu gave me a headache. Because we keep coming back here a lot. 

The food is consistently good, with fresh quality ingredients well-sourced. The service is very good, and the cocktails are pretty darn fabulous. And if you're lucky, you'll get to see one of the chefs come around spinning a big hank of noodles and showing off. 

If you want cocktails and food, someplace near BART, an after-work date or place to meet friends, this one's worth having. Especially as they do have room to seat groups. The food is varied enough to feed most dietary needs and types, from Midwestern stranger to Asian food (what were those guys doing at the next table?) to jaded San Franciscans, who have had better but will eat it anyway.
author: Anne K.

description:
Pricey chinese food but actually taste good. I guess this is as expected since they are partnered up with Koi Palace (at least that's the idea I got from their website). Service is great and efficient usually - except one time the waiter spilled sauce on my jacket and didn't really offered to comp for dry cleaning.

Food is good though, I would recommend:
Spicy Seafood dumplings (the sauce is awesome)
Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles (not sure if it's really boar meat, but whatever that meat was, it's good)
Forbidden Rice -- This is a great rice dish, but at $8 per order, it's borderline ripoff price

Overall food quality is good. Ambience of the place is really nice, but noisy if you are trying to hold a conversation.
author: Karen W.

description:
Wow I was so disappointed in my meal here last night. First and foremost, my lungs were burning from the smoke in the restaurant. I noticed that everyone in my party was coughing throughout our meal, though we could not see smoke.

Regarding the timing of the food service. Another big problem. Two of us ordered soup, but our soups were served 5 minutes apart. Come on, how difficult is it to fire two soups to come out at the same time? Same thing happened with our entrees. Two of us received our food (honey walnut shrimp) at one time, and then two who ordered the sea bass, didn't get served until 5 minutes later. 

For the final nail in the coffin, I have had stomach issues all morning. Will not return.
author: Kathy O.

description: Nice atmosphere and friendly service. The food was good but not exceptional. As a Chinese, I would still prefer more authenticity than fancy ;)
author: Fiona J.

description:
Decided to come eat here on a whim last night and was pleasantly surprised.

Wasn't sure what to expect food wise, whether it would be similar to Morimoto's (famous name/expensive/mediocre food).

Had the dim sum chefs choice, whole wheat potstickers, wild boar scissor cut noodles, sweet and sour pork and crispy organic tofu.

Everything came out as soon as it was prepared, hot and tasty.

Highlights were the wild boar scissor cut noodles and crispy tofu.

Also, we sat in front of the wok station, so we were able to watch them cook all our food over that intense heat from the wok inferno.
author: Peter L.

description:
I've been here four times now, and I've enjoyed it each time.
I was not expecting to like it, especially considering the venue, but the service and the food have been great each time. 

We always start wit hthe spicy seafood dumplings. I love these; the wrapper is chewy and delicious, and the dumplings are stuffed with seafood. The sauce could be spicier, but it is really flavorful. 
The beef hand pulled noodle soup is also a winner. The noodles are chewy and delicious, and the broth is rich and delicious. The beef is tender and the bok choy is cooked perfectly. 
We've also ordered the shrimp, which are crispy, sweet and spicy. This is my favorite non-noodle soup dish we've gotten.

The roasted chicken is nothing special. It was a little dry and bland.

The Hong Kong Crispy Noodles are pretty good, but nowhere near as tasty as the noodle soup. 

The egg puffs are also great. Crispy and sugary on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside. The sauces provided keep the dish from being too sweet; the vanilla cream anglaise is light and not too sweet, the raspberry sauce is tangy, and the chocolate sauce is rich and dark. 

Overall, I really like this place. If you order the right things, you won't be disappointed.
author: Cami J.

description:
I had higher hopes for this place.

We visited on CNY and were lucky to get our table for 11 without a reservation, the door hostess was friendly and accommodating. Our server was also patient and understanding.

Unfortunately it went down hill from there.

Could be the good chef's took the night off to celebrate CNY as well but the quality of food was not good at all. I can't think of many worse places in actuality.

The HK Crispy noodle was ok, the bang bang chicken lived up to its sweet and spicy billing and the honey walnut shrimp was edible but so many other dishes were not up to par.

The won ton soup was amazingly bland. I think they forgot to put any seasoning in it and it looked a lot like egg drop soup with some wontons inside.

The salt and pepper calamari was rubbery and terrible.

The garlic pea shoots were reasonable but for the price, you hardly got any, almost 1-2 shoots per person which was a bit on the stingy side...$16 for veggies?!

Pineapple seafood fried rice, not sure what happened to the rice but it just tasted off to many of us.

And last but not least, the worst was the peking roast duck. That was spectacularly terrible. Having had this delight many other places, I was hoping to enjoy this but not a chance.

The fat needs to be trimmed down almost completely to leave you with the crispy duck skin. This did not happen here, and who wants a pancake with fat and grease and chewy skin? That really was bad.

To add insult to injury, this place is not cheap and poor value in my opinion.
I'd avoid, I doubt we could have ordered so many poor dishes by chance.
author: Nick L.

description:
Went here on a whim hoping for the best.  Sorry to diss MY, but I kinda had a gut feeling he's not catering towards the Asian audience and more of a fusion style entrees. 

First course
Tea Pork Belly Sliders - not bad. Pork was nice and tender. However I didn't get the pickled items that go along with it. It over powered the pork flavor.

2nd Course
Wild Board Juicy Dumplings -  4 pieces per order for $8.  Highway robbery.  Meat was good, juicy and had enough liquids in the dumplings. Skin is a bit thick, but I'd come back out of desperation for a semi decent dumpling. I still think Din Tai Fung makes the best dumplings. 

3rd Course
Bang Bang Chicken Wings - so utterly disappointed.  It was just spicy/salty and nothing else. 

4th Course 
Dan Dan Noodles - Yuck - drowned in chilli oil.  Could not taste the noodles, pork, garlic as stated in the description.

Dessert
Macau Egg Tarts - doesn't taste anything like the original Macau egg tarts I've ever tried.  Since the last 2 course were so sad, this finally brought me back.  I've had wayyyy better at a lesser cost. 

As for the waitress, she never came back to check on us.  Since this isn't your usual Chinese restaurant, I expect better service.  She never came back to check on us during our meals. Maybe she knew we wouldn't like our meals and decided it's best not to ask? Only took our order and gave us the bill.
author: Susan T.

description:
Looking at the pictures before I went, M.Y. China didn't look too special. Typical Cantonese/Chinese food... or so I thought.

In actuality every dish had some sort of twist and was of higher quality than you'd expect at a typical Cantonese joint. I was happily surprised!

Here's what we ordered:
Forbidden Rice - For such a healthy dish, it was fairly tasty. Probably wouldn't get this again though (not sure why so many other reviewers were infatuated with it).

5 Spice Pork Ribs - Uhhhhhhmazing but a bit heavy. The meat just falls off the bone. The veggie shards it came with were well done too.

Hand Pulled Beef Noodle Soup - Beef and noodles were perfect. Soup was a bit too soy saucy for me though.

Wild Boar Soup Dumplings - Really good and juicy.

Pork & Black Truffle Soup Dumplings - My favorite dish of the night. So juicy and you can definitely taste the truffle.

Lotus Root Croquette - We were hesitant at ordering dessert at first, but we were glad we did. The texture of the croquette and the pairing of the almond ice cream were perfect.

In the end, we spent almost $30 a person and were stuffed. We probably could have ordered one less, but it was definitely worth it. I plan to go back to try more!
author: Jono L.

description:
Why are supermodels forever annoyed? Because they're hungry. And after my experience at M.Y. China, I've officially turned into Naomi-freaking-Campbell--cranky, annoyed, hungry, and unhappy.

After a really long day at work and in need of a cocktail (or three) I was looking forward to trying something new. But as I write this review while still sitting at the table, I'm disappointed; and here's why:

- We never got that refill on our adult beverages
- Our tables were so close to one another that I literally knew how everyone else's day went
- And because our main dish never arrived and when we asked our server to check on it she responded the order was placed but the kitchen was now closed. Seriously? 

We were, however, able to try the Pork Belly Sliders, Har Gow, Beef Fillet, and Garlic Pea Shoots which were mediocre at best. Sounds like a lot of food, but these were Mary-Kate and Ashley portions. I really wanted to like this spot and was looking forward to a delicious meal, but sadly it wasn't meant to be. 

I know they've only been open for about a week but after the misses this evening I doubt I'll be back for seconds. So like a true supermodel, I'm going to bed hungry.
author: Chris S.

description: We came here ffor dinner after the Chinese Newyear parade last Saturday as we were meeting my cousin nearby; though I was looking forward to staying in Chinatown, I was just as anxious to come back for dinner.  We were seated promptly, the hostas telling us "You missed the rush" at probably 8-30 or 9-00.  Our waitress was wonderful & cute; very friendly & knowledgable about the menu & was very fun & talked a little here & there.  She did not check up on us excessively or forget about us.  One of big highlights was meeting Martin Yan, a life long favorite of mine since I was in middle school 25 years ago.  He was going around to every table talking to everyone & he, himself was having dinner with friends.  He3 is the bowl full of energy you see on tv & wonderful to be around; we got a few pics thanks to my mother & one of his employees.  So, onto the food.  The Shanghai juicy buns were wonderful with a thin wrapper & well seasoned ground pork filling; perfect with black vinigre.  The Chareman Mao's chicken is crispy with a lite badder & moist interior with a sweet & spicy sauce served on the side for you to customize how much sauce & how spicy you want it; it is a very good sweet & spicy sauce with the perfect balance of the formentioned tastes.  The wok siered beef is tender wityh onions, peppers, & arugula with a spicy tangy Szechwan peppercorn sauce.  The wild bore hand cut noodles we could not resist ordering again as the noodles are hand made & chewy but not overly so with tender bore & fresh bean sprouts in a lite sauce.  For dessert, the lychee panicota is different with a smooth custard with bits of lychee & other fruit with fresh mint.  Round it off with a Tsing Tao & you will not be disappointed.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description:
Amazing food, service, and staff. The double-walled tea cups are really cool, as are the little individual dim sum platter thingies.
We had the Dim Sum sampler, honey walnut shrimp, soup dumplings, pork tacos, and pork belly sliders. Everything was great, I'd put the shrimp at the top but I should have gotten rice with it. Pork belly sliders were good but not my fav. I also had a peach Old Fashioned at the bar that made for a really great lunch cocktail!
The interior is pretty stunning; its a multi-area arrangement that totally makes you forget that you're in a mall. I hear the Buddhas on the back wall are really from China, and it was pointed out to me that one of the ones on the bottom row resembles the noodle-pullers that you get to watch in the kitchen bullpen. Noodle-pullers which are, incidentally, amazingly talented and entertaining!
author: Alex D.

description:
The Martin Yan restaurant right in town! Walking into the restaurant I went: 'Wow!' 

Just the décor and set up of the restaurant is a treat to begin the evening. I love the open concept of the kitchen stretching the entire back wall of the premises. The center section is where all the wok cooking action going on with a glass screens dividing the dining area. I stood there for a while just to watch the chef toss the food skillfully in the wok and creating 3 feet high of hot flames! Expanding to the both ends was the long open counter where the major food preparation, plating and quality check were going on. Very impressive! The food better be good, I thought. :D

Between my husband and I we ordered 3 appetizers to begin the meal. The Shanghai Xiao Long Bao (steam dumplings) was a good start to the evening. It was a great idea that the dumpling was served in individual spoon. As I picked up the dumpling from the top with the chopsticks, the pork fillings and the broth in the dumpling fell off from the bottom of the wrapper onto the spoon! 
It works perfectly well for me as a low carber to enjoy the dumpling content from the spoon and discard the starch wrappers. The meat filling and the broth were both very tender and flavorful. Wonderful! I could eat a whole basket all by myself!

The next item was wonton soup. Personally I was not much into this wonton soup. For my low carb eating lifestyle, I prefer an aromatic clear broth rather than a starchy broth that comes with it, also if the wonton could be wrapped with a thinner wrapper. So we shifted our focus to enjoy the super tasty deep fried tofu. It was soft in the center, lightly crisp on the outside sprinkled with a spicy salty spice, topped with bits of red pepper and spring onion. It was delicious!

With this good treats, we continue to order our main entrees. The wok stirfry lamb with ginger and spring onion was very flavorful! And the steamed Sea Bass slices with Chinese wine, ginger and mushroom reminds me of the steamed fish my parents used to cook for me during the Singapore days.

It was such a wonderful dinner experience that on the last evening of my food tasting tour, I have to come back to this restaurant again to try the lobster. Needless to say it was good and the photo of the lobster I took impresses all my fans on Facebook.

This restaurant is certainly in my keeping list!
author: Kelly P.

description:
MYC is still new and working out the kinks of the menu and operation. Food-wise, while a couple of the dishes we ordered were remarkable, the other items were just OK and need improvement in my opinion. I heard Martin Yan was not there for the opening due to filming in Asia, and I would wait to return until after he has had a chance to straighten and smooth things out.

My favorites: shui mai dumplings, the scissor-cut noodles, squid ink noodles (the seafood was cooked perfectly), and I could do shots of the tasty, garlicky dipping sauce that comes with the dim sum.

One of my main issues I had was that the dough-to-filling ratio of the beef and pork buns (bao) was too high. Thick dough and a joke of an amount of filling, and the filling was not intensely flavored enough so all I really tasted was dough. The dan dan noodles similarly contained only a tiny amount of pork; otherwise this chilled dish is refreshing and light (but the noodles are not hand-pulled). Lastly, the tea-smoked pork belly sliders were OK but thought the pickled daikon overpowered the delicate pork flavor. The smoking needs to be longer to infuse more flavor into it. (And again, the dough was quite thick and stuck to my teeth)

The service was friendly and attentive and the decor is very nice and upscale. Grab a seat at the counter to watch the culinary action live. As I mentioned before, I'd try it again in a couple months to see if anything has improved, but if it stays the same, some of the dishes are bland and not worth ordering.

Food right now is 2.5 to 3, and will hopefully improve.
author: Patrick H.

description:
I did not have high expectations for this place. I do usually prefer smaller independent neighborhood gems rather than big sprawling celebrity chef owned restaurants in a huge mall with lots of tourists. Andj this place is definitely that. My partner jokingly compared it to PF Chang.. but that was before we ordered anything. 

First, this place is quite impressive in looks and design and decor, it's big, and I think perfectly situated on the 4th level of Westfield, right there by the dome. Service was very good and attentive. We ordered only dim sum and small plates because we wanted a light lunch. And of course what lunch is complete without cocktails? I had East Meets West yum. Partner had Monkey King.. beware it's strong! Started off with the Bang Bang chicken wings.. absolutely crunchy deliciousness. Then the wild boar juicy dumplings.. pretty good. Nice presentation 4 dumplings on soup spoons.. not sure it's practical but looks nice. The Baked BBQ chicken bao was probably our favorite, very very good. Salt and Pepper calamari was perfectly cooked so tender and scrumptous.We also ordered Poached Asian Pear salad.. it was good but could have done without. The dishes are supposed to be shared which is fun. I didn't think it was that expensive but then again we went for lunch.

I really did not find anything wrong with this place. I think it's best experienced without preconceived notions.. is it Chinese, is it American Chinese, etc.. just enjoy the food and atmosphere! We thoroughly enjoyed our time.
author: Vol T.

description:
The poor man's Hakkasan perhaps?  

Spicy Seafood Dumplings:   The BEST I've ever had

Five Spice Pork Ribs:   Really good but very rich

Forbidden Rice:  BEST fried rice I've ever had

Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup:  Least favorite dish but the noodles were amazing.  I'd probably try the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles or the Dan Dan Noodles on my next visit
author: Fred X.

description:
Sure, I realize this place is in the Westfield Mall and can be a bit pricy. Still, that hasn't stopped me from enjoying two separate visits, induced or not by Martin Yan himself!

Their wild boar scissor cut noodles are among their better dishes, as are their tea smoked pork belly sliders. Seafood dumplings were just okay.

Upon each visit, I was particularly amused by how much effort our waiter put into demonstrating how to go about pouring the drink I ordered: Big Trouble in M.Y. China! It's basically a shot glass and Tsingtao beer, and from the sounds of each waiter, I doubt many other patrons tend to venture so far. I participate for equal amusement!

M.Y. China includes a unisex restroom, should you need to go... Thought I'd throw that tidbit of info in there, in case you're uncomfortable with that.
author: Garett T.

description:
It is going downhill...
I've been going to M.Y. China since it opened and always liked everything about it. Food, service and decor were all excellent, and I go there often as it is close to home. 
The past 3 times have been increasingly disappointing. The latest was the worst! Our server was clearly annoyed to be working there, and showed minimum interest in making us happy. We ordered two main dishes, an appetizer and brown rice. The main dishes arrived first, followed 10 minutes later by the appetizer and finally the rice. The brown rice was undercooked and dry. We sent it back and ordered white rice. Our server couldn't have cared less. The white rice came and, yes, hard by clumps. We were surprised, but not wanting to complain too much, kept it. The seared beef! ... In the past, it has been tender, juicy and tasty. This time around, it was more like beef jerky! dry and salty, and we had to use knives to cut it and eat it! In all, our waitress managed one 'sorry about that', but looked more like 'what do you expect, you are only paying ~$20-$25 per dish at this joint'... when we were leaving, a friendly bus-boy tried to apologize... he said about our server '... she's a tough lady...'  ??? 
The only positive are the noodles, which are always excellent. Too bad about the jerky and the other jerky. 
What's happening? this is SF!... unless they decided to give up on the foodie locals and concentrate on the tourist horde.
author: Hector M.

description: This is just a overpriced Panda Express.  In fact Panda Express has better food, and better service.
author: Allison G.

description: great service and ambiance.  I come here for the pork belly sliders and the beef chow fun but I ask to make it with gravy.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
We got to sit at the table in front of the clear divider so we can watch them cook our meal. The head chef in red was showing an employee how to make the noodles, and it's exactly as other reviewers have stated: twisting and twirling the noodle dough in the air several times and sometimes it look like they were beating the air with it. I wonder how their arms don't get tired from the repeated twirling! Unfortunately, we had already ordered our food so we didn't get to try the noodles, but there's always next time!

Since we wanted a light dinner, the dishes we ordered were:
Chairman Mao's chicken (not spicy at all but still good)
Pork dumplings with black truffle (nice twist though I can't really taste the black truffle, though it's the first time I've had black truffle; decent amount of soup in it!)
Steamed jasmine rice
Chrysanthemum tea
...and dessert was M.Y. sundae rice bowl (love the crunchiness and the different ice cream combos with the caramel!)

Overall, I liked how the food was light yet still filling. There's no heavy feeling you get with eating Chinese food sometimes, probably since their food isn't oily at all.

The waiters were very accommodating and take away dishes promptly once you are finished. We would come back here again to try the homemade noodles and other desserts!
author: Trish L.

description:
A hearty over priced lunch on Friday the 22nd of February for the WEALTH special on the Chinese New Year of the Snake menu. 

The menu consisted of four courses, plus dessert course.

Course 1: Juicy dumpling trio.  Soup dumplings of pork and truffle, wild boar and shrimp and pork.  Served with a side of vinegar and ginger.  The shrimp and pork xiao long bao were the best.  The truffle ones had little to no truffle flavor.  The wild boar were just ok as well.  Overall, one type of soup dumpling with a variety of other dim sum would have been better.  

Course 2: 1/2 a peking duck divided among two dishes.  First to arrive was the Peking duck, skin, cucumber and scallion on a bao bun (The Korean mini sandwich style).  This was 4 decent flavorful filling white bread sandwiches.  The next dish 2nd of 2 duck to arrive that came along with Courses 3 & 4.  This was the so called remainder of the 1/2 of duck.  It was the stir fried meat in lettuce cups.  Once dowsed in hoisin sauce it was much better.  

Course 3: Seafood Treasury with shrimp, scallop, calamari, carrots, snow peas and mushrooms in a fried taro nest.  This was a fresh and clean tasting dish and not too heavy.  The shrimp were big and the scallops were big.  The calamari was a little rubbery.  

Course 4: Stir-fried Longevity Noodlewith Shredded BBQ Pork.  The best dish by far.  With mushrooms, peppers, onions and the delicious bbq pork.  

Dessert: Sugar Puff (Custard filled donut thing with sugar sprinkled on it) with vanilla cream sauce, raspberry sauce and chocolate sauce.  

Over all, for the money, it was a great feast.  But the noodles were the most memorable dish.  Watching the noodles being hand pulled while seated at the counter was really cool.  The dumpling ladies making dumplings were having a great time and each looked folded to perfection.  

If you're in the Westfiled mall, this is a dining option.  You can get cheaper food here or in the mall, but it is worth a try.
author: Caesar R.

description: Today was our first visit to M.Y. China, we had a delightful lunch.  The food was Amazing.  We ordered the following: Wonton Soup, Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, Wok Seared Beef, Chairman Mao's Chicken and for desert we ordered Sugar Egg Puffs.  We also ordered these tantalizing cocktails: Blushing Dragon and Buddha Breeze.  We have now found a beautiful place to enjoy Chinese cuisine.  Thank you M.Y. China for making our dining experience perfection.
author: Anita W.

description: We went to dine here on a Thursday evening. All four of us being from UC Davis, we were pretty excited to check out what Martin, a celebrated UCD alum, had to offer. And he did not disappoint. The menu was an elegant mix of dishes from all over China, ranging from savory dumplings to a variety of wok items. Of the ones we had, the Spicy Seafood Dumplings, Kung Pao Chicken, Peking Roast Duck, and the Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp deserve a special mention. And to top it off, the service offered by our waitress, Victoria, was impeccable. She went out of her way to ensure that we were completely satisfied with our visit. Definitely going back!
author: Partha B.

description:
Went here at the height of lunch hour on a Saturday. The wait for a party of two wasn't bad, about 15 minutes. We went for an all vegetarian menu and had two noodle dishes and two apps.

The portobello sliders come in twos. They are well-prepared and are in the same dough as pork buns. It was a bit bland and could have used a bit of chili sauce

Crispy organic tofu was pretty standard and served with a sweet chili sauce. 

Beijing knife cut noodles: the house made noodles were great. It's in a sweet hoisin sauce. It's not too salty and a good veggie option.

Vegetarian longevity noodle soup: more house made noodles in a savory broth. It had a number of vegetables I didn't recognize, but added to the whole dish. I can't pinpoint what was missing, but the soup was lacking. Given a choice of the two vegetarian noodle dishes, go for the Beijing knife cut noodles.

Overall, it was a pleasant experience and not a terrible choice for inside a mall.
author: AJ L.

description: Dylan and Lalo are superstars. I have nothing to complain about. The food, the drinks and the service are world class.
author: John P.

description:
I was recently invited to the soft opening of Martin Yan's M.Y. China, his new restaurant in the Westfield Mall.  Ignoring the usual challenges restaurants undergo when first opening, I found the place to be open, well-appointed and cranking out huge amounts of scrumptious food.  From the understated clean and modern Asian decor to the smiles on the waitstaff we were treated to some of the delicacies they are planning on serving once open.  

The pork belly appetizer was crispy but I felt needed some more flavor to the Beijing noodles, which are made fresh as you watch them making it right in front of you, which was a bit on the sweet side, but quite tasty.  We tried their dim sum collection which had 1 piece of some of my favorite dishes, i.e., har gao, shiu mai, sticky rice, egg tart, and a crispy egg roll served in the steamer basket straight out of the steamer.  I got the Honey-glazed lamb chops which while very tasty were in need of a hotter fire to burn off some of the fat and cook the chop just a bit more.  The coconut sorbet was sensational.  All in all, I'm sure with Mr. Yan's exacting standards and all the notes we supplied them with, this place is going to be a go-to place to eat well, very well.  I'd recommend trying them after the hectic shopping season and after they've worked out all the bugs.  

What bugs you ask?  Well, while they offer free unlimited sparkling water and still water, the glasses are the same for both, so every 5 minutes someone is coming by to ask if it's still or sparkling.  With different glasses for each, this challenge could be rectified easily.  Also, the soy sauce containers pour soy sauce everywhere but where you want it.  As I said, these are very small details and can be easily fixed. It also seemed to be a very high ratio of staff to diners, wondering if they really need SO MANY people working there.  Lastly, another first, I believe, unisex bathrooms, great idea, forward thinking but alas, no signage and only 3 stalls for over 200 seats.  YIKES, that's going to be interesting.  With all the above though, I predict this is going to be a great success and one that is deserving of a great Bay Area Pioneer Celebrity Chef, like Mr. Yan.  Jao-jen.
author: Irv S.

description: Update:  The staff of MY China really go above and beyond to make sure their customers are happy with the food and service.  Managers Craig and Carol took in what my friend said before about the "tiny, tiny amount of tempeh," discussed it with their team, and ended up making the dish have 2 sliders and charge $2 more.  Good solution!  Not only that, but when I told them I was coming to the restaurant two weeks ago on a Friday, they asked to meet us.  They couldn't have been nicer.  I tried a new dish, the wok seared beef, and it was terrific.  My vegetarian friend had a tofu dish and loved the delicious sauce.  We both tried a new cocktail, the Tianjin Drum Tower.  It was superb!  Made with michter's bourbon, wu jia pi baijiu, and beet syrup, $13.  My only issue was that it came in a short glass, like for an old-fashioned, and the glass was nearly filled with the biggest honkin' ice cube I've ever seen.  I didn't even know ice cubes could be made that big.  The liquid rose up along the sides of the cube so it looked like a full glass, but really wasn't.  when I lifted the cube out of the glass, there was only about an inch of liquid.  I don't mind that the amount of drink was minimal - it's the quality, not the quantity - but I felt like the apocryphal Archimedes in the bathtub discovering the principle of displacement to measure volume.  When I asked Craig about it, he said the bartender said it was so that the drink would not get watered down.  But he cheerfully brought me and my friend fresh drinks with normal size ice cubes in them.  Five times five stars for service!
author: Patty A.

description:
We made a reservation here for when they open on Sunday at 5:30PM...there was a line that starts BEFORE 5:30, so even if you have a reservation, you are in a big line until you get up to the desk - which was about 5:45, so keep that in mind if you are trying to catch a movie of a show in the area as there wasn't a reservation first line it was first come first serve...enough of that let's talk about the restaurant.

For a mall - this was really a nice dining experience.  There are a couple of other restaurants up in that area that looked worth a try as well, but we wanted Chinese food and this place doesn't disappoint.

Restroom alert - they have co-ed restrooms, so don't be surprised is you walk into the hand washing area and see ladies thinking you have walked into the wrong area, you didn't.  They have individual WCs in there, but that was different for sure.

I had heard some reviews about the seating...this was not an issue for us.  We were sat in a low traffic area with a couple of other people, but we weren't that close - but close enough that you could see what others were getting and ask questions on what they were being served as everything looked great.

It was fun to watch the "show" happening in the visible kitchen with the LONG noodles and even the dumpling guy was tossing them in from a long distance, so that can be fun - just stay out of the way of the busy waiters who were hauling food back and forth from that area.

We started with a couple of fancy cocktails - the M.Y. China Mai Tai was pretty tasty, and had a kick to it...be careful if you order too many of these as they were pretty powerful.

Dim Sum - Our waiter recommended the Pork & Crab juicy dumplings - these were really good interesting combination of flavors- - maybe a little pricey, but crab is not cheap.  

We split the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup - easily enough for two people, but warning - these noodles are really long...and you will look like an episode from I LOVE LUCY where you need scissors to cut the noodles to get into your bowl...they are LONG.  Would have liked a little more zing in the taste and prefer my soup piping hot - so maybe try another one of these next time.

Main course:
Kung Pao Chicken - my favorite of the two we ordered - fresh ingredients and could have had just an order of this and would have been happy.
Wok Seared Beef Filet - in wine and peppercorns, okay - but really didn't send me to the moon - expected something different and it was kind of meh.
Rice - we tried the Forbidden Rice - has a lot of stuff in it - I'd be okay with Steamed rice next time...this was kind of like an Uncle Ben's wild rice - so, not sure I'd go for it again - worth a try, as it is different, but steamed for me next time.

Service - really friendly waiter - very helpful in recommendations.  We'd go back again and try other things on the menu.

Great place to stop after long day of shopping.
author: Steve A.

description:
If you are Chinese and grew up going to those Chinese restaurants run and opened for Chinese, you will find the concept of M.Y. China or any other upscale Chinese restaurant geared toward Westerners foreign.  The menu structure is odd in its presentation as Chinese people would never list the dishes in such a manner.  The food is not bad in fact decent.  The decor is beautiful from the tableware to the furnishings so what's not to like?  The thing is that you can easily get this food and more at many upper scale Chinese restaurants at a far lower price point.

I think this is a great option for those who have done a day's shopping and are now ready to relax and have some of their favorite Chinese dishes.  Also, a great place for those who are intimidated by the English-unfriendly restaurants.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Get the Forbidden Rice. It was my favorite dish. Not your typical fried rice! Spicy seafood dumplings (the ones that are in green spinach wraps) are also pretty bombalicious. Mushroom egg rolls and pea shoots were pretty tasty, but not anything to write home about. 

Best presentation goes to the pork sliders. Even though I'm not eating meat right now, those looked the most appetizing! 

Least liked dish was the chairman Mao chicken. I didn't eat it, and my friends at our table didn't eat it either. Although it was crunchy, the color was weird, reminding me that it might have still been raw. Presentation looked like it was just thrown on a plate. We didn't even bother to take it home; that's how bad it was. One of the sauces was also too sweet for our liking. I kinda liked the savory sauce for it, though. Super tangy!

I think the best thing about this place is where you sit. I really wanted to be facing the kitchen! The best seats in the house might be facing the noodle pulling bar. I totally want to sit there when I come back for the forbidden rice. I'm telling you. It's THAT amazing. 

I really wish I had the halibut. Also for next time. 

One big question: can someone tell me why the pea shoots cost twice as much as the forbidden rice?
author: Denise H.

description:
I will say it is nice to have more upscale options in at the mall compared to your standard food courts (although Westfield SF's food court isn't that bad at all).   As such, I was looking forward to M.Y. China, partly because of my familiarity with "Yan Can Cook."  In the end, the overall experience was fine but didn't quite live up to my heightened expectations.

For starters, the pork & black truffle dumplings were on the larger size but 5 for $18 still seemed pricey.  Also, the dumpling skin seemed too thick for a soup dumpling and had to be eaten in several bites, which takes away from the overall experience of eating a soup dumpling.  Also, couldn't even tell there was truffle in the dish.

Also, going in I knew that handmade noodles were supposedly the highlight here.  Going out, I believe this this reputation was mostly overrated.  Neither the wild boar scissor cut nor the Beijing knife cut noodles impressed me much - both were thick and chewy and in my opinion, just ok.  But I will say the hand-pulled noodle soup with its savory broth and extremely tender beef was excellent.

The non-noodle dishes also equally hit or miss.  Both the lamb chops and the honey glazed BBQ pork were very good and left everyone was pleasantly surprised.  Our favorite dishes of the night.  But conversely, the mapo tofu was probably the worst I've ever had.  Completely bland and devoid of any flavor whatsoever.  No heat, no salt, no nothing.  The only dish that wasn't finished.

Dessert-wise, the sugar egg puffs (basically large profiteroles) with different sauces were nice to share but again just ok.

Overall, the dishes were just too inconsistent for me - either great or really disappointing.
author: F. P.

description: It was packed and service was very good.  Restaurant is in the nicest mall in DT.   Food was ok at best.  For a reference, PF is better.  I would love to be able to take my $100 lunch back.
author: Chris W.

description:
Not good enough to rate a return.

The good: the special imperial rice (smoky and very tasty, but ultimately, it's rice), and the garlic pea shoots (but every Chinese restaurant in town does this competently).

The bad: servers served a side of thumb with every dish, daikon pickles were taken away before we were done (but maybe that's a good thing as they weren't that good), baby bok choy with salted fish was a weird combo of greens, white anchovies out of a can and a bizarre sauce...

Worst of all: the server had to show the table next to us our dumplings before finally delivering them to our table. WTF?  My food isn't a sideshow!  But, it would have been better if he served them to someone else as they were weak at best: no noticeable truffle and the skins were too weak to hold in the broth.  Topping that was the ginger crab.  Two words: old crab...some more words: tasted like bleach.

Avoid.
author: Frank M.

description:
Underwhelming and overpriced. Service needs to improve. We were delivered food we didn't order. Food seemed to come out at random order. The waiters reached over us quite often, but that could be because tables were small and so close together.

Went for dinner on a Wednesday night. 
What I had:
Calamari - Decent. Served with sweet chili sauce.
Forbidden Rice - Extremely dry. I would have preferred regular white rice.
Honey Glazed BBQ Pork - Meh.
Kung Pao Chicken - Best thing I had. Chicken was tender and juicy.

I would only go back to try the noodles or the dim sum.
author: Rhonald A.

description:
Very disappointed. Tried to eat there with my wife and daugther. They sat us at the counter table which is very small. I asked the person if we could get a table instead but he said no table are open. I pointed to him there are a lot of open tables. Even a  table enough for 3 person. He replied all tables are reserved. I asked back why no reserved sign and he replied this restorant don't need a reserve sign every think is computerised. Then he also added if want i table you could wait 20-30 minutes. A lot of open tables and have to wait another 20-30 minutes ??? Went there on saturday 12/22/12 around 1pm. 
I believe since that restaurant own by famous chef. the food must be good but after got this kind of exprience i think i skip. Too bad can't put 0 star for rating. I haven't tried the food yet
author: Arya H.

description:
I am REALLY impressed by this place. I know it's not China Chinese food, but its daaam good for what it is.

We had reservations on a Saturday afternoon, which is a good thing because they were packed! Our service was swift though which is always nice. We did feel a little rushed, but I am sure they get a lot of customers here on a time crunch so this didn't bother me.

The cocktails were awesome!

Food wise we had the Boar Steamed Dumplings, the Pork Tacos, bang bang chicken wings and Hong Kong Crispy Noodles with Chicken.  Everything was delicious! Finger bowls with the chicken wings would have been good, but oh well! Also the pork tacos are HUGE! I was expecting these tiny little tacos but they were a dam decent size. And so delicious.

When I go back for lunch I really wanna try something new, but I loved everything I ordered I might lean towards them again. Will have to solve that dilemma by going back for dinner and exploring the dinner menu!
author: Kym P.

description: It was just okay. Meh. I was disappointed with my meal. Everything was so salty, and then they bring you soy sauce which I didn't touch. Anyways the best thing I ate here was the whole wheat potstickers. I'd come back for that and some drinks any day. On to the meh. The lettuce wraps. WAY too much green onion and the sauce was too sweet, but the texture was nice. Then I had the vegetarian longevity noodle soup. The broth was super salty. The noodles were perfect, spinachy goodness. Long and chewy. It was fun seeing the sous chefs pulling the noodles behind glass so that's a plus. Overall everything is too hit and miss here, but something is telling me I need to explore more of the menu...hmmmm.
author: Courtney M.

description:
Came here at 5:30 for a quick dinner with my mom. The restaurant had a crowd outside and in the foyer, but the actual restaurant was 70% empty. I saw 2 available seats at the "wok bar" and asked the hostess if they were first come first serve. She said yes, but that it would be 5-10 minutes until we could sit there. I was confused, because there were table settings laid out. So we just sat at the regular bar which had several open seats. It was 10 minutes before we were given menus by the bartender. The other staff behind the bar was friendly and helpful, but the scattered bartender kept calling me "darling" and "sweetie". Stuff like that doesn't usually get to me, but he was relentless. 

We got around to ordering 2 salads, a glass of sparkling wine, and I ordered a hot tea. The bartender pressed "nothing to drink darling?" so I repeated "Just the hot tea". I was 6 weeks pregnant at the time, and hadn't told anyone yet.

The food came out quickly. The green papaya salad was very salty, and had about 3 times too many dried shrimp on it, and about 4 prawns. I was still starving, so I ordered a fresh spring roll, which was good, but average. The bill for 2 salads, 2 beverages (one non alcoholic) and 1 appetizer was nearly $50. 

While we only had a small sampling of the menu, I was disappointed by the food, which I found to be average tasting and overpriced. The service was poor, especially the front end staff. Hopefully that has been worked out. The decor is beautiful, and it is a good location. I won't be coming back unless I hear some glowing reviews.
author: M L.

description: Skip it.
author: Theresa D.

description: Try their amazing mu shu tacos. Peking duck dinner set was also great.
author: Music K.

description: I've been here about 6 times and each meal was solid.  Great noodle entrees, delicious buns/dim sum and a selection of booze/drinks that are very satisfying.  Special props to the bar keeps who keep me well hydrated and a master chef who actually cares about the quality and consistency of the food.  While this place doesn't have everything in terms of options, they do a consistent job each and every time.
author: Darin E.

description: They had me at pork juicy dumplings! OMG so yummy!!! Also had the BBQ pork and the crunchy noodles with chicken. Service was on point, and the food was delicious, as was the cocktail I ventured to try from the menu. I will definitely come back again.
author: Kimberly R.

description:
I live fairly close to Westfield, and had been looking forward to Martin Yan's restaurant opening for over a year. The minute I stopped checking on it, MY China had its grand opening without my knowledge (still bummed about that :-))

After all the anticipation I would have planned a more formal first visit, but as it turned out my friend and I were starving after shopping, and just grabbed a quick afternoon snack there. 

We only ordered three items: BBQ pork bun, spicy seafood dumpling, and eggplant. While the buns were fairly standard, the dumpling and eggplant were outstanding!  The ingredients were fresh, the dishes were creative, and very flavorful.  I will need to try more dishes, but I am tentatively going to give four stars. 

Yes it's pricier than Chinatown, but the food is a lot less greasy, the place is clean and well decorated, and how many holes in the wall in Chinatown come with a full bar?

Update January 12, 2013

Ok so I went back Friday night with my husband and cousin, and the place was hopping/busy.  I could tell the staff was spread thin and didn't mind the slightly longer delay between check-ins.  Even then they graciously accommodated the fact that were were 30 minutes early, and got the food out at a reasonable pace.

This time we tried the Hong Kong crispy noodles and squid ink seafood pasta, as well as the five-spice pork ribs; I skipped dessert but the Meyer's lemon tart and toasted rice sundae my hubby and cousin ordered looked pretty good.

Hong Kong- Crispy noodle pretty good, generous chunks of chicken and veggies.
Squid Ink Seafood Pasta- Very creative and pretty, good combination of flavors.
Five-Spice Pork Ribs- HAVE YOU GONE MAD??!!  Five-spice anything is best BRAISED, especially with pork ribs.  As it was the ribs were lightly fried (a la tempura style) with so little five-spice powder on it that I would not have guessed it was there.  I am far from a die-hard traditional person when it comes to cooking, but this new twist on an oldie is a fail.  However, I will say that the meat itself was juicy, fresh, and not too fatty.

I'll stick with the four stars for now.  Next to try:  Hand pulled beef noodle and the candied fruit dessert.
author: Rache C.

description:
Ordered a ton of stuff..what can I say...

- Baked chicken bao - 3/5 it's like your average bbq pork bun
- BBQ pork - 5/5 OMG this is great you have to get this as a side dish..it's tender and juicy n just lovely and divine
- HK crunchy noodle - 2.5/4 i like the crunch factor but everything is so damn greasy..why!!!
- Beef noodle soup - 4/5 the beef is great, the broth n noodle I care NOTHING about 
- MY Dim sum collection - 3.5/5 as it has great selection a bit of everything, it wasn't bad, but not as great as Hakkasan
- Wild boar noodles - 2/5 were like chow fun and the wild boar wasn't great..
- Wild boar lettuce cups - 3/5 as it was quite sweet and the fatty part of the wild boar didn't make it taste any better, but I do like the crunch in the lettuce wrap I think it's fried noodles
- Macau egg tart -3/5 what is so special? I don't know..I'm still puzzled..it's super tiny and comes in quantity of 3..nothing special..it's not flaky or crunchy
- Mixed green salad with roasted chicken -4/5 seriously took forever for this damn thing to come out and I wanted to cancel it and they wouldn't let me!..the chicken was good..the greens is eh..just romaines and a few other stuff that didn't add much to it..
- Black truffle dumpling - 3.5/5 nothing special, though you get a lot, and it's quite cool how it comes in spoons..dip it in sauce..and be sure to ask for hot sauce..you'll need it..

Overall, nothing special..I don't see what the rave is..the only that's good is the bbq pork and a few meat pieces from a few dishes..I didn't see Martin Yan, eh..

Would I come back? Not unless my parents want to go back..
author: Minerva L.

description:
