I'm actually sitting in the resultant writing my review. I would love to give it a better rating than three stars because the food is quite good. The service however is terrible. I sat for 15 minutes before someone even approached me. 

When I tired to ask my server what he thought of my wine selection he evidently didn't hear me walked off and disappeared. After 20 more minutes he came back over and said I'll be right over with your wine. I had not even ordered yet! Finally my wine came, not delivered by my server. 
Finally I was able to order after 35 minutes.

 My second course arrived 30 additional minutes after I received my first course. 
Wine and food was lovely, service left a lot to be desired. I will probably still be waiting for my check by the time you read this....
author: Marjorie K.

description: Wonderful environment and super awesome food ! Highly recommend! Especially the Peking Duck .... BTW, I'm a Chinese so I know how authentic and creative their dishes are ....
author: Yuqiao Z.

description: Love this place!  It's not cheap.  But the flavors are unique and delicious, the noodles freshly made, and the service good.  This is our "go-to" place when we're in downtown SF.  Highly recommended!
author: Steven C.

description: I gave the restaurant another try with my parents and the service was excellent.  The host sat us quickly and the server Ryan came to our table to ask if we wanted anything to drink.  Later the manager Daniel came by to check in on us also.  After Ryan told us some information about the starters.  We tried the Shandong potato and onion pancakes with beef.  Also got to try the scallop sui mai.  Both were great starters.  He was very good about answering questions about the entrees.  My Dad had the Beef noodle soup and my Mom had the Venison chow fun.  I ordered the Guangdong Lobster.   I normally order Lobster E-Fu mein at a Cantonese restaurant so I had to compare it with that.  The lobster was good not over cooked which can make it rubbery.  But it was served over vermicelli which didn't do much for the dish.  It came with a side of the hand cut noodles on the side which were delicious as always.  I guess I was expecting more from the lobster since I'm use to eating it with ginger and onions stir fried.  We shared everything family style and we were stuffed.  At the end of meal they brought us this unique dessert.  tt had three cups of ice cream which they make themselves, I think, in a waffle cup.  And the chef hand spins sugar from a wok that was placed on top of the cups of ice cream. When they presented to us the told us it was like sugar noodle, I called it a Chinese cotton candy,  but it wasn't as fluffy so noodle may be more correct.  It looked amazing and my dad really liked the sugar noodles.  I loved the green tea infused ice cream.  I would take my parents back again since they had a great time.  Thanks again M.Y. China staff.
author: David J.

description:
I have been to M.Y. China three times in the past two months and every time has been wonderful.  What makes my visits special?  Well, each time I go, I and my dining companion have sat at the bar.   Matt, the bartender/mixologist,  is incredible.  His drink and menu recommendations have been spot on each time.  To rave about M.Y. China is to rave about the people as well as the food.  

Oh!  And the happy hour (M-F, 3-6 p.m) is one of the best deals in town.  An order of the Pork Dumplings, Bang Bang Chicken wings and a mixed drink for under $20.
author: Beth V.

description:
I am actually surprised at how much I love this place.  The juicy dumplings are amazing.  The hand cut noodles are not to miss.

Also, the table service was outstanding.  And when I sit at the bar (during lunch) you can tell the bartenders are young and slightly inexperienced, however, they give great service and are always practicing their skills when its a slower service.

This place is great for the dinner and a movie experience.  A Mai Tai and a movie more like it.
author: S M.

description: I had reasonable expectations for M.Y. despite the fact that it sits in the middle of Westfield Mall, but it ended up being a P.F. Chang's equivalent with smaller portions and very average food. We started with the beef rolls, which were a little too greasy for my taste. The pancake didn't have the chew that I look for and the rolls were small for the price you pay. The beef noodle soup was an even greater disappointment, with probably enough noodles for a couple bites each. The only saving grace for the meal was the seafood scissor noodles, which was generously portioned in terms of seafood. The noodles were nice and chewy, and the portion size was much better. They gave us a complimentary calamari appetizer because of the wait, but the strange seasoning and sweet dipping sauce cancelled out the fact that the fry on the squid was pretty good. Overall, the meal wasn't satisfying at all and I won't be back for more.
author: Ashley T.

description:
I've been here twice.  Martin Yan was there last night and could not be sweeter or funnier.  I've loved him since I was a youngster!  He brought a few people to me to talk.  Adorable. 

Both times, I've sat at the counter.  Chef Tony is a character and really puts on a show.  Even for a person dining solo. :)  A warning though, it can get hot sitting there.  

To date, I've had the wild boar scissor cut noodles, green beans, wild boar dumplings and beef noodle soup.  Everything was pretty good, but a bit on the salty side.  I do not usually equate "flavor" with salt.  Maybe I can ask them to go easy next time.  The soup was a great and rich combo of salty, sweet, and spicy and the noodles were amazing.  I don't usually drink the broth out of ANY soup, so it's nothing personal.  I just ate all the stuff out of the bowl and left the broth.   The dumplings were great, albeit a little pricey at $2/per dumpling.  I would order them again though.
author: S. Y.

description:
My family came from out of town to visit and wanted to eat somewhere relatively close to bart. We decided on M.Y. China since it was nicer than the food court for our guests. I was expecting the restaurant to be bourgeois and expensive, with mediocre, pan-asian tasting food. We arrived at the restaurant and it was packed for a Monday night...a good sign! We were seated quickly and the service was pretty good/attentive. We ordered a lot of food, and I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and taste of it! The only down side was that they were out of their "famous" crispy roast chicken...bummer! I'll definitely be coming back to try it one of these days!

Overall, a good meal and environment! I recommend ordering the Wok Seared Beef Filet, Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, Pineapple Seafood Fried Rice, and Stir Fried Green Beans! You won't be disappointed!
author: Olivia D.

description:
3 1/2 stars

Really solid, slightly Americanised, but well done Chinese food.  We ordered about 10 dishes for a large table--including the fried chicken, claypot pork, among other dishes.  All were consistent, though none were standouts.  

MY China reminded me of a HK hotel food--lots of high gloss, professional food--sufficient spice, sugar, the "red cook" was accurate--but it will not be confused with family cooking or even smaller restaurant food.  

I liked the fact that they had chefs making noodles, hand cut, and even rolling the dumplings in the front.  It's a nice, Vegas-y, but smart touch.

Definitely would go back if we have a large gathering and need to have a respectable, clean, well designed atmosphere with good, solid food.
author: Jay C.

description: Martin Yan can cook and so can you. Try the mu shu pork tacos.
author: Joseph M.

description: Food was okay, service was bad. Made us wait while they had open seats for 1 hr because we didn't have a reservation which was fine. Then we get seated and get a very rude server, to make matters worst the food had no taste, like it was not seasoned. Long story short, I will not recommend anyone there.
author: Boubacar D.

description: One of the worst dinning experiences ever. The service was super slow. The signature chicken dish we ordered could only be described as putrid. When I brought this to the managers attention the response was a silent arrogant stare.
author: Robert M.

description: MY China food was delicious. The scallop appetizer was to die for. Victoria was our server and she was awesome. The chef doing his Gangam Style handmade noodle dance was a plus. Great California wine selection.
author: Fiona M.

description: This was my third visit here. Who would of thought a a great, sophisticated Chinese restaurant in a mall and not the food court variety. First two visits were great, and this visit was very good, although the 'fun' noodle dish seemed lackluster. The small plates are excellent particularly the tacos and boar in lettuce cups. The Fun with venison was just not up to the same standard. The venison was excellent, tender braised bite size pieces. The remainder just fell a little uninteresting. Service on all three visits was excellent. The wine list is divided nicely with a good choice of California, French and other choices. That said, I think their best choices are from the local California region. The space is very well decorated and even though it's a large space, there is ample room between tables to feel a sense of privacy.
author: Philip S.

description:
I did not expect to like this place - at all. A mall? Ick. Chinese food? Meh. There are so few places in the City that do good Chinese food, I couldn't imagine this place would be any different. So when my friend wanted to come here before our movie I was reluctant. But it was convenient and I like watching Martin Yan, so was willing to give it a try. I'm so glad I did! Our food was ridiculously good, the service was great and the price was very reasonable.  

Who knew Chinese noodles could be so great?! The hand-made Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles were flavor-packed without being a bomb of oil and salt. I was surprised the pea shoots were so expensive - as much as many entrees - but they were so tasty. The Sichuan green beans were crisp and perfectly spiced. All food was a hit. The wine list is user-friendly, well priced and I think almost any bottle would compliment any dish.  

M.Y.China is Y.U.M! I highly recommend and will definitely return.
author: Robin G.

description:
Excellent American Chinese.

- High quality ingredients
- Perfectly prepared dishes
- American chinese with a twist
- Extremely friendly service
- Beautiful ambiance

My shopping exploits in Westfield have found their perfect ending. Next time, I might trade the delicious Chrysanthemum tea for cocktails and call it a party! Recommended:

+ Any of the soup dumplings
+ Wok seared beef fillet on arugula
+ Hot & sour soup
+ Wheat potstickers
author: Janett R.

description:
I have eaten here four times and enjoyed more each time, always sit the bar order the seafood dumplings, noodles and the beef so Yummy. So far I have always had the Hispanic bartender who is knowledgeable polite makes a great drink and goes out of his way to make sure the customer is happy! He is awesome!

What a great experience to find a place like this in a shopping mall!
author: Bob C.

description:
Tasty food for apps. We sat at the viewing window.
 That was supper cool. We had the calamari, chicken wings, and steamed dumpling. Atmosphere is awesome! Wait staff was great too. The only negative is the price. The 3 things, coke and cranberry juice was $52.00. Outragous!!!!!
author: Cory M.

description:
After a bit of a rough start getting a table and service, Daniel from the bar came to our rescue!  He salvaged our experience so I'm giving 5 stars just for him.  He was attentive and went above and beyond - it's refreshing to see individuals like Daniel who obviously sees making customers happy as his job and not just serving those at his "station".  Several servers (and even the manager) walked by many times but Daniel was the one who came through for us.  He also made great food and drink recommendations:

East meets West cocktail - Daniel was right on:  this was an absolutely delicious drink.  Tastes handcrafted with a unique chrysanthemum tea flavor.

Bang Bang Chicken Wings - All three of us LOVED this appetizer.   Crispy without being greasy with just the right amount of sauce and spice.

Sichuan Green Beans - Easy to pass up...but don't!  There's no better way to get your greens.

Thanks, Daniel!  We'll be back just to see you...
author: Tone C.

description: This was my 5th or 6th time in the restaurant. In the past, all my experiences have been fantastic and have left me with the desire to go back and get more food. However, this last experience was terrible. The food as usual was good, but the service was horrible. The waiter served the food without any order. Appetizers came at the same time as main courses, with the exception of the side dish (Fried Rice). We asked for our fried rice at least 3 times and it did not come until 15 min after the last complain. When it finally came, our waitress did say we didn't have to pay for the fried rice--it's on the house--, but by the time, my lamb dish already got cold (and cold lamb isn't very tasty). So maybe it was bad luck, but I probably won't go back there for a while--at least 3 or 4 months.
author: Fanny Y.

description:
My 3 favorite dishes so far are the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup, the Hong Kong Crispy Noodle With Chicken and the Wok Seared Beef Filet (which rivals the R & G Special Beef at R & G Lounge).  

I give this place only 3 stars because there were a couple other dishes which fell short such as the Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood (very bland for what I expected) and M.Y. Hot and Sour Soup (tasted like there was tabasco sauce added which is not a good thing).  Also, the service was really slow.
author: Daphne N.

description: We had such a great time at M.Y. China... I'd let them know it was my husband's birthday... I didn't tell them it was his first birthday since the death of his wonderful mother, last November. They greeted us with complementary champagne, and Amber, the manager, walked us through her favorites on the menu. She even brought head chef Tony to our table, with a special dish he created just for us! We had the spicy seafood dumplings, sichuan green beans, wild boar scissor cut noodles,  and smoked jasmine tea sea bass. Everything was wonderful, the ambiance was delightful, and the service was everything we could have hoped for.  Thank you, M.Y. China!
author: Kelly M.

description: Wow what a shock. A mall restaurant that is really good. The roasted chicken was very tender and juicey. The forbidden rice was very tasty. Ths dumplings are great and just right. The duplings are not to much on the outside and jsut right enough contant on the inside. Just a great pleasant suprise.
author: P C.

description: The Juicy Dumplings & Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders are delicious and authentic. I enjoyed the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup a lot, the beef was very tender and juicy. Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles is also worth a try, I liked the texture of the noodle a lot!  Our server, Daniel, was great at suggesting dishes to try and was constantly checking in with us. He really made our dining experience that much better on top of all these delicious food!!!
author: Jenn M.

description: I grew up watching many different Martin Yan shows. Even recently his travel show in China has been inspiring. Knowing that he was teaming up with some of the best Chinese food in the brothers of Koi Palace I was excited. Unfortunately, it came out completely different than I thought. THe place is beautiful. the bar, the main dining room, the back dining room. the open kitchen. It looks awesome. However instead of getting the hardcore Koi Palace food experience, you're getting a dumbed down shy, pared down version of food for the mall folk. I guess you have to make money at the end of the day right? The peking style duck and the milk oolong tea were excellent. Truffle pork and wild boar dumplings were decent. The dan dan and squid ink snap noodles where underwhelming. We even sat right near the noddle makers which provided for a show. I just couldnt get over how underseasoned the food was. The cooking techniques were great. Seafood, perfectly cooked. Meat perfectly cooked. Noodles textures, great. Just need spices and salt! Such a shame as this could really have been a show case of how grand Chinese cooking could be. 3.5 stars
author: Kim N.

description: Phenomenal drinks from the bar and a great noodle dish that was perfect for a late lunch.
author: Cam M.

description: The food was pretty good. Some items were better than others. This place is a higher end PF changs for the most part. The biggest issue I had was everyone else's food came out but I had to wait 15 minutes longer for my meal even though we all ordered at the same time.
author: G K.

description: no dings here.    food was excellent and the portions were fair for the prices.   a refreshing find for a shopping mall eatery.   no pretentious prices or attitude that sometimes comes with a celebrity owner   the service was fine and the food was served hot and properly seasoned - the spicy menu items actually had some kick to them unlike many other restaurants that are bland beyond belief
author: Chris L.

description: For a mall restaurant, this place is great.  We really enjoyed the dumplings, and although I'm normally a xiaolongbao fan (shanghai dumpling), I actually preferred the Beijing dumplings at this establishment. We also ordered mapo tofu, which was frankly a little light on spice (both hot and flavor varieties) and the dry fried string beans. The dry fried string beans did not appear to be dry fried and came out as normal stir fry style string beans but were still good. Overall, I'd say- order dumplings and enjoy. Will go again if in the mall.
author: Amy L.

description: Sea Bass and Peking duck was tasty .Excellent service from Victoria. Great suggestions for wine and our complimentary Green Tea Tiramisu was bomb. $200.00 bill was sooo worth it. I'll see you again M.Y. China.
author: mai t.

description: Update This place is still a-ok.  I think the food is decent. It's just very pricey.  Service is still hit or miss.
author: Mr. C.

description: Off to a bad start on Mothers Day we had a table of 8 for 6:30 pm when I went to check in the hostess said your table is ready and here she brings me to a table of people I did not know. Turns out they gave my reservation to someone else with the same last name. We then had to wait another 30 min for a table. The manager did come out and offered to pay for our drinks. Now we are seating and ready to order........
author: Stanley C.

description: Food is phenomenal. A must every time we visit SF. Husband loves Peking duck. I love everything on their menu!
author: Natalie B.

description:
This was a surprise gem. 
I had low expectations for a good meal eating in a mall really.  Basically, that's what it was.  But, I kind of started to think of it as a Vegas kind of scene - decent restaurants in a nice mall...

The standouts I am dying to go back to order are the steamed dumplings, general's chicken and last but not least - the hand cut (scissor cut) noodles!!!  That was just amazing.  If you even kind of like noodles, this is a must try.  The texture of the cuts as well as this being fresh noodles, was just superb.   I could eat the noodles and dumplings probably a good 3 days in the same week before I needed to move on.

There were one or two dishes of the 7 we ordered that we could've skipped, but definitely ask your server for their recommendations.  That really helped.  

The setting is lovely - it has a nice modern and clean style and the server was excellent.  He got us in and out quickly like we asked so we could make our movie time!
author: Harper L.

description:
I would recommend the beef hand pulled noodle soup, honey glazed pork, and the yangzhou fried rice.  The Chairman Mao chicken was a bit dry and the beijing knife cut noodles had this strange flavor to it. 

But I got to give low ratings, because I clearly remember ordering the da dao big knife noodles and when I calmly mentioned that they brought the wrong dish to us, the waiter put me at fault.  He seemed a bit angry and unprofessional.  For what seems to be a high class institution, I was surprised at their low level of service.  

Yeah, I'm not feeling this place.
author: Olivia C.

description: I've always been a fan of the food here (excellent flavors, no msg) but now I'm also a fan of the exceptional service. I had some clients in town who only eat chinese food so i called to make a ressie here. The hostess told me that their reservation system was down that day and to just walk in and wait. Hours later we arrived only to find that they're now closed because of the system issues. Embarrassed we drove an hour with my client, I explained the situation to the manager, Mathew, who immediately seated us. Not only did he make an exception, he kindly introduced himself and came over multiple times to check on us. Not only is the food top notch, the accommodating nature of the staff is phenomenal.. needless to say, they have a customer for life.
author: J Z.

description:
We had lunch there inside the mall.  The food was very tasty especially the noodles which are made there in the restaurant .  We has the black squid noodle seafood with scallops,shrimps and squids which was very light.

The roast duck was good!  I recommend that.

And we also ordered pan fried noodles, good but just like any other Chinese restaurant .  The appetizer we had was spicy dumplings with shrimp.  Yummy but a little too spicy for us.

Overall, all was very flavorful .  The portions are big and they a la carte.
author: Carina R.

description: Very good food....   I dont usually like sweet & sour pork but my son ordered it so i tried it out.  I was very suprised, it was very good! Service was so, so.
author: Alex ..

description: You know what, those noodles are delicious! I had the squid ink seafood pasta dish, and it was superb - not too inky. The ambience was great. Try to sit inside the back room so you don't feel like you're in the mall. Innovative cocktails round out  a perfect menu. This is contemporary Chinese food, so yes, it does deviate from the more authentic family style foods you'll find in the Richmond. Good luck finding high quality Chinese food in Chinatown though. Most SF locals know that great Italian food hard to find in North Beach and great Chinese food is hard to find in Chinatown - possible though. My partner, who is Chinese, very much enjoyed his dish as well.  I'll be back for shopping, dinner and a movie very soon.
author: Mark S.

description: We were really pleasantly surprised at how good the food is here. We sat and watched the chefs make the food.  The food was very flavorful and reasonably price.  The seafood was also really fresh and tasty.  The service was a bit spotty since we were being attended to by the bartender. Otherwise, this is a great spot for some Chinese food, and it wasn't too greasy!
author: Tina U.

description: This is Martin Yan's restaurant. The food was fancy and probably over-priced (I don't know because I didn't pay). Nonetheless I enjoyed the food and the server was very attentive.
author: Pooky C.

description:
Food: Two stars
You would expect a restaurant like this making everything from scratch. We ordered Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles (vegetarian version) and Green Onion Pancakes and have very high hope that we'll be getting a killer made to order Green Onion Pancakes. The Scissors Cut Noodles is fantastic. When the waiter brought the Green Onion Pancakes, everything went south quickly. It is a frozen precooked stuff that you can get it from Chinatown for $1.49. It is clear that the chef doesn't respect his profession. I would feel that I'm insulting my customer if I serve instant noodle in my restaurant. If the chef doesn't know how to make a green onion pancake, go to Ark Chinese Restaurant in Alameda and learn. 

Services: Zero Stars
The services are terrible. I spilled the soy sauce on the floor. The waiter shows up, grabs my napkin, and mops the floor. Yes, with napkins that customers usually use them to wipe their mouth. Didn't come back with my cleaned napkin. Didn't come back to clean up the floor properly either. Just disappeared.

In addition to no common sense, they didn't even have basic manners. They don't even bother to present your dishes properly. They'd rather lean it forward from a far corner and hand your dishes behind you like a food truck service (to save some steps??) than walking to the proper spot (such as next to you?) and present it nicely.

Overall: One Star.
author: John C.

description: Really amazing food here. The hand made noodles are super good! It made mine and my wife's night!  We weren't sure about this place and how good it was going to be but it blew us away with how good the noodles tasted and how friendly the staff were. We went on a Saturday night with no reservations and they were kind enough to find us a table for two! We will be coming back again for sure!
author: Mike G.

description:
Saw this place on Check Please and wanted to try it. Really liked this place.

Its strange that it is in a mall, but get over this. The room is nicely decorated and the wait staff is very professional and do a great job. They have open kitchen and you get a free show watching the cooks pull noodles, cut noodles and making all the dishes. Before any food comes I was a fan of this place.

Still, a nice room and wait staff with bad food is still not a good place in my book, but everything we ordered was very good.

First up was a small bowl of hot and sour soup. A pretty boring order, but we wanted this, and they did a nice job with the soup. They had more items in the soup than standard Chinese place giving more depth to the soup and more textural elements. Good job overall on a simple item.

We then got the wild boar with hand cut noodles. Loved this dish. The texture of the noodles was perfect. The vegetables and meat and the sauce highlighted the noodles, this was a pure winner dish, delicious.

Next up was hand pulled noodles in beef noodle soup. This was an upscale take on the Beef Noodle Soup I get in Taipei. I liked the noodles, the broth was very tasty, the beef was cooked well and had proper amount of fat and they had bok chow with the soup. Not as good as the wild boar and cut noodles, but very good. 

We then had schwain green beans which were cooked perfect, still crispy but not raw at all and in a spicy but not too spicy sauce. As with the other items good size for the price, tasty, a winner.

I was full at this point, but we ordered dessert, when the food is so good I wanted to give them a chance with dessert. Ordered Hong Kong Egg puffs and got a big order of 5 puffs perfectly cooked served with raspberry coulis and hot chocolate and whipped cream. I never order dessert in Chinese place, but did here and really liked the dish.

Overall the food was great and the service and ambiance really nice. I saw a number of dishes on other tables that I want to try. I expected a good place and with Martin Yan's name associated I set my standards high for this place, but have to say they beat all my expectations. Definitely would recommend this place if looking for nice, slightly upscale Chinese.
author: Brad D.

description:
I was with a group of six and we ordered a lot of food. So, I got to taste a bunch of things. Mostly, I was not impressed with the price/value ratio. The food was for the most part just average good. The WIld Boar Scissor Cut Noodles being the standout dish. The deep fried spring rolls were greasy. The boar dumplings were OK. The vegetarian Longevity Noodle soup was very garlicky, so much so I couldn't taste much of anything else. Kung Pao chicken was boring and bland without any sauce at all. The Honey Glazed Shrimp were good. The Forbidden rice was really good. 

The service was uneven. Our waiter got waylaid taking the order from another table that was having a lot of indecision. We told one of the staff that we were ready to order and rather than send someone over, we were told we had to wait for our waiter. Not his fault at all, but usually someone will jump in to help out in situations like this. 

Empty dishes sat on our table for a long time, piling up as we finished each dish. After quite a while someone did come over and start clearing them away and from then on kept them cleared away. 

It was fun seeing the noodles being made and it really delighted the kids a the table next to us.
author: Scott R. D.

description: Concierge at hotel made our reservation so we were seated immediately upon arrival although I don't feel the reservation was necessary. Service was friendly but mediocre. We ordered wok seared beef, Yang Zhou fried rice, and stir fried baby bok choy. The wok seared beef arrived and we waited for our sides before we started. We waited and waited; at least 10 minutes. The beef got cold. Then the fried rice arrived...cold and lacking flavor. Five minutes after the rice, the bok choy arrived. It was flavorful but also cold. If you are not a fan of fish sauce, like my husband, you might not enjoy the bok choy. Maybe they over seasoned with the fish sauce? For $50 I would have liked to have had hot food presented at the same time. We will not return.
author: Carie W.

description: Service is not the best here... Especially during happy hour.  It is best to order everything at once.  The food and drinks are very inconsistent.  My first visit was good.  The frolic drink was yummy and so were those juicy dumplings.  The calamari is passable as they are big chunks rather than fried  squids (which I prefer .  The bang bang chicken wangs were not banging but some what just okay. Anyways, I thought the happy hour was decent so that following week, I went again and was disappointed. Everything was okay only.  My dumplings were not how I remembered the first time I had ate it.  I will give the establishment another try because we all have bad days...
author: Ann L.

description: The chef for whatever reason thought taking away the most popular dish, beef noodle soup, was a good idea?!  We plan to stop coming here until they bring back the beef noodle soup.
author: Alvin T.

description:
I have to say, without a doubt, this is the best Chinese/Cantonese cuisine you can have anywhere in the Bay Area.

You only need one word: Flavours!  M.Y. China delivers on that front in spades.

My cousin flew in and after nearly a full week of fancy eating (e.g.: Napa Valley right after the 6.0 quake, even) decided that she wanted to try Chinese.  After all San Francisco is a Chinese city too.  

Anyway I thought about where I could take her and honestly, within city limits, there was nothing that excited me.  But I thought to myself that maybe the novelty of that Martin Yan place could ease the painful fact that the Chinese food scene in SF is mostly embarrassingly bad restaurants.  In fact the Martin Yan brand was what prevented me from even trying it out when it first opened -- I thought it was all fancied up fake Chinese food (yeah, I've lived in the East Asia long enough to earn the snob points on food authenticity... so there!).  Heaven forgive me for being so wrong about staying away from M.Y. China for so long.

M.Y. China is not only authentic, it is how real Cantonese food should taste like.  Here is why:

We started with the Crispy Organic Tofu: beautiful silken texture within a golden crust that "grabs" on to the proper amount of seasoning with subtle hints of the jalapeno.

Beef Hand-Pulled Noodles Soup:  full of flavours. I know, another reviewer has found this too sweet but I think it's just by a touch.  The ribs were tender and moist, not jerky-like as in other establishments.  Most importantly the ribs were bursting with flavours.  The use of ribs here is a departure from the traditional cut used for this dish which is shanks -- beef shanks have a layer of silverskin that, if not removed, imparts a "offally" taste to the broth and many restaurants don't bother with removing it.  I understand, it's fiddly and labour intensive.  Which is why short ribs are a genius work around.  I, myself, use a chuck cut for this dish.

Venison Chow Fun: I cannot say enough about this one.  The "wok breath" shone through like nothing else.  This is a masterful, take-no-prisoner, artistic and technical tour de force.  The Fun retained the proper "pull", a texture hard to describe, you just have to try it, with the requisite smokey flavour accompanied by the also smokey crunch of the mung bean sprouts -- the sprouts were "kissed" by the very hot wok just enough.  The venison, almost a side note since the chow fun part was so spectacular, was tender and cut into small cubes.  Like the practice of Kung Fu, the wok "chi"/breath can only be wielded by a true Shifu (not that red panda in the cartoon but a true master).

Garlic Pea Shoots: the freshness comes through without being overpowered by the garlic (other restaurants doing this dish falls down on this dish in part for the still raw garlic flavour).  One can tell from the texture that it meets the "shoots" definition.  Shoots are "young", tender greens.  You don't necessarily get this level of tenderness at other restaurants serving this dish.  In addition, unlike many other restaurants that keep over-using the word "fresh"  (can't taste it... ) the Shifu/Chef actually let the freshness showcase itself in this dish.  You can actually taste that freshness.

Finally we finished our meal with the Lychee Panna Cotta: again, the flavour of the Lychee shone through both in the panna cotta itself and the granita sprinkled on top.  I don't know how the dessert chef managed to concentrate so much Lychee-ness into the Panna Cotta, it's more than just using chunks of the fruit.  It tastes as if the dish was somehow spritzed with a pure perfume of the Lychee essence.

Drinks: Tanqueray Martini extra dry, I emphasized "super extra dry" with a twist -- waitress thought I said Daiquiri Martini (what in the world is that?) is not bad but not chilled or dry enough but overall good enough.  A little stingy with the portion... I think.  I also had a glass of the  Gewrutzstraminer, Lafken 2011 (Chile) a little too sweet for my palate but a fine white to complement the meal anyway.

Note to bartender: try using a perfume spritzer bottle to spritz the vermouth (best to use Noilly Prat) on the outside of the martini glass.  Extra dry in my opinion is for olfactory enjoyment, not quite for gustatory enjoyment.  Also the lemon peel oil need to be squeezed out and rubbed on the rim a bit more.

Service: very courteous, just slightly understaffed, I think?  We had to remind a server for some request (I forgot what) once.

M.Y. China is a seriously good restaurant.  I haven't had such spectacular Chinese food (or other types of cuisine) in a long time.  While the dishes we ordered are considered street food in East Asia but they are street food done uncompromisingly properly.  Sometimes I think it's even difficult to find this level of care and technical flair in East Asia anymore.

Well done Martin Yan!  Well done M.Y. China.
author: Dave M.

description:
I was very excited to hear about this place opening to begin with! One night before meeting the bf before a movie and trying to decide where to eat, I was shopping at the Westfield and suggested this place. I walked in at 5:45 and asked about the wait and whether or not we needed a reservation. The hostess said that it should be about 1/2 hour which was perfect so I put my name down. A half an hour later, the bf shows up and  we wait for an additional 1/2 hour. 

We finally get in and we order the boars meat dumpling, Dan Dan noodles and shrimp w ginkgo nuts. Meh, sorry but they were nothing special.  Our waiter service was good though nice and the atmosphere was seemed kinda swanky.. for a mall. 

We might try it again but I didn't think it was anything special.
author: ThirtyTwo P.

description: The best Chinese food I have ever had. I go there occasionally. I am picky but this place gets a five star from me.
author: S S.

description:
Beautiful restaurant, solid service, and flavorful food, but my mapo tofu came out a little higher than room temperature twice.  The server said that maybe that was the temperature it was supposed to be...well, going to have to disagree with that theory. It should be served hot.  The dumplings were cold too. Maybe the food had been sitting at the pass too long because the restaurant was busy?

I grew up watching Martin Yan and have a lot of respect for him, but the restaurant sometimes falls short of his high standards. I've been three times and unfortunately, it's gotten worse each time.
author: Karthi X.

description:
Tasty but pricey, but you're paying for location and ambiance as well as food here.

Went with the bf on a Friday night around 8.  Restaurant was pretty full, but we were seated quickly.  

We had:

- pork dumplings with truffle:  delicious, however, didn't notice much of a truffle taste. Dumplings were juicy and delicious, but not sure that it was worth $18 for 5 dumplings.

- boar scissor cut noodles:  great noodle texture, and fun to see the guy cutting the noodles by hand behind the counter.  In a sauce that reminded me of chow fun, but done fancy.  The shape of the noodles reminded me of giant orzo.  A bit on the salty side;  we added some of the vinegar from the pork dumplings to lighten things up.

- pork belly sliders:  waiter lied when he told us the pork belly would have a nice crisp to them.  Felt like I was in an episode of Porklandia.  I kept asking in various different ways if the pork was crispy and not getting an answer.  Is it braised crispy?  Yes, it's braised. Finally I asked if there was skin on the pork, like pork cracklin's.  He looked mildly put off and said yes, it's got a nice crispness to it but not the full skin like a peking duck.  When we got the pork belly, we were sad that it didn't have that nice caramelized fatty crisp edge to it. 

All in all - I'd be back if I were in the area and craving pricey Chinese food (so not very often), or to see Martin Yan (if Yan can cook, so can you!)
author: Annie M.

description: Great special  spot for treating my auntie from out of town.  Very friendly and attentive staff.  Try the squid ink noodles and the honey walnut prawns with the Wasabi undertones.... It is really something different!
author: Patricia M.

description: This is my second try here. First, thanks Carol for this special arrangement. They are willing to take complains and make changes. Not much restaurant will do this. I really feel the service this time. Very good seating and no wait time for our reservation. Our server give very good recommendations. Once again,  the food was excellent.  Especially,  the lobster and lamb. The taste of lobster was very fresh and spicy. The lamb was juicy and the spices they put on was special.  Anyway this 2nd try did not disappoint me. I will definitely come back and recommend to my friends.
author: Sally C.

description: Great food and nice knowledgeable staff. Not many vegetarian options but the waiter knew the menu well and how to make something work. It doesn't seem like the healthiest food but it's all been delicious -- I started eating here before I became a vegetarian.
author: Dustin D.

description:
I was super-excited for this place. Living and working in close proximity, the more cool stuff they put in Westfield SF the better.

Tons of stars for service, ambiance, decor, location. Where they lose me is cost and taste. Of course being in downtown/Union Square/mall the prices will not be low. But for the cost, I expect "amazing, inventive, unique!" Which just wasn't there.

Don't get me wrong, everything tasted good but in San Francisco we are spoiled by the variety and abundance of great Asian/Dim Sum. 

Final thought: it's definitely worth one visit.

P.S. Hi Heather, thank you for your comments regarding my review. As I mentioned, the service, the ambiance etc. all got very good points from me, which is why I gave it 3 stars. I was talking up MY China before it opened as well as during the first few weeks to anyone who'd listen! 

When I was finally able to go myself, what was missing for me was the food factor. Everything was good. We had no complaints. But as I mentioned, Yank Sing probably has the "cloth napkins" dim sum tied up. And Chinatown has everything and anything in the 3-for-$1 category.

Bamboo on Polk has Honey Walnut Prawns for $12.95. MY China's dish was $22. Again, as I mentioned, because of the location, I understand things cost more. However, I expect that something extra or unique for the difference in price. The Rotunda at Neiman Marcus surely has the most expensive salads around, but it's exciting to go because they've made each meal a celebration with little baby cups of consommé and popovers with berry butter. It's their point of difference.

We tried a selection of dim sum, a noodle dish and the prawns. Came in under $100 (no drinks or dessert.) 

I talked up the place (ok, I begged for a month) and we're having a business lunch on Sunday 2/17, 2-4. If you see this message and can make some recommendations, I'd really appreciate it! Thank you, Alyssa
author: Alyssa P.

description:
My salad was pretty good, but overall I was not impressed.  

A couple friends and I ate here mid-Sunday afternoon, and the place was half full, if that.  We asked if we could sit at a booth-like table, and the host said they were expecting some larger parties, and seated us at a smaller table.  Which would be totally fine, except they seated another party of 3 there about 10 minutes later.  Okay.

The waiter came out and I asked what was gluten free on the menu, and he said "well this is an asian restaurant, so probably only salads".  This could have been true, but after making sure the chicken on my salad would not contain soy sauce, my friend (who is not gluten intolerant) got the exact same chicken.  So I don't really know if the salads were actually the only gluten free items on the menu, or if our server just didn't want to go ask about gf items.
Then my friend ordered kabocha soup, and the server "corrected" him, saying kabocha was pronounced like cabbage only KAbocha.  Since my friend lived in Japan for a couple of years, and I also speak Japanese, we tried to withhold our laughter until the waiter was out of earshot.

My salad was very tasty, but also very simple.  Chopped up lettuce, raisins, vinaigrette, and roasted chicken on top.

There's better food and service in the mall.
author: Liadan R.

description: Wow this place has gone down hill. Came for lunch and walked out due to horrible food. Sent back the soup 2 times because it was cold. Next, they served me cold wings and soup dumplings. Walked out. Enough is enough!
author: Kim K.

description: I went for happy hour and order all the menu (except fried beancurd). They are good. Unfortunately we don't like the table seating. We were seated on the high table next to the bar and share with other people. There were plenty tables inside but I guess its only for dinner. I might be back if I can have a sit inside. As long as I don't have to share with others (not comfortable).
author: Maria S.

description:
The first thought is, really? A great (non-chain) restaurant in a mall? It's true. The energy of the place is incredible with the open faced kitchen where you can see the many chefs preparing everything by hand. Martin Yan was entertaining a group the night we were there, complete with camera crew so we got to see something special. The head chef, Tony, is one of the top chefs from China and he is incredibly warm as well as incredibly talented. We watched him make hand pulled noodles blindfolded. If you've ever seen this done, it's already a feat using your sight.

Drinks:  Tasty and creative. There was a spicy drink called Fire in the Wok that I recommend if you want a little bite or something to fight off a cold. I enjoyed Under the Bronze Bell, a champagne drink mixed with ginger liquor and St. Germain Elderflower (and a touch of grenadine I think), named after the huge bell shipped from China that is now the centerpiece of the bar.

I'm actually giving 4.5 stars. Half star goes away for our server not telling us we'd ordered too much food for our table of 8 even after we specifically asked her to let us know if we ordered too much. For starters, we could have done without duplicates of the dishes. It didn't help that there was some confusion among our group as to what people were ordering. But having said that, our server and the rest of the staff were outstanding.

Now the upside to ordering all the food we had is that I can say there are SO many yummy things on the menu. 

Dumplings: Wild boar, pork & crab, seafood, all were outstanding. I'm a huge fan of DTF and am waiting for the day one opens in the south bay (please let it be soon). The first two are served in traditional steam baskets and dramatically served in individual soup spoons (careful, they're hot!) and a slice of carrot. Downside is the carrot doesn't cover the whole surface area so the dumplings still tear open. Upside is the spoon catches all the delicous broth from the dumpling so you can enjoy it with the chewy perfection that is the skin.

Avocado shrimp rolls: I could have skipped this one. Fresh ingredients but even with the peanut dipping sauce I was more interested in devouring other things.

Mu Shu tacos: Very generous helping for 2 tacos. Can easily feed 4 as an appetizer.

Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles: One of our favorites, highly recommended.

Dan Dan Noodles: Cold, so maybe not everyone is a fan, but these thinner noodles have lots of flavor and a little spice.

HK Crispy Noodles: You can't go wrong with crispy noodles. =) Very traditional and one of my childhood favorites, the noodles around the outside are crispy and then soft in the middle under the sauce and toppings.

Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp: This is delicious pretty much anywhere you go but these are great. Lightly glazed, not drowning in sauce.

Bok Choy: Simple, basic, and a good side that goes with everything.

Mapo Tofu: Great if you like silken tofu. Not so great if you prefer the texture of firmer tofu.

Forbidden Rice: You want to order it just for the name. But it doesn't disappoint. This was probably the dish that surprised everyone with all the flavor.

Two of our table had their own soup noodle dishes, the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup and the Vegetarian Longevity Noodle Soup. Both were a big hit and happily devoured.

Lastly, we received a very cool dessert made by Tony. It was a large plate of very fine noodles fried and covered in sugar, strawberry syrup, and berries. It may sound strange but it was so light and delicious. It was almost like Chinese cotton candy.

In general, because the menu can be a little confusing portion-wise, the noodle and wok dishes can easily feed a table of 4. Even some of the sides like the bok choy and mapo tofu can feed up to 6 unless you want a generous portion of those items and don't plan on sampling other things.

This is a little far for me to visit all the time but I will definitely be back!
author: Nicole T.

description:
I came here last night because I knew Martin would be in the house, and managed to rope a friend in. I was a tad worried because I hadn't made reservations ahead of time, but we were seated within 30 minutes, just as the hostess said! We sat right in front of the kitchen's giant glass window, and head chef Tony (and others) smiled and waved several times at us during the meal. SO much fun!!

We ordered the "Wealth" menu, because it just seemed like such a better deal than the less expensive "Prosperity" one. I, for one, am over shiu mais and har gows after eating them at dimsum for 11 years in LA. And the Green pepper ribeye and XO chicken crispy noodle also seemed too common for such an occasion. Anyway, on to the food we did eat!

Juicy Dumplings Sampler - WOW. Absolutely 5 stars for taste, presentation, the whole shebang. I love that each dumpling was served steamed in a color-coordinated spoon so there's no chance of breaking the skin when picking them up with chopsticks, which is often the case with shaolong baos, AND I exactly which one I'm eating!! I can't decide which is my favorite - crab or wild boar. The pork with black truffle was good but too heavy for me, but it was my friend's favorite.

Peking duck in lettuce cups - The meat is supposed to be juicy stir-fried, not dried out and have the texture of crunchy jerky meat. It was like they had a pile that stayed heated (hence dried out) somewhere and just sprinkled them in for each order. The crispy noodle bed was nice, not greasy tasting, but a bit too much padding and made it very difficult to eat neatly. I have never spilled stuff out of a lettuce cup before this one!

Seafood Treasury - Shrimps, scallops, etc. in a bird's nest. It looked great, as bird's nests usually do. The flavors were OK, just nothing too exciting. The server did bring us this awesome chili paste that went really well with the dish. Also, my friend previously hated scallops, but after trying this dish, she has discovered that she really likes them. We think she just had one that was really not fresh...

Stir-fried Longevity Noodle w/ Shredded BBQ Pork - By the name, I was expecting the hand-pulled super long noodles that MY China is famous for...or at the very least the "yi mien" that are served at Chinese birthday dinner banquets. Imagine my shock when a bowl of UDON came out!! I almost had to ask if we got the right food. Granted, the dish was actually good and really great with the chili. But...what the hell? And the Udon noodles weren't even that long!!!

**Update: Heather responded saying the noodles were indeed hand-pulled (see her reply below), but the server who brought out the dish was the one who called it "Stir-fry pork udon". 

Peking duck skin in sliders - I wonder if they messed up the order of the food (as listed on the menu it's the 2nd item), or if this was actually intended to come out last. I'm not sure whether I liked the duck already in steamed buns with cucumber and green onions, but they sure looked pretty! The skin wasn't crispy enough, and I think being served in buns was the main reason. It tasted good, no shortage of duck meat. But my friend is sensitive to fattiness, and had to spit out entire chunks of fat while eating. She still really liked them though.

Sugar Puff w/ Sauces - The puffs are huge, airy, and full of awesome. We even got an extra thrown in for free! The sauces are raspberry, chocolate fudge, and creme fraiche. Not a huge fan of the first 2, since raspberry anything is usually sour (probably would've loved the strawberry one if they had it) and chocolate too sweet/heavy. But a tiny bit of either/both and a chunk of creme on the puff? MMM!!!

Overall service was great. My friend even said it was the BEST service she ever had at a restaurant, and actually tipped a non-embarrassing amount!! (She's a very stingy tipper.........Yeah, I don't eat with her very often. Sigh.) 

The highlight of the evening was of course meeting Martin Yan, who was extremely friendly and came by our table at least 3 times. When we were getting the check, near closing time, Martin strode into the kitchen. He and Tony put on a giant show waving woks around, making huge fires, and just generally being awesome. We were SO happy we stayed and caught that!!! 

As it turned out, my friend also watched Yan Can Cook shows years ago with her daughter...like I did with my mother while living in Hong Kong! I hadn't told her M.Y. China was owned by Martin, so it was pretty much the best surprise ever (just wish it was her birthday LOL)!! She's telling everyone about the experience, and has her heart set on coming back next time Martin is in the house. I should definitely make reservations this time though ;)
author: Genevieve W.

description: Don't order beef pull noodle soup. It not made by hand pull, only made by machine, but charge is high.  When I found it today, they are still lying to me. Noodle is totally different thin by hand. Don't order roast duck. they will warm it with only oil fried again, not really fresh roasted. I have been taking Chinese food over 40 years. I am so disappointed about this restaurant because too many people............
author: Jerry L.

description:
The first time I went I thought oh! the dim sum is a bit pricey but the scissor cut wild boar noodles are great (and a good value). But after I left I couldn't stop thinking about the noodles.
I've been back two more times (and am going again today!) and had the noodles each time. I've also tried the beef noodles and they were excellent. The soups are great and we had some doughnuts for dessert one time that were really good.
I've brought friends there and they've gone back again and again. It's a great addition to the neighborhood and, well, kinda an addiction.
author: Margie L.

description:
7pm reservations on a Friday night and they were ready for us with no waiting.  Decent ambiance/trendy dining room.  Considering it's in Westfield, patrons were dressed and behaved nicely which was welcome.

Decent wine and cocktail options.  Started with the pork & crab juicy dumplings.  Good, but not over the top.  Entrees were the Hong Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken and the Wok Seared Beef Fillet.  Rice and beans were our two side dishes.  They were good, but nothing I'd go out of my way to eat again. Chose the Sugar Egg Puffs and Lemon Egg Tart for dessert.  Both were very good.

I would absolutely go back to explore more of the menu, but by no means was the experience anything I was talking about the next day.  My only real gripe was with the service.  Our entrees and sides were all served separately.  The rice fist, about 5 minutes later, the first entree, then another 5 minutes for the beans, and then about 5 minutes later the beef.  This made the dinner very clunky and nothing was the same temperature.  I don't know if this is normal or the server/kitchen screwed up.  All of us were very annoyed with our server.  The place is noisy and he mumbled and was very soft spoken.  It finally got to the point we were so tired of asking him to repeat himself that we just stopped asking anything.
author: Jeff M.

description: This is what I would call upscale Chinese American food. Don't get me wrong it tastes good but the price in the mall kind of pricey. I did love the egg rolls, and dim sum offerings. I will go back since my friends love it and I do want to try more but keep it in my price range. The service though is amazing they were so kind.
author: Nadia N.

description:
I went there last night with my wife. We had:

  Beijing  Knife Cut  Noodles
  Wok Tossed Shrimp With Ginko Nuts
  Salt & Pepper Calamari
  Stir Fried Green Beans

The food was good and beautifully prepared. The noodles were really good, with a tasty non-bland but non-overpowering hoisin sauce-based broth. The other dishes are ones that are available in most bay-area Chinese restaurants, but the preparation at M.Y. China seems to be better. The fried Calamari was perfectly not greasy and the beans were spicy but not so spicy that you couldn't taste the beans. The Ginko nuts and berries in the shrimp made a great combination.

So the food was good. Other aspects:

It was noisy and the tables were really close. It was hard to talk and everyone at the nearby tables were talking really loud to overcome the din. The *very* loud Christmas music from the mall just made the problem worse.

The portions were not large, but the prices were reasonable. We got out for about $50 plus tip and tax.

Remember, it's a Chinese restaurant in a shopping mall. It might in fact be the best Chinese restaurant in a mall anywhere but there's a limit on how good a mall restaurant can be. It's great food, but not elegant dining. If you set your expectations based on that, you'll see that it's a very good restaurant.
author: Bruce K.

description:
I came here for a staff lunch and it was very refreshing! I loved the decor of the restaurant and the wait staff was very nice, although could be more attentive. 

We had the M.Y. dim sum combo special (something like that) and I found it so awesome that they put the dumplings on little metal plates for the convenience of picking it up. Very clever. I didn't get to try all the dim sum in the combo, but I did try the siu mai and it was pretty solid. 

We also ordered the dan dan noodles, crispy noodles, and beijing knife cut noodles. The crispy noodles were good, nothing different from other places. I didn't try the dan dan noodles but I heard they were tasty. I was very interested in the knife cut noodles as I had some in Hong Kong and I haven't been able to find them here. I was disappointed because the texture was not as chewy as I'd like. However, the flavor was definitely there. 

My coworkers had the fried sesame cakes for dessert. I didn't get one because there wasn't enough to go around, but they all said it was delicious!
author: L M.

description: Food has a lot of thoughts specially the green spicy dumpling. The ambience is not okay if you somehow are seated outside.
author: Huan S.

description: In a mall but don't worry not in the food court. The sea bass and the dumplings were incredible. Excellent waiters, entertaining chef.
author: Jamshid A.

description:
Came here for lunch a couple days ago with one of my good friend. Let's just say that I usually don't like to go to these bougey Chinese places because I can definitely get great Chinese food for cheaper and without all the extra bells and whistles. But my friend said it was good so I said why not I'm always open to new places. Ordered the Siu Long Bao, har gau, Dan Dan mien and our waitress, who was super friendly, recommended the Mu Shu  pork tacos.

The things that we picked out were actually really good and on point on the texture and flavors. The har gau was actually pretty exceptional especially because it is such a dim sum staple and you don't expect it to be any better, but it was. The wrap wasn't too thick or rough and the shrimp mixture had the right texture and flavors. The Siu Long Baos were really good. That is something that I love to order when I go to get dim sum. This place can compare to a place I went to in H.K. The Dan Dan Mien was decent, lacking in the peanuty flavor than I love mix with the kick of the spiciness. The Mu Shu tacos did not do it for me, waitress was sweet to recommended but it felt too artificial for me...the sauce was too strong tasted like a lot of msg (?). But my friend liked it, so maybe I got the stronger flavored tasting one. Overall, it was a great experience and the food was good. I mean this place is by Martin Yan and he can cook. :)

With such an extensive menu, I would be willing to give this place a try if I was back at the mall to shop again and with more time. So until next time.
author: Fanny C.

description:
With Martin's name attached, my expectations of taste were definitely higher than the typical Chinese dive. We ordered:
1) Beijing knife cut noodles- my 5yo sums it up well..."they are too plain". When a dish consists of noodles and tofu, I want to be able to SEE the tofu, as in bigger chunks. These were smaller than the tiny bits such as in miso soup. The vinegarette needs more punch with such thick noodles. 
2) Braised short rib soup- OK. 
3) Sweet sour pork- loved the sauce, especially since it had fresh pineapple....bonus! Loved the crispiness of the pork chunks. 
4) wok fried green beans- great.
5) jasmine rice- was the smallest per person portion we have ever been served at a restaurant which serves rice! 

Here's the clincher- I couldn't be more annoyed with our server. It was like as soon as he walked up to the table it was a totally scripted acting gig of marketing the restaurant. I know who Martin Yan is, but multiple uses of "world renowned" in your intro just makes you look like an ass. Tell me your name, and maybe your favorite dish will help you to be more personable. I don't need a refill of my ice tea after only 2 sips. (Awkward). If the first person to service the table fills our water glass half full, great! But don't you show up 3 minutes later to introduce yourself and go around the table and fill each glass up to 3/4 full. (Awkward). I've been out of waiting tables since college, but my lord, I could go in and do a better job. Hostess staff? Very friendly, smiling, cheerful, great first impression!
author: Jodie S.

description: Not sure why the naysayers.  Do a little shopping, a lucky bhudda, crispy sweet wings
author: David C.

description:
Lunch:
Wild boar soup dumplings - The spoons that the dumplings were steamed in were too hot to pickup. Wrappers were thick and the bottom stuck to the spoon. Usually the use of a spoon is so that you don't lose the soup, but the spoons were way too big to fit in ones mouth. The flavor of the wild boar was just so so. It's terrible that they served with the sweet red vinegar instead of the traditional fragrant black vinegar. For an Asian fine dinning establishment, Hakkasan clearly has the much superior soup dumplings and with the service to match.

Beef noodle soup - extremely soggy spongy noodles, beef consists of mostly tendon and the broth was not tasty and sweet.

Whole wheat potstickers - Greasy and not crispy on the bottom at all.

Shrimp dumplings and Shiu Mai were average.

Dinner:
Pork and Truffle juice dumplings - Could not detect ANY truffle essences at all. $18 an order.

Wild boar lettuce cups - Extremely greasy, loaded with deep fried noodles. Very sweet and slightly fatty meat. When the lettuce cup was tilted, grease was running off of it. Not good...

Hong Kong crispy noodles with chicken - Very blend noodle dish and the chicken chunks were huge like nuggets. Any average Cantonese restaurant can make much better noodles than this for a lot less.

Five spice pork ribs - OMG... The huge ribs (looks almost like beef rib) were breaded and deep fried. Not falling off the bones at all.

Wok tossed shrimp with Ginkgo nuts - No flavors and the shrimp wasn't fresh.

Honey glazed BBQ pork - Very sweet and fatty. Again, you can get much better pork for a lot less at an average Cantonese place.

We will not return.
author: TopCat W.

description: I love this restaurant.  I have eaten at the bar three times and now once at the tables for a full meal.  Ink the food is fresh and exceptional. The small bites at happy hour are great.  I admit service at the bar depends on who is working but most of them are great!
author: Posey P.

description:
I came here a few weeks ago.  The food was not good.  It looked like PF Changs but the food was not as good.  The service was strange my server totally cool but then there was a woman that came by what seemed like every 5 minutes to check in and make sure every thing was good.  Totally necessary.

I'd go downstairs and have the food court options.  You will be happier.
author: Cristin C.

description:
I went back to M.Y. China this weekend to give the place a second shot.  After all, I had been looking forward to the opening forever, and the guys at Koi Palace make such great food.  My second experience was much better than my first.  This time we were seated in the back of the restaurant, which is just as lovely, though a bit more quiet than the front.  Our waiter was extremely attentive and very knowledgeable.  

This time we started with the spicy seafood dumpling.  This was by far the best dish of the meal, and we could not stop talking about it when we left.  The wrapper is green (on the menu it is described as a spinach wrapper) and inside are juicy bits of shrimp and scallop.  But the most innovative part was the tasty chili sauce, which was flavorful and caused your tongue to numb in the best way possible.  

We also had the knife cut noodles which tasted great, but were slightly overcooked.  I'm sure this is just the kitchen working out kinks, since they were slammed on a Saturday afternoon.  The hand pulled noodles in the beef soup were tasty, as were the General Mao chicken bites.  We also had the wok shrimp, and I really appreciated that the shrimp were not overcooked.  The only disappointing thing we ordered was the pork belly sliders.  And this may just be because the versions at Momofuku (in NY), Heaven's Dog, and the Chairman truck are so spectacular.  These were not quite as flavorful and seemed to be missing the luxurious mouth-feel that you would expect from pork belly.  

Ultimately M.Y. China is a beautiful restaurant, and the waitstaff was great on this last visit.  It's a solid option during a day of shopping, and its easy to forget that you are in a mall.  The prices are a bit on the high side, but if you stick with the small plates, and the dim sum options, you won't be disappointed.  

*3 and a half stars.
author: Dana H.

description:
Came here Sunday for lunch. It was pretty busy at 1:00 PM and waited about ten minutes. 

MY China does a pretty good job representing regional Chinese food. We ordered the beef pancake rolls, pan fried buns, and scissor noodles. All were pretty good. 

I thought that pancake rolls had way too much hoisin sauce (too sweet!), the pan fried buns were a little soggy (and also too sweet) and the scissor noodles were pretty good. 

Nicely done restaurant. Great feel, spacious, clean.

Service was fine. Portions were pretty good, prices reasonable.
author: Cindy Y.

description:
I really like this place - the ambiance and decor are super cute.
It was super fun to watch them hand make and pull their noodles.

Downside is that they don't have a lot of gluten-free options. I had the same thing both times i went because there wasn't much else, but the pork with the glaze, and the fried rice bowl, were both very good.

My vegetarian wife loved her food both times - had a veggie noodle bowl once, and a rice bowl another time. Our friends who are neither gf or vegetarian, also loved their food.  

Also, the martini i had was possibly the best martini i've ever had in my life.

Price wise, it is a bit on the expensive side for what you get.  i would go back if in the mall again, but probably wouldn't go to the mall just to go back.
author: Min M.

description:
I feel like i have to split this review into 2 parts

As a Chinese person from San Francisco, this place doesn't give you tea, portions are extremely small, no soup in the beginning, and the peking duck is served with tortillas instead of buns!  The food is subpar as well.  It literally costs twice as much as you would normally pay.  My mom wanted to go somewhere nice for her birthday, we should have gotten Italian or something.  There was no desert either.  

As an American, the service was good, and the ambiance was nice (whatever that means).  The food was arranged beautifully and we didn't get too full!
author: Andrew W.

description: My husband and I order delivery (via Caviar) from here often and its one of the only places where delivery tastes as good as the restaurant.  I highly recommend the scissor cut boar noodles, pan seared beef which is served on a bed of arugula, sweet and sour chicken and walnut prawns.  SO GOOD!!
author: Heather M.

description:
I like this place! Especially the following dishes:
-Wild boat scissor cut noodles
-Seven spice pork ribs 
- Chairman Mao Chicken
author: Danlu H.

description: My friend convinced me to try this place because he claims it's the best Chinese food he's had. He normally refuses to get Chinese food with me because he's not a fan so I figure I'd go for it. We've gone here twice within a month and ordered the same dishes both time - chicken wings, beef roll, wonton soup, and beef noodle soup. I thought the beef noodle soup was pretty good, but the chicken wings and beef roll were too flavorful whereas the wonton soup was really plain. It was pretty pricey too. I don't think I've ever paid ~$50 for Chinese food for two.
author: Amanda R.

description: Came here on SF Restaurant Week for USD 25 lunch, nice atmosphere, good service, good food, trendy, pricy.  Happy hour 3PM-6PM with food bites at USD 5 each.
author: George L.

description:
Pretty good food, but horrible service.

I stood for 5-10 minute and the host ignored me while he chatting with his friends. I tried to flag him down, but had to run after him when he escaped to a blind spot behind a wall that separated him from the main restaurant (!!) I literally watched him pace the mall instead of checking in on the diners.

It is a shame, because the food was actually pretty delectable, and the noodles excellent.  But the host looked 19 and was hostile and really gave off a "I REALLY don't care about your experience" vibe. My server was nice (once she arrived 10 minutes after I sat down in an empty dining room) and the guy who cleared the plates was nice. I think the service is either mismanaged or someone's son got a cushy job.

Fire him and fire a professional in his place, and I'll come back.
author: Loulou Z.

description: For this restaurant, I must start with the restroom.  It is designed the way a nice restroom should.  Beautiful black, orchids all around, thick napkins to dry your hands.  That's a 5.  Then there was the middle of my lunch fire drill.  Really?  All of a sudden the medal divider com sliding down the center of the dining room slashing out room in half, sirens blowing.  The saving grace was no sprinklers activated.  Yeah, not in the restaurants control but you should've at least fore warned us.  I'm sure the building gave you a heads up on it.  I had a ladies group luncheon with 10 ladies.  All of us were in disbelief.  That deserves a 1.  Now to the meat.  The food was good but not great.  Our bill was around $330.  Not too bad, but we had some pretty basic dishes.  The har gow was made with large shrimps, the forbidden rice was great, the shaken beef with arugula was sub par, and wild boar scissor cut noodles were no more than par.  Overall food was more like a 3.5.  Is it worth going?  Absolutely, It's no more expensive than other restaurants in the Westfield Shopping Center and it's better than PF Change Chinese.  Go for it.  If you want authentic Chinese, go to R & G Lounge.  Until next time, ciao!
author: Dee Dee L.

description:
Four of us had drinks and dinner at M. Y. China on Saturday, April 30th.  We had a reservation but were early and had a drink at the bar.  The drinks were very good, reasonably priced and the bartenders were funny and engaging.

We chose a table outside in the rotunda and despite having been warned by friends that it could be noisy out there, we found that was not the case.  Noise level was not a problem.  We started with Pork Juicy Dumplings and Crispy Organic Tofu, both of which were very good, with the tofu being excellent.  We had all the dishes family-style and went on to have Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles (very good), Wok Seared Seafood (excellent), Peking Roast Duck (outstanding!) and sides of steamed rice and Sichuan Green Beans.  They were all delicious, fresh and hot.  The Wok Seared Seafood was especially good, with a subtle and interesting flavor, not spicy, not bland.  The Peking Roast Duck was really excellent, the skin being perfectly crisped and the duck meat being perfectly moist, juicy and flavorful.  We did sample two deserts, the Sugar Egg Puffs and the house-made Candied Ginger Ice Cream.  I preferred the ice cream which was full-flavored and refreshing.

The wine list is eclectic and interesting.

Service was provided by Cedric, a true professional waiter.  This being our first visit, he took us through the rather extensive menu and made some suggestions which turned out to be winners.  Service was prompt, efficient and friendly.  Cedric seemed to really take an interest in his work and was not merely going through the motions.  Thank you Cedric!  You added to our enjoyment of the meal.

We lingered a bit at the table and did not feel rushed at any time.  M. Y. China is a bit more expensive than the average Chinese restaurant, but it is very much worth it.
author: John G.

description: What a disappointment. It was nothing special, except the noodles. I should have stayed in Castro Valley and gone to Hong King BBQ.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Touristy. Tasty. Well worth it. 
Cocktails were excellent. Servers were OK altho a bit rushed. Beef rolls, beef filet, roast chicken, sea bass, several vegetables, forbidden rice were all excellent. Noodles with wild boar were delicious but weren't that much better than other Chinese fried noodles. Only real miss was an odd appetizer of pickles. It's a convenient location and a large place with good turnover so seating isn't a problem.  This is good dependable food that may not be super authentic, but is a crowd pleaser.
author: Al M.

description:
I've been want to try this place since it opened and finally got around to doing so on a date.  I think the current 3.5 star average is exactly what I would've given it.

Ordered
Grandma's Gai Lan (w/ Chinese Sausage)
Poached Asian Pear Salad
Lobster w/ Scissor Cut Noodles (substituting chow fun for my gluten free date)
Lychee Panna Cotta

What's there to say about this?  Well, the food quality/taste of what we ordered was damn good.  Like within range of Chinatown restaurant quality.  More authentic than P.F. Chang's   (since that is technically fusion).  Better quality than Panda Express (ok, that's a low bar to clear).  It was also as expensive as both of those places combined, but that was to be expected.  The serving sizes were plenty generous (we had leftovers of everything except the dessert).  I would've liked more sausage in the Gai Lan, but that's minor (and I really like Chinese Sausage).  The Asian pears - delicious (I didn't have much of the salad).   The lobster, also scrumptious, and cooked/cut in a way that much of the lobster was easy to extract from its carapace.  Finally, the Lychee panna cotta was inspiring, in that I want to make it for myself now (or a variation that has lychee bits in almond jello).  I was tempted to order the Honey Walnut Prawns, but $22 for it seemed excessive.



So ..
Food quality/taste - 4.5/5
Food portions - 4/5
Price - 3/5 (ouch!  Thankfully it's not too often I run up a $100+ bill between two people, especially for Chinese food)
Ambiance 4/5 - We were seated at the bar and the bartender was extremely friendly.

If it was at the same pricing as P.F. Chang's, the comparison between the two would be no contest.  As is, the pricing is just enough to push this into a category where I'd eat here once or twice a year.  However, the food is pretty close to legit, as I would expect from a Martin Yan inspired restaurant.  If you're at Westfield and looking for something fancy/posh, this would hit the spot.  If you're in SF and looking for bang for your buck, Chinatown has comparable options for less.
author: Wesley C.

description: Fish noodles were a scam. No taste or texture of fish whatsoever, unlike real fish noodles (like at Grace Garden in Odenton MD). That the famous Martin Yan, supposedly a noodle master, would allow fish noodles that are indistinguishable from spaghetti to leave his kitchen is a disgrace. Xiao long bao / juicy dumplings also stuck to the spoons and broke apart as soon as you try to lift the soup dumplings off the spoon. Cheaper and far better soup dumplings at Yank sing a few blocks away.
author: H S.

description: From the moment you approach this restaurant, you hope that this is going to be a unique experience and you do not leave disappointed!!  The menu is varied and everything we tried was flavorful and beyond delightful. Dim Sum at its finest! And every dessert was absolutely wonderful. The cocktails were different and refreshing. The decor of the place is classy, sophisticated, upscale and unique and watching the kitchen and prep added to the overall experience tremendously. The six of us in our party will highly recommend this as a San Francisco visit must!  Coming back two days later only added to the experience.  We had to taste the Forbidden Rice again and the Walnut Shrimp plus several desserts!  Love this place!!
author: Vicky D.

description:
Best Dim Sum next to 4-5 star Chinese hotels in Asia. Having lived and worked in Asia and big an of Chinese food I have yet to seek a good dim sum in SF, LA or NY. Okay the price is on the pricey side, but it is authentic quality dim sum. I live in SOMA so it's about a 15 min walk to the mall. 

Had ordered pork buns, siu mai, har gow, braised beef noodle with fresh pulled noodles, and the best in the US was their roasted Peking duck! I am sooo in love makes my mouth water! We told our waiter it was the best next thing to eating in Asia! I am from Bangkok and have dined at best Chinese restaurants and I have old my husband, finally somewhere eat other than the other places in sf but we have no other options SUCH as the following: Canton frozen bland, Koi Palace oily oily, the places in Millbrae crowded rude obnoxious crowd, RJ Lounge for their over priced  greasy crab, seamless web Chinese delivery, Yank Sing -this is hat we called Americanized overpriced dim sum....etc.....

Those of you who have written negative reviews either have not dined in authentic dim sum houses made by world class chefs or are use to eating in dumps for cheap prices....you get what you pay for

Update: Jan 2013 got to meet Mr Yan.....great guy.....staff in front of house ------who hires them? Rude and unattractive.....they should be working t McDonalds
author: Diana S.

description:
We basically liked 3 out of 5 items that we had here.  The green papaya salad was nothing compared to the one at Out the Door.  The Mu Shu tacos were good.  The kung pao chicken was nothing to write home about.  The scallops were good.  The Sunday rice bowl dessert was good.  Maybe we need to try other things.  

We  would go here again if we can get a reservation because it is near the theaters, but would not make a special trip.
author: Alan B.

description: Ordered from here via Caviar.  Food was inedible.  Smelled/tasted like a dead fish (I ordered chicken).  Even the cat tried to bury it under a paper towel.  Horrible...waiting for the food poisoning to kick in after the two bites I forced myself to try.  Major screw up Caviar for having this restaurant on your list!
author: Rachel D.

description: Between my last review I've been to M.Y. a number of times.  However, I didn't want to write another review until I considered something worth reviewing. Remember, I said the "best of the best."  I finally made it to the wok seared beef. I accompanied that dish with just a bowl of plain rice, because frankly, I couldn't determine what would pair nicely with the  beef (Carol can probably make some recommendations). It was good, however. An easy 4.5 stars. I then tried the mu shu pork tacos. The ingredients in the tacos were light and very tasteful, at least to my palate. However, I couldn't help thinking the ingredients in the taco would have worked better with shrimp instead of pork. The next time I order that dish, I will request a shrimp substitute. Again an easy 4.5 stars, but I'm rounding it off to 5.
author: Anthony W.

description:
