Came here for a small lunch around 4 waiting for my friend too get off work. I had read the yelp reviews and decided I should just try it for my self. So I had the potstickers and the calamari. I can sum the trip up in 2 words, "expensive" and "bland". These 2 dishes plus a regular Tsingtao beer totaled about $23! Seriously? For a beer and 2 starters that were pretty small, they had another beer here as well for $12, I literally blinked several times too see if I was seeing things. So here were my thoughts about the food and service though.

Service (this only goes for the bar, I have not ate at the regular dinning room!):

Pretty good, bartender was chill, nice, and pretty upbeat for how dead it was

Food:
Now I have only tried 2 dishes from the bar menu, but it was a huge disappointment, here is what I had...

Salt and Pepper Calamari $8
 - Not a bad price point at 1st, but once you bite into your 1st bite, you see why. Calamari was wayyyyyyyyy too chewy, seasoning you think would taste like salt and pepper right? WRONG! The seasoning had a kick, but a bland taste of nothing. Literally tasted the chili, fried batter, and the squid, but no salt or pepper at all! This was a huge disappointment and needs a major revamp! 

Whole Wheat Potstickers 5 for $7
 -These were just weird. I like the idea of a healthier alternative pot-sticker but damn, these SUCK! Probably one of the weirdest tastes I have ever tasted, it made me use the sauce the give on the side just too finish them and changed the flavor profile completely!


Overal from my brief experience with My China I may give it a chance, but not until the reviews start too reflect the food a lot better and/ or what Micheal Bauer thinks of this place...gotta wait and see.
author: Brannon T.

description:
Very nice modern decor, which was my favorite part of dining here. Food is made of high quality ingredients but is not traditional Chinese. For example, the honey walnut shrimp is unlike anything I ever tasted. Infused with the odd flavor of cucumbers and wasabi. A bit too unconventional for me as I was craving traditional Chinese. However I was pleased with the crispy noodle chicken dish.

My main complaint was the wait time and procedures. We were told 20 minutes but it ended up being one hour. What made it worse was that they have a terrible system in which they make you stand in the doorway, physically waiting in line, as there is no "wait list". My family of 4 had to stand there mercilessly watching people eat for way longer than we expected. My kids were practically in tears. Could you at least add benches to sit on, if you are going to make people wait in line? I have never had to deal with such an unnecessary inconvenience before.
author: K S.

description: I remember as a child I would see Martin on TV.  I decided to try a couple of items off their menu.  My meal was pretty good so I decided to host a business meeting on the 17th of February.  However I just read a review by one of my collegue and she gave you a 3 star.  She said to me if we can have a meeting at your location she would be so happy.  So here's looking at an awesome meal with great feedback.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Wow. My husband and I were so excited to try out Martin Yan's restaurant. I'll admit we were a bit unsure once we realized it was inside a mall but a soon as we were seated you would have no idea. 

Service here was great. We got an awesome explanation about a bunch of items we asked about on the menu plus some of the fun art around the restaurant. We shared a bunch of plates and we weren't disappointed AT all. 

The chicken wings were outstanding. Seriously awesome flavor with some heat. SO good. 

The pork dumplings were so tasty and the presentation was great...each dumpling served on their own spoon. Yum. 

Mu Shu Pork Tacos were amazing. Seriously. I'm drooling writing about them. Mu Shu flavor in a taco formation with some added crunch. If I could get an order of these right now I'd die a happy girl. 

We shared the Beef Hand Pulled Noodles and I was a bit sure about them because of the star anise which I am not usually a fan of but these were awesome. I can't even describe the noodles they were so delicious. It was so fun to watch them being pulled. If we'd had room I would have ordered the scissor cut noodles. 

We also shared a bottle of prosecco and skipped dessert or else someone would have had to rollllllllllllll me out of there. Leaving a restaurant with food this delicious and a bottle of booze for under $100 blew me away (that of course included a very nice tip.) 

If you're going to SF or live there and don't know about this place or are hesitant to try it don't be! Get your butt in there!
author: Michelle S.

description:
We came here a week ago. He raved about this place, and since I trust his Foodie-judgement I was willing to eat in the mall. Definitely not your typical mall-type restaurant. It's a great location before catching a movie. 
It wasn't that busy when we arrived on a Thur night, but perhaps this is more a tourist spot. He was a bit disappointed, because apparently it has always been packed when he has dined here. It didn't matter to me, I was tired and really wasn't in the mood for a crowded dining area. 
He did all the ordering as usual... And everything was delicious. Crab-shrimp dim sum was my favorite! But the crispy noodles with chicken and some other fresh noodles was pretty tasty too. All in all a healthier Chinese (mall-genre) restaurant... not too salty and not greasy. I didn't get to see this, but if one dines by the noodle bar, you can watch them make the fresh noodles.
author: Myra M.

description: Nice ambience. Good food and even better service. I am a fan.
author: John T.

description:
M.Y. China may be the only Chinese restaurant that serves delicious cocktails, but the food isn't as good as the posh decor. It's a great option if you don't want to eat a the typical dingy Chinese eatery, but you will be paying the price!

Today's experience at MY china was quite a mess. It was a while before our server noticed we didn't have any menus. We did not get any napkins until after our food was served. We had to ask for water and dipping sauces several times. 

My rating is based on food and not service.
author: Jeanne C.

description: GREAT PLACE!!  recommended to us by the concierge at the hotel.  He did not disappoint!  My wife and I say at the hot bar so we could watch the WOK chefs.  Great happy hour drink specials. We got the 1/2 duck and wild boar noodles.  Did not disappoint!!
author: Brad M.

description:
Mall Chinese in San Francisco is probably one of the few places on earth where that's acceptable. Such is the depth of tasty Chinese cuisine in San Francisco that you don't feel like a mook for eating exotic dishes from the Far East at a place normally reserved for broody teenagers.

The scissor-cut noodles were a delight and so was every appetizer, and by that I mean virtually every dumpling on the menu, our large group tried. I think the service was a little slow, I would have liked to have more than one drink through my meal but I suppose serving a table of 12 near the end of service is understandable.
author: Andre L.

description:
Eh. Modern Asian cuisine at bloated prices. Granted, we do have to pay for the expertise, quality ingredients and upscale decor.  

Sugar egg puffs - glorified with fancy sauces and cream. Funny, the waiter gave me a spoon to eat this with.

Whole wheat potstickers (5) - beautiful and even scalloped edges. Tastes like a regular potsticker but the skin has more texture. Accompanied by a spicy soy sauce.

Shandong beef rolls (2 and cut into halves)- quite tasty and not dry because of an ample amount of hoisin sauce. The green onion pancake has a pleasing texture that is easy to bite into.

Wild boar scissor cut noodles - Nice flavors and textures and you can see the skill in the making of the noodles. 

Dan dan noodles - this was overly spicy for some reason. May be inconsistent because my friend said it was rather bland the last time she ordered it.  I like that there weren't too many peanuts and no peanut sauce flavor...personal preference. Still had a good flavor profile despite the spiciness.

Pork and black truffle juicy dumplings (5)- (otherwise known as xiao long bao XLB) rather disappointing. Sharp presentation with each dumpling resting in a large soup spoon.  Genius because you could just eat it off the spoon, IF it weren't for the fact that the spoon is scalding hot.  There is also a thin slice of carrot underneath the dumpling to separate it from the spoon, but that didn't seem to prevent the skin from sticking to the spoon and tearing upon consumption. In terms of taste, it was just average...  definitely had better xlb with less extravagant ingredients.

At my table of 4, I had the honor of eating the 5th and last dumpling. After the first bite, I noticed a little something sticking out of the meat. Out of curiosity, I pulled it...and pulled it... and pulled it... and it turns out it was a hair.  Major sad face because why is hair usually found in food AFTER most of it is consumed? Well at least it has been in my experience.  We called a manager over and showed him.  His face immediately turned grim and sullen, he took away the remainder of the dish and left promptly.  We saw him talking to one of the kitchen workers; one of the perks of an open kitchen, we customers can see most of what's going on. He came back to our table and told us he ordered another 3 pork and black truffle dumplings on the house for us.  Very odd arrangement, but we really weren't expecting anything since we ate the majority of the dish already. We didn't really want the extra 3 dumplings either since we were getting full already.  Just glad that he took action and wasn't aloof about it.

Towards the end of our meal, a chef came out dancing around the dining area to perform noodle pulling to the Gangnam Style song.  Definitely cool. Seems to happen on a timely basis.

Have a chuckle while reading menu the with its puns and clever wordplay.
author: Renee L.

description:
Nice setting, nice servers. Surprisingly meh food. Spicy seafood dumpings in some kind of chili oil seemed more like seafood ravioli (thick, pasta-like wrappers) in spicy ketchup. The server said that we might want to save that sauce to season the other dishes. My date and I looked at each other, like, "Has this guy actually tasted this sauce?" Blah. The green beans were fairly flavorless. Wild boar lettuce cups were nice, but I've made that recipe at home (with chicken)--that recipe is hard to screw up. And the Dang Dang Noodles tasted like something someone might throw together for a potluck picnic with a julienned cucumber, a handful of ground meat, and splashes of whatever Asian sauces they have on hand.

I hate to hate, but I think one of the other reviewers summed it up best: "Are they tasting the food before it leaves the kitchen?" In this most Asian of American cities, and with so many kick-ass Asian restaurants (fusion and traditional), a place with this high of a profile should be serving food several quality levels of magnitude higher.
author: M Z.

description: One of my favorite places in SF. Authentic Chinese food with great ambiance and service. Been here a couple times, and very happy with each visit. Very accommodating to kids by providing food recommendations and crayons. More expensive compared to cheaper Chinese restaurants, but you'll get better dining experience at M.Y. China. Some reviewers have compared this place to PF Changs, which is not as authentic and about the same price. I highly recommend the noodles dishes.
author: Mike L.

description: I had my birthday dinner on Tuesday the 8th, and was excited to try their hand pulled noodles. My friend helped reserve a table for 15. The interior is gorgeous. I like the way they have a separate bar, main dining area, and a dining area facing the kitchen. I began with a vodka infused chrysanthemum cocktail, which was amazing. It was refreshing and strong, a total creeper drink. The memorable dishes were the spareribs, mushu-style duck, and beef noodles. I loved how soft the rib meat was and accented with red and green peppers. The mushu-style pork was excellent, although lacking in meat, I liked the sliced chives and the black bean sauce. Finally the beef noodles were the same authentic flavor I recall eating in Shanghai. It had a "herbally" flavor from the star anise, but youll have to try to understand what I mean. Service was nice, although the servers kept asking which side of the table ordered what dish. Even with a large party, I would hope a high caliber spot would have figured it out. I did appreciate the complimentary green onion fried pancake. Reasonable pricing from my quick peek at the receipt. I'd come back for lunch, date or happy hour.
author: Thomas L.

description: My goodness this place is great! While taking a break from shopping we decided to have a couple of cocktails and appetizers here during happy hour. My cocktail of choice was the Frolic--it's delicious, so I had two. My appetizers: the Calamari and the Pork Bao. The Calamari tasted fresh, was spicy, and breaded well for slight crunch--I'm a fan and wouldn't mind a whole meal made up of this calamari. The Pork Bao appetizer is served in a steam basket, each in it's own large porcelain soup spoon with broth. They tasted very good but reminded me more of steamed wontons than pork bao. Because the atmosphere was fun and the appetizers and drinks were good we decided to order a dish of the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles. It was the perfect noodle dish for us. I will pay M.Y. China a visit every time I'm here shopping.
author: Lola B.

description: Their happy hour menu is a great deal!! I highly recommend the Hemingway Daiquiri and Buddha Breeze--both are very refreshing!
author: Carmen A.

description:
I came here for a company dinner and first impressions are everything. We were greeted by a rude hostess who had no personality and was very unwelcoming! Luckily, we didn't have to deal with her for long after we were seated.

In regards to the food it was good. The usual small portions and over priced food you can expect from a "fancy" restaurant. The waiters were professional and accomodating. We didn't have to wait long for our food as everything was pre-ordered ahead of time.

The restaurant is pretty big, but does get packed so I would plan accordingly if you don't have reservations. Overall, it was a so so experience. I'd eat here if someone wanted to eat here, but wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Albert C.

description: Great Chinese. Fabulous Atmosphere. Hostess... Rude. Worst place to have a person greet people into your restaurant with ATTITUDE. Not feeling her vibe. Long Day? Take a break. Don't show me how your day is going! Really. I WANT to enjoy my dinner.
author: Zee R.

description:
Trendy place you would not expect inside a Westfield mall. Very nicely decorated inside: upscale and spacious. Buddhas everywhere.

We came in just to order the Peking duck. It was around $35 for a whole duck. But being Chinese, we noticed that it didn't look like a full duck. There were also abnormally large amounts of fat on the duck pieces. The dish came with many buns, so that was good.

The pork noodles were pretty good. Overall, way better than PF Chang's, easy to make a reservation last minute, not crazy pricey.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Atmosphere was pleasurable. The mai tai was delicious. The food was lackluster and after all it is a restaurant and it's all about food, therefore two stars.
author: John A.

description: The scissor cut noodles and steamed buns are my favorite items on the menu. Also can't go wrong with the cod fried rice or standard Kung Pow chicken. Really like what they have done ambiance wise to create an upper-mid range Chinese restaurant that feels accessible. Also, I love the dome under Westfield!
author: Milan T.

description: Good thing I took BART because it wasn't worth paying SF parking rates for. Dumplings in individual soup spoons were good and the green beans were done well. Crispy chicken was good enough. The lobster with the noodles was a disappointment. Few strands of fat chewy hand-pulled noodles that was neither here nor there. Sauce was the sweet kind and for the first time had whole string beans paired with lobster.  We felt it was more of a filler. Parts of the lobster was firm but others were mushy as if they came from a different lobster that was less fresh. Altogether it was okay, but for the money we could have eaten better for less elsewhere. Unless someone else is buying I won't be back.
author: Nancy T.

description:
My wife and I have always been fans of Martin Yan's cookbooks and shows, so we were quite excited when we came upon his M Y China restaurant while visiting San Francisco last week.  We arrived fairly late in the evening and while the restaurant was still quite busy, had no problem getting a table. The decor is elegant, yet casual enough for a couple of tourists returning from a long day at Fisherman's Wharf.

For dinner, we ordered the Squid Ink Snap Noodles, Five (Seven?) Spice Pork Ribs and Yang Zhou Fried Rice.  The noodles were delicious and probably the highlight of the meal.  The black noodles were visually striking and accompanied by a assortment of seafood - very tasty.  The pork ribs were a delightful surprise featuring a light, crisp, well seasoned outer crust and very tender meat.  The fried rice was a bit of a disappointment in the context of the other two dishes - okay but nothing special and maybe lacking a little in seasoning.  Next time we would probably just go with the steamed jasmine rice.

For dessert, we enjoyed the Almond Rice(?) ice cream and the Sugar Egg Puffs.  Both were excellent. We weren't sure about the puffs when we first saw them on the menu but they were delicious!

We had a hard time choosing between 4 and 5 stars for this review only because the fried rice fell a little short of expectation - I would do 4.5 stars if I could.  The service however was excellent and our server (Sarina) deserves a full 5 stars.

We expect to be back in the Bay area again in the near future and hope to pay M Y China another visit!
author: R C.

description: Do not get the crispy noodle unless you want something so bland it is like washing your mouth with water over and over again. I dont remember it being this bad the last time I had it. This is a horrible and unqualified rendition of the dish. You are warned. The tapas and happy hour is ok.
author: Mary H.

description:
Conveniently located on the very tippy top of the mall you can totally burn some eating calories by shopping before or after.  I met some of my girl friends here for Sunday brunch and for most of us it was our first time.  I heard their food is made from the same place as Koi Palace so it was good without the hour long wait.    Their bloody mary's are made with fish sauce so I had to try it.  I'm glad I did but I will not order it again if I ever came back.  

They didn't have scissors to cut up the dim sum dishes when there was an odd amount for our group of 5.   This would automatically done elsewhere at a real dim sum place.  

I loved the decor, I enjoyed the food, noise level was almost too high sitting outside, (imagine eating in Caesar's Forum in Vegas but not as bad).  I would come back if I was in the area craving dim sum but otherwise I wouldn't bother.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Pleasantly surprised!  It's always dangerous doing "upscale" Chinese food in a town full of people who know what authentic Chinese food tastes like, but all in all, M.Y. China did a good job.  The decor is very nice and classy, especially in contrast to the bleak 70s-era decor of most Chinese restaurants.  The menu is thankfully short with clear English explanations--no "secret menu" written in cryptic Chinese and tacked to the walls.  The food was relatively authentic and all of it was pretty good.  My favorite was the braised beef soup with hand-pulled noodles, which was possibly the best version of this dish I've ever had.  The Peking Duck was also good, though I've had much better.  And the cocktail menu is quite nice.  (Their take on a Pimm's Cup is particularly yummy.)

The service could be improved, but was not so bad that it hurt the meal.  My waiter was a little slow to bring us items we requested.  I had to ask for white rice three times, and our water carafes were empty after 10 minutes and were never refilled.  We also never got our pea shoots order (though I didn't even notice until long after we had left, so I couldn't complain.)  Our waiter wasn't rude, though he was far from charming, and I saw flashes of annoyance in his face whenever I asked for something.  I try very hard to be a courteous diner, so this definitely rubbed me the wrong way.

The prices are a good 30-50% higher than a comparable Chinese restaurant in the Richmond or Chinatown, so I would never bring my grandparents here (I can already hear my grandma "aiya"ing about the $15 bowl of noodles).  Foodies seeking the most authentic steamed fish or xiaolongbao should also probably look elsewhere.  But minor service issues aside, I'd recommend MY China for a clean, upscale, classy environment that's accessible to "Westerners", (mostly) authentic Chinese food, and a solid cocktail.
author: Matt Y.

description: 20 minute wait on Saturday night, without reservation, not bad and allowed for some shopping. Great ambience.  Fast service. Food was mostly predictable. Kung Pao chicken was a good presentation, not too spicy and tasty veggies.
author: Chris C.

description:
i was pleasantly surprised!  usually i don't eat "fancy" chinese food, but last night i went to see martin yan at the commonwealth club, so we decided to come here for dinner after.

we shared the spicy seafood dumplings, wok fried beef, scissor cut noodles w/ wild boar, baby bok choy, and scallop fried rice.  for 3 of us, that was the perfect amount of food.  i liked the arugula w/ the beef, which made it lighter.  the sauce that came w/ the dumplings was also perfect to drizzle on the bok choy and rice.

martin yan actually came here for dinner also and recognized us from the talk.  he came by and chatted w/ us a bit.  he's just as friendly in person as he looks on tv!
author: Helen T.

description:
M. Y. China ... kinda reminds you of P. F. Chang, right?  Silly puns.  Besides the similarities in puns, the decor in M.Y. China is very similar to P.F. Chang as well.  I'd also like to say that it is quite similar to the structure of the menu and drinks as well.

But remember this:  this place is not a Chinese restaurant; it just happens to serve Chinese food.

That said, the food was fine.  I ordered some dim sum along with the squid ink seafood noodles, which ended up being pretty tasty.  The drinks aren't all that to write about, though I had some interest in their concoction of a bloody mary that also contains fish sauce.  Yeah.

Overall, this place is pretty decent, but don't expect anything great coming out of M.Y. China.  Unless of course, Martin Yan comes out of the woodwork to cook my food.
author: Ren L.

description:
A modern, fresh and delicious take on Chinese food. I've been here several times for lunch, dinner & drinks/bar food. Each time has been awesome. 

Today I went for lunch and was delighted to get to meet Martin Yan! He was so humble and friendly. He was walking around chatting with every table, meeting his customers, taking pictures and making sure everyone was enjoying themselves! 

Great experience, good food.
author: Kate C.

description:
Worst dining experience ever! 

One they took a very long time to ask us our beverage of choice. I only wanted water they brought everyone their drinks but mine. We had to wave down our waiter ; which I find that very tacky and should never have to do it! We did that probably 4-5 times trough out the whole night. 

We all got our meals the food was very tasty. I was still waiting for one item. Which I NEVER got. I asked him and he forgot to "write it down" or obviously didn't listen when I ordered it. 10min later I'm still waiting he comes back and asks if I still want them. In my head I'm like are you freaking kidding me!!! Obviously I do. At this point I just say no! Everyone is done eating and I had totally lost my appetite with this horrid service. 

I am leavening sooo bummed out. I really wanted the Wild Bore Wrap. I read such good reviews about everything. I just happened to luck out! As I am writing this review we are still waiting to get our change back and it has been about 10min. And it's not busy at all! 

I didn't even get to enjoy my food.
author: Itzel M.

description:
Happy to hear that this new addition to the Westfield mall is finally here, however, It left me somewhat, underwhelmed.

The vegetarian slider buns were yummy but a bit pricey for only 3 pieces. The pineapple fried rice was also worth trying. The not-so-good included: wonton soup, green beans, and the lobster & crab dumplings. 

The servers were very attentive. The look of M.Y. China was very sleek and modern, with intimate lighting- great for groups and fun date nights.
author: C M.

description: I know, you wouldn't expect a place like this to be good because you're thinking "EXPENSIVE CHINESE FOOD?!?! THAT'S FOR PEOPLE WHO AREN'T CHINESE!" Well, this place is pretty good for a fancy Chinese restaurant in a mall. I go here pretty often and I always get the hot and sour soup and wild boar scissor cut noodles. Those are my two favorite things to order because the soup doesn't make me feel sick after, like take out soup, and I love hand drawn noodles. This place is a bit pricey but worth it due to the quality of their dishes. Service is a hit or miss. The ambiance is pretty neat and it's cool to have a view of the kitchen. This is Chinese food that everybody will enjoy, unless you're a cheapo.
author: Yuxuan N.

description:
SImply put.. you can find better food for cheaper at select food trucks (Chairman Bao) and Chinatown restaurants.

Pork belly sliders - small and not flavorful
Wild boar lettuce cups - good but not great
MY Dim Sum collection - the highlight of the meal - solid presentation and assortment
Calimari - overdone not flavorful but the cuts were nice 
Egg Tarts - shamefully small and unflavorful

I wanted to like this a lot and it is in a great location but just once is fine for me.
author: C K.

description: We walked in for lunch and they took us right away, the ambiance and the food are great, we ordered the seafood noodles , dim sum and the beef from the wok menu , we felt rushed they brought everything at the same time , we will go back.
author: Johnny A.

description: It might not be your typical Chinese restaurant, but the service is top notched. No hidden cost and the order delivered quickly. I and my two gal pals had a good time. The serving size is  not big but it can fill you up. I loved the stir fried bok choy. The hot and sour soup was good.  The place is spacious and you can carry a conversation quite easily.
author: Wing W.

description:
MY China in the Westfield Mall is pretty new and is still working out some kinks.  The fact that it is in and open to the mall tells you something about what your meal will be like.  Lots of foot traffic, noise and distractions.  And during the meal you may see Martin Yan walking through the restaurant showing off one of his noodle pullers.  The noodles are twirled around like a lariat and it is fun to see.  Too bad it is hard to hear Mr. Yan describe the spectacle: he needs a microphone.  

To start, they need to do some work at the reception desk, as there is confusion, clusters of people, and little guidance.  Whatever, you will get to your table. 

I started with wild boar scissor cut noodles.  This was an ample plating of tasty, al dente noodles interspersed with meat.  Unfortunately, the spicing in the dish masked the taste of the meat.  Nevertheless, this was a good beginning to my meal.

Next, a half order of Peking duck.  The duck skin was crisp and the meat of the duck was served on the side.  The skin was not quite so crisp as I have had elsewhere and the meat was haphazardly cut with a some stray fat accompanying the duck.  Nevertheless, this was also pretty well done.

A glass of barbera was well-poured, properly priced, and nice save for a bit of cork in the glass.  

Service was a bit distracted (they are obviously still learning the ropes) but got the food to the table while it was hot.
author: David D.

description: A unique dining experience. Delicious food, cooked and served quickly. Nice to watch when they are making the noodles. Happy hour snacks are cheaper (4-6pm).
author: Jed I.

description: Horrible Food!! We ordered the scallop fried rice, and kung pao chicken and green beans everything sucked the green beans were Raw.  Good customer service though
author: James W.

description:
6:15 pm reservations last night, a Friday. Recommend res because had to wait 5 min even with res.  Super busy with families, couples, large groups seeming to be enjoying themselves immensely.  Don't let the fact that there's multitudinous staff deter you, or that it's in a mall.  Our waitstaff bent over backwards to be helpful. The restaurant ambience is good/lively.  

Satisfying variety of food and a nice selection of hot tea kept our family of 4 happy. Server made sure we had all our goodies so we could make Lion King show start. 19 yr old said the beef was so tender in his noodle soup. 17 yr old enjoyed the sweet and sour pork and couldn't keep her chopsticks out of the scissor cut noodles with boar. We ate the 5 spice pork ribs to the bone. Yummy whole wheat pork pot stickers. Salty and greasy seem the norm, but nothing I couldn't handle. 

Thank you, Martin.  I only see this place getting better!
author: Carol E.

description: I really like this place for a group meal - first of all, it doesn't look or taste like a typical mall restaurant. The food is excellent. I loved the individual spoons that the juicy dumplings come in (excellent skin thickness, though the crab flavor wasn't pronounced through all the dumplings). The Chairman Mao's chicken was so delicious, and the ma pao tofu actually tasted (probably deceptively) healthy. But the best thing was the kung pao dungeness crab. It was perfectly cooked, and the flavoring on the shell was amazing. Would definitely go back.
author: Ruchi M.

description: There are many outstanding dishes on the menu, but  the sweet and sour pork is the best in SF, by far!
author: Terry K.

description:
Great food, great kitchen team.  Poor service , waiters - lack of food knowledge , can't even make recommendations. Ask them pack your left overs , came back and tell you ( sorry we tossed it away by mistake ) 
$100 for 2 people for Chinese food , we are looking for good service . Why not go to Koi Palace for Chinese Food . 
Showed Yan is a great cook , but poor in management . 
Spoilt my valentine day's dinner . 
Do not recommend
author: Miriam M.

description:
Four of us dined at M.Y. China last night. As others have noted, the food was delicious. However, this review focuses on the staff and the service. We had a reservation, but, unfortunately, a large cocktail event was planned very near our table, which would have made conversation quite challenging. Rather than compete with the noise, we were going to leave for another restaurant. That would have been disappointing because we were all looking forward to eating here. 

I discussed this with the staff. They were sympathetic and acted promptly and professionally. They arranged for us to move to another table when one became available. It was a busy evening for the staff with this major charity event going on, as well as a line of customers, but the staff, especially Matt, was quick to respond to our dilemma. Service was unobtrusive, courteous, and efficient. The management of this restaurant should commend their workers. We really appreciated how they "saved" the evening for us and we didn't have to end up eating in the basement food court!
author: franny s.

description:
I'm a meat eater. I liked my China. I had a 1/2 order of Peking Duck and Shu Mai. Both were very good. My date, a vegetarian, had a bowl of noodles with tofu and plum sauce, and pea shoots. Both were pretty good. I felt that the duck, at $20, was fairly priced. The pea shoots, at $16, was bizarrely priced.

The restaurant is pleasant and comfortable, but I won't be taking my vegetarian friends.
author: Andrew F.

description: Wonderful time here for my 21year-old birthday party! The food and the service were good!
author: Lingye W.

description:
A group of three of us ate at M.Y. China yesterday.  I highly recommend the restaurant.  The restaurant had a good ambiance and great food and cocktails. 

I should note that our friend works at the restaurant at the sous chef. In the cocktail department, my husband especially enjoyed the Smoke and Slaughter and I liked the Wealth and Indulgence.  The food was delicious!  If we were to go again, we would definitely order one of their home-made noodle dishes again, the crispy organic tofu, and the stir fried green beans.  Though, I wouldn't mind eating the whole meal again.

We had a variety of dishes:
-stir fried green beans
-mapo organic tofu
-roasted portabella sliders (portabellas are cooked three times!)
-wild boar lettuce cups
-BBQ pork
-wild boar scissor cut noodles
-vegetarian longevity noodle soup
-crispy organic tofu

I noticed that other reviews mentioned that price.  I don't think that the prices are higher than other places in SF, such as Hong Kong Lounge.
author: Chau T.

description:
Had dinner here with my friends after work. We ordered a variety of dishes like crispy fried chicken, wild boar scissor cut noodles, wonton soup and their papaya salad w/ shrimp. Their salad dressing was so bland and no taste or kick...

Their food is ok. Service was kinda average as it was a busy Friday night.
author: Lourdes A.

description:
So I made a reservation on Opentable but we arrived 10 minutes early. The hostess (not the same as before) was very friendly and seated us right away. Our waitress was friendly and attentive. We started with a couple appetizers (spring rolls and dumplings) which were excellent. I had my beef noodle soup which was amazing. My friend had the pork (I think) ribs....the serving was massive and he took most of it to go. 

The chefs were performing 'noodle tricks' (get your minds out of the gutter) for the patrons which added to a fun atmosphere. One chef even gave me a piece of his noodle after he was done (again, minds out of gutter). It was a tasty meal topped with excellent service. 

One thing: I've read quite a few comments about the food being a bit too salty. I tried my friend's ribs, and although they were tasty they did seem to be overly-salted. Other than that M.Y. China is back on my list of favorite restaurants.
author: John H.

description: I found it quite authentic if a bit pricey. It's what you get for something in a high-tent district. Portion sizes are a bit feast for eyes than stomach ifyouknowwhutimean...
author: Frank X.

description: Wonderful food! My family shared several dishes. The kids loved the sweet and sour chicken. As a GF person I had King Mao's chicken dish.  We will be back'
author: amy j.

description:
M.Y. China is anything but mall food.  My family and I had the pleasure of dining in this new, upscale, unique Chinese restaurant and enjoyed every minute of it.

Our evening started with a warm and very friendly greeting from not only the restaurant's lovely hostess, but also by each individual staff member that walked by us while we waited for our table.  We were lucky enough to be able to grab an early reservation, but arrived before the restaurant opened, and therefore had to linger a while.  Each member of the staff was so busy bustling around getting the place ready for service, yet they all had time for a warm smile and/or a friendly greeting.  

Once seated, we were promptly greeted by our server and offered drinks, which we happily ordered.  My husband ordered an East Meets West...YUM.  I ordered an Under the Bronze Bell...a delightful prosecco cocktail.  Both were brought to the table quickly, along with the sodas my kids ordered.  

While we sipped our cocktails and pondered the menu, we were entertained by the restaurants expert noodle pullers (not sure the industry term!) who pulled and snipped long noodles into huge pots of bubbling water in the action packed open kitchen.  Some guys were throwing noodles from a couple of feet away into the pots...it was like acrobatic noodle making.  Very fun to watch.

When it was time to order food, our server was very helpful, as we wanted to order every single thing on the menu.  She was able to narrow things down for us...

We ordered:

Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders- DELICIOUS.  I would totally order these again.

Shandong Beef Rolls- We watched a little video of them being made before we went to the restaurant.  They did NOT disappoint!

Mu Shu Pork Tacos- Another delightful dish, highly recommended.

Beef Hand Pulled Noodles
Braised Beef Short Ribs in a Claypot- This is my only complaint of the entire evening, and it's a petty one....The above noodle dish and claypot dish were both ordered, and they were both delicious, but they are almost exactly the same flavor...the only difference really is that one is served over noodles.  Now I want to make it perfectly clear that both dishes were absolutely worth ordering, but there were so many other yummy looking things on the menu, I only wished we had chosen one of the beef dishes and then got something else.  I feel that the server should have given us a little heads up on the similarities thereby giving us the option to choose something else...

M.Y. Sweet and Sour Pork:  Um....Best I've ever had in my entire San Francisco raised life...

Garlic Pea Shoots- Very tasty but expensive.  Not sure if they are a really rare type of pea shoot or what, but a plate of them was $16 versus stir fried green beans (which we didn't try) at $8.  I'm guessing the price must be justifiable, I just forgot to ask what was special about them.  Next time though, I'd probably go for the green beans.

Mapo Organic Tofu- We ordered it extra spicy and it was delicious.  

Overall, our experience was fantastic.  There are so many places in SF for good Asian food, but if you're looking for something a little upscale and special, this is definitely the place.  I will go back, for sure.
author: L L.

description: This place was delicious! As long as you don't pay attention to the stupid noodle dance that reminded me a little of Disneyland.
author: Rosa M.

description: A little pricey, but flavors are great! Love the shanghai dumplings.
author: Lotus L.

description:
We made no reservations but was able to get seats anyway!  Yes! 
A friend and I ordered the pulled beef noodles, wild boar dumplings, pork ribs and chicken wings!  Sooo delicious and flavorful! The chicken wings reminded me of Sam Tung, with it's crispy sweet and savory outer layer.  The beef pulled noodles were like an intense version of pho but with soba noodles.  We loved talking to the guy at the noodle bar who kept us entertained.  He was so sweet!
author: Sierra D.

description:
My daughter walked in and were seated at the counter overlooking the kitchen.
We noticed 2 workers washing the windows over the cooking area. I asked our waiter why they were washing the window over the cooking food? He said they were "going around" the food. WRONG. We finished our appetizer and left quickly. 
Soapy and dirty bits in our food is not cool. Will not go back.
author: L. L.

description:
We don't get Chinese very often so when we do its a treat. Tonight we tried My China and found the place to be very very good. 

We were in a hurry so told the server and he did a great job getting the food out quickly. 

Although expensive for Chinese it was well worth it.
author: Dan Q.

description: We went for happy hour specials and it sucked-  it was $5 for the sm bites but nothing that great. And really $18 for a Knob Creek Manhattan?! What a joke! WE WON'T BE BACK!
author: Gary P.

description: We were old friends wanting to talk, talk, talk and eat some delicious food.  I loved the design of the restaurant...the low lighting, the colors, the smaller dining areas.  The menu was super intriguing, but we wanted to get on with our talking so we went with the fixed duck menu (I forget the exact name) and everything was interesting and delicious.  We also both found the perfect drinks....wine and mixed drinks.  Our server was great at judging from afar what our needs were, so wasn't constantly interrupting and asking questions.  She was really great.  By 8:30 the noise level was getting a little intense, but before that it was great for having a quality conversation.
author: E J C.

description: Five stars. I love this place because even if it's a fancy Chinese resto, it's not pretentious. I had the xia Lang bao and Orange chicken. Both very yummy. The xia Lang bao was oozing with truffle juiciness. Heaven. My mom had lobster which was actually delish. Definitely come back
author: Leslie M.

description: Living in SF, I have been to A LOT of Chinese places, and something about M.Y. China was just so special and different that made it absolutely perfect. As soon as you enter, you are greeted with all smiles and top level customer service. As well as beautiful, trendy, upscale Chinese decor (all inside a mall!). And the food is higher class Chinese food, just perfect. We got the dim sum collection 8 dim sums (2 each), a pork bun, and a leaf with rice: easy to share, delicious, and a variety of tastes. The crispy noodle with chicken had the sauce of the chicken soak the noodles making them very flavorful, and the chili paste given on the side added the ideal zest of flavor. The scallop fried rice was pretty good, lacking a bit in scallops, but considering its only $10, I understand. And last, and most important, the quail! Get the quail! A delicious fried quail stuffed with rice and mushroom cooked to a crisp, so good! I had a great experience here, and I have no problem paying more to come here for Chinese food.
author: Nikita K.

description: Pricey but surprisingly good Chinese food in a nice mall location.  Environment feels nice for an asian place and the food surprised, definitely no PF Chang's.
author: Jon L.

description:
I was excited to try this restaurant ever since they started advertising for this place. I finally went on Monday but I was very disappointed. The service was great but the food was not. Every employee was friendly and greeted us the whole time. They were very attentive to the customer's need. Andrew our server was very nice & attentive.

If I were a tourist that do not know anything about Chinese food then that's OK but I am not. I live locally and have had better Chinese food for a lot less if you go to the Richmond District. 

We ordered 1/2 Peking duck but what we got looked like it's about an 1/8 of a Peking duck. The serving was very small, for $20 we got about 8-10 pcs of squared skin, 6 buns and a few pieces of duck meat. The calamari was OK, nothing special about it. We also got wok seared beef on a bed of baby arugula. The meat was very tender but it super bland. The steamed rice that should come free with the dishes was $2 per tiny container was good. The dessert that we got was the M.Y. China sundae (i think that's what it's called). It came with three table spoon sized ice cream, some toasted rice crumbled under the ice cream and some caramel sauce that's very sweet & feels like gritty sand.The complimentary bottled water came in a fancy bottle but it taste like tap water.

If you want to experience the real & authentic Chinese food, I suggest that you walk up a few blocks to China Town. It may cost you the same but at least you can say you had some good Chinese food. 

One thing I enjoyed was the noodle making show. I mean, it was entertaining although I've seen the stunt at other places before. They made some type of dessert out of the noodle after which we got along with the dessert that we ordered. They deep fried the noodles & threw a few pieces of strawberries in the plate with the fried noodles and called a dessert. 

It's a shame that a famous chef would put his name on the line by serving crap.
author: Kathy P.

description:
-1 star for 15 min wait inspite of a reservation.

Went by recos of fellow yelpers to place order.

Bang bang chicken wings - excellent sauce. Chicken was very tasty.

Spicy seafood dumpling - loved it. Perfect spice level. Seafood filling was full of flavor.

Seared beef - although pretty good in taste, thought the portion size was kind of smaller than other Chinese joints.

Forbidden rice - so underwhelming. I guess this wild ricy dish is not just our thing.

Scissor cut noodle - hardly enough to share amongst 2, let alone the four in our party. Barely any wild boar to be found. Didn't do much for me in terms of taste for me anyway.

Taking one more star out for the last 2 dishes

Ordered desserts. Lychee pana cotta was pretty good. Daughter's spicy mango sorbet the only non dairy dessert in the menu was a hit with everyone in the table.

Will probably be back to try out other items in the menu.
author: junk m.

description: Ohh my were do I start ! I am an avid crab & sea food eater and this place is uniquely amazing ! out waitress Victoria has the BEST. Customer service skills I have seen in a long time . She is very opinionated and helped us with our meal selection . My Bf and I shared the large seasoned yet spicy crab / salt & pepper calamari and the boar noodles ! Each dish was amazing and extremely tasteful ! I had to do a lot to find this place I accurately was on Instagram in the explorer section were I saw this picture a girl posted of this AMAZING looking crab . I clicked did some stalking in the comments and she wasn't giving up the name of the restaurant to her followers ... So I hesitated and finally added her , then screen shot the picture and DM her she replied quickly with idk the name but it's the 1st restaurant it's next to the nordstrom cosmetics exit . So I hop in a cab from my hotel and go on the search ! ( I remember thinking omg what if this girl is just sending me on a wild goose chase haha) sure enough there it was ! I'm so pleased with this place & our waitress !!
author: Sara L.

description: I had the lamb and onion stir fry and it was absolutely delicious. The waitress was beyond friendly. Restrooms luxurious.
author: R S.

description: Born and Raised Bay Area native and well traveled, huge fan of  Chinese food in particular and Asian food in general. Having said that I had very low bar expectations, maybe a PF Chang sorta Chinese food experience. Nope! Excellent interpretation of fine Cantonese food. Fresh, well spiced, quality and quantity. We had  very good service. Not nearly as arrogant as Roy's staff has become. Ambience is contemporary and the tables well spaced. It's in the Westfield Mall, but easy access if you take Muni or BART. Wine selection is good and priced very fairly.  While not quite as lux as the original Mandarin in G Square, very nice digs. I will return!
author: Chad R.

description: Unimpressed.  Our waitress was very sweet but the food took forever to be served, we didn't get some of our order, and they left those missing items on our bill. The food itself tasted okay but nothing to jump up-and-down about. The location within the mall was a bit foodcourt-like and it was a very, very loud.  Found it to be entirely overpriced for the location, the quality of service, and the quality of the food.
author: Karen T.

description: Nice place for a drink in between shopping sessions. There are better places to get Chinese.
author: Maggie L.

description: Presentation was lovely but quality of the food was poor. We ordered what we thought would be epic dishes including peking duck, lobster, xiao long bao and a few other dishes, but alas while everything looked delicious, it all tasted mediocre. Nothing stood out and the lobster was dry. For crying out loud, how could they overcook the lobster?!
author: Gina S.

description: Went here last month in April with my mom for a mother daughter day since I promise to take her shopping in San Francisco. Originally we were planning on going to a different restaurant however we could not find the location of the other restaurant; therefore, we decided to shop more at the Westfield mall. And once my mom and I got hungry we decided to eat at this place. The staff is super friendly, and the food is amazing. The green onion pancakes are buttery, crisp and taste awesome, I also loved the BBQ pork, we also had the Beijing knife cut noodles and the pork bao buns, which were also amazing. I would love to go here again since the food is great and the price is a bargain, in my opinion.
author: Grace M.

description: modern approach to chinese dining...westfield mall fourth floor, bloomingdale's side...reservations and seated by various buddha figurines...a wine list presented...gruner veltliner rebenfeld $thirty each bottle...double typical $fifteen market price charged...ordering to share amongst four....crispy tofu $eight and fantastic...perfect outer crisp and soft silky inner with sweet dip delectable...shandong beef roll too tough 'n' dry at $nine...can't recommend...beijing knife-cut noodles $twelve the least favorite and "bad"...taste of hoisin over bloated noodles...redemption in peking roast duck $twenty...crisp squares of delicious duck skin...the meat shredded and piled separate....soft "taco" white buns soft and subtle sweetness...garlic pea shoots $sixteen tasteful...slight horseradish twist to traditional honey walnut shrimp $twenty-two...touch of horseradish a good complimenting sense to creamy sweet shrimp...crab juicy dumpling good for $twelve, but thicker dumpling skin...truffle juicy dumplings $eighteen with same thicker dumpling skin, but almost no taste of truffle...where is the truffle?...$eight pork belly slider pair a tough chew, but good seasoning...$sixty per person total dinner with two bottles of gruner....chinese at higher class without the bastardization to traditional chinese cooking....
author: Hen A.

description: Nice atmosphere, excellent presentation, yummy food, good for kids, really cool watching hand-pulled noodles being made out on the floor, a little pricey.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
"Yan CAN'T cook" If I could give zero stars I would.

Had a work lunch there today and was thoroughly disappointed with everything I ordered. I should have known from the beginning when I asked the waiter for an ice water and he brought me water with NO ice. In a nut shell, this is bland but somehow salty,  "fancy" Chinese food that is extremely overpriced. I can't believe I just paid $28 for 5 chunks of bland chicken, over-cooked green beans, and steamed rice. What restaurant charges $2 for a tablespoon of steamed rice? Did I mention this was lunch time? I feel ripped off and will never go back. I hate to say this but Panda Express is better and I would have never thought frozen food would be better than a world class chef. Save your money, there are plenty of other Chinese restaurants that don't include the ambiance in their meal pricing. Too bad Martin Yan wasn't present today as I would have given him a piece of my mind.
author: Jaz M.

description: The mixed drinks are for the sure the highlight of this place. Great decor though and friendly service... Food could kick it up a notch for sure.. With all the other selections in this mall it would be in my top three places to check out. Better for drinks and apps! :)
author: Chauntel B.

description:
Went here on a Wednesday night, so it was very easy to get a table, and service was quick and friendly. Ordered three dishes and two drinks between two people, and it was only about ~35 each, so pretty reasonable. We ordered the dumpling sampler, Sichuan green beans, and crispy Hong Kong noodles. The green beans were excellent and very tasty, my only suggestion would be to add some spice to them. The Hong Kong noodles were also good, and the chicken that comes on them was amazing.

They have the kitchen open and you can see chefs spinning the noodles, which is fun and makes me want to go back to try different noodles there. The restaurant is open to the mall dome, which makes it feel oddly like Vegas or something, but is also nice because it feels spacious and like eating on a climate controlled patio.

Overall recommend it. It's not super cheap but not expensive either; the dishes are big and we were both plenty full after dinner.
author: K W.

description:
I don't even know where to begin.

Came in for dinner on a Sunday evening with my girlfriend and another couple.

Let's just say if this place even deserves a star, it's for the decor and ambiance. It really is a pleasant looking restaurant and the aesthetics of the open-ish kitchen are also nice as you walk in. The hostess led us to a less-than-desirable table by the hallway to the bathroom (yes, we did have reservations for 4 through OpenTable), and upon asking to be re-seated at a number of other open tables were told they were all also "reserved". Not a big deal but more on this later (you can probably guess what happened). 

The service to start was prompt, and the waitress seemed personable and took our orders. We elected to go with 2 Hot & Sour Soups, 2 Westlake Wonton Soups, the Beijing Beef Cut Noodles, Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, Pork Sliders, Chairman Mao's Chicken, and Wok Seared Beef Filet. The first red flag should have been when our waitress took our order mentally, and then returned a minute later to double-check which entree our friends had ordered (there's a reason why servers write it down)

The soups came out quickly, litteraly about 2 minutes after the waitress "confirmed" our order- I got the Hot & Sour, which I am a huge fan of at 99% of Chinese restaurants. Not this one. At first glance I would tell something was wrong... the soup wasn't of its traditional brown hue but concentrated very heavily with a vibrant red. One taste of the soup told me enough- it tasted like a thick paste mixed with Sriracha. Literally inedible and probably the worst thing I've tasted in a long, long time. I alerted our waitress to send the soup back (either this is the worst recipe on the planet or the chef of the night dumped way too much hot sauce into the soup) and request a bowl of the Westlake instead. She snatched the bowl off the table like I had personally offended her, and stormed off to the kitchen. She then disappeared for no-less than 15 minutes and forced us to ask two other different servers where our soup was ("Coming right out"). The replacement bowl of the Wonton soup made it out, followed 30 seconds later by our noodles and entrees. Great. 

The soup itself- bland. Tasted like water, egg whites, and chives with two wontons. Had to dump a whole ramekin of Soy Sauce into the soup to get through it. Not the worst I've had, not even comparable to the Hot-and-Sour atrocity, but yet bland none the less.

As my party started to eat the entrees as I was still finishing my soup, I got the sense they were underwhelmed with the food. Wow, was that an understatement.

The Wok Seared Filet ($18) was one of the worst beef dishes I've ever tasted in my life. I don't know whose bright idea it is to take a "Filet", pound it out like a Flank Steak, and then serve it essentially deep fried in a tasteless sauce but it's just plain bad. The beef has some spice, but absolutely no flavor whatsoever. After chewing through two pieces (I've had sirloin steaks from Chinese fast food places that's more tender) I was done with this dish. 

Next up was the Chairman Mao's Chicken ($16). It's essentially five pieces of chicken deep-fried in a basket with no seasoning or sauce. They give you two ramekins of "sweet and spicy" sauce but it's barely enough to cover one piece of the tasteless fried chicken. I wouldn't be surprised if the chefs here (at least that evening) has never seen a salt or pepper shaker. 

Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles ($14)- this was the only okay dish on the table. The noodles were tasty, however the Wild Boar wasn't very flavorful (no seasoning, big surprise...) and prepared poorly (so much gristle.. yuck!)

Beijing Knife Cut Noodles ($12) - Probably just as disappointing on par with the Hot and Sour Soup and "Filet". The dish looked like a bowl of Top Ramen after the served "mixed" it together and had a weird, sweet hint to it. 

Pork Belly Sliders - Never came, waitress probably "forgot" since she took our order in her head.  The rest of the meal and service was so laughable we didn't even ask about it. 

Overall- this is probably the worst "Chinese" place I've ever encountered in my lifetime. Everyone in our party was displeased and left us wishing we had made the trek out to somewhere such as San Tung instead. The food was so bland it makes airplane cuisine sound appealing. To top it off- the vacant tables that we had requested ("Sorry those are reserved") were still sitting empty 2 hours later. 

If you're into foo-foo fancy looking expensive "Chinese" food that tastes like cardboard this is the place for you. 

My recommendation- save about $20/head and go to Panda Express downstairs instead if you're really craving Asian food.  They will actually put some thought into seasoning your food and the person serving you probably won't act like they take it personally if you don't like something.
author: L B.

description: Probably some of the best Chinese I've ever had. You can watch them make their famously long noodles from behind the bar counter. I came at lunch rush and there was a 15 minute wait  for a party of two. Food is a bit pricey but absolutely worth it. I recommend the longevity noodle soup and the fried rice.
author: Dean B.

description: Had dinner on my own tonight after an afternoon of marginally successful shopping.  I will say that the menu is not great for solo diners, as all of my dishes were huge.  However, my bf will be happy with my leftovers.  My server was lovely, knowledgeable and helpful.  She steered me away from dishes that were just way too much for one person and helped me order so that I tried a few different things.  I loved the open kitchen, and the selection of drinks and wines by the glass were good.  My food was excellent: riffs on traditional Chinese-American dishes, but very, very well done.  If I have a quibble, it is that, even though it isn't traditionally Chinese to eat alone, in a mall setting, it must be common.  To be offered a tasting menu that I can't order is just torture!  I will be back, but not likely alone.
author: Lisa R.

description: Only weak item was hot and sour soup which was too tomato-ey and tangy for our tastes. Kudos however for the Beijing cut noodles which came with spicy pork, cucumbers and sprouts and were mixed up at the table. I think the point of having somewhat small portions (2-3 persons) is to have you order more dishes, which is what we did. The splendid Chairman Mao's Chicken delights ---perfectly and cleanly rendered fried chicken chunks in spicy sauce with veggies. Dumplings were also good, as was the $11 Singapore Sling that was way too small. But all was forgiven with the dessert: the fried egg sugar puffs served with creme chantilly, chocolate sauce and raspberry coulis. Magic!
author: Alfonso L.

description:
everyone complaining about prices and "authenticity" need to get up and out of westfield mall and walk to chinatown instead. martin yan has designed a nicely appointed restaurant with attentive service, a variety of popular and recognizable chinese dishes, and prices to match. m.y. china's competition is p.f. chang's, not chinatown - know what you're going for and you won't be disappointed!

specifically about the food - beef noodle soup lacks the punch i prefer from the taiwanese and szechuan versions but flavors are great.  looking for that spiciness, i found that the szechuan green beans were my favorite dish here.  the dim sum and xiao long baos were beautifully presented on spoons and tasted fine but i wouldn't come here just for that. overall, martin yan takes classic chinese dishes, cooks them well, doesn't do anything shocking, and presents it all in a pretty package.
author: Sherman L.

description: Nate, the bartender/waiter is awesome!  Ask him about Turkey,  oh and take any recommendations on food he gives.  Amazing service.  A+++
author: Jasmine N.

description:
I will review this restaurant in three categories: food, ambiance, service

Ambiance = 4 star
food = 2 star
service = 4 star

The restaurant is in a mall.  It's clean, spacious so one doesn't feel cramped.  The bathrooms are clean.  The bar is quite extensive. 

The food is nothing special.  In fact, I would say it's very Americanized.  Lots of sweet and sour type dishes.  I didn't try the fish.  I tried the dim sum, mu shoo pork, crispy chicken, bok choi veggie and the wild boar noodle.   Nothing was special.  The noodle, bok choi, dim sum, and mu shoo pork was just average.  The chicken was drier than it should be.  In a bit of irony, the dim sum and the mu shoo pork were very the most creative dish.  Both dishes were made better by creative presentation.  The dim sum was in vinegar and garlic sauce which help hide the poor quality.   The mu shoo pork was served as a taco.  We figured it was because it was too difficult for most people prepare the mu shoo burrito properly by themselves like it's usually done.   

The service was good.  Everyone was very pleasant. 

The total bill came to mid 90's for two people.  That's to be expected for a location like this with such a nice bar.   

When we arrived, the restaurant was about 95% full.  If you believe there is a correlation between good Chinese food and the number of Asian customers, it may be helpful for you to know there were 6 Asians there compared 50ish (guess) non-Asian. 

The conclusion is, I would go there again.  It would be my first choice for a business dinner because of the ambiance, especially with business guest from the Mid West.  If my business guest came from San Francisco, Asia or NYC, I would avoid the restaurant.  I would totally avoid the restaurant with anyone that knows Chinese food. 

I must give the restaurant some credit for their confidence to open a restaurant in a city with so much better Chinese Food.   A better alternative is Koi Palace if convenience wasn't the most important criteria.
author: Han S.

description:
Food was great!  Love the decor!  We would definitely come back!
We ate there during happy hour, and the prices were great!
Wild Boar noodles - delicious!
Bang Bang Chicken wings - sweet, flavorful and delicious!
Pork Bao - very, very good


DISLIKE:
The only thing that was a little odd was the restroom set up.   It was a co-ed / unisex bathroom, and I did not like that at all.  I felt a little uneasy in there, knowing that a man could walk in at any time and be using the stall right next to me.  Not cool.
author: Sonja W.

description: What happened here, did all the chefs move out? The first time I ate here it was a whole lot better tasting.
author: m K.

description: The employees here are the best! I worked at Nordstrom for three years. Until MY China opened, I always avoided eating at the mall. This place is such a treat! Wild boar noodles are my favorite
author: Christina R.

description: i was nervous eating here cuz i thought ok just another crappy azn restaurant. the water seemed like it came from the tap and wasnt really cold.  had no idea what to get. got the something tacos which were ok and some shrimp dumplings with sweet sauce. it was good dont know if id come back tho.
author: Maryse JR G.

description:
We went to M. Y. China last Sunday night for a late dinner.  We were seated at the table directly in front of the open kitchen and the time was almost 9 PM.  The restaurant was mostly empty with a handful of tables finishing the remains of their dinners.  

The food was fine, little on the sweet side and some dishes more authentic than others.  The waiter was attentive.  The food arrived within a reasonable time.  The Whole Wheat Potstickers were fine if less than crispy.  The Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles were well done and had a nice firm chewy texture, the Stir Fried Green Beans were tasty and  nicely crunchy. The Shandong Beef Rolls were less successful, the beef was not marinated in the traditional northern style and with too much sauce.  

Beyond the food, the kitchen staff was irritating with their persistently loud and energetic bantering.  They were shouting, gesturing and taking pictures of each other with their IPhones.  We both knew Cantonese and Taishanese and the loud noise in the open kitchen was getting more tedious as the night wore on.   

At the end of our meal, we finally mentioned to the manager about the irritating noise from the kitchen and he told us that we could move to another table.  He also went on to explain to us that the kitchen staff needed to be able to communicate with each other about their work.  Fine, is shouting really necessary for the communication?  

We both knew Caucasian friends that are well versed in Chinese, some with greater eloquence than us.  This manager was obviously clueless about what is being bantered about in the open kitchen or he would not have offered his explanation.  He was also obviously a block head since he got all huffy when I told him he does not know what the hell was talking about.  He then got up within inches of my face and spoke directly into my ear and said in a threatening tone "you should watch how you speak to me!"  

What?!?  Was this guy going to do me the Tony Soprano or the Al Capone?

Well, that was actually the high point of the dinner.  The guy made me laugh and that is worth something.  And the noise from the open kitchen seems to have faded and that is worth more.  

We will probably return for the comedy.
author: Ken w.

description: I love their happy hour. Their dim sum is delish. Esp their HK Crispy noodles. It will most def fill you up!
author: Elle A.

description: The ambience is a bit nicer than a typical PF Chang. Martin Yan has added his name to this place and this time, he did good. We had both meat and veggie fishes and enjoyed all of them. I only wish that the portion size was a bit bigger for the premium price.
author: Arthur L.

description: A $30+ meal comprised of one dish and one appetizer and no drinks is awfully hard to justify in a shopping mall, and this one didn't. The place has good energy and style, but the kitchen was slow and uneven (I sat right at the viewing window) and the dishes were full of unnecessary sugar.
author: Christopher C.

description:
M.Y. China is, despite being in a mall, about as far from Panda Express as you can get.   It's upscale (and expensive) Chinese food with a Californian twist in a very elegant space.   I ate there for a business luncheon with 9 others, and tried a variety of foods off their menu (everything is served family style).  I especially loved the noodles with the wild boar.   The service is white-tablecloth, and the courteous wait staff does a good job of keeping the carafes of water (fizzy and flat, but both are free!) topped up.   

In short, if you are looking for a cheap, authentic, hole-in-the-wall place with rude waiters, go elsewhere.  But you've got out of town relatives visiting who might not be quite so adventurous but are still ready to graduate from sweet-n-sour chicken, this is the ticket.  Especially if they are footing the bill.
author: Susan C.

description: If you consider eating here on a weekend you should make a reservation ahead of time or you might be waiting for a bit. Dishes were on the pricier side compared to most Chinese restaurants in the city, but they do not disappoint. I recommend  the seared beef, and the halibut fillet. I am not a fan of their honey walnut shrimp, it has wasabi  in it.  For dessert, the sugar egg puffs were great!
author: Mav M.

description:
Martin Yan's restaurant was good for the experience and the staff was courteous and helpful for the suggestions made for the food choices for a large group of people.  First time going there and the food came out quickly for a busy Friday night.  I have been a fan of his cooking show on PBS and his off humor about chinese culture my trip to the bay area tempt my curiosity to visit.

We tried several varieties of the noodles, I really enjoyed the Beijing Knife Cut Noodles the most as they are shaven noodles made from scratch.  The dumplings came in 3 with pork 3 with crab roe and pork where they should make it with a choice like the Din Tai Fung chain as I'm particular with the Pork Dumplings.  

Overall, the authenticity of this has some east/west fusion but an enjoyable setting for those that want to check out this restaurant and overall food was good in the taste and presentation.
author: Norman L.

description: Had my kid's birthday dinner here.  My expectations were of PF changs, but MY CHina came off as much more authentic chinese cuisine.  It's a great place to take kids because they have outdoor in the mall seating and kids can run around. We had a chicken salad. The knife-cut noodle with pork was delicious. We also had the single serving chicken soup which tasted like something my mom would make for a day. The server gave us complimentary fried puffs with birthday candle which I think she improvised for us.  Very nice experience dining here!
author: James W.

description:
First.  Reservation on Christmas Eve, so yes you have to be patient..  So it was 20 minutes late for a table for two. (I observed 4 empty tables that remained that way even when we were seated.) 
The front desk didn't let us know what the procedure was for allotting tables, but several tables arriving before and after us were seated before us, all with 7:30 reservations.   
   The waitress was prompt and sharp.  She was quick with water, though the water glasses had bit of  dried flecks from the dishwasher on it.  (Change that dishwasher water a bit more often.) Inside looked clean.  The Szechuan style stir fried green beans were nery good. Spicy and just the right amount of crunch.  The same is true for the stir fried pea shoots. They were just tender and crunchy enough with a good balance between the green, fresh taste and the savory garlic.  The jasmine rice was of a good consistency.  The siau long bao was fair, but it could never come to the level of flavor and tenderness of a place such as Kingdom of Dumpling.  Still. It was good compared to so many of the doughy, flavorless dumplings you can encounter in the City. All in all a disappointment for a tv chef I admire at prices that weren't justified by the flavor.
author: Michael E.

description: I've given this place three tries. The food is disappointing-it lacks flavor and any sort of creativity. The prices are extremely high for what you get and the service leaves a lot to be desired. Three strikes. I'm done.
author: Malarie J.

description: Came here for my birthday and enjoyed the most amazing food and service. I would highly recommend this restaurant. I'll be back!
author: Jennett N.

description:
I was so excited when I first heard about Martin Yan's new restaurant in Westfield, and I really think it lives to the hype! At first, I was a little put off by the mediocre ratings, but the food was great, the service was amazing, and I am totally in love with the restaurant decor! Located on the 4th floor of the mall, the restaurant is large, looks super modern, and has an open kitchen!

My friend and I made reservations at opening (5:30p) on Sunday, and we were seated right away at the Chef's counter! I really recommend requesting these seats if you're here in a small group! You get to see the chefs at work making different noodles and dim sum! Yum! The restaurant got pretty crowded as the night went on, so definitely come early!

Though the food isn't cheap, it's definitely super filling! We ordered 3 dishes to share, and ended up with way too much food!

**Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles ($14)**
The one thing I knew I wanted to try were their noodles; we ended up deciding on this one based off of Yelp tips :P, and I really liked it! It's a little salty/greasy, so for those who might be a little more health conscious, I don't know if this dish is for you. But, I loved the texture of the noodles! They're super soft and thick, so they're nice & chewy!
**Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders ($8)**
This looks almost exactly like The Chariman's steamed baos. I was expecting something more like mini burgers, but they use white steamed buns (similar to those used for peking duck). The flavour was really good, and I liked the addition of daikon! However, I do prefer The Chairman's pork belly bao, as it's a little cheaper and they give you larger pieces of meat. 
**Forbidden Rice ($8)**
This reminded me of wild rice; the dish includes different types of rice mixed with wolfberries, corn, and pineapple! My friend really liked the rice, and I think this could be a good vegetarian option.
**East Meets West Cocktail ($11)**
I was super intrigued by this drink! It's like vodka with chrysanthemum tea, and surprisingly, this combination works! Slightly sweet, without an overwhelming taste of alcohol, I feel like I could easily down a couple of these haha. 

I reallly love the ambiance of this place! Can't wait to come back!
author: Stephanie W.

description: I love their cocktails, especially East Meets West and Smoke and Slaughter. The food is surprisingly good as well. Their flour based dishes (including dumplings and noodles) are all very solid. I'm also a big fan of their hot sauce (on request) - more fragrant than flaming hot. I think food alone is probably more of a 3.5 star but combined with the convenient location and awesome drinks, it's a solid 4 star in my book.
author: June W.

description: Not expecting much but was good. Took forever to get seated as they have intermittent power outages that take down their computers. Dim sum was great, noodle dish was ok but 3x the cost for the same dish at Tu lan and beef dish had good beef but couldn't taste any sezchuan pepper and no spice. 4 stars because I expected them to such and it was ok.
author: reza n.

description: Grab a drink and app at the bar pre-movie.
author: Vicki L.

description: I cant rave about this place more! I loved everything about it! The pulled noodles were to die for! The drinks were amazing, the service was great! From the beginning to the end I loved everything about it! I will be going back there for the crab next!
author: Shelynn R.

description: My husband and I ate lunch here for the first time on June 21st and were seated right away.  The only thing is, is that the only seats for 2 people seemed to be a section that put you real close to others.  This section was a connected area that left about a foot of distance between your section of the table and the tables next to you.  I did not like this little seating arrangements.  The food however, was delicious!  We ordered the Shrimp & Avocado Fresh Spring Rolls, it was ok, but my husband really liked it.  For our meals,  we ordered a small Won Ton Soup that we shared and the Hone Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken.  Both were great, and very tasty.  Needless to say, we cleaned the plate off.  The ambiance is really nice, decor is great.  I would highly recommend trying M.Y. China if you are looking for some Chinese food.
author: Paula V.

description: Returned recently for dinner with a larger party, my sons and their dates, so we tried the steamed dim sum.  I never really liked dim sum until now--I always sensed that it was sort of like undercooked pasta that somewhat gummy.  Here, the covering was warm, tender and was very well done with all the variety of fillings.  Also tried the walnut shrimp, it was perfect and not too creamy or salty, like it can be, and actually had more walnuts than we could finish. Try the riesling they serve--it pairs perfectly with this food.
author: Janet G.

description:
M.Y. China was good when it 1st opened. Staff was knowledgeable & excited. 
Now none of the dishes we ordered were any good. Beijing noodles - sauce was salty & the short ribs were tough. Crispy chicken noodles were lacking everything....
author: Gloria D.

description: Food wasn't that great, reminded us of Panda Express. The service wasn't that great either. Probably wouldn't come back again.
author: S D.

description: The honey glazed walnut shrimp is a must-have. The dish is a perfect balance of salty and sweet, combined with a hint of wasabi for a minor kick. Incredible!
author: Marshall N.

description: Nice, semi-fancy Chinese restaurant. The beef noodle soup and the pork juicy dumplings were delicious. If you like spicy, ask for their spicy dipping sauce.
author: Diana F.

description: This place was very good.  Stopped by for a late lunch during a weekday.  Service was very nice from being seated to out server.  Had the green onion pancake, whole wheat dumpling, wild boar pulled noodles (great recomm from waitress) and 5 spice ribs.  All hits except the ribs.  Seemed to lack flavor although they were very tender.  Prices higher than average chinese place but ambiance and location are probably the reasons.  Would be back
author: Dkac C.

description: The best crab we've ever had!!! A must try. Didn't try any of the other dishes but walked by and saw a family eating carb and just had to have some- it looked so good. Did not disappoint!
author: Mary T.

description: Nice place, food is not bad, price is a little high, but then again it's in downtown SF. It's a nice place to bring your date to.
author: Mack A.

description: An experience with ups and downs. The place itself is very nice on the inside even though it's inside a mall. The food was good but not amazing. We really liked the lettuce wraps but the chicken we ordered was too spicy (we're from Mexico and my wife loves spicy but this was too much). I may come back to give it another try.
author: Jorge Z.

description: Really good noodles, be the crispy, the hand cut or the hand pulled. The "Juicy Dumplings" are actually just very good soup dumplings. The bao were very good. The 'Big Trouble in M.Y. China' drink was a Tsingtao with a shot of Baijiu, which I had never had before, and it was strong, like a lighter, smoother tequila. I recomend trying it if you are adventurous. The service was very good. It was on the pricier side, but I was OK with that as I could watch my noodles being made by hand as I ordered them.  Remember to get their house made chili sauce as some of the food lacked spice.
author: Michael J.

description:
First rate medium to fancy Chinese, with price and decor to match. Gorgeous interior and a busy show kitchen that's more entertaining than watching chefs on TV. They're really capable here and working like mad pulling noodles, frying in woks, deep frying, assembling, making soup. Everything's been prepped earlier so no cutting on display, just lots of crazy hectic activity.
