The menu is fairly long and varied for a fancy restaurant, but not for a Chinese place. You really don't have many choices. Each particular kind of noodle is served one way so if you want the hong kong fried noodles it's with chicken, the pulled noodles it's wild boar, the dumplings it's shrimp.

A basic dish like pea shoots in garlic was done so well, perfectly cooked, perfect texture, it was for sure the best I'd had. Salt and pepper squid was nice texture, a great (but too thick for me) batter, and a very complex dipping sauce, it would have been better if they would include lemons without asking. Whole wheat potstickers were decent. The wok fried shrimp was the standout, just a really complex, subtle, tasty dish, with an ingredient list that reads like "things children are not going to like": ginko nuts, acai berries, thick ginger strips, and cooked cucumber, but the dish was just fantastic. We watched the head chef make it himself, while showing an assistant how it's done. It started with a head-turning giant flame of Chinese liquor so hot that we cringed from behind the protective glass six feet away. Then each ingredient cooked quickly and separately in the wok in its own special liquid, then stored. Shrimp last, cooked for several seconds, all assembled, on the plate, then out to our server. The whole thing took barely over a minute, a real treat to watch then eat.

Service was a little unpolished and not sure of the menu. Different people had different tones, manners, and attitudes, it wasn't consistent. But it was only the third day.

It's a little pricey, two appetizers plus two entrees and tea, a little over sixty dollars including tax and tip for lunch. Tea service was nice, a classy pot with tiny Bodum double-walled glasses.

Definitely want to come back and try basically everything on the menu. It's such a rare treat in SF to have gourmet quality Chinese food.
author: Gil S.

description: I have been there multiple times and never disappointed.  The quality of the food is really good.  Granted they are not authentic but improved upon.  Services consistently good.  Highly recommended.
author: Adrian H.

description: Solid but unspectacular. The beef rolls, as other have mentioned, were mediocre, and the salt and pepper calamari was too spicy for either of us to finish. But the food was flavorful, we got two rounds of tasty drinks, and the atmosphere was fun and busy for a casual, above-average dinner.
author: Alvin L.

description:
Pretty restaurant, competent wait staff. 
Not a lot that is vegetarian, but they did accommodate diet restrictions at table without any reserve...
High prices; $2.00 for a single serving of steam rice...jasmine or not..that is high.

Bar drinks look yummy..

It does not feel like your typical mall restaurant.
author: Darlene A.

description: Went there a few weeks ago for my brother's birthday.  Everything from dim sum to scissor-knifed noodle is good, but the real star is the Kobe beef!  It was panfried to perfection -- crispy on the outside and tender on the inside, and was seasoned just right.  This dish is on a level of its own!  It isn't cheap but is well worth it, trust me.
author: Angela Y.

description: As this place was being put together, I kept thinking oh sure - Martin Yan in the mall. Turns out I was way off base - every dish I have ordered has been borderline amazing, and I fear I am somewhat addicted to the wok beef (was up to about three times take out last week).  I usually sit at the bar and ask for take-out, and am thoroughly entertained by the friendly bar staff. I did have one strange experience at a table one night -- Martin was there making the rounds and I don't know if the staff was uptight or what, but the rice came way after the meal and then we ordered coffee and dessert, and the coffee took quite some time. I casually asked the server if she could check on the coffee and got a stern, "I don't believe you understand our coffee is individually brewed." I said that was fine, but the dessert was about gone, and I thought it would have been better to hold the dessert till the coffee was ready -- and then mentioned the late rice.  She really bristled up and told me (again) that I didn't understand their service, that it was family style.  Not sure what that has to do with bringing the rice 10 minutes after you finish the meal, but the maitre d' woman stepped in, got the coffee and sincerely apologized for the incident. Even that did not diminish my 5 star review of the food. One caution: the portions are very large, so beware over-ordering on first visit.
author: Robert M.

description: This was a great spot to bring some friends from out of town who suggested Chinese. I needed something more than take-out, but they weren't quite up to going to Chinatown for the "really authentic" stuff, so I think this worked perfectly. I had the Hong Kong crispy noodles and the prices were decent (around $15/plate). Fair price for a pretty good sized portion. I was satisfied and my friends were happy with it.
author: A Y.

description: Had Kung Pao chicken, squid ink snap noodles with tons of veggies and ended the lunch with egg puffs as dessert.  Everything was delicious and hit the spot. I'll definitely be back.
author: Beril Y.

description:
Beautiful decor with wait staff that are clearly trying hard to live up to the hype and the owners' ambitious plans for an upmarket-ish chinese restaurant.

I went for dinner last Saturday night.  I tried to make reservations but was told they were completely booked all night.  However, since I was shopping in the mall, I decided to walk in and check for availability (considering the restaurant only looked 1/3 full at best) and was told there was a 45min wait.... so, ok... I give them the benefit of the doubt and perhaps they were not operating at full capacity yet given new restaurant, staff, etc.  So I wait the 45min...

The Good
- decor
- drinks were excellent
- servers tried really hard 
- convenient location (for me anyhow)
- har gow was excellent


Need Improvement....
- all the food came at one time!  they had to pull an empty table to fit all of our food (good thing they weren't at full capacity!)  but my food got cold and dumplings should never be eaten cold or rushed (especially when they are $18!)
- extremely nervous, inexperience servers - forgot order (had to come back and take order), taking forever to come back, only checks in on us near end of meal
- dishware is too big for the small tables.  seems petty but if you're gonna bring all my food out at once, which numerous pieces of pretty but impractical tableware, something has got to give and I say nay to the giant, earth ware bowls
- what's up with the pretty tiny glass teacups from vita leaf paired with the old tea pots from Koi Palace (yes, we know!).
- dumplings were presented beautifully in individual spoons but they lack in texture and taste versus lower priced Din Tai Fung or comparable Yank Sing
- rest of the food was ok but over-priced since not of it was memorable or particularly great.  Spring rolls were fine but tasted the same as the ones from Panda Express but 3X more expensive.  I appreciate that overhead is high but I'm just asking for better quality food and service.  My dumplings shouldn't have super thick skin that sticks to the spoon or so much fat content that I can't even taste the meat.  And most certainly not when it cost me $18 and I can't even taste the truffles.

Overall, as someone already said.. overpriced and underwhelmed.  I don't mind paying higher prices for the great decor and excellent location but the food and service is truly lacking.  I am unlikely to head back.  I would choose Straits instead for Asian fare in the mall.
author: Win L.

description:
LIKES: noodles!!
i crave their hand pulled noodles, and its the reason i keep coming back. their springy bouncy al dente texture always makes me happy. my favorite are the wild boar scissor cut noodles (WBSCN) i had those every day for a 4 day period before. the wild boar meat is a bit tough for my taste, but the noodles. oh the nice wok fired noodle goodness..... 

the squid ink snap noodles have the same texture as the scissor noodles, in a cap-like shape, but i'm really not a fan of their excessive use of squid as protein filler, considering the price. also i hate the cornstarch slurry sauce that's not my favorite thing to see on chinese food. the flavors are nice and the wok fired taste is nice, but its definitely no WBSCN.

beijing cut noodles are nothing like the authentic northern chinese version, but i think this version might actually be better! its much sweeter, less salty, with corn and way more meat than the authentic version, overall, i love it, but again, i still prefer the WBSCN

beef noodles. this is probably the best version of nou rou mien i've had in nor cal, which admittedly i'm not a huge fan of. deep flavorful mildly spicy soy anise flavored broth, that definitely shows off the cantonese heritage of the koi palace brothers- it's as satisfying as any bowl of brisket soup i've had in HK. the beef is a bit tough for my taste, but the wonderful noodles again make the dish. that being said, still doesnt beat my favorite WBSCN, in terms of satisfying my carb cravings.

baked chicken bao - this has the crumbly crispy shortbread crust baked on top of a mediocre bao with pretty good fllling. but the star of baked bao IS the crust and its great here, just like in HK.

macau tarts- expensive, small, but oh so good. it will never pass muster in HK, they are maybe 3.5/5, but it def hits the spot in terms of the crust and the flavor of the custard

the ambience, presentation, and decor are very on-point and just like a trendy bougie "seafood palace" in HK- minus the giant flat screen TVs, scrolling ticker symbols and news headlines at every table. it expensive, but hey so is the same vibe in HK. i wouldn't expect any less out of koi.

they have a decent beer and wine list, and i love that i can have a speakeasy tallulah with my dim sum. 

DISLIKES: service. they really don't have their sh*t together- random courses take forever (after 3 or 4 rounds of checking with the manager and the kitchen), the rookie that asked me three times and gave me a triple take (and a " really dude?" look)  when i asked for change for $30 on a $20 tab, checks that take forever to show up, sometimes gruff and overeager busboys (i had one smack my table like a las vegas strip(per) flyer) but at least they are always friendly and courteous and very attentive.

its never clear whether they are going for a western "one waiter takes care of the table" or a chinese  "just flag down someone that looks like in a position of authority" style of service. i think the former, but i've also had all kinds of random people follow up/ bring me checks. again, i would expect koi to have this down like they do in DC.

MEH: dim sum. flavor is great and on point, and similar to what i would expect from koi. anyone that says they prefer yank sing is definitely not chinese... koi knows what it tastes like in HK
what's off for me is the execution. the litmus test for dim sum is always how well the wrappers hold up. the har gow came on individual metal spoon/ steaming vessels - which the dried out bottoms stuck to and ripped apart while eating. same with all flavors of soup dumplings. i know there are challenges to maintaining freshness for all day dim sum service, but i would think koi has the art of "steaming to order" down, which makes this even more disappointing as the flavors are so wonderful and authentic.
that being said, i love the convenience to being able to pop into the westfield on a whim at any hour and sortof satisfy my dim sum cravings
author: v d.

description: I have been here once and it's good. Since I work nearby and frequent Chinatown a lot I don't see why M.Y. China has more to offer except presentation and atmosphere. I have been to the R&G Lounge and it's more authentic. Also, dim sum is cheaper in Chinatown and more authentic. At M.Y. China, dim sum is $2 per piece v. $3.30 for 2 steamed pork buns, 2 shu mai and 2 pork dumplings. It depends, if you want an upscale experience and modern Chinese cuisine more suited to American tastes then I recommend M.Y. China.
author: herm p.

description:
What a delightful stop while shopping and a great place when not shopping as well. I have been here three times and have enjoyed my dinning experience every time. 

The crescent bar is a lovely place to sip on a yummy cocktail. Good wine list as well. 

I came here for their opening night and was wowed by the menu selection and finesse of the dishes. I'm not a huge fan of Chinese food in general but I have liked everything I have  had at M.Y. China. Do yourself a favor and get the shumai! 

Be back for more soon and to watch the noodle pulling.
author: Zoe M.

description: After a long(ish) day, we decided to give this place a shot and we were quite happy with this choice. We ordered the Wok Seared Beef Filet, Honey Glazed BBQ Pork, Peking Roast Duck, Whole Wheat Potstickers, and the Spicy Seafood Dumplings. It was weird in which the order that everything came out but everything was quite tasty which led to an enjoyable experience.
author: Shauna S.

description: A great restaurant!! I had an amazing lunch the other day, at MY China!! I was served by Anouk, she was amazing! She was so sweet, and took the time to recommend a glass of wine to pair with my food. The food was fast and amazing!  Everything Anouk recommend was perfect!! Thanks Anouk!!
author: Robert J.

description:
Two words:
Dis. Appointing.
Martin Yan can cook, but the people who work at his restaurant need a few more lessons. Yes, the place is brand new, but you'll pay top dollar for o.k. dim sum, food that lacks the complexity of really great Chinese, small portions and noise.

It's cleaner than most restaurants in Chinatown, which is a plus, but there is no brown rice and no gluten free choices in circa 2012 Northern California. Huh?

If you want clean, natural and organic and tasty cross the bridge to Mill Valley and go to Harmony. For better dim sum in the city, you have a dozen choices, tops being Yank Sing.

Let's hope that over the next few months this place improves its food and moves its menu into the 21st century!
author: Jonathan S.

description:
We were a large party so it was like doing a tasting menu.

We had the pork belly sliders, the boar lettuce wraps, the crispy roast duck, crispy chicken, crispy quail, beef pulled noodles and sauteed bok choy, 

The food in general was of good quality.  The pork belly sliders were interesting.  The pork belly was well-seasoned and served with what looked like radish slaw.  The boar lettuce wraps were yummy.  The flavor of the boar was really nice against the crisp lettuce.  The roast duck which I guess is their treatment of Peking duck was ok.  The duck skin looked dry and lifeless.  It was crispy and flavorful but not as visually appealing.  The crispy chicken on the other hand was excellent.  Good crispy skin with really moist chicken.   I could've passed on the quail.  With the duck & the chicken, the quail was redundant.  I've had quail all my life and it was a flavor I missed.  Their version was ok but nothing compared to what I've had in the pasts.  I can't comment about the Beef pulled noodles as the kids demolished that dish.  I could only assume that it was not bad.

The service was good.  The waiters were very attentive and we were seated quickly.  The place had great ambiance and was meticulously designed with optimal view of the dome in the outer section of the restaurant.

On a whole, it's not bad food  However for the price paid, you could get the same quality cuisine elsewhere.  Nonetheless I knew that as I stepped out of the elevator at Neiman Marcus that this was going to be an expensive meal.  This is the only reason why it did not get the 4th star as it is really not a great value.
author: Fran C.

description: Had an outstanding dinner here with 7 friends recently.  10 courses and they were all very good to excellent.  The star was Chairman Mao's chicken.  Great flavor.  Great colors.  Nicely portioned.  Glad we ordered two rounds of this.  Stir fried green beans were another big hit.  We did one order as listed (i.e. spicy) and one order not spicy.  Amazingly the non-spicy version had even more depth on the flavor.  Crispy chicken was delicious.  Peking duck was awesome.  Bang bang chicken wings were yummy too - not as spicy as you might think.  Beijing knife cut noodles were great.  Wish we had ordered more of those.  We modified the chow fun and had them prepare it with beef instead of venison. Nice.  And we got to see the noodle guy put on his show several times during dinner.  And finally - the service was attentive and quick.  Much better than last time.  Overall it was a fun and delicious meal.
author: Lewis C.

description:
I came here with my brother and his fiancee for his birthday.  I was surprised that they wanted to go to the mall to celebrate, but it was a good choice.  Not what you'd expect from a mall restaurant.  The atmosphere and the decor make you forget that you are inside a mall.  

We had come for an early dinner and it was pretty empty when we arrived.  Later it did get crowded and there were photographers as the mayor was there with a large party.  

We sat near the kitchen, which gave us a good view of the noodle making.  Our server told us that they do a table-side demonstration, but they only do it later in the evening.  My brother's fiancee was disappointed that we were going to miss it and our server made an effort to see if they could start earlier, but it didn't work out.  At least he tried.  

The service was great. Our server was very attentive and friendly...as well as the rest of the staff. It probably helped that there weren't many diners at that time.  

We ordered a lot of food as there were so many things we wanted to sample.  My favorites were the wild boar and pork & black truffle dumplings...part of the Juicy Dumpling Trio.  The third kind in that trio--the pork and crab dumpling--was not a hit at our table.  I also really liked the Wild Boar Scissors Cut Noodles.

My brother and his fiancee are foodies and although they enjoyed the meal they didn't seem too impressed.  I liked it though...the food and the restaurant.  I hadn't heard of this place before we came so had no expectations. I would definitely go back sometime.  

For dessert with had the Sugar Egg Puffs.  Light and delicate.
author: Mari R.

description: Have been here four times, three of which were very good experiences.  Service in general is so-so, but food is consistently good.  Not the most authentic Chinese food but good quality and tasty.  Decor is very nice.
author: A C.

description:
ok, I really didn't want to like it because I can't stand Yan can cook... He acts like an idiot but a friend kept telling me to try it and so I did. Better than I expected. The Beef Noodle Soup is the best. Although a bit pricey, I would do it again. The broth was delicious with no taste of MSG and the beef was tender. Loved the wild boar dumplings and the truffle ones as well. Not sure which I like better, but I do like how each dumpling has its own soup. Great way to catch all the soup gushing out of the dumpling. Loved the portebelli sliders. Nice to have something lite as well. The shrimps were large in the shrimp and avocado rice rolls, 2 to an order. Yummy. And the side order of mushroom has that nice wok flavoring. Best for last .... the Macau egg tart.. perfect size... 3 to an order... I could have eaten 3 more...Order the items you normally do not see on regular Chinese menu. Give it a try. You may be surprised like me.

Btw, for the ones who complain that the soup spoon for the dumpling is too big to put in their mouths..... HELLO.... the soup spoon is suppose to catch all the delicious soup coming out of the dumpling when you politely take a bite out of the dumpling. You don't stick the whole big dumpling in your BIG MOUTH and eat like a chimpmunk!
author: Jay S.

description: Walked up to a 2/3 empty restaurant looking for a table for two. They said it would be 45 mins. Fine keep your resturant empty. Went to Staits instead and got seated right away.
author: Greg M.

description: I really love this place.the food are very good especially the dessert. Our server is Ken who is very friendly and professional. And he even give us a delicious rice pudding for our anniversary . I will definitely go back
author: Tony H.

description: First time here and I started off with the crispy veggie egg rolls. Great choice! Didn't take much time for them to come out hot and smelling great. The mushroom is hidden and tenderly prepared, while the light crisped outside is fried with barely any traces of oil. My friendly waitress qyillchecked up on me as I eagerly ate and typed.
author: T G.

description: We came for a farewell and congrat on her new job for our co-worker.  The food was good but nothing special.  Juicy dumpling combo (good), wild boar scissor cut noodles (Where's the boar?  What boar was there was chopped meat.), green beans (good), roast Peking duck (very good), Yang Zhou fried rice (where the roast pork and shrimp), sugar puffs with chocolate to drizzle, whipped cream and raspberry coulis (no taste).  Not sure if I would go back if I had to pay myself.
author: M. K.

description: Came on one saturday with my family, we orderd lobster and other dishes, have to say they are all amazing. Even i grew up in China, it still taste my hometown flavor. Worth to try! Their noodle dishes are all taste great, i like the recommandation of the scissor cut noodle and beef hand pull noodle, they are the must have dishes.
author: Brighton L.

description: The Four Course lunch is an awesome deal.  More than enough and the Dim Sum is very tasty. Will for sure return.
author: Karl S.

description: I think the food here is very very good and this is my to-to lunch spot when I am downtown shopping.  Always try to come with a couple of people to get a variety of food.  Love the noodle dishes and dim sum.  It is more expensive than the Chinese restaurants in my neighborhood (Inner Sunset) but the food is much better than all except San Tung.  I really like to decor and watching the people preparing the dumplings and noodles.
author: Kay P.

description: Yes it is at the mall, but the decor is great, the atmosphere is nice and the service was very attentive. The kitchen is open space and neat to see the interaction behind the scenes. My other recommendation is to make reservations. They are pretty busy especially on the weekends. We started off with some Smoked Pork Belly sliders, Pork and black Truffle Juicy Dumplings and some Beef hand puled noodle soup. They were all great. When you do order the hand pulled noodles, you do see a cook stretching out the noddles before being dropped in the brothel. It is a great date night with a movie and dinner. Enjoy!!!!
author: Bryan O.

description: If you love Panda Express but feel poor when taking a date there, go to M.Y. China; same food, double the price! M.Y. China specializes in creating an authentic feeling of Bangkok, Liangxiang Prison to be exact. One of the local prisoners at my table crossed the line by ordering dinner while the guards were still on appetizer duty, boy was the guard furious! Some of the other prisoners waited and waited for their dinner to arrive until their stomachs gave up. A lucky few of us made it out alive and were set free only to find out that "were still in the fuckin mall!"
author: Tubyet P.

description: Fantastic food; cool ceilings, too!
author: Will O.

description:
This is a tough review to write.
I really want to give them a higher rating.
The food was very good (four stars). I was with a group of six, so we were able to sample quite a bit of the lunch menu. It was all good. Very fresh flavors, very well executed.
The waiter was good, friendly without being overly chatty.
However.....
The kitchen was unable to get our food out in a reasonable time, sequence, or spacing.
Dishes dribbled out over an hour and a half. Our rice came after we had been eating for well over 45 minutes.
Tea took thirty minutes.
Two or three dishes would come out together, then nothing for thirty minutes more.
Or sometimes there was only a few minutes between deliveries.
We started our meal at 1:30, so it was after the lunch rush and was not very crowded.
After we finally finished our meal around 3:00, they had the nerve to try and rush us out.
They have great potential, but really need to work on their timing.
author: Ken P.

description:
The restaurant looks great, the staff is courteous, the food was presented well but the taste is just ok for me. It's over priced too. I think they serve very Americanized Chinese food which is why non-Asians seem to love this place so much. 

I enjoyed the meal but would not go out of my way to eat there again.
author: Paula U.

description:
hostess almost turns you off, talking to the officer, I braved a front and stepped up.

bartender was attentive but not overbearing

the menu a bit more then when I first stopped by..probably because that was when they opened.  

the Beijing dumplings? not what I expected, I guess that comes from being a more (I hope) refined or couture style of food...but nope, the taste was OK. am sad that they decided to have the dumpling on top of a very shallow pool of sauce..rather then on the side..

same with dan dan noodles, not horrible, but not spectacular either, when straying from what you'd usually expect.

the mapo tofu was pretty good,  surprised they had it considering the other offerings but good nonetheless.

didn't have custard buns but BBQ..

the place is really pretty, even the unisex bathroom..staff save hostess part is genuinely friendly, but alas, the food is Ok for the price commanded..even in the more pricy part of the mall.
author: Whitne Y.

description:
Expensive place for rather ordinary food. Much better chinese food is available in other less expensive restaurants in the city and bay area.

We had reservations but still had to wait 20min to get a table which happened to be outside in the mall hallway which was an added disappointment.

We ordered lamb wok, vegetarian longevity noodles and chicken wings. I would rate the lamb wok at 4 stars. The rest were 3 star dishes.

Overall, it was okay to try once. Probably not worth visiting again.
author: S P.

description: I look back on some reviews and think, ok it's time to update. This place does qualify for "Yay! I'm a fan," but not for what you might think. It isn't for the food, which is good, not authentic though. It isn't for the atmosphere, which is actually reminiscent of Vegas. Definitely not the price, unless it's happy hour which carry double digits for all a la carte items. It's the people. And that aspect can be sorely missed in any business. In fact, for me a good review is based 50% on the service. I just went to a Leica store to buy cameras that average $4k a piece, and that place made me feel dead inside. Especially since I did buy one and found out I couldn't return it after I bought it, but I digress. The people at M.Y. China are great. I love the young staff, and yeah I'm being biased but I now go here once every 2 weeks. I'm not the best at customer service myself, and it's always been something I've worked on, and if I can't do a good job, or don't feel 100% myself I get someone else to be that shining light, because customers and clients come first and everyone deserves to be treated good. Their there to support you. Why wouldn't you try your best to make them happy? You look at a lot of bad reviews on Yelp. Sometimes it's the food, but more times it's the service. I know I said some not so great things about Martin Yan basically selling out, and I stand by that he can probably do more to spread Authentic food at least to keep American's educated on what Chinese eat, but he has a great team driving his restaurant. I enjoy the people there very much and even when it gets crowded....I'll wait and wait to grab a seat. Thumbs up for friendly service.
author: Marcus C.

description: So I've only ate here once! On my way to San Francisco right now just to eat here again! Yes, I drive all the way from Sac just for this food! I've been craving it since my last encounter! Everything about it was amazing. Should consider opening one in the sacramento area! Not that I mind coming to the city!
author: Blair H.

description: Chinese Fusion.  Went there today for lunch with my son (3) and husband.  Waited about 15 minutes for a table- which is good for this place because we have tried before and the waiting list was at times an hour.  Sat down in what seemed to be the kid section (toward the back of the restaurant).  Food was good- mainly ate "dimsum".  All very tasty but on the pricey side (but that's what you pay for quality and prime location).  Gave it 4 stars because the restrooms were not stocked (no handsoap) and toilet seat was up (unisex restroom).   If they are going to do a unisex restroom they should do what the Slanted Door in the Ferry Building does and pay someone to clean up after each person uses the restroom to ensure that its up to par.
author: Annalisa T.

description: their food was surprisingly good for a restaurant located inside a mall. very good service too! Our server was always there when we needed her. I don't like how close the table are to each other though. I dont talk very loud and if you get seated to people who love to hear themselves talk, well there goes your catching up time! lol Just settled with watching the warriors game on our phones since surprisingly, the sfsu wifi is working there xD
author: Niko B.

description: This is like the best place to try Chinese food without going to Vancouver or Hong Kong or the suburbs.  In a Mall? you ask?  Yes.  It doesn't feel like a mall if you are seated inside with the Buddhas.  The food is really fresh, done to perfection.  This is a good introduction to good Chinese food, no more greasy hole in the wall places for you.  This is upscale!  You've arrived.   Martin Yan really took the time to make sure the dining experience is special.  The waitstaff actually smile.  The best seat is at the open kitchen to watch the noodle demonstration.  They actually are dancing with the noodles.  That is so cool.  There is no MSG.  If only, I had lots of money.  You would have to ask for chili sauce or mustard or soy sauce if you like those stuff.  The fried spare ribs is to die for, but don't even look at the smart phone for calories.  Did anyone say spicy chicken wings?  This drinking food.  The baby bok choy, little tiny "big" pearls.
author: Helen L.

description:
I've been to a lot of Chinese places from here to Taiwan and this place has amazing food, quality, service! 
5 stars!!!!
Must try!
The beef noodle soup is amazing! Better than Taiwan!
Dim sum is perfect texture, flavor, ingredients (best dim sum in Bay Area!)
Martin yan was there too saying hi to everyone :)
author: A C.

description: Had a meeting to go to but my tummy was grumbling. Stopped into this place at the mall thinking...mall food. But happy hour is $5 for some small apps. $3 beer n $6.wine.  the wait to order took a little bit as it was busy but they check back at reasonable periods. All in all food was decent for the price.
author: Sharra C.

description: My girlfriend and I went here and ordered 4 items: hot and sour soup, peppered beef, bok chow, and a cup of coffee. Our waiter forgot the soup AND the coffee and we had to remind him about both. To be fair, they did comp. the cost of the soup, but it wasn't very good anyway. The beef and bok chow dishes were both good but probably over prices. All in all we weren't very impressed, especially for the price.
author: Brian V.

description: The soup dumplings with pork and truffle were good, but worth $18?  Not sure.  The funny thing was that each was served individually on an oversized ceramic soup spoon within the bamboo steaming chamber and the spoon handles were scary hot to touch, so had to wait to pick them up to eat them and by that time, the dumplings were starting to cool off a lot.  And, the oversized ceramic spoons were impossible to fit in the mouth.  How can you eat this without looking like a piggy?  The beef noodle soup was good and the chunks of beef were huge and fatty.  No complaints there, but had to de-fat the meat or eat it in its full fatty form, which many people do.  Not my preference.  It was good, but didn't wow me.
author: B S.

description: Food is average. Service here is terrible. They charged me for a dish that I didn't order. I asked that the charge be removed and the waiter ran around looking for his manager and eventually told me that he couldn't find him. You can't sit a customer down for an extra 20 minutes because you can't find your manager to remove a charge on a bill. Horrible.
author: Julia H.

description:
I absolutely love this restaurant!!!  I went with my room-mate for lunch; and was seated right in front of the noodle pullers.  I highly recommend doing so; we were so entertained both by action & the stories being told by the only white guy in the kitchen.  He was such a hoot!!

The meal we were serve was so delicious that I wanted to lick that even 8 hours later we are still talking about it.  Because it was our first time there, we decided to get several dishes and share them.  This also I highly recommend; there is just so much on the menu that sounds good.  

To start off, we got the M.Y. Dim Sum Collection.  I comes with shiu mai, har gow, steamed bbq pork boa, multi grain sticky rice, a crispy spring roll and a Macau egg tart.  The dim sum was high class; the egg tart was so light & flaky - (definitely NOT like the heavy tarts that a person is  usually given at those cheap buffets).  Our next course we ordered the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup.  OMG!!  This was soo good that I wanted to lick the bowl right in front of everyone.  When the waitress tried to take  the very large bowl away, I started to grieve.  The last small eat we had was the Salt & Pepper Calamari.  The calamari was well seasoned and tender to the tooth.  

Obviously this menu was well thought out; and the chefs there have perfected their craft.  We cannot stop talking about the noodle soup!!  We are already planning our next meal there at M.Y China.
author: Tina E.

description: Greatest restaurant ever! Very nice people and wonderful food. Not completely overpriced but not exactly cheap. But very high quality and very clean!
author: Jean W.

description: Not only a perfect meal but trained guides(M.Y. China word for wait staff)  made ordering a delight. Favorite dishes include Forbidden Rice, Dim Sum menus were scrumptious. This is not just a dim sum restaurant it is so much more! Small plates, full lunch and dinner fare with some outstanding offerings; walnut shrimp, honey glazed lamb chops, Peking duck is luscious and you will want to try all the deserts. The setting for all this is remarkable from the many ton great cast Bell from China to the 36 Buddha Monks individually placed on a wall. We didn't to leave
author: John D.

description: The operation was confusing; why would a nice restaurant close at 9pm when the movie theater nearby in the same mall is open past midnight? The kitchen closed at 830pm - only half an hour after our reservation time. Some of our dishes weren't available. Our waiter saved the evening by apologizing, getting us substitute dishes and a couple of free ones. The food was solid, though not memorable.
author: Mike H.

description:
we had to wait about 20 minutes during an off peak lunch hour 2pm for a table for two.

the place is decorated way more than any other chinese restaurant.  maybe sino at santana row. martin yan was running around while we tried to have lunch here.  he wanted us to pay attention to the hand pulled noodle dance.  we even got a bit of raw noodle.

we ordered har gow and also beef handpulled noodle soup.  the shrimp dumpling wasnt the best.  the dough wrapper stuck to the metal holder and it tasted a bit stale or frozen before.  the beef noodle soup was pretty good.  the noodles were good.  i dont know why i expected a better texture from hand pulled noodles.  the beef was super fatty
author: claudia y.

description: Solid offering. Largely free of SF foodies, which makes for a better quality dining experience.
author: John M.

description: Just left there 2 hours ago.  Horrible, horrible experience.  Service-wise. The waiter was not even apologetic.  The Assistant Manager was not even sincere in his apologies. Why were we treated that way?  Was it the way we look?  Isnt "Old Navy" shirts, jeans and sneakers not acceptable in your place? Im sure it's not a race thing.  Do we look like we don't have money?  We're not rich, but we can afford upscale dining from time to time. People around us (people who came after us) are leaving after enjoying their meal. But us?  we had to wait for a long time.  But when orders came, they were the wrong ones.  Twice.  What is going on?!
author: Una H.

description: Probably 4.5 stars. Surpassed all expectations. Great dumplings, delicious entrees, amazing tea, and spectacular setting. Longer review is on Chowhound. Will be back!
author: Michael B.

description: Food is good.Service is fast and quick.Order jasmine tea for my drink, had to return the tea cup big crack check quality control pls... such a beautiful ambiance all around had to be perfection.But all in all we finish happy and satisfied.Such a good thing that you can order half Peking duck my fave served w/ that fluffy buns.Our steamed dumplings cute presentation. Just enough for two one serving of the pulled noodle w/ big medallions of beef even better if it serves really hot.Were definitely coming back
author: Lolit F.

description: This place has a nice ambiance, and to me is like a glorified P.F. Chang's. Same kind of food, but pricier. We got the wonton soup, ok, best part was the wonton's since the soup had a very distinct ricey taste. Also had the shanghai noodles, good, but again nothing special and a crispy chicken dish that was good as well. I would think it would be less Americanized based on the "celebrity" chef, I would go back with a big group, it is a overall nice place with good service.
author: Misha Z.

description: Celebrated my birthday here with friends.  Wonderful experience.  Cooking demonstrations. Mr Martin Yan was there came to the table several times made me a special desert and was great host.  Food was great. And thoroughly recommend this restaurant.  Selena was our waitress and she was great !!
author: Skye G.

description: The food was very good.  We had to seat at the bar because of the wait and we did not have time, but we enjoyed the environment.  If you can it would be worth the wait to seat at a table.  The chicken and the pork was very good and service was topnotch.
author: Steve M.

description: We visited San Francisco and found M.Y. China near our hotel to dine as our last dinner in SF. The restaurant was easily found and looked clean and classy. We ordered Beijing Knife Cut Noodles, Garlic Pea Shoots, and Mapo Organic Tofu. The noodles were served cold and tasted horrible (I'm a noodle lover). The pea shoots were good. The mapo tofu was not impressive. I would dine at somewhere else if I had known..
author: Shoku U.

description: I had some reservation going to this place.  However, the food was surprisingly good; it's just not traditional Chinese.  The decor and service is nice.  The quality of vegi and meat is top, and the flavor is nice.  The price is on high-side.  I wouldn't go back here for my normal Chinese meal out since there are so many nice inexpensive traditional Chinese restaurants in Bay area.  However, I'll consider taking out of town non-Asian guests here for a pleasant introduction to Chinese food.
author: Yoon L.

description: Twice the price for food you could find just as good almost anywhere else in town. It's like you're paying for the privilege of eating in a fancy mall more than anything else.
author: Jacob M.

description: I was having dinner tonight.  Fifth time visited this place.  I always order the scissor cut noodles, wild Boar Lettuce cups, Shanghai dumpling.  I tried the dessert  Panacotta, very good. They have the happy hours menu.  I would like to try next time.
author: Lulu H.

description: The service and the ambience is fantastic. Beautiful decor. We sat in front of the wok stations. Watching the chefs in action was really cool. The wheat potstickers and the fried tofu were mediocre. The wild boar lettuce wraps are worth a try. The highlight was the Beijing knive-cut noodles (really tender and well-seasoned).
author: Laura W.

description: We've eaten here several times and have never been disappointed.  Food is exceptional.  Service is a bit amateurish, but well intentioned. A favorite downtown.
author: Yella W.

description:
I was bummed that it wasn't a mind blowing experience for us. It's what a customer would naturally expect for paying such high prices for Chinese food in a town where we can easily find hundreds of great, authentic, Chinese restaurants (the best in the nation!). The food was prepared fine and tasted OK but it seemed to lack passion and creativity... Not even when it comes to garnishing. The outside looks upscale but effort says otherwise. More importantly it tasted like it lacked "wok hay". You'll have to Google that but only experienced chefs can get it right and it's difficult to define (but not difficult to identify when you taste the difference!) It is one of the most important attributes that Cantonese people look for in Chinese food. It's what gives food life and excitement. Merely being palatable is not enough.

We had Chairman Mao's Chicken, which I expected to be drenched in some kind of sauce but wasn't...just a basket of crispy breaded chicken pieces with dipping sauce. We didn't even get any veggies in ours just a basket of breaded chicken. (Come to think of it nothing we had came with veggies not even for looks). This was listed as an entree item not a side or appetizer so I was already disappointed with our main course. I felt mislead. We were going to have this over our white rice but it just didn't go well together texture wise. It's definitely not like walking into a traditional Chinese restaurant, ordering any main course and being able to co-mingle everything together over rice. More upsetting that I look online at another version of the M.Y. China menu and this item is listed as a "bar item" / small bites and not an entree. (And it was $9 not the $16 we paid). This is equivalent to a restaurant adding a few extra chicken wings to their appetizer and changing it to a dinner plate...sorry but whether it's 6 pieces or a dozen, it's still an appetizer.

We also had whole wheat potstickers which were yum, salt and pepper calamari which was mediocre (edible but had no pizzazz in terms of preparation and presentation), 2 bowls of white rice, Peking duck (very good fresh buns but stingy on the duck skin...which weren't crispy and hot either. All I tasted was bun and no skin), and mu shu pork tacos which I enjoyed because it was different though my husband did not like the combination. 

Overall we spent about $80 which easily could have gotten us a family style Chinese dinner for 6 elsewhere. I was really hoping to either find some really great authentic food or something off the wall different but M.Y. China doesn't quite achieve either of them. Though the food will suit American tastes just fine, it might not be the place to take your Chinese parents to but it made for a nice date night for us. Even got to watch the light show under the dome while we ate. My only regret is not trying the noodles as fresh pulled noodles have got to be pretty awesome.

One last thing worth mentioning was the service. I don't know what happened but it went from excellent service at the beginning of our meal to nosediving at the end. The table next to us had a different server from us...however we finished eating around the same time. Up until that point, we had extremely attentive servers who kept coming to check on us. Then they suddenly disappeared. Not for 10 minutes, but for over 30 minutes. It was so bad, that the table next to us had to get up and wander towards the back of the restaurant looking for their waiter so they could pay the bill. They were visibly upset and so were we. From what we could tell no one was able to help them in the back either (I'm assuming the server had the bill). We had to waive a busboy down to help us...who looked unsure how to help us, even asking if we wanted him to box our food or us to do it ourselves. When our server finally got back to us (we waived him down), he wasn't apologetic and maybe was oblivious to how long we were waiting. He never offered dessert or anything...which I probably would've liked to try.

Finally, the bill....which came clamped inside a giant metal fortune cookie. As cute as it may be, I'm surprised by how no one knew this would be a bad idea..HELLO? a huge bill in a fortune cookie for the incredibly superstitious? 1. It's like handing someone a red envelope with a "You Owe ME" in it and  # 2. Can you say Cliche'? Fortune cookies are about as authentic to Chinese food as the Taco Bell chihuahua is to Mexican food. #3. What are you wishing on me as I'm about to leave your establishment? Chinese people can we all together say "CHOY GOH NAY!" While we grab some incense to re-bless ourselves from your ignorance of our customs and beliefs. WTH? LMAO!
author: Carol A.

description: We had ordered a ginger onion live crab and it was nothing even close to a live crab taste.  The meat had shrunk 2 sizes like it had been microwaved and it was hard and chewy.  The hot and sour soup had a strange "bamboo sitting in water" smell.  The only thing that was good was their shangdong beef roll and their beef noodle soup. If you are charging ppl $42+ for a crab at least get the stuff that the regular chinese restaurants sell. Those are cheaper and taste much better.
author: Mee-stique K.

description: This is a very stylish restaurant in the Westfield Mall. Particularly like the Dim Sum sampler on the Menu. Also, like the Shandong Beef Rolls and Braised Green Beans.
author: David R.

description: The food was very good but the service was a little lacking. After seating us, we had to wait quite a while to get our orders in. They didn't even bring our drink order and the food was being served already. I figured that this might have been a busy night for them even for a Monday night but the restaurant didn't look 50% full.
author: Tony L.

description: OMG finally this restaurant is open xD  we went yesterday and the food was heavenly GOOD!!! We had the 5 Spice pork ribs the pineapple sea food rice the dan dan doodles and the dumplings of shrimp delicious!!!  we have been here many times more then 7 i think since it open xD
author: Doris F.

description:
Great ambience with a view of the chefs at work.

I thought the few dishes I had for lunch were OK, but nothing too special. Maybe it's the philistine in me, but the hand-cut noodles didn't taste any better than pre-packaged ones elsewhere. 

I also had the cheung-fun. Instead of the traditional wide rice noodles wrapped around minced meat and steamed, their version consists of little rolled-up noodles and stirred fried. Kinda like Chinese gnocchi. Didn't work for me.

Similarly, chow fun with chunks of venison would have been better with the traditional sliced beef. Venison is just too lean and tasteless for this dish.

Finally, Westfield Mall basically forces a customer to wander thru most of the mall +/- Nordstrom's to get to and from the restaurants. Yeah, I know it is designed to lure shoppers, but it is incredibly annoying and actually decreases my likelihood of repeat visits.
author: Bill T.

description: It's upscale mall food. Sorry, I can't say it differently. Not bad and it was suitably Chinesey as opposed to PF Chang. My duck was good. I was effin hungry and I ate it. The tea was really nice and was perhaps worth the price. Also the waiter was attentive and that's saying a lot since my aura tends to cause humans to stay as far away from me as possible lol. The overall feeling was that it was very commercial Chinese food. Take it or leave it.
author: Miguel L.

description: Yan Can Cook! We had a wonderful lunch here! Our party of three ordered pot stickers, kung pao chicken, dan dan noodles, and forbidden rice. The food was really, really good. We were seated right away, and our server was very pleasant and attentive. As an added bonus, we were seated facing out to the mall so that we could people-watch. And boy, was that some good scenery! We plan to come back on our next trip to SF.
author: Lisa W.

description: Nice atmosphere. The Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup is just awesome. Roasted duck however is a bit disappointing. Still, four star.
author: Max Z.

description: Don't get the Dan Dan noodles. I was expecting the peanutty buttery taste of goodness but his style is more "Americanized" with vinegar and chilies and it wasn't the kind of noodle I prefer. But the Beef noodle soup was good and the szechuan green beans were great as well. Wished I caught Martin Yan there though.
author: Jamie T.

description: The Dim Sum here is delicious. This is one of the best pricier Chinese restaurants in San Francisco. Too bad Martin Yan wasn't here when I was.
author: Leo T.

description: Great for the novelty and great if you're into celebrity chefs. I'm glad I tried this place. The food was "A-OK" hence the solid three stars. The service was okay. For a Chinese restaurant though, they should really have a few more chinese characters on the nearly all-English menu. If you were a fan of Martin Yan / Yan Can Cook, you should definitely try this place at least once. Otherwise, I'd only go if I was already in the area (and craving chinese food in a nicer atmosphere than usual).
author: Peggy N.

description: The food here is absolutely outstanding.  I went in with high expectations and was surprised at how they were topped.  Things not to miss: Peking duck (wow!), shrimp dumplings, wild boar noodles, and if you are a Kung Pao fan like I am, this one is one of the best versions I've ever had...and I've tried a lot.  I think the small kinks in service will smooth themselves out after this joint is open a little while longer.  Going to make this place a regular habit and attempt to try everything on the menu if the mention items don't steer me off that course for needing repeat tries!
author: e w.

description:
The food and service was good but overpriced.

I came here with my boss and coworkers. There were 5 of us and we ordered:

Pork and Crab Juicy Dumplings - the dumplings were good. The only issue I had was that they steamed the spoons with the dumplings so the spoon was so hot, you couldn't pick it up from the steam tray. I get it looks pretty but how do you expect people to eat it without burning their fingers and their lips?!

Wild Boar scissor cut noodles - Pretty good. A little on the oily side.

Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood - the noodles were cut into tiny bite size pieces..you could barely find any noodles in the dish! Really a bummer because the main ingredient is the squid ink noodles.

Honey glazed walnut shrimp - Shrimps were huge! Very tasty dish.

Honey glazed BBQ pork - nothing special. Just typical BBQ pork you can get at any other Chinese restaurant

Half Peking Duck - Crispy skins and soft buns. Delicious!

Stir Fried Green beans - Has a kick to it but good. 

Forbidden Rice - We ordered it cuz it's "forbidden" =) Not much flavor

Chinese Brocolli - same as what you can get at a typical Chinese restaurant except this one cost 10x more.

Overall, the food here is decent, but you can get the same food at much cheaper price elsewhere. I will not be coming back.
.
author: Jenny L.

description: Last night is my first time to M.Y.China.The food is realy nice.Tony Wu is a true chief.He is be good at cooking，humor and affinity.I enjoy last night. It was nice memory for me。
author: Yu W.

description: calm environment...good location/view in the mall...good service...good food...so overall, pretty good!  would go back
author: Ara L.

description:
We enjoyed the food there quite a bit!
Our expectations were limited because the restaurant is in a mall and is fairly new
We tried both the Dim Sum menu as well as noodles and they were all excellent
Each dish was very fresh and the noodles each had a twist
We will be back for more!
author: FOO D.

description: Amazing Dinner experience. We had numerous dishes but our favorites were the deep fried crab, juicy dumplings, salt and pepper calamari, jasmine tea smoked sea bass, crispy roast chicken, Big Knife fish noodles, and Sugar Egg Puffs. Would highly recommend!
author: Jody O.

description: The Beijing noodles were tasty, but was cold by the time it reached our table (unless that's supposed to be the way they're served). I liked the seared beef fillet a lot, and the mapo tofu was pretty good. The special smoked duck appetizer was good too, like duck tacos but with steamed rice bread instead of tortillas. The Buddha beer was interesting... a beer bottle actually shaped like Buddha. God's elixir? Friendly server, nice decor--you'll forget you're at the mall if you sit inside.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
We were in the area so we decided to try this place out. Unfortunately since we didn't know of the place before hand, we weren't able to get a seat to watch the noodles. Taste wise, the noodles and Siu Long Bow were pretty good. The fried green beans weren't too bad either. I would definitely suggest trying the noodles if you come here!

Price wise, this is definitely more expensive than your normal chinese restaurant, and I wouldn't say it's that much better. It was pretty good, but you could get the same thing at a regular Chinese restaurant for less. It's probably a little higher quality than what you normal get, but I wouldn't say it's worth it. If you're in the area, it's not a bad place to eat, but if you have a hankering for some Chinese food, it's not worth the trip out!
author: Justin W.

description: superb food. travelled all over asia including shanghai and this place is on par with any meal in shanghai.  highly recommended!
author: Paul B.

description: My wife and I love peking duck and rank MY China as the best in San Francisco.  We devoured an entire duck with a side of bok choy and finished our feast with an order of the Chinese donuts with the dipping sauce. As an added pleasure to this meal we were served by a very courteous and knowledgeable young lady Victoria.  She was a delight  and when we return we definitely will have the duck again and ask for Victoria.
author: Don B.

description:
I left MY CHINA immediately recommending it.  These folks have done something amazing, creating a destination restaurant in a mall with no parking. The food was that good!

I was surprised to see a full crowd at 5:30, wonderful servers, interesting spots to view but most important of all -- the quality. The spring rolls were so simple, such clean taste and absolutely perfect. Clearly attention was taken to get the very best shrimp.

The tea was incredible. It got better with each cup and I learned that the comes from washing the leaves to bring out a deeper, more profound flavor. I believe I had the People's Tea. Incredible and it seemed so healthy.

The real feat is great presentation, wonderful Chinese food without the heaviness and additives and in a California style with emphasis on freshness. You can get a single dish and be out for $20 or eat heavily and be out at about $50 and you'll feel like you were eating healthy as well as filling fare that sticks with you.

The plate I had with the gogi beans (?) and red berries (?) was absolutely delicious and clearly a plate to be shared for two. The multiple kinds of rice with the tiny bits of pineapple was "to die for" and yet I couldn't taste any kind of sauce. This was a rice that would be ruined by the addition of Tamari or soy. Absolutely delicious.


The green beans just made me plain envious. I steam all the time but I don't create the kind of simple excitement MY CHINE  did with the beans and again this was plentiful enough to share .


Due to some other engagements I missed dessert but looking at the menu the desserts seemed quite exotic and I was told that they too were made fresh or took some time to prepare.


The freshness, clean clear tastes, ambiance, pure fun, make this a delightful experience that can be compounded by shopping before or after dinner. I love the Buddha room and think it would be an ideal place to stage parties.
author: ALLEGRA A.

description: Worst experience we have had in a long time.  Waiter never asked us if we wanted beverage other than water.  Ordered most expensive appetizer, a pork truffle dumpling that didn't have a hint of truffle.  Then ignored for 45 minutes.  Tables on both sides of us seated after us were served and nearly done when 2 of 3 dinners arrived, one cold.  The cold pork returned to be warmed and I was told to continue eating, not to let mine get cold.  I finished my dinner before the other dinners arrived.  No dessert was offered although we were told the cold pork would be removed from our bill, and it was.  I had to ask for the bill 3 times.  I will never return.
author: Lark H.

description: This place as not what we expected at all. Itwas our first time here, so of course we had many questions,yet our server seemed annoyed with our questions,and very short with her answers She would also walk inthe middle of questions.  I had very high expectations for this place and was very disappointed.The food was mediocre at best.It was not authentic in the least.  I've had better Chinese at Panda Express. To top it off many of us got sick!  Terrible service, poor quality food way overpriced....bad deal all the way around.
author: Kelly G.

description: My husband and I wanted to try a restaurant "under the Dome" at Westfield, and chose the new M.Y. China because of the chance to view friendly kitchen staff making, swinging fresh noodles (which only keep for two hours), effortlessly assembling soups and dim sum on our side. We sat right at kitchen counter, watching them enjoy their work, while the wait staff pampered us. We chose hot and sour soup - rich, lovely broth. So good. Mu Shu Pork tacos - also mouthwateringly tasty and light. Chicken potstickers were ever so tender, with rich dipping sauce, BBQ sliced pork was good but less eventful. What a joy to be at the best Chinese restaurant we have experienced, even living in SF for last 43 years. Such a high standard and quality. Cannot wait to try the Beef Noodle soup which a lot of the other tables were enjoying.
author: Carolyn D.

description:
Overall pretty good for a recently opened restaurant.

The spectacle is key so opt to sit near the open kitchen! You can watch the cooks cut and pull noodles in interesting manners.

The food was underseasoned in general, but the place delivers on the traditional flavors.  I would think the timid seasoning was due to simply being cautious in light of an American palate.

The beef noodle was very flavorful. The broth was very well seasoned, albeit a tad bit sweet. Sliced ribeye was the choice and it does deliver both the flavor and fattiness that suits the dish. Traditionally, it would be something like beef shin, but I think that wouldn't be as accessible to most people.

Five Spice Ribs were basically the salt and pepper pork cutlets you find in chinatown. Ribs were probably chosen because they have fewer bones and are easier to eat. The five spice was barely tastable, but the tempura like batter was very crispy and aggressively salted. This did provide a good contrast.

The springrolls may have been a tad bit overcooked. They likely should have been fried at a higher temperature, but I noticed that several orders came out at once. This would suggest that the cooks packed too many into a single fryer, resulting in a more mushy filling (overcooked). The crust was still very crisp, but a tad bit palid (also suggesting an lower temperature fryer).

The pricing is good 10-15$ per entree and the service is very attentive. The kitchen may be a bit slow but I suspect it's due to training and the speed will improve with time. The atmosphere is nice; the tables are a bit tight, but no uncomfortably so.

If you're from the East Bay, this is everything Noodle Theory should be...
author: Charlie H.

description: The front of house is atrocious.  They manage a list for walkins but you will never get in even between meal times. We waited an hour an a half for 2 people and they kept calling people from the wait list that had already left.  I understand that walkins have to wait but be honest with people about the wait time.  My suggestion is that you train some people.  Too bad, the food looked good.
author: James B.

description: Martin Yan and company did a good job with this new restaurant.  Very modern (looks like one of the Las Vegas hip restaurants).  A little more training of the staff, but all in all - a good experience.  Food is a tad pricey for Asian food, but as everything else in the City.  Delicious entrees!
author: Lou E.

description: Under the big top! What a circus. Loved the way you can watch the kitchen cut, cook, and juggle the noodles. The chef set out a beautifully carved watermelon (looked like a giant chrysanthemum) and a carved pumpkin (looked like a peacock.) Wow.  He also walked around with a huge bundle of noodles and let people touch them and even take samples. Everyone loved it. We sat at the long row of two tops. It's more like a communal table and our fellow diners were comparing and talking about the food as they ordered. After looking around and seeing what people were eating. We had the Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles, Garlic pea shoots, Spicy Green Papaya Pickles, Jasmine pearl tea and Sugar Egg Puffs. Everything was great except the pickles They were bland. Could have used some spice. The Egg Puffs were divine! Hot and sugary. If I could sing, I would have sang to those puffs. Now for the clang. I don't mind co-ed bathrooms but you have to have an attendant in there. Some hu-Mans might have mad skills just no bathroom skills.
author: Liz J.

description: I think there are enough reviews to give you a good idea of what to expect. The food and the service in my opinion are mediocre. There are much better food and service options nearby to waste your time here.
author: Maggie D.

description: Good place to dine alone or with friends. The service & food are both decent. The wait isn't bad & just right at the shopping mall.
author: Frost L.

description: Food is mixed...some dishes were quite decent (e.g. noodles, stir fried pea sprouts), others were mediocre (e.g. Peking duck which tasted more like Cantonese roast duck).  Great for people who don't have distinguishing palates for real quality Chinese food.  The space is beautiful.  Very good cocktails.
author: Eric C.

description: The sugared egg puffs, alone, are worthy of my 5-star rating; they're THAT good. Do yourself a favor and look past the fact that it's in a mall (albeit a high-end mall).
author: Dimitri S.

description: Ate here for the third time and the squid ink noodles are one of my "must have" dishes. So unique and different and a very colorful presentation. Good mix of seafood, too. Some places say "scallops" and you get one measly scallop but this wasn't the case here.
author: John R.

description: We had a much anticipated dinner last night at MY China and sadly, our experience did not live up to our expectations.  We had made a reservation but when we arrived were made to wait in line with those who did not and were seated in the mall area where we were treated to the howls of screaming children throughout our dinner.  The waitress recommended the Hot and Sour Soup which tasted exactly like a base of Campbell's Tomato Soup with some wood ears and bamboo shoots added.  Plus she assured us it was enough for two, but it came in a small bowl with only one spoon.  Blah.  The beef rolls were tasty but, to coin a old cliche "WHERE'S THE BEEF?".  There were only one or two small nuggets the size of an almond in each roll. The chili crab was very good but it was not cracked and we had to ask for crab utensils.   Cocktails were excellent.  All in all it just didn't live up to the hype and the wait staff could have been much more attentive.
author: Katherine W.

description: I came in on a Wednesday for lunch, ate like a king and thoroughly enjoyed my experience. Although the food was delicious, the drinks perfectly prepared, what really stood out and earned this restaurant a 5-star review was the service! Our server, Ivan was so sweet, so attentive, so friendly and went out of his way to ensure our satisfaction. I will definitely be returning soon! THANK YOU MY CHINA!
author: Chicken N.

description: Extremely oily food, tried half a dozen dishes, and all of us left with a really upset stomach. if you want to try this loser, please ask for "dry" food. So many other fine restaurants in SF... avoid this mall food. Also very slow service. ZERO  STARS
author: doron b.

description:
Hostess was a disaster and service was mediocre.  We were a walk-in (4 of us).  It was 8:30 on a Saturday.  She looked at us like we were crazy and said that they weren't even taking reservations.  We decided to go somewhere else.  But as we left, I logged onto Open Table and got a reservation at M.Y. China for 8:45.  So we had to wait 15 minutes, no big deal.  But why take a reservation from Open table and not take someone who is standing right there.  There were TONS of empty tables including an enormous table right next to us that the staff used (I guess rather than letting walk-ins sit there).

The waitress was friendly enough, but didn't come by very often and took forever to bring the bill.  There was about a 10 minute gap in between when everyone got their food.  Why not serve everyone at the same time?  And then about 5 minute gap before the sides of rice came.

There are too many good restaurants in this city to waste your time with this one.
author: Eric S.

description: Wanted to try it cause I saw it on TV and of course because its new. But the service was just ok and the food is not that great, and also the portions are little for the price you pay for. It's worth to try once but definitely not going back unless its free.
author: Joiera C.

description: Super tasty scissor cut noodles and crispy fried ones too. Free sparkling water and a great atmosphere make this a great stop if you are near the mall. I would go back again in a second. The only problem seems to be the lame fortune cookies.
author: Huckleberry B.

description: Stayed in Union Square so decided to try M.Y. since it was convenient. Overall pretty good. Had the five spiced ribs, beef roll, wheat potstickers, HK crispy noodles and fried rice. Ribs were probably the best thing we ate. Felt like a more authentic version of PF Chang. Hope that's not offensive to MY, but that's how it felt to me.
author: FF Rainmaker S.

description: If you want to pay a million bucks for dim sum this is your place.  I'd rather spend $5.00 on Stockton in China town for real authentic dim sum.  One dish here starts at $5.00.  Your entire lunch on Stockton will cost $5.00.  Sure there's no cloth napkins and you have to take it to go but let's face it with today's economy who wants to over spend?  Other food we tried beyond the dim sum was nothing worth talking about.
author: David G.

description:
It's not the best chinese food, but the service is great. I came here with family to check it out since we wanted to try a different chinese restaurant than our usual (S&T Restaurant, San Tung, Fat Wong, Koi Palace...etc).  Surprisingly, this is a nice restaurant that offers the usual: honey walnut prawn, crispy chicken, five spice pork ribs, steamed dumplings, stir fried green beans.  We ordered a lot of dishes, but I would have to say most of them were not great and were pretty pricey compared to other restaurants where you can order the same thing.  The honey walnut prawn was bland, perhaps, because the cucumbers just didn't go well with this dish.  I'm not sure if they were trying to counter how unhealthy this dish was with something fresh, but the cucumbers just didn't go well with the prawns.  The crispy chicken was good, but nothing to rave about as well.  Lastly, the five spice pork ribs is really something that I've never tasted nor liked.  Perhaps it is the fact that is was fried dish, but the flavoring was just not doing it for me. 

The restaurant itself is small but it does have nice ambiance.  I'm not too sure how I feel about the chef walking around the restaurant demonstrating the pulled noodles like it's a trick.  I think I'd rather watch them demonstrate at the kitchen (like at Yu's Mandarin in Illinois).  I'm still puzzled why Martin Yan decided to open this restaurant....I just feel the flavors aren't quite there yet.
author: Lisa W.

description: Excellent food, and outstanding customer service!  We've only discovered M.Y. China recently and have only gone twice.  Really enjoyed the Kung Pao Chicken, Steamed Fish, and Squid Ink Noodles.  Highly recommended if you are in the San Francisco downtown area.  The only downside is that they don't have a restaurant in the East Bay where we live.
author: Noel S.

description:
Benihana, PF Changs, McDonalds, Panda Express.  I'll stop there, but will try to communicate my point via analogy.

Panda Express -- one of the most successful fast food chains in history, but no one is confusing this place for Chinese food.  It's cheap, consistent American food and I actually don't mind eating there from time to time when I'm in that mood and I don't have to make an effort.

McDonalds -- even on their best days, quite possibly the worst commercially successful food you'll find.  If you take out price/value, there isn't a single thing on their menu that can compete beyond (maybe) their fries.  But that's not the point.  When you're starving, have no other options, speed maters, and forgot your wallet at home -- you find all of the spare change in your car and head over to their drive through.  They clearly have a place in this world and their business success and growth over time proves this.

Benihana -- yes, started by a Japanese guy, but there's nothing Japanese about this place.  I used to be a little embarrassed going to this sort of place, but certain friends and business parters just can't get enough of it, so I make the trip every now and then.  Unless you actually enjoy the presentations, there's no value here and the food is pretty standard given that it receives so much help being (the equivalent of) pan fried in so much butter and oil.

PF Changs (and similar) -- in these parts, this is where I take business folks or really, really Americanized friends for decent American food with the right ambiance, and no uncomfortable feelings.  No one is going to snicker here if you order some fried rice variant, mu shu pork, or something along the lines of beef broccoli.  It's all good and I'll eat more than my fair share too of "that" food.  Compare to other, so-called authentic Chinese places in the city, Cupertino, or Fremont -- there is no intimidation factor with hoards of native speakers, the service, or the menu.   And lest you think I'm being a Chinese food snob, that really isn't the point at all.  I know Chinese and Japanese food reasonably well, but so what?  I'm sure many of the Indian and Pakistani joints I frequent are considered only so-so by many of my more knowledgeable friends.  No one cares. There's clearly a worthy market here and these businesses are in it to make money, not get caught up in what's more authentic vs. Americanized.  Unless that's directly and strongly connected to making more money.


M.Y. China is clearly in the same bucket as PF Chang's but I think a notch higher.  Better decor, decent celebrity power with Yan (though I wonder how some of his other ventures are doing), and the guy knows what's out there.  Marketing is top notch and the service was great.  He's not going to be able to compete at all on price relative to almost all other "traditional" Chinese venues in the city (very few can), but he's light years ahead of those same venues when it comes to a more American demographic.  And that's definitely intentional.  We're in America, there are a lot of Americans here.


Though I must say that the one of the small dishes we tried (and we tried a lot) which really stood out as an absolute waste of time was the Chairman Mao's Chicken "Small Eats" basket.  Almost no taste, wasn't exactly light, and I couldn't understand what went wrong.  Even roasted chicken with (only) salt and pepper would be far more tasty than this.  Something must have been off that night. 

And I think the mu shu pork tacos were below average as well.  Nothing jumped out in terms of flavor, freshness, or a new interpretation on this fusion offering.  Certainly not inedible or bad, but we were all underwhelmed -- two native Chinese, American-born Asians, a World Traveler, and a gentleman from the UK.

(Sure, you can poke fun at anyone who orders a dish with these sorts of names, but that's no excuse.  These guys know how to cook flavorful dishes.)

Finally -- MSG or a lot of sodium in the dishes?  Going through an adjustment period?  We had symptoms.
author: Chris E.

description:
3.5 this is marketing gold.  finally a place to attempt to please the Chinese and non-Chinese alike.  just look at the video screens on the walls with food and prep demoes that draw you in.  open kitchen, clean, with traditional and chinese american dishes.  finally a mainstream place that can break the stereotype of Chinese takeout.  decor great and salesmen waiters.  handmade noodles for all to see.  that will excite the Chinese.  wild boar, truffles, morel mushrooms, etc. all the words to excite the non-Chinese.  
sampled the wild boar scissor cut noodles, nicely stir fried.  the beijing knife cut noodle was not Chinese though, more like gochujang spicy and weirdly mixed with the other ingredients.  the lunch combo with westlake beef soup was weak and had some doughy wontons.  also tried the m.y. china dim sum sampler, which had ok dumplings but is a great way to intro non-Chinese into how to order.  had the pork and crab dumplings (5).  smart to deliver in individual spoons but the wrappers then had too much moisture on the bottom.  flavor was good though.  honey glazed bbq pork was done surprisingly well.  tender and juicy with good flavor, despite the departure from traditional prep and more sesame.  baby bok choy ok.  hats off to a successful venture M.Y.
author: Rob C.

description: Judging by its appearance (very modern and sleek) and Martin Yan's name, it does not look it would offer authentic Chinese food. But to my surprise, their house made noodles are extraordinary, fresh and elastic! You don't find this kind quality (noodle speaking) in many Chinese restaurants. They also offer unique cocktails using traditional Chinese liquor, such as Big Trouble, it is actually a shot of Red Star Er Guo Tou Baijiu with Tsingtao Beer. I think it can be only found in this restaurant.
author: Emmy P.

description: This is not a tradition Chinese restaurant.  If you come with the expectation that this is a traditional Chinese restaurant, you will be disappointed.
author: Stink C.

description: My family & I stumbled upon this gem and absolutely loved it! 5 stars for ambiance, 5 stars for delicious & unique food, and 5 stars for excellent service. Our waiter Bolivar, made our dining experience exceptional! We will definitely be back.
author: Kim G.

description: Bland, oily, mediocre. Their problems are both in the sourcing of the ingredients (inferior products yield inferior results) and the execution (is anyone on staff tasting the food). It just sucked. Thank goodness we ordered the bok choy- somehow they didn't ruin that. Meal was distinctly gross. Never again.
author: Simcha K.

description: Decent food but service could use a lot of improvement. Friend and I tried this place for dinner and the food was decent (braised beef soup and beef rolled pancake) though a bit pricey. However, what really killed it for me was the service. We had to switch table after we ordered due to noise and the new server we had was just a buzz kill. She had no smile on her face, no how was the food, no filling up the glass and no check up on us. If this was in Chinatown I would be ok with that. But if I'm paying 14 dollars doe a bowl of noodle soup the service had better reflect the price. Just unfortunate.
author: Kevin L.

description: Yesterday  was our second time to eat at MY China. The first time we went to the one at The Graton Casino with my uncle and his friends. The staff and service was great but even better at MYChina at the Westfield shopping center.  The food was great as much as we always love asian food, but the server who we believe named Ary, shes so professional, and energetic though we heard she just hurt her ankle, she helped us to figure out what we should eat and drink while we had no clue what to get, shes very helpful. My uncle and his friends were happy that we came back to MYChina again!
author: Erma N.

description: the environment and the servers are very nice here but not the best. I had been a alot of high end restaurants but the price for the food here is not what you are expected.  As a Chinese i have to say this is not real Chinese food. i would not come back to satisfy my stomach again.
author: M.Y B.

description: I liked the atmosphere at the bar (first come, first served), and the service was great.  We had the very filling mu shu pork tacos and the wild boar lettuce cups.  Both were tasty but a tad too salty and nothing special.  The Peking duck was very good though - with steaming hot buns to eat them with.  Good cocktails too.
author: B. Y.

description: We had an average overall meal at M.Y. China. The juicy dumplings were tasty but as other reviewers noted they come on ceramic spoons in the steamer. The spoons are VERY hot and the dumplings stick to the spoon so when cool enough to eat they break open. We prefer our dumplings smaller so you can eat the dumplings in one bite so all the juice can be enjoyed IN your mouth. The Har Gow were also large...I wanted to cut everything but with only a fork and chopsticks this was not easy....in hope they have knives because next time we will ask for them! The steamed pork buns were good but would be improved with more filling...but the dough was one of the best tasting we've had. Our favorite item was the mu shu pork tacos. Service was friendly and attentive. We'd like to try some noodles on our next visit..watching those noodles being stretched and pulled was certainly entertaining.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Fried peppers. The Xiaolongbao were super good, but they were kind of silly how they pumped them up so much. "But how did we get the soup inside???"
