Well, I have the Internet so I know how they get the soup in there. It is quite a delicious menu though, and the service is good, and I wouldn't even feel too bad that it's in the mall. It's a pretty good restaurant. It's in a mall. There's Martin Yan. Yay.
author: Klevin D.

description: Wow, best King Pao I've ever had. Hong Kong crispy noodles where amazing. Waitress went beyond duty, was late with soup, but comped desert, awesome. Highly recommended! Waitress name was Amber.
author: Michael L.

description: While the food is delicious, the prices are a bit too high - have been here twice now and can say that the chicken wings are outstanding, the noodles are perfectly cooked (and fresh made on site), and overall the food is really, really good - however, one is subject to a bit of sticker shock when you get the bill - worth a shot or two, but not on a regular basis - service is great and decor is also very good - noticed a lot of tourists doing the shopping thing (makes sense), however, if you live in the city, I'd say this is a try once type of place.
author: Richard D.

description: Broth was flavorful, mushrooms were plentiful, tofu was yummy, noodles were a little bland.
author: dk h.

description: This is a great addition to the mall.  Although the quality is good, it is expensive.  Everything is fresh and well prepared.  I doubt I would go unless I was in the mall, but I will be back next time I am shopping.
author: Amber B.

description: Stopped in last minute for a quick dinner, we did not have reservations but that did not delay our meal since they seated us at the wok bar which was much better then sitting at a table since we could watch all the chefs cooking and the master chef in all red personally acknowledged all the customers at the wok bar waving to us from the other side of the window. Now on to the food, we ordered the HK Crispy noodle, Wok Seared Beef, Honey Roasted Pork, Jasmine Rice and Iron Tea. Overall all the food tasted great and we finished it all leaving the plates clean. We ended our meal at MY with yummy dessert of Egg Puffs with chocolate & raspberry dipping sauce and whipped cream so good you got to experience this for sure. I will definitely be back to experience more of MY's great food.
author: Masa M.

description:
I am debating for awhile on how many stars I will give MY China and decided to give them one star base on my visit this afternoon.  
The service is pretty good and our waiter is very polite.  For some reason the food service is extremely slow today and we have to ask our waiter to check on our food a couple of times and we are not please about it.  
Here come the main reason I give MY China only one star:  We have a party of four and every course of our food were way too salty!   The dim sum is average (you can get it at any dim sum restaurant for 1/2 the price and taste just as good); the Hot and sour soup taste like sweet and sour sauce; the Kung Pau Shrimp and the beef filet dish portion is good but they were so salty that we need to drink lots of water to wash it down (if they use less soy and salt, it could be wonderful!).  The Beef noodle soup is tasty and once again,way too salty ( it taste very good on the first bite but after a few you realized the bowl of noodle soup is full of salt and msg).  The only dish is decent is the Hong Kong style fried noodle but I expect a little bit more.
After trying Martin Yan restaurants for a couple of times.  I decided I could do without it and so as my other 3 friends.  Sorry Martin, I am a fan of yours for years and enjoyed watching you on TV.  However, my experiences at your restaurants was a little disappointed.  On the other hand, the space is spacious and comfortable.  It is a nice place to meet up with friends.
author: George L.

description:
This is a follow-up review from my last visit this past December.

I decided to give them another try. Although this visit was better, it wasn't better by much. There are still kinks they need to work out. The main area of concern was the speed of the food. We ordered 4 dishes. The first three were brought out timely. The fourth dish took way to long. In fact it arrived over 20 minutes after the third dish. I was about to cancel the order right when it was finally brought out. The explanation was there were "kitchen issues."

There must of been a lot of "kitchen issues" as the table next to me was brought their dessert when they still had one entree that hadn't come out. The table next to them had to ask the server when the last two of their dishes would be brought out.

On a different note, I noticed one of the "suit" employees spend at lot time by the corner terminal just to the left of the noodle area texting. Business or not, she could have done this not in plain view of the dining area.

The food is tasty but still a lot of "issues" that need to be addressed. I am also happy to report that they did not run out of alcohol as they did last time.
author: Kai W.

description:
Don't be put off by the restaurant in a mall.  Went with some colleagues while on a business trip.  Shared a bunch of things and all were very good, some excellent.

Service was good, place is very pretty, and perhaps it is because we came from NY, but I thought the pricing was quite reasonable.  More food than we could eat and a bottle of wine for $125--not "cheap" chinese food, but certainly reasonable for NY or SF for a very good meal.

Best items:
-Spicy seafood dumplings--delicious
-forbidden rice
-Squid ink noodles with seafood--really delicious

Very good-
-MaPo Tofu (vegetarian option here)
-Shrimp with gingko berries

Good, but not as special
-Portobello sliders--good quality, not as much flavor
-Spring rolls--tasty, but greasy

Would definitely go back again when in town.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Inexcusable service from the host, Dec. 22, 1pm.. My wife is waiting in line to be seated after explaining to the lady, we want to be seated outside. The gentleman, seemed like the manager, seats the folks behind her. Both of us and the people behind us asked for 3 seats. No number, no sign-in list. He comes up and asks who needs 3 seats and takes the people  behind her. Comes back takes us to an inside table. We explain we asked for an outside table, he replies, why we didn't  say that in the first place.  Takes us to a table.  One of  seats is dirty  with sauce  dripping. We tell him, he says  it's ok and walks away. Food is good but, this is not acceptable.
author: Good M.

description: I went to MY CHINA at least 4 /5  times in the past 12 months. Foods are good. Beijing duck is recommended. Big Knife noodle is good but a bit on the oily side. Atmosphere is nice - right inside shopping center. I would love to give them 4 stars for the foods and atmosphere. BUT, service is not up to par. One time the wait staff let a few parties go before me. I was about to leave and she finally noticed and took me to the table(almost feel pointless to make reservation). The most recent visit,  we were seated to a small round table with only 5 chairs while we have 6 people (including a 4 yr old). I asked twice so we finally moved to a bigger table with 6 chairs. We were left at the bigger table for 5 mins without water. The servicer was seem twice throughout dinner: take order and check. Upon leaving the restaurant, ran into her at the door but she looked away, no bye or thank you or anything. Just to be fair, there are some really good serviers at MY China, but these two individuals keep me away.
author: Sandra L.

description: food is above average. but service is a disaster. our server is nowhere to be seen and when we ask other server, nothing happened.
author: Jennifer W.

description: This place shines when it comes to food and decor. We tried 4 dishes and there wasn't one I wouldn't order again. The guys next to us ordered 12 (seriously) and they were fans of pretty much everything. The noodles are a clear standout and shouldn't be missed. The one draw back was the service. The waiters seems to wander aimlessly without purpose and the people who bring the food more often than not have no idea what they are serving. The drinks also take a long while to come to double up on your order and make sure you aren't stiffed on their relatively short pours. Otherwise, I am super excited for visit #2 so I can try the other 40 things I wanted to order.
author: Ray C.

description:
hip places but food so so, all dish are warm to cold
5 spice pork rib:oily and can't taste the meat, all the favorite and spice are on the coating and herbs

Beef hand pulled noodle soup: not bad, beef is tender and noodle could be more chewy

Pork and black truffle dumpling(round one): bad design of presentation, each dumpling on a red ceramic spoon, too hot to touch to take it out from the steam basket. Dumpling are over cook, top skin is too thick, bottom skin is too thin, when it get to the table all the dumpling were pop open in the middle and the bottom skin is stick to the spoon. Can't taste any truffle at all ($18) and the dumpling also comes with 
wrong sauce. should be dark vinegar instead of the red one.

HK Crispy noodle with chicken: just rite but u can get it anywhere

Whole Wheat Potstickers: the crispy side is ok the other side is kind of raw. one of the potsticker is not fully cooked(raw pork??)

Forbidden Rice: the only nice thing about this restaurant. all 3 stars for this dish.

Sugar puff: comes with 3 different sauces(chocolate, whipped cream, raseberry) real nice

Lemon Egg tart: taste good but lemon favorite is too light like no lemon at all.
author: Marco L.

description: I especially like the lobster. It takes a lot of effort to eat it but it's all worth it. Service is  great. Food is not greasy and very tasty. Location is awesome. I brought my staff with me for lunch and they enjoyed the dumplings and kung pao chicken.
author: Mohamed A.

description: Had the opportunity to attend the Lucky Rice Event at the Ferry Building a month or so ago. My China was there. Met Tony Wu the Chef. Great presentation of the String Noodles. I tried their dish there and found it very tasty. Decided to go the the restaurant. Went there on a Saturday. Had the 2 orders of the Prix Fixe Lunch. One for my wife and the other for myself. We would get a better sense of their dishes, We both had various Dumplings (made up of five) ,Soup (Won Ton or Hot and Sour) and Main Entree (Beef and Kung Pao Shrimp). Everything was delicious. We also ordered a couple of glasses of some Sauvignon Wine ($15 per) to go along with lunch. If you get the opportunity to sit by the kitchen, do so. Check Out the show. If you are looking for good Chinese food while shopping and don't blink about price, this might be your place. Overall, I probably paid more for service and ambiance. You can get as good Chinese and pay half the price somewhere else. I'll go back, but will probably be more selective.
author: J G.

description:
This place is really good chinese food, and not too expensive (if you stay away from the sides).  

We got the peking duck half order.  Was the best peking duck i've ever had and not really too small of a portion either.  Came with really tasty pieces of crispy duck skin which i've never seen separated from the duck before.

We also got the garlic pea shoots, which were tasty but pretty expensive for what we got.  I'd recommend staying away unless you really want to try it.

Finally we had the boar scissor cut noodles which were also tasty.  I usually don't care about service, but of note, the service here is really good.
author: Brian G.

description: Received a very thoughtful email from the restaurant regarding the concerns in my review. I appreciate their reaching out to follow up and make things right.
author: Lolo U.

description:
absolutely loved the food here and used to rave about it to everyone. was really excited to come back this time but had a rather disappointing experience. the food was still good but doesn't seem to taste good when the service is as bad as it was.

the times we needed the server, there was no one around. it took several minutes of literally waving arms in the air to get any attention. when they brought the steamed dumplings they didn't explain which was the crab vs truffle vs wild boar. when they cleared the dishes, they didn't bother to wipe the table and we ordered crabs so there were a few messy spots that needed to be taken care of so we could have a clean table for dessert. 

oh but they forgot the dessert, or didn't bother to make it. we ordered the set crab menu that includes dessert and I was so looking forward to it. the server explained that the kitchen closed already and couldn't make the dessert. why didn't they make it before they closed? because it would get cold was the response. it would've been nice to let us know the situation that we were at risk of not getting dessert and ask if we want it early etc. instead they just dropped the bomb at the end of the meal when we expecting dessert, and without any inclination that they did something wrong

not enjoyable experience and I don't know if I will return. don't support that
author: Angela Z.

description:
I went here on a Saturday afternoon to celebrate family birthdays. We made reservations and had one of the nice round tables "outside", which made fun people watching for my teenager. 
I eat a lot of asian styled food, typically more casual. It was nice to try an upscale restaurant. We ordered several orders of dim sum. The shiu mai were nice fat dumplings, larger then normal. The steamed bao dough was fresh and not dry. The whole wheat dumplings didn't have the heavy wheat texture, you could tell the dough was house made. When our juicy dumplings were brought out the servers explained how to eat them and warned of the hot spoons. Of course we ordered the wild boar noodles which were tasty and not heavy with a sauce. We also ordered the sweet and sour pork, this had large pieces of pork which had a thin coating (it's nice to have more meat than batter).
Our orders were brought one at a time, which made it nice enjoy each dish before moving onto the next. 
The only reason I subtracted a star is that I had to ask for soy sauce (the dishes come with a chili soy, it was good but not for everyone). If you order the tea be aware, the cups are very small. After two sips you have to pour more. Also, even though I told our waiter we had a person with shellfish alergies, I had to ask which orders of dim sum had the fish in them before eating.
The nice ending was our server comped our birthday dessert, the egg puffs. Which had a custard taste, but were light.
author: Emily W.

description:
I went to MY China late December 2012 between lunch and dinner service (on the 30th between 3 and 4PM)  after my GF and I got spa treatments at Burke Williams.  We sat at the bar.  Ambiance is nice.  There is a limited menu at the bar in between lunch and dinner but it was pretty adequate considering.  The service was a bit spotty; we had to ask for place settings, etc after the food arrived.  The food was really good!  

However, observing the bar service was not good.  The bartenders did not appear to be terribly experienced and each time someone ordered a drink the bartender closest to us would look up the ingredients in a book.  (Admittedly, I didn't hear the orders, so they may have been obscure drinks.)  My friend ordered a beer and the bartender got the wrong one out twice and opened it, and then just threw them away when she corrected him.  Seems a tad careless/wasteful of restaurant resources.  Then the worst part: someone had ordered champagne and as the bartender unskillfully poured it into the glass, there was a lot of foam at the top, over the top of the glass.  Instead of just waiting for it to die down to finish pouring it, he actually blew the foam off the top of the glass into the trash...yes, with his mouth.  My GF and I were speechless: I said, "did i just see that right?"  She confirmed that I had.  We were glad not to have ordered similarly.  This display made me feel concerned about sanitation in general.  For this reason, I do like that they have a glass walled kitchen, but if the bartenders are so poorly trained they think it's ok to blow into someone's glass, what else is happening behind the scenes?  

We are hoping it had something to do with the newness of the restaurant, when service can frequently be spotty, but who would hire such a clearly inexperienced bartender?

I will go back again for food during regular service hours and give it another try because the food was very tasty.
author: C J.

description: Super disappointed! I was looking forward to trying this place because I grew up watching his cooking show. The food was mediocre and overpriced. The most disappointing part was the service, though! Rude, unhelpful waitress only checked on us once. The hostess was friendly to me, but my friend came a few minutes late and they told him to walk around the restaurant to look for us....who does that?
author: N V.

description: The food is great, the atmosphere is nice and the service is great. My husband and I were pleasantly surprised by this restaurant in a mall. We have returned numerous times since our first visit and will go back again. The food is traditional, yet a bit more interesting. My Chinese in-laws were very impressed.
author: Karina S.

description: what a awesome experience !!! the owner yen can cook was there and greeted us like family !!! gave us a tour of the place as well as a cooking performance with fire etc !!! he took pics with us !!! great place to eat !!! we had dim sum and it was so delicious !!!
author: Kev B.

description: I know what you're thinking, a good restaurant inside a mall? Trust me, go try this place. Their Dan Dan Noodles are hands-down, the best I have ever had. I now crave them incessantly. The seafood dumplings, scissor cut noodles and soup dumplings are also fantastic. If you have love places like Din Tai Fung and Red 8, then you will surely be impressed with MY China. They just opened another location in the new casino, which I can't wait to visit.
author: Teresa B.

description: I cant believe im saying this but Panda Express is a million times better than Martin Yan's restaurant. I spent $28 on bland kung pao chicken and rice. WTF? Since when does half a chicken breast and spoonful of rice cost that much??? Martin Yan you should be embarrassed of yourself. Went here with a group of coworkers and we were ALL disapointed. Nothing had flavor. Please do not waste your time coming here.
author: KittenKatty D.

description:
I was disappointed when I ate at M.Y. China. I called ahead of time letting them know that I have a gluten sensitivity (not celiac), and I was reassured that they could
accommodate my dietary restrictions. When we arrived, the server said that the only thing I could choose from were the salads and there was one noodle dish they could substitute using rice noodles. Sorry, but I don't recommend this restaurant to anyone who has any dietary allergies even if he is a top chef!
author: Donna R.

description: My partner and I decided to try M.Y. China.  It is supposed to be associated to Chef Martin Yan, but the only assosciation is his name.  We were seated at the counter, which was ok, but it would have been nice to sit at a table which were in abundance.  We ordered 4 dishes-onion cakes which needed a dipping sauce which we did get, szechwan green beans, which were ordinary, dan dan noodles, served cold with NO flavor (go to a real Szechwan restaurant for dan dan noodles) and crispy chicken which were absolutely delicious.  Would I go back?  Maybe.
author: David P.

description:
I celebrated my birthday at M.Y. China.  The only thing I have to say, the food is delicious; the decor is classy and the service is better than any I have experienced at the best restaurants both here and in New York.

I don't know how anyone could eat here and not think it was delicious.  My hat is off the Martin Chan and the entire team!  5 Stars.   Jackie W.
author: Jacquelyn W.

description:
It's been a long wait for the opening of M.Y. China restaurant at the Westfield Mall but it was worthwhile. 

On January 6th 2013 I finally had the pleasure to take my mother who was visiting from Brazil and a friend of mine for his birthday's dinner party. 

We ordered three main course and a side order of Forbidden Rice - b.t.w. very well prepared and the presentation quite interesting.

For appetizer we had Chairman Mao's Chicken. It was crispy without being greezy -fried perfectly. The chicken was juicy and tender, the jalapeno gave it a kick and together with red bell pepper it balanced the taste. I was savoring my seventh piece when disaster stroke, I bit in a big chunck of cartilage -  it completely ruined  for me. I always have bad luck regarding chicken, if there is a cartilage it will be on my plate. At that point I was worried about, but things turned out better.  
 
As always the chinese way of serving family style reminds me of home, so we were able to taste from everything. 

My mother had the Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp. My friend and I usually eat that particular dish at the Sky Dragon in South San Francisco - they do a pretty good job there and we always thought it was the best in the Bay Area although I have to admit Martin Yan took the dish experience to a whole new level. It was glazed to perfection, the flavors well balanced, the cucumber touch added freshness - a detail you don't find at Sky Dragon.
 
My friend ordered Wild Boar Scissor Cut Noodles. The last time I had wild boar was in Parana State in Brazil but we prepare completely different from the Chinese. Nevertheless it was delicious the way they served at M.Y. China, a little salty which I like. The noodles were cooked al dente to my surprise - usually the Chinese overcook the noodles which I find a little hard on the digestion. To me this was the best of all the dishes. 

I ordered the Wok Tossed Shrimp with Ginkgo Nuts. Unfortunately I didn't care much about, it was blend, a little gooey, and too safe - it is something you order if you are not adventurous. The best part of the dish it was the ginkgo nuts, never had before - the taste and texture are incomparable to anything. We all agreed the dish was a minus - don't order it you will be disappointed.
 
The waiter who served us was very efficient although I would rather have someone less uptight speaking a little slower - she ran her tongue like a speed boat, it was hard to catch up with her.
 
Overall it was a pleasant experience and I will definitely go back to try other items on the menu. The only strange thing I found it was to seat at a restaurant in a mall and eat well. Hope this will open a door to other malls in U.S. to invite good restaurants into their lease
author: Marcello C.

description: The food was good but the service really sucked. They brought our soup to the table but took forever to bring any bowls or spoons. We finally had to get up and ask for some, then they bring only 1/2 the bowls we need and no spoons. We had to return the soup because it got cold by the time we got all the proper eating supples. After that, the service didn't get any better. The waiter was pretty much non existent. We aren't going back, there's much better Chinese food in this city with 100% better service.
author: Ashley L.

description: Surprisingly good food at a restaurant in a mall. Upscale/fusion/western Chinese food, a must try when in San Francisco
author: Ritu H.

description: We were at MYChina last night and were touched by the manager Julie Chu's gesture. The food was great especially the mu shu pork tacos and halibut alongwith dumpling trio. Will come back again!
author: Kalpesh K.

description: Quite over priced for the level of service they are trying to offer. Therefore, A one Star for this restaurant. The food is just okay, bit on the greasy side. Noise level to on the high side. Limited number of staff to attend to your needs. However, the decor is on the trendy side.
author: Anthony H.

description: Out of my expectation!! The food is amazing!! It's not traditional Chinese food but it's good especially the shrimp!
author: WY Y.

description: light dinner, dumplings, pot stickers and small soup. all very excellent. The table we were placed at was off kilter and kept tipping.  When we pointed this out, we were not moved, just told "that's the way it is".
author: Jennifer F.

description: I love, love this place.  They have the best happy hour in town.  The fried chicken wings, spicy tofu sticks and the dumplings on the happy hour menu are fantastic.  For $3.00 for a beer, you can't beat it.  Also, had the hand made noodles, also delic.  Will be definately going back there.
author: Mary B.

description:
We were waiting anxiously for this place to open. Finally the board about the story of the bird that flew out of the teapot came down, and there is the sleek, modern restaurant opened on the fourth floor of Westfield Mall. Stunning.
I have been here 3 times.
The first time, it was a holiday party with my coworkers. We all came from different ethnicity, Russian, Cambodian, Philippino, Peruvian, American, Vietnamese, Chinese... And we totally enjoyed the lunch at M.Y China. We did not know how big the portions were, so we ordered, and kept ordering.. Food came out pretty fast, and hot.. We all left totally happy.
The next day, my sister and her daughter came from San Jose to go shopping. And I took them to M.Y China, and I ordered all the good dishes that I had enjoyed the previous day: hand pulled noodles with braised beef, Mushu tacos, wok seared beef, crispy noodle with chicken.. We told the waitress we had shopping to do, so the food came out fast. Another good positive experience.
This last Saturday, we brought some other relatives to experience M.Y China. Since I knew the menu already, I gave the waiter the whole order. That was the biggest mistake. The hand pulled noodles with beef were served right away, and the cocktails only arrived after we finished the soup. Then the wok dishes arrived fast and furious: lobster, the awesome wok seared beef, the ginkgo nuts shrimp, the walnut shrimp and the Mushu tacos. Everybody at the table moaned, we thought we would have the dim sum and the Peking duck first!! Those arrived AFTER we finished, and while we were eating the duck, the pork and crab juicy dumplings got cold. Everybody was too stuffed already to really enjoy the dumplings. But I still ordered the airy egg puffs, I love those, I wish I live near by so I can have them every morning with my cappuccino. Oh yeah, why is that Chinese restaurants, no matter how upscale, never have an espresso/ cappuccinos machine? Also, our tea came very late in the meal, there was a problem with stolen teapots...weird.
Lesson learned: I will order the dim sum then will tell the waiter to come back for my next order. The kitchen does not seem to course my meal, it seems the cooks are only happy to send the orders out. Is there a chef to supervise and expedite the orders? Also, it must be the new trend for waiters to memorize the orders and not to write them down, but you guys kept forgetting a few items of my order..
I understand the place is brand new and need to work out the kinks. We totally enjoyed the food and the experience. 
And to the people who say the food is not authentic or over priced, may I ask what is authentic? The greasy joint with the cockroaches all over the place? Overpriced? Have you seen the artwork, the quality of the furnishings? Have you shopped for truffles, quality meat or wild boar? San Francisco is not a cheap town, for rent or for labor. So if you decide to eat out, please enjoy the company, the food and the experience.
We totally enjoyed M.Y China and will definitely come back. The one star off was for the sequence of service, hope it will be worked out soon for a smoother flow for a perfect meal.
author: lovetoeat a.

description:
I grew up watching Martin Yan's cooking show so naturally when Martin Yan opened up a restaurant in San Francisco, I was very psyched to go. We had an Open Table reservation for 5 at 6:30PM on a Friday night. We got a table as soon as we got to the restaurant. The lady was even kind enough to fulfill our request to seat us in one of  the nice round tables at the front of the restaurant where it's less noisy than inside. 

For dinner we ordered
1)  Kabocha Squash Soup - comes with fried wonton. Definitely felt that there could have been more wonton (it was so good) but the soup was very good for a starter. 2 orders is more than good for 5 people.
2) Hong Kong Crispy Noodle with Chicken
So good! The sauce was excellent - far trumped any crispy noodle experience I had
3) Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp
Most expensive dish we ordered - At $22 it was a phenomenal dish. I typically hate honey glazed walnut shrimp, but convinced by my friends, I tried one and I actually think this is the only honey glazed walnut shrimp I ever really liked. The dish tends to be too mayo-ey for my taste, but MYChina had the perfect amount of glaze and perfect texture.
4) Honey Glazed BBQ Pork 
Instant favorite among us. It's a small portion however. But it is sooo good! Words do not describe!
5) Forbidden Rice. 
Love love love the forbidden rice - it's red + regular rice together I think - the wolfberries and a bit of egg - the combo is just creative and really good. It has great texture, perfect blend of nuttiness and a bit (subtle) hint of sweet with the wolfberries. Great as a side.

People even went around the entire restaurant and did noodle pulling demonstrations. Really funny and cool to see! 

This experience also doesn't hurt the wallet too much- For all five of us, we ended up spending about $80. That's less than $20 per person! For the food - that was totally worth it.

Customer service was speedy - lots of waiters from my observation - we got our food in a reasonable time.

Would definitely go again! Me and my friends are already planning another outing to this place the next time we're all back in the city from college.

Thanks MYChina for the good food and good experience! Met my expectations for Martin Yan.
author: Hana S.

description: I love the hot and sour soup but anyone who can't eat spicy be careful .the potstickers and noodle good
author: J l.

description: The food was good and when the server explained how strange it was about the difference between the waitstaff and the kitchen, it made some sense. Nice to sit underneath the dome.
author: Fzarond K.

description: My wife and family dropped in for lunch which consisted of Beef Noodle Soup, Steamed Pork Buns and Fried Rice for our child. Unfortunately, it was one of the worst meals we have had in recent memory. The restaurant is gorgeous and the service was very attentive. If only the food were good. The pork buns were rubbery and the pork filling was sickly sweet. The noodles had a decent consistency and the short rib meat was pretty good, but they dumped whole heads of bok choy in the dish which were tough and difficult to eat. Why not cut the Bok Choy leaves off before you plunk them into soup? Both wife and child turned their noses up at the fried rice. So most of our food was thrown away and we left $50 poorer. We won't be returning here.
author: Peter R.

description: The food is average.  The price is way more expensive than what you can buy in the China Town in a restaurant with comparable food.
author: Walter K.

description: We recently stayed in San Fran and loved this restaurant. We had the dim sum sampler, the wok entree of ginger, walnut prawns with wasabi sauce and it was to die for. Much better than I ever thought for a restaurant in a mall. We loved the drinks, cucumber martini. The wait staff was very helpful and knew the menu inside out.
author: Gregory J.

description: Ok, I get it, the food isn't as authentic as the stuff one can get in the avenues.  I agree, but when you need a Chinese food fix at the mall, in a sit-down restaurant and not at the food court, this place is a lifesaver.  And seriously, if you think about it, it is waycheaper than Yank Sing downtown.  I appreciate the gwai-lo (me) friendly menu (although the Chinese wife likes the more ethnic stuff like squid soup).   Look, it serves booze, you can get away from the crowd for an hour or so, and it isn't too expensive.  Not gonna replace Ton Kiang, but it serves a noble purpose.
author: Miles N.

description: Great restaurant! Unique Chinese food.  Entertaining chefs.  (And Martin Yan was there on Sunday 22 Sep).  Look for an opening in Rohnert Park he says.
author: Gary N.

description: Having eaten Dim Sum worldwide, we found M.Y.Chins provided an excellent atmosphere, good service, and above average Dim Sum.  While on the pricey side, probably the best place to get Dim Sum within a half a dozen blocks of Union Square.  We got there about 11:30 a.m., on a Saturday and were treated to a view of the chefs carving a dragon's head out of winter squash while we dined.  At the end of the meal, we were treated to a final view of the wonderful foot long 3-D product.
author: FB F.

description: One of the best Chinese dinners I have ever eaten. Friends from out of town joined us, and every dish was excellent. A cook strolled by, stretching out the longevity noodles, so it was like dinner AND a show. The service was a little spotty (one of our party did not receive his sweet and sour pork until the rest of us had had our food for some time), and it was noisy. But we will definitely go back, and soon.
author: Christine S.

description:
The food is pretty tasty. It's good quality high brow Chinese food. A bit expensive but you have to spend some dough to eat good Chinese food in SF sometimes. 
One thing I do find consistent at M.Y. China is the shoddy service. They must hire inexperienced wait staff. Our waiter over pour one ofour waters and left a running pile of water that was quickly heading towards us. he didn't wipe it up nor come back with a towel. He walked away and let us defend ourselves from the overpowered water. That's sloppy. Oh and talking about sloppy, the restaurant itself is dirty. So this dinner would be my third time at MY China and each time I've had bad service. Maybe they expect their clientele to be one time visiting tourists, or sit at the bar date night couples and wannabe garish Chinese business people perhaps service and cleanliness is not important. I saw a lot of fallen napkins and utensils on the floor. If the staff doesnt care it may mean.... 'Add your comment here'. Mine starts w M ends w T - there is a man somewhere in there.
I want to give this two stars but the food is pretty good. That extra star weights heavy on their food. I would probably take my parents there if they came to visit.
author: flashegirl e.

description: M.Y. China is one of the best Chinese Restaurants i have experienced, as far as the food, it is fantastic, very well presented, good taste and to consider the ambiance it is very classy. I just had my son's senior HS graduation recently. It was a very special occassion that's why I thought we should celebrate it at MY China. This is my 3rd time to dine here and finally I was able to bring my whole family, so they can experience to eat the best dimsum, chinese cuisine I ever had. We ordered dimsum as my family loves dimsum, they were so good and also we ordered the Peking Duck, fantastic..We all love what we ordered, my favorite was the green dimsum which was made from veggie that is why it's healthy..all of the dimsums were great!.My family were impressed with their service, they were fast and courteous. We even had a performer chef who showed his expertise on how to prepare the noodles, he was amazing. My family had a great time had enjoyed every moment there and we hope we can go back again soon. MY China is the best place for special occassions, even a small party of 3 to 4 will make your time well spent in going to MY China.
author: Rose C.

description:
We came here over the weekend, and had a great experience.  The interior is modern, and the service is friendly.  The food is fresh, with exceptional flavors.  The dan dan noodle was one of my favorite.  The dipping sauce made all the difference.  It's a combination of sweet, sour, and a bit spicy.  The bbq items (pork, and duck) were delicious, they were served warm unlike the take out you get at regular Chinese restaurants.  I was surprised by the number of desserts available on the menu, we tried sugar puffs, it was fantastic.  It was a simple dish that is served in many places, but they added chocolate sauce, raspberry sauce and whipped cream, and made it 10 times better.  The other desserts we had, chocolate cake, and sundae, were fantastic as well, we loved the toasted rice ice cream in particular.
If you know your food, you can tell that they pay attention to details, flavors, and freshness. You really can't compare this to the regular Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, well, unless you don't know what you are eating...
author: Tim R.

description: This ain't no P.F.Changs!  I'll agree it's Chinese food for white people, but I'm ok with that.  I don't need any fish heads in my soup to know it's good.  This place is swanky.  M.Y. spent some bucks on this establishment from the huge bell over the bar, to the wall of Buddhas, to the huge unisex bathroom.  The food was pretty stellar as well.  I'm no dumpling expert but the pork and crab dumplings and the wild boar dumplings were great.  We split some kung pao chicken and the highly recommended scissor cut wild boar noodles.  Both were amazing and very fresh (not greasy) tasting.  The noodles could have perhaps used some more wild boar, but the noodles were so tasty.  The kung pao chicken had roasted jalapenos that were so crispy and not too spicy.  For dessert we got those steamed buns with pork.  Those were amazing.  I usually find those buns to be too much bun and not enough pork, but these were perfect.  Very sweet and yummy tasting.  Yes, we won't be returning the P. F. Changs anymore, and me and my friends all agreed it was better than Yank Sing. Pretty reasonably priced too considering the overall quality of the food. Can't wait to go back!
author: Poochie M.

description: I came here today for the third time, and I can't explain why.  They try to be a higher end Chinese restaurant with it's modern decor and exorbitant prices, but their service is subpar and many of the items or their menu taste worse than fast food Chinese.  The waiters have been inattentive on every visit.  My last trip, it took over 15 minutes before our waiter came by.  Also, do not expect the servers to bring the food to the table all at once.  They come out several minutes in between.  As for the food, I can tell that the ingredients are higher than average and fresh, but a lot of the dishes dishes lack flavor.  This place is a mediocre, overpriced Chinese restaurant with a pretty cover.
author: June P.

description: Came here for our valentines day dinner. The place was packed. Ordered food and it didn't come for like 15 mins. Finally food came and it was not in the right order. The juicy dumpling ( appetizer) came after the pork chop (main dish). The dumpling was good, but it's also $3 a piece. We also ordered beef noodle soup and it was disappointing. As a Chinese person I have had my fair share of beef noodle soup and this is not to my standard. The noodle was thick and not smooth. The soup base was not good either. The pork chop was crispy but it's bland. The rice we ordered came the last!!!! After we told the server that we don't want it anymore. He was nice enough to take it off the bill at last. Probably won't be back on our own again... With the same amount of money, you got much better and twice amount of food in Chinatown !!!
author: Rachel O.

description: The beef noodles are fantastic.  I am a real Chinese! I was like the noodles I had in China and the spicy sauce, too!!
author: Vivi L.

description: Typical Americanized Chinese restaurant located at the Westfield Mall in DTSF. You want to know why I felt it was Americanized? Because it had great service, despite a very subpar menu, and you usually wouldn't see this kind of service if you were at a real Chinese restaurant (no offense, but you all know it's true for the most part). I did like the spicy seafood dumpling we started off with. The rest of our course was an upscale Panda Express. The duck was not even that good. However, midway through our course we were entertained by one of their employees who played with his dough (?) in the middle of the restaurant, which I thought was cool. If you are looking for a quick Chinese food fix, this is the place to be. Otherwise, it's a little overpriced for the quality of food.
author: Ana B.

description: Food was decent. Venison chow fun great,  duck good but not enough garnish, ginkgo shrimp ok, pear salad boring. Kabocha squash soup fine... But service was pretty bad. They didn't come over often... Dishes left on table for 10 minutes at least after being eaten. Original wine not any good and it took us 10-15 minutes to get the waiter back over, but they did comp us a replacement . Might come back for chow fun but overall was not that impressed, especially by the service. It was too expensive for this poor service!
author: BC M.

description: Our horrible experience began with a pretentious host who was "too busy" to seat us even though the restaurant was half empty :-(  I wanted to enjoy the food given it was owned by a celebrity chef however, the food is really mediocre given all the hype.  You can find better Chinese cuisine in less pretentious places...
author: Jerry N.

description:
I normally don't write reviews, but due to the extremely unsatisfied experience(s) we had in less than 2 days, I feel others should be made well aware.

Two very bad experiences at this restaurant. First, a few days ago we had dinner there. Got there for our reservation and seated, then waited a pretty good 10 minutes until our server came to greet us, by this time, we had already looked at the menu back and forth a few times, so when he finally came, we put our drinks and food order in. Food came out, tasted fine, we needed some chili sauce and some refills, but our server was nowhere to be found, we had to flag down some other server to assist us. I don't even think our server came back to check on us once.  Martin Yan, was going around the restaurant greeting guests and even he stopped by our table more than our server.  He actually cleared some plates off our table because our server was so un-attentive. We even tried to order dessert but couldn't get a dessert menu because once again, our server was nowhere to be found. The General Manager of the restaurant had to take our dessert order. 

Then comes today at lunch, server was more attentive today, but they somehow lose our credit card. We could see something was wrong when we saw our server looking in drawers and throwing his hands up in the air. He, for whatever reason, could not come tell us that he had lost our credit card, somehow that duty belonged to the hostess, who began to apologize profusely and told us they would look for it when they stop serving at 2 o' clock. We look at the time and its about 2:30 and some people are just beginning to order. A little later while waiting for them to locate the card, our original server comes up and apologizes he's still looking for the card. He goes on to tell us that they actually stop seating people at 2:30, but people will continue to be served. So in other words, the hostess came up to us and told us a lie just to pacify us for the time. 

And would you believe... that after an HOUR LATER, a Manager (Stan Gee) FINALLY comes up to us to "clarify" the situation and apparently took us for idiots claiming that while they were not going to disturb other patrons to look for our credit card (THAT THEY LOST); they would however, do a thorough sweep through the restaurant with all servers once things were "not busy".  Whatever.  It was just more damn lies to pacify the already almost 2 HOURS we sat there.  To further add to the pile of bullshit lies we were being fed, Mr. Gee promised to contact us regardless whether they found the card or not following lunch service and during the break hours of the restaurant (~5pm).  Mr. Gee also claimed that this happens at least twice a year with every restaurant. (UNBELIEVABLE)

Well, it is now ~5pm... and go figure, NO CALLS have been received.  On top of that, since it was our only credit card; our vacation came to a screeching halt such that on freakin new year's eve, we had to just sit in the hotel room due to the inexcusable mistake by the restaurant and it's CARELESS staff!!!

Conclusion: Food was ok. Service, hostess, and management SUCKS!!!!
author: T N.

description: Finally got to try M.Y. China and had a very good experience.  The service was excellent (Carla is awesome), the food was good, and the prices were not as bad as I expected.  I will definitely go back.
author: Garrett H.

description: Absolutely disgraceful. Not even sure where to start on this restaurant. I was under the impression that when you go to a restaurant, they bring out the meals that you order. Obviously i was wrong. After a 35 minute wait, and watching various other patrons who arrived significantly later than us get served first, I had seen enough. The head chef was more interested in putting on a show with the making of the noodles, marching his staff around the patrons whilst spinning the noodles, then actually getting the food out to the customers. To add insult, the waiter stated "please don't judge us on this and come back again soon". Give this place a miss.
author: Andrew G.

description: My sister and I dined here for lunch on 12/18/2012.  We had the delicious crab/pork juicy dumplings, delicious pork belly sliders (although a little too much daikon), the ok chilled eggplant, the very blah westlake 6 won ton soup(sized large, $12.00), and delicious sugar puffs.  Both of us have been sick ever since; 24 hrs of diarrhea, don't know which was the culprit.  The servers were efficient and friendly, the latino hostess who showed us to the table was super; the opened kitchens look beautiful, the bathrooms are beautiful but all in all including parking, the hefty bill and our stomach problems, I will not return.
author: Jeanne L.

description: restaurant's decor is so beautiful.  hand pulled noodle was delicious. the perfect dish is the hand pulled noodles from the beef noodle soup combined with the sauce and topping of the knife cut noodles.
author: Wakako U.

description: Kudos to Maitre d' Ms. Ashley! She's simply unbelievable in her care for her customers at MY Chins. I also had the honor of meeting Mr. Martin Yan, Chef Partner and let him know how lucky MY China is to have Ms. Ashley! Go for the "dim sum" and desserts (ice cream/sorbet excepted!)!
author: Ricardo D.

description: Great new Chinese restaurant in the upscale mall in San Francisco. I had a very simple walnut encrusted shrimp with a glass of wine. I also had some pork steamed dumplings as well. I had a great view of the chef and kitchen. Fun, classy, place!
author: Mike S.

description: Sitting in front of the kitchen watching the chefs at work on the woks is cool. Food was ok. I dont even remember what we ate. It was that memorable. Id rather go to red jade.
author: LT B.

description: The meal started off with five stars, we had the Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup, Potstickers, and Pork and Crab Dumplings and were in love. The spicy soy sauce with the potstickers was to die for! Sadly, the meal took a turn for the worse after this. We waited 25 minutes for the Kung Pao chicken, which when it finally turned up was so dry, we couldn't eat it. No one once asked how our food was, so we had no chance to let them know about the chicken.  As soon as someone noticed we had set our napkins down, someone grabbed the plates, dropped the check and we were off. The meal started off so strong, but the lasting impression was not good.
author: Katrina E.

description:
pros: convenient location, nice atmosphere, quick service
cons: slightly over priced (probably due to the fancy decors, and the fact that it is in the mall)

food is ok but nothing too special. i think it is trying to be a upscale kind of fusion chinese. they have some non chinese cooks that make the noodles, which is kind of fun to watch, and the whole kitchen area is wide open, you can see the cooks make food right in front of you especially if you sit at the bar. 

we ordered:

pork ribs, oh NO. no flavors very greasy....... good amount of food tho. 
sauteed mushrooms. not lots of flavors but it is alright.
whole wheat potstickers. very mediocre. 
scissor cut noodles: they are not bad. just slightly too sweet. 

total $55 without tips. 

overall you are not missing out on anything. but if you are in the mall looking for some nice place to sit down, it is ok.
author: Danielle A.

description: Horrible service experience (we gave 0% tip). The food is decent but overpriced. Will not come again!
author: Kolja S.

description: Food and service was great... however it's still eating inside a mall. This restaurant would have gotten 5 stars if it were in a cool location, not inside a mall. Will be back!
author: Massimo L.

description: My friends and I had a wonderful night enjoying my birthday dinner. I ordered the beef noodles which was really tasty, and the egg puff was my favorite. Our server Ken has a great attitude service and always with smile on it. Me and my friends will definitely go to M.Y China again next time.
author: Ching L.

description:
Great place.  I love that it has authentic flavor with good quality ingredients - I'm so glad to see more great Chinese places that aren't holes in the wall.  I'm really impressed that Yan has managed to put together a concept that caters to yuppy bay area sensibilities without sacrificing the essence of the food that he is serving.
beef noodle soup - delicious - the flavor was spot on. not greasy, but beef was deliciously flavorful and tender.  noodles were also amazing - thick and chewy.  actually, someone from the kitchen took out a huge piece of dough and started flinging it around and showing people how the noodles are made around the time that my noodle soup came, which was kinda funny.
XLB - got the pork and crab variety. these are big and delicious, really good.  Gives Yank Sing a run for their money.  Yank Sing's are slightly smaller, but have more soup inside, and a more delicate skin.  MY China's have a thicker skin and are bigger and has a very hearty filling.  I need to go to Yank Sing again before declaring a winner.
DanDan noodles - this was the weakest link in our meal.  Instead of being thick noodles with a gooey sauce, these were rice noodles with a light sauce. didn't really work for me, but was ok.
anyway, looking forward to coming back with more friends.
Good job Martin Yan!!
author: Yin L.

description: Sister and I finally chose to dine at this place over the Straights Cafe on a Friday evening. What a horrible experience! Since there was a long wait so we( two middle aged Asian ladies) sat at the Bar. We ordered two glasses Red,  the most expensive one on their list, $18/glass, but it was so plain. Simply not worth the price. Then we ordered four dishes( quite a lot for two ladies. We were hungry). The food was okay but overpriced.  What horrifying was soon after we started, the bartenders, two of them, took turns to ask if we were going to order more drinks, but our wine glasses were still half full, then if we needed to get our check or order desserts, but we were only half way in working on our food! What more upsetting was we were the only ones being asked in the whole Bar, and so many times! Was it because we were Asian, middle aged, not dressed to kill, and speaking second language English? I hate to say this place is discriminating, but sadly this is the only conclusion I can draw. Long story short, $ 130.00 dinner bill by the end, but simply a humiliating and upsetting experience! Minus or zero is what I can give, but it doesn't give me such an option!
author: Kathy Z.

description: Excellent dining experience both times I went to M.Y. China!  Late lunch with the family (kids loved the noodle demonstration/floor show) was comprised of multiple dim sum dishes, but the har gow was everyone's favorite. Kung pao chicken was very flavorful and the sautéed  red peppers were not hot, but provided a wonderful mouth feel contrasted to the tender bite-sized chicken pieces. The Squid Ink Snap Noodles with Seafood was my "reach" selection and it did not disappoint. The noodle and sauce are smooth and fulfilling.  But the single selection that will bring me back is the Tea Smoked Pork Belly Sliders. Moist and bursting with flavor. Words do not do justice to these appetizing morsels of pork goodness!  And let's not forget the creative mixology...not just Asian sounding drinks that you find at other wanna-be upscale Asian restaurants, but thoughtfully crafted beverages that compliment the exceptional fare without getting overly chi-chi. My recommendation is the Monkey King...like a Old Fashioned...great with Bang Bang Chicken Wings!
author: Al K.

description:
Tried this place for the first time. I was a bit skeptical when I was kind of "restaurant watching" it across from La Boulange a while ago.. I got just a bit grossed out because one of their chefs was going from table to table stretching and twisting this large mass of dough in the air. I suppose it's part of the entertainment but I imagined lint and hair getting trapped in it and was hoping they weren't about to cook that. 

Well I decided to try it anyways. It wasn't busy and there was no dough stretching or some man in a suit trying to entertain people  with his microphone. Yeah.. that was another time I was restaurant watching. This man in a suit had a microphone and I guess he was trying to entertain people by talking and asking questions while people were eating. No!

Uh.. anyways.. back to yesterday when I actually went. We were seated promptly, the table settings were neat, everything was clean, ambiance was nice, service was great and you're offered regular or sparkling water. Ooo fahncy.

Food? Ordered some dim sum (forgot what they were) and were not bad at all! The accompanying sauces actually made it more delicious. The "Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup" could have been great - the beef was really tender but the broth was way too salty... like it was pure stock or something and it needed more water. The noodles.. well they said "long noodles, long life", but I'm sharing this soup with someone and all of it kept going in my bowl when I tried to get some and I didn't even know where the hell the noodles ended. Nice and chewy but too long. There was this other beef dish we tried. Again.. it could've been good.. but it was tooo salty and it comes in a bed of too much arugula.  Oh, and there was like little crunchy bits in each meat. It felt like when you find egg shells.  I don't know what that was. Ay ya yai. For dessert we ordered the Chocolate Ginger Mousse Chocolate Cake with Tangerine Sorbet. That was probably the best part.  But thennnn there were these weird choclate looking pieces under the sorbet. They looked like cocoa nibs.. sorta, but they tasted like the Flinestones vitamins :( Womp womp. 

3 stars. I guess it could've been 2. But 3 stars because it's a nice looking place and the dim sum was good. I'd go back for dim sum.
author: Mila B.

description: My husband and I just had the worst anniversary dinner EVER!! We ordered the lobster for two (58.00) and a side of noodles with pork.. we got our pork noodles and still waited and waited and waited for our Lobster. Our server did not order our lobster. instead we had to wait another 45 minutes to get it.. they cleared our table before anyone told our server that he had made an error.  Nobody came around to ask us anything. when I told  the Very Rude floor manager  Amber Black that the lobster was not served with anything that we could use to crack the shell with, she said. " You should have told someone about it" as I would have if anyone would have asked.. she charged us the full price even though we could only it  1/3 of the lobster that we waited  FOREVER for.  and then had the nerve to blame us! she charged us 97.88 for noodles and pork, 2 glasses of wine and Lobster that was not only late, but not served properly.  Amber was not our server. our server was a young black man who was obviously overwhelmed with his new job of understanding  "lobster for two, and a side of pork noodles" DUH! when I Told Amber  Black that she was very rude, she said "thank you"  service sucked. attitude was over the top.. never going back again...
author: Judy B.

description: Great atmosphere but the service was poor. Food came in stages, not all at once. Took forever for the rice to come.  Ordered roast pork and it took 40 minutes to get it.  By the time it was served we had lost our appetite and the pork was tough.  Our server had an attitude which we didn't appreciate.  Will never go back.
author: Maria C.

description: Overall a poor experience.  Started with the hostess---playing games with us when there were plenty of tables open.  Then we were seated at a table that was broken.  When we asked to be moved, they gave us the option for a table at the corner.  When we asked if we could sit at a 4 top in the front, they stated it was only for four people--later we saw that they sat other couples there.  They got our drink order wrong twice and gave us some attitude about it.  Food was mediocre and pricey for what it was (ie $16 for a small plate of pea shoots).  When we were low on water, the waitress asked if we wanted more water but never came back with it.  Would not go back.
author: H M.

description:
I have to say, I was a little disappointed. Maybe my expectations were too high, but I feel like if I am going to shell out $80+ for lunch for two people I want to be blown away.
The food was okay, enjoyable but the dim sum seemed very overpriced. I have to admit, I do have a bit of difficulty with upscale dim sum since I have yet to taste any that is drastically better than what I can get for dollars at my favorite take out place. I was excited by the idea of the truffle and pork dumplings but I didn't feel they were worth $18 after tasting them. My favorite dish of the meal was the wild boar scissor cut noodles but I was hunting for the tiny pieces of boar. I know the dish is supposed to be about the noodles (which were yummy) but I would have liked a bit more meat, maybe a bit bigger pieces, I was literally hunting for them on the plate.
The service was a bit rough. Our server was incredibly sweet but also incredibly green around the gills. He warned us that he was new right off the bat so we were happy to excuse a little nervousness and a few hiccups. However, it did take 20 + minutes to get our drinks and the poor guy was so nervous it made us a little nervous. I wish I could say it didn't affect our experience, but it did a little. But I want to say again he was very nice and I appreciated his honesty and my date and I both agreed that with a little confidence and experience he would be fine. The intention and potential were there.
The ambiance and decor were very nice.
author: Kater C.

description: M.Y. China offers some excellent dishes, mostly sichuan influenced cuisine with a modern, contemporary flair.  The cuisine is creative, inspired and very stimulating to the palate.  However, the service is very spotty at times, and the ambience is somewhat odd and frenetic because the restaurant is located in the Westfield  shopping mall, a temple of materialism and crass commercialization.  The decor is hip and ultra modern, very tasteful an interesting., every bit as good as the rival restaurant, Hakasan.  The menu is diverse.  However, the description of the dishes is cursory, making it difficult to select dishes.  I ordered the Shanghai dumplings, which were delicious but served at scalding temperature.  The sichuan green beens are to die for, served with the perfect amount of oil and red pepper sauce.  The highlight for me is always the Kung Pao Crab. It's absolutely out of this world, served with a lot of garlic peanuts, onions and red bell peppers.  (if you like Crab, however, go to PPQ in the avenues---it's cheaper and much more authentic. Unfortunately, the kitchen staff neglected to remove one of the stickers from a red pepper, making the experience someone "stickery."  The sauce on the beef dished was a bit to sweet for my liking.  The waiter was very enthusiastic, but as others noted, the sequence and timing of the delivery of the dishes was incorrect.  One dish arrived early, and then "pow," seven dishes arrived simultaneously, making it difficult to each everything before the food got cold.   The prices are very, very high.  This is not a restaurant for those "top ramen" months when you have to catch your pennies. So, you're eyes, already watery from the spice s in the food, will get even wetter when you see the bill.  Martin Yan has done a wonderful job with this restaurant.  With a few tweaks, an improvement in the service, at a bit more attention to detail, this modern Chinese restaurant will become "the" destination for those seeking high-end Chinese food.  ~Daniel
author: Daniel F.

description: One of the worst Chinese restaurants in town. We ordered wonton soup, honey walnut shrimps and pea sprout shoots. The wontons had almost no stuffing inside, it's like eating flour wrappers, the other 2 dishes were soooooo salty that i could barely swallow. The waitress never came around to ask if we needed more water. No tea was served in the restaurant. Very poor quality in food and service but high prices on menu. Will Never ever return.
author: P Y.

description: Nice presentation, average taste, poor service and pricey for what you get.  Nice decor but it is very noisy since you're almost bumping arms with the couple next to you.  Had the dim sum (better to walk a few blocks up to Chinatown), Noodle with chicken (it was good but the texture of the chicken was interesting), pear salad (would not recommend this).   Hate to say this but I enjoyed a meal at Panda Express more.  :(
author: Roy S.

description: Good food, dim sam, roasted Pork, Pat Choi, hand cut noodles are delicious.
author: Ana H.

description: Food was just a "okay" nothing new like I thought it would be. I was hoping to get more for my buck as the portions are a little small. The services was great; however, they did forget to bring our side orders. I am hoping to see more items on the menu in the future. There weren't many choices to choose on the desert side.
author: Huy T.

description: Went there last night with family and had a good time.  Our server Ken was very friendly and  knowledgeable about the menu.  He made a great recommendation  for our dinner and we enjoyed everything we ate.  The only thing that might needs to improves is to control the temperature of the food.  Had a beef  hand pull noodel soup and the soup was not hot enough.  but overall it was great experience and will definitely visit again in the future.
author: Marion C.

description: Disappointing food, over priced.  I anticipated a great meal based on the ambiance - but you can save yourself a lot of money and enjoy a much better meal somewhere else.  In San Francisco this place is a disappointment - it tastes like mid-western mass produced chinese food - worse than PF Changs - really.
author: Priya H.

description: I was SO looking forward to dining at M.Y. China, but after my first visit there today I can honestly say that, save the glass of wine, that was the biggest waste of $35 I've had in a long while.  As lovely as the restaurant is, and as nice and friendly as the staff is, the food left far too much to be desired.  For me, the pork-heavy menu was an immediate turn-off, and the non-pork-based dishes were few and far between and not nearly as inspired or inspiring as those including the beloved pig.  Usually I have no trouble finding delicious fare at most restaurants, despite the fact that I don't eat pork or red meat.  After sitting with the menu for several minutes, I settled on the Har Gow (shrimp dumplings) and kung pao chicken bao, and a side of jasmine rice.  At first I was served the BBQ chicken bao erroneously; the dough tasted like it was straight from the freezer.  Of course, when I realized I had the wrong item the server very kindly took them back and I was brought the kung pao boa.  Honestly, those weren't much better--the dough was chalky and flavorless, and I kept biting down into hard bits of who knows what.  The Har Gow was a little better, but the shrimp was a little underdone for my preference.  The rice was boring.  Plain jasmine rice can be an exquisite experience, but this was flat and dull and just not worth it.  For all the hype surrounding the opening of this restaurant, I am terribly disappointed in the food.
author: Rhonda N.

description: Decided with a friend today to drop in and try out My China for lunch.  I'll say, the restaurant is absolutely beautiful with enough space between the tables.  The food is in the upper echelon of San Francisco Chinese for sure.  It's unfortunate for a restaurant of this potential caliber to be marked down to an experience I would rather not repeat, due only to it's service (or lack thereof).  We arrived for our lunch and decided to stay because it didn't look too crowded plus there seemed to be one person on staff for every patron in the restaurant which to me means fast service.  It took 25 minutes before anybody came and asked if we would like water, another 10 before our waiter came by to take our order.  Mind you, we're on a lunch break, not tourists, waiting 35 minutes just to place our order is cutting it close on our lunch hour.  The food arrived promptly so the wait there wasn't bad, however, our waiter disappeared for another 35 minutes!  We eventually had to flag down someone cleaning the table next to us and ask for the check.  I wouldn't recommend coming here if you have any time constraints.
author: Nate W.

description: Went here on Friday at about 2:30 for a festive lunch with my son and a friend.  Planned to go to Straits, but got sucked in by the newness. There was one other table of diners and what appeared to be a staff meeting at a large table. Our server was friendly, helped us choose, etc.  All was well until the mediocre food arrived. The pork belly sliders were served on cold buns and the belly was so tough and crunchy it was difficult to eat. (Perhaps they need a lesson from the Chairman truck!) My 8 year old ordered the calamari but it was so salty he only managed to eat one piece. The pork dumplings were fine, but not at all special. The most disappointing dish was the crispy noodles with chicken. Our server had suggested them, so we had high expectations but the noodles were really oily and the chicken/vegetables were in a salty thick sauce that was pretty unappealing.  I was surprised when our check was delivered about 3/4 of the way through our meal, but the server said there was no rush. While waiting for our food we had exchanged Christmas presents, so when we finished eating my son asked if we could play the card game he received. Other than one table across the room and the staff meeting on the other side of the divider we were the only ones there, so I said sure. We played a 5 minute round or two and were having a nice time when our server came over and asked us to pay. Really?  Not like we were lingering in a crowded place with people waiting for our table. As if the sad food weren't reason enough to not return, this bit of business pushed me over the edge. We paid quickly, took our things and left. The worst part was walking out into the mall and seeing Straits across the way. Honestly the only reason I gave two stars instead of one is because it looks like the manager reads these reviews and is working hard to make things better.
author: Bonita H.

description: I have come to M.Y. China many times since its grand opening.  I met Martin in one of Saturday evenings.  He's cheerful and full of energy like in his shows on TV.  This place reminds me the upscale restaurants I ate when I visited my birth place, Hong Kong.  The Beef Hand Pulled Noodle Soup and the Spicy Seafood Dumplings are my favor.  I found out that I shouldn't order the Wild Boar Juicy Dumplings, and Pork and Crab Juicy Dumplings together.  The soup inside the dumplings was always tasty, but if I ate two different soup dumplings at the same time, I couldn't tell which one was which.  For the Har Gow, well, Hong Kong has the best Har Gow.  The service was a little slow during the busy hours, but I always got a good service.  I didn't have a bad meal and so far I like all dishes I tried on the menu.  I also like the aging Pu-erh tea.  It serves with a white teapot with a tiny glass tea cup that is similar to the Kung-Fu tea cup.  One thing I don't know is whether I can ask for more tea leaves after a couple rounds of refills of water in the teapot.  I eat out a lot because I don't want to cook . I tried out the next doors the Straits and the pizza place, and I still like M.Y.China better.
author: Raymond C.
